title: Pera University student hospitalised
author: Author not found
Content: A first-year student of Peradeniya University was hospitalised after a fourth-year student who was under the influence of liquor assaulted him.  The attack had taken place at Ivor Jennings Dormitory around 6:00 p.m. on 17 December and he was rushed to the Peradeniya Teaching Hospital. The victim is a first-year student at the Faculty of Arts and is a resident of Norton Bridge. The attacker is a resident of Jaffna. Peradeniya Police and the university administration are conducting separate investigations regarding the incident. The victim said, three senior students threatened him while he was in the hostel and one of them kicked him and another student aided and abetted in the attack. By K.L. Suraweera

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Politicians must retire at 60 – Maha Sangha
author: Author not found
Content: The Maha Sangha is of the view that local politicians should voluntarily retire at the age of 60 and give opportunities to young people who can work. If doctors, engineers, and other professionals in the State service retire at the age of sixty, the same law must apply to all politicians, according to Venerable Kappitiyagoda Sirivimala Thera, Anunayake of the Rajopavanaramadhipati Ramanna Nikaya of Gatambe. He was speaking at the  Gatambe Vihara when Prof. G.L. Peiris paid a visit yesterday (18). “The Prime Minister has issued a circular in this regard stating that at the age of sixty, all State employees should retire. This means that after the age of sixty, people experience physical, mental, and health problems, as well as other weaknesses, so the retirement age has been set at sixty years, as recommended by doctors. How can politicians work after sixty years?” he queried. Speaking further, he said the same law should apply to politicians as well. Otherwise it was a grave  injustice for retire only state employees to retire at sixty. “How can politicians work if state employees cannot? This is an amusing fact. We, the Maha Sangha, believe that politicians in this country should voluntarily retire at the age of 60 and make opportunities available to young people who can work. Otherwise, there is no reason to stay in Parliament until you walk with a walking stick. Many people define public service as serving themselves. Because of the privileges, many do not even consider retiring from Parliament,” he said. Speaking further, the Thera highlighted that this system should be changed and that youth groups should be given opportunities, adding that Parliament was the most powerful place in the country to take decisions and make laws.”How can people who can’t think and whose health has deteriorated work to build a country?” he queried. “If there are academics or other people over the age of sixty, they can get their services by forming a voluntary parliamentary advisory council. The masses are unable to bear the burden of life. Despite claims that there is no money to do anything in the country, the number of ministers continues to grow. They are attempting to spend and sell the country’s resources to accomplish this,” he said. The Thera also requested that all such things should stop, that political opinions be set aside and that everyone should come together and work to lift the country out of the abyss it has fallen into, even if only for a short time. BY K. L. Suraweera – Kandy

title: Navy seizes 128 kg ICE, 106 kg heroin
author: Author not found
Content: Local trawlers with over 128 Kg ICE and 106 Kg heroin worth over Rs 4,586 million gross street value was apprehended. The suspects were held by the Navy in the southern waters and brought to Colombo Harbour, yesterday (18). Also along with the consignment, the 14 suspects and the two trawlers used in the racket was also brought to the harbour. Including the latest arrest, the Sri Lanka Navy has held drugs with a gross street value of over Rs 28.05 billion during operations in 2022. A special operation conducted by the Navy in coordination with the State Intelligence Service and Police Narcotic Bureau in the seas about 229 nautical miles (424km) off Dondra led to the interception of two local fishing trawlers and the apprehension of a large consignment of narcotics along with  the suspects on 14 December. The haul of illegal drugs included over 128kg and 327g of ICE in 94 packages and 106kg and 474g of heroin in 98 packages and in 13 sacks. The consignment was disguised as coffee packaged in 1kg in two different types of coffee packets. The SLNS Samudura also apprehended another local fishing trawler with six suspects who arrived to replenish fuel to the drug-carrying trawler. The suspects were brought to the Colombo Harbour by the Navy, yesterday. The naval crew involved in the special operation were praised by the Commander. The suspects have been identified as residents of Tangalle, Nakulugamuwa, Kosgoda and Balapitiya and were between the ages of 29 to 59 and will be handed over to the Police Narcotic Bureau for legal action.   Sri Lanka Navy – the country’s first line of defence is committed to coordinating with other law enforcement authorities, to carry out anti-drug operations of this nature to foil drug smuggling attempts being made in the guise of fishing, a spokesman said.  Pix by Nuwan Amarawansha BY Nabiya Vaffoor

title: Galle District Has 7,848 Malnourished Children – Specialist
author: Author not found
Content: A total of 7,848 children, under the age of five, are malnourished in the Galle District, according to the weight for height, said Southern Province Health Services Director Specialist Chandima Siritunga. Speaking at the Galle District National Food Security Progress Review meeting, he noted that 1,137 of these children are suffering from acute malnutrition and 6,711 are suffering from severe malnutrition. According to him, 69,560 children under the age of five were registered in the Galle District this year (2022). According to the Director, the malnutrition condition of children in the Galle District will increase by 2.6 per cent this year compared to the previous year (2021), based on weight for height. He said, 9.5 per cent of children were malnourished based on weight for height last year (2021), and the number of malnourished children has increased to 12.1 percent this year (2022). Prime Minister Dinesh Gunawardena presided over the meeting, which was held in Galle. BY Kamal Wijehewa – Galle

title: Educational exhibition at Dehiwala Zoo from 23 – 25 December
author: Author not found
Content: Director-General of the National Zoological Gardens, Dr.Tilak Premakanta said arrangements have been made to hold an educational exhibition at the Dehiwela National Zoo from 23 – 25 December, between 8.30 a.m. and 6.00 p.m. This will be organised on the people’s behalf to promote positive attitudes toward animals and the environments in which they live. On the opening day of the exhibition, school children under the age of 12 will be allowed to visit  free of charge. With the help of the Central Environment Authority, the school environment pilot team will run several special programmes for schoolchildren on that day.  24 December is reserved for senior citizens, and those over the age of 60 are entitled to a free zoo visit. Anoma Prihayadarshani, Zoo Operations Director, announced a series of Christmas programmes on 25 December. BY Vidyan Pathirana – Dehiwala

title: Commercial ship service between Kankesanthurai and Karaikkal Port
author: Author not found
Content: Jaffna Business Forum President, A. Jeyasekaram yesterday (18) announced that arrangements have been made to operate a commercial ship service between Kankesanthurai Harbour and Karaikkal Port in Tamil Nadu, India. He said that the proposed ship service will benefit tourism between Sri Lanka and India, particularly Tamil Nadu. According to Jeyasekaram, once this service is launched, a large number of holidaymakers from both countries will benefit. He said they were in talks with two cruiseline operators about the start of the proposed commercial ship service. However, only ships weighing less than 1,000 metric tons will be permitted to operate, according to Jeyasekaram. By Naalir Jamaldeen

title: Thief in Army camouflage arrested in K’nochchi
author: Author not found
Content: On the night of 17 December, villagers in Kilinochchi, Punareen Police Division, in Iraneimata Nagar area, caught a person engaged in robbing houses at night attired in Army camouflage and handed him over to Police. The suspect was armed with a sharp weapon and had entered a house in Iraneimata Nagar and stole gold, when the owner spotted him. When the homeowner shouted for help, the robber attempted to flee with the sharp weapon in his hand. Local residents apprehended the suspect and in the melee injured the owner. The victim was hospitalised while local residents informed  Mulankavil Police and handed him over. According to Mulankavil Police, the suspect is said to be a resident of Iraneimata Nagar. BY Shashi Kumar – MuLlaItivu

title: Navy rescues 132 Myanmar nationals mid sea
author: Author not found
Content: The Sri Lanka Navy rescued 132 passengers from a boat in the deep sea when it met with an accident on 17 December, about one hundred nautical miles away from Maradankeni sea in Jaffna. The victims were brought to the Kankasanthurai Port. Despite the passengers being identified as Myanmar nationals, immigration officials in Jaffna said they could not reveal any information about them because investigations were still ongoing. After a group of fishermen alerted the Navy that a boat was in danger in the middle of the sea, four Navy vessels moved to the location and rescued the victims. The Navy has also taken steps to bring the boat involved in the accident back to shore and provided medical assistance and basic first aid to passengers in distress in mid sea. The incident is being investigated by the Kankasanthurai Police and the Navy. BY Rasadi Chathurangi Gamage – Vavuniya

title: Grade 5 Schol exam held
author: Author not found
Content: The Grade 5 Scholarship Examination was held, in 2,894 centres around the country, yesterday (18). Students from across the country were seen arriving at the exam centres with enthusiasm to face the examination Strict Police security was deployed at all examination centres.

title: J’pura University student drowns in Weerawila
author: Author not found
Content: A first-year student of Sri Jayawardenepura University drowned while bathing near the sluice of Weerawila Lake. Police said a group consisting of nearly 30 students from the Art Faculty of Sri Jayawardenepura University had visited a fellow student’s house in Debarawewa, Tissamaharama. They had gone to bathe in the lake on the way back. The body of the student was recovered on 17 December. The victim is a 21-year-old resident of Dematawelhinna, Badulla, Police said. By Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: Title not found
author: Author not found
Content: Date:  The Sri Lanka Navy rescued 104 Myanmar nationals yesterday (18) who had trespassed into the Sri Lankan waters on the night of 17 December. The Navy assisted in the rescue of the Myanmar nationals aboard a passenger vessel in Sri Lankan waters about 3.5 nautical miles north of Veththalakerni. Following a mechanical failure while transporting these people from Myanmar to Indonesia, the distressed vessel is said to have trespassed into Sri Lankan waters. Upon receipt of the distress call by the Operations Room of the Northern Naval Command, the Navy on 17 December rushed SLNS Udara as well as Fast Attack Craft P 411 and P497 of the fourth Fast Attack Flotilla attached to the Northern Naval Command for the rescue of these distressed people, to the sea area where the incident was reported. In rough sea condition, the Navy made a strenuous effort and rescued the 104 Myanmar nationals who were aboard the non-operational craft and were brought to the Kankasanthurai Harbour and their basic needs were taken care of. Meanwhile, they will be handed over to the relevant authorities for onward action. In accordance with Sri Lanka’s international obligations to the International Convention for the Safety of Life at Sea 1974 – SOLAS and International Convention on Maritime Search and Rescue 1979, the Navy remains ever alert to assist maritime and fishing communities in distress in Sri Lanka’s Search and Rescue Region, a spokesman said. BY NabiyaVaffoor Popular

title: Navy bids farewell to Admiral Nishantha Ulugetenne
author: Author not found
Content: Admiral Nishantha Ulugetenne relinquished command of the Sri Lanka Navy on completion of his term yesterday (18). He assumed office as the 24th Commander of the Navy on 15 July 2020.  The outgoing Commander handed over duties of the command to his successor Vice Admiral Priyantha Perera at the Commander’s office in the Navy Headquarters before his departure. Admiral Nishantha Ulugetenne rendered a distinguished service to the Navy and motherland during his naval career spanning over 37 years. The retiring senior officer was accorded a Guard of Honour in accordance with naval traditions. After the Board of Management and senior naval officers made their formal farewells, senior and junior sailors making a street line bade farewell to Admiral Ulugetenne who was sent off mounted on a decorated vehicle, amidst cheers.

title: Monk rushed to hospital after being poisoned
author: Author not found
Content: A 17-year-old monk was rushed to hospital yesterday (18) after being forced to drink poison. Attaragama Dhammarathana Thera, of Hindagala Rajamaha Viharaya, which falls under the purview of Malwathu Maha Viharaya, was admitted to the ICU of Peradeniya Teaching Hospital after being poisoned. An unknown person, who was staying near a waterway in the temple grounds, had threatened to consume a bottle of poison, and when the Thera had informed him not to do so in the temple grounds and urged him to leave, the unknown person had put a knife to the Thera’s neck and forced him to drink the poison, according to investigations. According to Ven. Ambilmeegama Pannakitthi Thera, Hindagala Rajamaha Viharadhivasi, the unknown person who had been visiting the temple grounds for several days had poisoned the 17-year-old Thera. The Thera had handed over the bottle of poison to the hospital. The 17-year-old Thera sustained facial trauma in the incident. Pannakitthi Thera lodged a complaint with the Peradeniya Police. Investigations are ongoing. By K.L. Suraweera – Kandy

title: CID takes over former Pera Uni VC assault probe
author: Author not found
Content: The CID has taken over the investigation into the assault on Professor Athula Senaratne, former Vice Chancellor of the University of Peradeniya and his son. According to the Police Media Division, the investigations were handed over to the CID on the orders of IGP C.D. Wickramaratne. He was assaulted by a group of university students near his residence on 10 December, Police said. A group of university students confronted Prof. Senaratne, alleging that his son’s car collided with a parked motorcycle. Police said, approximately 300 university students protested and then vandalised Prof. Senaratne’s official residence. Peradeniya Police arrived and dispersed the crowd. Prof. Senaratne was admitted to the Peradeniya Hospital, while his son was admitted to the Kandy Teaching Hospital, Police said. At least ten students from the University were arrested for assaulting the former Vice Chancellor. Police said the students were arrested after they surrendered to Peradeniya Police on 12 December. BY Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: Entomologists call for legal backing to carry out field duties
author: Author not found
Content: The Health Entomologists Association (HEA) urged Health Ministry Secretary and the Director General Health Services (DGHS) to provide Entomologists with legal backing to execute field duties. With the number of dengue cases soaring to over 70, 000 by the second week of December 2022 the National Convener, HEA, Disnaka Dissanayake urged the two top officials in the Health Ministry to give them legal backing to inspect domestic premises. He said yesterday (18) that his members quite often faced public hostility when they visited houses to inspect and research for the dengue vector. In the most recent incident which occurred on Friday (16) when an Entomologist had been faced with the hostile behaviour by a member of the public in Bandaragama, Kalutara area during vector inspection work. The person is seen in a video clip allegedly using obscene language, threatening the Entomologist and demanded that prior notice should be given before visiting. He vehemently objects to the Entomologist’s presence in his premises saying that they too are like the Sri Lanka Police.  “This is not the only time that people have shown hostility towards us and behaved threateningly,” he lamented noting that lack of awareness with regard to the work carried out by Entomologists was possibly one of the reasons for such hostility. “ Entomologists only go to carry out vector inspections and research work. We don’t want to add to the burden of the public as we understand that they too are under tremendous stress,” he said. However, Entomologists only aim to inspect and research the dengue mosquito vector and reduce the public burden of falling ill with dengue fever at this juncture.  There is no necessity to add to the burden that people already carry by having to deal with a mosquito borne disease as well, Dissanayake observed. According to the Dengue Sentinel Site Surveillance, Epidemiology Unit (DenSys) last year when there were only a few over 35 924 dengue cases this year from 01 January to 18 December 2022 there have been over 72, 321cases. The cases for November amounted to 4,561. The high risk areas at present were Colombo (16,326), Gampaha (12,169) and Kalmunai (1,822).  The vector density is high in Gampaha and Puttalam. According to the Dengue Control Unit’s Dengue update Kalutara has recorded 5,940 dengue cases by the 49th week.      Incidents such as this have been reported in the past when public health inspectors (PHIs) and the Tri Forces who assisted the dengue control programme faced severe hostility and even paid with their lives during house to house inspections. By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: HRCSL probes lack of postal services in estate areas
author: Author not found
Content: The Human Rights Commission of Sri Lanka (HRCSL) has launched an investigation into the complaints that people in estates do not receive postal services. Shortage of mail carriers who are fluent in Tamil, shutting down of many sub-post offices in estate areas and the absence of numbers to identify the houses in estates are the reasons for this issue, the HRCSL said in a statement.  After the complaints, the HRCSL summoned officials of the Postal Department, Ministry of Home Affairs and State Ministry of Estate Housing and Community infrastructure to probe the matter. The officials pledged to provide a report on the matter prior to 6 January 2023, the HRCSL said.

title: SL assured of GSP+ till 2025
author: Author not found
Content: Sri Lanka is assured of GSP+ till 2025, but it needs to work from now onwards towards ensuring that it will be secured post-2025 as well, French Ambassador to Sri Lanka Jean-Francois Pactet told the media at his official residence in Rajagiriya yesterday. Pactet further said that the European Commission (EC) will be reviewing GSP + in 2025. A key condition in ensuring GSP+ post-2025 is Sri Lanka’s adherence to human rights (HR). Asked whether a Truth Commission in the lines of South Africa’s… …Truth Commission would be to the satisfaction of the EU/France, Pactet said that he would have to first speak to civil society here before expressing an opinion on this subject. Pactet, a career diplomat, assumed office as France’s Ambassador to Sri Lanka last month.  When told that China has no qualms on HR when dealing with Sri Lanka, the Ambassador said that he cannot speak for or on China, on this subject.  When asked whether he would take issue with Colombo in respect of the killing of 17 Sri Lankan aid workers attached to a French NGO in August 2006, the Ambassador said that he needs to first ascertain the facts of the incident before taking it up with Colombo. “But I do admit that it’s over 16 years when this massacre took place which is a long time,” he said.  EU after the USA is Sri Lanka’s second largest merchandise export market. GSP+ enables duty free exports of a number of merchandise goods, including garments, Sri Lanka’s second largest foreign exchange earner after remittances to that region. BY Paneetha Ameresekere

title: Public officials should not give excuses – President
author: Author not found
Content: President Ranil Wickremesinghe emphasised that it is the responsibility of public officials to provide the maximum public service without causing conflicts between public institutions and they should never give reasons for not performing their duties. “I don’t need any excuses,” the President said. President Wickremesinghe stated this, while participating in the District Development Committee meeting held at the Badulla District Secretariat yesterday (15) morning. During the meeting, the President emphasised that Government officials should use the law as a shield to serve the people and not the companies. The President further said, “A scientific report should be obtained before removing pine trees from these areas. During the rule of the English in this country, tea was cultivated while pine trees were also there. Therefore, don’t fall for the wrong ideas. Before removing the pine trees, it is necessary to scientifically investigate if they would have an impact on the catchment areas. Why do you want to uproot the pine cultivation and opt for turpentine cultivation it will have an impact on the catchment areas.” “Government officials should act efficiently. I don’t need excuses. There is no way that there could be problems between government departments. As a government, everyone should come together and serve the people. In the plantation field, some officials use the law as a shield. I paid attention to this when preparing this Act in the ‘80s,” he added. When discussing the educational problems in this area, the shortage of teachers was highlighted. A year or two after the appointment of teachers, they get transfers. The Ministry of Education and the Provincial Council should discuss and take a decision not to transfer teachers until five years pass after their appointment. The President said the proposal to get new land for plantation schools will be considered and necessary steps will be taken. “For the promotion of the health sector in the Badulla District, the necessary facilities will be provided to upgrade the Mahiyangana Regional Hospital to a District Hospital. Also, we are working to allocate money for the expenses of the kidney hospital in Girandurukotte. If a problem has arisen regarding the development of the Bandarawela Hospital due to the Diyatalawa Base Hospital, steps will be taken to investigate it. The steps to upgrade the Bandarawela District Hospital to a base hospital have been assigned to the Ministry of Health, and they should look into it. Moreover, there may be some delay in providing money for the necessary equipment to the Badulla General Hospital, as receiving of foreign aid has stopped due to the declaration of bankruptcy of our country,” he revealed. “All the lands related to the development of the Badulla Province General Hospital have been released so far. I request you to implement its future activities. In the future, we will work towards establishing an emergency treatment unit for tourists in that hospital. There is a possibility of earning foreign exchange through it,” he pointed out

title: SLPP to form broad coalition with UNP, 15 other Parties
author: Author not found
Content: Sri Lanka Podujana Peramuna (SLPP) MP Prof. Ranjith Bandara says that his Party would tie up with UNP and with another 15 political Parties to contest all future elections via a broad coalition. He revealed this while addressing the media in Kandy yesterday (15) and added there were neither sworn enemies nor lifelong friends in Party politics. Speaking further, he said, “Today there is no division in party politics as right or left wing. It was there around half a century ago. All those who had ruled this country had activated a free market policy either in full or partially. It was natural for the Opposition to criticise the ruling party and this is no exception even today. There have already been a few talks between our (SLPP) National Organiser Basil Rajapaksa and the President. It is based on understandings reached at those talks that we have decided to contest future polls with the UNP and a few other parties. We will see how it all pans out, but we as the SLPP would like state that we are ready to contest any election at any given time.” BY K.L. Suraweera – Kandy

title: Social media activist stabbed
author: Author not found
Content: Social media activist Dilan Senanayake was stabbed by two unidentified individuals in Nugegoda. Police said the stabbing had taken place in the night of 14 December in a studio on Pagoda Road, Nugegoda. Senanayake was admitted to the Kalubowila Hospital. CCTV footage revealed that the two assailants had arrived in a three-wheeler, Police said. Mirihana Police are conducting investigations to arrest the suspects. BY Aloka Kasturiarachchi

When discussing the educational problems in this area, the shortage of teachers was highlighted. A year or two after the appointment of teachers, they get transfers. The Ministry of Education and the Provincial Council should discuss and take a decision not to transfer teachers until five years pass after their appointment. The President said the proposal to get new land for plantation schools will be considered and necessary steps will be taken. “For the promotion of the health sector in the Badulla District, the necessary facilities will be provided to upgrade the Mahiyangana Regional Hospital to a District Hospital. Also, we are working to allocate money for the expenses of the kidney hospital in Girandurukotte. If a problem has arisen regarding the development of the Bandarawela Hospital due to the Diyatalawa Base Hospital, steps will be taken to investigate it. The steps to upgrade the Bandarawela District Hospital to a base hospital have been assigned to the Ministry of Health, and they should look into it. Moreover, there may be some delay in providing money for the necessary equipment to the Badulla General Hospital, as receiving of foreign aid has stopped due to the declaration of bankruptcy of our country,” he revealed. “All the lands related to the development of the Badulla Province General Hospital have been released so far. I request you to implement its future activities. In the future, we will work towards establishing an emergency treatment unit for tourists in that hospital. There is a possibility of earning foreign exchange through it,” he pointed out

title: SLPP to form broad coalition with UNP, 15 other Parties
author: Author not found
Content: Sri Lanka Podujana Peramuna (SLPP) MP Prof. Ranjith Bandara says that his Party would tie up with UNP and with another 15 political Parties to contest all future elections via a broad coalition. He revealed this while addressing the media in Kandy yesterday (15) and added there were neither sworn enemies nor lifelong friends in Party politics. Speaking further, he said, “Today there is no division in party politics as right or left wing. It was there around half a century ago. All those who had ruled this country had activated a free market policy either in full or partially. It was natural for the Opposition to criticise the ruling party and this is no exception even today. There have already been a few talks between our (SLPP) National Organiser Basil Rajapaksa and the President. It is based on understandings reached at those talks that we have decided to contest future polls with the UNP and a few other parties. We will see how it all pans out, but we as the SLPP would like state that we are ready to contest any election at any given time.” BY K.L. Suraweera – Kandy

title: Social media activist stabbed
author: Author not found
Content: Social media activist Dilan Senanayake was stabbed by two unidentified individuals in Nugegoda. Police said the stabbing had taken place in the night of 14 December in a studio on Pagoda Road, Nugegoda. Senanayake was admitted to the Kalubowila Hospital. CCTV footage revealed that the two assailants had arrived in a three-wheeler, Police said. Mirihana Police are conducting investigations to arrest the suspects. BY Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: Diana’s travel ban temporarily lifted
author: Author not found
Content: Colombo Chief Magistrate Nandana Amerasinghe yesterday (15) temporarily lifted the overseas travel ban imposed on State Minister Diana Gamage, for a period of four days, from 21 December. Gamage has been charged with flouting immigration and emigration laws when obtaining a passport. Court ordered that two sureties of 10 million rupees be provided for the travel ban to be temporarily lifted. President’s Counsel Sarath Jayamanne, representing the State Minister, stated that as his client has to fly out to Singapore and Doha Qatar on official business, the overseas travel ban imposed on her should be lifted temporarily, for a four-day duration, effective 21 December. The case was convened, to determine whether the overseas travel ban imposed on the suspect, should be either extended or lifted completely. However, Chief Magistrate Amerasinghe mentioned that the travel ban imposed on the suspect, will not be totally lifted but temporarily, based on the necessity. Further proceedings of the trial were fixed for 5 January, next year. The CID has filed the lawsuit against Gamage, on charges of violating Provisions contained in Section 175 of the Penal  Code and Section 45 (1) of the Immigrants and Emigrants Act No. 20 of 1948. By Hansi Nanayakkara

title: Court suspends Gazette on MRP for eggs
author: Author not found
Content: The Court of Appeal yesterday (15), issued an interim order suspending the Extraordinary Gazette, issued setting a maximum retail price (MRP) of eggs until the final determination of the case filed challenging the Gazette. This was when the Petition filed by the Egg Producers’ Association was taken before Court of Appeal judges Prasantha de Silva and K.A. Swarnadipathi. While the Court on Wednesday (14) issued an interim stay order to the Consumer Affairs Authority (CAA) to suspend the said Gazette, the Consumer Affairs Council was ordered to report the revised price to Court yesterday (15). Accordingly, when the case was taken up yesterday (15), the Consumer Affairs Council informed Court it has been decided to set the price of white eggs at Rs 42 and brown eggs at Rs 44. The lawyers appearing on behalf of the petitioners however, refused to agree to such revision. Thereby, Court ordered for the suspension of the Gazette until the final determination of the case. Further hearing of the case was set for 6 February.  President’s Counsel Kuvera de Soyza, Dasun Nagashena, Rakitha Rajapakshe, Madhava Jayawardhana and Pasindu Bandara appeared on behalf of the petitioner.  According to the Extraordinary Gazette Notification, issued by the CAA Chairman, under the powers vested in him by Section 20 (5) of the Consumer Affairs Authority Act, No. 9 of 2003 on 19 August 2022, a maximum retail price of Rs 43 was set for white eggs and Rs 45 was set for brown/red eggs. The Gazette Notification prohibited manufacturers, producers, suppliers, distributors and traders from exceeding this price. BY Faadhila Thassim

title: SL should move fast in restructuring debt – French Envoy
author: Author not found
Content: It’s in the interest of all creditors and Sri Lanka (SL) to move fast towards reaching an agreement in restructuring Sri Lanka’s debt, French Ambassador in Sri Lanka Jean-Francois Pactet told the media at his Rajagiriya official residence yesterday. He said that as a result of Sri Lanka’s debt default in April 2022, some Euro 400 million worth of French funded projects, covering the areas of water supply, sewerage and sanitation and waste management and such like have been put on hold.  Pactet further said that France, after China, India and Japan, not necessarily in that order, was Sri Lanka’s fourth largest bilateral aid donor. The Paris Club, of which France is a member and which has its Secretariat in Paris and includes some of Sri Lanka’s key creditors, but not China, has agreed to Sri Lanka’s debt restructuring process in an open and transparent manner,  Pactet said. Some of Paris Club’s other key members include countries like the USA, UK and Japan. India enjoys observer status of the Paris Club. He said that despite Sri Lanka’s difficulties, France’s national carrier Air France, currently flies thrice weekly to Colombo, targeting this tourist holiday season. “We are not telling the French not to come to Sri Lanka,” Pactet said. BY Paneetha Ameresekere

title: Two more remanded over assault on former VC
author: Author not found
Content: Two more students were arrested over their involvement in the recent assault on former Vice Chancellor of the University of Peradeniya Prof. Athula Senaratne and his son. The arrests were made on 14 December when the two students surrendered to the Police. The arrested suspects were identified as 24 and 23-year-old residents of Rambukkana and Belihul-Oya. The suspects were remanded until 22 December by the Kandy Magistrate’s Court. Former Vice Chancellor of University of Peradeniya, Prof. Athula Senaratne was assaulted by a group of university students near his residence on 10 December, Police said. A group of university students got into an argument with Prof. Senaratne, alleging that his son’s car had collided with a parked motorcycle. Police said, around 300 university students had protested and thereafter damaged Prof. Senaratne’s official residence. Peradeniya Police arrived at the scene and dispersed the crowd. Prof. Senaratne was admitted to the Peradeniya Hospital, while his son was admitted to the Kandy Teaching Hospital, Police said. Earlier, 10 University students were arrested when they surrendered to the Peradeniya Police on 12 December. Police are conducting further investigations into the accident. BY Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: Over 15,000 soldiers seek legal discharge
author: Author not found
Content: More than 15,000 military personnel have offered to quit the service during the General Amnesty period that has been granted for the Tri-Forces absentees to receive a legal discharge from their respective services.  The Ministry of Defence announced a General Amnesty period from 15 November to 31 December for the Tri-Forces personnel who have been absent from duty without leave. Accordingly, 15,476 Army personnel have come forward so far to receive the legal discharge, said Brigadier Ravi Herath, the Army Media Spokesman, highlighting that necessary measures have already been completed to legally discharge 15,165 of them. Another 194 officers will reportedly be released from the service after obtaining the clearance reports. Brigadier Ravi Herath further stated that the General Amnesty period will be in effect until December 31 and that the Tri-Forces absentees still have the opportunity to leave their respective services legally.

title: Money printing at Rs 3.28 Trillion
author: Author not found
Content: Government of Sri Lanka’s (GoSL’s) face value money printing (FVMP) debt decreased by 0.35 per cent (Rs 11,564 million) to Rs 3,283,509.39 million (Rs 3.2835 trillion) on Wednesday (14), thereby marginally defraying demand-pull inflationary pressure. However, GoSL’s FVMP debt has been over three trillion rupees for a record consecutive 110 market days to Wednesday due to a persistent lack of revenue. Liquidity was uplift by Rs 25,286 million (US$ 69.62 million)  to Wednesday due to the settlement/s of swaps between the Central Bank of Sri Lanka (CBSL) and the GoSL and/or between CBSL and the market. Swaps between GoSL and CBSL are foreign reserves neutral. GoSL’s at least theoretical MP borrowing costs (BCs) decreased for the third consecutive market day to Wednesday, this time such a fall accelerating by 2.10 per cent (Rs 2,542.05 million) to Rs 118,254.09 million due to ‘sustained’ buying pressure of Treasury (T) Bills and T Bonds in secondary market trading, enticed by high yields offered at the expense of lending to the private sector, the engine of growth. Market shortfall decreased by 3.38 per cent (Rs 13,722 million) to Rs 392,766 million, nonetheless causing sustained rate pressure on Wednesday. Market was short for a record 310 market days to Wednesday.  GoSL’s highest to the 315th highest FVMP debt has been recorded in the 315 consecutive market days to Wednesday. CBSL which administers daily open market operations (OMO) lacks transparency. GoSL’s FVMP debt is equivalent to the totality of CBSL’s T Bill and T Bond holdings. MP is the exclusive right of CBSL.  GoSL’s MPBCs are prorated to the outcome in secondary market trading of T Bills and T Bonds on the reference day. ‘Spot’ trades are settled after two market days from the date of transaction. CBSL, the steward of GoSL debt and its foreign reserves deals in ‘spot’. The ‘spot’ is administered to minimise GoSL’s foreign debt in rupee terms and to lower the cost of energy imports which are met from the country’s foreign reserves and not from the market, to prevent further depreciative pressure on the rupee as Sri Lanka is an import dependent economy. BY PaneethaAmeresekere

title: PM visits former Archbishop
author: Author not found
Content: Prime Minister Dinesh Gunawardena paid a courtesy call, as he does every Christmas season, on His Grace the Most Reverend Dr. Oswald Gomis and extended Christmas greetings to him, the PM’s Office said in a media release. The PM, who was accompanied by State Minister of Indigenous Medicine Sisira Jayakody and SLPP MP Yadamini Gunawardena, visited the official residence of the former Archbishop situated at St. Anne’s Elders Home premises in Kelaniya on 14 December. The Prime Minister extended his well wishes to His Grace the Most Reverend Dr. Oswald Gomis and wished him success in his future endeavours. Rev. Fr. Victor Jayamanne was present.

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: 300-year-old ‘sandagala’ stolen
author: Author not found
Content: Officials from the Department of Archaeology have lodged a complaint with the Pallekele Police stating that the historic Sandagala archaeological monument weighing 1000kg and located at Udamaluwa Archaeological Reservation at Kundasale had been robbed at dawn on 14 December. According to the residents of the area the stolen artefact had belonged to the reign of the last Sinhalese King, Sri Veera Parakrama Narendra Singha, and is believed to be over 300 years old, according to historians. According to officials from the Archaeology Department, the historic artefact had been removed by using a backhoe, despite the presence of two security officers deployed at the site by the Department. BY K.L. Suraweera – Kandy

title: Speaker signs Tax Bill
author: Author not found
Content: Speaker Mahinda Yapa Abeywardana signed Value Added Tax (Amendment) Bill on Wednesday (14). The Value Added Tax (Amendment) Bill was passed in Parliament with a majority of votes, with amendments 9 December. The Second Reading for the Bill was thus passed in Parliament with a majority of 82 votes cast in favour of the Bill and 41 cast against. Accordingly, the Value Added Tax (Amendment) Bill is in effect as the Value Added Tax (Amendment) Act No. 44 of 2022 from the 14 December onwards.

title: NARA, NAQDA research centres for Jaffna
author: Author not found
Content: Fisheries Minister Douglas Devananda has made the necessary arrangements to set up the National Aquatic Resources Research and Development Agency (NARA) and National Aquaculture Development Authority (NAQDA) research centres in Jaffna. Devananda said that through the establishment of those research centres it has been planned to expedite the research activities to develop fresh water fisheries in the Northern Province. Minister Devananda met the heads of NARA and NAQDA at the Fisheries Ministry to discuss the matter and instructed them to take prompt action to establish these centres. There is a need to pay more attention towards developing the fresh water fishery because a large number of families across the country are depending on it for their survival, according to Devananda. He said that a large number of investors from China and India, who met him, promised to provide large sums of money to establish sea cucumber fingerlings breeding centres at suitable locations. Devananda said that he told them that only those who can release 25 million sea cucumber fingerlings can come forward. “As the Chinese investors were not willing to introduce their sea cucumber fingerling breeding technology, we have to think further with regard to the provision of permission to establish such centres,” Devananda said. Ministry Secretary Indu Ratnayake, Additional Secretary Namal Thalangama, Director General of Department of Fisheries and Aquatic Resources were also present during the meeting. By Naalir Jamaldeen

title: FSP Secy, Bhikku Federation Convener noticed
author: Author not found
Content: Colombo Chief Magistrate Nandana Amarasinghe on Wednesday (14) noticed eight suspects including Propaganda Secretary of Frontline Socialist Party (FSP) Duminda Nagamuwa, Convener of Inter University Bhikku Federation (IUBF) Ven. Galwewa Siridhamma Thera, and actor Jehan Appuhamy, to appear before him on 31 January 2023. This was in connection with the case filed against them, on charges of Contempt of Court, along with obstructing traffic opposite the Colombo Chief Magistrate’s Court and disrupting the proceedings of Court. The others who were noticed by the Court, were identified as Ven. Rathkarawwe Jinarathana Thera and Ven. Pokunuwita Siridhamma Thera of the IUBF, Amal Salindra, Anjana Rodrigo, and Mala Fernando. Keselwatta Police informed Chief Magistrate Amarasinghe that on 12 December, when a case had been taken up at the said Court, around 100 people had gathered near the Court premises at around 11:45 a.m. Police said this group had then proceeded to obstruct movement of lawyers and the public to and from the Court premises, while engaging in a protest displaying banners and placards, which read ‘Victory to the Aragalaya’ and ‘Release Wasantha Mudalige.’ The prosecution mentioned that the actions of the suspects had flouted Section 140 of the Code of Criminal Procedure, 59 (1) of the Thoroughfares Ordinance, and 55 (1) (2) of the Judicature Act and to issue notice on them to appear in Court. By Hansi Nanayakkara

title: Title not found
author: Author not found
Content: Date:  Colombo High Court Judge Amal Ranaraja on Wednesday (14) acquitted former Deputy Minister Shantha Premaratne, who had been charged with soliciting a bribe of Rs 350,000, under the pretext of providing public sector jobs. Announcing the verdict of the trial, Judge Ranaraja, mentioned that the Commission to Investigate Allegations of Bribery or Corruption (CIABOC) had failed to prove the charges filed against the accused, former Deputy Minister, beyond a reasonable doubt. Hence, the Court acquitted the accused from all charges filed against him without calling for submissions from the defence. The Bribery Commission had indicted Premaratne before the High Court, on six counts and over the alleged offence of seeking the said bribe, to provide State employment to children of three individuals in January, 15 years ago. By Hansi Nanayakkara Popular

title: Time to unite North and South
author: Author not found
Content: Colombo Mayor Rosy Senanayake said the time has come to strengthen mutual understanding and harmony between the country’s North and South, particularly at a time when certain elements are attempting to promote racism and religiosity in the country. She said she was aware of problems faced by people in Jaffna. “Northerners’ mistrust of the people of the South must be dispelled,” she said. “At a time when the morals of the country are deteriorating, when there is no respect for one another, especially when an environment of racism and religiosity is created, everyone must work together like the children of one family,” she added. She said the Colombo Municipal Council pioneered to rebuild the relations of South with the North of this country which had been disrupted due to various reasons in the past. To prepare the necessary background to help each other, a team of 95 comprising the members and chairpersons of Valikamam Northwest and Valikamam South Pradeshiya Sabhas and Jaffna Municipal Council visited the Colombo Municipal Council recently. “The media severely criticised us for touring the North. However, the visit has paid off,” Senanayake said. “The harmony created by this visit is priceless. Before the end of this year, all CMC members are waiting with great enthusiasm to show our love, kindness, and compassion to the people of the North,” Mayor Senanayake said. “I went to Jaffna and Mullaitivu in 2001. After that, when I was the Minister of Women and Child Affairs, I went to Jaffna to give a nutritional bag worth Rs 20,000 to pregnant women introduced on my concept,” Senanayake added. By Naalir Jamaldeen

title: Wooden bridge dilapidated
author: Author not found
Content: Walapane PS member Rajapaksa Banda says that the wooden bridge, connecting the Yatimadura village with the Kandeyaya village in the Walapane Divisional Secretariat, is in a dilapidated state. He warned that if the bridge is not renovated promptly it will even lead to loss of life and some could even suffer life threatening injuries as well. Banda made these remarks during the recent sessions of the Walapanne PS. BY Chadrasiri Mahagama – Nuwara Eliya

title: Large scale corruption when implementing water projects – PS Member
author: Author not found
Content: UNP member of the Polpithigama PS Ranjith Priya Bandara says that several large scale acts of corruption had taken place, when a few water projects were being implemented with the support of the people of Polpithigama. He made this revelation during the monthly sessions of the said PS held under the aegis of its Chairman SLPP member Ranjith Wijenayake. Bandara stated that these acts of corruption had taken place via the levying of water bills for the drinking water supplied through the Deduru Oya project. He urged the PS to conduct an audit regarding various unions that tend to compile water bills according to their own whims and fancies while fleecing the public and end the acts of frauds taking place. BY Nandana Kelegama – Polpithigama

title: J’pura Marketers hold ‘X-Universe’ to welcome freshers
author: Author not found
Content: X-Universe, an event organised by the second year undergraduates of the University of Sri Jayewardenepura’s Marketing Team, with the objective to develop skills such as leadership, team building and confidence of first year undergraduates, was held recently at the university premises. There were nine groups with 15 members of first year undergraduates in each team competing in six sessions. The event kicked off at around 8.30 a.m. on 1 December. The first session was ‘Fly pool’: a game associated with a swimming pool which paved a fresh opening to the event where all the team members participated. Next, was ‘Galaxy Walk,’ which was organised to provide the chance to test the physical strength of  competitors.  ‘Tele Brain’, was a general knowledge competition. To spice up the competition further ‘Star Kitchen’, a vibrant cooking game was held. The event next in line was the carom tournament.  ‘Tone Comet’ was an open mike singing competition. The event was praised by many for the innovative approach taken by the Marketing Team to welcome the first year undergraduates. BY K.A.D. Tharushi Himasha

title: Led by inflation, poverty line rises for 18th consecutive month
author: Author not found
Content: Sri Lanka’s monthly official poverty line (OPL) increased for the eighteenth consecutive month to October 2022, spurred by near record high inflation, thereby increasing by 1.73 per cent (Rs 238) to Rs 13,810 month on month (MoM), ie  October 2022 over September 2022, Census and Statistics Department (CSD) data, released on Wednesday (14), showed.   In the previous month September, this monthly figure (OPL) was Rs 13,460. The monthly OPL at Rs 13,810 in October 2022 means that an individual needed to earn a minimum of Rs 13,882 that month to be able to buy the bare necessities of life and thus to be considered as being non-poor, according to the CSD. Meanwhile, in the 18-month period beginning April 2021 and ending October 2022, Sri Lanka’s OPL has increased by over two fold or by more than 150 per cent (Rs 8,633) to Rs 13,810; a 166.76 per cent increase, led by a depreciated rupee, scarred harvests and import bans and controls that have given an impetus to record high inflation, official data further showed. The OPL in April 2021 was a mere Rs 5,177. The last time OPL, MoM, declined was 18 months ago from October 2022, ie in April 2021 over March 2021, where the OPL fell by a negligible 0.08 per cent (four rupees) to Rs 5,177, before increasing since. The OPL in March 2021 was Rs 5,181. The definition of OPL by the CSD is the minimum monthly earnings needed by an individual in the country to be considered as being ‘non-poor’. The meaning of ‘non poor’ is the amount needed by such an individual to buy the bare necessities of life for a month in order to keep ‘his nose above the water’ without falling into poverty and want, as per the CSD definition. According to the last official poverty survey conducted by the CSD in 2019, it was found that 3.04 million of Sri Lanka’s population was poor. This accounted for 14.3 per cent of Sri Lanka’s population that year. BY Paneetha Ameresekere

title: Nuwara Eliya residents against building high wall across golf course
author: Author not found
Content: Residents of Nuwara Eliya are protesting over the moves being made to build an 8-foot-long wall across the golf course situated within the town limits. They stated that if such a wall is constructed it will diminish the luster of the Nuwara Eliya town as well as take away the interest shown by both locals and foreigners who love to play golf during the holiday season. They added that if such a high rise wall is constructed it will prevent the public from witnessing locals and foreigners from playing golf and that it will not augur well for Nuwara Eliya’s reputation as a leading tourist destination. BY Neeta Pathma Kumari – Norwood

title: ‘Like dragging a mad dog for a bath’ – SJB
author: Author not found
Content: The Samagi Jana Balawegaya (SJB) claimed that they are trying to get this government to agree on holding an election is like “dragging a mad dog for a bath.” Addressing the media, yesterday (15), SJB MP Ashok Abeysinghe, noted that although the Sri Lanka Podujana Peramuna (SLPP) members do not accept that this is their government, 134 SLPP MPs voted and appointed the current President and the Cabinet consists of SLPP MPs. “So, how can they deny that they are the ones who rule the country,” he queried. “Basil Rajapaksa recently said that the people do not have enough food now and the government is not theirs and they cannot be held accountable for the current problems of the people. How can he say that?” he queried. (NV)

title: Indian CNS calls on Air Force Chief
author: Author not found
Content: Chief of Naval Staff of the Indian Navy, Admiral R. Hari Kumar called on Air Force Commander, Air Marshal Sudarshana Pathirana on 14 December at Air Force Headquarters, Colombo. The Indian Navy Chief was received by the Commanding Officer SLAF Station Colombo, Air Commodore P.S.N. Fernando and was accorded a Guard of Honour by the No. 43 Colour Wing of the SLAF. The visiting Naval Chief discussed matters of mutual interest with the SLAF Commander. Admiral Kumar also met the Chief of Staff of the SLAF and the Air Force Board of Management after which mementos were exchanged to mark the occasion.

title: Rajarata University cultivation programme a success
author: Author not found
Content: The food crops cultivation programme launched by the Rajarata University as a solution to the food shortage of university students has been a success. According to sources, due to rising costs of essential food items, universities are struggling to run canteens. To overcome this issue, the University launched a sustainable agriculture programme last September. As part of this initiative, a vegetable cultivation was started next to the Puliyankulama Agriculture Faculty on a six-acre plot of land. Harvesting commenced under the supervision of University Vice Chancellor, Prof. Sanjeewani Ginigaddara on 15 December. By Wickrema Ralapanawa – Anuradhapura

title: Four burglars arrested
author: Author not found
Content: Point Pedro Police, on 14 December, arrested four persons who had broken into a house in the Point Pedro area, of the Jaffna District. According to the Police, the suspects robbed jewellery and cash on 7 December, after breaking into a house in the Puloli Sarayadi area, while the owners were in hospital. The victims had filed a complaint with Point Pedro Police in this connection and they had launched a manhunt to apprehend the suspects and they were apprehended in the Point Pedro area. Police recovered 14 sovereigns of gold jewellery including a ring, thalikkodi and a ear-ring. Point Pedro Police are conducting further inquiries while holding the suspects in detention. By Naalir Jamaldeen
