title: Driver of Mercedes remanded
author: Author not found
Content: The driver of the Mercedes car that was involved in a fatal accident in Kollupitiya recently, in which one person was killed, was arrested at the BIA and was remanded till 16 December by the Hulftsdorp Magistrate. An overseas travel ban had been imposed on the suspect. Police said the suspect was arrested by Immigration Officers on returning from Dubai on 12 December night. He was later handed over to the Kollupitiya Police Station and was identified as a 26-year-old resident of  Wellampitiya. A 58-year-old three-wheeler driver died after a car returning from a night club crashed into his three-wheeler in Kollupitiya, on 10 December. The car was plying from Bambalapitiya towards Galle Face. The three-wheeler driver, who was critically injured in the accident, was pronounced dead on admission to the Colombo National Hospital. The deceased is a resident of Kahathuduwa, Polgasowita. Police said three women and two men were in the car at the time of the accident. Two women aged 29 and 31 were also injured and were admitted to the Colombo National Hospital. By Hansi Nanayakkara and Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: No harmony within SJB – Rangebandara
author: Author not found
Content: UNP General Secretary Palitha Rangebandara yesterday (13) said the recent Party Convention of Samagi Jana Balawegaya (SJB) clearly showed there is no agreement between party members and they also don’t have any respect for Party Leader Sajith Premadasa. He questioned whether any progressive decision to resolve the economic crisis was made during the recent SJB National Convention held on Sunday (11). “It was clearly observed that they don’t have any agreement with party members. They don’t have any respect for the Party Leader. They don’t have any progressive policy either,” he stressed. Speaking to the media at Sirikotha, Rangebandara said Opposition Leader Sajith Premadasa still has time to work for the country. By Naalir Jamaldeen

title: Govt cannot give special treatment – Siyambalapitiya
author: Author not found
Content: State Minister of Finance Ranjith Siyambalapitiya rejected Opposition Leader Sajith Premadasa’s request to extend the retirement age of Parliamentary Officers by one more year. Siyambalapitiya said if they make an exception only for the officers of Parliament, the accusation will arise that they are providing special treatment and it will be controversial. Speaking in Parliament yesterday (13), Premadasa said the Staff Advisory Committee met and decided on the retirement of the employees of Parliament and said everyone except Siyambalapitiya has signed it. He said after the retirement age changed from 60 years to 65 years, a majority of the people had obtained loans and said Parliamentary Officers are among them. “However, after it was changed again to 60 years, the banks are requesting them to settle the loans. Therefore, the committee decided to extend the time period for another year,” he said. We request to implement the decision that is already taken, Premadasa added. “Siyambalapitiya has to represent the opinion of the Treasury. However, how do these people settle these debts? The Government should immediately implement the decision of the Staff Advisory Committee,” he added. Siyambalapitiya: “The Treasury does not see this issue as a single issue. All State employees have the same issue. There is no other option. The Treasury today is in a position of stick to the policy. We must realise this truth. The country should understand the present situation. The Treasury has not behaved inhumanly. The Treasury is obliged to protect the Government’s policies.” By Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: SLFEB calls for Health Ministry probe
author: Author not found
Content: With accusations being levelled against the Director of Colombo East Base Hospital (CEBH), Mulleriyawa of attempting to scupper an agreement between the Government of Sri Lanka and Republic of Singapore which offered job opportunities to local nurses, the Sri Lanka Bureau of Foreign Employment (SLBFE) has urged the Health Ministry Secretary, to probe and resolve the issue pertaining to one nurse who allegedly submitted a forged document. The CEBH Director on 6 December wrote to the National University Health System, Singapore stating that neither he nor the Special Grade Nursing Officer would take responsibility for the forged document that had been submitted.     Following this letter, the quota granted by Singapore for Sri Lankan nurses could be cancelled, allegations have been levelled. Deputy Director General (Education, Training and Research) of the Health Ministry, Dr. Sunil de Alwis said he was aware of the issue. The Ministry, he said would have to conduct a preliminary investigation into the matter to verify as to what really had happened. He said the two governments had a good understanding and that delegates from Singapore had visited Sri Lanka and selected nurses to serve in their hospitals. When contacted, informed health sources yesterday (13) said contrary to the claims made by a particular nurse who had left Sri Lanka to serve in Singapore and the local nursing unions, she (the nurse) had left for Singapore through a foreign job agency. “There were talks between the two countries for the deployment of State hospital nurses to Singapore for jobs. However, the particular nurse had allegedly submitted a forged document using the hospital letterhead as a certification of her service in many of the CEBH’s units to obtain the job.” They pointed out that the hospital could only issue a “service report.” According to the Establishment Code, a letterhead could not be used on such occasions. However, in this case the particular nurse had submitted certification from the Chief Special Grade Nursing Officer using the hospital letterhead, sources alleged. But now the Grade Medical Officer denies having issued such a letter in writing while the Hospital Director, Dr. Priyantha Karunarathne had sent indirect copies to the particular job agency and the Hospital in which the nurse was serving in Singapore. Parties with vested interests were attempting to convince the public that she had left for Singapore with a group comprising other nurses in keeping with a government to government agreement inked by President Ranil Wickremesinghe. By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: Ceylon Today shines at Journalism Awards
author: Author not found
Content: Ceylon Today bagged two main awards and a merit award at the most coveted awards ceremony of the year for Print Journalism in the country, the Journalism Awards for Excellence, organised by the Sri Lanka Press Institute together with the Editors’ Guild of  Sri Lanka. At the 23rd edition of the most anticipated Awards night, held at the Mount Lavinia Hotel yesterday (13), Anjana Kalhara Kaluarachchi won the Sports Journalist of the Year 2021, Award (English) for the second consecutive year, Faadhila Thassim won the Best Environmental Reporter of the Year Award (English), and Dilshani Palugaswewa won the Merit Award for the B.A. Siriwardene Columnist of the Year (English). Saman Kumara Nammunige of Ceylon Today’s sister paper Mawbima won the Merit Award for the Upali Wijewardene Feature Writer of the Year 2021. Pix by Nuwan Amarawansha

title: UMA OYA PROJECT TO BE COMPLETED IN JUNE 2023 – KANCHANA
author: Author not found
Content: The Uma Oya Multipurpose Development Project is expected to be connected to the National Grid by June 2023, Minister of Power and Energy Kanchana Wijesekera said yesterday (13). In a tweet, Wijesekera said a meeting was held on the Uma Oya Project which will add 120 MW of hydropower to the National Grid. The Minister added that they can also assure that the Uma Oya Project will be connected to the National Grid by June 2023. “Officials of Farab Energy and Water Projects of Iran and Farab International FZE, the construction and engineering company, have assured that construction will be completed by the end of April 2023,” he said. The Uma Oya Multipurpose Development Project is being implemented by the Ministry of Irrigation and Water Management. The project site is located in Welimada, Badulla District. The project includes the construction of two dams across Uma Oya and a tributary at Welimada, trans-basin diversion tunnel, and underground hydropower plant, diversion of 145 MCM of water to irrigate approximately 5,000 hectares of land in Hambantota and Moneragala districts and other downstream requirements. The expected annual energy production is 290 GWh. The total estimated cost of the project is USD 529 million. (NV)

title: IUSF’s Mudalige further remanded
author: Author not found
Content: Convener of Inter University Students’ Federation (IUSF) Wasantha Mudalige, who was arrested as per Provisions of the PTA and detained for interrogation and subsequently remanded, was further remanded till 17 January next year, till such time advice is received from Attorney General Sanjay Rajaratnam. When the case was convened, the Additional Magistrate Mahawatta further remanded the suspect till the aforesaid date, as instructions from how to proceed on the matter, had not been received from the Attorney General. The Magistrate also informed the Terrorism Investigation Division (TID) to expedite the probe into the case and to submit a detailed report, with regard to evidence compiled against the suspect and advised them to conduct a transparent and an unbiased probe. President’s Counsel Saliya Peiris  appeared on behalf of the suspect. He told Magistrate Mahawatta, that in the ‘B’ Report compiled by the TID against his client, they had failed to specifically pinpoint the Provisions in the PTA, which had been flouted by his client. He stated that when several other suspects arrested and produced in Court by the TID, had been charged with violating Provisions contained only inthe Penal Code and the Thoroughfares Ordinance, it was unjust for his client and Ven. Galwewa Siridhamma Thera to have been charged solely under the PTA. He then requested the Court, to issue an order to the prosecution to withdraw the PTA, under which his client has been charged with. Senior Deputy Solicitor General Dileepa Peiris and officers from the TID prosecuted. DSG Peiris stated that the probe into the actions of the suspect is being conducted to decipher, whether he had violated Provisions of the PTA and that it has not been confined solely to a solitary incident. He stated that following statements recorded from two witnesses, namely Piyumal Samarasinghe alias ‘Motivation Appachchi’ and Gemunu Wijewardena, they had mentioned that the anti-Government rallies staged by them and a few other parties, had been hijacked by the IUSF. According to DSG Peiris, in statements given by both of them they had maintained that the actions of the IUSF, had taken place as they had been pumped with cash via global terrorist groups. The DSG mentioned that though there was nothing untoward towards the staging of anti-Government protests, the prosecution was carrying out a probe to determine as to how it had turned violent. Taking the submissions into consideration, the Additional Magistrate stated that for any activity there has to be leadership and that the suspect concerned seems to have provided that leadership to the activitymentioned. She stated that she had advised the probe teams to inquire the incident expeditiously, from the outset and noted that scores of suspects have already been charged with Provisions contained in the Public Properties Act and the Thoroughfares Ordinance. Afterwards the Court ordered the TID, to expedite its probe into the case in an unbiased manner and submit a detailed report of evidence, related to the suspect at the next hearing set for the said date. By Hansi Nanayakkara

title: Guarantee academic freedom – Bandula
author: Author not found
Content: Minister of Transport, Highways and Mass Media Dr. Bandula Gunawardana said a long discussion was held in Cabinet regarding the attack on former Vice Chancellor of University of Peradeniya, Prof. Atula Senaratne and his family by a group of students from the same university. Speaking in Parliament, he said the President informed to conduct an impartial investigation and submit a report expeditiously. He added that academic freedom should be guaranteed in universities. “It is a problem if university professors cannot teach without fear and doubt. The common law of the country should become the law of the universities as well,” he said. Both Government and Opposition MPs condemned the attack. SLPP MP Gunathilaka Rajapaksha alleged the students must be influenced by the ‘Aragalaya.’ “The JVP and Frontline Socialist Party (FSP) are responsible for this incident,” he said. MP Charitha Herath stressed what was initially a conflict between student groups is turning into a conflict between students and teachers. “If we want to make education certain in this country, we need to stop such conflicts,” he said. “The education sector is heading towards a serious crisis and such things have never happened in history. The Minister of Education should make a special statement regarding this incident,” he emphasised. “We should ensure that such things do not happen in universities in the future. They no longer trust each other. Never before has a teacher been influenced or beaten. Senaratne is a recognised geologist of this country. When such things happen, scientists will leave the country,” he warned. MP Herath requested the Ministry to present a detailed explanation to the country about the matter. While strongly condemning the incident, Chief Opposition Whip Lakshman Kiriella requested to take legal action against those who are involved in the attack. He said students should have a peaceful atmosphere to study in universities. In addition, MP Ashoka Priyantha claimed if everyone united when the MPs were being attacked, the issues would have been resolved by now. He stressed that his house was also attacked and he still doesn’t have a house. Further, Chief Government Whip Prasanna Ranatunga said he condemns the incident and requested that the law be implemented. He added that when the law is implemented against university students, some political parties oppose such action. He said there shouldn’t be double standards and the law must be implemented equally. Ranatunga alleged that several university academics were among those who instigated the destruction of MPs’ houses. “Many institutions are afraid to take graduates from State universities and that’s why the graduates from private universities are hired in a majority of companies.” He also said the reports on the destruction of MPs’ houses should be submitted to Parliament. By Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: Final decision after Committee Report – Semasinghe
author: Author not found
Content: State Minister of Finance Shehan Semasinghe informed Parliament that the final decision on restructuring Sri Lanka Telecom (SLT) will be made when the report of the Finance Ministry’s State institutions restructuring unit comes out. Semasinghe was responding to Opposition Leader Sajith Premadasa in Parliament yesterday (13), when he raised concerns whether SLT will also be privatised. “A special unit has been set up to look into the restructuring of certain state institutions as per the Budget. This unit will look into how each institution should be restructured. Therefore, the final decision on how SLT is to be restructured will be made after the report is submitted,” the State Minister said. He also assured that the Government will not jeopardise the country’s national security. By Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: Seven given bail in Oman human smuggling racket
author: Author not found
Content: Colombo Chief Magistrate Nandana Amerasinghe yesterday (13), released on bail seven suspects, including interdicted Third Secretary of the Sri Lankan Embassy in Oman E. Kushan and Asha Dissanayake, who had been in charge of the safe house, affiliated to the Embassy, who had been in remand on charges of being involved in a human smuggling racket. The Court also impounded the passports of the suspects and instructed them to report to the CID, on the last Sunday of each month between 9.00 a.m. and 12.00 p.m. The CID informed Magistrate Amerasinghe, that to date they have identified 24 Sri Lankan brokers, involved in the racket and that three of them have already been apprehended. They added that in order to further expedite the probe into the case, a team from the CID had flown out to the Sri Lankan Embassy in Oman on 10 December. They added that following inquiries carried out thus far, it has been revealed that a total of 90 people, had sought protection at the safe house situated in Oman. Taking the submissions into consideration, the Magistrate released the suspects on bail. By Hansi Nanayakkara

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Four minors arrested for stealing lorry
author: Author not found
Content: Four minors from a children’s home in Nuwara Eliya were arrested following an accident in Nittambuwa. According to Police, a lorry plying from Kandy towards Colombo had collided with a van travelling in the same direction. Following the accident, the lorry sped away and the van driver gave chase and stopped it. Police launched investigations based on a complaint lodged by the van driver. Investigations showed that four minors had been travelling in the lorry and a 16-year-old was at the wheel at the time of the accident. Police said the other three passengers are aged 11 to 12 and are residents of Nuwara Eliya, Talawakelle, and Pundalu Oya. According to Police, the children had been placed at the children’s home in Nuwara Eliya in keeping with a Court order. However, the children had stolen a lorry from the centre in the hope of driving off to Negombo and met with an accident in Nittambuwa. Nittambuwa Police are conducting further investigations. By Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: Details only revealed to Security Council – Bandula
author: Author not found
Content: Details of President Ranil Wickremesinghe’s meeting with the Head of India’s Research and Analysis Wing (RAW) could only be revealed to the Security Council, Cabinet Spokesman Dr. Bandula Gunawardana said. Gunawardana, speaking during the Cabinet media briefing last week, told reporters he forgot to ask the President about the said meeting and promised to provide a response this week. Keeping his word, Gunawardana said the President told him that as the Head of State, many officials from various groups meet and hold discussions with him, and he informs the appropriate people about those meetings. When queried about the meeting with the RAW Chief, the President said information about intelligence services or defence could only be revealed at the weekly Security Council meeting, Gunawardana added. Reports were published that RAW Head Samant Kumar Goel, met President Wickremesinghe on 21 November for extensive talks alongside the President’s Senior National Security Adviser Sagala Ratnayaka and Sri Lanka’s High Commissioner to India Milinda Moragoda. By Thameenah Razeek

title: Kidney racket suspect further remanded
author: Author not found
Content: Colombo Additional Magistrate Rajindra Jayasuriya yesterday (13), further remanded, till 28 December, a suspect who was charged with promising cash to persons from underprivileged families and then cheating them after having sold their kidneys to both locals and foreigners. Though the suspect was produced before an identification parade yesterday, the Court ordered to postpone the proceedings, due to the suspect being ill. Accordingly the Magistrate, ordered the suspect, to be produced before a fresh identification parade on 3 January next year. By Hansi Nanayakkara

title: Indian CNS calls on Navy Chief
author: Author not found
Content: Chief of Naval Staff of India, Admiral R. Hari Kumar, who is presently on an official visit to Sri Lanka, met Navy Commander, Vice Admiral Nishantha Ulugetenne at Navy Headquarters, yesterday (13). He arrived in the island on 12 December night on a six-day official visit, aiming to bolster existing bilateral maritime cooperation between the two navies. He was received at the BIA by Chief of Staff of the Sri Lanka Navy, Rear Admiral Priyantha Perera. Admiral Kumar also visited Navy Headquarters in Colombo, where he was received by Commander Western Naval Area and Commandant Volunteer Naval Force, Rear Admiral Dammika Kumara. Thereupon, Admiral Kumar was accorded a formal and elegant Guard of Honour by the Sri Lanka Navy. Subsequently, Navy Commander, Vice Admiral Nishantha Ulugetenne warmly welcomed the visiting naval dignitary from India and introduced him to the Board of Management. After exchange of pleasantries, the top military brass discussed several matters important to the navies of both countries, recalling long-standing relations between India and Sri Lanka. The cordial discussion drew to a close with an exchange of mementoes to mark the goodwill and camaraderie. Having posed for a group photograph with the Navy Commander and the Board of Management, Admiral Kumar signed the Visitor’s Book at the office of the Navy Commander and took leave from Navy Headquarters. As part of this official visit, Admiral Kumar is scheduled to call on the President, the Prime Minister, the State Minister of Defence, the Defence Secretary, the Chief of Defence Staff, and meet Commanders of the Army and Air Force. In addition, he will grace the Commissioning Ceremony of Midshipmen at the Naval and Maritime Academy, as the Chief Guest. Concluding the official visit, the Chief of Naval Staff of India will leave the island on 17 December. (NV)

title: Drastic decline in estate sector school attendance – Stalin
author: Author not found
Content: Ceylon Teachers’ Union (CTU) General Secretary Joseph Stalin said, the attendance of students in estate sector schools had declined drastically and there was a strong possibility of estate sector education collapsing. He stated that scores of children of school-going age in the estate sector were also addicted to illegal drugs. He made these remarks during a media conference held at Hatton on Monday (12). According to Stalin malnutrition among children in the estate sector had also become a serious issue and he stressed that the Ministry of Education should address the burning issues of the upcountry people or else the entire education system in the sector would crumble. BY Neeta Pathma Kumari -Norwood

title: Ten Pera university students remanded over attack on fmr VC
author: Author not found
Content: Ten university students, who were charged with the recent assault, on former Vice Chancellor of the Peradeniya University Prof. Athula Senaratne and his son, were remanded until 22 December by the Kandy Magistrate’s Court. Police said the students were arrested after they surrendered to the Peradeniya Police on 12 December. The arrested students, aged between 23 and 25 are residents of Nittambuwa, Sandalangala, Girithale, Matale, Hengamuwa and Galagamwatta. Police are conducting further investigations. Former Vice Chancellor of Peradeniya University Prof. Athula Senaratne was assaulted by a group near his official residence and was hospitalised. Police said the altercation occurred due to an alleged vehicle accident caused by Prof. Senaratne’s son. Some university students had an argument with Prof. Senaratne on 10 December, stating that his son’s car had collided with a parked motorcycle. Police said a group of around 300 university students had protested and later attacked and damaged the official university residence of Prof. Senaratne. Later, Peradeniya Police have arrived at the location and dispersed the crowd. Prof. Senaratne, was admitted to the Peradeniya Hospital while his son was admitted to the Kandy Teaching Hospital, Police said. BY Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: Child died of brain infection – JMO
author: Author not found
Content: Trincomalee General Hospital Judicial Medical Officer (JMO) Dr. P.A. Kiriella giving his verdict on one of the deceased children from Kantale, due to recent extreme cold weather, had stated that child had died following a germ infection in brain. The JMO advised that parts of the remains of the other deceased child be sent to the Government Analyst to determine the cause of death. A two-month and 11-days old girl and a three-year-old boy from Rajaela and Perathuweli in Kantale died on 9 December, allegedly due to the recent extreme cold weather conditions. BY Lakmal K. Baduge – Trincomalee

title: Bad weather injured rises to 25
author: Author not found
Content: Inclement weather experienced in the four consecutive days to Sunday (11), killed three, made one to go missing, injured 25, damaged 6,613 houses, destroyed another six, and impacted 7,180 families comprising 25,523 people, the Disaster Management Centre (DMC) said yesterday (13). The deaths were reported from Nuwara Eliya (two) and Ratnapura districts (one), the single missing person reported, from Trincomalee on Thursday, while the 25 injured were seven from Badulla, Moneragala (three), Nuwara Eliya (four) and Ratnapura (11), it said. The six destroyed houses were reported from Ratnapura (two), Jaffna (two), Mullaitivu (one) and Hambantota (one), respectively. Inclement weather also damaged 53 small and medium enterprises (SMEs) and 41 critical infrastructures, it said. The 53 SMEs damaged were from Badulla (21), Moneragala (three), Nuwara Eliya (two), Ampara (one), Trincomalee (nine), Jaffna (eight), Mullaitivu (two), Vavuniya (two), Kilinochchi (three) and Mannar (two),  respectively and the 30 critical infrastructure facilities damaged were Badulla (26) and Jaffna (two) and Mullaitivu (two), respectively. And the 41 critical infrastructures damaged, Badulla (31), Trincomalee (six), Jaffna (two) and Mullaitivu (two), respectively. Meanwhile, the district-wise breakdown of the impacted families were, 2,293 families comprising 8,074 people from Badulla, 581 families comprising 1,968 people from Moneragala, 199 families comprising 773 people from Nuwara Eliya, 130 families comprising 459 people from Ampara, 44 families comprising 173 people from Batticaloa, 96 families comprising 343 people from Trincomalee, 2,807 families comprising 10,241 people from Ratnapura, 28 families comprising 109 people from Kegalle, 153 families comprising 577 people from Jaffna, 358 families comprising 1,169 people from Mullaitivu, nine families comprising 29 people from Vavuniya, 365 families comprising 1,185 people from Kilinochchi, 50 families comprising 184 people from Mannar, 12 families comprising 36 people from Hambantota, eight families comprising 33 people from Anuradhapura, one family comprising one person from Puttalam, and 46 families comprising 169 people from Gampaha, respectively. And the district-wise breakdown of the damaged houses, Badulla (2,228), Moneragala (578), Nuwara Eliya (188), Ampara (129), Batticaloa (44),Trincomalee (84), Ratnapura (2,771), Kegalle (27), Jaffna (103), Mullaitivu (293), Vavuniya (seven), Kilinochchi (85), Mannar (11), Hambantota (11), Anuradhapura (eight), Puttalam (one), and Gampaha (45 ), respectively. By Paneetha Ameresekere

title: Sri Lanka proposes setting up eminent group to combat terrorist financing
author: Author not found
Content: Sri Lanka has proposed setting up a group of Eminent Persons with a view to helping galvanise greater political will and to create further international awareness among States on the importance of combating terrorist financing. The proposal was made at the recently concluded third ‘No Money For Terror’ (NMFT) Ministerial Conference in New Delhi. Sri Lanka’s High Commissioner to India, Milinda Moragoda, who led the Sri Lankan delegation to the Ministerial Conference, made this proposal in his statement to the Conference on 19 November. The ‘No Money For Terror’ Ministerial Conference on Counter-Terrorism Financing’ was held on 18 and 19 November 2022 in New Delhi. It was hosted by the Government of India. The Conference, which was inaugurated by the Prime Minister of India Shri Narendra Modi on 18 November saw the participation of delegations from ninety-three countries and multilateral organisations. The Conference extensively discussed global trends in terrorism and terrorist financing, use of formal and informal channels of funds for terrorism, emerging technologies and terrorist financing and request international co-operation to address challenges in combating terrorist financing.  Delivering Sri Lanka’s country statement, Moragoda further stated that political will on the part of member States is the most significant component in international cooperation to address the multi-faceted challenges faced when combating terrorist financing. He said that though the objective of the Conference on ‘No Money for Terror’, which is to sensitise the international community to the dangers of ignoring this issue, is commendable, there should be a mechanism to provide continuity to the work of the Conference. In this context, Moragoda proposed that India, as the Chair of the present Conference, take the lead in creating a group of eminent persons selected from among the member States with a view to helping galvanise greater political will and to create further international awareness among States on the importance of combating terrorist financing.  The first and second ‘No Money For Terror’ Ministerial Conferences were held in Paris in 2018 and Melbourne in 2019. The third NMFT Conference was built on the progressive agenda of an integrated approach with collective involvement initiated in the first two Conferences.  (SRM)

title: NADF says Govt should curb narcotic use in schools
author: Author not found
Content: By 2023 the Government should initiate a comprehensive programme to control and prevent the use of Ice, marijuana and other dangerous drugs in all schools in the island, the National Anti-Drug Front (NADF) said.  Convener of the NADF, Chathura Liyanarachchi, said the Government and the Ministry of Education should take immediate measures to formulate a programme, taking into consideration the media reports and most essentially revelations made in Parliament- essentially those by Justice Minister, Dr. Wijeyadasa Rajapakshe regarding the use of drugs in both girls and boys schools and draw up a prevention and control programme for schools. Minister Rajapakshe said there were over 500,000 addicted to dangerous drugs. But there is a severe need to fortify the rehabilitation process to cater to all those victims of drug abuse. Liyanarachchi said pointing out that currently there were only rehabilitation centres set up by National Dangerous Drug Control Board and the Bureau of the Commissioner General of Rehabilitation which has only the Kandakadu Rehabilitation Centre. At present there were 5,000 inmates being rehabilitated in Kandakadu, he noted adding that it was highly inadequate at this juncture when the use of dangerous drugs had increased tremendously. The government should move to set up rehabilitation centres in all districts and formulate three-month short-term programmes for the rehabilitation of all drug users. “We understand that the government would not have sufficient funds to be able to cater to the needs of all those centres. But there are a large number of non-government and civil organisations prepared to help and provide funds for the centres.  Small time drug users should be sent for rehabilitation and not to prison where they allegedly come into contact with other criminals and drug pedlars. When they come out of prison they too would have formed new alliances and would have fine tuned their knowledge and may resort to other forms of criminal activities, Liyanarachchi warned urging the law enforcement officers and government authorities to issue prison terms only to those involved in the drug racket and not to the users.  The NADF Convener said that a National Task Force comprising members of the Tri-Forces, Police and the Excise Department should be set up to carry out operations and they should be made responsible to the public. There should be transparency in their activities and they should be able to keep the public informed with regard to their activities at least on a monthly basis.          By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: Urbanisation kills 40% of Colombo’s wetlands – WB
author: Author not found
Content: About 40 per cent of Colombo’s wetlands have been lost to urbanisation over the last several decades, the World Bank (WB) said on Monday (12). The WB, in an article titled ‘Cities Look to Nature for Climate Solutions,’ said consequently two major floods in 2010 highlighted the need to restore them. Colombo’s wetlands form a teeming network of ecosystems among office towers, colonial buildings, temples, and minarets, it said. This expanse of nearly 20 square kilometres of freshwater lakes, wet woodlands, wet grasslands, and swamps is home to pink lotus flowers, spotted butterflies, and the elusive fishing cat, the WB said. Consequently, the Metro Colombo Urban Development Project, supported by the WB, led to technical and policy dialogue that resulted in the preservation of Colombo’s remaining wetlands such as the above and their integration into the city – earning Colombo international recognition as the first capital to be accredited as a wetland city under the Ramsar Convention on Wetlands, the WB said. The project’s goal goes beyond preventing future flooding to reposition urban parks and wetlands as the beating heart of city life, it said. Beyond improvements at the urban core, projects like this, offer more widespread economic lift, while keeping in line with goals to limit the emissions that contribute to a changing climate, the WB said. Because wetlands mitigate disaster risk in a cost-effective way while strengthening or rehabilitating ecosystems, nature-based solutions programmes can offer other benefits including enhanced agriculture and fisheries, improved water supply services, and opportunities to increase tourism, recreation, and access to cultural heritage, which support local economic and human welfare, the WB said. Further, wetlands soak up floodwaters and release them safely when the waters recede, working together with hard infrastructure such as pumping stations and underground tunnels to protect the City. Wetlands also operate as natural air conditioners, water and air purifiers, carbon sinks, agricultural havens, and safe harbours for biodiversity, it said. By addressing climate change, improving the lives of the most vulnerable, and increasing economic development, nature-based solutions offer a win-win-win for people and planet, the WB in conclusion said. (PA)

title: INS Sahyadri docks at Colombo Port
author: Author not found
Content: Indian Naval Ship (INS) Sahyadri arrived at the Colombo Port on a formal visit yesterday (13) morning. The ship was ceremoniously welcomed by the Sri Lanka Navy. INS Sahyadri is a 143-metre long frigate manned by a crew of 390 and the ship is commanded by Captain M.M. Thomas. The Commanding Officer of INS Sahyadri was scheduled to call on Commander Western Naval Area at the Western Naval Command Headquarters yesterday. The crew of the vessel will participate in several programmes organised by the Sri Lanka Navy, with a view to promoting cooperation and goodwill between the two navies. In addition, INS Sahyadri is expected to conduct a naval exercise with the Sri Lanka Navy in Western seas on its departure on 16 December. Naval exercises of this nature with regional navies will enable each partner to overcome common maritime challenges in the future, through enhanced cooperation. (NV)

title: Cargo ship service to link KKS with India – Devananda
author: Author not found
Content: Fisheries Minister Douglas Devananda said on 12 December that his efforts to start a cargo ship service between Kankesanthurai, Karaikkal, and Pondicherry harbours will pay off very soon. Minister Devananda said this at the event to mark the resumption of direct passenger flights between Jaffna and Chennai on 12 December. “It will take nearly 22 hours for the cruise from Karaikkal to Kankesanthurai. Pondicherry Port will be an ideal selection as the sea in the Nagapattinam area is deep,” he said.  Devananda expressed confidence that once the proposed cargo ship service is commenced between Kankesanthurai, Pondicherry, and Karaikkal, kerosene, diesel, and essential commodities like palm oil can be brought to the North with ease. As the transport cost is reduced significantly, goods can be sold to customers at a reasonable price, Devananda added.  By Naalir Jamaldeen

title: Public Security Minister inks MoU with J’pura University
author: Author not found
Content: A Memorandum of Understanding (MoU) was signed between the Police and University of Sri Jayewardenepura to introduce a degree programme for Police Officers recently. The event took place at the Ministry of Public Security. Minister of Public Security Tiran Alles and Vice Chancellor of the University Sudantha Liyanage signed the MoU. Through this agreement, the Police will be offered a three-year degree programme for the first time. The event was also attended by IGP C.D. Wickramaratne, UGC Head, Prof. Sampath Amaratunga, and senior Police Officers.

title: Indian Navy Chief in town
author: Author not found
Content: India’s Navy Commander, Admiral R. Hari Kumar, Chief of Naval Staff (CNS), arrived in Colombo on Monday (12) on a four-day official visit to Sri Lanka at the invitation of Sri Lanka Navy (SLN) Commander, Vice Admiral Nishantha Ulugetenne, India’s High Commission in Sri Lanka said yesterday (13). During the visit, Kumar is scheduled to call on President Ranil Wickremesinghe, Prime Minister Dinesh Gunawardena, and State Minister of Defence Premitha Bandara Tennakoon. Other engagements include meetings with Defence Secretary, Chief of Defence Staff, and service commanders, the High Commission said. The Admiral will be the Chief Guest at the passing out parade of Naval and Maritime Academy, Trincomalee, to be held tomorrow (15). Indigenous Indian Naval Ship Sahyadri, a multi-role missile frigate of the Indian Navy was scheduled to make a port call in Colombo yesterday (13) to complement Kumar’s visit, it said. The ship will engage in training engagements with the SLN and participate in maritime partnership exercises with the SLN, it added. SLN Chief of Staff, Rear Admiral Priyantha Perera welcomed Kumar on his arrival, the High Commission further said.

title: Schools will process Grade 1 admissions
author: Author not found
Content: The Ministry of Education announced that admission of Grade 1 students will only be carried out by schools and not via the Education Ministry. The Ministry further said that GCE Ordinary Level 2022 students, whose schools do not have their preferred GCE Advanced Level streams, will be required to submit applications to the schools with the relevant GCE Advanced Level streams. GCE Ordinary Level 2022 students have been instructed not to forward such applications to the Education Ministry. The Education Ministry also said the process of providing admission to students to enroll in schools mid-term has been halted from 5 December 2022.  The enrollment of students mid-term for 2023 will commence only after the completion of the 2022 third academic term, which is on the 24 March 2023. The admissions will be provided after inspecting applications and based on vacancies in schools, the ministry added. BY Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: SLPP ready to form Alliance with UNP
author: Author not found
Content: Sri Lanka Podujana Peramuna (SLPP) yesterday (12) gave the green light to forming an alliance with the United National Party (UNP). The SLPP is open for discussions with the UNP, with the possibilities of forming an alliance, General Secretary of the Party, Sagara Kariyawasam told the media. He added that if an alliance is vital for the betterment of the country, the SLPP is ready to hold discussions with UNP and arrive at a common ground. Responding to a question at the media briefing, held at the party headquarters, Kariyawasam said discussions with UNP will have to focus on the manner in which an alliance can be formed without affecting the policies of both parties. While stating that no decision has yet been made as to holding such discussion, he said there could be a possibility, adding that UNP is one of the oldest political parties and would be an additional strength to the SLPP if an alliance is to be formed. “UNP Leader, Ranil Wickremesinghe came to power as President with the support of SLPP and there has been a strong relationship between the parties since then,” he added. BY Faadhila Thassim

title: Chennai-Jaffna flights resume
author: Author not found
Content: Direct flights between Jaffna and Chennai resumed yesterday (12). The first flight from Chennai landed at the Jaffna International Airport in Palaly. Alliance Air of India will operate four weekly flights between Palaly and Chennai, on Mondays, Tuesdays, Thursdays, and Saturdays. Alliance Air, a wholly owned subsidiary of Air India Asset Holdings Ltd (AIAHL), began international flight operations to Jaffna on 11 November 2019 with a frequency of three flights per week and then suspended operations due to the Covid-19 pandemic. Given the increasing demand for air travel from the country’s North, Alliance Air, with the support of the Governments of India and Sri Lanka, has decided to operate direct flights four days a week with the goal of connecting to the neighbouring countries and providing better connectivity to all in South India and Northern Sri Lanka, Alliance Air said.  By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: All-Party Leaders’ Confab Today
author: Author not found
Content: President Ranil Wickremesinghe has called an All Party Leaders’ conference today (13) at 5:30 p.m. at the Presidential Secretariat, where the Tamil speaking Party leaders will be discussing the national question and other related minority issues. Tamil National Alliance Leader R. Sampanthan, and his alliance Leaders, namely, MP D. Siddarthan of the People’s Liberation Organisation of Tamil Eelam (PLOTE) and Leader of Tamil Eelam Liberation Organisation (TELO) Selvam Adaikalanathan will be present. Many others including Tamil Progressive Alliance (TPA) Leader MP Mano Ganesan, EPDP Leader Douglas Devananda, Tamil Makkal Kootani (TMK) Leader Justice C.V. Wigneswaran, All Ceylon Makkal Congress (ACMC) Leader Rishad Bathiudeen, and Sri Lanka Muslim Congress (SLMC) Leader Rauff Hakeem are also expected to be present. However, MP Gajendrakumar Ponnambalam, Leader of the Tamil National People’s Front (TNPF), has stated that he will not attend because the President has not specified the parameters of the conference and what will be discussed. He added, “We’ve seen several of these types of conferences that resulted in nothing.” Furthermore, the President should inform the Southern political Parties of his intentions regarding the national issue, he pointed out. He added that the truth should be told in his discussion before seeing the Tamils. “I received a text message about a meeting at the Presidential Secretariat. We’ve been discussing constitutional reforms, but let him explain the federal system that we are demanding for, and then we’ll talk,” he said. TMK Leader MP C.V. Wigneswaran said it would be good to have all the leaders of the political parties but again we would wait to see how it would relate to the Tamil issues. Meanwhile, TPA Leader MP Ganesan added that he would seek right placement in the Sri Lankan national polity at the all-party discussions and he would be representing the Hill Country Tamil community of recent Indian origin, who live outside Northern and Eastern Provinces. “Our political aspirations demand mainstreaming as full citizens in the Sri Lankan national polity,” MP Ganesan added. He confirmed participating in the all-party conclave called by the President and added, “We will impress upon the Government and the nation of our urge to find right placement within an undivided Sri Lanka as full citizens. We will put forward our proposals while extending moral support to the Tamil and Muslim political parties of the Northern and Eastern Provinces within the larger picture of the National Question,” he stressed. “We request the Government to appoint separate authoritative expert committees, as the first stage, to talk to the political leadership of different ethnicities and at the second stage to bring all proposals together to formulate a new Constitution.” According to Samangi Jana Balawegaya (SJB) General Secretary MP Ranjith Maduma Bandara, Opposition and Party Leader Sajith Premadasa will also participate. By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: TUs to strike if ECT offered to Japan or any other
author: Author not found
Content: The All Ceylon General Employees’ Union declared yesterday (12) that they would resist the sale of the East Container Terminal (ECT) to Japan, in the same way that they had fought to free the terminal from Indian control. They also recalled that the former President had attempted to sell the ECT, but they had defeated him. In a letter to President Ranil Wickremesinghe, the union urged him to change his mind or back off from offering the ECT to Japan, otherwise they would take massive trade union action. The union stated that they vehemently disagree with the president’s claim that he would offer the ECT to Japan and, if they declined, to some other investors. They added that they are not opposed to discussions or suggestions regarding the quest for investment, but they do reject offering the ECT to others before Sri Lankans can fully utilise it. They added the ECT will be the second-deep draft container terminal in the South Harbour with annual capacity of 2.4 million TEUs, 1200m quay wall at -18m depth. The terminal will be built over three phases and work is expected to be completed in 2024. At ECT, 440 meters of the quay wall, a nearby yard area, and connected facilities have already been developed by SLPA. According to the current plan, the ECT, which is spread over an area of 75 hectares, is 1,320 meters long. Once completed, the Sri Lanka Ports Authority (SLPA) will inherit a fully-fledged terminal equipped with 12 STC cranes that handle operations from ships to the land and 40 Rail Mounted Gantry (RMG) Cranes. Even though the SLPA has almost completed their mission, the TUs stated yesterday that it is not acceptable to give it away to Japan or another nation. By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: Diana’s citizenship case fixed for argument in January
author: Author not found
Content: The Court of Appeal yesterday (12), fixed 26 January 2023 for argument of the Writ application, seeking an order disqualifying State Minister of Tourism Diana Gamage from holding office as a Parliamentarian, after the Petitioners moved Court that the case was one of serious urgency. This was when the Writ application filed by Social activist Oshala Herath was taken before Court of Appeal Judges Sobitha Rajakaruna and Dhammika Ganepola. Court also ordered the Attorney General to file documents requested by the Petitioner on the next date. Previously, the Court ordered the Controller General of Immigration and Emigration (CGIE) to submit all documents pertaining to Gamage’s citizenship. Attorneys-at-Law Hafeel Farisz with Nishika Fonseka, instructed by Attorney-at-Law Gayan Darshan, appearing on behalf of the petitioner, noted that the matter should be considered as one of extreme urgency as the decisions made by Gamage in her capacity as an MP are illegal. The Petitioner sought an order in the nature of a Writ of Quo Warranto, requiring Gamage to show by what authority she claims to hold office and continues to function as a Member of Parliament of Sri Lanka. Further, a mandate in the nature of a Writ of Quo Warranto, declaring that Gamage is disqualified to be an MP, was also sought. It was also stated in the Petition that Gamage is a British citizen and had concealed the fact that she was a British citizen, while stating that she is also not a Sri Lankan citizen. Further, the petitioner noted that Gamage had on several occasions used her British Passport to apply for and obtain visas to visit Sri Lanka. BY Faadhila Thassim

title: Cardinal urges religious leaders to unite against ‘night life’
author: Author not found
Content: All religious leaders should rally together to prevent the proposed night life activities and thereby safeguard Sri Lanka’s culture, urged Archbishop of Colombo Malcolm Cardinal Ranjith. Addressing a gathering at Kurana, Negombo, on Sunday (11) Cardinal Ranjith said that the culture nurtured by Buddhism should not be destroyed by night life activities. “What Sri Lanka needs is a philosophical revolution,” he observed. “Some ‘parangiyas’, who had come to Sri Lanka after being abroad, have proposed an increase in night life and the growth of cannabis. All this is being proposed while striving to make Sri Lanka free of dangerous drugs. There are talks about sentencing those found guilty of drug related offences to death. This together with other night life activities will destroy the Sri Lankan culture which is based on Buddhist philosophy. Therefore we urge religious leaders, particularly the Buddhist clergy, to take the lead in safeguarding our rich culture,” he said. Seeing how various institutions, lands and companies are handed over to various foreign companies and individuals, the Cardinal reminded the political leaders to refrain from using public favour to gain power and position.

title: Bad weather to continue in North, East
author: Author not found
Content: Showers or thundershowers will occur at several places in the Northern, Eastern and Uva Provinces and in the Anuradhapura District during the afternoon or night, today, the Met Department said yesterday. “A few showers are likely in the Western Province (WP) and in the Galle and Matara Districts,” it said. Temporary localised strong winds and lightning will accompany thundershowers, the Department further said. In its weather forecast, with reference to the adjacent sea areas of the country for the 24 hours ending at 12 Noon today, the Met Department said that showers or thundershowers will occur at several places in the sea areas off the coast extending from Puttalam to Trincomalee via Mannar, Kankasanthurai  and Mullaitivu. “Winds will be westerly to south-westerly and wind speed will be (20-30) kmph,” it said. The wind speed can increase up to 40 kmph at times in the sea area off the coast extending from Puttalam to Kankasanthurai via Mannar and the sea area off the coast extending from Matara to Hambantota, the Department said.  The sea area off the coast extending from Puttalam to Kankasanthurai via Mannar and the sea area off the coast extending from Matara to Hambantota will be moderate, it said. Other sea areas around the island will be slight. Temporarily strong gusty winds and very rough seas can be expected during thundershowers, it further said. (PA)

title: Overseas Lankans have a role in rebuilding country – Anura Kumara
author: Author not found
Content: Sri Lankans residing in foreign countries have a huge role to play in creating a force of people to rebuild the country, Jathika Jana Balawegaya (JJB) Leader MP Anura Kumara Dissanayake said. Addressing a special gathering in Naples, Italy recently Dissanayake said, “The wave to elect Gotabaya Rajapaksa as the President was created by Sri Lankan migrant workers. When I see the crowd here in Naples today, I can sense a new wave that is about to be created.” He claimed that even if Budget 2023 wins in the Parliament, it would not be approved by the general public of the country. Dissanayake noted that Parliament does not represent the true opinion of the people. Instead of such a parliament, a parliament that represents the true opinion and wishes of the people should be appointed, he added. Dissanayake stressed that a country’s security depends on how economically strong it is. “In an economically collapsed country, security, pride, and dependence do not exist. The Prime Minister of Bangladesh says that Bangladesh will not be allowed to meet the same fate as Sri Lanka. The Parliament of Kenya says that it will not allow the calamity of Sri Lanka happen to Kenya,” he said. Dissanayake emphasised that Sri Lanka is being used as an international example of a country going bankrupt. “What has happened today is that the Treasury will not get any income even to pay the debt installments and interest for the coming year. The heads of State who have ruled this country for a long time have dragged the country into a situation where it does not have enough income to pay the debt interest and installments for a year,” he added. Dissanayake noted that even though the country is poor, the rulers are rich and their bank accounts are overflowing. Wealth that could have been used for health, education, factories and jobs has been looted by a small group and politicians are at the top of this group, he said. Only the JJB will punish the corrupt and take back the stolen wealth to re-build the country, he vowed and added, “The JJB would make economic changes that encourage Sri Lankans living abroad for the sake of building the country. We expect a large contribution from Sri Lankans abroad to get the foreign currency that we need immediately. We will create a government you can trust for that. Every dollar you send to the country will be used as an investment.” BY Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: Mudalige remanded till today
author: Author not found
Content: Colombo Additional Magistrate T.N.L. Mahawatta yesterday (12) further remanded, till today, Inter University Students’ Federation (IUSF) Convener Wasantha Mudalige till instructions are received from Attorney General Sanjay Rajaratnam. Mudalige, who was initially apprehended based on Provisions of the PTA, was subsequently detained for questioning, after which he was remanded, after having being produced in Court. Mudalige, along with Ven. Galwewa Siridhamma Thera, were arrested over allegations related to their participation at an anti-government protest rally, held at Galle Face Green last August. The monk, who was produced in Court on 23 November, was enlarged on strict bail conditions and two sureties of Rs 500,000 each, while Mudalige was further remanded. By Hansi Nanayakkara

title: Schools will process Grade 1 admissions
author: Author not found
Content: The Ministry of Education announced that admission of Grade 1 students will only be carried out by schools and not via the Education Ministry. The Ministry further said that GCE Ordinary Level 2022 students, whose schools do not have their preferred GCE Advanced Level streams, will be required to submit applications to the schools with the relevant GCE Advanced Level streams. GCE Ordinary Level 2022 students have been instructed not to forward such applications to the Education Ministry. The Education Ministry also said the process of providing admission to students to enroll in schools mid-term has been halted from 5 December 2022.  The enrollment of students mid-term for 2023 will commence only after the completion of the 2022 third academic term, which is on the 24 March 2023. The admissions will be provided after inspecting applications and based on vacancies in schools, the ministry added. BY Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: SLPP ready to form Alliance with UNP
author: Author not found
Content: Sri Lanka Podujana Peramuna (SLPP) yesterday (12) gave the green light to forming an alliance with the United National Party (UNP). The SLPP is open for discussions with the UNP, with the possibilities of forming an alliance, General Secretary of the Party, Sagara Kariyawasam told the media. He added that if an alliance is vital for the betterment of the country, the SLPP is ready to hold discussions with UNP and arrive at a common ground. Responding to a question at the media briefing, held at the party headquarters, Kariyawasam said discussions with UNP will have to focus on the manner in which an alliance can be formed without affecting the policies of both parties. While stating that no decision has yet been made as to holding such discussion, he said there could be a possibility, adding that UNP is one of the oldest political parties and would be an additional strength to the SLPP if an alliance is to be formed. “UNP Leader, Ranil Wickremesinghe came to power as President with the support of SLPP and there has been a strong relationship between the parties since then,” he added. BY Faadhila Thassim

title: Chennai-Jaffna flights resume
author: Author not found
Content: Direct flights between Jaffna and Chennai resumed yesterday (12). The first flight from Chennai landed at the Jaffna International Airport in Palaly. Alliance Air of India will operate four weekly flights between Palaly and Chennai, on Mondays, Tuesdays, Thursdays, and Saturdays. Alliance Air, a wholly owned subsidiary of Air India Asset Holdings Ltd (AIAHL), began international flight operations to Jaffna on 11 November 2019 with a frequency of three flights per week and then suspended operations due to the Covid-19 pandemic. Given the increasing demand for air travel from the country’s North, Alliance Air, with the support of the Governments of India and Sri Lanka, has decided to operate direct flights four days a week with the goal of connecting to the neighbouring countries and providing better connectivity to all in South India and Northern Sri Lanka, Alliance Air said.  By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

author: Author not found
