title: Integral Players in determining innovative solutions to fully inclusive societies
author: Author not found
Content: Ten years ago, the Asia-Pacific region came together and designed the world’s first set of disability-specific development goals: the Incheon Strategy to “Make the Right Real” for Persons with Disabilities. This week, we meet again to assess how the governments have delivered on their commitments, to secure those gains and develop the innovative solutions needed to achieve fully inclusive societies. Ministers, government officials, persons with disabilities, civil society and private sector allies from across Asia and the Pacific will gather from 19 to 21 October in Jakarta to mark the birth of a new era for 700 million persons with disabilities and proclaim a fourth Asian and Pacific Decade of Persons with Disabilities. Our region is unique, having already declared three decades to protect and uphold the rights of persons with disabilities; 44 Asian and Pacific governments have ratified the Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities; and we celebrate achievements in the development of disability laws, policies, strategies and programmes. Today, we have more parliamentarians and policymakers with disabilities. Their everyday business is national decision-making. They also monitor policy implementation. We find them active across the Asia-Pacific region: Australia, Bangladesh, China, Japan, Kazakhstan, Malaysia, the Marshall Islands, the Republic of Korea, Singapore, Thailand and Türkiye. They have promoted inclusive public procurement to support disability-inclusive businesses and accessible facilities, advanced sign language interpretation in media programmes and parliamentary sessions, focused policy attention on overlooked groups and directed numerous policy initiatives towards inclusion. Less visible but no less important are local-level elected politicians with disabilities in India, Japan and the Republic of Korea. Indonesia witnessed 42 candidates with disabilities standing in the last election. Grassroots disability organisations have emerged as rapid responders to emerging issues such as Covid-19 and other crises. Organisations of and for persons with disabilities in Bangladesh have distinguished themselves in disability-inclusive Covid-19 responses, and created programmes to support persons with psychosocial disabilities and autism. The past decade saw the emergence of private sector leadership in disability-inclusive business. Wipro, headquartered in India, pioneers disability inclusion in its multinational growth strategy. This is a pillar of Wipro’s diversity and inclusion initiatives. Employees with disabilities are at the core of designing and delivering Wipro digital services. Yet, there is always more unfinished business to address. Even though we applaud the increasing participation of persons with disabilities in policymaking, there are still only eight persons with disabilities for every 1,000 parliamentarians in the region. On the right to work, ‘3 in 4 persons’ with disabilities are not employed, while ‘7 in 10 persons’ with disabilities do not enjoy any form of social protection. This sobering picture points to the need for disability-specific and disability-inclusive policies and their sustained implementation in partnership with women and men with disabilities. One of the first steps to inclusion is recognising the rights of persons with disabilities. This model focuses on the person and their dignity, aspirations, individuality and value as a human being. As such, government offices, banks and public transportation and spaces must be made accessible for persons with diverse disabilities. To this end, governments in the region have conducted accessibility audits of government buildings and public transportation stations. Partnerships with the private sector have led to reasonable accommodations at work, promoting employment in a variety of sectors. Despite the thrust of the Incheon Strategy on data collection and analysis, persons with disabilities still are often left out of official data because the questions that allow for disaggregation are excluded from surveys and accommodations are not made to ensure their participation. This reflects a continued lack of policy priority and budgetary allocations. To create evidence-based policies, we need reliable and comparable data disaggregated by disability status, sex and geographic location. There is hope in the technology leap to 5G in the Asia-Pacific region. The implications for the empowerment of persons are limitless: from digital access, e-health care and assistive devices at affordable prices to remote learning and working, and exercising the right to vote. This is a critical moment to ensure disability-inclusive digitalisation. We live in a world of volatile change. A disability-inclusive approach to shaping this world would benefit everyone, particularly in a rapidly ageing Asia-Pacific region where everyone’s contributions will matter. As we stand on the precipice of a fourth Asian and Pacific Decade of Persons with Disabilities it remains our duty to insist on a paradigm shift to celebrate diversity and disability inclusion. When we dismantle barriers and persons with disabilities surge ahead, everyone benefits. Armida Salsiah Alisjahbana is an Under-Secretary-General of the United Nations and Executive Secretary of the Economic and Social Commission for Asia and the Pacific (ESCAP) By Armida Salsiah Alisjahbana

title: Sri Lankan Bhikkunis say they are deprived of obtaining NICs
author: Author not found
Content: Sri Lankan Bhikkunis recently informed Speaker Mahinda Yapa Abeywardena, about the struggles they have to face due to the authorities depriving them of obtaining National Identity Cards (NIC). This was when a delegation from the International Network of Engaged Buddhists, representing Myanmar, Thailand, and Sri Lanka visited the Parliament. The Bhikkunis, in the delegation from Sri Lanka, disclosed that Bhikkunis in Sri Lanka have been deprived of obtaining a National Identity Card (NIC) and as a result, it has been challenging for young Bhikkunis to sit for State examinations. The Speaker was presented with a valuable book from Myanmar. The delegation representing Myanmar stated that the book took 30 years to be written and 20 years to be translated and is a part of their national heritage. Whilst MPs present expressed their views on this occasion, the Sangha also shared their experiences and the challenges they faced. Accordingly, discussions were held regarding navigating through such challenges. Deputy Speaker Ajith Rajapakse, State Minister Dr. Suren Raghavan, MPs Dr. Sudarshini Fernandopulle, Rauff Hakeem, Premnath C. Dolawatte and Dr. Harini Amarasuriya and Chief of Staff and Deputy Secretary General of the Parliament Kushani Rohanadeera were present at this discussion.

title: Dengue eradication programme launched in Kalmunai
author: Author not found
Content: Dengue eradication programme were launched on Saturday (10), in Kalmunai on a mass scale as Akkaraipattu MOH Division has been declared a high-risk area for dengue. Officials of Kalmunai Regional Health Services including Dr. I.L.M. Rifas assisted the programme along with PHIs, Municipal Council officials, and volunteers from sports clubs and social services movements. The inaugural programme was commenced at Athaullah Arangam. Participants were divided into 60 groups to conduct inspections. While red notices and strict warnings were issued to many residents, a few were noticed to appear in Court. Text and Pic by M.A.P. Deen – Ampara

title: SL ‘infamous’ for human rights violations – Rasamanickam
author: Author not found
Content: Illankai Tamil Arasu Kachchi (ITAK) MP Shanakiyan Rasamanickam said, the economy cannot be developed as long as Sri Lanka doesn’t respect human rights. Relatives of forcibly disappeared persons protested near Batticaloa Ghandi Park after a march from near Batticaloa Kallady on International Human Rights Day on 10 December, seeking justice for their family members. Rasamanickam alleged that Sri Lanka was infamous for human rights violations. A large number human rights violations, especially against the Tamil community have taken place in Sri Lanka, he said. “The bodies of Muslim Covid-19 victims were forcibly cremated, violating their religious norms and values that come with last rites. It was a great violation of fundamental rights of the Muslim community,” he said. At the time when peaceful protests at GotaGoGama were suppressed by the Government, the whole country condemned it and we told them such incidents had been taking place in the North and East for years, he added. “There won’t be a good future for Sri Lanka until the country protects human rights. If anyone thought that the mothers of forcibly disappeared persons will stop their struggles to seek justice, it will not happen. They will hand over the struggle to their next generation,” Rasamanickam said. By Naalir Jamaldeen

title: Vehicle racketeers arrested
author: Author not found
Content: The Colombo Crime Division (CCD) recently arrested three suspects who had been involved in a racket, where they had illegally sold vehicles after having fraudulently changed the chassis and engine numbers. The suspects have been charged with compilation and possession of fake documents and aiding and abetting in the operation. Police said inquiries conducted into the racket had revealed that the suspects had obtained vehicle registration certificates pertaining to vehicles that are due to be dispensed with by leasing firms after which they had carried out their illegal activity. They added that two three-wheelers that were due to be sold by the suspects had also been seized by them. Police said the suspects are residents of the Weliweriya, Polonnaruwa and Makawita areas and would be produced before the Gampaha Chief Magistrate’s Court shortly. BY Chathura Deshan Liyanage – Colombo

title: Asoka Dias wins science communication award
author: Author not found
Content: The premier scientific body in the country, Sri Lanka Association for the Advancement of Science (SLAAS), adjudged Asoka Dias the winner of this year’s SLAAS Media Award. SLAAS annually presents awards for the popularisation of science among the general public through print and electronic media. This year, at the annual sessions of SLAAS, held under the theme of ‘Effective Science Communication for an Informed Society’, Asoka was awarded this prestigious accolade for his contribution for the Sinhala language television programme, Pathikada on News First, Sirasa TV.  The Pathikada programme has made a concerted effort to represent and promote scientific thought in diverse disciplines including medicine, agriculture, engineering, computer and social sciences. Asoka Dias started his career as a science communicator and later moved on to electronic media. He is a journalist and host of current affairs programmes with more than 30 years of experience in print, electronic and digital media. Currently, he serves as Director MTV Channel (Pvt) Ltd and MBC Networks (Pvt) Ltd, collectively known as Sirasa Media Network. He has Master’s Degrees in Mass Communication and Business Administration. Asoka is the Country Representative for the Manila-based, Asian Media Information and Communication Centre (AMIC), that serves as a regional research hub for media and communication issues. The SLAAS Media Awards were presented at the ceremonial inauguration of the 78th annual sessions of SLAAS, held on Sunday, 11 December 2022, at the Faculty of Medicine, University of Colombo. Pic courtesy: Nalaka Gunawadene (Twitter)

title: Officials checking weighing scales obstructed
author: Author not found
Content: Officers from the Kurunegala District Scales and Standard Office had been obstructed, by traders and businessmen, from performing their duty at the Kurunegala Weekly Fair, according to the duty officer of the office. He said officials had attempted to inspect scales and various measurement equipment used by traders and businessmen at the fair following several complaints.  But, he alleged that certain unscrupulous traders and businessmen had obstructed his officials from carrying out their job and that they were forced to leave the venue amidst Police protection. According to Pinwala, they seized eight scales which had been used without any seals since 2015, along with four other unlicensed scales. He added the scales seized will be produced before the Kuliyapitiya Chief Magistrate’s Court today (13) and would subsequently be confiscated. BY Ravindu Sooriyabandara – Kurunegala

title: Sri Lanka Press Freedom Slips From 127 to 146
author: Author not found
Content: Sri Lanka dropped to 146 this year, from 127 in 2021, in the Reporters Without Borders (RSF) Freedom of the World Press 2022 index, remaining in the problematic range. The RSF thus concluded that fewer than one in five Sri Lankan citizens have access to politically independent media. In the ecnomic context, it revealed that the mass media market is highly concentrated. In broadcasting, the four big firms of the sector share approximately 80% of total viewership. Political authorities exert strong influence on appointments and dismissals of editors-in-chief, whether through political friendships, control over subsidies and advertising contracts or, simply, through corruption. As a result, the most independent news content comes from online networks. Journalists who run them, however, are not exempt from pressure and intimidation.  The survey included 180 countries, with Sri Lanka ranking 144 in the political indicator and 163 in the economic indicator. It ranks 150 in the social indicator and 134 in the security indicator.  The purpose of the World Press Freedom Index is to compare the level of press freedom enjoyed by journalists and media in 180 countries and territories. This comparison is based on a definition of press freedom formulated by RSF and its panel of experts when developing the new methodology to be used from 2022 onwards. The Index’s rankings are based on a score ranging from 0 to 100 that is assigned to each country or territory, with 100 being the best possible score (the highest possible level of press freedom) and 0 the worst. Press freedom issues are closely tied to the war against terrorism that ravaged the island until 2009, and to the crimes – still left unpunished – against many journalists during the crushing of the Tamil terrorist rebellion. With a media sector lacking diversity and highly dependent on major political clans, journalism is at risk. On Sri Lankan, the index notes that the Sri Lankan legal framework does not restrict freedom of expression, but there are no guarantees of protection for journalists. Above all, the Press Council, established in 1973 to “regulate” the sector, poses a major problem because the president appoints the majority of its members. Officials frequently use anti-terrorism legislation to silence journalists, particularly those who attempt to report on the conditions of the Tamil minority in the island’s North and East. By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: Court orders skeletal remains be sent to JMO
author: Author not found
Content: The Magisterial inquiry into the skeletal remains of an individual, which were located from near Pilioya in Dambegoda, Maligawila was conducted by Wellawaya Additional District Judge and Chief Magistrate M. Wazim Ahmed yesterday (12). Police protection had been provided to the site following submissions made to Court by the OIC of the Okkampitiya Police. A group of workers from the Archeological Department, who had been travelling nearby, had first spotted the skeletal remains after which they had notified the Okkampitiya Police. Later the Magistrate ordered the Police to submit the skeletal remains to the Badulla JMO and submit a report on it to him at the next hearing. BY G.I. Roshan – Wellawaya

title: Title not found
author: Author not found
Content: Date:  The Court of Appeal yesterday (12), granted the Attorney General time, until 17 January, to file contempt of Court charges against State Minister of Water Supply Sanath Nishantha. This was when the Contempt of Court case filed against him was taken before Court of Appeal Judges Nissanka Bandula Karunaratne and R.Gurusinghe. Although Nishantha previously failed to appear before Court, when noticed to do so, following which he was warned by Court, he appeared before the Court for proceedings yesterday (12).  The Petitions were filed by Lawyers Vijith Kumar and Priyalal Sirisena and the Judicial Service Association of Sri Lanka (JSASL). It was stated, in the Petitions, that Nishantha, who spoke at a media conference, held at the SLPP headquarters on 23 August, had expressed critical views on the manner in which Magistrates acted in granting bail to the suspects involved in the ‘Aragalaya’ protest movement and that the MP has damaged the honour and the image of the Judiciary. The petitioners further charged that Nishantha has committed contempt of the Court through the aforementioned act, adding that it is a punishable offence in accordance with Article 105 (3) of the Constitution. Accordingly, the petitioners requested the Court to issue an order to summon before the Court the original video clips of the concerned press conference which were aired by several private television channels. Furthermore, the petitions also requested the Court to issue an interim order for Nishantha to refrain from making any statements that may be in contempt, in the future. Moreover, the petitions sought an order to be issued to the Attorney General to file a charge sheet against the respondent, charging him with contempt of Court and a summons to be issued to the concerned MP to appear before the Court and further to question the reasons why he should not be punished. In addition, the petitions requested that a hearing of the petition be held and Nishantha be charged with contempt of Court under Article 105 (3) of the Constitution. BY Faadhila Thassim Popular

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Dayasiri demands changes to Excise Ordinance
author: Author not found
Content: SLFP General Secretary Dayasiri Jayasekara demanded the Finance Ministry to amend the Excise Ordinance with strong clauses to strengthen the excise taxation policy. Jayasekara said, according to the Excise Ordinance introduced by the British, taxes were received when liquor stocks were released to the market. However, after the amendment introduced to the ordinance in 2014 by then Finance Minister Mahinda Rajapaksa, taxes can be paid 15 days after releasing the stock, he stressed. Jayasekara said tax worth over Rs 20 billion is not paid to the Excise Department annually and demanded to introduce necessary amendments to the ordinance to regulate taxes. The SLFP General Secretary also said a few MPs own liquor licences, which is illegal. He requested the Finance Ministry and the Excise Department to probe these irregularities. By Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: SL will launch climate change initiatives in 2023 – President
author: Author not found
Content: Sri Lanka will launch its mitigation of climate change initiatives next year, President Ranil Wickremesinghe said, adding that he has already set up a Climate Change Office. The President said, this at the Leo District 306C2 Mass Induction and Leo Day Celebrations held at Navarangahala, Royal College, Colombo yesterday (11), to enrol over 6,500 new Leo members from across the country. The President emphasised the importance of youth participation in finding meaningful solutions to the present crisis facing the nation. He pointed out that solutions should be made to prepare the country to face the next 25 years. “Despite the economic and political situation of the country, I decided to serve the voice of the youth and took over the country to create a better future for the youth. We have to look into solutions that suit the next 25 years which is a digitally developed future that will benefit the young generation. Accordingly, necessary arrangements were taken to appoint a young member for oversight committees to look into the solutions for the present crisis facing the nation,” he said. Speaking further, the President said in line with the 75th Independence Day celebrations in 2023, the National Youth Platform has been set up and requested the future generation to join the platform to rebuild the country and the economy that will benefit the youth and work in line with Singapore, Japan, China, and other developed countries in the region. He also requested the Leos to join hands with the recently launched ‘Climate Change Programme’ to obtain meaningful action from the youth to mitigate the climate change issues that have been a global crisis. The President, who inspected the exhibition which was organised by the Leo clubs of District 306C2, appreciated the most creative and talented idea of a seed paper done by Ananda College, Colombo. District President Leo Indunil Udara Palihawadana presented mementos to the President and Senior Advisor to the President on National Security and Chief of Staff of the President Sagala Ratnayaka while the President also presented awards to the Leo members. Colombo Mayor Rosy Senanayake, Principal Royal College M.V.S. Gunathilake, Past District Governor Lion Lasantha Goonewardena, District Governor Lion Bannet Gamalath, and Head Prefect Royal College Leo Kavisha Ratnayaka were also present at this occasion.

title: Budget airlines will be launched soon
author: Author not found
Content: Budget airlines will soon be set up in Sri Lanka to make air travel affordable to the masses, Aviation Minister Nimal Siripala de Silva said. He was speaking at an event to mark the 78th International Aviation Day and the completion of 110 years of Sri Lanka’s aviation industry, held by the Civil Aviation Authority of Sri Lanka (CAASL) recently at the CAASL Head Office in Katunayake. “Air services which are limited to the elite of Sri Lanka should be implemented in such a way that the public can also use them. For this purpose, budget airlines will be launched as soon as possible. Otherwise, it is social injustice,” he said. “In addition, many countries have launched low-cost but safe airlines for the public, but as there is no such airline in Sri Lanka, it is necessary to prepare a work plan for it. Also, the youth should be encouraged to take up jobs in the aviation industry and become pilots as well. Through this, the country can earn a large amount of foreign exchange,” he further said. Further, the Minister said Sri Lankan airports ensure the safety of every arriving and departing aircraft. “Our civil aviation services are compliant with International Civil Aviation Organization (ICAO) standards,” he added. The theme of this year’s International Aviation Day is ‘forward through innovation for global aviation.’ The event was chaired by the Minister and a group of officials including Ministry Secretary K.D.S. Ruwanchandra. Civil Aviation Authority Chairman Upul Dharmadasa and Director General P.A. Jayakantha participated. A digital smart card pilot’s licence was issued, an islandwide aviation innovation competition was launched, and a human-powered aircraft manufactured by Negombo Aeromodellers was introduced at this event.

title: Sajith re-elected SJB Leader
author: Author not found
Content: Opposition Leader Sajith Premadasa was re-elected as Samagi Jana Balawegaya (SJB) Leader at the annual party convention held yesterday (11), at Campbell Park, Borella. Premadasa said, the ‘Aragalaya’ is still valid and the public are the leaders of the ‘Aragalaya’ which chased away the robbers and corrupt politicians from the country. He pledged that the SJB will stand for the ones who were arrested during the ‘Aragalaya’ and ensure the release of everyone who was arrested by this “suppressive government.” He told party members and supporters to prepare for the Local Government Election and choose the best people to lead the nation towards stability. “Those who say unuth ekai, munuth ekai are conspiring to destroy the SJB. I am challenging them to do it. Let’s face an election. It will be possible to measure the strengths of the parties through an election,” Premadasa said. “Loss-making state institutions should be restructured. However, we will not send the employees home. We will do it through public-private partnerships. We will replace the Prevention of Terrorism Act with new legislation. We will ensure that human rights are safeguarded,” he further said. Commenting on the recent incidents where illegal substances were being distributed near schools, Premadasa also insisted that the ones who distribute illegal substances such as heroin and ‘Ice’ should be severely dealt with and anyone who is involved in such rackets should be arrested regardless of their status. He also said Sri Lanka should be developed as a tech hub.  SJB members and supporters attended the convention in two marches from Kolonnawa and Borella junction towards Campbell Park. MPs Dullas Alahapperuma and Chandima Weerakkody who became independent in Parliament from the Sri Lanka Podujana Peramuna (SLPP) were also present at the occasion. Premadasa also launched the official website of the SJB on this occasion. Field Marshal MP Sarath Fonseka was appointed as the Party Chairman while MP Ranjith Maddumabandara was appointed as the General Secretary. MPs Dr. Harsha de Silva and MP Tissa Attanayake were elected as the Treasurer and National Organiser, respectively. MPs Lakshman Kiriella, Kabir Hashim, Imthiaz Bakeer Markar, Dr. Rajitha Senaratne and Ravindra Samaraweera were elected as Senior Deputy Chairpersons. MPs Thalatha Athukorala, Gayantha Karunatilleka, Dilip Wedaarachchi, H.M. Haleem, Chandraani Bandara, P. Harrison, Sujeewa Senasinghe, and MP J.C. Alawathuwala were elected as Vice Presidents. Meanwhile, the conference proposed to delegate to the Executive Committee all necessary powers to carry out the responsibilities and functions of the National Executive Committee. MP S.M. Marikkar was seen taking measures to remove people who wore costumes to ridicule certain politicians including President Ranil Wickremesinghe and MPs Diana Gamage, Kanchana Wijesekera, and Mahindananda Aluthgamage. By Nabiya Vaffoor

title: EXTREME COLD KILLS OVER 1,000 LIVESTOCK IN N AND E
author: Author not found
Content: Samples of cattle, buffalo, and goats that died suddenly in Kilinochchi and Mullaitivu in the Northern Province and Trincomalee, Batticaloa, and Ampara Districts in the Eastern Province on Thursday (8) and Friday (9), following extreme cold weather, have been sent for biopsy, the Livestock Unit of the Ministry of Agriculture said. Over 1,000 animals died in those areas due to extreme cold. Agriculture Minister Mahinda Amaraweera instructed Ministry Secretary Gunadasa Samarasinghe to submit a report on these deaths. The Livestock Unit said, it is believed the animals might have died due to unbearable cold following strong winds blowing in from India. However, samples were sent for a biopsy to determine the exact cause of death. Veterinary Investigation Officers, in the first phase, have conducted preliminary investigations through the District Veterinary Investigation Centres in the respective districts of the Eastern and Northern Provinces, and they suspect that these animals have died due to a shock caused by cold weather islandwide. Accordingly, a team of veterinarians and officers from the Animal Health Division of the Peradeniya Head Office of the Animal Production and Health Department collected samples of the dead animals from Kilinochchi, Mullaitivu, Trincomalee, Batticaloa, and Ampara districts today. Meanwhile, President Ranil Wickremesinghe instructed to suspend the transportation of beef and mutton at district and provincial level with immediate effect to safeguard public health in light of these animal deaths. The President has also instructed the relevant district officers and the Police to act responsibly in this regard. North and East Animal Production and Health Department officials and veterinarians are visiting these places, providing necessary healthcare facilities to the animals. Director General of the Department of Animal Production and Health Dr. Hemali Kothalawala said the samples of animals will be analysed in laboratories at the Gannoruwa Veterinary Research Institute yesterday (11) and today (12). The President has ordered to suspend the transportation of beef and mutton at the district and provincial level with immediate effect until samples are analysed and reports are released. In the Northern Province, 358 cattle died while 478 cattle and buffaloes died in the Eastern Province. Further, 191 goats died in the Northern Province and 352 died in the Eastern Province. The condition of nearly 1,000 animals is critical as well.  Owing to these unexpected deaths, animal owners have faced a loss of over Rs 500 million. More bodies of animals are being found.  Animal owners have started lighting fires to keep the animals warm.  A tally on other animal deaths hasn’t been conducted so far.   By Savani Sheashadhi, Amith Maduranga Gamage, Shashi Kumar – Mullaitivu, Rasadi Chathuranga Gamage – Vavuniya andW.M. Wickramasinghe – Kantale

title: Former VC of Pera University assaulted
author: Author not found
Content: Former Vice Chancellor of University of Peradeniya, Prof. Athula Senaratne was assaulted by a group of university students near his residence on 10 December, Police said. A group of university students got into an argument with Prof. Senaratne, alleging that his son’s car had collided with a parked motorcycle. Police said, around 300 university students had protested and thereafter damaged the official residence of Prof. Senaratne. Peradeniya Police arrived at the scene and dispersed the crowd. Prof. Senaratne was admitted to the Peradeniya Hospital while his son was admitted to the Kandy Teaching Hospital, Police said. No arrests have been made so far. Peradeniya Police are conducting further investigations. By Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: US sanctions Major Prabath Bulathwatte
author: Author not found
Content: The US Department of State has designated Major Prabath Bulathwatte, former head of a clandestine Sri Lanka Army platoon, known as the ‘Tripoli Platoon,’ for ‘gross violation of human rights.’ “Pursuant to Section 7031(c), the Department of State is designating Bulathwatte for his involvement in a gross violation of human rights, namely torture and/or cruel, inhuman, or degrading treatment or punishment of Sri Lankan journalist, Keith Noyahr, in May 2008,” the department’s website said.  According to the US Department of State, all property and interests in property of individuals or entities designated under E.O.s 14024, 13818, 13722, 13687, or 13553 that are in the United States or in the possession or control of US persons are blocked and must be reported to the Department of the Treasury’s Office of Foreign Assets Control (OFAC). In addition, any entities that are owned, directly or indirectly, 50 per cent or more by one or more blocked persons are also blocked. Unless authorised by a general or specific licence issued by OFAC, or otherwise exempt, all transactions by US persons or within (or transiting) the United States that involve any property or interests in property of designated or otherwise blocked persons are prohibited. The prohibitions include the making of any contribution or provision of funds, goods, or services by, to, or for the benefit of any blocked person or the receipt of any contribution or provision of funds, goods, or services from any such person. Section 7031(c) provides that in cases where there is credible information that officials of foreign governments have been involved in significant corruption or a gross violation of human rights, those individuals and their immediate family members are generally ineligible for entry into the United States and must be either publicly or privately designated. INA Section 212(a)(3)(C) provides grounds for the Secretary of State to exclude any alien whose entry he determines would have potentially serious adverse foreign policy consequences for the US. In February 2020, the US had also imposed sanctions on former Army Commander and Chief of Defence Staff General Shavendra Silva for alleged war crimes committed during the final stages of the war in 2009.

title: LGBTQI+ community reps meet Police top brass
author: Author not found
Content: Representatives of Sri Lanka’s LGBTQI+ community met high-ranking Police Officers on Friday (9). They discussed how any inconveniences can be avoided during interactions between the two parties. Accordingly, it was decided that the Police will pay special attention towards the transgender community in Sri Lanka. The DIG in charge of the Divisional Bureau for the Prevention of Abuse of Children and Women will deal with all issues related to the matter. The IGP and the Secretary to the Ministry of Women, Child Affairs and Social Empowerment were also present at the discussion. By Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: Schools to reopen today – Education Ministry
author: Author not found
Content: State and State funded schools that closed owing to the unhealthy air quality levels are set to open today (12), the Ministry of Education said. State and State funded schools islandwide closed on Friday (9), due to the sudden drop in air quality. Air quality in Sri Lanka has improved compared to Friday (9) as per the latest Air Quality Index (AQI) yesterday (11), the National Building Research Organization (NBRO) said. The index is based on the measurement of particulate matter (PM2.5 and PM10), Ozone (O3), Nitrogen Dioxide (NO2), Sulphur Dioxide (SO2) and Carbon Monoxide (CO) emissions. Accordingly, schools will operate as usual from today (12), the Education Ministry said.

title: Bad weather kills three, injures 19
author: Author not found
Content: High winds and rains experienced in various parts of the country over three days from Wednesday to Friday, killed three, injured 19, damaged 4,385 houses, destroyed another five and impacted 4,825 families comprising 16,360 people, the Disaster Management Centre (DMC) said yesterday (11). The deaths were reported from Nuwara Eliya (two) and Ratnapura districts (one), while the 19 injured were seven from Badulla, Moneragala (three), Nuwara-Eliya (four) and Ratnapura (five), it said. The five destroyed houses were reported Ratnapura (one), Jaffna (two), Mullaitivu (one) and Hambantota (one), respectively. High winds and rains also damaged 79 small and medium enterprises (SMEs) and 30 critical infrastructure, it said. The 79 SMEs damaged were from Badulla (three), Moneragala (three), Nuwara Eliya (two),Ampara (one), Trincomalee (four), Ratnapura (52), Jaffna (eight), Mullaitivu (two), Vavuniya (two), Mannar (two), respectively and the 30 critical infrastructure facilities damaged were Badulla (26) and Jaffna (two) and Mullaitivu (two), respectively. Meanwhile, the district-wise breakdown of the impacted families were, 1,587 families comprising 4,765 people from Badulla, 2,168 families comprising 6,733 people from Moneragala, 199 families comprising 773 people from Nuwara Eliya, 130 families comprising 459 people from Ampara, 44 families comprising 173 people from Batticaloa, 80 families comprising 279 people from Trincomalee,1,366 families comprising 5,107 people from Ratnapura, two families comprising seven people from Kegalle, 142 families comprising 534 people from Jaffna, 346 families comprising 1,124 people from Mullaitivu, nine families comprising 29 people from Vavuniya, 273 families comprising 899 people from Kilinochchi, 50 families comprising 184 people from Mannar, seven families comprising 25 people from Hambantota, eight families comprising 33 people from Anuradhapura and one family comprising one person from Puttalam, respectively. Consequently, two families comprising six people from Ratnapura were moved to a safety location to a building belonging to the Pradeshiya Sabha, Kolonne, DMC said. And the district-wise breakdown of the damaged houses, Badulla (1,525), Moneragala (578), Nuwara Eliya (188), Ampara (129), Batticaloa (44),Trincomalee (250), Ratnapura (1,361), Kegalle (1,363), Jaffna (98), Mullaitivu (281), Vavuniya (seven), Kilinochchi (69), Mannar (11), Hambantota (six), Anuradhapura (eight and Puttalam (one), respectively. By Paneetha Ameresekere

title: NEC ORGANISES FIRST BIENNIAL SYMPOSIUM
author: Author not found
Content: The National Education Commission (NEC) has organised the National Education Commission 1st Biennial Symposium on Education. The event will be held biennially commencing from this year to create a national platform for those who are in diverse institutions engaging in education research to meet and share findings and exchange views and opinions. It will bring together a wide audience of political leadership, policy planners, officers of implementing agencies, educationists and academics, postgraduates and undergraduate students for scholarly discourses and debates. State Minister for Higher Education Dr. Suren Raghavan will grace the occasion as the chief guest. It will be held on 16 December from 8.00 am to 5.00 pm at the BMICH, Colombo 7. The programme consists of eight keynote/ guest speeches delivered by eminent experts in education, allied fields and 27 research communications by researchers from the Universities, the National Institute of Education and Colleges of Education The National Education Commission (NEC), mandated by an Act of Parliament, is the apex body responsible for formulating national education policies and guiding education policy reforms in the country. The NEC was established as one of the outcomes of the recommendations made by the Youth Commission appointed in 1989, in the immediate aftermath of the 2nd Youth Insurrection during 1987 – 1989 period. It was stated that the Youth Commission had observed that there was a mismatch between education and employment, leading to large-scale unemployment and frustration among school leavers either before or after their examinations irrespective of whether they had passed or failed their examinations. It has also noted the moral vacuum, which the curriculum and the teaching methods or indifference of teachers had created. There were other major factors which had also caused much discontent among youth, but defects in the educational system inclusive of tertiary education had been perceived as the primary root causes of the problem. It was stated that therefore, there was an urgent need for introducing reforms into the education sector to eradicate the primary root causes of youth unrest while addressing their grievances. Then Minister of Education, Lalith Athulathudali in presenting the Bill for the establishment of the NEC at the parliament delivering his speech had stated that this Act will be the most important Act in the history of Sri Lankan education as it will provide the legal framework to prepare and maintain a sustainable education policy for the country. “It is the general acceptance of the society that the education policy changes from government to government, minister to minister and officer to officer. Therefore, the purpose of presenting this Bill is for the establishment of an institutional mechanism to prepare and maintain a continuing and consistent national education policy,” he said. The first Commission was instituted in July 2021 and was headed by Prof. Lakshman Jayathilake who served as the Chairman of the Youth Commission. Since its inspection, there have been eight successive Commissions with 5-year tenures consisting of renowned personalities, it was stated. The functions of the Commission as defined by the National Education Commission Act No. 19 of 1991 are to make recommendations to the President, on educational policy in all aspects. Also, to review and analyse periodically the national education policy plans or plans in operation and when necessary, to recommend to the President, changes in such policy. Additionally, plan to advise the President on any other matter relating to education which may be referred to it by the President, for its advice.   The NEC is also mandated to review and analyse periodically the national education policy and plans in operation and where necessary recommend changes. The most recent policy document titled ‘National Education Policy Framework (2020 – 2030)’ was released in June 2022. It is the first policy document which was formulated by taking into consideration of the entire education sector that includes eight sub-sectors. They are namely, Early Childhood Care and Education, General Education, Higher Education, Technical and Vocational Education and Training, Pirivena Education, Special and Inclusive Education, Non – Formal Education and International School Education. The National Education Policy Framework (2020 – 2030) was formally submitted to the Minister of Education in June 2022 for forwarding to the President. This policy framework has now been accepted by the Ministry of Education as the basis for formulating the reforms to bring far – reaching reforms into the national education system. BY Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: VAT, Inland Revenue Bills passed
author: Author not found
Content: The controversial Value Added Tax (Amendment) and Inland Revenue (Amendment) Bills were passed in Parliament with a majority and with amendments on Friday (9) The Second Reading debate of the Bills was held on Friday (9) and the Opposition called for a division for the Second Reading of the Value Added Tax (Amendment) Bill. Accordingly, the Bill received 82 votes in favour with 52 against. A division was called for the Third Reading of the Value Added Tax (Amendment) Bill by the Opposition to which 82 votes were cast in favour of the Bill and 41 against. A division was also called for the Second Reading of the Inland Revenue (Amendment) Bill by the Opposition. Accordingly, 83 votes were cast in favour of the Bill and 41 against. A division was called for the Third Reading of the Inland Revenue (Amendment) Bill by the Opposition to which 79 votes were cast in favour of the Bill to 36 against.

title: Govt cannot be toppled by protestors
author: Author not found
Content: The Government cannot be toppled by anti-government protests or demonstrations. If a party or faction thinks they can seize power through such efforts that can take the country towards anarchy, the public must oppose them, UNP Chairman, MP Wajira Abeywardana said yesterday (11). “Such efforts will lead the country going back to anarchy and therefore the leaders and members of every political party in Parliament must arrive at a national consensus, setting aside their political agendas, considering the future of the country,” he said. Speaking to the media in Colombo, Abeywardana said Budget 2023 has the proposals to resolve the country’s economic crisis. “President Ranil Wickremesinghe has taken the responsibility of correcting some mistakes made by his predecessors,” he added. “If any political party or group is not able to arrive at a national consensus at this time, it will make things worse. We have to overcome the economic challenges and make Sri Lanka a developed nation,” Abeywardana said. By Naalir Jamaldeen

title: Solo art exhibition held at Olcott Maha Vidyalaya
author: Author not found
Content: ‘Gee Sithuwam,’ a solo art and cartoon exhibition by Priyadarshana Siriratne, a teacher at Olcott Maha Vidyalaya, Galle was held on 10 December. The exhibition was held from 8:00 a.m. to 4:00 p.m. at the school premises. Creative paintings as well as cartoons on current events added colour to the exhibition. Admission was free and participants were allowed to purchase their favourite paintings. (AK)

title: Mercedes crashes into three-wheeler at Kollupitiya
author: Author not found
Content: A speeding Mercedes-Benz car returning from a night club crashed into a three-wheeler in Kollupitiya, killing the 58-year-old three-wheeler driver on the spot. Police said the car which was travelling from Bambalapitiya towards Galle Face, crashed into the three-wheeler travelling in the same direction. The three-wheeler driver, who was critically injured in the accident, was pronounced dead on admission to the Colombo National Hospital. The deceased is a 58-year-old resident of Kahathuduwa, Polgasowita. Police said three women and two men were inside the car at the time of the accident. Two women aged 29 and 31 were also injured and were admitted to the Colombo National Hospital. The driver of the car fled the scene. Statements have been obtained from the remaining two passengers of the car. Preliminary investigations showed they were returning from a night club. Kollupitiya Police are conducting further investigations. By Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: FAO, UNODC upskill prison inmates in agricultural practices
author: Author not found
Content: The Food and Agriculture Organisation of the United Nations (FAO) and the United Nations Office on Drugs and Crime (UNODC) are working with the Department of Prisons to enhance the skills of inmates in modern agricultural practices. Accordingly, a selection of agricultural land under the Mahara Prison and the Pallansena Youth Correctional Centre is being utilised to set up sustainable farming structures. FAO and UNODC are providing technical equipment such as greenhouses, irrigation systems including solar water pumps and sprinkler systems, and mushroom cultivation units along with training on sustainable agricultural practices for inmates and officials engaged in agriculture within these prisons. The officials and inmates will be granted certificates to recognise the skills developed as part of the project and support the inmates’ access to livelihoods in the agriculture sector at the point of reintegration into society. Commissioner-General of Prisons Thushara Upuldeniya, describing the added value of the initiative said, “Inmates must be provided opportunities to develop their skills in a meaningful way to ensure successful reintegration into society. The modern farming structures at the correctional facilities will also help strengthen the food security of the inmates. We thank FAO and UNODC for their support.” Speaking on the initiative, FAO Representative for Sri Lanka and the Maldives, Vimlendra Sharan said, “As FAO, we are committed to encouraging urban agriculture by developing skills and promoting livelihoods in the agriculture sector. The technical knowledge and skills transferred through this project will support the participants by providing increased employment opportunities in the agriculture sector at the point of reintegration into society.” Speaking on UNODC’s commitment, Head of the UNODC Global Maritime Crime Programme, Siri Bjune said, “UNODC’s Global Maritime Crime Programme is committed to further support Sri Lanka Prisons to improve their capacities in managing secure, sustainable, and human rights compliant detention facilities, that also promote effective rehabilitation. UNODC would like to see this project contribute toward improved mental and physical well-being of the prisoners and further encourages Sri Lanka to meet international standards in treatment of prisoners and prison facilities.”

title: Nalin moots providing low-interest loans
author: Author not found
Content: In a backdrop of egg prices skyrocketing, Minister of Trade Nalin Fernando instructed Government officials to take necessary steps to provide low-interest loans to egg producers to increase market supply. This was disclosed during a meeting with egg producers at the Ministry of Trade to discuss egg supply to the market. Egg producers who participated in the discussion highlighted that selling an egg at Rs 50 is not a problem given the cost of production. According to them, the Covid-19 pandemic, the ongoing fuel shortage, and the rapid increase in the prices of animal feed such as soy, corn, and others have all had a negative impact on the egg production industry, resulting in a decrease in egg supply. In response, the Minister said animal feed prices are presently decreasing and will continue to fall in the future. The Minister queried Government officials about the possibility of providing loans to egg producers to increase market supply. By Thameenah Razeek

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Steps taken to fill PS chair vacancies
author: Author not found
Content: Local Government (LG) Commissioners have taken steps to expedite the process of filling up the Chairperson vacancies in the Lunugala Pradeshiya Sabha (PS) of the Badulla District and the Manmunai South Eruvilpattu PS in the Batticaloa District. As part of these measures the LG Commissioners had decided to convene a session of the Lunugala PS on 20 December, while a similar session is slated to be convened at the Eruvilpattu PS three days later. The Gazette Notification regarding the election of the Lunugala PS Chairman has been issued by Uva LG Commissioner M. M. Wijenayake while a similar Notification had been issued with regard to the election of the Eruvilpattu PS head by Eastern Province LG Commissioner N. Maniwannan. BY Amith Gamage

title: Budget Third Reading passed with amendments
author: Author not found
Content: The Third Reading of Budget 2023 was passed in Parliament, with amendments, by a majority of 43 votes. One hundred and twenty three (123) MPs voted in favour of the Bill, while 80 voted against. Two abstained from voting.  MPs C.V. Wigneswaran and Velu Kumar abstained. The Committee Stage debate of the Budget 2023 was held for 13 days. It commenced on 23 November following the division on the Second Reading on 22 November, which was passed by a majority of 37 votes. President Ranil Wickremesinghe, in his capacity as the Minister of Finance, presented the Budget 2023 to Parliament on 14 November, aimed at creating long-term stable economic growth. According to Budget 2023, 77th budget of independent Sri Lanka, the total expenditure for 2023 will be Rs 5,819 billion (19.2%) and the total revenue and grants will be Rs. 3,415 billion (11.3%). Meanwhile, the budget deficit for the fiscal year 2023 is estimated at Rs 2,404 billion, which is 7.9 as a percentage. Through this budget, the Government has allocated Rs 4,609 billion for recurring expenditure such as subsidies and salary payments. For salaries and wages, Rs 1,002 billion has been set aside, and Rs. 1,114 billion for subsidies and transfers.

title: Arrested for obstructing Police
author: Author not found
Content: An individual named Amesh Ruwantha, who obstructed the duties of Traffic Police officers at Delkanda was arrested by the Mirihana Police, Police Media Spokesperson SSP Nihal Thalduwa said. SSP Thalduwa said the Police have launched an investigation after a video of this person threatening two Police officers on traffic duty has gone viral on social media several days ago. It was revealed that the incident took place in Delkanda, ​​Nugegoda when the officers had signalled him to stop the car over violation of traffic rules. The suspect was then seen obstructing and verbally abusing the two Police officers.

title: Russians in SL earning forex from other tourists here
author: Author not found
Content: Secretary of the Unawatuna Hoteliers’ Association Sumith Ubesiri said the Russians in Sri Lanka have now begun to provide services to other foreign tourists to earn money. He said now the Russians are earning US dollars and taking them back to Russia. According to him, some Russians residing in Sri Lanka have begun to encroach on jobs handled by locals, thereby impeding Sri Lanka’s ability to earn valuable foreign exchange through the tourism industry. Ubesiri urged the Ministry of Tourism and Land to intervene and implement a programme to monitor and analyse the activities of Russians residing in the country in order to prevent them from unfairly encroaching on the services provided to tourists by locals. BY Kamal Wijehewa – Galle

title: Title not found
author: Author not found
Content: Date:  Not imposing night time power-cuts, during upcoming GCE Advanced Level Examination 2022, scheduled for January next year, could be considered, said Power and Energy Minister Kanchana Wijesekara. Wijesekara said this in Parliament in response to a question from MP Wimal Weerawansa. On a separate occasion, Wijesekara who said each power plant will be transformed into company to increase the efficiency emphasised that all the power plants will continue to be under the Government. Responding to questions raised by the Opposition as to whether there are plants to divide CEB into several companies, Wijesekara said no one should fight against the restructuring of CEB just because they were not able to restructure and stabilise the power sector. Wijesekara said that restructuring plan has to go ahead to ensure uninterrupted power supply. The loss by CEB by the end of December is expected to be Rs 152 billion, he stressed. He also said that some parties claim that CEB is currently enjoying an operational profit. He explained that it is because the thermal and furnace oil power generations were halted.  BY Aloka Kasturiarachchi Popular

title: COPF approves Casino Business Act
author: Author not found
Content: Chairman of the Committee on Public Finance (COPF), Dr. Harsha de Silva informed Parliament that COPF approved regulations under the Casino Business (Regulation) Act under strict conditions. COPF previously refused to approve regulations under the Casino Business (Regulation) Act since the relevant Bill is being brought for the first time to license and regulate casinos. Presenting a report prepared by COPF to Parliament yesterday (8), Dr. de Silva emphasised that even though there were attempts to issue Casino licences without a regulatory body, COPF rejected that proposal. MP de Silva said they only approved the Casino Business (Regulation) Act under strict conditions and that they will be inspecting the businesses every month. He said after they rejected the proposal to issue licences without a regulatory body previously, information was sought as to when a regulatory authority will be set up, who will be responsible for it, and what their responsibilities are if approval is to be given. He said the committee opposed the proposal requesting a time period of another two years. Accordingly, based on the promise to set up a regulatory authority by 30 September 2023, the committee approved the regulations. He further said the businesses will be monitored once a month and that they had obtained a signed document from the relevant parties that they will follow the rules and regulations. By Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: Maho-Jaffna rail line offline from 5 January – SLTDA
author: Author not found
Content: Chairman of the Sri Lanka Tourism Development Authority (SLTDA), Priyantha Fernando said the rail line between Maho and Jaffna will be closed from 5 January for renovation, which is expected to take five months. He said during the peak tourist season, the rail line between Maho and Jaffna is critical because the luxury Colombo-Jaffna train is fully operational. It is presently booked, and this service will be suspended from January to June 2023 due to the importance of the renovation. “We attempted to postpone the rail line renovation until at least April next year, but the Railway Department said they cannot take the risk, and rail line maintenance is critical, to prevent further derailments,” he said. By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: Election Expenditure Bill tabled in Parliament
author: Author not found
Content: The Election Expenditure Bill was tabled in Parliament yesterday (8). It was tabled in the House by Minister of Justice, Prison Affairs and Constitutional Reforms Dr. Wijeyadasa Rajapakshe. The Bill will encompass the Local Authorities Elections (Amendment) Act No. 16 of 2017, Provincial Councils Act No. 2 of 1988, Parliament Elections Act No. 1 of 1981 and the Presidential Elections Act No. 15 of 1981. As per provisions contained in the Bill, all expenses incurred by prospective contestants vying for each of the aforesaid polls will henceforth be monitored.

title: 1,000 schools without water supply – Eran
author: Author not found
Content: SJB MP Eran Wickramaratne stressed that there are over 1,000 schools without water supply and over 1,800 schools without sanitation facilities  in Sri Lanka. Speaking during the debate on the Budget Heads of the Ministry of Finance, Economic Stabilization and National Policies, Wickramaratne questioned whether the Budget 2023 is presented for the greater good of the citizens or for their own survival in the Government. Stressing that the Budget was not presented for the people, Wickramaratne said it is not possible to develop the economy by throwing parties in luxury hotels or living extravagantly. By Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: EC to announce nominations date last week of Dec
author: Author not found
Content: Amid criticisms over the delay in holding Local Government elections, the Election Commission of Sri Lanka (EC) said it would officially announce the date to call for nominations for the elections in the last week of December. Accordingly, the Gazette Notification on the number of representatives to be elected for each division will be issued dated 8 December 2022. In a statement, EC Chairman Nimal Punchihewa said it was decided during a meeting held by the EC members yesterday (8). The LG elections were postponed by one year in February last year. The elections should be held by 20 March 2023.

title: Tax waiver for MIRA to be reintroduced – SLTDA Chairman
author: Author not found
Content: Chairman of the Sri Lanka Tourism Development Authority (SLTDA) Priyantha Fernando, stated that steps have been taken to reintroduce the waiver of embarkation tax for airlines flying into Mattala International Airport (MIRA). The Chairman stated that the USD 60 embarkation tax and 50% discount for landing rights at Mattala Airport will be reinstated in order to attract tourism. We want to attract 70,000 to 80,000 tourists to use the Mattala Airport he stressed. He stated that they had submitted a proposal to carry out the plan that was in place during the peak of the pandemic in 2021. We expect it to be gazetted soon, the SLTDA Chairman added. By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: Female filmmakers combat GBV, promote women’s rights
author: Author not found
Content: “It is important to train women in filmmaking. No doubt the art of filmmaking empowers women. At the beginning of a workshop, I observed a young Muslim girl, who was very shy to talk; reluctant to express her ideas and finding it difficult to confidently articulate her thoughts. However, when she was involved in filmmaking, I found her to be one of the exceptional talents in the team to provide art direction support. She could amazingly draw a storyboard. She had a unique ability to convert entire script to pictures. She organised the filming setting very creatively. Towards the end of the training, she was very confidently making suggestions and ideas,” Sumudu Malalagama, a short film director and a producer shared her observation after completing a four-day training workshop for female filmmakers in Batticaloa. The Centre for Media and Information Literacy (CMIL) conducted two mobile short film training programmes in Jaffna (24-27 November) and Batticaloa (1-4 December) to upskill 50 young female short film makers (26 from the North and 24 from the East) to use smartphones to produce compelling short films, addressing various human rights issues affecting women living in marginalised settings. The training programmes are organised under the initiative ‘Film for Equality’ and designed to enhance the capacity of the young women to use smartphones to produce compelling short films, capturing the lived realities of women in marginalised settings, and specifically focusing on how their human rights are systemically violated. Addressing GBV During both training programmes, young girls learnt how to produce short films to address issues such as economic inequality, GBV, climate injustice, digital misogyny, a lack of gender sensitivity, political and civic participation through mobile-based short filmmaking. The girls from Jaffna made a practice film on sexual harassment, where they discussed how young women are trapped by officials of the corporate and State institutions. Viewing the film, those girls maintained that a culture of zero tolerance is needed to eliminate sexual harassment. The girls collectively affirmed that fear of sexual harassment discourages women from discovering their own potential, achieving their goals, and fulfilling their aspirations. Thanushiya, a young filmmaker and university graduate said, “short films in Jaffna society has created a greater awareness amongst the young people on the rights of the LGBTQ community and the young girls. However, creating a culture of respect and recognition is a lifelong challenge.” She further said, “when girls remain in silence, it becomes extremely hard to create constant recognition for equality.”  They learnt how to shoot and edit video using freely available mobile applications such as KineMaster™. Each participant went through individualised training on developing emotionally powerful characters, story ideas, and converting them into meaningful films reflecting the voice of women. Breaking Silence “It is extremely vital for women to break their silence against gender-based violence (GBV) and human rights violations and continue to challenge the systemic oppression against women and young girls. One of the most effective ways to make this happen is to empower women to produce critical narratives articulating their lived realities,” said Ayesha Chathurangi, Lecturer at University of the Visual and Performing Arts. She made this point amongst young women short film makers from the Northern Province. When Ayesha said the majority of women are in greater silence against GBV, almost all the women in attendance endorsed it; many complemented her statement with their personal stories. Substantiating Ayesha’s statement, the majority of girls from the Northern Province said sexual bribery, sexual harassment on public transport, gender-based discrimination, cyber misogyny, and denying access to the public sphere, are some of the issues that they face in their daily life. Yet, most of the women do not speak out loud about their lived experience, in seeking justice. Rights to Safe Abortion The girls from the Eastern Province made two exercise films focusing on the right to marital consent of girls and right to safe abortion. Young girls were given the opportunity to contribute to the story development where they shared their personal experience in crafting their script.  Keshayini Edmond, a participant and short film maker directed the short film about the right to safe abortion, which highlighted stigma around safe abortion. Young girls indicated that some fathers and families dismantle the right of girls to choose a partner of their choice. Some girls said consent of young girls is not often valued when it comes to marriage. Prof. Indika Ferdinando, a national and international award-winning Sri Lankan theatre practitioner and film director and Sumudu Malalagama, film producer and director conducted the training programmes. The initiative ‘Film Incubator for Equality’ is supported by the Royal Netherlands Embassy in Colombo. During the training, those female short film makers shared their own insights on how GBV is systematically normalised too. Divya Rasathurai, a young female short film maker said, “when producing films on the lived reality of women, it is important to use metaphoric approaches and to engage the audience emotionally, intellectually, spiritually, and physically. Women should not be portrayed as powerless, helpless, voiceless and vulnerable individuals.” The same training programmes will be conducted in the Eastern and Southern provinces too. Under the ‘Film Incubator for Equality’ project, 76 young female filmmakers will be trained on promoting greater equality and gender justice. CMIL is working closely with the University of Jaffna, the University of Trincomalee campus, and The University of Visual and Performing Arts, Colombo, in designing a digital curriculum on filmmaking through smartphones and addressing human rights issues affecting women. The digital course will be available free of charge to all film enthusiasts in Sri Lanka.

title: Naveen lauds President’s Budget
author: Author not found
Content: Former Minister Naveen Dissanayake claimed that President Ranil Wickremesinghe has set a great target through the budget, aiming to develop the crisis-affected economy while achieving sustainable development goals, as the final vote on budget 2023 is scheduled for 9 December in Parliament after a months deliberation. “The Budget can be viewed as timely proposals and recommendations made by President Wickremesinghe to resolve the country’s current economic crisis. As a result of the President’s unwavering efforts, many pressing issues have been resolved thus far and solutions to many others are being sought,” he said. He made these remarks while speaking to the media at Sirikotha about the budget proposals for 2023 and the progress of the country’s economy. Dissanayake expressed confidence that President Wickremesinghe will create an environment in which he will be able to repair the country’s bankrupt economy. “I won’t think that there would be any strong opposition from the Opposition Party regarding the budget. The opposition is yet to make any announcement of their stand regarding the budget vote,” Dissanayake said. Dissanayake alleged that Opposition was talking about holding the election and of their political activities without any concerns or commitment about the current situation of the country. The Opposition, blames the Government on every occasion and that is a normal occurrence but they must have the mechanisms to build the country. The Opposition has not made any proposals or recommendations to rebuild the country and it is a matter of concern, according to Dissanayake. President Wickremesinghe has made several efficient and productive proposals through the budget. Establishing a university for Uva Province and several welfare programmes targeting the farmers and students are among them, Dissanayake added. BY Naalir Jamaldeen
