title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Female filmmakers combat GBV, promote women’s rights
author: Author not found
Content: “It is important to train women in filmmaking. No doubt the art of filmmaking empowers women. At the beginning of a workshop, I observed a young Muslim girl, who was very shy to talk; reluctant to express her ideas and finding it difficult to confidently articulate her thoughts. However, when she was involved in filmmaking, I found her to be one of the exceptional talents in the team to provide art direction support. She could amazingly draw a storyboard. She had a unique ability to convert entire script to pictures. She organised the filming setting very creatively. Towards the end of the training, she was very confidently making suggestions and ideas,” Sumudu Malalagama, a short film director and a producer shared her observation after completing a four-day training workshop for female filmmakers in Batticaloa. The Centre for Media and Information Literacy (CMIL) conducted two mobile short film training programmes in Jaffna (24-27 November) and Batticaloa (1-4 December) to upskill 50 young female short film makers (26 from the North and 24 from the East) to use smartphones to produce compelling short films, addressing various human rights issues affecting women living in marginalised settings. The training programmes are organised under the initiative ‘Film for Equality’ and designed to enhance the capacity of the young women to use smartphones to produce compelling short films, capturing the lived realities of women in marginalised settings, and specifically focusing on how their human rights are systemically violated. Addressing GBV During both training programmes, young girls learnt how to produce short films to address issues such as economic inequality, GBV, climate injustice, digital misogyny, a lack of gender sensitivity, political and civic participation through mobile-based short filmmaking. The girls from Jaffna made a practice film on sexual harassment, where they discussed how young women are trapped by officials of the corporate and State institutions. Viewing the film, those girls maintained that a culture of zero tolerance is needed to eliminate sexual harassment. The girls collectively affirmed that fear of sexual harassment discourages women from discovering their own potential, achieving their goals, and fulfilling their aspirations. Thanushiya, a young filmmaker and university graduate said, “short films in Jaffna society has created a greater awareness amongst the young people on the rights of the LGBTQ community and the young girls. However, creating a culture of respect and recognition is a lifelong challenge.” She further said, “when girls remain in silence, it becomes extremely hard to create constant recognition for equality.”  They learnt how to shoot and edit video using freely available mobile applications such as KineMaster™. Each participant went through individualised training on developing emotionally powerful characters, story ideas, and converting them into meaningful films reflecting the voice of women. Breaking Silence “It is extremely vital for women to break their silence against gender-based violence (GBV) and human rights violations and continue to challenge the systemic oppression against women and young girls. One of the most effective ways to make this happen is to empower women to produce critical narratives articulating their lived realities,” said Ayesha Chathurangi, Lecturer at University of the Visual and Performing Arts. She made this point amongst young women short film makers from the Northern Province. When Ayesha said the majority of women are in greater silence against GBV, almost all the women in attendance endorsed it; many complemented her statement with their personal stories. Substantiating Ayesha’s statement, the majority of girls from the Northern Province said sexual bribery, sexual harassment on public transport, gender-based discrimination, cyber misogyny, and denying access to the public sphere, are some of the issues that they face in their daily life. Yet, most of the women do not speak out loud about their lived experience, in seeking justice. Rights to Safe Abortion The girls from the Eastern Province made two exercise films focusing on the right to marital consent of girls and right to safe abortion. Young girls were given the opportunity to contribute to the story development where they shared their personal experience in crafting their script.  Keshayini Edmond, a participant and short film maker directed the short film about the right to safe abortion, which highlighted stigma around safe abortion. Young girls indicated that some fathers and families dismantle the right of girls to choose a partner of their choice. Some girls said consent of young girls is not often valued when it comes to marriage. Prof. Indika Ferdinando, a national and international award-winning Sri Lankan theatre practitioner and film director and Sumudu Malalagama, film producer and director conducted the training programmes. The initiative ‘Film Incubator for Equality’ is supported by the Royal Netherlands Embassy in Colombo. During the training, those female short film makers shared their own insights on how GBV is systematically normalised too. Divya Rasathurai, a young female short film maker said, “when producing films on the lived reality of women, it is important to use metaphoric approaches and to engage the audience emotionally, intellectually, spiritually, and physically. Women should not be portrayed as powerless, helpless, voiceless and vulnerable individuals.” The same training programmes will be conducted in the Eastern and Southern provinces too. Under the ‘Film Incubator for Equality’ project, 76 young female filmmakers will be trained on promoting greater equality and gender justice. CMIL is working closely with the University of Jaffna, the University of Trincomalee campus, and The University of Visual and Performing Arts, Colombo, in designing a digital curriculum on filmmaking through smartphones and addressing human rights issues affecting women. The digital course will be available free of charge to all film enthusiasts in Sri Lanka.

title: STF arrests man with Valampuri worth millions
author: Author not found
Content: The STF arrested an individual with a Valampuri conch shell worth millions of rupees, the Kattankudy Police said on Tuesday (6). Kattankudy Police added that following a tip-off received by the Ampara STF on 5 December, a group of STF personnel conducted a raid and arrested the suspect with the Valampuri conch shell. Police said the suspect is a 42-year-old and a resident of the same area. The suspect was handed over to the Kattankudy Police for onward legal action. Kattankudy Police are conducting investigations. By Naalir Jamaldeen

title: AID FROM LEFTOVERS NOT AN ECONOMIC VICTORY – KIRIELLA
author: Author not found
Content: Chief Opposition Whip Lakshman Kiriella said that even if saved by Courts, those who contributed to the country’s bankruptcy will not be saved in the afterlife. Kiriella said the Government glorifies providing subsidies to the citizens, while spending the leftover money since they are not paying any loans at the moment. He added that providing aid from leftover money is not an economic victory.  Kiriella said that although many governments ruled the country after its independence, not a single government bankrupted the country but saved money for the next government. BY Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: Three cattle rustlers arrested
author: Author not found
Content: Three suspects, including an Army deserter, were arrested for stealing two heads of cattle on 7 December, Mahiyanganaya Police said According to the Police, the driver of the vehicle, transporting cattle, from Dehiaththakandiya to Mahiyanganaya, had attempted to run over Police officers at a checkpoint. Therefore, the Policemen on duty at the checkpoint opened fire at the vehicle causing injuries to the Army deserter. Police said that the stolen cattle were worth Rs 300,000, adding that the suspects were ordered to stop at the checkpoint following a tip-off received from officers on duty at 2nd Mile Post, Girandurukotte. However, the suspects did not stop the vehicle and attempted to run over the Police officers at which point Police opened fire. BY Nishantha Abeygunawardene – Badulla

title: Form CC without delay – Muzammil
author: Author not found
Content: MP Mohomad Muzammil urged the Government to not delay the formation of the Constitutional Council (CC) any further. He made this request during a media conference convened by Uththara Lanka Sabhagaya which comprises independent MPs. He charged that in the aftermath of the ratification of 21 Amendment to the Constitution, the Government is delaying the formation of the CC thereby neglecting its pledge to the people. Muzammil therefore urged both the Government and the Opposition to expedite the process of appointing members to the CC. By Bingun Menaka Gamage

title: SL’s foreign debt rises to USD 56.6B
author: Author not found
Content: Sri Lanka’s (SL’s) external debt, 2021 over 2020, Year-on-Year (YoY) increased by 0.52 per cent (USD 293 million) to USD 56,592 million (USD 56.6 billion), a World Bank (WB) report released on Tuesday (6) said. The report titled ‘International Debt Report’ further said the contributory factors to this external debt increase were Sri Lanka’s debt to the IMF, YoY increasing by 34.56 per cent (USD 666 million) to USD 2,593 million and its short-term external debt increasing by 2.69 per cent (USD 226 million) to USD 8,622 million. However, GoSL’s long-term external debt in the review period fell by 1.31 per cent (USD 600 million) to USD 45,377 million, WB data showed. Subsequently, Sri Lanka’s foreign reserves as a percentage to its total external debt stock, 2021 over 2020, declined by four percentage points (44.44 per cent) to five per cent, the WB said. It also said last year (2021), total external debt stock as percentage of exports that year stood at 375 per cent. Further, the totality of external debt stock in 2021 as a percentage to gross national income (GNI) stood at 69 per cent, Sri Lanka’s short term external debt stock as a percentage of total external debt stock stood at 15 per cent in the review period (2021) and Sri Lanka’s debt stock owed to multilateral agencies such as the IMF, WB and the Asian Development Bank (ADB) stood at 17 per cent last year. Meanwhile, Sri Lanka’s GNI, 2021 over 2022, increased by 4.81 per cent (USD 3,784 million) to USD 82,474 million, the WB said. By Paneetha Ameresekere

title: Blood donation camp in Kalutara
author: Author not found

Approximately 150 persons donated blood At this camp  and the collected blood was transported to the Blood Bank of the Kalutara Teaching Hospital. BY S.S.H.Lunuwila – Wadduwa

title: Indo-Sri Lanka JPMC to begin procurement for SL-UDI
author: Author not found
Content: The Indo-Sri Lanka Joint Project Monitoring Committee (JPMC), for the Sri Lanka Unique Digital Identity Project (SL-UDI), has decided to begin the procurement process right away. Government representatives, including State Minister of Technology Kanaka Herath and Indian High Commissioner Gopal Baglay met at the President’s Secretariat and it was decided to begin the procurement work for the project immediately. This joint committee met for the second time in relation to the project as an extension of the MoU signed between Sri Lanka and India on 28 March. The project’s progress was reviewed during the discussion and attention was paid to the bilateral issues required for its successful completion. As a result, the primary goal in launching this project has been to identify a suitable supplier organisation or group of organisations to install the required information technology system in this country. The quotation for the said supplier or group of suppliers will be completed soon. The Government of India is overseeing the software development for the Sri Lanka Unique Digital Identity Project (SL-UDI). The Indian Government has agreed to contribute three billion Indian rupees to this cause. As a result, major automated biometric systems and other software systems will be installed with the Information and Communication Technology Agency of Sri Lanka’s full supervision and consultation (ICTA). The Digital National Identity Card, to be introduced by the Department of Registration of Persons, will take a new look with the Sri Lanka Unique Digital Identity Project. Accordingly, the Information and Communication Technology Agency will provide all the related software and necessary technical guidance to prepare the digital identity card. The Information and Communication Technology Agency of Sri Lanka will assist the Department of Registration of Persons in creating a National Register of Citizens as a centralised system, including biographical information, biometric characteristics, (facial, iris, and fingerprint) of citizens aged 15 and above in accordance with International Civil Aviation Organisation (ICAO) standards. Data modification, unauthorised access and identity theft are no longer possible after enrolling in the Sri Lanka Unique Digital Identity System. This will also aid in the prevention of unauthorised use and cybercrime. Furthermore, the Sri Lanka Unique Digital Identity Project will enable reliable and efficient access to services not only in the public sector but also in the private sector, including banks, hospitals, insurance, and other services. Thus, the project’s goal is to provide a digital identity card to all eligible individuals within a year and a half. The progress of this project will be continuously monitored and reviewed by the Indo-Sri Lanka Joint Project Monitoring Committee. Personal data collection is set to begin in 2024, following the completion of procurement for the installation of information technology systems. Apart from State Minister Herath, and the Indian High Commissioner to Sri Lanka, Gopal Bagle, Chief of Presidential Staff and Senior Adviser to the President on National Security, Sagala Ratnayake, and the Secretary of the Ministry of Technology, Prof. Neranjan Gunawardena, attended the meeting. Commissioner General of the Department of Registration of Persons, Viani Gunathilaka, Director General of Economic Affairs of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, M.E.M. Wininger and the Chief Digital Officer of the Information and Communication Technology Agency of Sri Lanka, Kanchana Tudugala, were among those who attended.

title: Manusha instructs to prepare monitoring mechanism
author: Author not found
Content: Minister of Labour and Foreign Employment, MP Manusha Nanayakkara decided to implement a special system to ensure fair working conditions and the safety of domestic workers in the country. Nanayakkara instructed the Commissioner General of Labour to immediately implement a work permit for that purpose. The decision to implement this system was made during a monthly progress review meeting of the Ministry. “Everyone only talks about domestic workers in foreign countries, just about them being persecuted. More people are working as domestic workers in the country than the number going abroad as domestic workers. Because of this, more attention should be paid to domestic workers who work locally. Therefore, a special system is being implemented regarding their safety and working conditions,” Nanayakkara said. At present, a system is being implemented through the Sri Lanka Foreign Employment Bureau (SLBFE) to ensure the safety of domestic workers taking up foreign jobs. The Minister drew attention to the lack of a system to monitor domestic workers and instructed to prepare a system for this purpose. (NV)

title: Discussion held at Buttala Regional Secretariat
author: Author not found
Content: A discussion on the measures to be taken to reduce the damage caused by wild elephants to the villages in the Buttala Divisional Secretariat was held at the Buttala Regional Secretariat Auditorium. In the recent past, wild elephants that broke into many villages in Buttala Gonaganara caused extensive damage to houses, crops, and other properties. Several people were also killed. Villagers of the respective Grama Seva divisions, officials of the Wildlife and Forest Conservation Department, village officials, Police and Civil Security Department officials, and officials of the Pelwatte Sugar Company were present to provide immediate solutions to the existing problems. It was decided to properly maintain the elephant groves with needles and to provide farmers with elephant shots. State Minister of Foreign Employment Jagath Pushpakumara took part in this discussion via Zoom. The discussion was moderated by Buttala Regional Secretary R.M.S. Thilakaratne.

title: Ten-hour water cut
author: Author not found
Content: A 10-hour water cut will be imposed in Colombo and several suburban areas on Saturday (10), the National Water Supply and Drainage Board (NWSDB) announced yesterday (8). This is due to essential repairs on the pipes supplying water to the Ambatale Water Purification Plant. Colombo, Dehiwala, Mount Lavinia, Kotte, and Kaduwela Municipal Council areas, Maharagama, Boralesgamuwa, and Kolonnawa Urban Council areas Kotikawatta and Mulleriyawa Pradeshiya Sabha areas Ratmalana and Katubedda will be affected by the water cut. It will be enforced from 10.00 a.m. to 08.00 p.m. on Saturday (10)

title: USAID to provide advanced agri tech to farmers
author: Author not found
Content: The United States Agency for International Development (USAID) pledged to provide the world’s most advanced agricultural technology to Sri Lankan Farmers. USAID representatives, during a discussion with Minister of Agriculture Mahinda Amaraweera observed that in order to increase the efficiency in the agricultural sector in Sri Lanka, new agricultural technology should be resorted to instead of the use of traditional agricultural knowledge. Amaraweera noted during the discussion that Sri Lanka has found it difficult to reach self-sufficiency through the agricultural sector adding that to date certain crops that could be cultivated locally are being imported. While pledging support by providing advanced technology to overcome the difficulties faced in the agricultural sector, USAID pointed out that the current relationship between the Department of Agriculture and the Department of Agrarian Development of Sri Lanka with farmers is weak, due to which farmers are not informed about the decisions and programs taken by the government, which is a serious problem for agricultural development. Thereby, USAID also pledged to provide all necessary support if both the departments prepare programmes to connect with farmers.

title: Energy Bills Bleed Reserves by USD 52M
author: Author not found
Content: Reserves hemorrhaged for the third consecutive market day to Thursday, this time by USD 17.31 million (Rs 6.288 billion) and in the three consecutive market days to yesterday by USD 51.86 million (Rs 18.839 billion) due to the settlement of energy import bills. Thursday’s conversions are based on the value of the administered and benchmark official’spot’ fixed at Rs 363.18 to the US dollar on Monday and on the other two days at Rs 363.19 to the value, which was the fixed value of the official ‘spot’ on Thursday and Friday (3 & 4). Government of Sri Lanka’s (GoSL)face value money printing (FVMP) debt increased for the third consecutive market day to  yesterday, this time by 0.09 per cent (Rs 2,845 million) to Rs 3,265,661.05 million (Rs 3.2657 trillion)  due to a persistent lack of revenue. However, this increase was non-demand pull inflationary as it was used to meet the above external commitment.  GoSL’s at least theoretical MP borrowing costs (BCs) decreased for the third consecutive market day to yesterday, this time by 3.52 per cent ((Rs 4,637.04 million) to Rs 127,060.13 million due to continuous buying pressure of Treasury Bills and T Bonds in secondary market trading because of high yields offered by the same due to the twin reasons of GoSL’s huge borrowing appetite and uncertainty.  Market shortfall increased by 0.89 per cent (Rs 3,443 million) to Rs 391,029 million yesterday, thereby causing sustained rate pressure. Market was short for a record 306 market days to yesterday.   GoSL’s FVMP debt has been over Rs three trillion for a record consecutive 106 market days to yesterday due to a persistent lack of revenue. GoSL’s highest to the 311th highest FVMP debt has been recorded in the 311 consecutive market days to yesterday. CBSL which administers daily open market operations (OMO) lacks transparency. GoSL’s FVMP debt is equivalent to the totality of CBSL’s T Bill and T Bond holdings. MP is the exclusive right of CBSL.  GoSL’s MPBCs are prorated to the outcome in secondary market trading of T Bills and T Bonds on the reference day. ‘Spot’ trades are settled after two market days from the date of transaction. CBSL, the steward of GoSL debt and its foreign reserves deals in ‘spot’. The ‘spot’ is administered to minimise GoSL’s foreign debt in rupee terms and to lower the cost of energy imports which are met from the country’s foreign reserves and not from the market, to prevent further depreciative pressure on the rupee as Sri Lanka is an import dependent economy.  Transactions between CBSL and GoSL are foreign reserves neutral. BY Paneetha Ameresekere

title: Navy promotes 3,770 personnel to mark 72nd Anniversary
author: Author not found
Content: Sri Lanka Navy, which is held in high esteem as the First Line of Defence of the Nation, marks its 72nd Anniversary today (9). Coinciding with its anniversary, 222 officers as well as 3,548 senior and junior sailors, were promoted and will advance to their next higher ranks and rates today, on the recommendation of Commander of the Navy, Vice Admiral Nishantha Ulugetenne. On the directive of Vice Admiral Ulugetenne, a wide range of programmes are being conducted in each Naval Command, giving prominence to time-honoured naval customs and religious practices. In addition, capital ships of the Sri Lanka Navy will rest at anchor off the Galle Face Green today, giving the public an opportunity to have a glance of some of the major ships of the Sri Lanka Navy.

title: Ambassadors’ Forum to launch book on Foreign Policy
author: Author not found
Content: The Ambassadors’ Forum, led by Ambassador Sarath Wijesinghe, PC, will be coming out with its 8th volume of articles on ‘Foreign Policy Perspectives on Human Rights Development and New World Order 22/25.”    The book has 25 articles and is edited by Ambassador Wijesinghe and Amila Wijesinghe. The book is a timely addition to the discussion that needs to be undertaken on key issues relating to foreign policy and human rights that confront the country at present. The series of UNHRC resolutions on Sri Lanka are a direct outcome of this country’s inability to resolve its democracy and foreign policy challenges in a manner that meets the needs of its citizens. Authors in this volume include those from different professions, academics, journalists and political commentators. Some of the contributions can be mentioned to give a flavour of the topics and authors. There is Ambassador Dayantha Laksiri Mendis on ‘The application of human rights law and humanitarian law treaties in Sri Lanka and elsewhere’, Rohan Gunaratna on ‘Developing a balanced approach to national security in Sri Lanka’, lawyer Rajeev Amarasuriya on ‘Foreign policy perspectives, human rights and development in the new world order’, and journalist Shamindra Ferdinando on ‘Sri Lanka’s foreign policy dilemma’. As a diplomat who served in hotspot areas in the world including Israel, Ambassador Wijesinghe has had a vast exposure to diplomacy and its challenges. He has utilised his extensive network of contacts to obtain important contributions to this book. The Ambassadors’ Forum has maintained its impartiality and balance in dealing with current and timely topics without any affiliation, political or otherwise. Ambassador Wijesinghe’s drive to add more to the store of knowledge that would serve the country’s foreign policy-makers needs to be appreciated.   The Ambassadors’ Forum has contributed to the debate on the country’s foreign policy perspectives since the launch of the first volume in 2020 and thereafter the issue of seven volumes, namely Foreign Policy Perspectives for Sri Lanka in 2020, Foreign Policy Perspectives Port City Colombo and International Finance Centre, Foreign Policy Perspectives after Covid-19, Foreign Policy Perspectives Sri Lanka First, The Geneva Crisis the Way Forward, Peace and Reconciliation, and Promoting Tourism, Employment, Investment, Agriculture, Foreign Policy and Education. It is to the credit of the Ambassadors’ Forum and Ambassador Wijesinghe that eight volumes have been published within a space of two years.   Ambassador Wijesinghe also needs to be congratulated for having mobilised editors, sub editors, trainees, and many others who assisted in various ways in the publication of the series. At a time when Sri Lanka needs international support and solidarity, the Ambassadors’ Forum has stepped forward to give the country a better chance. Their services, and offers to serve, need to be utilised in the national interest. The present volume will be launched on 9 December at the OPA Auditorium to coincide with International Human Rights Day. The Ambassadors’ Forum invites its readers, well-wishers and friendly groups to register for the event by contacting 0777 880166 or by emailing <[email protected]>

title: Female filmmakers combat GBV, promote women’s rights
author: Author not found
Content: “It is important to train women in filmmaking. No doubt the art of filmmaking empowers women. At the beginning of a workshop, I observed a young Muslim girl, who was very shy to talk; reluctant to express her ideas and finding it difficult to confidently articulate her thoughts. However, when she was involved in filmmaking, I found her to be one of the exceptional talents in the team to provide art direction support. She could amazingly draw a storyboard. She had a unique ability to convert entire script to pictures. She organised the filming setting very creatively. Towards the end of the training, she was very confidently making suggestions and ideas,” Sumudu Malalagama, a short film director and a producer shared her observation after completing a four-day training workshop for female filmmakers in Batticaloa. The Centre for Media and Information Literacy (CMIL) conducted two mobile short film training programmes in Jaffna (24-27 November) and Batticaloa (1-4 December) to upskill 50 young female short film makers (26 from the North and 24 from the East) to use smartphones to produce compelling short films, addressing various human rights issues affecting women living in marginalised settings. The training programmes are organised under the initiative ‘Film for Equality’ and designed to enhance the capacity of the young women to use smartphones to produce compelling short films, capturing the lived realities of women in marginalised settings, and specifically focusing on how their human rights are systemically violated. Addressing GBV During both training programmes, young girls learnt how to produce short films to address issues such as economic inequality, GBV, climate injustice, digital misogyny, a lack of gender sensitivity, political and civic participation through mobile-based short filmmaking. The girls from Jaffna made a practice film on sexual harassment, where they discussed how young women are trapped by officials of the corporate and State institutions. Viewing the film, those girls maintained that a culture of zero tolerance is needed to eliminate sexual harassment. The girls collectively affirmed that fear of sexual harassment discourages women from discovering their own potential, achieving their goals, and fulfilling their aspirations. Thanushiya, a young filmmaker and university graduate said, “short films in Jaffna society has created a greater awareness amongst the young people on the rights of the LGBTQ community and the young girls. However, creating a culture of respect and recognition is a lifelong challenge.” She further said, “when girls remain in silence, it becomes extremely hard to create constant recognition for equality.”  They learnt how to shoot and edit video using freely available mobile applications such as KineMaster™. Each participant went through individualised training on developing emotionally powerful characters, story ideas, and converting them into meaningful films reflecting the voice of women. Breaking Silence “It is extremely vital for women to break their silence against gender-based violence (GBV) and human rights violations and continue to challenge the systemic oppression against women and young girls. One of the most effective ways to make this happen is to empower women to produce critical narratives articulating their lived realities,” said Ayesha Chathurangi, Lecturer at University of the Visual and Performing Arts. She made this point amongst young women short film makers from the Northern Province. When Ayesha said the majority of women are in greater silence against GBV, almost all the women in attendance endorsed it; many complemented her statement with their personal stories. Substantiating Ayesha’s statement, the majority of girls from the Northern Province said sexual bribery, sexual harassment on public transport, gender-based discrimination, cyber misogyny, and denying access to the public sphere, are some of the issues that they face in their daily life. Yet, most of the women do not speak out loud about their lived experience, in seeking justice. Rights to Safe Abortion The girls from the Eastern Province made two exercise films focusing on the right to marital consent of girls and right to safe abortion. Young girls were given the opportunity to contribute to the story development where they shared their personal experience in crafting their script.  Keshayini Edmond, a participant and short film maker directed the short film about the right to safe abortion, which highlighted stigma around safe abortion. Young girls indicated that some fathers and families dismantle the right of girls to choose a partner of their choice. Some girls said consent of young girls is not often valued when it comes to marriage. Prof. Indika Ferdinando, a national and international award-winning Sri Lankan theatre practitioner and film director and Sumudu Malalagama, film producer and director conducted the training programmes. The initiative ‘Film Incubator for Equality’ is supported by the Royal Netherlands Embassy in Colombo. During the training, those female short film makers shared their own insights on how GBV is systematically normalised too. Divya Rasathurai, a young female short film maker said, “when producing films on the lived reality of women, it is important to use metaphoric approaches and to engage the audience emotionally, intellectually, spiritually, and physically. Women should not be portrayed as powerless, helpless, voiceless and vulnerable individuals.” The same training programmes will be conducted in the Eastern and Southern provinces too. Under the ‘Film Incubator for Equality’ project, 76 young female filmmakers will be trained on promoting greater equality and gender justice. CMIL is working closely with the University of Jaffna, the University of Trincomalee campus, and The University of Visual and Performing Arts, Colombo, in designing a digital curriculum on filmmaking through smartphones and addressing human rights issues affecting women. The digital course will be available free of charge to all film enthusiasts in Sri Lanka.

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Indo-Sri Lanka JPMC to begin procurement for SL-UDI
author: Author not found
Content: The Indo-Sri Lanka Joint Project Monitoring Committee (JPMC), for the Sri Lanka Unique Digital Identity Project (SL-UDI), has decided to begin the procurement process right away. Government representatives, including State Minister of Technology Kanaka Herath and Indian High Commissioner Gopal Baglay met at the President’s Secretariat and it was decided to begin the procurement work for the project immediately. This joint committee met for the second time in relation to the project as an extension of the MoU signed between Sri Lanka and India on 28 March. The project’s progress was reviewed during the discussion and attention was paid to the bilateral issues required for its successful completion. As a result, the primary goal in launching this project has been to identify a suitable supplier organisation or group of organisations to install the required information technology system in this country. The quotation for the said supplier or group of suppliers will be completed soon. The Government of India is overseeing the software development for the Sri Lanka Unique Digital Identity Project (SL-UDI). The Indian Government has agreed to contribute three billion Indian rupees to this cause. As a result, major automated biometric systems and other software systems will be installed with the Information and Communication Technology Agency of Sri Lanka’s full supervision and consultation (ICTA). The Digital National Identity Card, to be introduced by the Department of Registration of Persons, will take a new look with the Sri Lanka Unique Digital Identity Project. Accordingly, the Information and Communication Technology Agency will provide all the related software and necessary technical guidance to prepare the digital identity card. The Information and Communication Technology Agency of Sri Lanka will assist the Department of Registration of Persons in creating a National Register of Citizens as a centralised system, including biographical information, biometric characteristics, (facial, iris, and fingerprint) of citizens aged 15 and above in accordance with International Civil Aviation Organisation (ICAO) standards. Data modification, unauthorised access and identity theft are no longer possible after enrolling in the Sri Lanka Unique Digital Identity System. This will also aid in the prevention of unauthorised use and cybercrime. Furthermore, the Sri Lanka Unique Digital Identity Project will enable reliable and efficient access to services not only in the public sector but also in the private sector, including banks, hospitals, insurance, and other services. Thus, the project’s goal is to provide a digital identity card to all eligible individuals within a year and a half. The progress of this project will be continuously monitored and reviewed by the Indo-Sri Lanka Joint Project Monitoring Committee. Personal data collection is set to begin in 2024, following the completion of procurement for the installation of information technology systems. Apart from State Minister Herath, and the Indian High Commissioner to Sri Lanka, Gopal Bagle, Chief of Presidential Staff and Senior Adviser to the President on National Security, Sagala Ratnayake, and the Secretary of the Ministry of Technology, Prof. Neranjan Gunawardena, attended the meeting. Commissioner General of the Department of Registration of Persons, Viani Gunathilaka, Director General of Economic Affairs of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, M.E.M. Wininger and the Chief Digital Officer of the Information and Communication Technology Agency of Sri Lanka, Kanchana Tudugala, were among those who attended.

title: Manusha instructs to prepare monitoring mechanism
author: Author not found
Content: Minister of Labour and Foreign Employment, MP Manusha Nanayakkara decided to implement a special system to ensure fair working conditions and the safety of domestic workers in the country. Nanayakkara instructed the Commissioner General of Labour to immediately implement a work permit for that purpose. The decision to implement this system was made during a monthly progress review meeting of the Ministry. “Everyone only talks about domestic workers in foreign countries, just about them being persecuted. More people are working as domestic workers in the country than the number going abroad as domestic workers. Because of this, more attention should be paid to domestic workers who work locally. Therefore, a special system is being implemented regarding their safety and working conditions,” Nanayakkara said. At present, a system is being implemented through the Sri Lanka Foreign Employment Bureau (SLBFE) to ensure the safety of domestic workers taking up foreign jobs. The Minister drew attention to the lack of a system to monitor domestic workers and instructed to prepare a system for this purpose. (NV)

title: Discussion held at Buttala Regional Secretariat
author: Author not found
Content: A discussion on the measures to be taken to reduce the damage caused by wild elephants to the villages in the Buttala Divisional Secretariat was held at the Buttala Regional Secretariat Auditorium. In the recent past, wild elephants that broke into many villages in Buttala Gonaganara caused extensive damage to houses, crops, and other properties. Several people were also killed. Villagers of the respective Grama Seva divisions, officials of the Wildlife and Forest Conservation Department, village officials, Police and Civil Security Department officials, and officials of the Pelwatte Sugar Company were present to provide immediate solutions to the existing problems. It was decided to properly maintain the elephant groves with needles and to provide farmers with elephant shots. State Minister of Foreign Employment Jagath Pushpakumara took part in this discussion via Zoom. The discussion was moderated by Buttala Regional Secretary R.M.S. Thilakaratne.

title: TWO IN FIVE HOUSEHOLDS SPEND 75% OF EARNINGS ON FOOD
author: Author not found
Content: Two in five households (42 per cent) spend more than 75 per cent of their expenditures on purchasing food, leaving little to spend on health and education, UNICEF in its recent report on Sri Lanka said. UNICEF said an acute economic crisis since early 2022 has caused severe food insecurity in Sri Lanka, and the situation is predicted to deteriorate between October 2022 and February 2023. According to the report, an estimated 6.2 million people (28 per cent of the population) are moderately acute food insecure, while 66,000 people are severely acute food insecure. Two in five households (41.8 per cent) spend more than 75 per cent of their expenditures on purchasing food, leaving little to spend on health and education. Many families have exhausted their savings and are struggling due to crippling inflation. UNICEF said it will prioritise access to basic social services to reduce the need for vulnerable families to resort to negative coping strategies. UNICEF will address humanitarian needs through existing systems, where possible, and incorporate community-based approaches where relevant. UNICEF requires USD 28.3 million to meet critical needs linked to nutrition, social protection and humanitarian cash transfers, education and child protection among the most vulnerable children and families affected by the economic crisis.

title: CTU protest in Jaffna tomorrow
author: Author not found
Content: Making various demands in front of the Northern Province Governor’s Secretariat, the  Sri Lanka Teachers’ Union (CTU) has decided to launch a protest tomorrow (9), Deputy President of the Northern Province Union, Deepan Thileesan said. The protest will be staged after the schools close at 2.00 p.m.  Thileesan, at a media conference held in Jaffna, said they would protest over the irregularities in the Northern Province Education Ministry and the lack of administrative leadership. In December 2021, they had submitted a 100-page complaint, in accordance with the request from the Northern Province Governor, regarding the irregularities in the education sector in the Northern Province. An inquiry committee was appointed for it. The Secretary of the Ministry of Education of the Northern Province has been asked to submit a report on the said investigation, but it has not been submitted as yet, Thileesan said. “Even though it has been almost a year since the complaint was filed, the investigation has not been completed and we have doubts about compilation. The third term has already started but the condition of the Northern Province Ministry of Education and the Northern Province Education Department has reached such a level that the second term examination cannot be held. Over these irregularities, we will advance the protest by presenting various other demands,” he added. Photo and text By T. Pratheepan

title: Covid vaccine certificate requirement waived
author: Author not found
Content: The Health Ministry has waived the requirement to produce a Covid-19 vaccination certificate by persons arriving in Sri Lanka via any airport or seaport. Director General of Health Services, Dr. Asela Gunawardena in a letter on ‘Preventive measures for persons arriving from overseas during the pandemic,’ “removed the requirement to produce the Covid-19 Vaccination Certificate on arrival at any of the airports or seaports from yesterday (7).” In a letter addressed to all Deputy Director Generals, Director Quarantine, Chief Epidemiologist, Coordinator in Charge Covid-19 Operations of Health Ministry, Provincial, Regional Health Directors, Regional Epidemiologists, Medical Officer, Airport/Port Health Offices and Medical Officers of Health (MOHs), Dr. Gunawardena further said the requirement to produce a pre-boarding or on arrival negative Covid-19 test (PCR or RAT) by any persons arriving in the island via any airport or seaport had also been removed. However, if any foreign nationals or tourists tested positive for Covid-19 after arriving in the island, they were to isolate for seven days in either a private hospital, a hotel or place of residence. The cost of treatment or isolation was to be borne by those individuals (foreign nationals or tourists). He said the measures were applicable irrespective of other directives in any previous guidelines, letters or circulars which had been issued. Health sources said the World Health Organisation (WHO) had earlier issued temporary recommendations to states parties (SP) with regard to international traffic following the 13th meeting of the International Health Regulations (IHR) Emergency Committee for Covid -19 held on 13 October. Accordingly, “24 (+1) states parties still required vaccination as a condition for entry” which was not consistent with IHR provisions or current temporary recommendations. 160 SPs were easing or totally lifting restrictions for international travel.  By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: Set aside political agendas for better future
author: Author not found
Content: UNP Chairman, MP Wajira Abeywardana urged Parliamentarians that if Sri Lanka is to strengthen its economy, everyone must set aside their narrow political agendas and reach a national consensus. He also urged the leaders and members of all political parties to join the National Council and join hands to rebuild the country’s collapsed economy and restore normalcy. MP Abeywardana was speaking to the media at Sirikotha about the country’s economic crisis and associated mitigation measures. Budget 2023 has been presented at a critical juncture, he said. “President Ranil Wickremesinghe is looking to create national unity for the future of this country. It should be remembered that if certain political parties and groups are unable to achieve national unity at this time, a national disaster is imminent,” he added. By Naalir Jamaldeen

title: SL makes USD 45,000 from palmyrah product exports
author: Author not found
Content: Palmyrah Development Board (PDB) Chairman Krishantha Pathiraja said Sri Lanka has earned USD 45,000 from the export of palmyrah products. He added that the export of Sri Lankan palmyrah products to France has increased significantly. He said efforts are being made to promote Sri Lankan palmyrah products worldwide, while expressing confidence that the palmyrah industry can be used to address the foreign exchange crisis. Participating in agricultural product exhibitions abroad will help to promote our palmyrah products in foreign countries, the PDB Chairman said. “There is huge potential to earn more income from the export of palmyrah products to European markets,” Pathiraja said. The PDB has developed the palmyrah industry of this country, providing required technical knowhow and proper guidance to those engaging in the industry, Pathiraja added. By Naalir Jamaldeen

title: Title not found
author: Author not found
Content: Date: The Ministry of Power and Energy has decided to introduce paperless bills and receipts to all customers from January 2023. It was also decided to regulate the fixing of street lamps and operating street lamps, outsourced services to be done with existing staff, Power and Energy Minister Kanchana Wijesekera tweeted. Further, work that cannot be completed by the Ceylon Electricity Board (CEB) needs to be done with the assistance of Local Councils, he said. During a meeting held with CEB management, steps taken to reduce expenses and further steps that could be taken to reduce the operating costs of the Ceylon Electricity Board were discussed.  Wijesekera said instructions were also given to hold the ongoing construction work of the CEB’s new headquarters. (TR) Popular

title: Merchandise export earnings decline
author: Author not found
Content: Earnings from merchandise exports declined in October 2022, on a Year-on-Year (YoY) basis, for the first time since March 2022, mainly due to lower earnings from garment exports, Central Bank of Sri Lanka (CBSL) said yesterday. Garment exports have been Sri Lanka’s second largest foreign exchange (FX) earner after remittances since 2009. This resulted in the trade deficit at the end of the first 10 months of the year recording a value of USD 4.4 billion. Consequently, earnings from merchandise exports declined by 11.9 per cent YoY in October 2022, over October 2021, to USD 1,051 million, CBSL said. Though overall merchandise imports declined by 21.2 per cent to USD 1,336 million in October 2022, compared to USD 1,694 million in October 2021, however, the country experienced a trade deficit of USD 285 million in October 2022, CBSL said. Subsequently, the country’s trade deficit in the first 10 months of the year widened to USD 4,389.2 million (USD 4.4 billion), though merchandise exports in the first 10 months of the year grew by 8.9 per cent YoY  to USD 11,031.7 million and imports in the commensurate period fell by 7.3 per cent to USD 15,420.9 million, it said. (PA)
