title: Six suspects granted bail
author: Author not found
Content: Chief Security Officer of the Nallathanni Wildlife Reserve Office, Prabash Karunathileka, said six suspects had been taken into custody by them on charges of being engaged in illegal camping at the Saptha Kanya Forest Reserve in Norton Bridge on 5 December afternoon. He said, the suspects had gone camping without seeking approval from authorities. According to Karunathileka, his officers and Norton Bridge Police had conducted a search operation after relatives reported the campers missing. The suspects were enlarged on bail and ordered to appear at the Hatton District Court on 27 December. By Neeta Pathma Kumari – Norwood

title: Ten black stone quarries closed in Balangoda
author: Author not found
Content: Over ten black stone quarries in Balangoda have been closed due to increases in fuel prices and electricity bills, owners said. Further, due to increases in the prices of gunpowder, ammonia nitrate, service thread, dynamite, and imported cap materials, as well as a lack of water, it has been impossible to keep the work sites operational. Thus, workers were laid off, and nearly 200 persons are unemployed at present. Wasantha Kumara, owner of a quarry in Balangoda, said it is impossible to maintain quarries due to rising electricity bills, rising fuel prices, and a lack of gunpowder. He added that businessmen who run these sites are in dire straits due to a variety of issues, including an increase in employee wages. H. Pemaratne, who worked in a black stone quarry, said he has lost his livelihood. He requested authorities to look into this matter expeditiously. By S. Weerawansa – Kalthota

title: Despite diesel price drop, bus associations say no fare reduction
author: Author not found
Content: A conflict has arisen between private bus owners’ associations on reducing the number of buses in operation on weekends and public holidays. However, they are in agreement when it comes to requesting a fare hike from the Government. Speaking to Ceylon Today, yesterday (6), Lanka Private Bus Owners’ Association, Chairman, Gamunu Wijeratne, noted that they have reduced the number of buses by 50 per cent on weekends and 40 per cent on public holidays. He said that this decision was taken due to the decrease in daily income due to lack of passengers. Wijeratne also stated that though the diesel price has been reduced, they do not plan on reducing bus fares. “Only 1.1 per cent of relief has been provided from the Rs 10 price reduction of fuel. Therefore, they cannot expect us to reduce the bus fares following such small concessions,” he added. He stated that between 35 and 40 per cent of the daily income from buses is spent on fuel and money has to be allocated for maintenance. “The prices of spare parts and service activities have increased three to four fold. Besides, due to the increase in the price of lubricating oil and the increase in the salaries of employees, a situation has been created where it will not be possible to maintain the bus service,” he added. Meanwhile, Anjana Prithyanjith, Secretary of the All Ceylon Private Bus Owners’ Association, said his union does not support this decision and that the passengers will be greatly inconvenienced due to such decisions. He further said that the bus owners are going through huge losses on a daily basis therefore, their association has decided to go for an increase in fares and will discuss it with the government. By Nabiya Vaffoor

title: ‘Most NHSL minor staffers addicted to substances’
author: Author not found
Content: A sizeable proportion of minor employees at the National Hospital, Colombo is under the influence of either ‘Ice,’ marijuana, or some other dangerous substance and there are a large number of absentees from amongst them at the hospital on a daily basis, Deputy Director of the Hospital and President of the Government Medical Officers’ Forum (GMOF), Dr. Rukshan Bellana, alleged yesterday (7). He accused the Government and Police of failing to take action against the dangerous drug mafia operating within one of the country’s primary tertiary care institutions. Although NHSL authorities followed lenient measures during the Covid-19 pandemic with regard to attendance, now the situation has changed. The Hospital was worried that they will not be able to deal with the present situation. Some employees amongst them had found second jobs for which they were being remunerated, he alleged, noting that some of these jobs included drug trafficking, it had resulted in alleged thefts taking place inside hospital wards and the car park. Health staff complained on numerous occasions of parts of their vehicles being stolen while inside the hospital patients lose their belongings. Unfortunately, the authorities also have their hands tied as no action can be taken without incurring the wrath of the trade unions which were allegedly “paid to go on pickets and other forms of trade union action” in the face of disciplinary action being taken against the erring minor employees, the GMOF President accused.   He accused the Police of allegedly turning a blind eye to the situation at NHSL. The Hospital came under the purview of the Maradana and Borella Police stations. The hospital has been unable to bring either of the two law enforcing authorities down to discuss the issue and formulate a control plan due to the lethargic attitude shown by them. The GMOF President lambasted the Government for permitting five per cent of the health staff at the hospital to control and influence 95 per cent of the persons including patients who most often came from the peripheries and had to endure mental pain as well as physical pain as a result.  Meanwhile, responding to allegations, General Secretary of the Joint Health Workers’ Union (JHWU), Ven. Tempitiye Sugathananda Thera said his outfit had discussed the accusations levelled against minor employees of the hospital with the Hospital Director and warned that they would be forced to resort to trade union action against Dr. Bellana who was the Deputy Director. “We have no issues if he in his capacity as a medical administrator took disciplinary action against any of the minor employees engaged in theft, addiction to dangerous drugs or was engaged in the sale of it,” he said. But in this case the Deputy Director of the Hospital was only abusing his power by plucking mobile phones from minor employees and using abusive language, he accused. “Further, dangerous substances arrive in the country either by air or by sea. But none of the minor employees at NHSL have any contact with any of the dealers or anyone in the Air Force or Navy for that matter to be able to even have vague access to any of these substances,” he added. The Ven. Thera said he had been at the NHSL the whole of yesterday (7) and that a motorbike and a three-wheeler had been stolen. The thieves were nabbed and handed over to the Deputy Director. The Thera accused the GMOF President of merely carrying out a media show instead of doing his duty and taking disciplinary action. “It is obvious that he is the cat’s paw for the Government to carry out a coup so that health service employees could be slashed to keep up with the demands of the IMF,” he further said. By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Railway system will be restructured – Bandula
author: Author not found
Content: Although the Railways Department has earned a profit of over Rs 1 billion recently for the first time in its history, it can only cover the cost of fuel, Minister of Transport and Highways Bandula Gunawardana said. When queried during the weekly Cabinet media briefing if there are plans to privatise the Railways Department, he said as Minister of Railways he held discussions with Railway employees about how to run the institution profitably. He also said discussions are underway to convert Sri Lanka Railways into an Authority, similar to the Ports Authority. Furthermore, the Ministry of Transport is mooting plans to restructure the country’s railway tracks by obtaining an Indian Credit Line. Gunawardana said the British railway system, which connects every district in the country, should be restructured. He said the speed limit on railway tracks is between 20 kmph and 30 kmph because the tracks are two to three decades old, resulting in accidents and derailments. He said thus, a credit line will be obtained to restructure these tracks.   By Thameenah Razeek

title: Wildlife Dept gets cash windfall
author: Author not found
Content: The Department of Wildlife Conservation earned record revenue from foreign tourists who arrived in the two luxury cruise ships that recently docked in Sri Lanka. 551 foreign tourists from the ship that arrived on 30 November visited the Yala National Park in 110 vehicles, generating an income of Rs 6.2 million for the day. Further, 86 tourists who arrived in the second cruise ship on 5 December visited the Yala National Park in 18 vehicles, generating a revenue of Rs 981,981. Minister of Wildlife Conservation Mahinda Amaraweera instructed the Department to open more ticket counters to avoid long queues. Amaraweera also instructed the Department that if tourists arriving on luxury cruise ships are to visit the Yala National Park in the future, there has to be coordination with the Ministry of Tourism to ensure it could be organised effectively. (FT)

title: Confirm essential staff, remove surplus
author: Author not found
Content: The Committee on Public Accounts (COPA) has instructed the Western Province Provincial Road Development Authority to look into the possibility of confirming the employment of essential workers and consider removing the excess workers by giving compensation.  It was disclosed there are 556 employees working on daily wage basis and under contract basis as at 31 December 2021, exceeding the number of employees of the approved … staff of the Western Province Provincial Road Development Authority. The committee made these remarks during its meeting to examine the Auditor General’s reports and performance of the Western Provincial Road Development Authority for the years 2018, 2019, and 2020. Dr. Charitha Herath, who chaired the meeting, said although there were a large number of projects in the past period, road development projects have been reduced due to several factors including the dollar crisis. Therefore, if all these employees are hired on a permanent basis, they will have to pay their salaries from the Treasury money. Therefore, COPA members pointed out that it is necessary to look into the confirmation of employment for only the employees required and if there is excess labour, they should be compensated for and considered for removal. Dr. Herath recommended that a report be given to COPA within 3 months setting out the priority list of the number of employees according to requirement as there are only a few projects at the moment. It was disclosed that there are 396 employees on daily wage basis and 160 employees on contract basis. The officials pointed out that these employees are essential employees. It is said that several attempts were made to recruit these employees on a permanent basis and it could not be done due to several factors including changes in policies due to the change of government. These employees were recruited on project basis and were paid from the profits of those projects. It was also discussed that two concrete paving machines and a curb machine worth 6 million which were purchased at a cost of Rs 158 million in 2012 were still lying idle. The two concrete paving machines were used for only 420 hours from 2012 to November 2022 and the curb machine remained idle from 2012 until now. Thus, the officials pointed out that around 2011, road concreting was done on a large-scale and because of this, these machines were purchased in 2012. But after the purchase of these machines, the concrete paving of the roads gradually decreased and therefore the usefulness of these machines decreased. Therefore, they stated that given the present context, one of the two machines is sufficient for them. Furthermore, the Secretary to the Ministry indicated that a programme is presently being carried out with the intervention of the ministry regarding the use of these machines. Therefore, it will be used in the future. Accordingly, it was recommended to produce a report to COPA within 3 months pertaining to the next step. Furthermore, there was a discussion about the recruitment of two officers from October 2020 for a position called project coordination position, which is not in the approved staff of the authority, and about the vehicle rental and fuel expenses given to them. The officials pointed out that the officers are being recruited for special projects and their services will be terminated when the project is completed. Accordingly, COPA recommended giving a report on this regard within a month. Apart from the above, the misplacement of 6 vehicles belonging to the authority which is 20 years old, a contractor obtaining asphalt on credit basis in 2012 and 2013 and recovering the amount, along with several other matters were discussed at the Committee meeting. State Ministers Lasantha Alagiyawanna, Prasanna Ranaweera, Diana Gamage, MPs Tissa Attanayake, J.C. Alawathuwala, Dr. Sudarshani Fernandopulle, Hector Appuhamy, Ashok Abeysinghe, Weerasumana Weerasinghe, Sarath Weerasekera, and Major Pradeep Undugoda were present at the Committee meeting.

title: Set up new College of Education in Trinco – Imran
author: Author not found
Content: Samagi Jana Balawegaya (SJB) Trincomalee District MP M. Imran urged President Ranil Wickremesinghe and the relevant authorities to consider setting up a new National College of Education in Trincomalee District. This will facilitate a large number of Sinhala and Tamil medium students who will enter the teaching profession in the future, MP Imran said. MP Imran said this during a discussion with educationists and teachers in Kinniya on Sunday (4). “The main reason why Trincomalee District is seen as an educationally backward district is the shortage of teachers. If this issue is to be resolved, another college of education must be set up in the Trincomalee District as soon as possible. Sinhala medium schools in Morawala, Gomarankadawala, and Padavi Sripura will benefit immensely once this proposal is implemented,” MP Imran said. Trincomalee Town and Gravets Divisional Secretary have offered a 15-acre stretch in Trincomalee Sardharura area to set up the proposed College of Education. The subject Minister must take necessary action to set up this college as soon as possible. Taking this matter into consideration, new education zones must be established for Kuchchaveli and Mullipothana, Imran said. Muslim schools in Thambalagamuwa Divisional Secretariat Division have been affiliated with Kinniya Zonal Education Office while affiliating the Tamil and Sinhala schools with Trincomalee and Kantale zonal offices. Mullipothana Education Zone must be established in the manner of facilitating these schools. Once this zone is established, 30 schools including 16 Muslim schools, six Sinhala schools, and eight Tamil schools in the region will benefit, MP Imran added. By Naalir Jamaldeen

title: Don’t betray our fishermen
author: Author not found
Content: Deputy Chairman of Committees, Chairman of Jaffna District Development Committee, Vice Secretary and Jaffna District Leader of SLFP Angajan Ramanathan, said no one in the North opposed the sea cucumber industry, but cautioned against concentrating on mortgaging the sea and the land to outsiders for commercial purposes without considering the welfare of fishermen. Don’t connect with people who haven’t worked in the fisheries industry just to make money, hinted the MP. He said, “Instead of working with people who have no connection at all to the fishing trade, we should provide technical and commercial assistance to our fishermen who have a long history with the sea and the industry.” While addressing the group discussion regarding agriculture, fisheries, and irrigation sectors held yesterday (6), the MP further noted that self-sustenance of the country depends on not betraying the people who have been protecting the resources of the country for generations and helped build the economy for a long time, he added. “I want to tell the President of this country that such a short-term popular project will only give short-term income.” In this way, seafood needs of the local people can be met and the fishermen can get export profits. Please do not mortgage our marine resources in order for someone to profit entirely, lamented the MP. According to the MP, fishermen are concerned that the Ministry of Fisheries and institutions such as the National Aquaculture Development Authority (NAQDA), which are supposed to work with them, are working against them. Fifty years ago, local traders in Jaffna caught, processed, and traded natural sea cucumbers without harming the marine environment or fishermen. However, they are in a trade of catching baby sea cucumbers, setting up farms, and artificially breeding them. If this practice is allowed to continue, it has the potential to deplete the natural resources available to fishermen, he said. He also added that fishermen of Ilavankudah, in Kiranji area have been protesting continuously for 70 days. The Jaffna District Seafood Co-operative Societies Federation is fighting to remove the 50-acre sea cucumber farm set up in Parutthithivu near Analaithivu Island. “But cases have been filed against those who are protesting and they are falsifying the cases against the fishermen who are fighting for their livelihood rights and taking revenge is the highest level of politics that is continuing to this date,” he added. He said the Government should probe the sea cucumber issue. “Our people do not eat sea cucumber, but catching the fish they eat poses significant challenges, such as Indian trawlers invading our sea and destroying their livelihood, and now the sea cucumber business is eating into the profits of Northern fishermen,” he added. He added that the fishermen had been duped once again. Because of the dollars generated by sea cucumber exports, people are being forced to import even the fish they eat and the fishermen are polarised over this, he said. By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: Cabinet Decisions
author: Author not found
Content: National Environmental Action Plan Cabinet approved the National Environmental Policy on 20 June. Accordingly, the Ministry of Environment has prepared the National Environmental Action Plan for the period of 2022-2030 with the contribution of all relevant parties by paying attention to environmental challenges in the twenty first century as well as considering the Sustainable Development Goals of the UN to implement the National Environmental Policy. Cabinet approved the resolution presented by the Minister of Environment to implement the said action plan, to take policy decisions at national level in that connection and to establish the consolidated environment and development policy committee chaired by the President’s Secretary to monitor the same. Sri Lanka Navy Hydrographic Service Discussions were held at the Cabinet meeting on 5 September about the proposal to entrust the Sri Lanka Navy with the naval and maritime services in local waters and economic zone of Sri Lanka and a sub-committee was appointed with the Minister of Ports, Shipping and Aviation as the head to submit recommendations by studying further facts about the said proposal. Cabinet approved the proposal presented by the President as the Minister of Defence to entrust the naval and maritime activities to Sri Lanka Navy in local waters and economic zone of Sri Lanka as a non-naval duty as per the recommendation of the above sub-committee and to set up a National Maritime Office so that all institutions related to this subject can collaborate. Parliamentary Budget Office A preliminary Bill to set up the Parliamentary Budget Office was presented by the President at the Cabinet meeting on 31 October. It was decided to forward the draft Bill to all party leaders and get their opinions. Accordingly, the Prime Minister has discussed the relevant preliminary Bill with party leaders and the ideas presented in the discussion were submitted for Cabinet approval. Accordingly, Cabinet decided to instruct the Legal Draftsman to prepare a Bill based on the preliminary Bill considering the comments made. Australian Volunteers Cooperation Programme 2022-2027 The Australian Volunteers Cooperation Programme funded by the Australian Government is in operation in over 26 countries. Grants are made under the programme to make a change through actions carried out at the local level and to assist partner organisations in achieving the Sustainable Development Goals. A memorandum of understanding was signed in 2017 to implement this programme in Sri Lanka. The period of that MoU has now ended. As such, Cabinet approved the proposal presented by the President in his capacity as the Minister of Finance, Economic Stabilisation and National Policies to sign an affiliated agreement to implement the said programme for another 5 years in the country. MoU on immigration between SL-Maldives In the course of bilateral relations between Sri Lanka and the Maldives, it has been proposed to sign a Memorandum of Understanding on cooperation in immigration matters between the two countries. Accordingly, Cabinet approved the proposal presented by the Minister of Public Security to enter into a Memorandum of Understanding to strengthen cooperation in immigration matters between the two countries to achieve the objectives of assisting in frontier control management for mutual benefit, providing mutual facilities for capacity building in HR systems and technology sectors, exchanging training facilities of immigration officials, preventing international crimes such as informal migration, human trafficking and trading human beings and promoting cooperation related to the problems of blacklisted travellers. (TR)

title: Highways Ministry owes contractors Rs 80B – Bandula
author: Author not found
Content: The Ministry of Highways is struggling to pay over Rs 80 billion to road construction contractors. According to Cabinet Spokesman Bandula Gunawardana, those payments are being made in instalments, which is difficult to bear at the moment. He said there have been reports that those roads are damaged and he does not have the funds to repair the broken roads despite being the Minister of Highways. Gunawardana said at the weekly Cabinet media briefing that even if people demand that the roads be repaired, the contractors will not budge without payment. “This is not our problem. This is public property. Roads should be repaired when they crack. For that, the tax money collected from the public should be managed properly. The tax money collected from the people is used to pay State employees’ salaries, pensions, and interest. It is the responsibility of every political party to come up with a system to end this norm,” he said. By Thameenah Razeek

title: KANCHANA WARNS OF 6-8 HOUR POWER CUTS
author: Author not found
Content: Minister of Power and Energy Kanchana Wijesekera warned the country will have to face power cuts of six to eight hours per day next year if the proposed electricity tariff hike is not approved. Minister Wijesekera also rejected claims made by the Chairman of the Public Utilities Commission of Sri Lanka (PUCSL) that the proposed electricity tariff hike is to cover previous losses of the Ceylon Electricity Board (CEB) over the past years. Making a special statement in Parliament yesterday (6), Wijesekera explained no proposals have been submitted to Cabinet to recover previous losses and the only proposal that was made was to revise electricity tariffs to match the power generation costs. The Minister said the report presented to Cabinet only outlines the losses incurred by the CEB over the past years and the financial assistance offered by the Treasury to help the CEB. Wijesekera emphasised that he has proposed electricity tariff hikes under two stages next year to ensure uninterrupted power supply. “We requested the CEB to provide a continuous power supply in 2023 and the CEB pointed out that there might be a drought next year. They said there might be reduction in rain and that would lead to the reduction in hydropower generation,” he said. Therefore, CEB calculated that Rs 59.60 will be required for the generation of one power unit and over 17,000 GW in total is required for next year, the Minister said. He also stressed PUCSL has not approved the tariff revision requested by the CEB and the tariff was revised last August after a period of nine years. He further said it is the responsibility of the PUCSL to revise tariffs yearly, however, they had not followed protocol. The Minister said if the ministry does not receive the necessary money to purchase fuel and coal the country can expect power cuts of six to eight hours next year. By Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: Large crowds at AIMS Int’l book sale, carnival
author: Author not found
Content: A large number of parents attended AIMS International School’s ‘Book Sale and Food Carnival’ at the AIMS  grounds last Friday. The programme, chaired by its Director Studies M. A. Thasreef, was attended by Ampara District Additional Secretary V. Jegatheeswaran who was the Chief Guest. District Disaster Management Centre Deputy Director M.A.C. Riyas, Former Diplomat of the Sri Lanka Foreign Services M. A. Abdul Rasheed, and Amana Bank Akkaraiapttu Manager Zaheer Ahamed were Guests of Honor. The guests were greeted at the AIMS International School’s entrance and led in a procession flanked by ‘Polladi’ to the venue of the Book Sale, where the area’s leading book shops displayed reading material, books related to children, short stories, songs, and quizzes. Mothers were more interested in buying the books of their choice. The ‘Crazy Hat Festival,’ which was organised as part of the programme in the morning, was one of the highlights of the first day of the event. The goal of this event is for AIMS students to dress up as famous childhood cartoon characters such as Robin Hood, Harry Potter, Barbie Girl, and so on. BY M.A.P. Deen – Ampara

title: Merchandise export earnings decline
author: Author not found
Content: Earnings from merchandise exports declined in October 2022, on a Year-on-Year (YoY) basis, for the first time since March 2022, mainly due to lower earnings from garments exports, Central Bank of Sri Lanka (CBSL) said yesterday. Garment exports have been Sri Lanka’s second largest foreign exchange (FX) earner after remittances since 2009. This resulted in the trade deficit at the end of the first 10 months of the year recording a value of USD 4.4 billion. Consequently, earnings from merchandise exports declined by 11.9 per cent YoY in October 2022, over October 2021, to USD 1,051 million, CBSL said. Though overall merchandise imports declined by 21.2 per cent to USD 1,336 million in October 2022, compared to USD 1,694 million in October 2021, however, the country experienced a trade deficit of USD 285 million in October 2022, CBSL said. Subsequently, the country’s trade deficit in the first 10 months of the year widened to USD 4,389.2 million (USD 4.4 billion), though merchandise exports in the first 10 months of the year grew by 8.9 per cent YoY  to USD 11,031.7 million and imports in the commensurate period fell by 7.3 per cent to USD 15,420.9 million, it said. (PA)

title: Highways Ministry owes contractors Rs 80B – Bandula
author: Author not found
Content: The Ministry of Highways is struggling to pay over Rs 80 billion to road construction contractors. According to Cabinet Spokesman Bandula Gunawardana, those payments are being made in instalments, which is difficult to bear at the moment. He said there have been reports that those roads are damaged and he does not have the funds to repair the broken roads despite being the Minister of Highways. Gunawardana said at the weekly Cabinet media briefing that even if people demand that the roads be repaired, the contractors will not budge without payment. “This is not our problem. This is public property. Roads should be repaired when they crack. For that, the tax money collected from the public should be managed properly. The tax money collected from the people is used to pay State employees’ salaries, pensions, and interest. It is the responsibility of every political party to come up with a system to end this norm,” he said. By Thameenah Razeek

title: KANCHANA WARNS OF 6-8 HOUR POWER CUTS
author: Author not found
Content: Minister of Power and Energy Kanchana Wijesekera warned the country will have to face power cuts of six to eight hours per day next year if the proposed electricity tariff hike is not approved. Minister Wijesekera also rejected claims made by the Chairman of the Public Utilities Commission of Sri Lanka (PUCSL) that the proposed electricity tariff hike is to cover previous losses of the Ceylon Electricity Board (CEB) over the past years. Making a special statement in Parliament yesterday (6), Wijesekera explained no proposals have been submitted to Cabinet to recover previous losses and the only proposal that was made was to revise electricity tariffs to match the power generation costs. The Minister said the report presented to Cabinet only outlines the losses incurred by the CEB over the past years and the financial assistance offered by the Treasury to help the CEB. Wijesekera emphasised that he has proposed electricity tariff hikes under two stages next year to ensure uninterrupted power supply. “We requested the CEB to provide a continuous power supply in 2023 and the CEB pointed out that there might be a drought next year. They said there might be reduction in rain and that would lead to the reduction in hydropower generation,” he said. Therefore, CEB calculated that Rs 59.60 will be required for the generation of one power unit and over 17,000 GW in total is required for next year, the Minister said. He also stressed PUCSL has not approved the tariff revision requested by the CEB and the tariff was revised last August after a period of nine years. He further said it is the responsibility of the PUCSL to revise tariffs yearly, however, they had not followed protocol. The Minister said if the ministry does not receive the necessary money to purchase fuel and coal the country can expect power cuts of six to eight hours next year. By Aloka Kasturiarachchi

Riyas, Former Diplomat of the Sri Lanka Foreign Services M. A. Abdul Rasheed, and Amana Bank Akkaraiapttu Manager Zaheer Ahamed were Guests of Honor. title: Merchandise export earnings decline
author: Author not found
Content: Earnings from merchandise exports declined in October 2022, on a Year-on-Year (YoY) basis, for the first time since March 2022, mainly due to lower earnings from garments exports, Central Bank of Sri Lanka (CBSL) said yesterday. Garment exports have been Sri Lanka’s second largest foreign exchange (FX) earner after remittances since 2009. This resulted in the trade deficit at the end of the first 10 months of the year recording a value of USD 4.4 billion. Consequently, earnings from merchandise exports declined by 11.9 per cent YoY in October 2022, over October 2021, to USD 1,051 million, CBSL said. Though overall merchandise imports declined by 21.2 per cent to USD 1,336 million in October 2022, compared to USD 1,694 million in October 2021, however, the country experienced a trade deficit of USD 285 million in October 2022, CBSL said. Subsequently, the country’s trade deficit in the first 10 months of the year widened to USD 4,389.2 million (USD 4.4 billion), though merchandise exports in the first 10 months of the year grew by 8.9 per cent YoY  to USD 11,031.7 million and imports in the commensurate period fell by 7.3 per cent to USD 15,420.9 million, it said. (PA)

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Don’t betray our fishermen
author: Author not found
Content: Deputy Chairman of Committees, Chairman of Jaffna District Development Committee, Vice Secretary and Jaffna District Leader of SLFP Angajan Ramanathan, said no one in the North opposed the sea cucumber industry, but cautioned against concentrating on mortgaging the sea and the land to outsiders for commercial purposes without considering the welfare of fishermen. Don’t connect with people who haven’t worked in the fisheries industry just to make money, hinted the MP. He said, “Instead of working with people who have no connection at all to the fishing trade, we should provide technical and commercial assistance to our fishermen who have a long history with the sea and the industry.” While addressing the group discussion regarding agriculture, fisheries, and irrigation sectors held yesterday (6), the MP further noted that self-sustenance of the country depends on not betraying the people who have been protecting the resources of the country for generations and helped build the economy for a long time, he added. “I want to tell the President of this country that such a short-term popular project will only give short-term income.” In this way, seafood needs of the local people can be met and the fishermen can get export profits. Please do not mortgage our marine resources in order for someone to profit entirely, lamented the MP. According to the MP, fishermen are concerned that the Ministry of Fisheries and institutions such as the National Aquaculture Development Authority (NAQDA), which are supposed to work with them, are working against them. Fifty years ago, local traders in Jaffna caught, processed, and traded natural sea cucumbers without harming the marine environment or fishermen. However, they are in a trade of catching baby sea cucumbers, setting up farms, and artificially breeding them. If this practice is allowed to continue, it has the potential to deplete the natural resources available to fishermen, he said. He also added that fishermen of Ilavankudah, in Kiranji area have been protesting continuously for 70 days. The Jaffna District Seafood Co-operative Societies Federation is fighting to remove the 50-acre sea cucumber farm set up in Parutthithivu near Analaithivu Island. “But cases have been filed against those who are protesting and they are falsifying the cases against the fishermen who are fighting for their livelihood rights and taking revenge is the highest level of politics that is continuing to this date,” he added. He said the Government should probe the sea cucumber issue. “Our people do not eat sea cucumber, but catching the fish they eat poses significant challenges, such as Indian trawlers invading our sea and destroying their livelihood, and now the sea cucumber business is eating into the profits of Northern fishermen,” he added. He added that the fishermen had been duped once again. Because of the dollars generated by sea cucumber exports, people are being forced to import even the fish they eat and the fishermen are polarised over this, he said. By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

Parliamentary Budget Office A preliminary Bill to set up the Parliamentary Budget Office was presented by the President at the Cabinet meeting on 31 October. It was decided to forward the draft Bill to all party leaders and get their opinions. Accordingly, the Prime Minister has discussed the relevant preliminary Bill with party leaders and the ideas presented in the discussion were submitted for Cabinet approval. Accordingly, Cabinet decided to instruct the Legal Draftsman to prepare a Bill based on the preliminary Bill considering the comments made. Australian Volunteers Cooperation Programme 2022-2027 The Australian Volunteers Cooperation Programme funded by the Australian Government is in operation in over 26 countries. Grants are made under the programme to make a change through actions carried out at the local level and to assist partner organisations in achieving the Sustainable Development Goals. A memorandum of understanding was signed in 2017 to implement this programme in Sri Lanka. The period of that MoU has now ended. As such, Cabinet approved the proposal presented by the President in his capacity as the Minister of Finance, Economic Stabilisation and National Policies to sign an affiliated agreement to implement the said programme for another 5 years in the country. MoU on immigration between SL-Maldives In the course of bilateral relations between Sri Lanka and the Maldives, it has been proposed to sign a Memorandum of Understanding on cooperation in immigration matters between the two countries. Accordingly, Cabinet approved the proposal presented by the Minister of Public Security to enter into a Memorandum of Understanding to strengthen cooperation in immigration matters between the two countries to achieve the objectives of assisting in frontier control management for mutual benefit, providing mutual facilities for capacity building in HR systems and technology sectors, exchanging training facilities of immigration officials, preventing international crimes such as informal migration, human trafficking and trading human beings and promoting cooperation related to the problems of blacklisted travellers. (TR)

title: Highways Ministry owes contractors Rs 80B – Bandula
author: Author not found
Content: The Ministry of Highways is struggling to pay over Rs 80 billion to road construction contractors. According to Cabinet Spokesman Bandula Gunawardana, those payments are being made in instalments, which is difficult to bear at the moment. He said there have been reports that those roads are damaged and he does not have the funds to repair the broken roads despite being the Minister of Highways. Gunawardana said at the weekly Cabinet media briefing that even if people demand that the roads be repaired, the contractors will not budge without payment. “This is not our problem. This is public property. Roads should be repaired when they crack. For that, the tax money collected from the public should be managed properly. The tax money collected from the people is used to pay State employees’ salaries, pensions, and interest. It is the responsibility of every political party to come up with a system to end this norm,” he said. By Thameenah Razeek

title: KANCHANA WARNS OF 6-8 HOUR POWER CUTS
author: Author not found
Content: Minister of Power and Energy Kanchana Wijesekera warned the country will have to face power cuts of six to eight hours per day next year if the proposed electricity tariff hike is not approved. Minister Wijesekera also rejected claims made by the Chairman of the Public Utilities Commission of Sri Lanka (PUCSL) that the proposed electricity tariff hike is to cover previous losses of the Ceylon Electricity Board (CEB) over the past years. Making a special statement in Parliament yesterday (6), Wijesekera explained no proposals have been submitted to Cabinet to recover previous losses and the only proposal that was made was to revise electricity tariffs to match the power generation costs. The Minister said the report presented to Cabinet only outlines the losses incurred by the CEB over the past years and the financial assistance offered by the Treasury to help the CEB. Wijesekera emphasised that he has proposed electricity tariff hikes under two stages next year to ensure uninterrupted power supply. “We requested the CEB to provide a continuous power supply in 2023 and the CEB pointed out that there might be a drought next year. They said there might be reduction in rain and that would lead to the reduction in hydropower generation,” he said. Therefore, CEB calculated that Rs 59.60 will be required for the generation of one power unit and over 17,000 GW in total is required for next year, the Minister said. He also stressed PUCSL has not approved the tariff revision requested by the CEB and the tariff was revised last August after a period of nine years. He further said it is the responsibility of the PUCSL to revise tariffs yearly, however, they had not followed protocol. The Minister said if the ministry does not receive the necessary money to purchase fuel and coal the country can expect power cuts of six to eight hours next year. By Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: Police Dog Shaggy catches murder suspect
author: Author not found
Content: A 46-year-old person, who murdered his younger brother over a paddy field dispute, was arrested after the K9 dog ‘Shaggy’, attached to Hasalaka Police Kennel Unit tracked him to a house in Dikpitiya. According to Police, the victim’s wife had lodged a complaint on 4 December about the disappearance of the 44-year-old, who went to tend for the cattle. Following the complaint, Diwulapitiya Police had conducted an investigation and recovered the deceased’s body with the help of the villagers on 5 December.   The body was found in a forest in Dikpitiya and Police also seized a sharp weapon and a rock near the crime scene. Police then had conducted investigations to arrest the suspect with the help of the K9 dog Shaggy. Accordingly, Shaggy had gone to the suspect’s house and entered his room. Shaggy had also gone out of the house and sniffed the suspect’s washed clothes. Thus, the suspect was arrested and was identified as the elder brother of the victim. According to the Police the suspect and the victim had a long-standing dispute over a paddy field and the murder was committed due to that dispute. BY Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: Don’t overburden consumers – Ven. Ihalawatte Gunawansa Thera
author: Author not found
Content: Convener of the Sabaragamuwa Hetak Organisation, Ven. Ihalawatte Gunawansa Thera stressed the CEB should not unjustly raise electricity tariffs to cover up fraud and corruption at the organisation. The Ven. Thera said, the CEB should do its best to curtail large-scale fraud and corruption of its own officers rather than further burdening the already struggling consumers. The Thera said this during an event held at the Ratnapura Buddhist Centre recently. By K.A.S. Piyathilaka – Kuruvita

title: Court allows CID take over probe
author: Author not found
Content: Colombo Chief Magistrate Nandana Amerasinghe yesterday, granted approval to the CID, to conduct a probe into the theft of gold items, valued at Rs 10 million, which had been stored in the Court’s Productions Room. The Chief Magistrate gave his approval, following a request made to him by Keselwatta Police, who sought to transfer the probe to the CID. OIC of the Keselwatta Police, Chief Inspector Bamunusinghe, stated that they had commenced initial inquiries into the incident following lodged by the Registrar of the Colombo Chief Magistrate’s Court. The OIC stated that as per the complaint, 48.5 sovereigns of gold items, weighing 388.43 g, which had been kept in the Court Productions Room No.4, had been taken away having submitted fake documents to Court. According to the complaint, a Constable attached to the CID had removed the gold items from the Court Productions Room, having furnished bogus documents to Court, on the pretext of submitting it to the National Gem and Jewellery Authority. These details had come to light, when perusing documents where an order had been issued by the Court, concerning gold items weighing 79 sovereigns, which had been ordered to be released to its owner, related to a lawsuit concerning the Maligawatta Police. The complaint had further mentioned that an individual posing as a CID Constable, had also removed a few other Court Productions from the Borella Police Station too on 23 November, after having produced fake documents to Court. Keselwatta Police informed Chief Magistrate Amerasinghe, that the theft had been brought to the notice of the Court Registrar, by the temporary guard of the Court Productions Room Mohammad Niyaz, after which the Registrar had lodged the complaint with the Police. They added that following initial inquiries conducted into the theft, it had come to light that the Provisions contained in Sections 402, 454 and 386 of the Penal Code, had been flouted and hence they urged the Court, to hand over the entire probe of the case to the CID.   By Hansi Nanayakkara

title: U.S. donates fertiliser for free distribution
author: Author not found
Content: The United States of America officially handed over 9,300 tonnes of urea fertiliser, to the Ministry of Agriculture, to be distributed among more than 193,000 smallholder paddy farmers in the Jaffna, Mullaitivu, Mannar, Vavuniya, Anuradhapura, Trincomalee, Batticaloa and Monaragala Districts. The fertiliser, procured by FAO, with funding from the US Agency for International Development (USAID), is the first shipment of USAID-supported fertiliser assistance, with additional supplies anticipated in the coming months that will reach close to one million farmers across the country.  “This fertiliser, provided by the American people, will help Sri Lankan farmers to keep countless Sri Lankan families fed in the months ahead,” said US Ambassador to Sri Lanka Julie Chung, speaking at the handing over held at the Colombo Port. “I know that fertiliser alone will not meet all of Sri Lanka’s needs, but this assistance is just one aspect of the United States’ much greater investment in and support for the people and Government of Sri Lanka at this challenging time. In total, we’ve announced over $240 million in new assistance and additional loans for small businesses over the last year, – and we’ll keep at it. Assistance like today’s fertiliser demonstrates America’s goodwill and true commitment to the people of Sri Lanka.” Minister of Agriculture, Mahinda Amaraweera said Sri Lankan paddy farmers are capable of feeding the country, and we are working to ensure that they have the inputs needed to support their livelihood and strengthen the food security of the country. “We thank the US Government and the FAO for their support in ensuring that vulnerable farmers receive essential fertiliser free of charge,” he said The United States, through USAID, has provided $46 million in funding to procure essential fertiliser to increase paddy production and avert a food crisis – a portion of which arrived yesterday. This funding will also provide cash assistance to small-holder farmers who have suffered due to low yields over the last two agricultural seasons and on account of the prevailing economic crisis. USAID and its partners have mechanisms in place to monitor and evaluate their work, ensuring that assistance reaches its intended recipients and benefits the vulnerable farming households.    “We are delivering on a commitment we made to reach small-holder paddy farmers with much-needed fertiliser during the planting season to increase their yield and harvests. This is part of our support to Sri Lankans during this complex emergency to ensure they lead healthier and more productive lives,” said Änjali Kaur, USAID’s Deputy Assistant Administrator of the Asia Bureau who is currently visiting Sri Lanka. “At FAO, we believe that saving livelihoods saves lives. The 9,300 tonnes of Urea, procured through USAID, will ensure smallholder farmers take to productive agriculture practices and are able to meet their food and nutrition requirements in these extremely difficult days the country faces. We thank the US Government for its support in this endeavour and look forward to working with USAID in taking Sri Lankan agriculture forward,” stated Vimlendra Sharan, Country Director of FAO.  Today’s handing over ceremony was attended by the United States Ambassador to Sri Lanka, Julie Chung; Sri Lanka’s Minister of Agriculture Mahinda Amaraweera, USAID’s Deputy Assistant Administrator for Asia, Anjali Kaur; FAO Representative for Sri Lanka and the Maldives, Vimlendra Sharan and USAID Mission Director for Sri Lanka and Maldives, Gabriel Grau.

title: Sirisena denies expenses news
author: Author not found
Content: Former President Maithripala Sirisena denied the news circulating in print and electronic media which stated that 57 per cent of the President’s Expenditure Head had been spent on his personal staff. Raising a privilege matter in Parliament yesterday (5) the former President said the money spent on national level projects, implemented by him, during his presidency, has been miscalculated. Sirisena emphasised that the salaries of the officials who were appointed to the relevant projects have also been calculated. He said, he initiated seven projects such as National Drug Prevention Programme, National Environment Programme, National Kidney Disease Prevention and Control Campaign, Smart Sri Lanka Programme, Save the Children Programme to save abused children, Prevention of Violence Against Women Programme and Grama Shakti Programme. He claimed that officers were recruited from other government agencies and also doctors and engineers were recruited for this programme. “This amount is shown along with the salaries of the officials appointed for these projects. This is completely false news. I do not need an investigation for this. I only request to correct the wrong news,” he said. BY Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: AG tells Court Shani will be given Police protection
author: Author not found
Content: The Attorney General yesterday (5), informed Court of Appeal that three Police officers will be deployed for the security of former Director of the Criminal Investigation Department, SSP Shani Abeysekara, due to the alleged threats to life faced by the latter. This was when the Writ Application filed by Abeysekara, seeking an order to be issued to the Inspector General of Police to enhance the security provided to him, on the basis that he and his family has been receiving threats to life was taken before Court of Appeal Judges Dhammika Ganepola and Sobitha Rajakaruna. Additional Solicitor General Rohantha Abeysuriya, on behalf of the Attorney General informed Courts thereby that three Police officers will be deployed for the protection of Abeysekara and his residence. The Lawyer appearing on behalf of Abeysekara informed Court that if such statement is not complied with, further actions will have to be initiated in the Supreme Court. The Writ Application was set to be taken up for further hearing on 15 January. BY Faadhila Thassim

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Nineteen hospitalised as bus topples
author: Author not found
Content: Nineteen persons, including an infant, were admitted to the Kilinochchi Hospital after a private bus, they were travelling in toppled on the Kandy – Jaffna A9 road yesterday (5). According to the Police the bus travelling from Colombo to Jaffna had collided with a cow causing the driver to lose control and the bus had toppled on to its side. Eleven 11 men, seven women and an 18- month-old child were admitted to the hospital. The driver and the conductor were arrested and Kilinochchi Police are conducting investigations into the accident. BY Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: Ministry to revoke studentships of 54
author: Author not found
Content: Chief Commissioner of National Colleges of Education, Ranjith Chandrasekara, said the Education Ministry has decided to revoke the studentships of the 54 students involved in the recent clash at the Ruhuna National College of Education. The Ministry of Education said in a statement that, in addition to the disciplinary investigation being conducted by the Ruhunu College of Education, a separate investigation will be conducted under the supervision of an Additional Secretary of the Ministry of Education. “The Ministry of Education has been paying close attention to the recent student clash at Ruhunu College of Education,” it said. Chandrasekara said, the Ministry of Education will take all possible measures to ensure the students’ discipline at the National Colleges of Education.  (TR)

title: Euro 1.2M grant from France to fight violence against women
author: Author not found
Content: The French Embassy in Sri Lanka yesterday announced a grant of euro 1.2 million grant to Sri Lanka for the fight against gender-based violence. Up to 40 per cent of Sri Lankan women are victims of gender-based violence, it said. This grant will be distributed among non-Government organizations (NGOs) promoting ‘anti-gender-based violence’, a French Embassy spokesperson, who didn’t want to be named, told this newspaper. Though the Sri Lankan Constitution prohibits discrimination on the basis of gender and the Women’s Charter obligates the State to combat violence against women, however, with soaring economic pressures due to the current crisis, women and girls are at further risk of gender-based violence and local district officials report such an increase despite their limited means to monitor, the Embassy further said. This grant coincides with the internationally sponsored ‘16 days of activism against gender-based violence’, which began on 25 November and ends on Saturday (10 December). In this connection, the French Agency for Development (AFD), the overseas development arm of the French Government, will today (6) gather Sri Lankan feminist organisations and development partners to announce the upcoming support fund for feminist organisations in Colombo, the Embassy said. In addition to announcing the fund, the floor will be open to feminist organisations in Sri Lanka to highlight their actions and needs and to raise awareness of ongoing gender-based violence in the country,  where up to 40 per cent of women indicate being victims in their lifetime, it added. (PA)

title: CID tells Court probe launched
author: Author not found
Content: The CID yesterday informed Colombo Chief Magistrate Nandana Amerasinghe that they had launched a probe into the illegal acquisition of 10 containers of dhal sans payment of cash for them, along with the misappropriation of Australian Dollars 243,610 and the criminal use and misappropriation of machinery and equipment worth Rs 210 million. The CID told the Chief Magistrate, that they had begun a probe into a complaint, lodged on 23 November, by Manoj Rajaratne, a resident of No. 7 Melbourne, Victoria, Australia. They stated that as per the complaint, the plaintiff had been attached to a dhal exporting firm, since 20 January two years ago. The plaintiff had stated in his complaint, that the dhal so exported had been purchased by a firm in Sri Lanka and that initially the firm, had bought 10 such containers after payment of cash. However, the plaintiff had mentioned that after release of 10 dhal containers from the Sri Lanka Ports Authority, to date, the cash had not been paid for the stock in question. The plaintiff had also stated, that he had begun a factory and store at Piliyandala and that the Directors of that factory and store had criminally misused and misappropriated equipment and machinery, amounting to Rs 210 million, without informing him. Taking the submissions into perusal, the Chief Magistrate, ordered the CID to expedite the probe into the case and file a progress report at the next hearing. By Hansi Nanayakkara

title: Over 11,000 in South fail Maths
author: Author not found
Content: A report released by the Department of Examinations has revealed that 11,033 students who had sat for the 2021 G.C.E. Ordinary Level Examination, from the Southern Province, had failed in mathematics. According to Examinations Department, a total of 39,415 students had taken the said subject and 28,382 had passed in mathematics. BY Kamal Wijehewa – Galle

title: Doctors slam Health Minister’s claims
author: Author not found
Content: Medical Specialists vehemently condemned Health Minister Keheliya Rambukwella’s Parliamentary speech about doctors leaving the country, warning that they would remain united in combating all challenges that the Government and his Ministry would do to “humiliate, harass and defame Sri Lankan doctors.” In a letter signed by the President and Secretary of the Association of Medical Specialists (AMS), Drs. LakKumar Fernando and R. Gnanasekeram yesterday (5), they urged President Ranil Wickramesinghe and the government to seriously review the alleged measures taken to prevent medical practitioners from leaving the country. The duo alleged that in his speech on 29 November 2022, Minister Rambukwella had said that the Government was to request foreign diplomatic missions to refrain from issuing visas to doctors in the State service, who were attempting to leave the country for employment purposes sans approved leave. “The exodus of all categories of State health services became inevitable with the current economic crisis,” they said observing that their outfit agreed that any government employee leaving the country without approval was in violation of the Establishments Code. It needs to be dealt with accordingly by serving the particular employee with a vacation of post and recovering the bond money, if there was any. Lashing out, Drs Fernando and Gnanasekeram alleged that the Health Minister’s statement implied that the government was purportedly targeting only medical specialists leaving aside many other health professionals, which “violated the fundamental right to equality provided by Article 12 of the Constitution of Democratic Socialist Republic of Sri Lanka.”  His statement also violated article 14(1) (h) and 14(1) (i) of the Constitution which guaranteed freedom of movement and freedom of returning to Sri Lanka to all citizens, they accused. They urged the Health Minister to streamline and attend to any foreign leave and resignation approval processes without undue delay, rather than humiliating and harassing the medical specialists.  “We noted that the Minister also stated that among other steps to discourage medical staff leaving the country without authorisation, the airport will also be informed not to allow them to leave the country, if they do not have approved leave. It is deeply shocking that the government was attempting to defame medical practitioners like “terrorists and criminals at airports and foreign missions.” The duo lashed out.  They accused the Minister of also having   said that the licences (registrations) given to doctors by the Sri Lanka Medical Council (SLMC) would be cancelled. The duo said that it amounted to an arbitrary usurpation of the authority of the SLMC which looked after patient welfare with equitable medical governance. The Minister also warned at the time that doctors who leave the country without approved leave would be blacklisted. The AMS consider these overwhelming reactions as atrocious and devastating acts against the reputation of Sri Lankan medical practitioners in the international arena and seriously breached their professional dignity and the fundamental rights, the AMS President and Secretary added.  (DJ)

title: India to provide tech assistance to uplift local milk production
author: Author not found
Content: President Ranil Wickremesinghe has appointed a committee, comprising representatives of the public and private sectors, to work with the multidisciplinary team of the National Livestock Development Board of India, to prepare a short, medium and long-term plan to increase local milk production to reduce the country’s dependence on imported milk powder. Accordingly, India’s National Livestock Development Board and the Indian Amul Milk Company have taken steps to provide the necessary technical support for the production of liquid milk in Sri Lanka, and a preliminary discussion was held in this regard at the Presidential Secretariat yesterday (5), under the chairmanship of President’s Secretary Saman Ekanayake. It was discussed at length about doubling local milk production by implementing short and medium-term plans and making Sri Lanka self-sufficient in milk in the long run through a targeted programme. Additional Secretary to the Ministry of Agriculture, Dr. Nimal Samaranayake, Chairman of the National Livestock Development Board, Professor H.W. Cyril and other committee members and officials of the Ministry of Agriculture and line agencies, Indian National Livestock Development Board Senior General Manager Rajesh Onkarnath Gupta, General Manager Sunil Shivprasad Sinha, Senior Manager Rajesh Kumar Sharma and other representatives participated in this discussion.

title: Sirisena tells Court he cannot take responsibility
author: Author not found
Content: Former President Maithripala Sirisena told the Colombo Civil Appellate High Court yesterday (5), he cannot personally take responsibility for the failure to prevent the Easter Sunday attacks. This was when the Appeal, filed by Sirisena, against the decision taken by the Colombo District Court to reject the request made by him, to discharge him as a respondent in the cases filed in relation to the Easter Sunday attacks, was taken up before the Court. He said, as he is not the President anymore, victims of the Easter Sunday attacks should claim compensation from the Government or by making the Attorney General a party to the action and not from him in his personal capacity. The Colombo District Court on 7 January 2022 rejected the request made by Sirisena to be discharged from the cases filed by the families and victims of the Easter Sunday attacks.

title: Bogambara Stadium unusable despite Rs 35M spent on renovation
author: Author not found
Content: The management of the Bogambara Stadium in Kandy said that although a sum of Rs 35 million had been spent to renovate the venue, it has currently become unusable for any kind of sports activity. The renovation of the Bogambara Stadium had been undertaken three years ago by then Minister of Sports Harin Fernando. The redevelopment project of the venue had been handed over to the Central Engineering Consultancy Bureau (CECB), by the Sugathadasa National Sports Development Authority, but the redevelopment had not been conducted accordingly by the firm to which the sub-contract was given. BY K. L. Suraweera – Kandy

title: Litro increases gas prices
author: Author not found
Content: Litro Gas decided to increase the prices of LP gas cylinders with effect from midnight yesterday (5). However, Laugfs Gas PLC said it won’t increase prices. Accordingly, the 12.5 Kg cylinder of Litro gas was increased by Rs 250 and the new price will be Rs 4,610, the 5 Kg was increased by Rs 100 and the new price is Rs 1,850. The 2.3 Kg cylinder was increased by Rs 45 and the new price is Rs 860. The company said, in a statement, that the increase in LP gas demand during the festive season and winter season is a normal situation during this period, and that the effects of the Ukraine-Russia crisis have caused an increase in international LP gas prices. Despite acknowledging the difficulties of consumers, the company stated that Litro Gas Company must make a minimum price increase to protect the company from price increases in the global market.
