title: Ten years RI and fine for raping minor
author: Author not found
Content: The Matara High Court recently convicted an accused on charges of raping a minor 10 years ago and sentenced him to 10 years Rigorous Imprisonment. Akuressa Police had charged the accused before the High Court over the rape of a 16-year-old girl in Akuressa. The verdict, following a long drawn out trial, was delivered by Matara High Court Judge Tamara Tennakoon. The convict was identified as R. Sunil Rajapaksa, a father of three. The Judge also ordered the convict to pay a fine of Rs 35,000 besides his prison term and warned that failure to pay it would result in an additional 12-months being added to his jail term. Furthermore the convict was also ordered to pay compensation a sum of Rs 150,000 to the victim and warned failure to pay it would result in a further four-year term being added to his prison sentence. (To report child abuses dial 1929 – the hotline of National Child Protection Authority (NCPA)) BY Udaya Ranaweera – Matara

title: Basil says SLPP ready for polls
author: Author not found
Content: Strategist and national organiser of the Sri Lanka Podujana Peramuna (SLPP) Basil Rajapaksa, who recently returned from the United States, told the media yesterday (5) that the SLPP is ready for elections. His statement came after he met Samant Kumar Goel, Head of India’s external intelligence agency, Research and Analysis Wing (RAW), who visited Sri Lanka on 28 November. Apparently, Goel has stressed that the Government of Sri Lanka should fulfil the commitments it made since 1987. He had met President Ranil Wickremesinghe, Sri Lankan High Commissioner Milinda Moragoda and many others including Basil Rajapaksa.  Speaking to the media at the SLPP’s fourth anniversary, at their media centre yesterday (5), he said, “It’s time for election, and the SLPP is ready to face the election.” Rajapaksa, who was removed from his parliamentary seat, due to his dual citizenship, following the adoption of the 21st Amendment to the Constitution, refuted claims that his Party is afraid to face elections. He was asked whether his Party is afraid to face the polls because it is unpopular among the masses and as there is friction within the party following the ousting of the former president by protesters. He said, his party is not split but there are some issues and he will address them all. I will remain in politics he said adding that some have left the SLPP but the party is strong. “Our party is not split, not the way the anniversary cake was cut,” he said pointing at the cake that was displayed front of him. But he did not rule out that there are some who have rebelled and left for good. By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: Seized heroin released as wheat flour – Wijeyadasa
author: Author not found
Content: Minister of Justice, Prisons Affairs and Constitutional Reforms Dr. Wijeyadasa Rajapakshe claimed, in Parliament, there is a racket through which heroin seized by the law enforcement agencies, is released into the society disguised as ‘wheat flour’. Rajapakshe stressed that some officers in the Police Narcotic Bureau (PNB) are involved in this racket. However, adequate action was taken against the officers who committed such crimes, he said. Rajapakshe was speaking during the Committee Stage Debate on the Expenditure Head of the Ministry of Justice, Prison Affairs and Constitutional Reforms. BY Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: Govt conspiring to splinter CEB into pieces – Kiriella
author: Author not found
Content: Chief Opposition Whip Lakshman Kiriella alleged the Government is conspiring to splinter the Ceylon Electricity Board (CEB) into eight parts. While stressing that the Government pledged to protect State resources, Kiriella questioned as to how the Government could go back on its own pledges. Raising concerns in Parliament yesterday (5) Kiriella inquired whether the Government has the people’s mandate to initiate such activity. In response, Leader of the House Susil Premajayantha said neither the Cabinet nor any other committee, that he is a member of, have discussed anything related to the matter. Kiriella then claimed that it was stated by Minister of Power and Energy Kanchana Wijesekara during a meeting of a committee that he is a member of. BY Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: Jailed for fraudulently pocketing salaries of four NHSL docs
author: Author not found
Content: Colombo High Court Judge Amal Ranaraja yesterday, convicted an accused, who had served as Assistant Manager of the Finance Division of the National Hospital in Colombo, after he pleaded guilty to charges of subtly depositing the salaries of four doctors of the hospital, to his personal bank account. As part of the punishment meted out to the convict, the Judge ordered the convict, to pay a fine amounting to thrice the sum that had been stolen by him from the four doctors, amounting to Rs 15 million. The convict was identified as W. W. Nishan Krishantha Fernando and he was also slapped with a term of six years Rigorous Imprisonment, as well as a four-year lenient jail term. The Attorney General had indicted the suspect before the Court in 2006, on two counts and on the aforesaid offence, which had been committed 19 years ago, while the hearing of testimony in the trial had commenced 12 years ago. When the case was convened yesterday, the accused pleaded guilty to the charges filed against him and he told Judge Ranaraja, that he is unable to pay the fine imposed on him by the Court. Senior State Counsel Agbo Pandiratne, prosecuted on behalf of the AGs Department. By Hansi Nanayakkara

title: Title not found
author: Author not found
Content: Date: People in poverty stricken families, who live around estates in Ukuwela, have become victims of a kidney racket and they have not received the promised money and medical care, Ceylon Today learns. During an inspection visit of the area, those who sold kidneys told Ceylon Today that brokers approach young people from poverty stricken families in secret, promising to pay Rs 300,000 – Rs 500,000 for a kidney. The people who live in estates tend to sell kidneys owing to poverty. Although they were promised money and medical care for the rest of their lives, after selling the kidneys, they were being ghosted. The brokers who get colossal sums of money only give a very small amount to the people and then ghost them, the victims said. One person told Ceylon Today that he sold his kidney as his family did not have a proper place to live. “The broker told me that I can sell kidney. We did not have a proper place to live. We did not even have a toilet. So I agreed to the deal. But my wife was against that. The broker promisedRs 500,000 and then we signed an agreement. After the surgery he gave money after taking me home following the surgery. “Sometimes I think I should not have sold the kidney. But now my family have a proper place to live. I cannot do any work because I get exhausted easily. I cannot walk for long and I cannot even wash clothes,” he said. Another person said he was not provided medical care as promised after the surgery. “My house was mortgaged and my wife got burnt in a fire. That was when a broker came and asked me whether I liked to sell a kidney for Rs 500,000. But I only received Rs 400,000.  Although I was taken to Colombo by a vehicle, they did not even provide transport to come home after the surgery. They only dropped me at the Pettah bus stand. The surgical wound was infected after a few days.” Ceylon Today learns that two persons who sold kidneys like this have already died. About 100 persons in the area have sold kidneys and health conditions of majority of them have deteriorated. When queried from Health Ministry Secretary Janaka Sri Chandragupta as to whether the ministry is aware of a kidney racket in Ukuwela, he said he is not aware of that. Chandaraguptha said, there isn’t sufficient evidence on the alleged kidney racket reported in Colombo and if there is evidence the Director General of Health Services (DGHS) has the necessary powers to take actions against it. The DGHS has been already informed to look into the matter, he said. Meanwhile, the Health Ministry has appointed a seven-member committee to probe the alleged kidney racket at Western Infirmary Hospital in Borella. DGHS Dr. Asela Gunawardena said, the committee was appointed following instructions from Health Minister Keheliya Rambukwella. Kidney transplant surgeries at the said hospital have been suspended until the investigation is concluded, Dr. Gunawardena said. BY K.K. Ariyadasa and Vineetha M. Gamage Popular

title: SLTB Chair told to quit immediately
author: Author not found
Content: Transport Minister Bandula Gunawardana has instructed Sri Lanka Transport Board (SLTB) Chairman Kingsley Ranawaka to immediately resign. This follows allegation that the SLTB Board of Directors was deliberately failing to implement Cabinet decisions. Gunawardena said Ranawaka was instructed to resign from the position immediately, in accordance with Section 5 of the first part of the SLTB Act No. 27 of 2005, for failing to comply with the measures taken to assist the people and to uplift and make the transport service more efficient. He noted that this was done in accordance with his powers as Minister of Transport. He also pointed out that the deliberate non-implementation of Cabinet decisions by the Board of Directors of SLTB is the immediate cause of this decision, as is the failure to contribute to moving the institution toward the people-friendly goals intended by the Government. (TR)

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Saudi Envoy says SL workers highest paid in his country
author: Author not found
Content: Saudi Arabia’s Ambassador to Sri Lanka, Khalid Hamoud Nasser Aldasam Alkahtani, said migrant workers from Sri Lanka are the highest paid in Saudi Arabia. He said this when paying a courtesy call on Speaker Mahinda Yapa Abeywardana, recently. The Ambassador further noted that he had suggested to Minister of Labour Manusha Nanayakkara to establish a vocational training centre to train migrant workers from Sri Lanka as there are many opportunities for them in Saudi Arabia. Cordial discussions were held regarding future investment and employment opportunities between Sri Lanka and Saudi Arabia. The Speaker whilst appreciating the constant assistance of Saudi Arabia to Sri Lanka, assured that Sri Lanka will always stand with Saudi Arabia in friendship.

title: SLC to get new constitution
author: Author not found
Content: The Minister of Sports informed the Court of Appeal yesterday (5) that steps will be taken to draft a new constitution for Sri Lanka Cricket (SLC) upon obtaining advice from the technical committee of the International Cricket Council (ICC). Accordingly, Additional Solicitor General Sumathi Dharmawardene informed Court that the Minister of Sports has, in writing, informed that steps will be taken to also amend the Sports Act and relevant Sports Regulations. This was when the Petition filed by 12 persons, including sports personalities, seeking a new Constitution for the SLC, which seeks to amend the voting structure prior to the next elections, was taken up before Court of Appeal Judge M.T. Mohammed Laffar. Dharmawardene informed Court of Appeal that instructions were given by the Attorney General to the Minister of Sports pertaining to measures that should be taken in this regard in writing in October 2022. Accordingly, based on the agreement made by the Sports Minister, President’s Counsel Sanjeeva Jayawardena, appearing on behalf of the petitioners, informed Court that the decision as to whether the case should be continued or not will be communicated to during the next hearing of the case. Further hearing of the case was fixed for 28 February 2023. BY Faadhila Thassim

title: Three glittering stars of Colombo South Int’l College
author: Author not found
Content: Three students of the Colombo South International College, namely Suzanne Tashiya Forbes, 3 A* stars and the highest mark in Sri Lanka for Economics, Rashmika Dineth Perera, 4 A* stars and Sasindu Dde Silva 7 Grade 9S and the highest mark in Asia for Commerce, received high awards at the Pearson Edexcel Awards Night, on 24 November 2022 at BMICH, due to their dedication, commitment and hard work, with the able guidance given by two teachers, Sanath Samarasinghe and Heshika Alahakoon. The principal of the school expressed heartfelt and sincere congratulations to the students, on behalf of Managing Director Mangala Wijekularatne and the senior management team, as the Award ceremony has generated value for students, teachers and the school.

title: Narcotics found in school canteen
author: Author not found
Content: Seven packets containing ‘ICE’ and 38 narcotic pills were discovered in a canteen of a school in Malwathuhiripitiya, Gampaha. Police arrested a 42-year-old woman who was operating the canteen. Police said, investigations were underway and the suspect would be produced in the Gampaha Magistrate’s Court.

title: Robber gang strikes at Police OIC’s house
author: Author not found
Content: An armed gang had stormed into the house of the Officer-in-Charge (OIC) of the Kalutara North Police and committed robbery on 3 December.  The gang had arrived in a white van. According to the Police, the gang had stolen over Rs 25,000 in cash, three mobile phones and two gold rings. The OIC’s wife, daughter, and a friend of the daughter were present in the house at the time of the robbery. The suspects had stormed into the house, claiming to be from the Police Special Task Force, and threatened the residents with a pistol, demanding a firearm. They had spent 30 minutes searching the house. Police suspects that the gang had come to the house in the absence of the OIC to find some kind of a firearm they suspected to be in the house. However, when they couldn’t find it they had stolen what they could have laid their hands on and fled. Welipanna Police are conducting investigations. BY Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: Suspect arrested at BIA
author: Author not found
Content: The Special Investigation Unit of the Sri Lanka Bureau of Foreign Employment (SLBFE) on 3 December arrested a broker who attempted to send five women to Malaysia as domestic workers on tourist visas. A law enforcement officer with the SLBFE’s Special Investigation Unit Sarath Wimalaweera said the broker was arrested at BIA. The arrest occurred when the broker took five female workers aged 21-40 from Pundaluoya Kaippu Kale Estate to BIA to be sent to Malaysia on tourist visas. According to the SLBFE Special Investigation Unit, the suspect woman is a resident of Saranankara Mawatha in Dehiwala, and she spent Rs 1,600,000 to send the concerned women abroad, as well as for visas, documents, and air tickets. By Prasanga Pawuluhewa – Ja Ela

title: Prasanna tables two audit reports
author: Author not found
Content: Minister of Urban Development and Housing Prasanna Ranatunga tabled two audit reports in Parliament regarding alleged fraud and corruption incidents in the Ministry of Housing while Opposition Leader Sajith Premadasa was the subject Minister. He said, the new proposals presented by MPs during the Ministry of Urban Development and Housing’s Expenditure Head will be submitted to the Advisory Committee and implemented accordingly. Minister Ranatunga tabled reports on errors and irregularities in the issuance of housing loans and aid by the Weerakatiya Zonal Office of the Hambantota District from 2017 to 2019, when Premadasa was Housing Minister. Also, two inspection reports related to posters and invitations printed for villages between 2016 and 2019 was tabled. He tabled the audit reports while delivering the vote of thanks on the Expenditure Head of the Ministry of Urban Development and Housing. By Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: NATA will support legalising cannabis – Chairman
author: Author not found
Content: The National Authority on Tobacco and Alcohol (NATA) said, if the Parliamentary Committee to legalise cannabis could prove countries have economically benefited from cannabis production and exports, NATA will support legalising cannabis in Sri Lanka. Addressing the ‘Nidhahas Aragalaya – Mathin Thora Deshayak,’ the NATA’s advocacy programme for Sri Lankan media personnel (Media Awards Ceremony) aimed at appreciating their contribution towards tobacco and alcohol prevention in the country, its Chairman Dr. Samadhi Rajapaksa claimed that the tobacco industry is behind the campaign to legalise cannabis. “There is a 6 per cent reduction in smoking tobacco consumption in Sri Lanka in 2022, if this continues in every country their industry will collapse.  Canada is the country which majorly started with nine factories to manufacture cannabis, but now they are facing a huge loss where all these factories have been closed. Even Lebanon is facing the same situation. If someone is trying to say that there is a huge market for cannabis because of its medical use that’s false. Worldwide research on cannabis-based medications have produced unexpected results.  There’s only one medicine which was used for epilepsy patients, yet in a very minimal quantity. Even if we collect the cannabis found illegally, we have a surplus,” he added. Rajapaksa further claimed that even when it comes to indigenous medicines, they have scientific evidence that cannabis wasn’t used in large quantities. “Indigenous doctors say they use oil or king coconut water to get rid of the poisonous aspect of cannabis even when using the slightest amount of it for certain medicines. We argue with scientifically proven facts, unlike some people who act on assumptions,” he said. The programme was held on 2 December at the Nelum Hall, Waters Edge, Battaramulla, as the focal point of prevention of tobacco and alcohol in Sri Lanka, Media Awards Ceremony.  By Nabiya Vaffoor

title: ICT to be added to O/L syllabus – Premajayantha
author: Author not found
Content: Minister of Education Dr. Susil Premajayantha said, Information Communication Technology (ICT) is expected to be added as a core subject in the G.C.E. Ordinary Level Examination curriculum in the future as part of the education reform process. He said, ICT will be combined with emerging subject streams such as nanotechnology, biotechnology, robotics, and artificial intelligence to provide students with both knowledge and technology. He said innovative solutions are required to overcome these future challenges. “Although we have more knowledge than other countries, because we lack a process to put that knowledge into practice, other countries take advantage of our human resources. The loss of focus of those in charge of the country’s economy has had a significant impact on that human resource. We must urgently recall Sri Lankan human resources, who are dispersed worldwide and equipped with knowledge, in order to pursue the fourth industrial revolution, which we are missing, and bridge the gap that is far away. This should help to shape the country’s future. To that end, the attention and support of this country’s economists should be focused on knowledge and technology,” he said. He said Rs 1,000 million will be spent on 1,000 schools and Internet facilities will be provided, no school in the island will be isolated, and by next March-April, all teachers and principals will be networked, and all placements and promotions will be done through that network, resulting in office and administrative savings.

title: Tax Bill not due in Parliament until 13 Dec –Siyambalapitiya
author: Author not found
Content: State Minister of Finance Ranjith Siyambalapitiya said, the Tax Amendment Bill will not be submitted to Parliament on 9 December. He said this during a programme held yesterday (4) in Ruwanwella, Morawatta. He also said statements made that a Tax Amendment Bill will be presented to Parliament on 9 December and that prices of goods will rise as a result are completely false. He said while a Tax Amendment Bill may be presented on 13 December in regard to the matters mentioned in the Interim Budget, which was presented prior to this year’s Budget proposals, there is no reason for the price of all goods to rise as a result of the amendment. By Amila Abeyratne

title: Kelanitissa Power Plant out of action
author: Author not found
Content: The Kelanitissa Combined Cycle Power Plant has been out of action since midnight on 3 December. According to the Ceylon Electricity Board Engineers’ Union, this plant was shut down due to a shortage of naphtha. This plant provides 165 megawatts of capacity to the National Grid. According to the Union, this plant received 4,000 metric tonnes of naphtha last Monday and has been operating at 165 megawatts since. However, due to the depletion of naphtha fuel, the power plant went offline at midnight on 3 December. By Chamara Amarasuriya

title: Lankan man charged with murder
author: Author not found
Content: A Lankan man has been charged with murder after a mother-of-three was stabbed to death in her home at Sandhurst in Melbourne’s south-east. The 44-year-old woman’s daughter rushed to her neighbours for help, but her mother could not be saved. In CCTV footage, the daughter can be heard knocking on her neighbours’ door and pleading for assistance. “Please, please, please,” the daughter says, before adding horrifying details of the alleged attack. “I’m pretty sure she’s dead.” “We’re coming, we’re coming, we’re coming,” a neighbour can be heard yelling out. But it was too late, her mother, Nelomie Perera, had been killed. “She was just saying, ‘My mum’s dead, my mum’s dead’,” neighbour Paul Vavitis told 9News. Police said in a statement a 45-year-old Sandhurst man had been charged with murder. 9News understands the man charged was the mother-of-three’s husband, Dinush Kurera. Kurera is alleged to have also attacked their teenage son, who managed to escape with a non-life-threatening head injury and was taken to hospital for treatment. The horrifying ordeal unfolded in Perera’s Sandurst home just before midnight. 9News understands Perera recently separated from her husband. Neighbours said she had just changed the locks on the family home. Those who knew Perera say she was a kind and sweet woman and an excellent mother. (9News)

title: Thondaman vows to take TU action
author: Author not found
Content: Ceylon Workers’ Congress General Secretary Jeevan Thondaman said, he will take trade union action against Horana Plantations PLC, alleging that the company does not allow workers to unionise, denying them… …representation and depriving them of labour rights. He also alleged that a worker named ‘Siva Kumar,’ a father of three, had been subjected to electric shocks during work hours, suffered third-degree burns, and is in critical condition at the Kandy Hospital. Workers are perturbed over this incident. Thondaman further alleged workers are not allowed to unionise to talk about their rights and not allowed to subscribe to a Union of their choice. He said the employer must recognise their rights as per the TU Ordinance. “Due to management irregularities and the refusal by the company to discuss matters pertaining to the well-being of workers, I initiated TU action against them,” Thondaman said. “The company belonging to the richest person in the country, has not only stopped work for the workers during this crisis, but has filed cases against estate workers and their children in Hatton,  Norwood, and Maskeliya Police stations for engaging in TU action,” he alleged.  Thondaman told the Police that they cannot interfere in TU action, and he, as the CWC General Secretary had ordered this action. “While the President had encouraged abandoned lands to be given for cultivation to people who are at risk of food insecurity, the management had forcibly destroyed cultivated lands belonging to unemployed youth in the estate with the help of the Police,” he further alleged. The management had sought the help of the CID special branch to intimidate the workers into ending the TU action by threatening them with six months imprisonment, according to Thondaman. “The plantation managers believe in an authoritarian form of management. While the company paints a pretty picture on the outside to show ‘ethical’ plucking, nothing could be further from the truth. The company controls Talawakelle, Kelani Valley, and Horana Plantations. While the owner entered Parliament in a supposed bid to save the country, it’ll be nice if the public could see the state of the people in his plantations,” claimed Thondaman. Workers who have worked for over 180 days haven’t been registered, he pointed out. Setting high norms at 20 kg and violating the Wages Board Ordinance by paying people only 500 if a kilo is plucked less. If a worker works for 8 hours, he/she must be paid Rs 1,000 as wage, he added. To clarify, if a worker plucks 21 kg, 3 kg is deducted per weigh in for various irrational reasons, thereby reducing the worker’s output to 18 kg. Moreover, the infamous Outgrower system of management proposed by them has never proven to benefit the estate worker. In fact, they are further subjugated into untold obligations and uncertainties. Workers are at risk of getting paid less for green leaves plucked and the management will remove the plots given to the workers at their discretion, he said. The living standards are in a pathetic state, not because of politicians and unions, but because the management believes that not even a toilet should be built in the line rooms. “If what I claim is false, I’d be more than happy to take anyone into the plantations managed by them and expose them for what they truly are,” Thondaman stressed. By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: No taxes on remittances – CBSL
author: Author not found
Content: The Central Bank of Sri Lanka (CBSL) announced that speculation that expatriate Sri Lankans’ remittances to Sri Lanka have been taxed and forcibly converted into Sri Lankan rupees is completely unfounded. “There are no taxes on remittances and expatriate Sri Lankans are free to hold such remittances in foreign currency form in their bank accounts or convert such remittances into Sri Lankan rupees at their discretion,” the Central Bank tweeted. Expatriate Sri Lankans continue to enjoy the current incentives without any change whatsoever, the CBSL further said.

title: 48 sovereigns of gold robbed from Hulftsdorp
author: Author not found
Content: An investigation has been launched into an incident where 48 sovereigns of gold kept as Court productions were robbed from the Hulftsdorp Magistrate’s Court using forged documents. These Court productions had been taken away from Number 2 and 4 of the Hulftsdorp Court Complex. The gold was labelled as Court productions of two cases that are being heard at the Courts. According to a senior Police Officer, an imposter masquerading as a CID Officer stole the Court productions by providing a forged Magistrate’s order. However, it later came to light that the person was not a CID Officer. The gold was released in good faith without checking the Case Book, believing that the documents were provided by the CID. The senior Police Officer further said, the storekeeper of Court Productions lodged a complaint over the theft with Keselwatta Police and an investigation has been launched.

title: Remanded for trying to bribe Crimes OIC
author: Author not found
Content: The Commission to Investigate Allegations of Bribery or Corruption (CIABOC) arrested an individual who attempted to bribe the OIC of the Avissawella Police Crimes Division. According to the Police, the suspect offered the OIC Rs 50,000 to release a suspect who was arrested with narcotics. Police had arrested a large-scale drug dealer in Avissawella with 10 grammes of ICE and 2,100 milligrammes of heroin. However, an individual claiming to be a friend of the suspect met the OIC and attempted to bribe him. The suspect had told the OIC that Rs 50,000 will be given to him in total.  He had said that on Saturday (3) morning Rs 25,000 will be given and then the balance Rs 25,000 will be given after the arrested was given bail, Police said. Later the OIC had informed the HQI of the station and had taken steps to inform the CIABOC. Accordingly, the suspect was arrested the following morning (3) while attempting to bribe the OIC. He was identified as a 32-year-old resident of Ruwanwella. The suspect was remanded until 16 December after being produced before the Avissawella Magistrate’s Court. Police said the suspect is the fifth person arrested by the Police for bribing the complainant Police OIC V.G.S.K. Sanjeewa. BY Aloka Kasturiarachchi and Bimal Jayasinghe – Colombo

title: Two suspects arrested
author: Author not found
Content: Officers from the Kurunegala Police Special Crime Investigation Unit arrested two individuals who claimed to be close contacts of politicians and duped unemployed youths by using Ministry letterheads promising Government jobs. These suspects were arrested on 3 and 4 December in Kurunegala and Wariyapola. They obtained Rs 400,000 by providing an appointment letter to a pre-school teacher in the Wellawa area, using Ministry of Administration letterheads, promising a job as an Assistant Manager in the North-West Provincial Council. These suspects claimed to be close contacts of MPs. The mastermind of this scam, a father of one living near Wariyapola city, was arrested yesterday (4) by Police Officers while at home, with the help of a broker who was arrested following a Police investigation. By Ravindu Sooriyabandara – Kurunegala

title: 400 employment agencies blacklisted – Manusha
author: Author not found
Content: Minister of Labour and Foreign Employment Manusha Nanayakkara informed Parliament that 400 employment agencies are under consideration for a ban for failing to provide necessary information regarding sending people overseas for work on tourist visas. Nanayakkara also said, temporary bans have been imposed on agencies that use the Undiyal money transfer system instead of using official banking channels. He also added that, while licences for such agencies were previously granted for Rs 750,000, they will be increased to Rs 3,000,000 in the near future under a newly implemented procedure. Accordingly, the licence will be provided after a thorough process and after conducting a special study of the relevant company. Responding to MP Thalatha Athukorala’s concerns on foreign employment in Parliament on 3 December, Nanayakkara claimed that migrant workers are irritated with the country due to the issues that occurred when they were quarantined in hotels during Covid-19. He alleged that some of the payments made to the hotels during quarantine were transferred into the accounts of the spouses of SL Army top brass. He said investigations are underway to identify such incidents. Nanayakkara further said to protect employees, entrepreneurs must be protected. He said citizens must not fall prey to rallies focused on disrupting the country’s progress.  “Until now, after presenting a Budget, there was a programme associated with it. This Budget is not just a programme, but a social and economic transformation,” he added. By Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: Suspect arrested at BIA
author: Author not found
Content: The Special Investigation Unit of the Sri Lanka Bureau of Foreign Employment (SLBFE) on 3 December arrested a broker who attempted to send five women to Malaysia as domestic workers on tourist visas. A law enforcement officer with the SLBFE’s Special Investigation Unit Sarath Wimalaweera said the broker was arrested at BIA. The arrest occurred when the broker took five female workers aged 21-40 from Pundaluoya Kaippu Kale Estate to BIA to be sent to Malaysia on tourist visas. According to the SLBFE Special Investigation Unit, the suspect woman is a resident of Saranankara Mawatha in Dehiwala, and she spent Rs 1,600,000 to send the concerned women abroad, as well as for visas, documents, and air tickets. By Prasanga Pawuluhewa – Ja Ela

title: Dry food packaging project launched in Godella
author: Author not found
Content: The inaugural programme of the dry food packaging project jointly implemented by Lanka Sathosa and Bopitiya Free Women’s Organisation under the guidance of Minister of Trade Nalin Fernando was held in Godella Bopitiya Pamunugama to empower women and uplift the rural economy. “From a loss-making company, Lanka Sathosa was able to provide necessary facilities and build trust among suppliers to become a place that earns a monthly income of 57,000, and managing 4,000 employees, a large number of branches, and a large product range is not an easy task. Because of the dedication of all the officials, it was possible to turn it into a profitable institution,” he said. Speaking further, he said the limited amount of food in the country, which was a major challenge given the present economic situation, was managed properly to avoid the formation of food queues, and that essential food was brought into the country utilising the ‘open account’ system and Indian credit line. He said a programme has been launched to control the prices of essential foods, books, pencils, and other products. “I hope that everyone will perform their duties properly and make this collaboration a success,” he said, adding that if the project is successful, he plans to extend it to other provinces.

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Differently-abled persons overlooked – President
author: Author not found
Content: President Ranil Wickremesinghe said the needs of differently-abled persons and child protection had been overlooked due to a lack of attention and funds. He said previously, it was handled under the Samurdhi programme, which was not successful because it was intended for economic empowerment, and that these areas would be addressed separately. The President said a special programme will be developed for the benefit of differently-abled persons. He said he has already directed Prime Minister Dinesh Gunawardena, along with the Women, Child Affairs and Social Empowerment State Minister, Education Minister, Health Minister, Youth Affairs and Sports Minister, to prepare a report in this regard. The President was speaking at the national ceremony to commemorate the International Day of Persons with Disabilities – 2022 under the theme, ‘Transformative solutions for inclusive development; the role of innovation in fuelling an accessible and equitable world,’ held at Temple Trees. He further said after the report is submitted to Cabinet, proposals will be included in the next Budget.  He also assured that these persons would be given the opportunity to serve the nation. He added that Lord Nelson, who defeated the fleet of ships of Napoleon, had only one hand while world-renowned musician Beethoven had lost his hearing when he composed his best music.

title: Ogilvy Group SL continues winning streak
author: Author not found
Content: Winners of the 29th Campaign Asia Pacific’s ‘Agency of the Year Awards’ were announced in Mumbai, recently, and the Ogilvy Group Sri Lanka continued its winning streak at the highly respected awards show this year, with silver and bronze awards. Phoenix Ogilvy bagged the Silver Award in the category titled ‘Rest of South Asia Advertising Agency of the Year’, an accolade given for outstanding business performance during the year. The highly, competitive category ‘Rest of South Asia Digital Agency of the Year’, saw Ogilvy Digital bagging the Bronze Award.  Campaign Asia Pacific’s Agency of the Year Awards is the most important awards show of the region, and celebrates the exceptional performances of media, advertising, creative, digital and PR agencies. This year’s edition of the awards show brought together a jury of highly, experienced industry veterans from across the Asia-Pacific region to select the most progressive and successful agencies in the territory.    The latest win is the 5th consecutive year the 280 strong Ogilvy group was recognized by the awards show as a high performing and innovative agency in Sri Lanka. “The Ogilvy Group successfully withstood all adversities of the business climate during some of the worst years in the recent history of the country, which rendered Sri Lanka bankrupt.” said Ogilvy Group Chairman Irvin Weerackody. “The stability of our group, across all disciplines of Creative, Digital, PR and Media buying and their ability to excel during these challenging times is a feat in itself. We have been agile, innovative, and strategic at all points these past few years and are steady in our growth and business performance.” The Ogilvy Group has been winning at the Campaign Asia Agency of the Year Awards show since 2016 and the total tally of metals under its belt now stands at 10.

title: President felicitated on completing 50 years at Bar
author: Author not found
Content: President Ranil Wickremesinghe said ethnic, religious, and other genuine concerns of the people could be put aside in order to avoid a fragmentation of the State’s unity and integrity by the country’s 75th Independence Day. He said as discussed by Parliamentarians, if the country’s Attorneys-at-Law would assist in this process, this task could be completed. He was speaking during the ceremony to felicitate him on completing 50 years at Bar, held in Colombo on 3 November.  He further said it is not an easy task, but neither is it an impossible task. He added that this task cannot be achieved merely through the efforts of politicians, but the support of the lawyers is vital in this endeavour. He said apart from the economic challenge, there is a greater challenge, where the younger generation is questioning the entire system. He added that now the country has the option of letting the wounds of the past heal or fester further. The Parliamentarians have decided to see how best to resolve the ethnic differences and work towards reconciliation, issues of religious differences, and all the other genuine concerns of the people, without breaking up the integrity and unity of the State. He also said if all the Attorneys-at-Law join hands, all the major problems could be put behind us and all communities could come together as children of one family as the country celebrates 75 years of independence next year. He added that it would also give all the opportunity to understand and appreciate each other’s views and prepare a Constitution which would enshrine the freedoms the people enjoy, but also allow for constitutional governance. President Ranil Wickremesinghe and First Lady, Professor Maithree Wickremesinghe were received at this occasion by President’s Counsel Ronald Perera. Addressing the gathering, President’s Counsel Romesh de Silva said the President has never worked for self-promotion, but has always worked to strengthen Parliament. President’s Counsel Romesh de Silva, President’s Counsel Thilak Marapana, and President’s Counsel Faiz Mustafa also spoke at the event. President’s Counsel Ronald Perera delivered the welcome speech and Attorney-at-Law Kushan de Alwis delivered the vote of thanks. Speaker Mahinda Yapa Abeywardena, Prime Minister Dinesh Gunawardena, former President Mahinda Rajapaksa , Chief Justice Jayantha Jayasuriya PC, UNP Chairman and Parliamentarian Wajira Abeywardena, Ports and Civil Aviation Minister Nimal Siripala de Silva, MP Anura Priyadarshana Yapa, MP Chandima Weerakkody, MP Udaya Gammanpila, MP M.A. Sumanthiran, MP Lakshman Kiriella, Justice, Prisons Affairs and Constitutional Reforms Minister Wijeyadasa Rajapakshe, Secretary to the President Saman Ekanayake, President’s Senior Adviser on National Security and Chief of Presidential Staff Sagala Ratnayake, Senior Advisor to President on Climate Change Ruwan Wijewardene,  Presidential Adviser Akila Viraj Kariyawasam, Presidents Adviser  Dr. R.H.S. Samarathunga, President’s Adviser K.P. Dayaratne, UNP General Secretary Palitha Rangebandara, Navin Dissanayake, and the President’s Private Secretary Sandra Perera were also present at the occasion.

title: ‘5G’ technology to be introduced from 2023
author: Author not found
Content: The Telecommunication Regulatory Commission (TRC) will make the necessary arrangements to start commercial activities, related to 5G technology from next year. State Minister of Technology Kanaka Herath said at the Ministerial Consultative Committee on Technology meeting held recently that a proposal will be submitted regarding the reactivation of Vidatha Technology centres islandwide under the Ministry of Technology. It was also discussed about TRC permission for 5G technology which is to be introduced by internet service providers. The State Minister was responding to a request by Parliamentarian Weerasumana Weerasinghe to bring Vidatha Centres back under the Ministry of Technology and develop them to suit the new era. The members also drew the committee’s attention to Sri Lanka Telecom PLC. In the last year, the profit of Sri Lanka Telecom Company was Rs 12 billion and the profit from January to September this year is approximately Rs 6 billion, company officials said. This was disclosed when Dr. Upul Galappatti, MP, requested information about the telecom company while commenting on the proposal to privatise it. Sri Lanka Telecom officials said the Government owns a 49.5 per cent stake in the company and if the company is privatised, the private sector will own the same amount of shares.

title: RE falls after 124 days
author: Author not found
Content: Cheap and clean renewable energy (RE), for the first time after 124 days, provided under 50 per cent of Sri Lanka’s total electricity needs on Friday (2), latest Ceylon Electricity Board (CEB) data released on Saturday (3) showed. On Friday, RE provided 47.10 per cent (18.42 Giga Watt hours (GWh)) of Sri Lanka’s total electricity needs. While the dirty and more expensive fossil fuels (FFs) provided 52.90 per cent (20.69 GWh). Prior to Friday, led by CEB hydroelectricity, RE met over 50 per cent of Sri Lanka’s total electricity needs continuously, beginning from 31 July. On Friday, Sri Lanka consumed a total of 39.11 GWh of electricity.In the 336 calendar days that have transpired  to Friday, RE has met over 50 per cent of Sri Lanka’s electricity needs in 174 (51.94 per cent) of those days, while the balance 162 days (48.21 per cent), the country’s electricity needs were met by FF. Meanwhile, Friday’s electricity split were FFS, comprising  CEB coal and CEB fuel oil, 12.96 and 7.73 GWh and RE split, comprising CEB hydro, CEB wind, private sector (PS) solar, PS biomass, PS mini-hydro and PS wind, 16.21, 0.35, 0.27, 0.24, 1.08 and 0.27 GWh. According to Central Bank of Sri Lanka’s (CBSL’s) 2021, Annual Report, the cheapest source of electricity generation to the CEB, last year, was CEB hydro at a cost of Rs 1.67 a kilo Watt hour (kWh) or per one unit of electricity, followed by CEB coal (Rs 10.68), CEB wind, PS biomass, PS mini-hydro and PS wind bunched together (Rs 16.22), (independent power producers’ (IPP’)/PS fuel oil (Rs 30.35) and CEB  fuel oil (Rs 32.03), respectively. BY Paneetha Ameresekere

title: Devananda inspects new electric boat engine
author: Author not found
Content: An observation tour was conducted yesterday (4) at the Panadura Fishing Harbour premises with the collaboration of Fisheries Minister Douglas Devananda to test new electric boats and engines that will be introduced for fishing boats. A private factory in Polgasowita manufactures the new electric boat engine. The minister travelled four kilometres in a fishing vessel equipped with the electric engine with the inventor. Devananda instructed Chaminda Ruwan Kumara, the inventor to rectify any defects observed in the engine. According to Devananda, fishermen were in dire straits due to the increase in the price of fuel, and as a result of its perseverance, a private factory in Kahathuduwa, Polgasowita manufactured this new electric charging fishing boat engine. “I believe it costs only Rs 86 to travel one hundred kilometres, which is a significant economic advantage for the fishermen. These new electric boat engines will be delivered to fishermen very soon,” he said. By Bimal Jayasinghe (Colombo) and Sumith Ranawaka (Pothupitiya)

title: Second volume of Jataka Tales audio book launched
author: Author not found
Content: Marking the arrival of Most Venerable Sanghamitta Theraniya from India to Sri Lanka, the second volume of the Jataka Tales Audio Book in Sinhala was released at Swami Vivekananda Cultural Centre (SVCC), cultural arm of the Indian High Commission on 2 December. The Audio Book contains 50 Jataka Tales, selected from Jataka Katha under the theme of ‘Good Advice’ and is dedicated to the people of Sri Lanka, particularly the visually impaired. It may be recalled that that first volume was released at the sacred Ruwanweli Maha Seya premises in Anuradhapura on the auspicious Poson Poya on 14 June to mark 75th anniversary of India-Sri Lanka diplomatic relations. Most Venerable Maha Sangha, High Commissioner of India Gopal Baglay, State Minister of Pirivena Education Vijitha Berugoda, Deputy High Commissioner Vinod K. Jacob, and several senior functionaries and representatives from various organisations including Ceylon School for the Deaf and Blind, Ratmalana and Centre for Contemporary Indian Studies (CCIS), University of Colombo, took part in the event. The ‘Jataka Tales Audio Book’ project is a joint collaboration between SVCC and CCIS, University of Colombo supervised by Most Ven. Rambukana Siddhartha Thera, several experts such as Prof. Upul Ranjith Hewawitanagamage, Chair Senior Professor of Hindi Studies, University of Kelaniya, Dr. W.A. Abeysinha and Wathsala Samarakoon, a popular TV and Radio presenter contributed towards the initiative. High Commissioner Gopal Baglay interacted with the winners of the International quiz competition on Buddhism and Buddhist Heritage who returned after a successful and enriching 5-day multi-city tour to key Buddhist sites of India. The winners thanked the Government and people of India for the care and affection they received during their trip to India. Organised by the High Commission in collaboration with the State Ministry of Pirivena Education, the quiz competition had witnessed the participation of about 6,000 Pirivena students.  Speaking on the occasion, the High Commissioner described the Audio Book as a Dhamma Daana from the people of India to the people of Sri Lanka. He also underlined that the Jataka Tales represent more than two millenia of close cultural ties between India and many countries, of which Sri Lanka has a very special place as one of the first countries to receive the gift of Buddhism from India. State Minister Berugoda thanked the Indian Government for supporting the Pirivenas and Dhamma education in Sri Lanka. Buddhism has been a key pillar binding the people of India and Sri Lanka. The Indian Government has committed to a USD 15 million grant for promotion of Buddhist ties between the two countries. The inaugural flight to the sacred city of Kushinagar from Sri Lanka on the auspicious ‘Vap Poya’ day in October 2021, multi-city exposition of the sacred Kapilavastu Buddha relics from the Rajaguru Sri Subhuthi Maha Vihara of Waskaduwa, in India in October 2021 are among the notable milestones that underscore the abiding Buddhist linkages between the two neighbours in the recent past.

title: Ali Sabry meets US Secy of State
author: Author not found
Content: Minister of Foreign Affairs M.U.M. Ali Sabry paid an official visit to Washington, D.C. from 30 November to 2 December. He was in the U.S. capital to meet the Secretary of State Antony Blinken. They held discussions at the Department of State on Friday (2), focused on further developing Sri Lanka – US relations in diverse spheres, including the 75th Anniversary of diplomatic relations which will be marked in 2023. In addition to the meeting with Secretary Blinken, the Embassy of Sri Lanka to the US facilitated further interactions during the visit which included meetings with key US interlocutors including political leaders from both the House of Representatives and the Senate representing both major parties and high officials of the State Department.  Minister Sabry met a member of the Senate Committee on Foreign Relations, Senator Bill Hagerty, (Republican – Tennessee). He held talks with members of Congress Rep. Bill Johnson (Republican – Ohio), Co-Chair of the Caucus on Ethnic and Religious Freedom in Sri Lanka and Rep. Raja Krishnamoorthi (Democrat – Illinois) who has shown an interest in Sri Lanka. The Minister also had a meeting with Administrator, United States Agency for International Development (USAID) Samantha Power and expressed his appreciation to USAID for their generous support to Sri Lanka. He met Under Secretary of State for Civilian Security, Democracy and Human Rights, Ambassador Uzra Zeya, who was accompanied by Deputy Assistant Secretary, Bureau of South and Central Asian Affairs of the Department of State, Afreen Akhter. Ambassador of Sri Lanka to the United States Mahinda Samarasinghe along with diplomats of the Embassy of Sri Lanka and officials of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs were also present at the meetings.

title: Sub-Committee chaired by President’s Secy appointed
author: Author not found
Content: The Sub-Committee on Identifying the Priorities in Formulation of Short, Medium and Long Term National Policies of the National Council held recently decided to appoint a sub-committee under the chairmanship of Secretary to the President Saman Ekanayake to prepare a basic model for the establishment of a National Policy Commission for the proper implementation of national policies with regulation.  Furthermore, it was agreed to appoint Anura Dissanayake Secretary to the Prime Minister, Secretary to the Ministry of Public Administration Priyantha Mayadunne, as well as well as representatives of the Ministry of Finance, Ministry of Health, University Grants Commission, Attorney General’s Department, Legal Draftsman’s Department and other relevant institutions as members. Ekanayake, Dissanayake, Mayadunne, and officials were present at this Committee meeting chaired by Namal Rajapaksa, MP. Rajapaksa said the commission is expected to be set up as an independent body for policy formulation, implementation, and monitoring by way of an Act and its basic plans are expected to be completed by mid January. The officials pointed out that this commission should be given full legal power to implement policies as well as regulate and supervise. The need to prepare these plans by studying the models of other countries that have succeeded in implementing policies through such an independent institution was also discussed.

title: No need to increase power tariffs now – PUCSL
author: Author not found
Content: Public Utilities Commission of Sri Lanka (PUCSL) Chairman Janaka Ratnayake said there is no need to raise the electricity tariffs now, adding that several issues must be resolved before increasing it. He said they are waiting for the Ceylon Electricity Board to forward the request to increase the electricity tariff, after which they will provide their solution. Addressing the media yesterday (1), Ratnayake said increasing the electricity tariff should be done methodically rather than haphazardly. “If this does not happen methodically, the electricity prices will be increased at random, just like the price of fuel, and people will find out when they wake up. We disagree because it cannot be done in this manner.” That is why we are requesting permission to import naphtha and furnace oil, as well as coal. “Everything in the global market has decreased,” he said. In addition, he noted that they previously advised that if the electricity board has the ability to import furnace oil and naphtha like coal, the Rs. 400 billion cost can be reduced by another Rs. 200 billion,” he said. BY Thameenah Razeek

title: Rat fever on the rise again
author: Author not found
Content: The Epidemiology Unit urged farming communities and those engaged in agricultural activities to be cautious of leptospirosis better known as rat fever. At least 6,000 to 8,000 cases of leptospirosis cases were detected each year and of them at least 100 deaths were reported. The increasing numbers that were currently being witnessed has the Epidemiology Unit concerned, Consultant Community Physician,Thushani Dabarera said yesterday (01).  An increase in cases was witnessed annually due to paddy cultivation activities during the Yala and Maha seasons – that is from April to May and September to December, she said.  Fielding questions, during a media briefing held at the Government Information Department, Dr. Dabarera said the highest numbers of rat fever cases have been recorded from Ratnapura, Kegalle, Galle, Kalutara and Matara.  An increase is seen also in the cases being reported from the North Central Province. Responding to questions, she noted that patients who seek treatment for fever condition should inform the medical practitioner treating them, if they had been engaged in agricultural work so as to avoid delays in diagnosis- or misdiagnosis. Fever, headache, muscle aches, chills, vomiting, abdominal pain jaundice (yellow skin and eyes) and red eyes were symptoms of the disease, the Consultant Community Physician noted.  Leptospirosis should be given attention just like dengue and other viral infections, Dr. Dabarera added. By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: Charter flights to land at Mattala instead of BIA – Sri Lanka Tourism
author: Author not found
Content: Sri Lanka Tourism acknowledged that there is congestion at the Bandaranaike International Airport (BIA) due to construction etc. and they are hoping to move the charter operations to Mattala Airport as a remedy and part of a short-term plan as well. The Government is expecting to reach a target of 1.5 million tourists in 2023 and the Sri Lanka Tourism official added that the BIA congestion is a big issue and if charter flights are moved to Mattala Airport, with better landing facilities that would be appropriate.  “We are in discussion on those lines with the Civil Aviation Authority and to continue to increase the seating capacity for tourists to come to Sri Lanka,” Sri Lanka tourism officials said. From June onwards they worked on increasing the number of flights and today the Azure, Aeroflot, Swiss Air and Air France have started to fly to Sri Lanka, a Sri Lanka Tourism official said. Due to the increase we would be able to see a steady growth of travellers he added.  He also said from 18 December another flight will come to Sri Lanka and Fly Dubai will start three flights per day in the coming weeks.  We are targeting three million travellers in 2024 surpassing   the 1.5 million next year, the officials said. By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: Kushan claims he conducted probe on Asha Dissanayake
author: Author not found
Content: The CID informed Colombo Chief Magistrate Nandana Amerasinghe yesterday (1), that former Third Secretary of the Sri Lanka Embassy in Oman E. Kushan, had given them a statement, that while he had been employed there he had conducted a probe into alleged acts of human trafficking carried out by Asha Dissanayake and that he had then deported her to Colombo. The CID made this submission to Court, when the lawsuit related to the human trafficking ring, connected to Sri Lankan women in Oman, was convened. When the case was taken up, suspect Asha Dissanayake, who had been previously released on bail after being arrested and produced in Court, was also present. Later, the Chief Magistrate ordered suspect Asha Dissanayake, to be remanded till 13 December, to enable the CID to conduct a probe on her and due to the other suspects also being remanded in the case. The CID, prosecuting, informed Chief Magistrate Amerasinghe, that suspect E. Kushan had mentioned in his statement to them that he had served at the SL Embassy in Oman in the post of Third Secretary, from 4 August last year up to 20 November this year. They added that Kushan had stated that following the revelation of illegal acts committed by suspect Asha Dissanayake, he had carried out an inquiry and afterwards, had taken steps to extradite her to Sri Lanka. The prosecution then stated that further inquiries were yet proceeding and urged the Court, to issue an order for the imprisonment of the suspects, to expedite the on-going investigation. The request was granted by the Chief Magistrate, who ordered the suspects, to be remanded till the aforesaid date. By Hansi Nanayakkara

title: Dr Sanjeewa’s FR Petition fixed for support
author: Author not found
Content: The Fundamental Rights Petition, filed by Dr. Galmangoda Guruge Chamal Sanjeewa, who was interdicted based on several allegations, following statements recently made by him with regard to malnutrition among children in Suriyawewa, was fixed for support on 14 December by the Supreme Court yesterday (1). This was when the Petition was taken up before Supreme Court Justices Buwaneka Aluwihare, Mahinda Samayawardhena and Gamini Amarasekera. It was stated that Dr. Sanjeewa, in his capacity as the President of the Medical and Civil Rights Professional Association of Doctors, visited the Walsapugala Koswagawa village in Suriyawewa in Hambanthota District to conduct a medical clinic for children in order to check their nutrition levels, health and that accordingly he carried out a survey. Further, out of the 20 children whose clinic cards were observed, about six were at severe malnutrition levels and about 10 were at moderate malnutrition levels in the weight chart of the Child Health and Development Record (CHDR). It was stated in the Petition however that the statements made by him were embellished by certain media entities. While stating that he was interdicted on the basis that his acts were in violation of the Establishment Code, Dr. Sanjeewa further stated that the observations however made by him cannot be regarded as an act in violation of the provisions of the relevant Act. He said thereby that the decisions of the Respondents resulted in the infringement of Petitioner’s Fundamental Rights guaranteed under Article 12(1), 14(1)(a) and 14(1)(g) of the Constitution. title: Time for filing Income tax returns extended
author: Author not found
Content: State Minister of Finance Shehan Semasinghe informed Parliament that the deadline for filing income tax returns has been extended for another week from 30 November as the system had faced issues due to heavy usage. Semasinghe noted that no fine will be charged during the extended period. Samagi Jana Balawegaya MP J.C. Alawathuwala, raising concerns in Parliament yesterday (1) noted that the Income Tax entry software has been disabled. He queried whether the system failure was caused intentionally or not and added because of the issue the related work has been halted. State Minister Semasinghe, in response, revealed that the system has faced issues due to heavy usage which caused a traffic jam. Semasinghe emphasised that the failure was not an act of sabotage and that measures have been taken to rectify the issue with the system. Accordingly, all income tax returns filed during the extended period will be considered as those filed on or before 30 November, he added. BY Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: Chinese Embassy says they are encouraging IMF to help SL
author: Author not found
Content: The Chinese Embassy in Colombo tweeted yesterday (1) that China is a major shareholder of the International Monetary Fund (IMF) and that China has been encouraging the IMF and other international financial institutions to support Sri Lanka promptly. The Chinese Embassy also refuted Tamil National Alliance MP Shanakiyan Rasamanickam’s statement, made in Parliament on Thursday (30 November), “If China truly wishes to stand with the people of Sri Lanka during difficult times, it should participate in the debt restructuring process. From what I understand, the entire IMF negotiations have come to a halt as a result of this.” The Chinese Embassy further explained that China actively participated in all the creditor meetings of Sri Lanka and that China is not the only or the largest creditor of the island. MP Rasamanickam had said, “Tell me a single investment that the Chinese have made in this country where Sri Lankan people have been given employment? I’m not talking about labourers. If China is truly Sri Lanka’s friend, tell them to help with the IMF programme.” The Chinese Embassy tweeted in response that the MP’s understanding is incorrect and incomplete. “China is the biggest supporter of Sri Lanka in fighting Covid-19 and providing livelihood relief, including for the MP’s Batticaloa District and China is also the first responder to Sri Lanka’s financial crisis since its default in April this year.” The Chinese President and their Prime Minister had reiterated China’s willingness and readiness to help Sri Lanka in various occasions, the Chinese Embassy said. Further, the financial departments of both countries have been maintaining communication at high and working levels. Financial institutions of China reached out to the Ministry of Finance and the Central Bank of Sri Lanka in April without delay. Working teams of different banks visited the island. Bilateral negotiations are on, noted the Chinese Embassy on Twitter. By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: Amaraweera instructs to provide free fuel to farmers
author: Author not found
Content: Minister of Agriculture, Mahinda Amaraweera instructed officials to provide 6.89 million litres of the fuel donated by China to farmers free of charge for cultivation during the Maha season. Amaraweera noted that the fuel required for rice cultivation has been provided to farmers, Islandwide, without any shortcoming. Further, during a discussion held between Amaraweera and officials, it was noted that due to the lack of rain in the Anuradhapura district, maize cultivation has been damaged in many areas and that the damage caused by the Sena caterpillar is on the rise again. Meanwhile, a total of 851,043 hectares of paddy land is expected to be cultivated for the 2022/23 Maha season, the Ministry of Agriculture stated. According to the Department of Agrarian Development, the total amount of paddy land that has been sown thus far is 636,348 hectares.

title: Govt to help teachers buy sarees
author: Author not found
Content: The Government is considering providing relief for female teachers who have financial issues, to buy sarees to wear to school, Education Minister Susil Premajayantha said. Responding to Samagi Jana Balawegaya (SJB) MP Rohini Kumari Wijerathna, Premajayantha said he regrets to hear that some teachers are facing economic difficulties to buy sarees to wear to school. He also recalled the media reports that were circulating on social media regarding teacher’s attires and said it was an unfortunate incident as some teachers were facing difficulties. Wijerathna claimed the circular issued by the Public Administration Ministry Secretary has not specified the dress code either for teachers or State employees. She noted that the issue is not whether the teachers are wearing sarees or anything else, but the quality of education provided in schools. Speaking during the debate on Budget 2023 in Parliament yesterday (1) Wijerathna further said Sri Lankan parents are in the middle of two questions such as educating their children or feeding them as majority cannot afford both at the same time. Wijerathna said that most of the parents have not been able to fulfill both these things for their children. BY Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Charter flights to land at Mattala instead of BIA – Sri Lanka Tourism
author: Author not found
Content: Sri Lanka Tourism acknowledged that there is congestion at the Bandaranaike International Airport (BIA) due to construction etc. and they are hoping to move the charter operations to Mattala Airport as a remedy and part of a short-term plan as well. The Government is expecting to reach a target of 1.5 million tourists in 2023 and the Sri Lanka Tourism official added that the BIA congestion is a big issue and if charter flights are moved to Mattala Airport, with better landing facilities that would be appropriate.  “We are in discussion on those lines with the Civil Aviation Authority and to continue to increase the seating capacity for tourists to come to Sri Lanka,” Sri Lanka tourism officials said. From June onwards they worked on increasing the number of flights and today the Azure, Aeroflot, Swiss Air and Air France have started to fly to Sri Lanka, a Sri Lanka Tourism official said. Due to the increase we would be able to see a steady growth of travellers he added.  He also said from 18 December another flight will come to Sri Lanka and Fly Dubai will start three flights per day in the coming weeks.  We are targeting three million travellers in 2024 surpassing   the 1.5 million next year, the officials said. By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: Kushan claims he conducted probe on Asha Dissanayake
author: Author not found
Content: The CID informed Colombo Chief Magistrate Nandana Amerasinghe yesterday (1), that former Third Secretary of the Sri Lanka Embassy in Oman E. Kushan, had given them a statement, that while he had been employed there he had conducted a probe into alleged acts of human trafficking carried out by Asha Dissanayake and that he had then deported her to Colombo. The CID made this submission to Court, when the lawsuit related to the human trafficking ring, connected to Sri Lankan women in Oman, was convened. When the case was taken up, suspect Asha Dissanayake, who had been previously released on bail after being arrested and produced in Court, was also present. Later, the Chief Magistrate ordered suspect Asha Dissanayake, to be remanded till 13 December, to enable the CID to conduct a probe on her and due to the other suspects also being remanded in the case. The CID, prosecuting, informed Chief Magistrate Amerasinghe, that suspect E. Kushan had mentioned in his statement to them that he had served at the SL Embassy in Oman in the post of Third Secretary, from 4 August last year up to 20 November this year. They added that Kushan had stated that following the revelation of illegal acts committed by suspect Asha Dissanayake, he had carried out an inquiry and afterwards, had taken steps to extradite her to Sri Lanka. The prosecution then stated that further inquiries were yet proceeding and urged the Court, to issue an order for the imprisonment of the suspects, to expedite the on-going investigation. The request was granted by the Chief Magistrate, who ordered the suspects, to be remanded till the aforesaid date. By Hansi Nanayakkara

title: Dr Sanjeewa’s FR Petition fixed for support
author: Author not found
Content: The Fundamental Rights Petition, filed by Dr. Galmangoda Guruge Chamal Sanjeewa, who was interdicted based on several allegations, following statements recently made by him with regard to malnutrition among children in Suriyawewa, was fixed for support on 14 December by the Supreme Court yesterday (1). This was when the Petition was taken up before Supreme Court Justices Buwaneka Aluwihare, Mahinda Samayawardhena and Gamini Amarasekera. It was stated that Dr. Sanjeewa, in his capacity as the President of the Medical and Civil Rights Professional Association of Doctors, visited the Walsapugala Koswagawa village in Suriyawewa in Hambanthota District to conduct a medical clinic for children in order to check their nutrition levels, health and that accordingly he carried out a survey. Further, out of the 20 children whose clinic cards were observed, about six were at severe malnutrition levels and about 10 were at moderate malnutrition levels in the weight chart of the Child Health and Development Record (CHDR). It was stated in the Petition however that the statements made by him were embellished by certain media entities. While stating that he was interdicted on the basis that his acts were in violation of the Establishment Code, Dr. Sanjeewa further stated that the observations however made by him cannot be regarded as an act in violation of the provisions of the relevant Act. He said thereby that the decisions of the Respondents resulted in the infringement of Petitioner’s Fundamental Rights guaranteed under Article 12(1), 14(1)(a) and 14(1)(g) of the Constitution. The petitioner also sought compensation of Rs 10,000,000. Minister of Health Dr. Keheliya Rambukwella, Secretary to the Ministry of Health S. Janaka Sri Chandraguptha, Director General of Health Services Dr. Asela Gunawardena, Chairman of the Public Service Commission, the Attorney General and 18 others were named as respondents to the Petition. By Faadhila Thassim
