title: Consul General of Hungary counter-sues Captain Anil Ronald Jayasinghe for Rs 1B in damages
author: Author not found
Content: Captain Anil Jayasinghe instituted an action against Rohana Nanayakkara, Honorary Consul General of the Republic of Hungary (1st Defendant), Ceylon Carriers Pvt. Ltd. (2nd Defendant) and another, alleging that the Defendants in this case on or about 20 September 2022 made an attempt illegally and wrongfully to construct a roller gate obstructing the residents entering into the Royal Gardens Housing Complex and obtained an ex-parte enjoining order restraining the Defendants from disturbing and/ or interfering with the Plaintiff’s right to access over the right of way to a certain allotment of land and/or constructing a roller gate obstructing the same right of way situated at Royal Gardens, Rajagiriya. When the case came up before Colombo District Judge Poornima Gamage, the Consul General of Hungary Rohana Nanayakkara filed his Answer through his Attorney-at-Law G. G. Arulpragasam claiming one billion rupees in damages. In his Answer it has been stated that the Office of the Consul General of Hungary in Sri Lanka is situated at the premises bearing Assessment No. 288/12/L, Sri Jayawardenapura Mawatha, Fifth Lane, Royal Gardens, Rajagiriya and the said property is owned by Ceylon Carriers Pvt. Ltd. (2nd Defendant) and the Consul General of Hungary is the tenant of the said premises. Rohana Nanayakkara is the Honorary Consul General of Hungary in Sri Lanka and has been appointed as such by the Minister of Foreign Affairs of the Republic of Hungary and the said appointment had been subsequently approved by the President of Sri Lanka in 1993. It has been further stated that Rohana Nanayakkara has been recognised for all the charitable and international achievements obtained by him as the Honorary Consul of Hungary in Sri Lanka since 1993. In his Answer Rohana Nanayakkara, the Consul General of Hungary, has further stated that this action was instituted by Captain Anil Jayasinghe representing the interest of a purported unincorporated Association by the name of ‘Royal Gardens Resident’s Association’ and Captain Anil Jayasinghe has failed to comply with Section 16 of the Civil Procedure Code and thereby the said cause of action cannot stand in law and should be dismissed in limine. Rohana Nanayakkara, the Consul General of Hungary has further claimed in his Answer that the Office of the Honorary Consul of Hungary is disrupted by Captain Anil Jayasinghe and the Royal Gardens Resident’s Association by a rear gate installed across certain allotments of land which directly corners the Office of the Consul General towards one entrance and exit. Moreover, he has stated that the association to which the Captain Anil Jayasinghe is the secretary has never given him keys to the rear gate and since the Office of the Honorary Consul General is left with only one entrance and exit, it has renovated the gate towards the entrance of its allotment of land for the benefit of all residents of the Royal Gardens. It is the position of Rohana Nanayakkara, the Consul General of Hungary that Captain Anil Jayasinghe has maliciously instituted this action to disrupt and disengage the official work of the Office of the Consul General of Hungary and to cause as much damage and humiliation to the said office. In response to the action filed by Captain Anil Jayasinghe,. Rohana Nanayakkara, the Consul General of Hungary, has set out a Claim in Reconvention on the basis that Captain Anil Jayasinghe has instituted the instant action by suppression and misrepresentation of fact, with malicious intent to harm the reputation of Rohana Nanayakkara, the Consul General of Hungary, and without a valid cause of action against him. In his Answer it is also stated that the Consul General of the Consulate of Hungary in Sri Lanka is entitled to the immunities, facilities and privileges under sections 7U and section 7P of the Consular Relations Act No 18 of 2006 (as amended) and the institution of this action could affect the diplomatic relationships between the two countries and deeply affect the reputation maintained by Rohana Nanayakkara, the Consul General of Hungary, throughout his long career as a diplomat. Court having accepted the answer directed the Plaintiff to file his Replication on 12 December 2022 and as the Defendants have filed the Objections in regard to the application for Interim Injunction, Court ordered to file Written Submissions of all parties also on the 12 December 2022. President’s Counsel Kuvera de Zoysa with Attorneys-at-Law Niranjan Arulpragasam, Vinuri Abeyratne and Rasara Jayasuriya, instructed by Attorney-at-Law G.G. Arulpragasam, appeared on behalf of the Defendants, Honorary Consul General of the Consulate of Hungary in Sri Lanka Rohana Nanayakkara, Ceylon Carriers (Pvt) Ltd and Chaminda Ratnasiri. Attorney-at-Law Shivan Cooray with Attorneys-at-law Dinithi Panambara, Chamath Wijeratne and Viran Fernando, instructed by Attorney-at-Law Sanath Wijewardena appeared on behalf the Plaintiff Captain Anil Ronald Jayasinghe

title: Mahaweli H Zone Office saves FX
author: Author not found
Content: The Mahaweli H Zone Resident Business Office says several projects have been implemented by them to save valuable foreign exchange for the country. According to sources attached to the office, a kg of chillies is presently being sold at Rs 1,500. According to them, they expect to produce 10,000 metric tonnes of chillies during the upcoming Maha Season. By K.M. Chandika – Rajanganaya

title: Two arrested selling moonshine
author: Author not found
Content: The Batticaloa Police arrested two individuals from Puthur early yesterday (1), morning for selling moonshine and seized a large stock from their possession. Following a tip-off the Police raided two houses and made the arrest. The Narcotic Division of Batticaloa Police along with the Police Intelligence Unit launched a special operation to prevent the sale and consumption of narcotics in Batticalao Town and the suburban. By Naalir Jamaldeen

title: Japanese to invest in developing aquatic industry
author: Author not found
Content: Fisheries Minister Douglas Devananda said yesterday (1), that steps will be taken to develop the sea cucumber and shrimp farms with support from Japan. Devananda added, a group of Japanese investors had agreed to provide support to develop the aquatic industry of this country. The Minister met a group of investors at the Fisheries Ministry in Maligawatta Colombo to discuss the possibilities of getting their support to uplift the fishery industry, predominantly to promote sea cucumber and shrimp farms. Devananda said, the Japanese investors also presented several business reports on how they would invest and expressed their willingness to invest in Sri Lanka’s aquatic industry. Devananda said, he brought to the attention of Japanese investors that Sri Lanka is an ideal destination to make investments and added that he was happy with regard to the willingness of investors from a giant country in the Asian Continent to invest in Sri Lanka. By Naalir Jamaldeen

title: Six types of narcotics used in NP – Governor
author: Author not found
Content: Northern Province Governor Jeevan Thiagarajah claimed that six kinds of narcotics are being used in the Northern Province and t only one of them is being smuggled via sea route. Thiagarajah claimed that they cannot sit idly by and watch this. “Every possible effort will be put in place to thwart the smuggling and trafficking of narcotics into the Northern Province and transform it as a region free from narcotics”. Thiagarajah was speaking to the media with regard to the narcotic trade and consumption which have become rampant in the province. “We are closely monitoring the narcotic-related matters and it is a matter of concern. We have learnt from reliable sources that certain narcotic dealers are helping the young men to inject narcotics with syringes. It is a big issue the Northern Province is facing today. When I visited the Jaffna Prison recently I saw young men being detained for drug-related offenses and it is a matter of concern. Some persons are aware of who the traffickers are. Arrests are being made identifying the drug users. The narcotic users who are in detention custody are being question to detect the narcotic traders,” Thiagarajah said. Thiagarajah expressed confidence that many drug dealers will be trapped very soon and the operation to detect the culprits has been intensified, while claiming that this effort will not be stopped at any time. “The narcotic issue in the Northern Province cannot be stopped easily. It is not an issue exclusively for Northern Province. This problem prevails everywhere in the country. Nearly 500 vessels are going to sea and narcotics can be brought to the shore on board one or two of them. This will also be thwarted very soon,” Thiagarajah added. By Naalir Jamaldeen

title: Forest Dept clings on to land in Moneragala
author: Author not found
Content: A group of UNP organisers in the Moneragala District have brought to the attention of the President the continued occupation of several uncultivated lands by the Forest Conservation Department. Though the President, during one of his recent visits to the District, had informed officials from the Department to release such lands for cultivation, these instructions had fallen on deaf ears, the UNP organisers said. They stressed that persons trying to cultivate are chased away and they also charged the Department Officers work according to their own agenda. By Amith Maduranga Gamage

title: NMCRP CLAIMS LAW VIOLATED
author: Author not found
Content: The National Movement for Consumer Rights Protection (NMCRP) alleged that by the Minister of Finance and the Minister of Power submitting a proposal to the Cabinet to increase the electricity bill, the law of the country has been violated. Issuing a special statement in this regard, yesterday (1) Ranjith Vithanage, President of NMCRP said that it has been proposed to increase the electricity bill on the first of January 2023 and again in June 2023 in the background of the electricity bill being revised in August 2022. Vithanage points out that if the Electricity Board wants to make an amendment to the electricity bill, the relevant proposal should first be submitted to the Public Utilities Commission ofSri Lanka (PUCSL) then the necessary calculations should be made and the public opinion should be sought and the electricity bill amended. He says that this proposal has been submitted to the Cabinet in violation of the provisions of the Sri Lanka Electricity Act No. 20 of 2009, Section 30. He states that it is unfair and illegal to impose the loss on the consumer due to the careless control and fraud of the electricity board. Vithanage said it is ridiculous to increase the electricity bill while the government has announced that it expects a large economic growth rate in the year 2023. He further said the electricity consumer expects the Minister to get electricity at a reasonable rate and requested the government to withdraw the proposal to increase the electricity rates presented to the Cabinet. By Nabiya Vaffoor

According to sources attached to the office, a kg of chillies is presently being sold at Rs 1,500. According to them, they expect to produce 10,000 metric tonnes of chillies during the upcoming Maha Season. By K.M. Chandika – Rajanganaya

title: Two arrested selling moonshine
author: Author not found
Content: The Batticaloa Police arrested two individuals from Puthur early yesterday (1), morning for selling moonshine and seized a large stock from their possession. Following a tip-off the Police raided two houses and made the arrest. The Narcotic Division of Batticaloa Police along with the Police Intelligence Unit launched a special operation to prevent the sale and consumption of narcotics in Batticalao Town and the suburban. By Naalir Jamaldeen

title: Japanese to invest in developing aquatic industry
author: Author not found
Content: Fisheries Minister Douglas Devananda said yesterday (1), that steps will be taken to develop the sea cucumber and shrimp farms with support from Japan. Devananda added, a group of Japanese investors had agreed to provide support to develop the aquatic industry of this country. The Minister met a group of investors at the Fisheries Ministry in Maligawatta Colombo to discuss the possibilities of getting their support to uplift the fishery industry, predominantly to promote sea cucumber and shrimp farms. Devananda said, the Japanese investors also presented several business reports on how they would invest and expressed their willingness to invest in Sri Lanka’s aquatic industry. Devananda said, he brought to the attention of Japanese investors that Sri Lanka is an ideal destination to make investments and added that he was happy with regard to the willingness of investors from a giant country in the Asian Continent to invest in Sri Lanka. By Naalir Jamaldeen

title: Six types of narcotics used in NP – Governor
author: Author not found
Content: Northern Province Governor Jeevan Thiagarajah claimed that six kinds of narcotics are being used in the Northern Province and t only one of them is being smuggled via sea route. Thiagarajah claimed that they cannot sit idly by and watch this. “Every possible effort will be put in place to thwart the smuggling and trafficking of narcotics into the Northern Province and transform it as a region free from narcotics”. Thiagarajah was speaking to the media with regard to the narcotic trade and consumption which have become rampant in the province. “We are closely monitoring the narcotic-related matters and it is a matter of concern. We have learnt from reliable sources that certain narcotic dealers are helping the young men to inject narcotics with syringes. It is a big issue the Northern Province is facing today. When I visited the Jaffna Prison recently I saw young men being detained for drug-related offenses and it is a matter of concern. Some persons are aware of who the traffickers are. Arrests are being made identifying the drug users. The narcotic users who are in detention custody are being question to detect the narcotic traders,” Thiagarajah said. Thiagarajah expressed confidence that many drug dealers will be trapped very soon and the operation to detect the culprits has been intensified, while claiming that this effort will not be stopped at any time. “The narcotic issue in the Northern Province cannot be stopped easily. It is not an issue exclusively for Northern Province. This problem prevails everywhere in the country. Nearly 500 vessels are going to sea and narcotics can be brought to the shore on board one or two of them. This will also be thwarted very soon,” Thiagarajah added. By Naalir Jamaldeen

title: Another 70% Electricity Tariff Mooted
author: Author not found
Content: To recover the losses of Ceylon Electricity Board (CEB), another tariff hike by about 70 per cent is needed, Ceylon Electricity Board (CEB) officials told the National Council Sub Committee on Economic Stabilization. The tariff hike would be done under two steps in January and June 2023 according to Cabinet approval. Measures are to be taken for the purpose of obtaining approval of the Public Utilities Commission, said CEB Additional General Manager Rohan Seneviratne. It was also revealed at the committee that the CEB is planning to spend a loan which is expected to be received to pay back money the CEB owed to power suppliers. Accordingly, the CEB expects to make part payment to the electricity suppliers by obtaining a Rs 50 billion loan. It was also disclosed that the Electricity Board presently owes nearly Rs 650 billion as loans to various parties including banks and electricity suppliers. The CEB representative said, out of the amount, nearly Rs 35 billion is to be paid to the organisations that supplied renewable energy and Rs 75 billion is to be paid to thermal power suppliers. By Methmalie Dissanayake

title: Two circulars on ‘appropriate attire’ revoked
author: Author not found
Content: Two circulars on the dress code for public officers permitting them to wear appropriate attire to work was withdrawn with immediate effect by the Secretary to the Ministry of Public Administration, Home Affairs, Provincial Councils and Local Government M.M.P.K Mayadunne yesterday (30). Accordingly, Public Administration Circular 13/2019 and Public Administration Circular letter 05/2022 were revoked while the circular issued in 1989 on attire for staff grade and other circulars applicable to uniform of officers will be valid. According to Public Administration Circular 13/2019, when public officers arrive at their office premises during the office hours, male officers should be dressed in trouser and shirt or national dress while female officers should be dressed in saree, Kandyan saree (Osari) or any other appropriate and modest attire so as to preserve the dignity of the public service. An officer should always be dressed in a manner which exposes the full face (except ears) and causes no hindrance to the provisions made with regard to public security. Further, the officers who are already receiving a uniform/uniform allowance should engage in their duties dressed in his/her approved uniform. Female officers in the public service should, during pregnancy, wear attire which is appropriate and convenient for them.  This was followed by Public Administration Circular letter 05/2022 precluding female public officers from having to compulsorily wear only saree or Kandyan saree (Osari) to office, while it was stated that public officers should be allowed to dress appropriate and modest attire so as to preserve the dignity of the public service. Thereby, these two circulars were revoked by way of Public Administration Circular 26/2022 issued to the Secretaries of Ministries, Chief Secretaries of Provinces and Heads of Departments. By Faadhila Thassim

title: Deploy military to ‘combat’ whitefly menace
author: Author not found
Content: MP Anura Priyadarshana Yapa requested Minister of Plantation Industries Dr. Ramesh Pathirana to deploy the military and helicopters to eradicate the whitefly menace that has affected coconut cultivation in the country badly. However, Dr. Pathirana said, it is not possible to deploy helicopters and spray chemicals as the whitefly is on the other side of the coconut leaf. Yapa: “Whitefly disease should be considered as a ‘war’ because this is a huge threat to the coconut cultivation. If actions are not taken now, coconut cultivation will vanish from the country. Chemicals have to be sprayed in a wide area. Therefore, I request the Plantation Minister to consider deploying the military.” The Plantation Industries Minister said chemicals have been distributed to several areas with machines at the moment. “I think we can control this disease,” he said. By Methmalie Dissanayake

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: No night power cut in tourism zones
author: Author not found
Content: Minister of Power and Energy Kanchana Wijesekara said Southern and Ella tourism zones will be exempted from the 1 hour 20 minutes night time power cut from 1 December. However, the islandwide power cut of 1 hour during the day and 1 hour 20 minutes during the night will be continued until 15 December. In a power management update, he said, with the scheduled addition of Unit 3 of Coal Plant to the Grid on 15 December, all tourism zones identified by the Ministry of Tourism will be exempted from night power cuts and islandwide night power cuts will be reduced to 1 hour. However, there will be no power cuts during Christmas and New Year. Meanwhile, Chairman of the Public Utilities Commission of Sri Lanka said in reference to communiqué by Minister of Power and Energy, the Ceylon Electricity Board was granted approval for power cuts until 30 November only. He said, no approval has been granted yet for power cuts beyond 30 November. Further, the Ceylon Electricity Board’s request for 3-hour power cuts on 25 November was rejected by the Public Utilities Commission of Sri Lanka and they were only granted 2-hour 20-minute power cuts. (TR)

title: SL owes Chinese lenders USD 7.4B – CARI
author: Author not found
Content: Sri Lanka owed Chinese lenders USD 7.4 billion – nearly a fifth of its public external debt – by the end of last year, calculations by the China Africa Research Initiative (CARI) published on Wednesday showed, an estimate higher than many others. The figure was above the “often-quoted 10 to 15 per cent figures,” the study said, adding a “significant portion” of the country’s debt to China had been recorded under lending to State-Owned Enterprises rather than Central Government. Crisis-hit Sri Lanka is in the midst of a debt restructuring after years of economic mismanagement combined with the Covid-19 pandemic saw the country plunge into the worst economic crisis since independence from Britain in 1948 and tip into default. Export-Import Bank of China (Exim Bank) and China Development Bank are the two largest Chinese lenders, accounting for USD 4.3 billion and USD 3 billion respectively, according to the data collected by CARI at the Johns Hopkins University School of Advanced International Studies. China is Sri Lanka’s largest bilateral creditor and, with India and Japan, part of official creditor talks to restructure the country’s debt. “China will have to play a major role in Sri Lanka’s debt restructuring process,” CARI researchers Umesh Moramudali and Thilina Panduwawala wrote in the report. The island nation kicked off talks with bilateral creditors in September after securing a Staff Level Agreement of USD 2.9 billion with the International Monetary Fund. But financing will not flow until the fund’s board approves the deal, a step that requires financial assurances from bilateral lenders. The latest talks initially expected earlier this month were postponed, casting doubt over how fast the debt rework can progress. The island nation’s total external debt is USD 37.6 billion, according to the report. Adding central bank foreign currency debt, including a USD 1.6 billion currency swap with China, public external debt rises to USD 40.6 billion, of which 22 per cent is from Chinese creditors. CARI’s total debt numbers differ from the USD 46.6 billion tally published by the Government in September as it excludes local hard-currency debt and loans to some State-owned enterprises. The CARI study also identified six different loans to the deep water port in Hambantota from Exim Bank between 2007 and 2013 for around USD 1.3 billion. The loan agreements have clauses that “submit the loans to Chinese governing law and arbitration before the China International Economic and Trade Arbitration Commission.” (Reuters)

title: COPF greenlights Tax Bill
author: Author not found
Content: The Committee on Public Finance (COPF) pointed out, decreasing export taxes should be considered during the Committee Stage of the Inland Revenue (Amendment) Bill. The COPF instructed the Ministry of Finance and the Department of Inland Revenue to indicate the expected revenue for each export sector by increasing the export tax of 14 per cent to 30 per cent. The committee pointed out that instead of short-term efforts to increase the Government’s income by raising export taxes, long-term action should be taken, and export taxes should be collected so as not to discourage exporters who bring dollars to the country. Therefore, the Chairman of the committee said the draft Bill should be considered pertaining to the lowering of the export tax percentage at the Committee Stage. COPF Chairman Dr. Harsha de Silva instructed Finance Ministry officials that an analytical report be submitted on the increase of export levy as per the Inland Revenue (Amendment) Bill which is expected to be passed in Parliament. Further, he informed officials to submit a detailed report on the amount of income obtained falling under the respective export sectors in consideration of the previous tax rates. The proposed increase in Personal Income Tax was also discussed at the COPF. The committee informed the officials to present a comparative analysis with the existing conditions of other countries in the region. Thus, subject to the above instructions, the Inland Revenue (Amendment) Bill received the approval of the COPF.

title: SJB submits Anti-Corruption Bill
author: Author not found
Content: The Samagi Jana Balawegaya (SJB) has submitted an Anti-Corruption Bill to Secretary-General of Parliament to prepare a legal system to eliminate corruption, SJB General Secretary Ranjith Maddumabandara said yesterday (30). Speaking to the media, Maddumabandara said Sri Lanka has fallen further from being 92nd last year to 106th in the Corruption Perceptions Index, as the country lacks an anti-corruption system. “That is why the country has fallen into this crisis today. Today, we have an Anti-Corruption Bill. Everyone knows that this country has become bankrupt because of large-scale corruption. Developed countries got to where they are because they have measures to prevent corruption,” he said.   By Nabiya Vaffoor

title: Ven. Sirisumana, Isuru Bandara granted bail
author: Author not found
Content: Colombo Fort Magistrate Thilina Gamage yesterday (30), ordered suspects Ven. Borelle Siri Sumana Thera and Isuru Bandara (Thilini Priyamali’s business partner), who were remanded on charges of being mired in the financial scams of fraudster Priyamali, to be enlarged on cash bail and on two sureties of Rs 10 million each. However, the Magistrate ordered the main suspect, scammer Priyamali and her two accomplices Janaki Siriwardene and Kasun Harshana, to be further remanded till 13 December. Magistrate Gamage mentioned that he was ordering the three suspects to be further remanded, in lieu of the fact that their release on bail, could seriously hinder, the ongoing probe by the CID. However, he ordered the main suspect Priyamali, to be granted bail with regard to a case filed against her, where she has been charged before the same Court, concerning a financial scam amounting to Rs 800,000. The CID prosecuting told the Court, that following investigations conducted to date, they have received seven complaints pertaining to the involvement of the main suspect (Priyamali), in large-scale financial fraud. They said as per orders obtained from Court, they had perused bank account details of the main suspect and that further investigations into the incident were ongoing. The prosecution further pointed out to the Fort Magistrate, that the ongoing probe had also shed light to the fact, that the main suspect had run a business in Dubai and that it had been registered under her name. The CID said to expedite the ongoing probe, they had also sought further information in this connection, from the CBSL and Interpol. They noted that accordingly, they will be submitting a detailed report to Court, concerning the evidence they had gathered thus far against each of the suspects. The prosecution then submitted 19 statements, along with evidence to the Fort Magistrate. They added that four reports of evidence was being submitted by them against suspect monk Ven. Borelle Siri Sumana Thera, six reports of evidence against suspect Janaki Siriwardene and three such reports related to suspect Isuru Bandara. Considering the submissions, the Court, deferred further proceedings of the trial to the said date. By Hansi Nanayakkara

title: Services at Pottuvil Base Hospital hampered
author: Author not found
Content: State hospital services of the Eastern Province are compromised due to an alleged conflict of interest between the doctors of Base Hospital Pottuvil and its Medical Superintendent. Media Committee Member of the Government Medical Officers’ Association (GMOA), Dr. Thanigaivasan Ratnasingam yesterday (30) said due to safety concerns regarding several of its members who were serving at the hospital, the Union had decided to withdraw them and station them at the office of the Provincial Director of Health Services (PDHS), Trincomalee. At present, only four doctors were stationed at BH Pottuvil as a result. The dilemma ensued when the Regional Director of Kalmunai who was supposed to be appointed to the post of Medical Superintendent was usurped by another administrator who also happened to be the owner of a private hospital in the area. The GMOA Media Committee Member accused the incumbent Medical Superintendent of Pottuvil of misconduct. His poor administration, harassment of medical officers who expose malpractice, and the conflict of interest due to the private hospital in the area owned by the particular Medical Superintendent were among allegations levelled against him. He accused the Medical Superintendent of harassing those who opposed his administration in the interest of patients who sought the services of the State hospital. The actions of a group of persons who with the knowledge of its present Administrator had breached hospital security had created an unsafe situation for its medical officers, Dr. Ratnasingam alleged, noting that steps had been take to inform the Director General of Health Services (DGHS) and the provincial authorities, to no avail. By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: Four Party leaders decide to keep away
author: Author not found
Content: The leaders of four Parties in the UPFA had sent separate letters to the alliance’s Leader, Maithripala Sirisena, informing him that they would not participate in the executive council meeting scheduled for 29 November afternoon. The party leaders specifically state that they accept that only Mahinda Amaraweera, the General Secretary of the UPFA, has the authority to convene an executive council meeting in this manner, and that the Leader of the UPFA does not. Thus, it has been stated that Amaraweera’s letter to the alliance’s leader, explaining the situation, is correct. Letters have been sent by National Congress Chief Secretary and MP A.L.M. Athaullah, Eelam People’s Democratic Party General Secretary and Minister Douglas Devananda, Mahajana Eksath Peramuna General Secretary Tissa Jayawardena, and Desha Vimukthi Janatha Party Chief Secretary D. Kalansuriya. (TR)

title: 14% of all leprosy cases are children under 14
author: Author not found
Content: Sri Lanka tops the list of countries in which children have been diagnosed with leprosy, the Anti Leprosy Campaign (ALC) revealed. Speaking to the media at the Health Promotion Bureau (HPB), Consultant Dermatologist Anti Leprosy Campaign, Dr. Indira Kahawita yesterday (30) said out of the total leprosy cases detected this year, 14 per cent were children below 14 years. Sri Lanka presently has the highest number of children who have been diagnosed with leprosy while the rest of the world has only 4.8 per cent children diagnosed with leprosy. Fielding questions, Dr. Kahawita said statistics should be brought down to ‘zero’ if the slow-growing Mycobacterial disease was to be controlled in the country. Leprosy was controlled in the island in 1995. However, the slowed down progress of the detection rate within the past two years led to an increase of the number of undiagnosed cases this year. Only 10 per cent of the newly detected cases were children in 2020 and 2021, she said.  “If Sri Lanka was to keep with the guidelines for leprosy eradication given by the World Health Organization (WHO) and bring the disease under control once more, the number of child cases should be zeroed,” Dr. Kahawita explained, adding that this would be a challenge to the ALC, as it could not give a set time period during which this could be achieved. However, if the spread is to be controlled, the detection and awareness process should be boosted, Dr. Kahawita added. Director of the ALC, Dr. Prasad Ranaweera said, from January till date the Campaign had had been able to detect 1,200 new cases – 459 cases during the first seven months of this year and another 750 within the last three months due to its extensive awareness campaigns. He said in 2020 a total 1,200 cases had been diagnosed while last year 1,016 cases had been diagnosed with the disease caused by Mycobacterium leprae.  By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: Teachers aren’t Staff Grade Officers – CTU
author: Author not found
Content: The Ceylon Teachers Union (CTU) claimed that revoking the two circulars issued in 2019 and 2022 stipulating a dress code for Staff Grade Officers in State sector cannot stop teachers from wearing appropriate attire for their duty, as teachers do not come under the category of Staff Grade Officers. Speaking to Ceylon Today, CTU General Secretary Joseph Stalin claimed that since there is no particular dress code specified for schoolteachers and since they do not come under the category of Staff Grade Officers, they do not have to abide by it. “The Government is carrying out a campaign that CTU is trying to force female teachers not to wear saree. It is absolutely the wrong picture. What we say is whoever wants to continue wear the saree may wear it, as well as the teachers who want to wear attire that is not a saree also should have the right to do so. Since revoking these previous circulars affects all the Staff Grade Officers we will wait and see what action is taken,” he added. By Nabiya Vaffoor

title: Gem fair re-started in Kahawattta town
author: Author not found
Content: A gem fair has been organised in Kahawattta town aimed at selling and purchasing of gems for both traders and buyers. This particular gem fair was opened last week and it will function every Monday from 6:30 am in Kahawatta town. This fair is organised by the Kahawatta United Trade Union and they said the purpose of this fair is to develop the gem industry by restarting the gem fair which had been in operation in the town in the past. By L. Niroshana – Kahawatta

title: Mobile sales outlets set up
author: Author not found
Content: To empower women in socioeconomic and development activities and allow them to stand on their own feet, the Affected Women Forum set up two mobile sales outlets in front of the Alayadivembu Divisional Secretariat, which were ceremoniously opened on Monday by Alayadivembu Divisional Secretary, V. Pavakaran. The ceremony was also attended by Chairman of the Alayadivembu Pradeshiya Sabha T. Kirojatharan, Assistant Director of Planning M.A. Hussaindeen, Coordinator Sioman Vaani, Project Coordinator Vaani Sutha and members of the Will Club. These mobile sales outlets pave the way for women to be self-employed and stand on their own feet. Text and Pic By M.A.P. Deen – Ampara

title: Three books on Islamic heritage launched
author: Author not found
Content: The Department of Cultural Affairs Eastern Province in association with the Department of Muslim Religious And Cultural Affairs launched three books on Islamic heritage, namely ‘Kaseetha’ (Islamic songs derived from Saudi Arabia), ‘Pakkeer Baith’ (rabban beatings with Islamic songs), and ‘Kalikambu’ – Folk Art (Sri Lankan Muslims’ traditional art of dance with sticks) and released a CD (visuals with narration of these three Islamic books) at a ceremony held at the Conference Hall of Akkaraipattu Divisional Secretariat. This was presided over by Divisional Secretary Ash-Sheikh T.M. Ansar (Naleemi). Our pictures show District Cultural Coordinator A.L. Thowfeek launching the first copy of ‘Kaseetha’ to former Director of Muslim Religious and Cultural Affairs A.B.M. Ashraff and former Director of Cultural Affairs E.P. Saravanamuthu Navaneethan while Author Ashroff Shihabdeen looks on. Text and Pic By M.A.P. Deen – Ampara

title: Wooing Japanese with cuisine
author: Author not found
Content: Embassy of Japan in Sri Lanka collaborated with the National Youth Services Council (NYSC) and conducted a demonstration on preparing and serving of Washoku dishes on Monday (28 November),  Japan’s Embassy in Sri Lanka said on Tuesday (29 November). ‘Washoku’  is a traditional Japanese cuisine which is integral to Japanese culture, hence, important in attracting Japanese tourists to Sri Lanka, it said. The cuisine comprises a bowl of rice prepared with several side dishes.  The Kanji character “和” in this regard means harmony, important to the Japanese psyche. This not only helps people appreciate the meal, but also adds another level of depth to the meals, the Embassy said.  Above demonstration dishes included Karaage (fried chicken), Chicken Nanban (chicken with vinegar and tartar sauce ) and Chicken Teriyaki (Sweet soy sauce-glazed chicken). NYSC cookery course students as well as instructors and NYSC leaders attended this demonstration. (PA)

title: PM hails S. Korean assistance to SL
author: Author not found
Content: Prime Minister Dinesh Gunawardena said, South Korean assistance to Sri Lanka by imparting knowledge and providing assistance in many fields is all the more praiseworthy as it is a continuous process. He pointed out that the Association of KOICA Fellows in Sri Lanka (AKOFE) continues to undertake many welfare measures keeping up with the Korea’s magnanimous gesture of assisting Sri Lanka. Addressing the AKOFE friendship event in Colombo on 28 November, the Prime Minister said the deep friendship and bilateral relations between the Republic of Korea and Sri Lanka continue to flourish to a remarkable level at present. Collaborations between the two countries also exist at a greater level including in academia, science and technology, defence, and cultural relations, he said. “Lankan officials are highly impressed with the Korean Development Model and Human Resources Capacity Development Activity Plans of Korea and I am happy to note that they are putting them into practice in Sri Lanka,” he said. Premier Gunawardena thanked the AKOFE Executive Committee for helping many hospitals and schools in Sri Lanka by donating health equipment, school equipment, and student requirements. “In my electorate, Pagngnagula Maha Vidyalaya Thummodara and Puwakpitiya Roman Catholic Vidyalaya are two very needy schools that received such help from AKOFE.” Speaker Mahinda Yapa Abeywardena, South Korean Ambassador Santhush Woonjin Jeong, KOICA Country Director Kim Myung Jin, and AKOFE President Romesh Serasinghe were also present on this occasion.

title: Josephian Christmas Carols 2022
author: Author not found
Content: The much awaited annual event of St. Joseph’s College, Colombo, gains an added significance, as the frontier Catholic College has just crossed its 125th anniversary milestone. The Josephian Christmas Carols 2022, titled ‘Jesu Redemptor Omnium’ will be held on 4 December, commencing at 6:30 p.m. at the College Auditorium. His Excellency the Archbishop, Brian Udaigwe, the Papal Nuncio to Sri Lanka, will grace the occasion as the Chief Guest. The spectacular presentation will include Carols, Anthems, Chants, and Choruses by modern and classical composers in English, Latin, French, Deutsche, Italian, Nigerian, as well as in the local languages. The 75-strong senior choir of the college, the 40-member primary school choir, as well as the international award-winning Old Boys Choir will render selected compositions in elegant harmony before an expected congregation of 2,000 people.

title: FMETU highlights sad working conditions of journos
author: Author not found
Content: General Secretary of the Federation of Media Employees’ Trade Unions (FMETU) M. Dharmasiri Lankapeli and Deputy General Secretary Indira Navagamuwa held a discussion with Minister of Labour and Foreign Employment Manusha Nanayakkara on 22 November, at the Ministry, which highlighted the sad working conditions of professional journalists in Sri Lanka. The FMETU explained in this discussion that professional journalists in Sri Lanka lack basic rights. The report compiled a unique exploration of the professional status of journalists and the challenges faced by the media industry by the FMETU. The matter was clarified to the Minister. The IFJ-Union to Union (UTU) Global Union programme with the guidance and support of the International Federation of Journalists (IFJ) organised this programme. The Minister agreed to hold a broad discussion on the professional issues faced by journalists and the challenges faced by the media industry on 13 December with a large representation of journalists. (SRM)

title: Personal dispute leads to stabbing
author: Author not found
Content: Hikkaduwa Police said three unidentified persons who arrived in a black car had stabbed a couple in front of a restaurant in Hikkaduwa yesterday (30). Police said following the stabbing, the husband had succumbed to his injuries, while his wife had been admitted to the Karapitiya Teaching Hospital in a critical condition.  The deceased is M. Prasanna, a tourist guide from Thiranagama, Hikkaduwa. Police added that a personal dispute led to the stabbing. The car used by the assailants was found abandoned near the crime scene. Hikkaduwa Police are conducting further investigations. By Kamal Wiijehewa – Galle

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Leisure complex planned at Yala National Park
author: Author not found
Content: Minister of Wildlife and Forest Resources Conservation Mahinda Amaraweera instructed Director General of Wildlife, Chandana Sooriyabandara to construct a leisure complex at Yala National Park for tourists to rest and recuperate. Amaraweera said while around 400 vehicles with local and foreign tourists visit the park daily, they have not had a suitable place to rest, while vehicles have been parked in a way that hinders wildlife.  Accordingly, a plot of land in the Patanangala Block B section of the forest has been allocated to build the rest area, which can accommodate at least 200 vehicles. “This rest area will be built in such a way that it does not harm flora and fauna while food and beverages and educational programmes to educate tourists about flora and fauna of Sri Lanka will also be made available in this area,” Amaraweera said. The Wildlife Conservation Department plans to spend Rs 56 million on this project.

title: Four missing fishers rescued off Andaman Islands
author: Author not found
Content: Valaichchenai Fishery Harbour Manager G. Vijitharan yesterday (30) said they learnt from reliable sources that four Valaichchenai fishermen who went missing had been rescued. He said these fishermen had been rescued by the Indian Coast Guard while stranded in the high seas near the Andaman Islands. Vijitharan said the fisherman faced an engine issue and were swept away by the tide. “The rescued fishermen were taken to Chennai Harbour and provided with food and medical treatment,” Vijitharan said. “The four fishermen had gone to deep sea from Valaichchenai Fishery Harbour in mid October and have been missing since. A search operation with the help of Sri Lanka Navy and the fishermen in the area had been launched in the deep and shallow seas off Valaichchenai. However, their efforts were futile and eventually the search operation was called off,” Vijitharan further said. Steps will be taken to repatriate the fishermen to Sri Lanka in consultation with the relevant authorities including Fisheries Minister Douglas Devananda, Vijitharan added. By Naalir Jamaldeen

title: Abeywardana vows to unite all politicians
author: Author not found
Content: UNP Chairman, MP Wajira Abeywardana vowed to gain the trust of leaders and members of all political parties to resolve the country’s present economic crisis. He added that President Ranil Wickremesinghe has been making every effort to resolve the country’s economic crisis, and that it is the bounden duty of people’s representatives and every citizen to work with him until the problems are resolved. He was speaking to the media in Colombo about the economic crisis and the timely measures being taken by the President to restore normalcy. “2022 is a special year for Sri Lanka because on one hand there was a revolution and on the other there was anarchy. This year can be named as a year in which a non-violent peaceful struggle and a terroristic struggle sparked in the country,” MP Abeywardana said. MP Abeywardana also said all people’s representatives must unite to restore normalcy in the country, setting aside their personal disputes and narrow political agendas. By Naalir Jamaldeen

title: Matale farmers hard hit by dry spell
author: Author not found
Content: Farmers in the Matale District said due to the sudden change in the weather conditions they are presently facing serious issues with regard to carrying out farming. They said the recent dry spell in the District had seriously hampered their cultivations. These farmers said due to the increase in dry days and also irregular setting of monsoons had dealt a severe blow to continuing with their cultivations. By I.A. Kumara – Naula

title: WB assures continuous support to SL
author: Author not found
Content: Prime Minister Dinesh Gunawardena held discussions with World Bank Country Director Chiyo Kanda and senior Strategy and Operations officials about the progress of ongoing projects and proposed future projects. The Prime Minister briefed the delegation about the steps taken by the Government to overcome economic challenges and said the new reforms would result in early conclusion of monetary arrangements with the International Monetary Fund (IMF). The WB Director expressed satisfaction over the short-term measures to ease the economic situation and stressed the need for continuous medium-term and long-term efforts. She assured continuous support to Sri Lanka. They exchanged views on the new reforms, including monetary and fiscal reforms which will soon be passed by Cabinet and Parliament to pull the country out of its present economic crisis. With most prior actions including but not limited to revenue enhancing policies, market pricing of energy and the commitment to restructure loss making State-owned enterprises have been either already implemented or embarked on, the Prime Minister said. The Government is committed to work on food security and export crop production, even amid the difficult situation, he stressed. The delegation noted the IMF package to unlock USD 2.9 billion over a four-year period as very good progress is being made on the debt-restructuring front. World Bank Director of Strategy and Operations for South Asia, Illango Patchamuthu, Senior Operations Officer Asela Dissanayake, and Additional Secretary to the Prime Minister, Mahinda Gunaratne also participated in the discussion.

title: Buying pressure on treasuries
author: Author not found
Content: Government of Sri Lanka’s (GoSL’s) at least theoretical money printing borrowing costs (MPBCs) decreased for the second consecutive market day to Tuesday (29 November), this time by 1.66 per cent (Rs 2,311.13 million) to Rs 136,895.07 million, due to ‘sustained’ buying pressure of Treasury Bills and T Bonds in secondary market trading because of high yields offered by the same due to near-record high inflation, coupled with the belief that yields/rates will fall in the near term. Yields/rates increase to counter high inflation so as to entice investors to invest in the fixed income market. Further, when yields/rates fall, it’s an advantage to investors who have already invested in T Bills and T Bonds when such were high, because, then they can maximise their profits, either by holding it to maturity or by selling such in secondary market trading at a profit. Swap settlements between GoSL and the Central bank of Sri Lanka (CBSL) and/or between CBSL and the market  saw a liquidity uplift of Rs 38,432 million (USD 105.87 million) on Tuesday. Conversions are based on the value of the administered and benchmark official ‘spot,’ fixed at Rs 363 to the US dollar on Friday (25 November). GoSL’s face value (FV) MP debt decreased  by 0.50 per cent (Rs 16,472 million) to Rs 3,261,216.50 million (Rs 3.2612 trillion) on Tuesday, thereby marginally defraying demand-pull inflationary pressure. Market shortfall decreased for the second consecutive market day to Tuesday, this time by 5.51 per cent (Rs 21,960 million) to Rs 376,516 million, nonetheless causing sustained rate pressure. Market was also short for a record 301 market days to Tuesday. GoSL’s FVMP debt has been over Rs 3 trillion for a record consecutive 100 market days to Tuesday due to a persistent lack of revenue. GoSL’s highest to the 305th highest FVMP debt has been recorded in the 305 consecutive market days to Tuesday. CBSL which administers daily open market operations (OMO) lacks transparency. GoSL’s FVMP debt is equivalent to the totality of CBSL’s T Bill and T Bond holdings. MP is the exclusive right of CBSL. GoSL’s MPBCs are prorated to the outcome in secondary market trading of T Bills and T Bonds on the reference day. ‘Spot’ trades are settled after two market days from the date of transaction. CBSL, the steward of GoSL debt and its foreign reserves deals in ‘spot.’ The ‘spot’ is administered to minimise GoSL’s foreign debt in rupee terms and to lower the cost of energy imports which are met from the country’s foreign reserves and not from the market, to prevent further depreciative pressure on the rupee, as Sri Lanka is an import-dependent economy. Transactions between CBSL and GoSL are foreign reserves-neutral. By Paneetha Ameresekere

title: 54 new leprosy patients detected in Galle
author: Author not found
Content: Galle District Regional Epidemiologist Dr. Eranga Hettiarachchi said 54 new leprosy patients had been detected in the District during the past 11 months. He said among these new patients was a child below 14. According to Dr. Hettiarachchi, a total of 56 leprosy patients had been detected last year, 62 in 2022, and 75 in 2019 from the Galle District. However, he added that when analysing the data it had become evident to them that in the past few years there has been a marked reduction in the number of patients afflicted with leprosy. He said they have decided to conduct skin clinics in Galle, Elpitiya, and Hikkaduwa, where a sizeable number of leprosy patients had been identified. By Kamal Wijehewa – Galle

title: 28-year-old arrested in Kandy
author: Author not found
Content: Kandy Police arrested a 28-year-old for pouring kerosene oil and setting on fire a 17-year-old in Ampitiya, Meekanuwa area in the Kandy District. Police said the suspect is a gang member who was involved in various crimes in the area. A live grenade was also recovered following interrogation.  Police said the victim had obtained 9As in the G.C.E. Ordinary Level Examination. The incident had occurred when the victim was returning home after visiting Ampitiya town with his parents in the night, Police said.  The suspect, who approached with a fire brand and kerosene, had tried to set the victim alight. The victim’s parents intervened and saved their son. However, the victim sustained critical injuries to his neck and hands. The victim underwent a surgery at the Kandy Teaching Hospital. Kandy Police said the suspect is a drug addict. He was arrested and further investigations are underway. By Naalir Jamaldeen

title: Proposals aimed at NGOs
author: Author not found
Content: Ven. Wadduwe Dhammawansa Thera of the Sri Lanka Ramanna Maha Nikaya said proposals being mooted to prevent boys below the age of 15 from being ordained as novice Buddhist monks are purely aimed at appeasing NGOs. He said the country’s Buddhist clergy should come forward to highlight their pressing issues with regard to the religion rather than becoming pawns of trade unions that are funded by foreign NGOs. By Janaka Hettiarachchi – Wadduwa

title: Several gallons of water wasted
author: Author not found
Content: Informed sources said a water pipe at the Panadura General Hospital had burst and that as a result a large quantity of water had been wasted over eight years. They said constant reminders to hospital authorities have fallen on deaf ears. A source at the main office of the hospital said they had brought the issue to the attention of the NWSDB and that its officers had arrived and taken a look at the burst pipe. He said they had promised to carry out urgent repairs. By Sumith Ranawaka – Pothupitiya
