title: Digana three-wheeler fares still sky high
author: Author not found
Content: Residents of Digana town say though the Government had reduced fuel prices thrice in the recent past, there has not been a noticeable reduction in three-wheeler fares in the area. Resident of Digana, Rajawella, Senarathwela, Kengalla and Ginawela said despite the recent reduction in fuel prices by the Government, such relief has not been passed on to consumers. They alleged that three-wheeler drivers in the aforesaid areas continue to charge exorbitant fares from the masses according to their own whims and fancies with no mechanism to monitor such activity. When contacted, Head of the Digana Three-Wheeler Drivers’ Union, Indika Rathnayake said though the public clamour for a fare reduction, they cannot grant such relief due to costs of spare parts and other expenses having increased. He said though the fuel price has been reduced, they have to incur heavy losses due to cost of spare parts being high and noted if the Government were to bring prices down they would be able to grant some relief to the public. By D. Wanniarachchi – Kandy

title: GOVT EXPLORES RETENTION STRATEGIES
author: Author not found
Content: In the backdrop of doctors leaving the country en masse owing to the economic crisis, threatening the stability of the health sector, the Government is trying to find solutions to retain them. Accordingly, foreign missions in Colombo have been requested not to grant visas to doctors if they do not have permission from the Health Ministry to go overseas and Immigration Officers at the airport have been instructed to check whether doctors who travel overseas have applied for leave. President Ranil Wickremesinghe said a solution is needed to address the exodus of doctors and engineers. “The Government spends Rs 6 million on each medical student.  This much of money is being spent with the intention of getting their services for the country, but instead they migrate. This has become a serious issue. We have to find a solution, as this has been ongoing for many years,” the President said. “In that case, we have provided far greater aid to those countries than the aid these countries provide us with,” he added. Meanwhile, Minister of Health Keheliya Rambukwella, who said around 300 doctors have left the country since January this year, warned there is a possibility of the Sri Lankan health sector collapsing as a result. Rambukwella in response to a question of Opposition Leader Sajith Premadasa, said the ministry gives permission to doctors to work overseas only for five years. Doctors who travel overseas without permission will be blacklisted and their licences issued by the Sri Lanka Medical Council (SLMC) will be revoked, so that they will not be able to practice medicine abroad. By Methmalie Dissanayake

title: Finish exams and make way for new enrolments
author: Author not found
Content: Education Minister Susil Premajayantha said students in State universities should be allowed to take examinations free of charge only on a limited number of occasions. The Minister observed it was up to the University Grants Commission (UGC) to decide the precise number of times that the students should be allowed to sit for examinations. Premajayantha added that due to actions of certain students who tend to spend years in the university system without sitting for examinations, the opportunity for new enrolments has been seriously curtailed. Hence, the Minister remarked that the onus was on students to sit for their requisite examinations on time and then serve the country via their chosen streams rather than wasting their time by joining trade unions. By Kumudu Upul Shantha

title: Construction of 26 electric fences hindered
author: Author not found
Content: The construction of over 26 electric fences that was due to be completed in 2022 has been hindered due to objections raised by villagers, Secretary to the Ministry of Wildlife and Forest Resources Conservation, Chandra Herath said. This was said during a meeting held with Minister of Wildlife and Forest Resources Conservation Mahinda Amaraweera to discuss progress on the electric fence projects. The total distance covered under the said project for the construction of 26 fences is 315 kilometres including districts with raging human-elephant conflicts (HEC) such as Hambantota, Ratnapura, Trincomalee, Moneragala, Vavuniya, Mullaitivu, Mannar, Batticaloa, and Kurunegala, she said, adding however that it has been halted due to persistent objections. While 125 projects were planned in 2022, seven projects have been completed covering 121.5 kilometres while construction of 33 others is presently ongoing, she said. Herath said, 52 projects have been halted due to shortage of necessary equipment.

title: Importer made false declaration
author: Author not found
Content: State Minister of Finance Ranjith Siyambalapitiya revealed in Parliament yesterday (29) that about 153,375 kg of milk powder in six containers that was imported from New Zealand by a certain company and has been held at the Colombo Port for over 25 days, had violated import and export regulations of the country. This stock of milk powder had been imported under the ‘open account’ system. In a statement, Siyambalapitiya informed Parliament that the milk powder stock had been imported as a raw material for chocolate and ready-made milk tea in a backdrop of importing milk powder as a raw material being suspended. “Importation of milk power is permitted under the ‘open account’ system for direct consumption. However, this particular company has imported the stock as a raw material claiming to be imported as direct consumption. If the Company followed proper procedure, the said stock would be released within a week. If they fail to rectify the issue, this stock will be disposed,” he said. By Methmalie Dissanayake

title: ‘Mein Schiff 5’ docks at Colombo Port
author: Author not found
Content: Mein Schiff 5, a luxury cruise ship, with about 2,000 tourists and 900 crew on board, docked at the Eastern Terminal (ECT) of Colombo Port yesterday (29). Ports, Shipping and Aviation Minister Nimal Siripala de Silva and Tourism Minister Harin Fernando welcomed the ship. A special plaque was exchanged between the Ministers and the captain of the ship, marking its arrival. The ship has facilities for 2,534 passengers and 1,030 crew members. The Malta-flagged vessel is 295.26 metres in length, 36.24 metres in width, and 8.05 metres in depth. This ship belonging to TUI Cruise Company made its first visit on 16 July 2016. The Sri Lankan representative of the ship is Hapag-Lloyd Lanka Company affiliated to Aitken Spence Travel Company. Hambantota Port is the next destination of the ship which came from Oman’s Muscat Port. Thereafter, the ship will sail to Penang Port in Malaysia. Participating in the event, Minister of Ports, Shipping and Aviation Nimal Siripala de Silva said, “Some time ago, foreign tourists came to Sri Lanka by passenger ships, but due to the unstable situation in Sri Lanka including the coronavirus pandemic and the economic crisis, cruise vessels stopped coming to Sri Lanka. The country faced a crisis of earning large foreign exchange. But this situation is gradually disappearing from our country. This is a huge relief for the progress of the tourism industry. As the Ministry of Ports, Navigation and Aviation Services, and as the Minister of Ports, Navigation and Aviation Services, we are working to provide full support to uplift the travel industry. For this purpose, I have given instructions to the relevant officials to provide all necessary infrastructure to tourists in the port and airport. Therefore, I request the people not to act to prevent tourists from coming to this country and to take measures to increase the arrival of tourists. I request everyone to work together with the Government for that.”

title: Dr. Arambepola thanks SL Envoy Premawardhane
author: Author not found
Content: State Minister of Health, Dr. Seetha Arambepola thanked Sri Lankan High Commissioner in Singapore Sashikala Premawardhane for her contribution to make the project of sending Sri Lankan nurses to Singapore a reality. Speaking in Parliament, Dr. Arambepola said, “We implemented this project in 2021. Although Sri Lanka tried for many years to send nurses to Singapore, it did not succeed as we could not provide nurses who match with standards of Singapore. This project we implemented in 2021 was not easy. We had to train the nurses, to hold workshops for them, to train them to face interviews. There were several rounds of discussions between the two countries as well. However, we were able to make the project a success. Singapore is recruiting the first batch of nurses fromSri Lanka now.” Apart from High Commissioner Premawardhane, the State Minister thanked High Commission official Nipuna Thibbutumunuwa, former Secretary of the Vocational Training and Skills Development Ministry and staff, and former Chairman of NAITA and staff as well. Further, she thanked Prof. Indika Karunaratne and Specialist Doctor Hiran Amarasekara.

title: Medical administrator demands extension of service
author: Author not found
Content: The longest serving medical administrator in the Health Ministry has allegedly demanded an extension of his service, in order to approve a tender for a physiotherapy machine. Well-informed sources of the Health Ministry yesterday (29) alleged that Health Minister Keheliya Rambukwella had instructed the awarding of a tender for a physiotherapy machine to the lowest bidder. However, the aforementioned medical administrator had allegedly said he will only do so if his retirement is postponed.   He had allegedly made the demand from Minister Rambukwella’s daughter. Medical practitioners attached to the Health Ministry alleged that the senior medical administrator of the Health Ministry had too much at stake owing to what they termed as “contract commitments” to suppliers for which he will be rewarded. They accused him of having charges of corruption against him. Cabinet approved the implementation of recommendations submitted by a Ministerial Sub-Committee Chaired by Premier Dinesh Gunawardena to extend the service of Specialist Medical Officers, Government Medical Officers, Dental Surgeons, and Government Registered Medical Officers by providing the opportunity to serve until 30 June of the relevant year for doctors whose birthday falls between 1 January and 30 June, and for doctors whose birthday falls between 1 July and 31 December in the relevant year. The sub-committee made recommendations for retirement with the opportunity to serve up to 31 December. By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: No Cabinet Paper so far – Bandula
author: Author not found
Content: Despite the Education Minister’s pledge to submit a Cabinet Paper requesting the removal of the Cess on school stationery, Cabinet Spokesman Bandula Gunawardana said no such Cabinet Paper has been submitted. He said if the Minister of Education submits a proposal to Cabinet, it will be considered. Gunawardana was responding to a question at the weekly Cabinet media briefing yesterday (29). “The Cess is imposed on those who import school stationery. It was enacted to protect local manufacturing industries, and it can be considered if the Minister of Education presents a proposal to Cabinet to provide some kind of concession after consulting the relevant parties. If the price rises due to the Cess, we will notify the Education Minister and ask him to submit a proposal to reduce it,” he said. In a speech to Parliament on 25 November, Education Minister Susil Premajayantha said, a Cabinet Paper will be submitted to remove the Cess on school stationery.

title: Immigration Dept refuses to name dual citizen MPs
author: Author not found
Content: In a backdrop where dual citizens are barred from holding MP posts by the recently passed 21st Amendment to the Constitution, the Department of Immigration and Emigration refused to reveal the names of dual citizen MPs who are in the present Parliament, citing, “Personal information will be refused if there is no relation to any public activity.” Ceylon Today sent an RTI application (DIE/LU/3/02) to the Department of Immigration and Emigration requesting a list of MPs who hold dual citizenship. However, the request was denied, citing “Section 5 (1) of the Immigration and Emigration Act, disclosure of information related to personal information will be refused if there is no relation to any public activity or relationship or if there is an unauthorised invasion of an individual’s privacy.” The request was for an appeal dated 16 November 2022, which Controller General of Immigration and Emigration, I.S.H.J. Illukpitiya, who is also the designated RTI Officer, refused to issue. Prior to this RTI application, an RTI (DIE/RTI/51/2022) was sent to the same official, requesting information on MPs with dual citizenship. Initially, Ceylon Today did not send the name list. In response, the RTI said, “information regarding dual citizenship of applicants is not entered into the data system based on the professionals’ status or rank, and that the data Ceylon Today requires is not in their possession.” Ceylon Today emailed the entire current MPs’ list to the Department of Immigration and Emigration, and the response was that they could not divulge the information due to Section 5 (1) of the Act. Ceylon Today requested through an RTI application who are the MPs who hold dual citizenship, as the Government passed a law stating that MPs who hold dual citizenship cannot continue to hold that position. The RTI Officer was asked “how many Sri Lankan MPs and Cabinet Ministers on the following list presently holding dual citizenship, holding either Sri Lankan or foreign passports. And can you specifically name those who have dual citizenship in which country, including Schengen visas.” By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Importer made false declaration
author: Author not found
Content: State Minister of Finance Ranjith Siyambalapitiya revealed in Parliament yesterday (29) that about 153,375 kg of milk powder in six containers that was imported from New Zealand by a certain company and has been held at the Colombo Port for over 25 days, had violated import and export regulations of the country. This stock of milk powder had been imported under the ‘open account’ system. In a statement, Siyambalapitiya informed Parliament that the milk powder stock had been imported as a raw material for chocolate and ready-made milk tea in a backdrop of importing milk powder as a raw material being suspended. “Importation of milk power is permitted under the ‘open account’ system for direct consumption. However, this particular company has imported the stock as a raw material claiming to be imported as direct consumption. If the Company followed proper procedure, the said stock would be released within a week. If they fail to rectify the issue, this stock will be disposed,” he said. By Methmalie Dissanayake

title: ‘Mein Schiff 5’ docks at Colombo Port
author: Author not found
Content: Mein Schiff 5, a luxury cruise ship, with about 2,000 tourists and 900 crew on board, docked at the Eastern Terminal (ECT) of Colombo Port yesterday (29). Ports, Shipping and Aviation Minister Nimal Siripala de Silva and Tourism Minister Harin Fernando welcomed the ship. A special plaque was exchanged between the Ministers and the captain of the ship, marking its arrival. The ship has facilities for 2,534 passengers and 1,030 crew members. The Malta-flagged vessel is 295.26 metres in length, 36.24 metres in width, and 8.05 metres in depth. This ship belonging to TUI Cruise Company made its first visit on 16 July 2016. The Sri Lankan representative of the ship is Hapag-Lloyd Lanka Company affiliated to Aitken Spence Travel Company. Hambantota Port is the next destination of the ship which came from Oman’s Muscat Port. Thereafter, the ship will sail to Penang Port in Malaysia. Participating in the event, Minister of Ports, Shipping and Aviation Nimal Siripala de Silva said, “Some time ago, foreign tourists came to Sri Lanka by passenger ships, but due to the unstable situation in Sri Lanka including the coronavirus pandemic and the economic crisis, cruise vessels stopped coming to Sri Lanka. The country faced a crisis of earning large foreign exchange. But this situation is gradually disappearing from our country. This is a huge relief for the progress of the tourism industry. As the Ministry of Ports, Navigation and Aviation Services, and as the Minister of Ports, Navigation and Aviation Services, we are working to provide full support to uplift the travel industry. For this purpose, I have given instructions to the relevant officials to provide all necessary infrastructure to tourists in the port and airport. Therefore, I request the people not to act to prevent tourists from coming to this country and to take measures to increase the arrival of tourists. I request everyone to work together with the Government for that.”

title: Dr. Arambepola thanks SL Envoy Premawardhane
author: Author not found
Content: State Minister of Health, Dr. Seetha Arambepola thanked Sri Lankan High Commissioner in Singapore Sashikala Premawardhane for her contribution to make the project of sending Sri Lankan nurses to Singapore a reality. Speaking in Parliament, Dr. Arambepola said, “We implemented this project in 2021. Although Sri Lanka tried for many years to send nurses to Singapore, it did not succeed as we could not provide nurses who match with standards of Singapore. This project we implemented in 2021 was not easy. We had to train the nurses, to hold workshops for them, to train them to face interviews. There were several rounds of discussions between the two countries as well. However, we were able to make the project a success. Singapore is recruiting the first batch of nurses fromSri Lanka now.” Apart from High Commissioner Premawardhane, the State Minister thanked High Commission official Nipuna Thibbutumunuwa, former Secretary of the Vocational Training and Skills Development Ministry and staff, and former Chairman of NAITA and staff as well. Further, she thanked Prof. Indika Karunaratne and Specialist Doctor Hiran Amarasekara.

title: Medical administrator demands extension of service
author: Author not found
Content: The longest serving medical administrator in the Health Ministry has allegedly demanded an extension of his service, in order to approve a tender for a physiotherapy machine. Well-informed sources of the Health Ministry yesterday (29) alleged that Health Minister Keheliya Rambukwella had instructed the awarding of a tender for a physiotherapy machine to the lowest bidder. However, the aforementioned medical administrator had allegedly said he will only do so if his retirement is postponed.   He had allegedly made the demand from Minister Rambukwella’s daughter. Medical practitioners attached to the Health Ministry alleged that the senior medical administrator of the Health Ministry had too much at stake owing to what they termed as “contract commitments” to suppliers for which he will be rewarded. They accused him of having charges of corruption against him. Cabinet approved the implementation of recommendations submitted by a Ministerial Sub-Committee Chaired by Premier Dinesh Gunawardena to extend the service of Specialist Medical Officers, Government Medical Officers, Dental Surgeons, and Government Registered Medical Officers by providing the opportunity to serve until 30 June of the relevant year for doctors whose birthday falls between 1 January and 30 June, and for doctors whose birthday falls between 1 July and 31 December in the relevant year. The sub-committee made recommendations for retirement with the opportunity to serve up to 31 December. By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: No Cabinet Paper so far – Bandula
author: Author not found
Content: Despite the Education Minister’s pledge to submit a Cabinet Paper requesting the removal of the Cess on school stationery, Cabinet Spokesman Bandula Gunawardana said no such Cabinet Paper has been submitted. He said if the Minister of Education submits a proposal to Cabinet, it will be considered. Gunawardana was responding to a question at the weekly Cabinet media briefing yesterday (29). “The Cess is imposed on those who import school stationery. It was enacted to protect local manufacturing industries, and it can be considered if the Minister of Education presents a proposal to Cabinet to provide some kind of concession after consulting the relevant parties. If the price rises due to the Cess, we will notify the Education Minister and ask him to submit a proposal to reduce it,” he said. In a speech to Parliament on 25 November, Education Minister Susil Premajayantha said, a Cabinet Paper will be submitted to remove the Cess on school stationery.

title: Brandix grants university schols to A/L top performers
author: Author not found
Content: Helping to shape the future of many youth, Brandix Apparel Ltd., under its ‘Manusathkara University Scholarship’ initiative, presented outstanding A/L performers with higher education opportunities, at a ceremony held recently. The 18 student beneficiaries, who have to date, completed their Orientation and English pre-academic programmes and about to enter formal undergraduate programmes at eight universities islandwide received their scholarships at the event. The ceremony was held at Brandix Fast Fashion Centre in Welisara and was graced by Prof. H.D. Karunaratne, Vice Chancellor, University of Colombo, Ashroff Omar, Group CEO, Brandix, and Natasha Boralessa, Group Director. Senior personnel from Brandix, parents, students, community representatives, and well-wishers were also present. Brandix launched its Manusathkara University Scholarship programme to provide an opportunity for exceptional performers at the Advanced Level Examination to pursue their higher education and strengthen their personal and professional development. For over a decade and a half, the organisation has been committed towards social sustainability initiatives, anchored to the pillars of Provide, Educate and Engage. Under the umbrella of educate, in both Sri Lanka and India, the ‘school essentials’ programme provides children from pre-school to senior school with schoolbags, books and other necessities for the entire school year, and has benefited over 45,000 children to date. Brandix has also provided hundreds of scholarships for the children of its own employees to pursue their higher education. With the addition of the Manusathkara University Scholarship, Brandix further commits to continuous education and the pursuit of individual aspirations as an important feature of its CSR and HR strategies, and this is also aligned to Goal 4: Quality Education, of the UN Sustainable Development Goals.

title: Children’s book published by Parliament launched
author: Author not found
Content: Children’s book Kurulu Parlimenthuwe Kathawa – Punchi Dupathe Kurulu Kathandare published by Parliament, was launched on Sunday (27) at the children’s section of the Colombo Public Library under the patronage of Speaker Mahinda Yapa Abeywardana. This book is published in Sinhala, Tamil, and English, which explains representative democracy and about the Parliament of Sri Lanka in simple language and in a delightful way for the children who are preparing for future leadership. Secretary-General of Parliament Dhammika Dasanayake presented the first copy of the book to the Speaker. Thereafter, the Speaker gifted this book to a group of children who participated in the event. Chief of Staff and Deputy Secretary-General of Parliament Kushani Rohanadeera in Sinhala, and Director (Administration) G. Tachchanarani in Tamil then read the story to the children who were present. Speaking at the event, the Speaker said, instead of education aimed only at exams, children should be given a basic idea about their environment and politics from an early age. The Speaker said he would like to express his thanks to all those who contributed towards this book written to achieve that purpose. This book under the editing assistance of Emeritus Professor J.B. Disanayake, was written by Nipuni Balagamage, Ishara Wickramasinghe, Rishmia Nootan, S. Jaya Prakash, Maheswaran Pirasath and P. Rudrakumar of the Department of Communication of Parliament. Further, the publication of this book was financially supported by the National Democratic Institute (NDI)

title: Cabinet Decisions
author: Author not found
Content: MoU between EDB and IPP of Switzerland Cabinet approved entering into a memorandum of understanding between the Sri Lanka Export Development Board and the Import Promotion Programme of Switzerland. It has been proposed to sign a Memorandum of Understanding between the Export Development Board of Sri Lanka and the Import Promotion Programme implemented under the Swiss State Secretariat for Economic Activities to conduct a detailed research in regard to processed food, sustainable fish and marine food and value-added garments export production. The objective of this proposed research is to gain access to the European market. The Import Promotion Programme of Switzerland will provide CHF 100,000 for this study. Higher impact community development projects under Indian assistance Cabinet approved the implementation of higher impact community development projects under Indian grant assistance. The project for the Implementation of higher impact community development projects under Indian grant assistance has been implemented since the year 2005. Accordingly, Memorandums of Understanding have been signed in regard to the periods 2005 – 2010, 2010 – 2015 and 2015 – 2020. Priority is given to provide infrastructure facilities in the sectors of Education, Health and Community Development under the project. The cost of one subproject implemented under the project is limited to only LKR 300 million and is subject to a maximum of LKR 5 billion of the value of the total number of projects implemented at any instance. However, due to the economic crisis and the higher inflation rate experienced within the country, some projects cannot be implemented within the maximum cost limit of LKR 300 million. Therefore, the two parties have agreed to raise the said limit up to a limit of LKR 600 million, and to raise to a maximum of LKR 10 billion of the value of the total number of projects implemented at any instance. The Cabinet Paper was submitted by the President as the Minister of Finance, Economic Stabilization and National Policies. Haritha policy dialogue to be financed with EU grants Cabinet approved to enter into the project to strengthen the social integrity and peace in Sri Lanka and the project to ease the green (Haritha) policy dialogue proposed to be financed by the grants of the European Union. With the objective of assisting a ‘Sri Lanka stabilised on the green policies’ and a ‘covered peaceful society’ from 2021 to 2027, it has been agreed to furnish funds under the Multi – Annual Indicative Programme of the European Union for Sri Lanka. Accordingly, the European Union has agreed to provide a grant of Euro 16 million to implement ‘Social Integrity and peace strengthening project’ and ‘Project to Ease the Green (Haritha) Policy Dialogue’ in Sri Lanka. The Cabinet Paper was submitted by the President as the Minister of Finance, Economic Stabilization and National Policies. International Water Summit – 2022 The Water Supply and Drainage Board has taken steps to organise the International Water Summit – 2022 from 14 December to 16 December. It is intended by holding this summit to gather water professionals, foreign representatives, international organisations, government officials, and journalists, to exchange views and knowledge for research, and create ties among water professionals as well as exchange experience and successes in the water sector in other countries. Accordingly, Cabinet approved the resolution submitted by the Minister of Water Supply to conduct the proposed summit with the participation of relevant local and international institutions. Project for small-scale rubber estate owners Cabinet approved entering into a Memorandum of Understanding between the Ministry of Plantation Industries and Ksapa Company, France for implementation of the capacity-building project for 6,000 small-scale rubber estate owners. It has been planned to implement ‘the project to increase the value chain of rubber products and enhance the capacity of the small-scale rubber estate owners’ to boost the economic strength of 6,000 small-scale rubber estate owners in Badalkukmbura and Medagama areas where rubber is planted in the Moneragala District by the Ksapa Company, France guided by the Ministry of Plantation Industries under the financial allocations of the Ministry of Economy, Finance and Recovery, France and the Michelin Group of France. The proposed project has been approved by the Department of National Policy Planning and it has been estimated that 726,700 Euros will be the total cost of the project. Signing enhanced second additional protocol to Budapest Convention Sri Lanka has signed as a stakeholder in the convention on cybercrimes (Budapest Convention) on cooperation and electronic evidence revelation and the Convention is in effect from 1 September 2015. A ceremony is to be held in Strasbourg, France on 30 November to sign the second additional protocol and Cabinet approved the combined resolution furnished by the Ministers of Justice, Prison Affairs and Constitutional Reforms, and Foreign Affairs to sign the said protocol. South Asian Sub-Regional Committee Meeting Asia-Pacific Network for Global Change Research is an intergovernmental network of 22 member countries working towards an Asia Pacific region that can successfully address the challenges of global change and sustainability. The main objective of the network is to conduct policy-based research and develop regional capacity for the regional changes required for global sustainable development in the Asia Pacific region. The Government of Sri Lanka has taken steps to host the sub-regional committee meeting of the Asia-Pacific Network for Global Change Research and the South Asian Project Proposal Development Workshop scheduled from 29 November to 1 December in Colombo. In this regard, the information presented by the Minister of Environment was considered by Cabinet.

title: Royal Masters bag Sasi Ganeshan Trophy
author: Author not found
Content: An unbroken 3rd wicket partnership of 136 runs in 75 balls between Chintaka Edirimanne (88*) and Naveen Samarakoon (58*) steered Royal Masters to an easy 8 wicket win against Thomian Masters in their 4th annual 30-over encounter played at the Colts Grounds on Sunday.  Batting first, Thomian Masters lost their first wicket in the very first over without a run on the board. Vajira Wijegunawardena (48) and Suresh Bulankulama (14) steadied the innings with a 41-run partnership for the second wicket. The fourth wicket pair of NIC Silva (79) and Ramesh Wannakuwatte (10) kept the score board ticking and helped the team pass the 100-run mark. Skipper Johann Peiris (15) also made a useful contribution to get them to a reasonable score. Bowling honours were shared by Chintaka Edirimanne, Sajith Liyanage, Shezard Nizar and Skipper Nalliah Devarajan, claiming 2 wickets each. Royal Masters openers Shezard Nizar and Nuwan Perera got them off to a fine start with a 47-run partnership. With the fall of Nuwan Perera’s wicket, Chintaka Edirimanne joined Shezard Nizar and the pair added a further 31 runs for the second wicket. With the dismissal of Shezard Nizar for a solid 32, Naveen Samarakoon joined Chintaka Edirimanne, and the pair played magnificently to overhaul the target without further loss. Naveen Samarakoon stroked a marvellous 58* while Chintaka Edirimanne played a star-studded innings with a classic knock of 88* (which included a six off the last ball of the 21st over), to take Royal Masters over the line in the 21st over. All-rounders Chintaka Edirimanne and Shezard Nizar had an excellent game, while sadly another all-rounder, Anal Karunaratne, had to be sidelined due to injury. Brief scores:  Thomian Masters: 208 (29.4) (Vajira Wijegunawardena 48, NIC Silva 79, Johann Peiris 15, Ramesh Wannakuwatte 10, Suresh Bulankulama 14, Chintaka Edirimanne 2/32, Sajith Liyanage 2/32, Shezard Nizar 2/22, Nalliah Devarajan 2/15) Royal Masters: 214/2 (21) (Shezard Nizar 32, Nuwan Perera 18, Chintaka Edirimanne 88*, Naveen Samarakoon 58*) By M.H. Yakeem

title: Indian CEO Forum partners with Colombo Rowing Club
author: Author not found
Content: The Indian CEO Forum (ICF) In association with LANKA IOC (LIOC) and POWER TECH Cement partnered with the Colombo Rowing Club for The Madras-Colombo Regatta’ which is considered to be the oldest regatta in the world between two cities of different countries and was held at the Colombo Rowing Club on Saturday, 26 November 2022. As per tradition, High Commissioner of India to Sri Lanka Gopal Baglay was the chief guest. It was the 81st edition of the event and was supported by the Indian CEO forum in Sri Lanka. Speaking at the event, the High Commissioner said, India will continue to row together with Sri Lanka in the race against common challenges and it is but natural for the people of India and the people of Sri Lanka to work together and build bonds. The Indian CEO Forum stepping in to assist and partner with the Colombo Rowing Club for this event is a clear example of how the neighbors encourage and support each other. “The Indian CEO Forum along with two other member companies — Lanka IOC and Power Tech Cement — have come forward to sponsor this exclusive event and make it a success. This is a great boost for rowing in Sri Lanka, especially at a time the country is trying its level best to regain glory in all aspects,” said President of the Rowing Club, Dimuth Gunawardena. “I am extremely thankful to Mr T.S. Prakash and Mr Kishore Reddy along with Mr Nagaraj who made this happen,” Gunawardena added. T.S. Prakash, president of the ICF said, “We are really happy that we associated with this event and member companies are extremely happy that such a partnership was established.” Kishore Reddy, the Vice President and Chairman membership of the ICF as well as the President of the Sri Lanka India Society said, “The Madras-Colombo Regatta has immense potential to be a permanent feature of the sporting calendar considering the history of the event and the traditions associated with it. We will work together with the Colombo Rowing Club to take this to the next level”. “We are glad to be the sponsors of the event and were not really aware of an event with such history before Mr. Kishore Reddy mentioned it,” said Manoj Gupta, the Managing Director of the Lanka IOC. “We look forward to supporting the Colombo Rowing Club for the next event as well,” said Gupta. Gaurav Mehta, the Managing Director of DHT cement and Power Tech Cement who were also the sponsors of the event mentioned, “We are happy that the newest brand of cement in Sri Lanka (Power Tech) has partnered with the oldest Regatta in the world. The event exceeded my expectation and we are proud that we are part of this and contributed to the success of the event”. Sagala Ratnayake, the guest of honour and also a past Oarsman who had rowed many times at the venue said, he is happy to see the partnership between the ICF and the Rowing Club. The first-ever Madras-Colombo Rowing Regatta was held way back in 1898 and is considered the oldest sporting encounter held between India and Sri Lanka. This time, the rivalry resumed after a break of three years due to the pandemic. Traditionally, the Madras Boat Club and the Colombo Rowing Club host the Regatta alternatively and this year it was the Colombo Rowing Club’s turn to host the Indian team. “We are extremely thankful to the Colombo Rowing Club for hosting us and for their great hospitality,” said President of the Madras Boat Club, Subramanium. “We will also try our best to match this hospitality, if not exceed when we host this event next year,” he added. The main event of the Regatta is the Men’s boat race, which is considered to be the second oldest boat race in the world, second only to the famous Oxford-Cambridge boat race. The events were for men and women over a distance of 1,000 metres. The winners of the Men’s event were Colombo and were awarded the prestigious Deepam Trophy while the Adyar Trophy was awarded to the Madras team who were the Women’s champions. The overall champions of the 81st Madras Colombo Regatta was COLOMBO.

title: Suspect enlarged on bail
author: Author not found
Content: Minuwangoda Chief Magistrate T. Thenabadu on 28 November ordered a female suspect who was arrested and produced before her on charges of cheating two women out of Rs 500,000 under the pretext of providing them with employment in Malaysia to be released on strict bail conditions. The suspect was enlarged on two sureties of Rs 200,000 each. The cash that was fleeced from the two plaintiffs by the suspect was ordered to be paid in full. The suspect was identified as B. Nadeera Kumari, a resident of Minuwangoda while the two plaintiffs are also residents of the same area. By Tony K. Athukorala – Minuwangoda

title: Over 26,000 Ayurveda Practitioners in SL
author: Author not found
Content: Sri Lanka (SL) had a total of 26,183 registered Ayurveda practitioners by last year end (2021), the Ayurvedic Medical Council’s Annual Report submitted to Parliament on Friday (25 November) said. Of those, 10,180 were ‘specialised’ Ayurveda practitioners, such as those who specialised in snakebite treatment, which comprised the bulk (4,024) of that group, followed by those ‘specialised’ in the treatment of fractures and dislocations (2,775) and so on, it said. The other Ayurveda practitioners comprised ‘traditional’ (6,854), diploma holders (5,743), and Ayurveda graduates (3,406), respectively. ‘Graduates,’ ‘traditional’ and ‘diploma holders,’ are known as Ayurveda general practitioners, the report said. The totality of such general practitioners as at last year end was 16,003. It further said during last year, a total of 3,800 Ayurvedic practitioners of all types, died. (PA)

title: Interview for UNP electoral organisers tomorrow
author: Author not found
Content: The interview to appoint UNP electoral organisers for 2023 will be held at Sirikotha tomorrow (1), UNP General Secretary Palitha Rangebandara said yesterday (29). Priority will be given to energetic youth and those who are capable of serving the public taking oneness and unity of diverse ethnic groups and to create ethnic reconciliation in the country, according to Rangebandara. Rangebandara said the UNP will be built up as a strong political force in the country and expressed confidence that it will secure a landslide victory in the Local Government Election.   The UNP General Secretary added that they have received a large number of applications from various parts of the country and applications can be submitted at Sirikotha. UNP Deputy Leader Ruwan Wijewardene, General Secretary Palitha Rangebandara, Chairman MP Wajira Abeywardena, National Organiser and Senior Adviser to the President Sagala Ratnayaka, Assistant Leader Akila Viraj Kariyawasam, former Minister Daya Gamage, and former Minister Navin Dissanayake will be on the interview panel, Sirikotha sources said. By Naalir Jamaldeen

The Cabinet Paper was submitted by the President as the Minister of Finance, Economic Stabilization and National Policies. Haritha policy dialogue to be financed with EU grants Cabinet approved to enter into the project to strengthen the social integrity and peace in Sri Lanka and the project to ease the green (Haritha) policy dialogue proposed to be financed by the grants of the European Union. With the objective of assisting a ‘Sri Lanka stabilised on the green policies’ and a ‘covered peaceful society’ from 2021 to 2027, it has been agreed to furnish funds under the Multi – Annual Indicative Programme of the European Union for Sri Lanka. Accordingly, the European Union has agreed to provide a grant of Euro 16 million to implement ‘Social Integrity and peace strengthening project’ and ‘Project to Ease the Green (Haritha) Policy Dialogue’ in Sri Lanka. The Cabinet Paper was submitted by the President as the Minister of Finance, Economic Stabilization and National Policies. International Water Summit – 2022 The Water Supply and Drainage Board has taken steps to organise the International Water Summit – 2022 from 14 December to 16 December. It is intended by holding this summit to gather water professionals, foreign representatives, international organisations, government officials, and journalists, to exchange views and knowledge for research, and create ties among water professionals as well as exchange experience and successes in the water sector in other countries. Accordingly, Cabinet approved the resolution submitted by the Minister of Water Supply to conduct the proposed summit with the participation of relevant local and international institutions. Project for small-scale rubber estate owners Cabinet approved entering into a Memorandum of Understanding between the Ministry of Plantation Industries and Ksapa Company, France for implementation of the capacity-building project for 6,000 small-scale rubber estate owners. It has been planned to implement ‘the project to increase the value chain of rubber products and enhance the capacity of the small-scale rubber estate owners’ to boost the economic strength of 6,000 small-scale rubber estate owners in Badalkukmbura and Medagama areas where rubber is planted in the Moneragala District by the Ksapa Company, France guided by the Ministry of Plantation Industries under the financial allocations of the Ministry of Economy, Finance and Recovery, France and the Michelin Group of France. The proposed project has been approved by the Department of National Policy Planning and it has been estimated that 726,700 Euros will be the total cost of the project. Signing enhanced second additional protocol to Budapest Convention Sri Lanka has signed as a stakeholder in the convention on cybercrimes (Budapest Convention) on cooperation and electronic evidence revelation and the Convention is in effect from 1 September 2015. A ceremony is to be held in Strasbourg, France on 30 November to sign the second additional protocol and Cabinet approved the combined resolution furnished by the Ministers of Justice, Prison Affairs and Constitutional Reforms, and Foreign Affairs to sign the said protocol. South Asian Sub-Regional Committee Meeting Asia-Pacific Network for Global Change Research is an intergovernmental network of 22 member countries working towards an Asia Pacific region that can successfully address the challenges of global change and sustainability. The main objective of the network is to conduct policy-based research and develop regional capacity for the regional changes required for global sustainable development in the Asia Pacific region. The Government of Sri Lanka has taken steps to host the sub-regional committee meeting of the Asia-Pacific Network for Global Change Research and the South Asian Project Proposal Development Workshop scheduled from 29 November to 1 December in Colombo. In this regard, the information presented by the Minister of Environment was considered by Cabinet.

title: Royal Masters bag Sasi Ganeshan Trophy
author: Author not found
Content: An unbroken 3rd wicket partnership of 136 runs in 75 balls between Chintaka Edirimanne (88*) and Naveen Samarakoon (58*) steered Royal Masters to an easy 8 wicket win against Thomian Masters in their 4th annual 30-over encounter played at the Colts Grounds on Sunday.  Batting first, Thomian Masters lost their first wicket in the very first over without a run on the board. Vajira Wijegunawardena (48) and Suresh Bulankulama (14) steadied the innings with a 41-run partnership for the second wicket. The fourth wicket pair of NIC Silva (79) and Ramesh Wannakuwatte (10) kept the score board ticking and helped the team pass the 100-run mark. Skipper Johann Peiris (15) also made a useful contribution to get them to a reasonable score. Bowling honours were shared by Chintaka Edirimanne, Sajith Liyanage, Shezard Nizar and Skipper Nalliah Devarajan, claiming 2 wickets each. Royal Masters openers Shezard Nizar and Nuwan Perera got them off to a fine start with a 47-run partnership. With the fall of Nuwan Perera’s wicket, Chintaka Edirimanne joined Shezard Nizar and the pair added a further 31 runs for the second wicket. With the dismissal of Shezard Nizar for a solid 32, Naveen Samarakoon joined Chintaka Edirimanne, and the pair played magnificently to overhaul the target without further loss. Naveen Samarakoon stroked a marvellous 58* while Chintaka Edirimanne played a star-studded innings with a classic knock of 88* (which included a six off the last ball of the 21st over), to take Royal Masters over the line in the 21st over. All-rounders Chintaka Edirimanne and Shezard Nizar had an excellent game, while sadly another all-rounder, Anal Karunaratne, had to be sidelined due to injury. Brief scores:  Thomian Masters: 208 (29.4) (Vajira Wijegunawardena 48, NIC Silva 79, Johann Peiris 15, Ramesh Wannakuwatte 10, Suresh Bulankulama 14, Chintaka Edirimanne 2/32, Sajith Liyanage 2/32, Shezard Nizar 2/22, Nalliah Devarajan 2/15) Royal Masters: 214/2 (21) (Shezard Nizar 32, Nuwan Perera 18, Chintaka Edirimanne 88*, Naveen Samarakoon 58*) By M.H. Yakeem

title: Indian CEO Forum partners with Colombo Rowing Club
author: Author not found
Content: The Indian CEO Forum (ICF) In association with LANKA IOC (LIOC) and POWER TECH Cement partnered with the Colombo Rowing Club for The Madras-Colombo Regatta’ which is considered to be the oldest regatta in the world between two cities of different countries and was held at the Colombo Rowing Club on Saturday, 26 November 2022. As per tradition, High Commissioner of India to Sri Lanka Gopal Baglay was the chief guest. It was the 81st edition of the event and was supported by the Indian CEO forum in Sri Lanka. Speaking at the event, the High Commissioner said, India will continue to row together with Sri Lanka in the race against common challenges and it is but natural for the people of India and the people of Sri Lanka to work together and build bonds. The Indian CEO Forum stepping in to assist and partner with the Colombo Rowing Club for this event is a clear example of how the neighbors encourage and support each other. “The Indian CEO Forum along with two other member companies — Lanka IOC and Power Tech Cement — have come forward to sponsor this exclusive event and make it a success. This is a great boost for rowing in Sri Lanka, especially at a time the country is trying its level best to regain glory in all aspects,” said President of the Rowing Club, Dimuth Gunawardena. “I am extremely thankful to Mr T.S. Prakash and Mr Kishore Reddy along with Mr Nagaraj who made this happen,” Gunawardena added. T.S. Prakash, president of the ICF said, “We are really happy that we associated with this event and member companies are extremely happy that such a partnership was established.” Kishore Reddy, the Vice President and Chairman membership of the ICF as well as the President of the Sri Lanka India Society said, “The Madras-Colombo Regatta has immense potential to be a permanent feature of the sporting calendar considering the history of the event and the traditions associated with it. We will work together with the Colombo Rowing Club to take this to the next level”. “We are glad to be the sponsors of the event and were not really aware of an event with such history before Mr. Kishore Reddy mentioned it,” said Manoj Gupta, the Managing Director of the Lanka IOC. “We look forward to supporting the Colombo Rowing Club for the next event as well,” said Gupta. Gaurav Mehta, the Managing Director of DHT cement and Power Tech Cement who were also the sponsors of the event mentioned, “We are happy that the newest brand of cement in Sri Lanka (Power Tech) has partnered with the oldest Regatta in the world. The event exceeded my expectation and we are proud that we are part of this and contributed to the success of the event”. Sagala Ratnayake, the guest of honour and also a past Oarsman who had rowed many times at the venue said, he is happy to see the partnership between the ICF and the Rowing Club. The first-ever Madras-Colombo Rowing Regatta was held way back in 1898 and is considered the oldest sporting encounter held between India and Sri Lanka. This time, the rivalry resumed after a break of three years due to the pandemic. Traditionally, the Madras Boat Club and the Colombo Rowing Club host the Regatta alternatively and this year it was the Colombo Rowing Club’s turn to host the Indian team. “We are extremely thankful to the Colombo Rowing Club for hosting us and for their great hospitality,” said President of the Madras Boat Club, Subramanium. “We will also try our best to match this hospitality, if not exceed when we host this event next year,” he added. The main event of the Regatta is the Men’s boat race, which is considered to be the second oldest boat race in the world, second only to the famous Oxford-Cambridge boat race. The events were for men and women over a distance of 1,000 metres. The winners of the Men’s event were Colombo and were awarded the prestigious Deepam Trophy while the Adyar Trophy was awarded to the Madras team who were the Women’s champions. The overall champions of the 81st Madras Colombo Regatta was COLOMBO.

title: Monkeys wreak havoc in Medadumbara
author: Author not found
Content: Residents living in three Grama Seva Divisions of Senarathgama, Nithulemada, and Wewegama which fall under the purview of the Medadumbara Divisional Secretariat in Theldeniya lament they have faced severe hardship for months due to their cultivations being damaged by scores of monkeys roaming in the area daily. According to sources, a majority of people residing in the Grama Seva Divisions depend on agriculture for their existence and they stressed that monkeys tend to destroy their crops and cultivations, dealing a body blow to them. They also said, monkeys tend to bite women and children and they urge the authorities to intervene and provide relief. By K.L. Suraweera – Kandy

title: ‘Inaintha Karankal’ distributes school equipment
author: Author not found
Content: ‘Inaintha Karankal’ (Join Hands), a Voluntary organisation based in Karaitivu with the mission of ‘Drive away poverty and continue education,’ has been lending a helping hand to distribute school equipment to the needy. Volunteers from the Inaintha Karankal took part in the programme by visiting Saraswathy Central College in the Gampola Education Zone and distributing school supplies to the needy. R. Thivvika, Coordinator, is seen handing over equipment to a student. L. Kajan, Team Leader, told our correspondent that they plan to run Advanced Level classes smoothly. Pic By M.A.P. Deen- Ampara

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: No country gives casino licences without regulatory body –Harsha
author: Author not found
Content: Committee on Public Finance (COPF) Chairman Dr. Harsha de Silva raised concerns in Parliament yesterday (28) on Sri Lanka not having a regulatory body to grant licences for casinos. Currently, there is no provision to operate a casino apart from the tax paid to the Inland Revenue Department and as a preliminary step they have taken measures to issue licences.    Dr. de Silva, presenting a report of COPF to the House, pointed out that no other country in the world gives licences to casinos without having a regulatory body. “COPF discussed this matter at the committee meeting which was held at the Parliamentary complex during the weekend. We discussed the regulations under the Casino Business (Regulation) Act No. 17 of 2010. We are of opinion that it would be best to give licences to casinos, after making sure that it would be effective for the development of the country,” he said. BY Methmalie Dissanayake

title: China’s donated diesel free for farmers, fishers
author: Author not found
Content: Minister of Power and Energy Kanchana Wijesekara said the 9,000 MT of Diesel, donated by the Government of China, will be delivered by CPC to the beneficiaries of the Agriculture and Fisheries sectors, identified by the two respective Ministries. According to a ministry spokesman, the diesel will be distributed free of charge to the agriculture and fisheries sectors via CEYPETCO fuel stations and ports. He said, the Ministry has now requested that the Divisional Secretary obtain information from farmers and fishermen prior to the distribution process. However, no specific date has been set for distribution. Oil tanker ‘Super Eastern’, carrying 9,000 metric tonnes of diesel donated by the Government of China to Sri Lankan farmers and fishermen, berthed at the Colombo Port on 26 November. BY Thameenah Razeek

title: Development process via PPPs – Prasanna
author: Author not found
Content: Minister of Urban Development and Housing Prasanna Ranatunga said steps were taken to implement the development process of the country through public-private partnerships (PPP), given that a large number of persons who have lost their jobs due to the ceasing of work in the construction sector. The Minister said this when MPs inquired regarding the matter at the Ministerial Consultative Committee on Urban Development & Housing held under his chairmanship on 22 November. He further mentioned that since there are private investors in the country, who are willing to spend on development programmes, development activities can be done through the partnership of the public and private sectors without using money from the treasury. Furthermore, the plans related to the development of the city were discussed at length at the Committee meeting and the officials pointed out that although no money has been allocated for the development activities, most of the plans related to development have already been completed and all plans can be completed in 2023.  The minister also instructed the officials to present the relevant plans to the district and regional development committees and complete them taking their needs into consideration. Officials pointed out that due to the huge increase in the price of construction materials, construction has been abandoned. Due to this, the officials pointed out that they are also receiving complaints from people who have paid money to buy houses pertaining to those projects. The minister advised to take legal action as soon as possible according to the terms of the relevant agreements.

title: Ports Minister orders goods be cleared in two months
author: Author not found
Content: Minister of Ports, Shipping and Aviation Nimal Siripala de Silva instructed the Customs and Port officials to, within two months, clear the goods that have been in the port warehouses for almost 10 years due to various Customs laws and regulations. Recently, during an inspection conducted by the Minister at the Sri Lanka Ports Authority’s warehouse premises, the port officials informed the Minister about the goods that had not been cleared. The Minister also said, in a discussion held at the Ministry that it was observed that 108 containers and warehouses stored these goods that were not cleared and due to this the Sri Lanka Port Authority has lost a lot of money in terms of warehouse fees and ground rent. Accordingly, the Minister held a special discussion with the relevant parties, including the Sri Lanka Customs and the Port Authority and it was decided that the clearance of these goods should be done within two months.  A committee consisting of officials from the Customs Department and the Sri Lanka Port Authority was also appointed for that purpose. Also, the customs officials pointed out that there are currently cases pending regarding certain goods and due to the pending cases, it was not possible to take a decision regarding the relevant goods. Accordingly, the Minister instructed to provide a report on such delayed proceedings. The Minister said that after discussing the issues related to the legal situation and getting a quick solution, he will get permission to auction and sell the items before they cannot be used and deposit the auction proceeds in Court.  (TR)

title: Gayantha asks Govt to reduce mobile phone, data charges
author: Author not found
Content: Samagi Jana Balawegaya MP Gayantha Karunatileka requested the Government to provide relief through the reduction of mobile phone prices and data charges, as those have become essentials for the people and have a great impact on the people’s lives at present. He added that it is very clear that a majority of the people watch television, listen to music, use social media and also educate themselves through mobile phones, using data. Speaking during the Third Reading of the Budget 2023 in Parliament yesterday (28) he said unfortunately prices of mobile phones and cost of data have skyrocketed. “Therefore, we request the media minister to direct the attention of the government to provide some relief through reduction of mobile phone and data charges,” he said. He said, economic reforms alone are not enough to recover an economically collapsed country. Karunatileka also said that Sri Lanka has fallen behind 19 countries in terms of the media freedom index within a year. While noting that when they were in power in 2015, Sri Lanka was ranked 165th out of 180 countries in the media freedom index, Karunatileka said, former Minister, the late Managala Samaraweera and himself were able bring the country to the 126th position in the media freedom index. However, it has come down to 146th position at present, Karunatileka stressed.  He added, the collapse of the economy is also a political and social collapse. BY Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: Amaraweera says he is still UPFA Gen Secy
author: Author not found
Content: Minister of Agriculture Mahinda Amaraweera has informed the National Election Commission, in writing, that he is still the United People’s Freedom Alliance’s General Secretary. He asserted that he has not given any notice that a new Secretary General has been appointed and that he will continue to serve as the General Secretary of the United People’s Freedom Alliance. He added that if the United People’s Freedom Alliance leaders send the EC a letter stating that the party had appointed a new general secretary, that announcement should not be accepted. (TR)

title: Appeal Court orders to submit documents on Diana’s citizenship
author: Author not found
Content: The Court of Appeal yesterday (28) ordered the Controller General of Immigration and Emigration (CGIE) to submit all documents pertaining to the citizenship of State Minister of Tourism Diana Gamage. This was when the Writ application, filed by Social activist Oshala Herath, seeking an order disqualifying Gamage from holding office as a Parliamentarian, was taken up before Court of Appeal Justices Sobitha Rajapakaruna and Dhammika Ganepola. The Court also decided to inquire into the application and issued formal notice on Gamage and the remaining respondents returnable on 12 December. Attorneys-at-Law Hafeel Farisz with Nishika Fonseka, instructed by Attorney-at-Law Gayan Darshan, previously, appearing on behalf of the petitioner, noted that the matter should be considered as one of extreme emergency as the decisions made by Gamage in her capacity as an MP are illegal. The Petitioner sought an order in the nature of a Writ of Quo Warranto, requiring Gamage to show by what authority she claims to hold office and continues to function as a Member of Parliament of Sri Lanka. Further, a mandate in the nature of a Writ of Quo Warranto, declaring that Gamage is disqualified to be an MP, was also sought. It was also stated in the Petition that Gamage is a British citizen and had concealed the fact that she was a British citizen, while stating that she is also not aSri Lankan citizen. Further, the petitioner noted that Gamage had on several occasions used her British Passport to apply for and obtain visas to visit Sri Lanka. The Petitioner also noted that Gamage had furnished forged Birth Certificates and an invalid National Identity Card to apply for aSri Lankan Passport and that at the time of signing her nomination papers and the holding of the 2020 General Election and taking oaths as a Member of Parliament, she was not a citizen of Sri Lanka. It was thereby stated that Gamage continues to hold office as a Member of Parliament without being a citizen ofSri Lanka. By Faadhila Thassim

title: Fishing boats to run on batteries
author: Author not found
Content: Fisheries Minister Douglas Devananda said yesterday (28) steps had been taken to introduce a boat engine capable of running on batteries as an alternative to fuel-powered engines. He said the fishing vessels in use run on fuel, and the fishermen must bear a high fuel cost. Engines that can function with the help of electric cells will be introduced as an alternative. Milton Motor Manufacturers in Bandaragama has taken action on Minister Devananda’s guidelines to manufacture boat engines capable of operating on motor cells. Minister Devananda said he visited to the boat motor manufacturing plant in Bandaragama and inspected the manufacturing process there. “The tests to check the functioning capacity of a battery run boat will be conducted in the seas by next week. These engines will be made available to fishermen very soon,” Devananda said. The boats engines manufactured with the capacity of functioning on electric cells will have the capacity of sailing 100 kilometres. The fishermen engaging in fishery on daily basis and the trawlers will immensely benefit after the introduction of this boat, according to Devananda. The aforesaid motor manufacturers have manufactured three-wheelers with the capacity of functioning on electric cells. I have planned to invite President Ranil Wickremesinghe to inspect this plant very soon, Minister Devananda added. By Naalir Jamaldeen
