title: DMT to Monitor Traffic Movements Via CCTV
author: Author not found
Content: The Department of Motor Traffic is considering monitoring vehicular movements on the road through CCTV surveillance system. Commissioner General of Motor Traffic N. A. Weerasinghe said the system was first introduced after receiving a grant and that even after the system was set up, it could not be used. However, he said they are now planning to reintroduce it. In this system, a controller in his controller room can monitor the routes drivers take and their movements at the signal lights. “The proposal comes amid allegations of corrupt invigilators and bribery to obtain driver’s licences. The use of CCTV cameras had previously been tested but abandoned. The Department of Motor Traffic intends to conduct another trial using CCTV cameras before implementing the new system throughout the island,” he said. BY Thameenah Razeek

title: Sabry to meet Blinken
author: Author not found
Content: The Minister of Foreign Affairs Ali Sabry will visit the United States of America from 29 November to 4 December 2022, on the invitation of the US Secretary of State Antony Blinken. Minister Sabry is scheduled to meet Secretary of State Blinken, members of the Congress and other senior interlocutors of the US Government during the visit.

title: Nabbed with liquor to be sold in the ‘black’
author: Author not found
Content: An individual was arrested by the Ilavalai Police, in the Jaffna District yesterday (28) for transporting more than the recommended quantity of liquor. Police seized 50 bottles of liquor, each containing 180 millilitres, from the individual. Preliminary investigations revealed that the suspect had purchased the liquor in the Pandatharippu area of Jaffna and had been transporting it to be sold at a higher price. The suspect is a 42-year-old individual and a resident of the Alaveddy area in Jaffna. Ilavalai Police were conducting further inquires while keeping the suspect under detention. BY Naalir Jamaldeen

title: Title not found
author: Author not found
Content: Date: The Government of Japan (GoJ), International Organisation for Migration (IOM) and the Labour and Foreign Employment Ministry launched a handloom production centre, under the project ‘Supporting the Socioeconomic Reintegration of Sri Lankan Migrant Workers Repatriated due to the COVID-19 Outbreak’, with funding from the Japanese Government, in the Puthukudurippu Arayampathy Divisional Secretariat area, of the Batticaloa District on 22 November 2022, the Japanese Embassy in Sri Lanka said. The establishment of the handloom production centre is part of the 22 livelihood and infrastructure development projects, planned across nine districts in Sri Lankaa, contributing to the ‘National Covid-19 Response Plan for Migrant Workers’ developed by the Ministry with technical support from IOM and ILO, it said. The project aims to reduce further vulnerability of migrant returnees by supporting them to sustainably reintegrate to their communities through livelihood support, entrepreneurship, and skills development activities, the Embassy added. Present at this occasion were Embassy of Japan inSri Lanka’s Kaori Imai, IOM Sri Lanka and Maldives Deputy Chief of Mission Andrew Gray, Ministry’s Additional Secretary Yamuna Perera and Additional District Secretary Batticaloa Sutharshini Srikanth. (PA) Popular

title: SEUSL enters into MoU with Indian College
author: Author not found
Content: In order to enhance the educational uplift of the South Eastern University of Sri Lanka (SEUSL), the International Affairs Unit of the SEUSL signed a Memorandum of Understanding (MoU) with several international universities to implement several special schemes and to increase the quality of education. The MoU was signed recently with the Indian K.S.R. College of Arts and Science for women at the Office of the Vice Chancellor of the University. Director of, Academic, Research and International Affairs Unit of the SEUSL Dr. M.S.A. Riyadh Roolie, along with the Head of Marketing Management of the Faculty of Management  and Commerce Dr. M.B.M. Ismail, exchanged the MoU with the Vice Chancellor of the SEUSL Professor Ramees  Aboobukcer. Prof.  Aboobucker said SEUSL has already signed MoUs with the Universities of USSR, Turkiye and Malaysia and intends to sign more MOUs with other reputed Universities in other Countries. (Pic by M.A.P. Deen- Ampara Correspondent)

title: Prosecution, defence to make written submissions
author: Author not found
Content: Colombo High Court Judge Navaratne Marasinghe yesterday (28) instructed both, the prosecution and the defence, to produce written submissions before 16 January next year, in connection with the lawsuit filed against former Minister and MP Wimal Weerawansa, by the Commission to Investigate Allegation of Bribery or Corruption (CIABOC). The Bribery Commission has accused the National Freedom Front (NFF) leader, before the High Court of earning income in excess of 75 million rupees, far exceeding his annual income, while functioning as a Cabinet Minister from 1 January 2010 to 31 December 2014 and thereby flouting Provisions contained in the Bribery Act. President’s Counsel Shavendra Fernando, appearing for Weerawansa, had mentioned at the previous hearing, that though charges had been filed against his client, as per the Provisions of the Bribery Act, he maintained that as per the said Act, charges can only be brought against State sector workers. Counsel Fernando had insisted, that such charges cannot be pressed against Cabinet Ministers or MPs. Accordingly, Judge Marasinghe, advised both parties present to hand over written submissions (objections and counter objections), pertaining to the trial, before the said date. By Hansi Nanayakkara

title: SriLankan flight returns immediately after takeoff
author: Author not found
Content: A SriLankan Airlines flight, which had taken off from Bandaranaike International Airport (BIA) to Madurai, India last afternoon, had been forced to land after being airborne for only five minutes, the BIA Duty Officer said. According to the Duty Officer, the flight in question is an Air Bus-321 of the Neo Brand, manufactured in France. The flight was carrying 41 passengers and eight staff. The flight had been scheduled to leave for Madurai at 1.40 p.m. yesterday (28) from the BIA. He added a technical issue in the plane had forced the pilots to land the plane on the BIA tarmac. It was not immediately clear as to when the flight would take off to India following the repairs. BY T.K.G. Kapila – Katunayake

title: LCC Chair says doing all possible to ensure continuous coal supply
author: Author not found
Content: Lanka Coal Company (LCC) Chairman Shehan Sumanasekara assured that in order to provide continuous electricity supply to the national grid in the future, they are doing everything possible to meet the coal supply demand. He said the Ministry of Power and Energy and the Ceylon Electricity Board are working together and paying special attention to the fundamental facts of the country’s foreign exchange shortage and economic recession. He said, the Norochcholai Power Plant provides between 40% and 50% of the National Electricity requirement to the national power grid. He noted that the Ceylon Coal Company prepares the quantity of coal required for this purpose in approximately 38 shipments every season, when coal is required. According to a statement from the Ministry of Power and Energy, four shipments of coal have completed the supply process for the fiscal year 2022-23, with the fifth shipment scheduled to arrive in Sri Lanka on 8 December. According to the statement, the initial payments have already been made. Sumanasekara said, while purchasing coal was difficult this time, unloading of 35 shipments have begun. He claimed that because the previous three tenders called to obtain long-term credit facilities did not meet the requirements of the objectives expected, the Cabinet of Ministers approved 12 new shipments (720000MT) from uncalled proposals. “The deadline for submitting proposals is 1 December. All suppliers who have written and agreed with Lanka Coal Company, all suppliers who have received bid documents for subsequent tenders, all suppliers who have submitted unsolicited proposals, and any suppliers who are willing to participate are invited to join,” he said. (TR)

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Total of 34 Easter attack cases in HC
author: Author not found
Content: A total of 34 cases are ongoing in the High Court, in connection with the Easter Sunday attacks, as at 15 November 2022, whilst a total of 72 accused have been indicted in High Court Trials. The President’s Office previously directed the Ministries of Foreign Affairs and Justice to take necessary steps to complete investigations into the accused persons as soon as possible, file charges against those who should be charged in Court, rehabilitate those who should be rehabilitated, and release those who have not been charged in relation to the Easter Sunday attacks.

title: Notice issued on Cabinet, DG Health
author: Author not found
Content: The Court of Appeal issued notice on the Cabinet of Ministers and the Director General of Health Services, returnable on 13 December, in connection with the Writ Application challenging the decision to reduce the compulsory retirement age of doctors to 60 years. This was when the Application filed by 176 consultant specialist doctors was taken up before Court of Appeal Justices Sobitha Rajakaruna and Dhammika Ganepola. President’s Counsel Sanjeeva Jayawardena, appearing for the petitioners, submitted to Court that the said decision of the Cabinet of Ministers, dated 17 October 2022, has been made illegally and in complete violation of their legitimate expectation to continue in service at least until 63 years of age. The Petitioners’ position is that since 2017, as consultant specialist doctors, they have been guaranteed a defined compulsory age of retirement of 63 years, by both Cabinet Decisions as well as by the Amendment to the Minute on Pensions and therefore, that they were distinctly identified as a separate category, different and separate to that of other categories of public officers in general and that this status and legitimate expectation had been continuing for a period of 5 years, from 2017 upto 2022.   They further stated that they have obtained their PGIM Board certification through a gruelling process over the years and that due cognisance had been taken of the important service that they dispense at the apex level of the public health care system and curative as well as the preventive segments of the patient care system, in the country. The said, Application was supported on behalf of the Petitioners by President’s Counsel Sanjeeva Jayawardena with Attorneys-at-Law Lakmini Warsevitane and Dr. Milhan Mohamed. Upon considering the same, the Court of Appeal , issued formal notice of the said Application on all the Respondents named in the Petition, on the basis that a prima facie case had been established by the Petitioners. President’s Counsel Uditha Egalahewa and Manohara de Silva appeared for seven other consultants, in connected applications. BY Faadhila Thassim

title: 80% attendance requirement for A/L will resume in 2023
author: Author not found
Content: The Ministry of Education announced yesterday (28) that from 2023 onwards, students sitting for the GCE Advanced Level will be required to have an 80 per cent attendance. According to Education Secretary’s letter No. ED/09/Ads (SA)/7 dated 12 August 2022, it is not necessary to have 80 per cent attendance for students taking the examination. As a result, said exemption applies only to GCE Advanced Level 2022 students, with no effect on GCE Advanced Level students beginning in 2023. The Ministry declared that students taking the exam must attend 80 per cent school attendance.

title: LPL held without Sports Ministry approval – Roshan
author: Author not found
Content: Minister of Sports Roshan Ranasinghe claimed that the Sri Lanka Premier League (LPL) tournament was held without the Sports Ministry’s approval. Ranasinghe told the House that neither the Sports Ministry nor he, as Sports Minister, had seen the agreement. He said, he had written to Sri Lanka Cricket (SLC) requesting the agreement. He was responding to a question from the Opposition during the Sports Ministry’s Committee Stage Debate in Parliament on 26 November. “I also learned only through media reports that a T10 tournament has been agreed upon. This is the scenario. There is definitely a problem here,” he stressed. By Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: TREASURY SECY ISSUES STERN REMINDER TO PUBLIC INSTITUTIONS
author: Author not found
Content: The Ministry of Finance, Economic Stability, and National Policies, has issued a stern reminder to public institutions to stop using public funds for events, openings, conferences, and other non-essential activities. Treasury Secretary K.M. Mahinda Siriwardena said in the circular that while President Ranil Wickremesinghe has stressed unequivocally that public funds should not be used for events, openings, conferences, and other events held by public institutions, which are deemed non-essential, it has been reported that such expenses continue to be incurred, in violation of the above terms, by certain ministries, departments, State corporations, companies, statutory boards, State enterprises, provincial councils, and other public institutions. “I reiterate that efforts should be made to avoid incurring expenses by using the earnings of the government or private institutions for holding all kinds of events, including ceremonies, friendly meetings, and receptions,” Siriwardena warned in a circular sent to Ministry Secretaries, Chief Secretaries of Provincial Councils, Heads of Departments/District Secretaries, Heads of State Corporations, Companies, and Statutory Boards, and Heads of State Banks. He said the National Budget Circular No. 03/2022, dated 26 April 2022, issued with the goal of strictly controlling public expenditure, stated that public funds should not be used for non-essential events. “As per the instructions of the Honourable President, the President’s Secretary has also given instructions through Circular No. PS/5B/Circular/10/2022 dated 15 August 2022. Also, it has been informed by the State Business Circular No. 04/2022 dated 8 August 2022 that expenses should not be incurred in connection with the festival activities,” he said. “In accordance with the President’s instructions, the President’s Secretary has issued instructions via Circular No. PS/5B/Circular/10/2022 dated 15 August 2022. Furthermore, the State Business Circular No. 04/2022 dated 8 August 2022 has advised that no expenses should be incurred in connection with the festival activities,” he said. Siriwardena stressed in addition, the Cabinet decision No. 22/VIV(032) dated 13 June 2022 regarding the seeking of Government funds by Government agencies for various events also allows Government agencies to organise events related to their scope as well as other events within the limited financial space.

title: Hantana estate workers afflicted with kidney disease
author: Author not found
Content: Employees of Hantana State Tea Estate are presently afflicted with many serious diseases including kidney disease. The Hantana State Tea Estate is spread over hundreds of acres and houses thousands of plantation workers. The majority of these persons are facing severe economic and social conflicts including education and health issues. These plantation workers are presently facing a severe drinking water problem and they state that due to drinking contaminated water, they are suffering from kidney disease, diarrhoea, jaundice, skin diseases, and headaches. So far, five people with kidney disease have been detected in Hantana Estate Houses and if a health survey is conducted in the entire estate, this number will definitely increase, they said. Workers say they met all their water needs from the springs that flowed from the top of Hantana Hill for centuries. However, due to human activities, the water springs and streams have been polluted and due to the illegal use of the streams by persons living above their area, the water they drink is now heavily polluted, they said. They said chemicals used for bathing, washing clothes, animal husbandry, and agriculture are mixed with the water and even toilet waste is added to it and they have to drink the dirty water without any purification. Workers emphasised that living within sight of the Kandy National Hospital, they have become severely insecure about their health and even small children are facing many diseases including kidney disease. Requests for clean water to estate managers, politicians, and relevant authorities have fallen on deaf ears for 25 years.  By K.L. Suraweera – Kandy

title: 12 injured in student clash
author: Author not found
Content: At least 12 students were injured and hospitalised after a fight between two groups of students from the Ruhuna National College of Education. According to the Police, a group of teacher trainees attacked a group of college students. On 26 November, a group of senior students held a party, and then a group of about 50 had come to the college grounds and carried out the attack. The 12 injured students were admitted to the Karapitiya Teaching Hospital. Akmeemana Police have launched investigations into the incident following a complaint made by the President of the Ruhuna National College of Education. By Farhan Nizamdin (Galle) and S. Diyagahage (Ahangama)

title: 13,000 in prison on drug-related charges
author: Author not found
Content: Over 13,000 were languishing in the entire prison system islandwide, over drug-related offences, at the beginning of 2022, the Department of Prisons statistics revealed. Of that number, 4,600 were convicted prisoners and 8,700 were remandees. The statistics also showed the numbers being detained over various offences show a marked increase since the beginning of 2022. According to statistics, 74 per cent of those who were incarcerated in 2021 were on drug-related charges. As of 25 November 2022, there are over 26,000 inmates in the entire prison system. Of this number, the total number of suspects is 16,000 (62 per cent), and the total number of convicts is 10,000 (38 per cent). The majority in the prison system, 62 per cent, are suspects, and more than 65 per cent of the suspects are in prison over drug-related offences. “Although the maximum number of inmates that can be held in the island’s prisons is around 13,200, the prisons are presently holding twice that number. Furthermore, it has been observed that some prisons have exceeded this to 300 per cent capacity,” he said. By Thameenah Razeek

title: Litro to release limited gas stocks till 29 Nov
author: Author not found
Content: Litro Gas Lanka Ltd will limit the amount of LP Gas stocks released to the market ahead of the anticipated LP Gas demand during the upcoming festival season. According to a media release, the company will only release LP Gas cylinders to factories, major hotels, and essential services on 27, 28, and 29 November. Apart from factories, 40,000 domestic gas cylinders will be released per day. However, beginning 30 November, 100,000 domestic gas cylinders will be distributed each day. On 30 November, approximately 4,000 metric tonnes of gas will arrive in Sri Lanka, and the company said it has ordered sufficient gas for the festive season. It has been forecast that there will be an increase in gas demand during the holiday season.

title: Raid Amazones returns to SL with SriLankan
author: Author not found
Content: SriLankan Airlines is set to partner with Raid Amazones 2023 for the second consecutive year, with the aim of reaffirming Sri Lanka’s stature as a sought-after tourist destination among the discerning contemporary traveller. The collaboration will see the popular French adventure trail unfolding in the country’s hill capital, Kandy in March 2023. Founder, Raid Amazones, Alexandre Debanne said, “Looking back at last year’s event, I can confidently say that, if not for SriLankan Airlines, we wouldn’t have been able to host it in Sri Lanka. Next year, we are returning with firm assurance and confidence that Sri Lanka will have all the novelty and excitement that the event embodies, and Kandy will provide a new perspective to the event’s diverse destination portfolio.” SriLankan Airlines Chairman, Ashok Pathirage said, “We are delighted to partner with Raid Amazones 2023 yet again, to position Sri Lanka in the hearts of adventure enthusiasts across the globe. As the National Carrier, we take pride in attracting global media attention and winning the trust of international travellers at a time that the country is progressing from the recent challenges. We anticipate Raid Amazones 2023 to have an overwhelming appeal both in terms of participants and the followers.” SriLankan Airlines sponsored Raid Amazones for the first time in 2022 as a result of recommencing operations to Paris. The airline carried 504 female French athletes, earning an immeasurable amount of global media visibility for Sri Lanka. The airline branded an aircraft with Raid Amazones 2022 themed livery, operated by an all-female crew to bring Sri Lanka into the limelight as an adventure and sports tourism destination on a global scale.

title: Uttara Lanka Sabhagaya conference disrupted
author: Author not found
Content: A group attacked the stage of the venue where the Uttara Lanka Sabhagaya’s Nuwara Eliya District Conference was to be held yesterday (27). The event was scheduled to take place at the Haguranketha Cultural Centre yesterday (27) at 9:30 a.m., but due to the incident, the organisers had to postpone the conference for an extended period of time. The stage and decorations were severely damaged, according to Nimal Piyatissa, the assembly’s main organiser, and the board was broken into three pieces. He said the person who planned the attack is a member of the Government’s Haguranketha Constituency, and that he and his brother are “acting like pigs.” He added that they cannot halt the progress of Uttara Lanka Sabhagaya. Piyatissa said the politician is acting in this manner because he did not receive a ministerial post, and he has all the information about the criminals who destroyed the stage, which he said he can provide to the CID if needed. He stressed that legal action will be taken in response to the attack and that the Northern Lanka Coalition is not afraid of the saboteurs. However, the conference was held after some delay, and a group of representatives, including MP Wimal Weerawansa, the Chairman of the Uttara Lanka Sabhagaya, attended. By Krishan Pathirath Jayasuriya

title: Milk powder stocks languish at Customs
author: Author not found
Content: State Minister of Finance Ranjith Siyambalapitiya has requested that Customs and the Import and Export Control Department conduct an investigation into the stock of milk powder held by Customs without being cleared and provide him with a report. During a media briefing, Siyambalapitiya said a shipment of 400,000 kg of imported milk powder had expired due to the inability to release it within the specified time frame. Meanwhile, Chairman of Milk Powder Importers’ Association, Lakshman Weerasuriya said the powdered milk is being held due to the implementation of a fraudulent scheme to inconvenience the people by allowing a shortage of powdered milk to emerge in the country. He added that the said consignment was going to be auctioned off for poultry food under the guise of being expired, so that they could earn a commission. Meanwhile, Customs denied allegations made against them in the news on 26 November that they are delaying the release of an imported milk powder consignment. Director of Customs and Customs Media Spokesman Sudaththa Silva confirmed that a Customs investigation commenced two months ago regarding the illegal departure of foreign exchange from the country linked to this company. Thereby, Silva said the concerned company is making false statements with the aim of disrupting the investigation and Customs will soon issue a statement in this connection to the media. By Nabiya Vaffoor

title: Circular on dress code for public sector next week
author: Author not found
Content: State Minister of Provincial Councils and Local Government Janaka Wakkumbura said, the Public Administration Ministry will issue a circular making mandatory all State employees to dress in accordance with the institution’s policies beginning next week. Speaking to the media, he said, as a policy decision, separate circulars were issued to Government officers indicating the appropriate dress code to report to work prior to the Covid-19 pandemic. “Thus, the Ministry will amend the issued circular to include the approved dress code for government officers. According to the circular issued following the pandemic, permission had been granted for State employees to report to work dressed appropriately,” he added. However, Wakkumbura said the Public Administration Ministry Secretary mentioned that the circular was not applicable to schools. Wakkumbura said the proposal in this regard will be presented to Cabinet, to bring the dress code policies into effect as they were before the Covid pandemic. By Nabiya Vaffoor

title: Canada’s Trudeau defends use of emergency powers
author: Author not found
Content: Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau on Friday defended invoking emergency powers to end anti-government protests that paralysed the capital earlier this year, citing the threat of violence and lack of a credible plan by Police. The ‘Freedom Convoy’ demonstrations against public health measures including vaccine mandates shut down Ottawa and blocked some border crossings for weeks in January and February. Trudeau portrayed the move to use emergency powers as unavoidable, saying it was not possible to negotiate with the protesters. “It wasn’t that they just wanted to be heard. They wanted to be obeyed,” Trudeau told the independent public commission looking into the Government’s use of the powers. I am absolutely, absolutely serene and confident that I made the right choice in agreeing with the invocation.” It was a rare appearance by a sitting Prime Minister at a public inquiry meant to shed light on the process that handed authorities extraordinary powers and determine whether decisions were made transparently with clear accountability. The final report is due to be presented in Canada’s Parliament by 20 February. Trudeau cited the threat of serious violence and local Police not having a credible plan to restore order as reasons that prompted him to invoke the Emergencies Act, which has not been used in its current form since it was created in the 1980s. Civil liberties advocates argued Police could have cleared the blockades using existing powers. Lawyers for the convoy organisers and others said Trudeau had not read a plan prepared by Ottawa Police and pointed to one border blockade being cleared and criminal charges laid at another without the use of emergency powers. Trudeau acknowledged that “not all tools had been used” by Police and said that was the problem. He said he would not have invoked emergency powers if anyone had convinced him the situation could have been resolved without them. “We kept hearing there was a plan…. (but it) was not even in the most generous of characterisations a plan,” Trudeau said. The act gave the Government temporary powers, including the ability to impose restrictions on public assembly and to mobilize federal support for local and provincial Police. It allowed financial institutions to temporarily freeze the bank accounts of people believed to be supporting the convoy and allowed the Government to order towing services to clear blockades. Earlier this week, Canadian Finance Minister Chrystia Freeland said Canada had faced “a dangerous moment” amid the protests, which shut down a vital trade corridor between the United States and Canada. Trudeau also said he had tried to reassure US President Joe Biden at the time that Canada was “going to continue to be a reliable partner” amid disruptions caused by border blockades. A lawyer for convoy organisers said the Emergencies Act could have been avoided had a “de-escalation agreement” with protesters been followed. She asked Trudeau: “When did you and your government start to become so afraid of your own citizens?” “I am not and we are not,” Trudeau replied. The impact of the protests reverberated in Canada and abroad long after the border blockades and Ottawa protests were cleared in February, with copycat protests featuring trailers and trucks following in the United States and France. (Reuters)

title: Wijeratne slams ‘Govt-affiliated scoundrel’
author: Author not found
Content: SJB MP Rohini Wijeratne said in Parliament that action should be taken regarding the statement made by a ‘Government-affiliated scoundrel’ regarding female teachers’ attire. While noting the ‘scoundrel’ had stated that female teachers are in favour of wearing comfortable clothes to misbehave with the fathers of the students who come to schools, MP Wijeratne stressed that the statement was an insult to all female teachers as well as fathers.Speaking in Parliament on 26 November, she said an investigation must be conducted and action must be taken against those who make such irresponsible statements. Wijeratne added that due to the high inflation in the country, teachers are unable to afford sarees. She requested the relevant authorities to provide an allowance to teachers to buy uniforms. Responding to these remarks, Education Minister, Dr. Susil Premajayantha said in Parliament that he is disgusted by the obscene things said to female teachers through Facebook and other social media platforms. Minister said such things occurred because some people raised an unnecessary issue and said if he could, he would lodge a CID complaint regarding the insults. He said there is a specific code of conduct for teachers in general and ethics, behavioural patterns are clearly mentioned in it.He also added that it does not say that it is necessary to wear a saree. The Minister further said a circular was issued during the Covid-19 pandemic in regard to the dress code to make matters easier for employees, however, a new circular will be issued detailing the dress code of State employees. He added that the Government does not have enough funds to provide an allowance for a uniform to the teachers, however, he will introduce a new programme to resolve this issue. By Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: Price of big onions to drop
author: Author not found
Content: The Food Policy Committee has recommended reducing the Special Commodity Tax (SCL) rate. Accordingly, increasing the ability to buy big onions in the market will help to reduce the price of big onions. The Policy Committee met on 24 November. The national requirement for big onions is about 300,000 MT per annum which is mainly fulfilled by imports (86 per cent). Thus, the self-sufficiency ratio amounts to 14 per cent. The retail prices of imported big onions varied between Rs 290 – Rs 390 and the price of local big onions varied between Rs 340 – Rs 400 per kg as of the third week of November. The average CIF of imported big onions was Rs 95.3 per kg in the third week of November and it has only shown a relatively modest increase since mid-August 2022. The Government increased the applicable SCL on imported big onions from Rs 10 per kg to Rs 50 per kg from 22 September 2022 onwards. Subsequently, the imports of big onions started to fall drastically. Imports fell from 27,889 MT in August to only 13,496 MT in November (till week 3). This drop in availability pushed up the price of imported big onions from about Rs 175 per kilogramme in August to Rs 328 per kilogramme in week 3 of November. Nevertheless, a sharp drop in price is evident from 22 November to Rs 250 per kilogramme, however, prices still remain high compared to the period leading up to the SCL increase. It is important to note that the CIF of imported big onions has only increased slightly since August. Hence, the sudden hike in prices can be attributed to the increase in the SCL rate in September. From the month of August, the import of large onions will be reduced by 1,000 kg. The price (CIF value) has increased only marginally, and the reason for this sudden price increase may be the increase in the rate of Special Commodity Duty (SCL) in September.

title: COPF instructs to calculate selling price of egg
author: Author not found
Content: Chairman of the Committee on Public Finance (COPF), Dr. Harsha de Silva, instructed the officials of the Ministry of Finance and Trade to calculate and give the proper price at which an egg can be sold in consideration of the regulations under the Import and Export (Control) Act No. 1 of 1969 related to the import of poultry feed into Sri Lanka, This matter was discussed at the COPF meeting held in Parliament on 24 November. The Committee also discussed the regulations under the Casino Business (Regulation) Act No. 17 of 2010, where the members of the Committee were of the opinion that it would be best to consider the approval after making it more effective for the development of the country. The committee also drew attention to the existing problems due to the absence of a casino regulatory authority. Dr. Harsha de Silva said no casino licence is granted without a casino regulatory body in any country. Thus, the officials said there is no provision to operate the casino apart from the tax paid to the Inland Revenue Department and as a preliminary step they have taken measures to issue these licences. There was a long discussion at the committee meeting regarding a number of issues related to the fact that there is no clear understanding of whether these casino businesses are paying the relevant taxes, how much tax has been collected by the Government or not, and there is no proper regulation regarding the existing casino businesses apart from the 4 registered casino businesses. Accordingly, the Committee on Public Finance decided to conduct a comparative study in this regard and reconsider the matter. (AK)

title: Three arrested for running unlicensed abattoir
author: Author not found
Content: The Panadura Walana Central Anti-Corruption Unit arrested three individuals following a raid on an unauthorised slaughterhouse, operating behind beef stalls in the Bandaragama Atulugama Galge Mandiya area. Police seized 164 kg of beef, a cow’s head, and the knives, hooks, and ropes used to slaughter the animal. The raid was conducted following a tip-off that an unauthorised slaughterhouse was operating behind a shop. On interrogation of the suspects, it became clear that the cow was stolen. It was also revealed that the Public Heath Inspector’s approval was not sought to sell beef. By Bimal Jayasinghe

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Hold LG Elections under old system – Alawathuwala
author: Author not found
Content: While noting that the Government should hold the Local Government Elections using the previous electoral system, SJB MP J.C. Alawathuwala said there has been a debate among citizens about whether the country requires this many people’s representatives. Some local government officials, according to the MP, are working against the people, and it is the Government’s responsibility to hold Local Government Elections as soon as possible to remove them and elect new officials. Speaking during the Committee Stage Debate of Budget 2023 in Parliament on 26 November, MP Alawathuwala said they are also of the opinion that the number of members in local government bodies is high and the numbers should be reduced. He also said due to the increase in the number of members of the local government bodies, there is insufficient space in their meeting halls. He said, therefore, the Government can hold the election under the previous electoral system by amending election laws. He said his faction will also support the move to amend the laws and conduct the election under the previous electoral system. By Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: Preliminary discussion held in Parliament
author: Author not found
Content: A preliminary discussion was held in Parliament pertaining to the future plan of getting support of the university academic staff through Vice Chancellors for the purpose of formulating national policies. This was decided at the National Council sub-committee on identifying short and medium-term programmes related to National Policy held recently, chaired by MP Namal Rajapaksa. The meeting was held with the presence of Professor Sampath Amaratunge, Chairman of the University Grants Commission, and a group of lecturers including vice chancellors of universities from across the country. They were able to arrive at a preliminary agreement regarding the basic structure identified by the sub-committee on identifying short and medium-term programmes related to National Policy. As a preamble to this programme, Professor Krishan Deheragoda gave an explanation to the Committee on the main areas where policy preparations should focus on. The university vice-chancellors and lecturers expressed their views on how policies should be prepared. Accordingly, it was decided to prepare basic structure identified by the sub-committee on identifying short and medium-term programmes related to National Policy together with university professors in accordance with each identified field given the priority and to move ahead. Addressing the Committee, Namal Rajapaksa said, they wish to propose to the National Council to set up a separate bureau for policy formulation and to effect the required legal changes through Parliament. (AK)

title: 81st Colombo-Madras Regatta held in Colombo
author: Author not found
Content: The 81st edition of Madras-Colombo Regatta was held at Colombo Rowing Club on 26 November. The High Commission of India tweeted that the Madras-Colombo Regatta is considered to be the oldest Regatta in the world between two cities in different countries. “A unique link between India and Sri Lanka, and indeed in the world!! Madras-Colombo Regatta is considered to be the oldest Regatta in the World between two cities in different countries. High Commissioner was the Chief Guest at its 81st edition, supported by #Indian CEO Forum and held at Colombo Rowing Club today. He cheered the competitors and said that #India will continue to row together with #SriLanka in the race against common challenges,” the Indian High Commission tweeted.

title: Title not found
author: Author not found
Content: Date: The new Ambassador of Oman to Sri Lanka Ahmed Ali Saeed Al Rashdi called on Speaker Mahinda Yapa Abeywardena on 25 November in Parliament. Commenting on the need to further strengthen the existing bilateral relations between the two countries, the Ambassador drew attention to the importance of forming the Sri Lanka-Oman Parliamentary Friendship Association. Discussions were also held on investment promotion opportunities between the two countries and making arrangements for business delegations from the two countries to visit. The Speaker commended the support given to Sri Lanka by Middle Eastern countries including Oman and expressed his appreciation to the Ambassador. Popular

title: Six moonshine distillers arrested in Kaluwanchikudy
author: Author not found
Content: Kaluwanchikudy Police yesterday (27) said, they arrested six individuals from various locations in the Kaluwanchikudy Police Division for their alleged involvement in the distillation of moonshine. The Kaluwanchikudy Police said, one woman was among the suspects. Kaluwanchikudy Police added that a huge stock of moonshine and ‘goda’ being used for the distillation of moonshine were seized. The raid was conducted following a tip-off received by the Intelligence Division.  Equipment used to distil moonshine including a gas cylinder and a motorcycle were seized as well. By Naalir Jamaldeen

title: Ban on passengers wearing gold jewellery over 22 carats
author: Author not found
Content: State Minister of Finance Ranjith Siyambalapitiya said the Government has decided to enforce the law against air passengers who smuggle gold to Sri Lanka. He said air passengers will be banned from wearing gold jewellery valued more than 22 carats without the approval of the Controller General of Imports and Exports. Customs officials have been instructed to use special techniques to ascertain the condition and quantities of gold items. He said the gazette notification pertaining to this decision will be issued in the coming week. He said migrant workers returning to the country or normal air passengers will not be affected by this move. Misusing the relaxed restrictions on the quality or amount of gold jewellery that an air passenger is allowed to wear, the smugglers illegally bring in at least 50 kg of gold per day, State Minister Siyambalapitiya explained. It has come to light that some smugglers travel overseas daily and bring 24-carat gold ornaments with them. According to Siyambalapitiya, it is estimated that Sri Lanka incurs a loss of USD 30 million per month as a result. The decision was taken after considering a report handed over by the Customs Director General to Siyambalapitiya recently.

title: Shed differences and unite for a better future
author: Author not found
Content: UNP Assistant Leader Akila Viraj Kariyawasam invited leaders and members of every political party to unite and work in collaboration, taking the future of this country into consideration, eliminating the hypocrisy and putting aside narrow political agendas. He said this is what happens to a country when the only objective is to preserve one’s own power. He said such persons need to stop the business of making their own opinion victorious, or making decisions for the sake of the time, and using people to form an opinion in the country and added that living with them is too difficult. “It is the bounden duty of everyone to extend their solid support to the Government led by President Ranil Wickremesinghe if the burning economic crisis is to be resolved and the life of crisis-hit people is to be fixed. I took every action to modernise the school education system when I was the Education Minister during the Good Governance Government led by the United National Front (UNF),” Kariyawasam said. Speaking further, he said they had prepared a 13-year education and a vocational education system consisting of 27 subjects and set of standards to produce qualified persons for the local and international job market. “Vocational education was introduced to students who failed in the G.C.E. O/L and G.C.E. A/L. Various vocational training courses were introduced including hotel management, agriculture, and sports during the Good Governance regime and some of them are still functional, but poor attention is paid towards them,” Kariyawasam said. If the programmes recommended during the Good Governance regime were implemented, a large number of skilled workers would have been able to go overseas and bring more foreign exchange to Sri Lanka and they could have been transformed into stakeholders to resolve the prevailing economic crisis in the country, according to Kariyawasam.  “It is not like sending workers to the Middle East. There would have been opportunities in Europe for skilled workers,” Kariyawasam added. By Naalir Jamaldeen

title: Kim Jong Un says N Korea aims to have ‘world’s strongest nuclear force’
author: Author not found
Content: North Korean leader Kim Jong Un said his country’s intends to have the world’s most powerful nuclear force as he promoted dozens of military officers involved in the recent launch of a new ballistic missile, state media reported on Sunday. The announcement comes after Kim inspected a Nov. 18 test of the Hwasong-17, North Korea’s largest intercontinental ballistic missile (ICBM) and pledged to counter what he called U.S. nuclear threats. North Korea’s “ultimate goal is to possess the world’s most powerful strategic force, the absolute force unprecedented in the century,” Kim said in the order promoting the officers, adding that building up the country’s nuclear capabilities would reliably protect the dignity and sovereignty of the state and the people. He described the Hwasong-17 as the “world’s strongest strategic weapon” and said it demonstrated North Korea’s resolve and ability to eventually build the world’s strongest army. North Korean scientists have made a “wonderful leap forward in the development of the technology of mounting nuclear warheads on ballistic missiles,” and were expected to expand and strengthen the country’s nuclear deterrent capabilities at an extraordinarily rapid pace, Kim was also quoted as saying. Kim was pictured in photos posing with scientists, engineers and military officials involved in the test. According to state media, those workers pledged to defend the “absolute authority” of the party and Kim, and vowed that “our missiles will fly vigorously only in the direction indicated” by Kim. Capable of reaching the U.S. mainland, the launch of the Hwasong-17 prompted the United States to call for a United Nations Security Council presidential statement to hold North Korea accountable for its missile tests, which are banned by Security Council resolutions. (Reuters)

title: Rasamanickam refutes Chandrakanthan’s allegations
author: Author not found
Content: Illankai Tamil Arasu Kachchi (ITAK) MP Shanakiyan Rasamanickam claimed yesterday (27) that State Minister Sivanesathurai Chandrakanthan alias Pillayan has made baseless allegations about him having lands in the Manmunai South and Eruvil Pattu Divisional Secretariat (DS) Divisions in the Batticaloa District, tarnishing his reputation. He said, this when queried about the alleged land acquisition issue. MP Shanakiyan also said,if State Minister Chandrakanthan’s allegations were true, he must prove it and be prepared to give evidence. “State Minister Chandrakanthan had said in Parliament without having proper evidence that MP Rasamanickam has unlawfully acquired 7 acres of State land in Onthachimadam village in the Manmunai South and Eruvil South DS Divisions. I can’t accept those baseless allegations,” MP Rasamanickam said. “I would like to say with responsibility that I have no land in the aforesaid DS Divisions in my name,” MP Rasamanickam said. “A complaint has been filed with the Kaluwanchikudy Police against Batti TV of the Tamil Makkal Viduthalai Pulikal (TMVP) party, which telecast false news in connection with this matter,” Rasamanickam added. By Naalir Jamaldeen

title: Pakistani Envoy inaugurates fifteen water wells in Mannar
author: Author not found
Content: Pakistani High Commissioner to Sri Lanka, Major General Umar Farooq Burki inaugurated fifteen community water wells in Mannar during his visit to the North. This drinking water well project is the first of its kind initiated by the Pakistani High Commission, Sri Lanka on behalf of the Government of Pakistan. This project covers approximately 40 km and benefits over 200 villagers including one preschool and one community mosque. These wells are the first of many more similar projects in different parts of Sri Lanka specifically for areas where the water table is very low and it is very difficult for the local community to get fresh water for drinking, irrigation, and other routine matters. Furthermore, he distributed desktop computers among four schools in Mannar. The school principals were extremely happy for this help as initially their students were not getting equal opportunities to study technology and related capabilities like the students in big cities. He also distributed sewing machines among deserving women of the local community. The ladies were extremely happy as they were now able to help their families by staying within the four walls of their house, looking after their children, as well as earning for themselves. Meanwhile, Pakistani High Commissioner Burki paid a courtesy call on the Mayor of Jaffna and Imam of community mosque in Jaffna. Matters of bilateral interest were discussed and the High Commissioner thanked them for their gracious hospitality. He also paid a courtesy call on Commander Kilinochichi and area Commander 54 Army Headquarters. The Sri Lankan Army Commanders along with their senior officers warmly welcomed the High Commissioner. Extensive discussions took place during the meetings about strengthening defence and military-civil relations between the two countries. The one week-long maiden tour of the High Commissioner of Pakistan to Sri Lanka, to the Northern Province is being deemed very important because of its multifaceted engagements and the response received from the local community, civil and military leadership of that region as well as by the Venerable Monks of Anuradhapura. The Pakistani High Commission will continue the goodwill activities which will benefit people of Sri Lanka regardless of gender, age, or ethnicity.
