title: Rotaract organises workshop
author: Author not found
Content: The Rotaract Club of Pearl Island has organised a workshop to enlighten on the word of ‘Rotaract’ including a Leadership programme followed by a BBQ and DJ night for fellowship.  The event will take place in 3 December from 3.00 p.m. at Trace City Expert, Colombo 10. The workshop will be conducted by the Past District Rotaract Representative for the years 2019- 2021 Rtn Rtr PP Krishan Balaji, Past District Rotaract Representative 2021-22 Rtn Rtr PP Akhila Wijethunga , District Rotaract Representative 2022-23 Rtn Rtr Past President Ahamed Hussain  and District Rotaract Representative Elect 2022-23 Rtn Rtr  President Sathma Jayasinghe. Rotaract is a Worldwide Youth – led voluntary movement with over 90+ clubs around Sri Lanka alone. The Rotaract movement volunteers to support the community including the marginalised. Various avenues such as Environment Services, Professional Development, International services and understanding, Club services, sports and recreation, p0ublic relations and so on. Youngsters have the opportunity to groom themselves through hands-on experience to support their personal life, career, family and social life. This event will be open for non-Rotaractors only. Tickets can be reserved through the link in the club’s Instagram page bio or contact the project chair Rtr Sajjaad Ahamed on  +94 76 677 8032. Rotaract is an ocean filled with opportunities.

title: Title not found
author: Author not found
Content: Date: For the second consecutive year, the Marketing Management Association (MMA), of the Department of Marketing Management, University of Sri Jayewardenepura, is organising the Marketing Architect webinar series, with the purpose of covering trending topics and providing insights that will help design a sharp marketer. Marketing architect 2.0 benefits many pillars in society by creating a path to build next level enthusiastic marketers as it imparts knowledge that helps fresh marketers develop their skills. Marketing Architect is well-known by its aspiring audience, as the series of webinars discusses novel topics that are related to the field of marketing, and they are eagerly waiting to get the experience of a lifetime. Japura marketers gave a blasting come back to marketing architect 2.0 and conducted many virtual sessions covering the topics of positioning businesses in the foreign market, industry experience in digital marketing, navigating the legal conduct in marketing, personal branding for fresh graduates, advertising in digital world, and astroturfing. The latest session for the year will be based on another interesting subject area, which is none other than the ‘Metaverse’. The metaverse is a hypothetical iteration of the internet as a single, universal, and immersive virtual world that is facilitated using virtual reality and augmented reality headsets. Businesses and marketing in today’s world are penetrated by technology and its development, and it has become the newest macro-goal for many of the world’s tech giants. Therefore, the Marketing Management Association is planning to conduct the final session of the Marketing Architect 2.0 this year as a discussion forum on ‘The Metaverse: Through a Marketer’s Eye’ under the theme ‘Decoding the Metaverse”’ and how virtual worlds will change the way we do almost everything. The panelists for the day will be Lalith Sumanisiri Godakanda, the Managing Director of Ogilvy Digital, Ogilvy Media and Redworks, Indika Bandara Wijesooriya, the Chief Innovation Officer at Arimac Lanka and Dr. Sapumal Ahangama, a Senior Lecturer at the Department of Computer Science and Engineering, University of Moratuwa. The moderator for the day will be Amitha Amarasinghe, the co-founder and CEO at APIDM. The session will be held on Monday (28), from 5.30 p.m. to 7.30 p.m. at the Senate Board Room of the University. Popular

title: Retirement age issue included in Order Paper
author: Author not found
Content: The recommendations of the Cabinet Sub Committee, headed by Prime Minister Dinesh Gunawardene, set up to decide on the compulsory retirement age for specialised services and posts including doctors, have been included in Order Paper of Parliament to be approved on 26 November. However, the Leader of the House informed Parliament yesterday (24), that the Cabinet Sub Committee will henceforth be acting on the advice received from the Attorney General as a few petitions had been submitted to Court pertaining to the Cabinet decisions. According to the recommendations, opportunity will be provided for doctors to serve until 30 June of the relevant year, whose birthday falls between 1 January and 30 June to retire. For doctors whose birthday falls between 1 July and 31 December can serve until 31 December of the year they should retire. The Cabinet had granted its approval to implement the recommendations pertaining to specialised doctors, Government sector medical professionals, dentists and State sector registered medical practitioners etc.

title: Sajith slams President’s statement
author: Author not found
Content: Opposition Leader Sajith Premadasa, who vehemently condemned President Ranil Wickremesinghe’s speech in Parliament on Wednesday (23), requested everyone to ignore the said statement. The President said in Parliament that he will not allow another ‘Aragalaya’ to happen to topple the Government and he will deploy the military and declare a State of Emergency to ‘handle’ such attempts. “The President does not understand the value of an election, as he wasn’t voted in as an MP, but was nominated on the National List, thus we are not surprised by his recent statement,” Premadasa said. Speaking in Parliament yesterday (24), Premadasa said 22 million citizens were saddened by the President’s speech and warned another uprising will take place for their democratic rights. “Some ‘slaves’ in the House cheered, showing their support to the President’s anti-democratic statements. It is pathetic to see that those who were voted into power are now cheering to violate people’s rights,” he stressed. Premadasa said the President should be thankful to ‘Aragalayites.’   He concluded by saying if he was a follower of Mahinda Rajapaksa as he was alleged to be, he would be the President, instead of Opposition Leader. By Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: Consent only to federal solution – Sampanthan
author: Author not found
Content: ITAK Leader MP R. Sampanthan has emphasised that all Tamil political parties, who intend to participate in a series of discussions with the Government next month, aimed at resolving the ethnic issue, should grant their consent solely to a federal solution. Ceylon Today learns, the ITAK Leader had aired these views during a round of talks with the representatives of political parties in the TNA, at his official residence in Colombo, on 23 November. During this discussion, Sampanthan had stressed that the move made by the President to commence an urgent dialogue with the Tamil political parties towards the resolution of the vexed North-East issue should be welcomed by all political parties in the country. He had then invited all representatives of political parties being represented in the TNA, to attend another round of talks in this connection in Colombo today (25). BY D.L. Jayakody

title: SriLankan in crisis due to exodus of pilots
author: Author not found
Content: A crisis has hit SriLankan Airlines, due to the mass exodus of airline pilots, owing to the current situation of the company, SriLankan Airlines CEO Richard Nuttall said yesterday (24). Addressing the media, Nuttall said although attention had been paid to the situation, they are handicapped as there are certain limitations imposed by the Government on new recruitments. “This is because there is a high demand for the pilots at the moment from many airlines companies in the world. We held a board meeting regarding the matter as well as with the Ministry of Aviation,” he said. He said the company is willing to extend its operations if the capacity could be expanded. We have not been receiving any financial assistance from the Government since last March, he said. BY Bingun Menaka Gamage

title: President talks tough
author: Author not found
Content: President Ranil Wickremesinghe emphasised that he will never allow violence and anarchy to prevail under the guise of human rights, adding that if any party engages in such an attempt, the security forces will be used to suppress it completely. Under such circumstances, the President emphasised that everyone from the soldier in the lowest rank of the Army to the rank of Field Marshal is obligated to fulfil their responsibility.   President Ranil Wickremesinghe said this delivering a special statement in Parliament yesterday (24). He accused certain factions of trying to constrain the Police under the guise of human rights. “Perhaps the Police have violated human rights. If some have done so, we are ready to take action against them if cases are filed and they are found guilty. Human rights cases are filed against the Police to stop them from taking action against those who create emergencies and riots. This is done not because of human rights, but to stop the Police from taking action against them. So, I asked the Attorney General to look into this. If they do that, the law should be implemented. This game cannot be allowed to continue forever.”  “When talking about the Army, some people said that the expenditure of the Army has increased. The allocations for the military cannot be reduced in 24 hours. The 25,000 employees cannot be put on the road at once. We are making a plan now. It should be done accordingly. The Army had to bear more expenses this time. We cannot stop it. Although the number of troops has decreased, promotions have increased. Such facts have also affected this. “The other thing is that now we have deployed the Army for food security programmes. Also, we get a lot of income from military farms and I have told them to use the Army as much as necessary for the transportation of those goods. We need to look at the future of the Army. We are working according to the Security 2030 report for that. We must plan our defences. “It is impossible to say that there is no threat in the world. These conditions are changing. Not the 1971 threat, the ‘80s, or the Easter Sunday incident. These threats happen in different ways. We must remember that. We must look at global conditions. We need to focus on the Indian Ocean. Our naval forces should be increased by 2030. The Army may decrease. “The Air Force may have more fighter jets. Drone technology is needed. By 2040, this situation will increase even more. We want to see how this will continue. We need to reduce our defence expenditure to maintain 3%-4%. “We have enough money to bring our economic growth rate to 8%. This situation was created in Singapore with this 8% economic growth for many years. We need to think anew. Also, those who leave the Army should have the opportunity to contribute to the work of this society. “Today, professionals are leaving this country. That gap can be filled by training our armed forces personnel and sending them to those places. That is why we have reduced the retirement age of military service from 22 to 18 years. Others have no problem. We have to plan these anew. We have to think anew. “I wish we could manufacture a new warship in Sri Lanka. We have that power. Only the money has to be found. We have also paid attention to the Police. We are getting a report called ‘Public Security Report’ to find out how to improve the Police in the next 10 years. I informed the Minister about it. Now the Police Ordinance has reached the stage where it has to be sent to the museum. We are now working on preparing a new Ordinance. There are many problems like drug trafficking and human trafficking today. We have to move forward in solving all these issues. I would like to remind the Minister of Education that not a single university student is in custody. Wasantha Mudalige was a university student for 8-9 years. This is very important. I left university at 21. Although Mudalige is 31 years old, he is still a university student. A student can only be given one extra year. After that, they should have to leave the university. I want to say something. I also want to protect human rights. Anarchy and violence cannot be allowed to encroach on human rights. Human rights cannot be used to create violence and anarchy. Those who cause violence in the name of human rights cannot be protected.”

title: IMF process won’t delay till March – CBSL Head
author: Author not found
Content: Central Bank Governor Dr. Nandalal Weerasinghe yesterday (24) said, if Sri Lanka misses the December deadline with International Monetary Fund (IMF), it is expected to make another request in January 2023. However, the process will not be delayed until March 2023. Dr. Weerasinghe said they are confident of getting assurance from bilateral creditors. The assurance from our bilateral creditors should be obtained in the next couple of weeks, he said.

title: SC issues notice on ex-President
author: Author not found
Content: The Supreme Court yesterday (24) issued notice on former President Gotabaya Rajapaksa, returnable on 16 December, to make statements in connection with the Presidential pardon granted to former MP Duminda Silva. This was when the Fundamental Rights (FR) Petitions filed against the Presidential pardon granted to Silva, who was sentenced to death in 2016 over the murder of Bharatha Lakshman Premachandra, was taken up before Supreme Court Justices Murdu Fernando and Yasantha Kodagoda. The two-Judge Bench approved the request made by the Petitioners to amend the caption of the Petition to include Rajapaksa in his personal capacity, as he is in no longer the President. Thereby, notice was ordered to be issued to Rajapaksa, to his private residence and to any other address in which he is accessible. Eraj de Silva with Daminda Wijayaratne and S Janagan instructed by Dimuthu Kuruppuarachchi, President’s Counsel M. A. Sumanthiran with Suren Fernando and Khyati Wickremanayake appeared on behalf the Petitioners. Previously, the Supreme Court issued an Interim Order suspending the operation of the Presidential pardon granted to Silva while an order impounding Silva’s passport was also made while the Criminal Investigation Department (CID) was directed to implement the interim order. While Silva was sentenced to death in 2016 for the murder of Bharatha Lakshman Premachandra in 2011, President Gotabaya Rajapaksa granted a special Presidential pardon to him in 2021. BY Faadhila Thassim

title: Gunaratnam not dual citizen – Jayagoda
author: Author not found
Content: Frontline Socialist Party (FSP) Educational Secretary Pubudu Jayagoda refuted the statement made by President Ranil Wickremesinghe in Parliament that FSP’s Kumar Gunaratnam is a dual citizen and the party was behind the 9 May violence and 13 July unrest near Parliament. The President claimed Gunaratnam has citizenship in Australia as well as in Sri Lanka. Jayagoda, addressing the media on the President’s allegations, claimed that President Ranil Wickremesinghe’s statements in Parliament on Wednesday (23) and yesterday (24) were a declaration of war against all citizens. “Wickremesinghe perfectly knows comrade Gunaratnam is not a citizen of Australia. Gunaratnam had to leave the country given the circumstances in that era. When he returned to the country to engage in politics, the then Government arrested him. Wickremesinghe was the Prime Minister of that Government. Now he is alleging that we are responsible for the violence on 9 May. This is completely false. If we had any connection to those incidents, he would not take it sitting down like this,” Jayagoda stressed. He said Ranil Wickremesinghe is breaking the law and the Constitution while saying he is protecting the Constitution. He said it is a joke that President is informing the people to obtain a permit to protest as the people are protesting against the Government. He said this war is between the people of the country and the clan which is filled with fraudsters, murderers, robber and the power hungry. The innocent people fought against the corrupt parties. The ‘Aragalaya’ was a fantastic uprising of the people, he said. While noting that the fight must be completed, as an incomplete fight is a failure, Jayagoda emphasised the FSP will protect the Aragalaya from all forces. He claimed the President is scared and that is why he is roaming around making arbitrary statements. Jayagoda requested the people to not be scared of these claims and to be strong. BY Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Suspended SLFPers say will take legal action if removed
author: Author not found
Content: The SLFP members who were suspended from the Party yesterday (24) said they were not informed in writing of their suspension. They noted that if they are removed from the Party and are formally informed, they will take legal action. They also stressed that they would never leave the Party even if they were removed from portfolios or membership. MPs Shantha Bandara, Chamara Sampath, Duminda Dissanayake, Nimal Siripala de Silva, Mahinda Amaraweera, Ranjith Siyambalapitiya, Jagath Pushpakumara, and Suren Raghawan were among the ministers who addressed the media briefing to express their concerns. De Silva also said they were working for the betterment of the country and that they could not be selfish or jealous in order to assist the country in overcoming this crisis. He said they will never join other parties and will always support the SLFP. He claimed that history has shown that there are members who have betrayed the SLFP. Addressing the media, Dissanayake said if mistakes were made in the past, he was also a part of them, but now, more than the party’s decision, they should consider the public. He noted that they have been SLFP members for generations and that no one can remove their membership based on a letter. He noted that their home is the SLFP, and that despite many attempts to persuade them to join other parties, they do not want to be a part of any other space. He also stressed that in order to address the issues that have arisen within the party, the leadership should be handed over to someone else, with SLFP Chairman Maithripala Sirisena acting as a patron. After they were kicked out of the UNP, no one went to the party’s headquarters in Sirikotha, according to Sampath. BY Savani Sheashadhi

title: Surge in H1N1 influenza cases
author: Author not found
Content: A rising trend is being witnessed in H1N1 influenza cases being detected among the adolescent and adult population in the country, Head of National Influenza Centre, Medical Research Institute (MRI), Consultant Virologist, Dr. Jude Jayamaha said. Dr. Jayamaha, when contacted yesterday (24), said patients with the viral subtype – especially those in the high-risk category should seek immediate medical attention. The high-risk groups (HRG) include pregnant women, children below two years, elderly persons, and those with chronic diseases. Dr. Jayamaha, identifying symptoms, said they included cold, sore throat, and fever. However, patients should not resort to taking nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDS) such as Ibuprofen and Diclofenac.   He said the H1N1 influenza strain was witnessed in the country during the months of November, December, January, and February, while the H3N2 subtype of the influenza A virus was mostly seen during the months of April, May, and June. Dr. Jayamaha urged patients, especially adults and adolescents suffering from H1N1 to seek immediate medical attention. “They also require adequate rest and hydration during this period,” the Consultant Virologist said.  By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: CB Governor says will not accept pension
author: Author not found
Content: Governor of the Central Bank, Dr. Nandalal Weerasinghe, stated yesterday that his salary as Governor of the Central Bank is only Rs 400,000 per month. In addition to that, he also receives a pension for his previous 29 years of service at the Central Bank. Dr. Weerasinghe was responding to a question posed to him at the Central Bank’s press conference yesterday. “I want to categorically state that I am not entitled to any retirement benefits as a consequence of my earlier two year secondment to the International Monetary Fund as the Alternate Executive Director to the IMF’s headquarters in Washington,” the Governor said. “Some politicians have implied that I am entitled to IMF retirement benefits, but that is not true.” He stated that Ajith Nivard Cabraal was appointed Central Bank Governor for the second time and elevated the post to a Cabinet rank, and that his salary was increased to Rs 400,000 per month. He claimed that Dr. Indrajit Coomaraswamy, the previous Governor, was paid only Rs 150,000. Dr. Weerasinghe also said that during Cabraal’s second term as governor, the Central Bank used tax money to pay for a private staff service. As a result, from October 2021 to April 2022, Cabraal had a separate private secretary, a private press secretary, and benefited from the ministerial security. Dr. Weerasinghe thinks that a person who works for the government should have to work for at least 10 years before getting a pension. He said that even though people who have been governor for a few months are eligible for retirement benefits, he does not plan to take a pension for his current job as Governor of the Central Bank. Reports say that former governors of the Central Bank, Dr. Indrajit Coomaraswamy and Sunil Mendis, turned down their pensions. Professor W.D. Lakshman was governor for only a few months. He is now retired and enjoying the retirement benefits of that job. By Ishara Gamage

title: Embassy official’s diplomatic passport revoked
author: Author not found
Content: The diplomatic passport of the third secretary of the Sri Lankan Embassy in Oman, E. Kushan, has been revoked over his alleged involvement with Oman sex trafficking incident, the Sri Lanka Bureau of Foreign Employment (SLBFE) said. SLBFE confirmed that the Cabinet has approved the repatriation of 77 women stranded in Oman and another 77 stranded in Dubai, as a result of human trafficking linked to overstaying on visit and tourist visas. Deputy General Manager of the SLBFE, Senarath Yapa, said there are SLBFE registered workers and undocumented (not with the SLBFE) workers  among those who had travelled to the those two countries.  He said out of the 77 in Oman, 12 were registered with the SLBFE, however, the entire group will be brought back to Sri Lanka and it has been approved. He added that while 77 were to be repatriated from Oman another four stranded so called domestic workers in Oman have surrendered to the welfare camp run by the Sri Lankan Mission. He added at that beginning of the month of November 2022, the issue of single visit visa and tourist visa for domestic workers were completely stopped and on 11 of November, the SLBFE stopped all employment agencies from issuing visit or tourist visa for domestic workers. It has been the tradition that the Middle Eastern countries accept visit and tourist visa and allow it to be transferred to employment visa, but this is now being highly exploited with some racketeers getting the visit visa and then not finding jobs for those arrive on visit visa and later engage them to cross the borders and enter into prostitution for survival. According to reliable sources, Sri Lankan women are forced into sexual slavery for amounts as much as Rs 2.5 million. Yapa said already three local officials have been arrested in connection with this exploitation racket and one of the SLBFE employees in Oman will be brought back for engaging in these nefarious activities. By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: Lankan refugee dies by suicide in Vietnam
author: Author not found
Content: The Foreign Ministry confirmed yesterday (24) that one of the 303 refugees, who sought refuge in Vietnam, who attempted suicide few days ago died in the hospital. This happened while the International Organisation for Migration (IOM) had completed their screening of the people who travelled by boat in order to reach Canada. Ceylon Today learns that another man among them is in critical condition. These two are among many others who tried to take their lives over frustration that they are to be repatriated to Sri Lanka, where legal prosecution may be expected due to their illegal boat ride from Sri Lanka. The boat began to sink off the Vietnam coast when they were rescued. It is said, that deceased, in his 30s, is a father of four. A local media report said that the Vietnam officials are claiming a big sum to bury the body. According to sources, the IOM had completed screening all the refugees, who were sheltered in Vietnam, as a humanitarian measure on 18 November 2022. The IOM has made the list of the individuals and families who could be sent to a third country as refugees and some back to Sri Lanka. All the boat people said that they don’t want to return to Sri Lanka as they have suffered enough during the war, lost their loved ones and now they are unable to survive due to the ongoing financial crisis in the country and remained as neglected families. They said, they rather die in the sea than going back to Sri Lanka. The Foreign Ministry and the IOM with the assistance of the Vietnam government is assisting them to remain in the detention camp that was set for them until further action. By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: NC to bring transport sector to single digital platform
author: Author not found
Content: The National Council (NC) sub-committee on identifying short- and medium-term programmes related to economic stabilisation, discussed the creation of passenger convenience by bringing transport services, including trains, buses, school vans and taxi services to a single digital level. Discussions were held at the National Council sub-committee on identifying short- and medium-term programmes related to economic stabilisation recently.  Representatives of several parties related to the transport sector of Sri Lanka participated and views of respective parties on the problems in the transport sector were considered. Representatives of transport services including the Sri Lanka Private Bus Owners Association, Three Wheeler Association, School Children Transport Association pointed out that due to the high fuel prices, restrictions imposed on the import of vehicles and restrictions imposed on vehicle spare parts, they faced severe difficulties. They also pointed out that the price of spare parts, including vehicle tyres, have increased by 300 per cent. Further, they pointed out that the number of vehicles used for transport, including buses, school vans and three-wheelers were on the decrease due to the shortage of auto parts. The committee said it will present suggestions focusing on these situations. Accordingly, it is proposed to bring all the transport services to one digital platform to create passenger convenience as an important proposal. The committee said that a combination of all these proposals is expected to be presented to the National Council in December. Minister Dr. Naseer Ahmed, Sate Minister Lasantha Alagiyawanna, MP Sivanesanthurai Chandrakanthan and MP Mano Ganesan were present at the meeting.

title: ‘If someone walks out of my meeting, I will not allow them to come for another meeting, or let them stay in their post’
author: Author not found
Content: Public Security Minister Tiran Alles, responding to a claim by SJB MP Sarath Fonseka, said in Parliament yesterday (24), “Sarath Fonseka said that certain media has published that an SSP has walked out of one of my meetings claiming that he was not ready to follow our directives and that he was unwilling to act in an unlawful manner. “This is completely false. If someone has walked out of my meeting I will not allow that person to come back for another meeting, or I will not allow that person to hold that post, as long as I’m the subject minister. “This is an absolute lie. “The other claim made by Fonseka is that a large number of officers in the Western Province have asked to be transferred out of the Province. I called for a report from the DIGs. But so far, no officer has asked for a transfer. If a certain officer asked to be transferred, then we are ready to comply with their request. There are twice as many who want to be transferred here.”

title: Cabraal’s travel ban extended
author: Author not found
Content: Colombo Additional Magistrate Harshana Kekunawela yesterday (24), further extended the overseas travel ban clamped on former Central Bank Governor Ajith Nivard Cabraal until 15 December. A private plaint, filed by former Governor of the Southern Province, Ranjith Keerthi Tennakoon via an affidavit, was called before Colombo Chief Magistrate’s Court last morning . The plaintiff has alleged that during his tenure as the Central Bank Governor, from 2006 to 2015, Cabraal had paid a sum of USD 6.5 million to a Pakistani-American political donor Imaad Zuberi with obtaining approval from the Cabinet of Ministers and is thereby responsible for criminal breach of trust and criminal abuse of funds. Tennakoon has also charged Cabraal with causing a loss of USD 500 million to the Government via sovereign bonds due on 18 January 2022, while serving as the Central Bank Governor. According to the plaintiff, the Sri Lankan Government incurred a loss of Rs 10.04 billion through the appointing of close relatives to positions and from the release of confidential information on Treasury bills and bond issues, during his tenure as the Governor of the Central Bank of Sri Lanka. When the case was taken up before Additional Magistrate Kekunawala, the lawyers representing Cabraal raised preliminary objections against proceeding with the matter. Accordingly, the lawyers, who appeared on behalf of the plaintiff, were ordered to present written submissions at the next hearing pertaining to the preliminary objections raised by the defence. Tennakoon, via his private plaint, has charged that the actions of the former CBSL Governor had flouted Provisions contained in Sections 388, 392 and 386 of the Penal Code as well as Provisions contained in Section 56 (1) of the Registered Stock and Securities Ordinance No. 7 of 1937. By Hansi Nanayakkara

title: Nat Uni of Education to be set up – Premajayantha
author: Author not found
Content: Minister of Education Susil Premajayantha informed Parliament that a new procedure will be introduced to recruit teachers in the future.  Minister Premajayantha said they are planning to set up a ‘National University of Education’ for those who plan to become teachers.  Responding to MP Dayasiri Jayasekara in Parliament yesterday (24), Premajayantha said they plan to set up this university by combining all 19 teacher training colleges in the country. Premajayantha said sweeping reforms will be introduced in teacher training and appointments.  He said the degree programme will take four years to complete. The Minister further said they plan to produce quality teachers through this programme. By Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: NHSL Dy Director clarifies
author: Author not found
Content: With reference to the article, ‘X-rays, CT scans halted at National Hospital due to machine malfunctions’, published in Ceylon Today on 31 October 2022, Dr. W.K. Wickremasinghe, Deputy Director General of the National Hospital of Sri Lanka (NHSL), Colombo has sent the following clarification: “The above-mentioned article published in the Ceylon Today newspaper on 31 October 2022 contained inaccurate information regarding the concerned matter of the National Hospital of Sri Lanka, which is the apex tertiary care hospital delivering patient care services to patients referred from many regions of the island. Therefore, I would like to provide you the accurate information about the relevant matter. I kindly hope that your office will arrange the necessary to publish the correct information described in this letter in your newspaper. The information “X-rays cannot be performed on patients arriving at the Hospital” is incorrect. The Accident and Emergency Unit is equipped to perform all necessary X-rays and is currently providing services as usual. In fact all necessary X-rays were carried out then and there. The X-Ray tests performed in the accident and emergency unit are forwarded to the relevant clinical departments through a computer system (PACS- Picture Archiving and Communication System) using digital technology. The X-Ray records are stored and examined with the help of this computer system without the use of paper (paperless) or the use of printed images (filmless). This computer system needs regular maintenance and upgrading. Therefore, during such maintenance work on the computer system, it had to be turned off for a short period. During this period necessary arrangements are made to prevent disruption of patient care services. The necessary facilities are provided to the medical officers to examine the X-Rays through other alternative methods. Since the accident and emergency unit operates 24 hours a day, essential maintenance and updates of the system are usually performed this way. We would like to mention that the required X- Ray tests for the patients arriving at the accident and emergency unit can be performed without any interruption. The CT machine installed at the accident and emergency unit is about 12 years old and is currently not functioning. This is because the manufacturer has discontinued production of the spare parts required to repair this machine. Therefore, the local agent and the Biomedical Engineering Unit of the Ministry of Health have reported that this CT machine cannot be repaired and commissioned again. Furthermore, the operating lifetime of this CT machine has been exceeded and during its lifetime the machine has been utilized to the maximum extent. The Ministry of Health has been requested to provide a new CT machine for the accident and emergency unit and we have come to know that the necessary work is underway to procure a new one. We would like to mention that arrangements are made to carry out required CT tests for patients attending the Accident and Emergency Unit using other CT machines in the hospital. I hope that the above information is adequate to convey accurate facts to the public. Furthermore, I would like to mention that we are ready to provide the correct information that can be provided upon your request regarding matters related to the National Hospital of Sri Lanka. Your support is highly appreciated.

title: Ali Sabry reaffirms SL’s commitment to maritime sustainability
author: Author not found
Content: Foreign Minister Ali Sabry, addressing the Council of Ministers’ meeting of Indian Ocean Rim Association (IORA) in Bangladesh yesterday (24), apprised member states with regard to Sri Lanka’s efforts in sustainable and efficacious usage of maritime resources and immense ocean pollution challenges as well as projects and programmes implemented to safeguard the coastal belt and the Indian Ocean and that Sri Lanka remains committed to a safe, secure Indian Ocean and sustainable use of its maritime resources. He underlined maintaining a pollution-free and cleaner Indian Ocean following the MV X-Press Pearl calamity last year and emphasised the necessity for countries to work in a concerted manner in addressing ocean pollution, especially during maritime disasters. “Our efforts in addressing massive ocean pollution challenges stem as a result of accidents such as the X-Press Pearl Disaster, which unfortunately, disrupted the region on an unprecedented scale. The X-Press Pearl incident is the worst maritime disaster that Sri Lanka has confronted in modern times. The vessel was carrying a total of nearly 1,500 containers that included cargo with hazardous substances, in addition to about 325 metric tonnes of fuel on board.” He added that the disaster is now considered as the largest ship disaster involving plastic pellets, hazardous and noxious materials, in the world. The geographic implications of the incident remain unknown given its developing nature. A substantial proportion of the plastic pellet pollution will remain mobilised in the ocean for decades to come. Modelling studies suggest that the pellets will make landfall across Indian Ocean coastlines. We have implemented a significant number of projects and programmes to ensure that our ocean remains less polluted and cleaner following this incident and we have been working with many other countries and international agencies, which deal and address ocean pollution to lessen the negative impact of this disaster. The Minister underscored the significance and necessity of actively engaging with the countries of IORA and that the IORA is to mutually advance economic and commercial interests of Sri Lanka as well as to maintain peace and stability in the Indian Ocean. He further stressed that Sri Lanka’s commitment to the matters that concern the Indian Ocean region remain as one of the key cornerstones of the economic and foreign policy of Sri Lanka. Recalling the historical background on trade and commerce as well as connectivity in the Indian Ocean region, the Minister highlighted that Sri Lanka is strategically positioned at the centre of one of the busiest sea lanes in the world. He also added that Sri Lanka’s traditional and ancient links with the countries of the Indian Ocean Rim Association go back many centuries and empirical evidence reveals that Sri Lanka’s geographical centrality markedly facilitated and aided maritime commerce and trade over the centuries. The Minister said, Sri Lanka has demonstrated manifestly significant openness to trade and commerce and, today, Sri Lanka is well positioned to be one of the major trading hubs of the Indian Ocean. Given the progression as an Indian Ocean hub, Sri Lanka has emerged as one of the most pivotal shipping lanes, as two-thirds of the petroleum products and half of the container shipments of the world criss-cross close to the Southern Coast of the island. Highlighting Sri Lanka’s interests in the IORA and the region, as well as Sri Lanka’s active role in the organisation as the current Vice Chair of IORA, the Minister said Sri Lanka will be the next Chair of the IORA from 2023 to 2025 with a firm conviction to further expand and elevate the scope and breadth of the organisation to be more relevant and more pertinent to the rapidly emerging importance of the Indian Ocean in the present geopolitical and geoeconomic scenario.

title: LOLC Group continues UoC Alumni partnership for 2022 / 2023
author: Author not found
Content: Leading conglomerate LOLC Group extended its MOU with the Alumni Association of the University of Colombo (UoC), for another year up to end 2023. The University of Colombo Alumni Partnership Programme is a continuing initiative of the Alumni Association of the University of Colombo, which represents all Alumni of the University of Colombo, to work closely with leading private and public sector organisations to provide opportunities for enhanced corporate sector involvement and support in the UoC’s activities. Formed in 1982, the Alumni Association of the University of Colombo is an apex body of the alumni of various faculties of the University, forming a link between its membership and the University. Members of the Association comprise all Alumni who have passed out of the University of Colombo. Today, the Association continues its role of fostering close ties between the student body, University and its alumni. The Alumni Association of the University of Colombo views its role as ‘connectors’ and thought leaders very seriously and to this end, not only conducts various programs and initiatives targeting the development and welfare of undergraduates and its members but also conducts public forums to create awareness and discussion in matters of public importance. Pradeep Uluwaduge, Chief Human Resource Officer of the LOLC Group said “As the largest conglomerate in Sri Lanka, we always treasure our strong rapport with the premier University in the country, the University of Colombo. In spite of the present economic and social stress, a close link between higher educational institutions and the industry is of paramount importance. I firmly believe our Corporate partnership with the UoC Alumni can play a pivotal role in new dimensions to bridge gaps in our traditional education system.” Rajeev Amarasuriya, UoC Alumni President said, “it was comforting to note that the Corporate Sector has not shelved their Corporate Social Responsibilities during these trying times for everyone. The LOLC Group has supported the activities of the Association now for several years, and we appreciate the support we receive, not only financially but technically as well.” Amarasuriya went on to state that the next significant activity of the Association was holding the 17th Annual Sujata Jayawardena Memorial Oration on the topic ‘Economic Crisis: Where are we, and where do we go from here?’ which will be delivered by Former Central Bank Governor Deshamanaya Indrajit Coomaraswamy on 29th November at the BMICH.

title: Wele Suda gun case on 9 December
author: Author not found
Content: Colombo High Court Judge Navaratne Marasinghe, on Wednesday (23), ordered the Pre-Trial Conference of the case filed against noted drug kingpin Gampola Vithanage Samantha Kumara alias Wele Suda on 9 December. The drug kingpin has been accused before the High Court of unlawful possession of a T-56 rifle and a revolver. When the case was called Judge Marasinghe noticed the witnesses to the trial including the OIC of the Borelesgamuwa Police to be present before him on the said date to testify. The Attorney General has indicted Wele Suda before the High Court of the aforesaid offences which had been committed on or before 24 April 16 years ago in Borella. The accused has already been convicted of a separate offence and is currently serving time on death row. By Hansi Nanayakkara

title: ‘I will not allow another Aragalaya’
author: Author not found
Content: President Ranil Wickremesinghe yesterday (23) warned in Parliament that he will not allow another ‘Aragalaya’ to take place in the country to topple the Government and he will use military and emergency laws to “handle” such attempts to prevent ‘Dinh Diem rule’ in Sri Lanka. “I will not let a ‘Dinh Diem rule’ be established in this country. There will be no more ‘Aragalaya’ to topple the Government. I will deploy the military and declare a State of Emergency to handle such attempts. There is no place for ‘Dinh Diems’ in this country,” the President stressed. Wickremesinghe, participating in the Committee Stage Debate on Budget 2023 said he will not dissolve the House until stability returns to the country. The President also said he will appoint a Presidential Commission of Inquiry (PCoI) to probe the “forces” who created unrest in the country and which media institutions incited people to burn down houses. “We have gone to Court in regard to the violence on 9 May. One MP was killed on the street. Another MP who first said ‘Gota Go Home’ was brutally assaulted. Houses of MPs were burnt down. Some of them did not even go to Temple Trees on that day. This violence is unacceptable. On 9 July, the former President was chased away. After that, so-called ‘Aragalayites’ captured the President’s House and Presidential Secretariat. Look at the damage they have done to those buildings. I have a full report of damage caused to those buildings,” he said. Speaking further, Wickremesinghe accused Frontline Socialist Party (FSP) Leader Kumar Gunaratnam of being behind the attempt to capture Parliament on 13 July, and trying to create chaos and violence islandwide “After that, they demanded that I resign. Why should I resign? Majority of Parliament was there. If an All-Party Government was set up then I could have resigned. When I said I will not resign from the post, my house was set alight. Then, on 13 July, there was an attempt to capture Parliament. They were to capture the Supreme Court next. They captured the Prime Minister’s Office. That was how they tried to set up a puppet government,” he alleged. How can the FSP leader, who is a dual citizen of Sri Lanka and Australia, say that Basil Rajapaksa should be barred from Parliament? he queried. He requested the Opposition not to be deceived by “vicious forces” that try to unleash chaos in the country. “Those who unleashed violence are not the common people. In the end, they accused me of being a dictator. They told foreign media that there is not dictator in the world like me. I was the one who brought 17th, 19th and 21st Amendments to the Constitution and now I have become a dictator like Hitler. Even Al Jazeera said Ranil is a dictator and asked me to be a democratic leader like the Qatari Emir. I cannot be like that,” he said. The President said he is not against legal protests. “I request the people to engage in protests, marches, and meetings in a legal manner. It is okay to scream that I am a dictator, I do not mind. But if you are trying to engage in such things without a licence and blocking the roads, that would not be permitted,” he asserted. By Methmalie Dissanayake

title: Siridhamma Thera enlarged on bail
author: Author not found
Content: Colombo Additional Magistrate T.N.L. Mahawatta yesterday (23) ordered the Convener of the Inter University Bhikku Federation (IUBF) Ven. Galwewa Siridhamma Thera who was arrested and detained for interrogation as per Provisions of the Prevention of Terrorism Act (PTA) and then remanded to be enlarged on bail as per advice of the Attorney General Sanjay Rajaratnam. Accordingly, the Additional Magistrate ordered the suspect to be released on two personal bails of Rs 500,000 each and the Magistrate also ordered to impound the passport of the monk. Furthermore, the Court also ordered the suspect Convener of the IUBF to report to the TID on last Sunday of each month and instructed him not to express views in public pertaining to the trial as part of the bail conditions imposed. The Court then ordered the suspect monk to refrain from engaging any acts of violence during the period the trial lasts and warned that if any complaints are brought to its attention in that regard his bail will be revoked and ordered to be remanded till the conclusion of the lawsuit. Ven. Siridhamma Thera was held along with the Convener of Inter University Students’ Federation (IUSF) Wasantha Mudalige for over 90 days. Senior Deputy Solicitor General Dileepa Peiris, producing submissions, informed the Court that Attorney General Rajaratnam has consented to grant conditional bail to the suspect, pursuant to Article 7(2) of the PTA.  He informed Additional Magistrate Mahawatta that the CID was currently carrying out a detailed probe with regard to certain incidents that had taken place from 31 March to 13 July this year. Peiris added that Mudallige has also been named as a suspect in the ongoing trial and that currently he was in remand after being arrested pursuant to an order issued by the Court as per the PTA. Further proceedings of the trial were then deferred to 12 December. Mudalige and Siridhamma Thera were among several other protesters who were placed under arrest following a protest march, organised by the IUSF against the incumbent Government, at Union Place in Colombo on 18 August. The Police initially obtained a 72-hour detention order on three activists including Mudalige and Siridhamma Thera. Later, the Ministry of Defence gave the nod for a request made by the Police to further detain the trio for a period of 90 days for interrogations. On 17 November, the Colombo Additional Magistrate ordered to remand Mudalige and Siridhamma Thera, who were detained at the Old Prison in Tangalle, until the AG’s orders are received. By Hansi Nanayakkara

title: Inland Revenue Dept suffers tax loss
author: Author not found
Content: SJB MP Buddhika Pathirana alleged that the sticker affixed on the lid of liquor bottles to confirm quality was fabricated thus depriving the Excise Department of intended revenue. Many Excise Department officials were concealling the true facts following inspection. He made these allegations while speaking on the last day of the Second Reading of Budget 2023 in Parliament on Tuesday (22). Pathirana added that some officials of the Excise Department were responsible for the incident. He also said, that he has informed Parliament about the sticker scam earlier. He questioned whether the authorities took action regarding the scam. He said as a result, the Inland Revenue Department has been deprived of collecting a large amount of taxes. BY Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: SL Embassy official was to be suspended in February
author: Author not found
Content: The official at the Sri Lankan Embassy in Oman, who allegedly has connections with trafficking Sri Lankan women into Oman for sexual slavery, has several other allegations against him and as a result a request had been made to suspend his service in February this year, it was revealed at the Committee on Public Accounts (COPA). COPA questioned SLBFE officials and expressed displeasure as to why the suspect was not suspended at that time. Accordingly, former Chairman of Sri Lanka Bureau of Foreign Employment (SLBFE) Major General Mahinda Hathurusinghe on 28 February 2022 had requested an internal audit with regard to the allegations of forging documents and financial malpractices against the suspect. Major General Hathurusinghe also requested to suspend the official and send him back to Sri Lanka. However, no action had been taken with regard to that, COPA learned. SLBFE officials said, although an internal audit was conducted, allegations against him could not be proved. After revelations of human trafficking in Oman, which forced nearly 80 women to be involved in sexual slavery, the official was suspended as per the report received from the CID, officials said. BY Methmalie Dissanayake

title: S’pore Health Ministry officials in town
author: Author not found
Content: Ten officials from the Ministry of Health, Singapore arrived in Colombo on 22 November night to conduct a feasibility study. According to sources from the Ministry of Health in Sri Lanka, the Singaporean Health Ministry delegation had arrived to explore the possibility of opening up employment opportunities to 4,000 Sri Lankan nurses in Singapore in 2023. An official from the Sri Lankan Embassy in Singapore said if this opportunity becomes a reality it would be after 20 years that Sri Lankan nurses will get the chance to work in Singapore. During their stay in Sri Lanka till 25 November, the Singaporean Health Ministry delegation is scheduled to visit the Sri Lanka Nursing College, Sri Jayewardenepura Hospital, a private hospital in Colombo, and a few Sri Lankan universities. By T.K.G. Kapila – Katunayake

title: Submit resolution to dissolve Parliament if you can
author: Author not found
Content: While challenging the Opposition to submit a proposal to dissolve Parliament, if they have the capacity to do it, Prime Minister Dinesh Gunawardena said the truth is that the Opposition is incapable of achieving support by proving themselves in Parliament.  The Premier rejected claims about the lack of a people’s mandate for the Government by declaring that Ranil Wickremesinghe became President with the vote of the majority of Parliament who represent the people. He said, Opposition parties who were silent when the ‘Aragalaya’ was destroying State institutes and homes of State employees, were now speaking about democracy and elections. He urged, the Opposition to end the culture of hate in politics and unite to work towards the success and of the people. Speaking during the Budget 2023 debate in Parliament yesterday (23), Prime Minister Gunawardena quoting former US President John F. Kennedy, said, the Opposition should start questioning themselves as to what they can do for the country instead of what the country can do for them. The Premier concluded declaring that the Government has taken a number of steps and sacrificed much to relieve the suffering of the citizens. By Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: Hanaa Singer meets Public Security Minister
author: Author not found
Content: UN Resident Coordinator in Sri Lanka, Hanaa Singer visited the Ministry of Public Security yesterday (23) to meet the Minister of Public Security, Tiran Alles. Recent public protests were discussed during the meeting and Singer appreciated how Sri Lanka Police acted during those protests. She also  appreciated the current democratic political environment in Sri Lanka and pledged that the UN will provide its full support to Sri Lanka’s fight against narcotics.

title: ‘I’m not an MP, I’m a Minister’
author: Author not found
Content: State Minister of Primary Industries, Chamara Sampath Dassanayake, felt belittled yesterday (23) when the Speaker referred to him as an MP, and not as ‘Minister’. Speaker Mahinda Yapa Abeywardena: “MP Chamara Sampath, now your turn to speak.” Dassanayake: “I am not an MP, but a ‘Minister’ now thanks to the President. President Ranil Wickremesinghe gave me a ministerial portfolio. Don’t you know that? So, don’t call me an MP. You should work according to the traditions of Parliament.” The Speaker, who was laughing at Dassanayake’s sudden outburst said, “Okay, okay. I am sorry ‘Minister.’ It is your turn to speak now!” Meanwhile, State Minister Dassanayake said he would resign from his portfolio, if he fails to collect USD 500 million from the gem industry next year. He stressed that although gems worth over USD 1 billion have been exported, payments for the exported gems have not been received yet. Dassanayake was responding to Opposition Leader Sajith Premadasa when the latter raised concerns on the gem industry. Premadasa said, gem businessmen as well as those engaged in the mining industry face severe difficulties due to the absence of an online system for gem exports. “The gem industry is a sector that makes a very special contribution to the economy of this country. In the last year (2021), an income of USD 276 million was earned through the exportation of gems, diamonds and jewellery in Sri Lanka. However, more money can be earned through this industry,” Premadasa said. In response, Dassanayake said he will never allow the industry to collapse and that he effort to earn USD 500 million from the industry within next year (2023). He added that income received from the gem industry is only USD 170 million for 2022 and he would resign from his ministerial post if he fails to earn the promised amount of USD 500 million. BY Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: Consultative Committee discusses Anti-Corruption Bill
author: Author not found
Content: The proposed Anti-Corruption Bill, inclusive of the establishment of an Independent Commission of Inquiry on Bribery and Corruption, which is accountable to Parliament, was looked into at the Ministerial Consultative Committee on Justice, Prison Affairs and Constitutional Reforms. This was discussed at the Ministerial Consultative Committee on Justice, Prison Affairs and Constitutional Reforms under the chairmanship of Minister Dr. Wijeyadasa Rajapakshe and President’s Counsel Sarath Jayamanne. The Minister said, all allegations of bribery and corruption in the country are being levelled at parliamentarians due to the failure to create a formal institutional structure and provide the necessary powers to prevent bribery, corruption, and fraud. President’s Counsel Sarath Jayamanne said, the proposed Bribery or Corruption Investigation Commission will be accountable to Parliament and that the Commission will submit its progress report to Parliament every three months. The Bill also proposes to appoint persons with over 20 years of experience in the fields of law, forensic audit, accounting, engineering, international relations and diplomatic service, and public administration as commissioners of the commission, he said. Commissioners are appointed by the President on the recommendation of the Constitutional Council and also the allocation of money for this commission should be done directly through Parliament, Sarath Jayamanne added. In addition, the draft has proposed to establish a separate board of directors to receive asset liability statements and deal with related issues. According to the Bill, it was stated that the relevant minister has the ability to make regulations regarding obtaining asset and liability statements of individuals in areas where corruption and bribery occur more, excluding executive officers of the public sector, Jayamanne said. He said, as important government departments are connected with this office through the Internet, inquiries about assets and liabilities can be made easily. It was discussed that it includes provisions to prevent bribery and corruption in the private sector, sports sector, and is not only limited to the public sector. The Committee also emphasised the need to give severe punishment to those found guilty in the investigation of bribery scams. The minister said he is expected to discuss the proposed Bill in a more democratic manner and make amendments. He also briefed the committee on “The Recovery of Possession of the Premises given on Lease (Special Provisions) Bill” to be passed in Parliament. He pointed out that the main objective of this enactment is to reduce the laws delay in any ordinary rent and ejectment action in regular procedure and to grant relief to the lessor in a very short period. This Bill introduces a swift and efficient process and an ejectment of overholding lessees who are in occupation of premises in relation to duly executed notarial lease agreements. Further, the Order published in Gazette Extraordinary No. 2301/33 dated 12 October 2022 enacted by the Minister of Justice under the Mutual Cooperation in Criminal Matters Act No. 25 of 2022 was also approved. By Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: 3,600 HIV patients in SL
author: Author not found
Content: The National STD/AIDS Control Programme said there are an estimated 3,600 Human Immunodeficiency Virus (HIV) patients in Sri Lanka. Speaking to the media at the Health Promotion Bureau (HPB), Consultant Community Physician (CCP), Dr. Janaka Weragoda said yesterday (23) that this year to date a total of 429 new HIV positive cases had been detected in the community while last year there had been 411 cases. “There has been a slight increase in numbers,” he said, adding… …that to-date only about 83 per cent of HIV cases had been detected from society.  In view of World AIDS Day, which will be marked on 1 December 2022, Dr. Weragoda said, from the cases that had been detected, there had been an increase in the number of men testing positive for HIV. When last year there had been five men testing positive for the virus, only one woman had tested positive for the virus. But by November 2022, the number had spiked to 1:7, which showed that when seven men tested positive for HIV, only one woman was HIV positive. “Testing should be increased, so as to ensure that patients are detected at an early stage. There should also be prevention and control programmes to control the disease,” he said. Consultant Venereologist, National STD/AIDS Control Programme, Dr. Nimali Jayasuriya said, UNAIDS had released a new set of targets. It aimed “for 95 per cent of people living with HIV to know their HIV situation, for 95 per cent of all people diagnosed with HIV infection to receive sustained antiretroviral therapy, and for 95 per cent of all people receiving antiretroviral therapy to have viral suppression by 2030.” She said, the virus could be controlled if patients were detected early. In Sri Lanka, 90 per cent of the time HIV is contracted due to unprotected sex. The high risk groups include men who have sex with men, transgender women, commercial sex workers, drug addicts, beach boys, and prisoners. Dr. Jayasuriya said, in addition to the early clinical method of testing, other testing methods such as the testing conducted on risk-prone persons in the field with the Rapid Test and the Self-test were also available.   By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: Counterfeit reagents for lab equipment
author: Author not found
Content: The Government Medical Officers’ Forum (GMOF) has urged the Health Ministry Secretary and the National Medicines Regulatory Authority during a discussion to launch a CID investigation into an alleged fraud which was costing Sri Lanka millions of dollars in purchasing allegedly counterfeit reagents for laboratory equipment. A concerned GMOF President, Dr. Rukshan Bellana said, yesterday (23) that his outfit had made submissions to the Health Secretary, Janaka Sri Chandragupta and the Chairman of the National Medicines Regulatory Authority (NMRA), Prof. S.D. Jayaratne calling for a probe into the Chinese-based company which he alleged was fake and had provided fraudulent details on the website with regard to its address. Dr. Bellana explaining said neither the Company nor its reagents was registered with the NMRA. However, several local agents purchased the generic reagent from it and sold it to the Health Ministry and private sector hospitals at an exorbitant price as though they were machine specific reagents. By Dilanthi Jayamanne
