title: Public Security Minister refutes allegations
author: Author not found
Content: Public Security Minister Tiran Alles refuted allegations that Police were searching houses in Colombo targeting the Tamil community. He was responding to a question raised by Samagi Jana Balawegaya (SJB) MP Mano Ganesan. Ganesan alleged that Police have commenced a house-to-house operation to register Tamil people in Colombo. “This is not war time. Why are the Police targeting Tamil people like this? I have informed all the responsible authorities about this including the Chairman of the National Police Commission. I don’t know whether he informed you about it. But what is happening is unacceptable. You have to correct this mistake,” he said. In response, the Public Security Minister said, “You are talking about Form 76. It has been there even before the war. If a person who is not a resident of Colombo but is living in Colombo, we have to obtain certain information about that person. And this has not been conducted targeting the Tamil community. The Police obtain information of such persons regardless of their ethnicity.” Ganesan: “Residents in Colombo too can flee to other districts after committing offences. It is not okay for the Police to go house-to-house collecting information. Please correct this mistake.” Alles: “I repeat, we are doing this without discriminating anyone. After you told me about this I looked into the matter. There was only one issue, and that was the form that is used to get the information is different from the previous form. We corrected it.” Ganesan: “But you have to re-check. I got information that this is being happening only in South-Colombo.” Alles: “If you insist, I will look into the matter again.” BY Methmalie Dissanayake

title: FERTILISER DISTRIBUTION TAINTED WITH CORRUPTION
author: Author not found
Content: The Welimada, Uva Paranagama Govijana Collective charged that the present programme to supply urea fertiliser to farmers free of charge is replete with fraud and corruption. The members of the Collective, speaking at a media briefing said, there is no criteria to monitor the distribution of urea fertiliser to farmers in the Welimada, Uva Paranagama area. They added that several underhand deals had been struck between officials and they said those truly deserving fertiliser have not received any stocks so far. Therefore, the members of the Collective request the authorities to intervene in the issue and implement a system where all farmers who are entitled to fertiliser stocks receive them, rather than allowing corrupt officers to make a killing off it. By Saman Nedungamuwa – Boralenda

title: LG voting system won’t be changed arbitrarily -PM
author: Author not found
Content: While noting that the Government is working to change the Local Government voting system, reduce the number of MP seats, and reduce election expenses, Prime Minister Dinesh Gunawardena said they will not do anything arbitrarily outside Parliament. The Prime Minister was responding to Opposition Leader Sajith Premadasa in Parliament yesterday (23) when he raised concerns regarding Local Government Elections. He said the recommendations of the parliamentary committee on changing the electoral system, which he chaired, made many proposals such as reducing election expenses and reducing the number of Local Government members. Gunawardena said as the Minister of Public Administration, Home Affairs, Provincial Councils and Local Government, he has the power to appoint a Delimitation Committee and that there is a difference between a committee and a commission. By Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: Fisheries Charter envisages new course for Fisheries sector – Devananda
author: Author not found
Content: Fisheries Minister Douglas Devananda said a Fisheries Charter containing proposals, recommendations, guidelines, and recommended solutions to fisher issues will be submitted. He expressed confidence that once the proposals and recommendations are implemented, the fishery industry will be steered in a new direction, benefiting both inland and sea fishermen. He also said the Fisheries Charter was presented to Prime Minister Dinesh Gunawardena recently during World Fishery Day events held in Beruwela with the participation State Minister of Fisheries,Piyal Nishantha de Silva. Devananda said the Charter pays significant attention to develop inland fishery industry. Minister Devananda said the Charter while ascertaining the rights of fishermen to do their profession consists of many proposals to be implemented towards the welfare of fishery families. Through the implementation of this Charter it is intended to uplift the fishery of this country to  international standard. Meanwhile, Fisheries State Minister said a revival in the fishery industry is being envisaged while giving new direction to the fishery sector. BY Naalir Jamaldeen

title: IMF programme hindered by corruption – TNA
author: Author not found
Content: The TNA says the economic crisis in the country is primarily due to corruption and added that an International Monetary Fund (IMF) report even mentioned that “there are corruption susceptibilities (in Sri Lanka).” TNA MP M.A. Sumanthiran said in Parliament on Tuesday that corruption is one of the challenges for the IMF in implementing their programme in this country. “The President, who is the Finance Minister, in his Budget speech said corruption will be dealt with,” but the MP said nothing has been done about it. In regard to the office of the Attorney General, the MP said the AG who appears on behalf of the Government, defends the Government even when the Right to Information Commission orders the Central Bank to divulge certain information. “Now these are public funds, these are monies of the people of this country.” The MP says there is absolutely no transparency; evidently, large-scale corruption and fraud and all that is covered up by the Government, by the Central Bank, by the EPF Department, and by the Attorney General. He pointed out that the Government pays lip service, but every action of the Government demonstrates the opposite and said Anura Kumara Dissanayake cited the case of a Minister who asked an Ambassador for a bribe, which was reported. Following that, he was suspended from Cabinet, and he got a committee of his choice appointed which exonerated him, but now he is back in Cabinet. To add insult to injury, that very Minister has been appointed as the President’s nominee on the Constitutional Council, a Constitutional Council which is supposed to appoint independent commissions – handpicked, handpicked because there is no one who is up to that mark, in Cabinet. “Now who has the brass to go and ask an Ambassador for a bribe? I suppose the other ministers are a little less corrupt. So you have to pick the most corrupt, to appoint to the Constitutional Council. You have a convicted extortionist as a Chief Government Whip. A convicted extortionist, so how do we then tell either the IMF or anyone else that we are dealing with corruption? The Government has really no intention of doing any of that sort, the President has no intention.” By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: Cop dies while trying to save dog
author: Author not found
Content: A Police Constable attached to Panamura Police Anti-Corruption Division died following an accident on Embilipitiya-Panamura road, while trying to save a dog. Police said, a team of Police Officers were returning to Panamura Police Station on motorcycles after conducting a raid. On their way, a dog had jumped in front of one of the motorcycles. The rider lost control of the motorcycle and veered off the road, colliding with a light post. The rider and the pillion rider were admitted to the Embilipitiya Hospital on 21 November. However, the rider had succumbed to his injuries on 22 November. The victim is a 36-year-old resident of Katuwana. The other officer who was injured in the incident is presently undergoing treatment at Embilipitiya Hospital. By Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: TNA campaigns for federal system
author: Author not found
Content: As the 13A has not been implemented, Northern political parties are pushing for a federal framework in the new Constitution out of “fear” that they will lose everything that the Tamils are looking forward to. People’s Liberation Organisation of Tamil Eelam (PLOTE) Leader, MP D. Sithadthan told Ceylon Today that if President Ranil Wickremesinghe wants to pursue devolution of power, his government must ratify it, which is unlikely. Instead, the President could do his best to implement the 13A as it is written into the Constitution. PLOTE is a political ally of TNA.  In addition, Leader of the Illankai Tamil Arasu Kachchi, MP Mavai Senathirajah, said they are requesting a federal system within the bounds of a unitary government. “We have tabled our proposal to former President Gotabaya Rajapaksa, the expert committees in the past,” said Senathirajah. MP Sithadthan said, the President is “active” in the Tamil issue, but never follows through on his promises. The MP added that the President recently said he would like to meet the Tamil political parties, but so far he has not given an appointment. “He said he wants to meet and I would like to know when that will happen.” “The hopes that the President would act are in limbo because the entire Southern media writes about his efforts to make amends and his tilt toward a political solution, but he never takes any action.” I think the maximum the President can do is to implement the 13A. The MP added that the TNA Leader meeting with the President recently must have reiterated the devolution of power to the North and East and a federal structure is a call for the TNA. Asked if a referendum should be called, he said it can be through a referendum and that’s possible. By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: 4 suspects arrested in attempted murder of Manna Kanna
author: Author not found
Content: Four suspects were arrested in the attempted murder of Marimuththu Ganesh alias ‘Manna Kanna’ in Navagampura, Grandpass, Police said. The arrests were made by the CID on 22 November for aiding and abetting the shooting. The suspects are identified as 20, 23, 28 and 42-year-old residents of Colombo 13 and 14. Investigations revealed that the shooting was carried out by an organised underworld gang. A leading underworld figure ‘Manna Kanna’ was injured following a shooting incident in Grandpass on 19 November. It was revealed that he had been at a relative’s house in Grandpass at the time of the shooting and was admitted to the Colombo National Hospital following the shooting. Manna Kanna is alleged to be the main suspect in  Kanjipani Imran’s father’s attack. BY Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: Environment Minister meets WGEO reps
author: Author not found
Content: Environment Minister Naseer Ahamed met senior officers of the UAE-based World Green Economy Organization (WGEO) on the sidelines of the COP27 Climate Summit being held from 7-18 November in Sharm El-Sheikh, Egypt. The bilateral discussion was held with the Director General of WGEO, Abdul Rahim Sultan at the UAE pavilion of the COP27 conference venue. In September this year, the Sri Lankan Government pledged its commitment to the Global Alliance on Green Economy at the Ministerial Roundtable held at the 8th World Green Economy Summit (WGES) held on 28 and 29 September in Dubai, UAE at which Sri Lanka was represented by Ahamed. Pursuant to the World Green Economy Summit 2022, theSri Lankan Government pledged its commitment to the Global Alliance on Green Economy and to further support Sri Lanka’s journey towards Climate Change actions, Ahamed presented to the DG of WGEO, four major areas for possible cooperation and support by the WGEO.

title: Brandix Sustainability Summit concludes for second consecutive year
author: Author not found
Content: The Sustainability Summit for 2022 hosted by Brandix Apparel Ltd. encompassing varied aspects of Environmental, Social and Governance (ESG) was held on Tuesday (22) November. The Summit covered the pressing issues that faced the world today, with a specific focus on the urgent need to give equal importance to all aspects of the triple bottom line – People, Planet and Profit. Hosted as a hybrid event, with virtual participants and a physical event at Brandix Essentials Ltd, Ratmalana, the Summit brought together an audience of business leaders, government representatives, NGOs, and others interested in this timely subject, a spokesman said. The sustainability journey of Brandix, commencing in 2007, has seen significant milestones been reached, and include the plant in Batticaloa, Sri Lanka being recognised as the world's first Net Zero Carbon Apparel Manufacturing facility in 2019. This was not the first time the company broke new ground – In 2008, it’s factory in Seeduwa, Sri Lanka became the World’s first LEED Platinum certified facility under the World Green Building Council, and today the Group has multiple other LEED certified facilities across Sri Lanka and India. A significant depiction of this commitment is the company’s pledge to be Net Zero Carbon across all manufacturing facilities in Sri Lanka by 2023, and all facilities in India by 2025, he added. This year’s panel of international speakers included Claire Kells, Senior Manager Corporate Engagement – UN Global Compact, who spoke of her organisation’s work in the areas of promoting best practices and offering methodologies to effectively track results, through the UN Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) and UN Global Compact’s ESG principles. Ruby Ojha, Senior Environmental and Social Development Specialist – International Finance Corporation (IFC), a member of the World Bank Group, shared insights on ESG for Sustainability, an overview of IFC Performance Standards and IFC’s initiatives relevant to Ready Made Garment Sector. The final of the international speakers, Tejas Sampat, Senior Director, Corporate Responsibility (SA) and Global Sustainability (Offshore) – PVH Corp. shared his views on how the fashion industry is changing and the opportunity to drive fashion forward for the good of all. Each speaker reinforced the summit’s objective of the need to act now, and to couple global know-how with local solutions, he further said. From hosts Brandix, two panellists, namely Akila Fernando – Deputy General Manager, Group Engineering and Vinura Jayewardene, Group Sustainability Engineer, took the audience through the company’s own sustainability journey spanning a decade and a half, and anchored to the pillars of Air, Water and Earth. “Brandix also works with the objective to make each location where it establishes its facilities, a better place than it was when the company arrived, through enhancing the living conditions and wellbeing of the community,” said Jayewardene. He elaborated that in Sri Lanka, its flagship initiative of Water Projects has provided access to clean water for drinking and household needs to over a quarter of a million people, whilst in India free eye camps screen patients and extend medical support and spectacles, with over 35,000 beneficiaries to date.

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Police investigate paddy theft
author: Author not found
Content: Thambuttegama Police launched an investigation to identify suspects behind the theft of 49 bushels of paddy valued at Rs 180,000 from a store in Thammannagama, Thambuttegama. According to sources, the store is located next to the BOC branch in Thambuttegama. The Police added that they had questioned the store owner and investigations are underway to arrest the suspects.    By C.M. Ariyapala – Hurigaswewa

title: Tea production falls to 27-month low
author: Author not found
Content: Sri Lanka’s total tea production, scarred by the Government’s seven-month ban on chemical fertiliser imports last year, hit a 27-year low at 211.39 million kilos in the first 10 months of this year, Forbes & Walker Tea Brokers in a report released yesterday (23) said. A lower figure than this was last reported in 1995 with a figure of 201.78 million kgs in the first 10 months of that year, it said. Year 1995 was the start of Eelam War IV after the breakdown of peace talks between the Chandrika Bandaranaike Kumaratunga Government and the LTTE in April 1994, underlined by the LTTE sinking two Sri Lankan naval craft at Trincomalee that month and, going forward, resulting in the crippling of the economy with the restarting of the Eelam war made worse by the reintroduction of curfews and checkpoints, hitting tea production. Meanwhile, tea production in the first 10 months of the year fell by 18.35 per cent (47.51 million kgs year-on-year (YoY) to 211.39 million kgs, compared to 258.90 million kgs recorded in the first 10 months of last year, said Forbes. It also said when compared with the Covid-19 scarred 2020, tea production, in the first 10 months of this year, vis-à-vis the first 10 months of 2020, decreased by 6.17 per cent (13.89 million kgs) to 211.39 million kgs. Tea production in the first 10 months of 2020 totalled 225.28 million kgs, Forbes added. Tea was Sri Lanka’s third largest foreign exchange earner for two consecutive years in 2020 and 2021, Central Bank of Sri Lanka said. In related developments, Eelam War I took place from 23 July 1983 to 29 July 1987, Eelam War II, the LTTE fighting the IPKF took place from October 1987 to March 1990, Eelam War III from June 1990 to August 1994 and Eelam War IV from April 1995 to December 2001, respectively.

title: Thushari Fernando acquited
author: Author not found
Content: Colombo High Court, Judge Amal Ranaraja yesterday ordered accused Thushari Fernando who had been indicted on charges of fleecing an individual to the tune of Rs 5.5 million to be acquitted from charges filed against her and be released from the trial. The HC Judge announcing his verdict in the case stating that he was ordering the acquittal of the accused as the prosecution had failed to prove the charges beyond  reasonable doubt. Counsel Asitha Vipulanayake looked into the interests of the accused. The Attorney General had indicted the accused before the High Court seven years ago and on charges of cheating an individual Mayura Buddhika a resident of Colombo of the aforesaid sum having urged him to invest the sum for a business venture between 20 March 2009 to 18 February 2010 and on charges of flouting Provisions contained in Section 403 of the Penal Code. By Hansi Nanayakkara

title: Forest burning getting out of hand
author: Author not found
Content: Several residents in the Central Province said, due to the ongoing dry weather conditions, several persons had begun to set fire to forests, and they warned that if the situation is not addressed urgently, the environment could suffer serious damage. They said, a group of unknown persons had set fire to a part of the Maeliya Reserve in Bogawantalawa on 22 November night. Further, another group of unknown persons had set fire to the Singimale Reserve in Hatton. They said, some tend to indulge in this activity for pure entertainment while others do so to hunt animals. Such activity could not only cause untold damage to the environment, but also damage water resources, which will impact the public seriously, they added. By C.D.H. Hewage – Watawala

title: Mother dead, daughter injured in scuffle in Walapane
author: Author not found
Content: Walapane Police yesterday (23) arrested a 27-year-old man for attacking two women with a sharp weapon killing one and causing minor injury to another. Walapane Police said, that the individuals involved were members of the same family and were the mother and daughter, while the suspect is said to be the son-in-law. The mother had succumbed to injuries on the spot while the daughter had escaped with minor injuries. Police said, the incident had occurred in the Kalangawatte area in the Walapane, Mukunugapitiya area in the Nuwara Eliya District on 22 November evening at a place where dry rations were being distributed to those living below the poverty line. Police added that the victims were also among those who had come to get dry rations, when an argument sparked off between them which turned into a scuffle. The son-in-law is then reported to have attacked with them a sharp weapon which was in his possession. The suspect is said to be a 27-year-old individual. The deceased has been identified as 59-year-old W. Geetha Ranasinghe and a resident of Mukunugapitiya area. The daughter is being treated at the Rikillagaskada Base Hospital,. The body was handed over to relatives after the post-mortem. Walapane police are conducting further inquiries while the suspect is under detention. By Naalir Jamaldeen

title: Embassy staffer linked to human trafficking interdicted
author: Author not found
Content: The officer at the Sri Lankan Embassy in Oman with allegations of being involved in the human trafficking racket has been interdicted and will be arrested on arrival for further investigations, Labour and Foreign Employment Minister Manusha Nanayakkara said. While noting that even though it is an allegation against that officer, legal proceedings are underway to bring down the suspect to Sri Lanka, and Nanayakkara said, whoever is found guilty will be severely dealt with regardless of position. He was responding to SJB MP Hector Appuhamy in Parliament yesterday (22) when the latter asked what action has been taken against the individual who was allegedly involved in the human trafficking racket in Oman. Commenting on the matter, SJB MP Chaminda Wijesiri said, he is pleased about the steps taken so far in regard to the racket, however, they were taken because of media exposure. Until then, the ministry and the responsible officials did not pay attention, he said. In response to these remarks, Minister Nanayakkara said, investigations were already underway in connection with human trafficking incidents. He said, the media exposed the human trafficking incident only a week ago and the warrant was issued a month ago to arrest the woman who was taken into custody on 21 November. Nanayakkara expressed his gratitude towards the media for their coverage. By Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: Local, foreign forces precluding development – MR
author: Author not found
Content: Former Prime Minister Mahinda Rajapaksa said yesterday (22) that several local and foreign ‘forces’ are working to prevent the development of Sri Lanka and interest of ‘foreign powers’ in Sri Lanka’s assets is a reason for the country’s economy to collapse. Owing to these forces, the Sri Lankan economy has to suffer on multiple occasions, Rajapaksa said. The former Prime Minister was participating in the second reading debate of Budget 2023. While noting that criticising the Budget and inciting the people against the Budget will not benefit the country, Rajapaksa said, everyone should support the Budget in accordance with adequate amendments. The President as the Finance Minister indicated a road to a new economy and to create such an economy there are many long-term and short-term procedures needed, Rajapaksa said. He said, everyone must understand the reality of the global economic and political process while doing so. He said, a brighter future can be created only with a strategic plan.  Therefore, it is important to support the Budget with amendments, he said. Rajapaksa further said, the Yahapalana Government accumulated a mountain of debt. “We did not abandon the citizens and run away. We took over the country amid a mountain of debt and we have given the necessary support to move forward as a country amid difficulties. It will not change in the future.” By Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: Teachers to face disciplinary action?
author: Author not found
Content: The Government is considering amending the circular issued to public sector employees reporting to work for Government offices dressed appropriately to exclude the teaching profession. State Minister of Mass Media Shantha Bandara said disciplinary action will be taken against teachers who violate the dress code. He stressed that Minister of Education Dr. Susil Premajayantha informed that no changes will be made to teachers’ school attire. Speaking to the media yesterday (22), he also said, the school system is the country’s future, and thus it is very clear that a female teacher in a school wearing an Osari or a Saari is tradition, and culture has long been a part of the society’s existence. “Some representatives from non-governmental organisations (NGOs) wanted to change it. The Government will not allow the school system to be destroyed. As a result, we will discuss this further in the future. I believe the Education Minister will take appropriate disciplinary action,” he said. Meanwhile, Secretary of the Ministry of Public Administration said the circular on the State sector workers’ dress codes is not applicable to teachers.  By Thameenah Razeek

title: Disciplinary action can’t be taken – CTU
author: Author not found
Content: The Ceylon Teachers’ Union (CTU) said it is illegal to take disciplinary action against female teachers who reported to work in comfortable and modest attire, instead of traditional Sari and Osari. Responding to a comment of Justice Minister Wijeyadasa Rajapakshe made during the Cabinet media briefing yesterday (22), that the circular issued allowing government officers to report to work in a comfortable and decent dress is not applicable to school teachers, CTU General Secretary, Joseph Stalin said, if the education system comes under the Public Administration and Home Affairs Ministry that they are legally entitled to Circular 5/2022 related to public administration and no one can deny their rights. He further said, the Government is trying to hang onto teachers’ attire and is turning a blind eye to the real issues in the education sector. Stalin added that there are pressing issues such as student malnutrition, children dropping out of school because they can’t afford stationery, and the ministers, MPs, and stakeholders are busy judging female teachers’ attire.  By Nabiya Vaffoor

title: Two remanded over trafficking women to Oman
author: Author not found
Content: Colombo Chief Magistrate Nandana Amerasinghe yesterday (22) remanded, till 1 December, two suspects who were charged with human trafficking to Oman. The suspects were arrested on charges of sending a group of Sri Lankan women to Oman under the pretence of providing them with employment and then forcing them to work as sex workers. The two suspects were identified as Ajith Samarakoon and Yogendra alias ‘Yoga’. The CID informed the Court that their probe had revealed that the two suspects had acted as intermediaries or brokers who had provided tourist visas to two women to leave for Oman. By Hansi Nanayakkara

title: Public to be allowed to visit parks free
author: Author not found
Content: The public will get the opportunity to visit national parks, entertainment parks, and botanical gardens free of charge in line with the 75th Independence Day that falls on 4 February 2023. title: Ven. Ethalawetunawewe Gnanathilaka Thera appointed Chief Incumbent
author: Author not found
Content: Ven. Ethalawetunawewe Gnanathilaka Thera has been appointed as the Chief Incumbent of the Ruwanweli Maha Seya Temple in Anuradhapura. The Venerable Thera who was born on 18 April 1969 in Pirappanmaduwa, Vavuniya and was ordained on 13 May 1981 in the terrace of the Ruwanweli Maha Seya. After being ordained, the Venerable Thera received his primary education at Anuradhapura Maha Vihara Pirivena and Shastrodaya Maha Pirivina in Sandalankawa. He received his higher education at the Paali and Buddhist University of Sri Lanka and obtained postgraduate degrees at the University of Kelaniya. He assumed the post of Chief Incumbent of the Mirisawetiya Rajamaha Viharaya in Anuradhapura in 1993. In 2020, the Venerable Thera was appointed as the Chancellor of University of Rajarata.

title: Cabinet Green-lights Campaign Finance Bill
author: Author not found
Content: Cabinet approved to publish the Campaign Finance Bill in Government Gazette and subsequently submit for Parliament’s approval. The Attorney General has approved the Bill prepared by the Legal Draftsman to provide for election expenditure control. Speaking at the Cabinet media briefing yesterday (22), Minister of Justice, Prison Affairs, and Constitutional Reforms Dr. Wijeyadasa Rajapakshe said the Election Commission determines the amount of money that can be spent by a candidate in an election by this act, and if the amount of money is spent in excess, the NEC can remove the candidate from his position as an MP. “This Act applies to all four acts, namely the Presidential Election, the Parliamentary Election, the Provincial Council Election, and the Local Government Elections. It is also prohibited to use State property, vehicles, or employees for political purposes. It could be various gangs, non-governmental organisations (NGOs), or foreign aid; receiving funds from them is strictly prohibited,” he said. Dr. Rajapakshe said regardless of victory or defeat, the candidate must provide an affidavit of account summaries of election funds three weeks after the election. He stressed that if false facts were mentioned in the affidavit, he has the authority to consider it an offence and impose a relevant punishment. “In addition, under this Act, the Magistrate’s Court has the authority to prosecute and punish for giving false affidavits under the Penal Code,” he added. By Thameenah Razeek

title: Wimal accuses Govt MP of taking bribe
author: Author not found
Content: National Freedom Front (NFF) Leader, Independent MP Wimal Weerawansa alleged in Parliament that a Government MP, who was a State Minister, took a bribe of 2,000 cement bags from a cement factory in Puttalam. Speaking in Parliament yesterday (22), Weerawansa said the same politician was seen welcoming ‘Kaputa’ recently. “This is the situation in the country today. Businesspersons are forced to give bribes to provincial politicians to survive. This particular MP had taken this bribe of 2,000 cement bags because the factory management sacked a bunch of his henchmen due to a drug problem. A complaint in this connection went to the President. But nothing has been done. How can a country be developed like this?” he queried. “That MP was seen welcoming ‘Kaputa’ recently. Actually, these types of MPs are the ones compatible with people like ‘Kaputa,’” Weerawansa added. The country cannot be rescued from the present crisis with mere talk. There are some serious questions that need to be addressed. Why isn’t the Foreign Exchange Act amended yet? These are the real questions, he said. “If the Government cannot focus on these matters, how can we overcome the present crisis? Instead of focusing on real problems, the Government imposes tax after tax on basic commodities of the people. Without doing anything positive, you (the Government) is only eying IMF relief,” he stressed. By Methmalie Dissanayake

title: Second reading passed with 37 votes
author: Author not found
Content: The second reading of Budget 2023 was passed in Parliament yesterday (22) with a majority of 37 votes. Accordingly, 121 MPs voted in favour of the Budget while 84 MPs voted against. MP C.V. Wigneswaran abstained from voting. Eighteen MPs were absent. The debate on the second reading of the Appropriation Bill began on 15 November, and the voting for the second reading took place on Tuesday (22) evening. The Committee Stage Debate of Budget 2023 will be held from today (23) to 8 December, and voting will be held on 8 December at 7:00 p.m. The Sri Lanka Freedom Party (SLFP), Samagi Jana Balawegaya (SJB), Jathika Jana Balawegaya (JJB), and Independent MPs of the ‘Uththara Lanka Sabhagaya’ voted against the Budget. The Tamil National Alliance (TNA) was absent during the vote. By Methmalie Dissanayake

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Red Cross launches ‘Elixir’ Platform
author: Author not found
Content: The Sri Lanka Red Cross Society launched Sri Lanka’s first medical-supply-to-donation matching platform on 19 October, called the ‘Elixir’ Platform. The initiative is a volunteer-run, public-private partnership under the aegis of the Sri Lanka Red Cross Society, and allows hospitals and treatment centres from across Sri Lanka to register their requirements for lifesaving medicines and medical supplies that may be in short supply, due to the country’s ongoing economic and foreign exchange crises. ‘Elixir’ also provides a single streamlined interface for donors who would like to support Sri Lanka at this time. By having all requirements and donations coming in via a unified and seamless platform, ‘Elixir’ can then match requirements and donations for efficient use of funds and time, while also reducing the total turnaround time for assistance and increasing transparency. Additionally, by having a large number of institutions registering their requirements, this allows the Sri Lanka Red Cross Society and its network of global volunteers to consider bulk order placement where possible to obtain the best possible prices, delivering maximum cost efficiency to all stakeholders. Designed and operated by the Sri Lanka Red Cross Society, together with its global network of volunteers and professionals, and in partnership with the Sri Lanka Medical Supplies Division of the Ministry of Health, the Elixir Platform is a huge collaborative undertaking to help Sri Lanka overcome the shortage of lifesaving medicines due to the present economic crisis. Discussing the initiative, Dr. Mahesh Gunasekara, Director General of the Sri Lanka Red Cross Society said, “First, we must express our sincere gratitude to all the donors, including individuals, charities, corporations and governments, who have come to Sri Lanka’s aid at this time of need. With the large amount of donations, we found that it was becoming challenging to track and fulfil medical needs across the system and prioritise based on urgency. Other challenges including oversupply due to duplicative efforts, high costs due to not utilising economies of scale, internal competition for donations and other issues have arisen, along with a lack of transparency. Thus, ‘Elixir’ is our answer to these problems, and will facilitate transparency and accountability throughout the entire supply chain for the benefit of all stakeholders. In fact, the Elixir platform will be audited on a monthly basis by KPMG. On behalf of the Sri Lanka Red Cross Society, I take this opportunity to thank all volunteers and partners in this endeavour. Elixir is truly a landmark achievement and we look forward to supporting Sri Lanka as it overcomes its present challenges.”

title: Vijayabahu commissioned
author: Author not found
Content: President Ranil Wickremesinghe, Secretary to the Ministry of Defence Kamal Gunaratne, Commander of the Sri Lanka Navy Vice Admiral Nishantha Ulugetenne and the U.S. Ambassador to Sri Lanka Julie Chung attended the commissioning of the Navy Ship Vijayabahu, formerly the U.S. Coast Guard Cutter Douglas Munro, in Colombo Harbour.  The United States had donated the ship to Sri Lanka on October 26, 2021 as part of its continuing commitment to strengthen Sri Lanka’s ability to protect its maritime sovereignty and security.

title: Title not found
author: Author not found
Content: Date:  Consultant Paediatrician, Dr. Deepal Perera warned of an increase in upper respiratory tract infection cases among children arriving at the Lady Ridgeway Hospital for Children (LRH). Dr. Perera, when contacted yesterday (22), said although the number of patients with Covid-19 has reduced, an increase is observed in the number of patients with upper respiratory tract infections. The main cause of the infection could be a virus, but all young patients cannot be given antibiotics, although some parents ask for antibiotics for their children. Identifying the symptoms, he said young patients who sought treatment had fever, runny nose or a blocked nose, cough, poor appetite, vomiting, and at times diarrhoea. In most cases, treatment was given for symptoms that children developed, he said. Dr. Perera explained that Paracetamol was prescribed for fever while parents should only use lukewarm water to sponge the sick child and refrain from using iced or tap water to do so.     The Consultant Paediatrician urged parents to refrain from sending their children to school or to day care centres should they develop upper respiratory tract infections. Further, he said it was best that children and even adults with such infections wear a mask as well as maintain hand hygiene by washing hands with soap. Also, when sneezing, it is always best to use the elbow to cover one’s nose and mouth. Those who contract lower respiratory tract infections may suffer from wheezing and even pneumonia if timely treatment is not sought. They may also develop complications with secondary bacterial infections which could worsen the condition of children below two years, pregnant women, the elderly, and those who are immunocompromised. By Dilanthi Jayamanne Popular

title: Police probe ‘Daddy’ musical instruments heist
author: Author not found
Content: Cinnamon Gardens Police on 21 November informed Colombo Chief Magistrate Nandana Amarasinghe that they had commenced a probe into the incident where a bag containing musical instruments of the musical group ‘Daddy’ had been robbed at the Viharamahadevi Open Air Theatre recently. The Police told the Chief Magistrate that they had launched a probe into a complaint lodged by Vihanga Anthony, a resident of Ragama, who has been entrusted with installing and removing musical instruments of the band. According to the complaint lodged at the Cinnamon Gardens Police, a musical show had been held at the said venue on 10 November, where eight bands featured including ‘Daddy’ and that the bag containing the musical instruments had been allegedly stolen between 10:30 to 11:30 p.m. By Hansi Nanayakkara

title: President to deliver Commemorative Freedom Speech
author: Author not found
Content: Marking the 86th birth anniversary of the Late Lalith Athulathmudali on 26 November, President Ranil Wickremesinghe will deliver the Lalith Athulathmudali Commemorative Freedom Speech today (23). The event organised by the Lalith Athulathmudali Foundation, in collaboration with the Institute for Democracy and Leadership and the Friedrich Naumann Foundation for Freedom – Sri Lanka, will be held today (23) at 5:00 p.m. at BMICH (Lotus Hall). The theme of the event is ‘Sri Lanka – the way forward.’ The Late Lalith Athulathmudali succumbed to the bullet of an unknown gunman at a political rally almost 30 years ago, but his legacy continues. A brilliant academic and a pragmatic politician, he held several portfolios in the governments of the Late Presidents, J.R. Jayewardene and Ranasinghe Premadasa.

title: Subsidies given to needy won’t be slashed – Semasinghe
author: Author not found
Content: Subsidies given to low-income earners and other selected groups will not be slashed, State Minister of Finance Shehan Semasinghe said. While rejecting all claims that the welfare payments have been reduced through Budget 2023, Semasinghe said the Government has decided to provide an additional payment to selected groups in the first four months of 2023. Speaking in Parliament yesterday (22), Semasinghe said they have been given an additional allowance for seven months, ending in December. However, the payment will continue for the months of January through April next year, he emphasised. He said all payments will be made by the Government and no allowance will be funded by the international community. Funding will not be received from external sources until the debt restructuring discussions are complete, he said. Semasinghe added that a census is underway to determine the number of persons eligible for grants from the Government. By Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: Govt further burdening taxpayer
author: Author not found
Content: Although the President has promised to grant subsidies to low-income earners through Budget 2023, the truth is the benefits of subsidies that are given at present have been reduced with the economic crisis, MP Shanakiyan Rasamanickam stressed. He queried as to how they can trust the policies in Budget 2023, if the Government is lying to the public.  Speaking during the Second Reading debate of Budget 2023 in Parliament yesterday (22), Rasamanickam said the amount reserved for subsidies through the Budget has only increased from Rs 1.021 trillion to Rs 1.114 trillion. He said the amount reserved for each and every sector has increased stating that inflation is high, however, the reserve for subsidies has not increased significantly. He said the Government has increased their income by putting the tax burden on citizens’ shoulders. By Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: Sky-high stationery prices keep students away
author: Author not found
Content: Teachers in Matara District said, due to the exorbitant prices of stationery and school equipment, scores of students are finding it difficult to attend school. They said even the prices of exercise books had gone through the ceiling, prompting parents to bar children from attending school. Owing to this situation, even teachers are finding it difficult to carry out their duties, as children are in dire straits.  They, therefore urge the Education Ministry to intervene and resolve this issue expeditiously. By Udaya Ranaweera – Matara

title: TUs acting like mafia – Wijeyadasa
author: Author not found
Content: Many concerns about privatising the Ceylon Electricity Board (CEB) and Ceylon Petroleum Corporation (CPC) have arisen because trade unions at these institutions are acting as mafia groups, working to weaken the institutions, Minister of Justice, Prisons Affairs and Constitutional Reforms Dr. Wijeyadasa Rajapakshe said yesterday (22). He said many trade union members, rather than performing their duties, are engaged in trade union activities that jeopardise the operations of the institutions. He said during the weekly Cabinet media briefing, that many trade unions in Sri Lanka are not operating to ensure the rights of employees. “Many trade unions work to advance political agendas to gain political power as desperate groups. There are many trade unions like this. However, the Government will not be shaken. There are trade unions that support the Government’s good decisions and some that criticise the Government’s bad decisions. But these types of trade unions are very rare in the country,” he explained. By Thameenah Razeek

title: Cabinet Decisions
author: Author not found
Content: Declaration of ‘National Biosphere Protection Day’ Cabinet approved the proposal submitted by the Minister of Education to declare 3 November of every year to be the ‘National Biosphere Protection Day.’ UNESCO has declared 3 November of each year as the ‘National Biosphere Protection Day.’ UNESCO emphasises that steps should be taken to draw the attention of the people by the member states of the organisation to encourage preserving the biosphere reserves. Exchange of offenders between SL and Mauritius Cabinet approved the resolution submitted by the Minister of Justice, Prisons Affairs and Constitutional Reforms to enter into the agreement between Sri Lanka and the Republic of Mauritius to exchange offenders between the two countries. In terms of the provisions of the Transfer of Offenders Act No. 5 of 1995, there is the opportunity for any foreigner proven guilty by a court of law in Sri Lanka and is prisoned to be under the imprisonment for him/her by being in his/her country where he/she is a citizen. Furthermore, the Act contains provisions for sending any Sri Lankan who has been under imprisonment in another country to Sri Lanka and be under the same imprisonment within Sri Lanka until the penalty is fully covered. In order to act in such a way, there should be an agreement entered into between Sri Lanka and the other country. Committee on Petroleum Products Section 5 (1) of the Petroleum Products (Special Provisions) Act No. 33 of 2002 comprises provisions that licences can be issued by the subject minister for import, export, sale, supply and distribution of petroleum to any individual or a company on the recommendations of the ‘Energy Supply Committee’ appointed as per the provisions of Section 2 of Energy Supply (Temporary Provisions) Act No. 2 of 2002. However, due to imposition of the Energy Supply (Temporary Provisions) Act No. 2 of 2002 for two years, the Energy Supply Committee appointed under the provisions of that Act has been abolished. In terms of the Petroleum Products (Special Provisions) (Amendment) Act No. 27 of 2022, provisions have been furnished to appoint a “Committee Appointed by the Cabinet of Ministers” instead of the “Energy Supply Committee.” Therefore, Cabinet approved the proposal furnished by the Minister of Electricity and Power to appoint the said Committee. Revision of National Archives Law No. 48 of 1973 According to Cabinet decision on 5 December 2012, the Legal Draftsman has been directed to prepare the Bill to amend the National Archives Law No. 48 of 1973. The Legal Draftsman has informed that the policy approval of the present Cabinet should be obtained for the Bill prepared accordingly. In addition to paper documents, audio-visual documents, film documents, and digital documents are widely available for preservation. Therefore, the need to further amend the Act to meet international standards and national needs has been identified. Cabinet approved the proposal presented by the Minister of Buddhasasana, Religious and Cultural Affairs to appoint a committee consisting of experts in document management, document preservation and digital document management to identify appropriate amendments and to take necessary steps to further amend the Bill prepared by the Legal Draftsman by including appropriate provisions. Import and Export Regulations Cabinet approved the proposal presented by the President in his capacity as the Minister of Finance, Economic Stabilization and National Policies to submit the Import Control Regulation for Payment Terms No. 19 of 2022 and Import and Export (Control) Regulations No. 20 of 2022 issued under the Import and Export (Control) Act No. 1 of 1969 to Parliament for approval. Proposed Banking (Special Provisions) Act The Central Bank of Sri Lanka (CBSL) has identified that strengthening the Bank Resolution Framework, under the Crisis Management Framework of Financial Institutions Regulated by the CBSL, as an urgent and priority task. The International Monetary Fund (IMF) and the World Bank have also pointed out the importance of strengthening the resolution framework to strengthen financial sector safety nets. It is difficult to enact a new complete banking law in a short period. Therefore, the proposed Banking (Special Provisions) Act will be drawn up as a supplement to the Banking Act No. 30 of 1988, introducing provisions for resolution of licensed banks, deposit insurance and winding up/liquidation of licensed banks. The CBSL has prepared an initial Bill and Cabinet approved the proposal presented by the President in his capacity as the Minister of Finance, Economic Stabilization and National Policies to advise the Legal Draftsman to prepare a Bill based on the initial Bill above.

title: Cabinet approves Task Force on Prevention of Narcotic Use
author: Author not found
Content: Cabinet has approved the formation of a Presidential Task Force for the Prevention of Narcotic and Dangerous Drug Use. Minister of Justice, Prisons Affairs, and Constitutional Reforms Dr. Wijeyadasa Rajapakshe said more than 80 per cent among the 26,000 inmates are in prisons owing to drug related offences. With this situation, he said, a Presidential Task Force will be formed, bringing together all security institutions under the chairmanship of the Secretary to the President. He said qualified members of the Security Forces will be joining the force in the future. The Cabinet Paper was prepared jointly by the President as Minister of Defence, Minister of Justice, Prisons Affairs, and Constitutional Reforms, and Minister of Public Security. It was submitted to Cabinet on 21 November. The Presidential Task Force will be set up to identify, plan, and implement appropriate practical measures to prevent the use of dangerous and narcotic drugs. Dr. Rajapakshe told the media yesterday (22) that eradicating the drug menace is more difficult than winning a war. ‘Ice’ (crystal methamphetamine) was not included in the Poisons, Opium, and Dangerous Drugs Ordinance, he said. However, he said large-scale raids are now taking place in order to arrest the perpetrators and eradicate the use of drugs, which is destroying society. Meanwhile, he also said the next major issue they had to deal with was that illicit drugs seized by the Police or other Security Forces were disappearing from record rooms when the samples were stored as Court productions. He said most of the time, these drugs are substituted with flour or Panadol powder. According to Dr. Rajapakshe, 10 to 15 g of drugs should be kept in the record room in the future. By Thameenah Razeek

title: N’ Eliya SLTB bus crews in lightning strike
author: Author not found
Content: Employees attached to the Nuwara Eliya SLTB Depot went on strike from 21 November afternoon, causing untold hardship to scores of commuters including schoolchildren. According to sources, the Nuwara Eliya SLTB Depot employees had launched a lightning strike protesting the decision by timekeepers and private bus crews at the Nuwara Eliya bus stand to object to parking of long-distance SLTB busses. Due to this decision, long-distance SLTB busses plying to areas such as Kataragama, Horana, Gampola, Bandarawela, Kalutara, and Kandy were not allowed to park. Furthermore, even SLTB busses plying to areas such as Welimada, Colombo, and Badulla had not been allowed to park at the Nuwara Eliya bus stand. In support of the strike launched by the SLTB employees, SLTB bus crews had also halted plying their busses to Nuwara Eliya from areas such as Hatton, Kotmale, Keppetipola, Bandarawela, and Badulla, worsening the situation. By Neeta Pathma Kumari – Norwood

title: Rambukwella, two others indicted
author: Author not found
Content: The Commission to Investigate Allegations of Bribery or Corruption (CIABOC) yesterday (22) handed over indictments to Health Minister Keheliya Rambukwella, former Chairman of Sri Lanka Rupavahini Corporation (SLRC) Wimal Rubasinghe and its former Director General Chandrapala Liyanage before Colombo High Court Judge Navaratne Marasinghe. The trio have been accused before the Court of causing a loss to the State over the purchase of GI pipes for political activity while using SLRC funds when Rambukwella had been functioning as the then Minister of Mass Media. Following the handing over of the indictments, Judge Marasinghe enlarged the three accused on cash bail in RS 20,000 each and two sureties of Rs 500,000 each. The High Court also impounded the passports of the trio and instructed them to submit their passports to Court. However, the Judge stated that as accused Rambukwella continues to be a Cabinet Minister and if he has to leave for overseas for official duty, he could make a request to that effect and noted that such a request will be considered if it is made. Later, the Court fixed the Pre-Trial Conference of the case for 1 February next year. The Bribery Commission has indicted Rambukwellla, Rubasinghe and Liyanage before the High Court for causing a loss of revenue to the Government amounting of Rs990,000 over the unlawful purchase of 600 GI pipes while Rambukwella had been serving as the former Minister of Mass Media from 2 to 10 December eight years ago and for flouting Provisions contained in Section 70 of the Bribery Act. By Hansi Nanayakkara

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Pension scheme for fishermen on the cards
author: Author not found
Content: The Ministry of Fisheries is planning to introduce a pension scheme for fishermen jointly with the Department of Agriculture and to introduce the ‘Deewara Kekulu’ savings account of Bank of Ceylon (BOC) exclusively for children of fishermen, State Minister of Fisheries, Piyal Nishantha de Silva said. Steps also have been taken to hold an interactive aesthetic programme titled, ‘Diriya Deewara Amma’ to help parents, in accordance with a new concept formulated to look into the well-being of fishery families. Coinciding with World Fisheries Day, a number of programmes have been organised, the State Minister said. “Going beyond the usual greetings on World Fisheries Day, I would like to happily inform you that this year we have initiated many activities that will truly bring happiness to the lives of fishermen,” State Minister de Silva added. “World Fisheries Day 2022, which falls on 21 November, must be used to address problems of fishermen engaging in salt water and fresh water fishery industry,” he said. He said, World Fisheries Day is important to Sri Lanka for many reasons. The sea is an invaluable resource for people of an island nation. There are thousands of fresh water bodies islandwide. “Fisheries Day is marked in Sri Lanka under the theme ‘The Rough Tide (Dhala Rala Saviya) 2022’ under the guidance of Fisheries Minister Douglas Devananda and based on my concept, taking the aforesaid features into consideration.” He said, instead of limiting this day to mere celebrations, we must try to resolve issues faced by fishermen. “We have set up a fishery mobile service to visit villages and beaches islandwide to resolve problems of fishermen,” State Minister Silva said. Steps have been taken to introduce a new insurance cover for fishermen in partnership with the Sri Lanka Insurance Corporation. By Naalir Jamaldeen

title: Cabinet approves National Policy on Environmentally-Sensitive Areas
author: Author not found
Content: Cabinet approval was granted to implement the National Policy on Environmentally-Sensitive Areas of Sri Lanka. This is in order to provide the necessary guidance required for the conservation of the environmentally-sensitive areas, as well as sustainable utilisation by ensuring management access at all levels along with obtaining the participation of all sectors such as the community, private sector, State sector and experts for planning land utilisation and management in those areas identifying the environmentally-sensitive areas islandwide. The Cabinet Paper was submitted by the Minister of Environment. Numerous issues have emerged such as degradation of ecosystems, soil erosion, drying of hydro-catchment areas/ water sources as well as human-wildlife conflicts due to various human activities such as informal land use, agricultural habits as well as the irregular disposal of waste and non-sustainable utilisation of national resources. As a result of this, the foundation of the biodiversity and ecosystems has been threatened. This may lead to a vicious circle of ecosystems degradation in the long run. Therefore, the purpose and the expectation of the establishment of National Policy on Environmentally-Sensitive Areas is to ensure a healthy, secure and conserved environment and an economy through establishment of environmentally-sensitive areas aimed at an environment where socio-economic well-being and liveability of everyone is ensured. (TR)

title: C’wealth Board to help set up Int’l CCS Uni
author: Author not found
Content: The Commonwealth Board has promised to extend its support to establish the International University of Climate Change Studies (CCS) in Sri Lanka, Senior Advisor to President and Deputy Leader of the UNP Ruwan Wijewardene said. Wijewardene said, the officials of Commonwealth Board gave this pledge during a discussion held following the COP27 held in Egypt. Apart from to the Commonwealth Board, the Asian Development Bank (ADB) has also agreed to facilitate the constructions of proposed International University of Climate Change studies, he said. Many countries across the world are interested in helping Sri Lanka to mitigate impacts caused by the climatic changes. USA, Great Britain, Japan and South Korea are ready to help Sri Lanka regarding the climatic changes and are ready to hold discussions in this connection in the near future, Wijewardene noted. A Bill to establish an operation centre to coordinate and oversee the construction work of the proposed university will be presented in Parliament in the near future, Wijewardene added. By Naalir Jamaldeen

title: Dr Sanjeewa files FR petition challenging interdiction
author: Author not found
Content: Dr. Galmangoda Guruge Chamal Sanjeewa, who was interdicted based on several allegations following statements recently made by him with regard to malnutrition among children in Suriyawewa, filed a Fundamental Rights Petition before the Supreme Court yesterday (22). He noted in the Petition that the decisions of the Respondents resulted in the infringement of Petitioner’s Fundamental Rights guaranteed under Article 12(1), 14(1)(a) and 14(1)(g) of the Constitution. It was stated that Dr. Sanjeewa, in his capacity as the President of the Medical and Civil Rights Professional Association of Doctors visited the Walsapugala Koswagawa village in Suriyawewa in Hambanthota District to conduct a medical clinic for children in order to check their nutrition levels, health and that accordingly he carried out a survey.Further, out of the 20 children whose clinic cards were observed, about six were at severe malnutrition levels and about 10 were at moderate malnutrition levels in the weight chart of the Child Health and Development Record (CHDR). It was stated  in the Petition however that the statements made by him were embellished by certain media entities. While stating that the he was interdicted on the basis that his acts were in violation of the Establishment Code, Dr. Sanjeewa further stated that the observations however made by him cannot be regarded as an act in violation of the provisions of the relevant Act. BY Faadhila Thassim

title: Any challenge can be overcome with commitment
author: Author not found
Content: Air Force Commander, Air Marshall Sudarshana Pathirana said, if an individual aims at a target and has dedication and commitment then any challenge could be overcome successfully. He said, this during a felicitation event held in his honour at his alma mater Dharmaraja College, Kandy recently. He said if any person carries out his or her entrusted duty with firm commitment and sans fear of favour and with honesty, such persons will be able to go far in life and for them the sky is the limit. The Air Force Commander also opened the sports complex of the school, which is funded by the Air Force. Principal of Dharmaraja College, Kamal Ariyasinghe presented a memento to Air Marshall Pathirana to appreciate his service to the school and the country. By K.L. Suraweera – Kandy

title: Cabinet approves replacing Police Ordinance
author: Author not found
Content: Cabinet approved to introduce a new Act in place of Police Ordinance No. 16 of 1865, in parallel with the present social circumstances. Police Ordinance No. 16 of 1865 presently in force has been amended 37 times in the past. Cabinet approval was granted to revise it again on 19 November 2014. However, it has been recognised that the introduction of a new Act is appropriate based on present social trends. Accordingly, Cabinet approved the proposal presented by the Minister of Public Security to take necessary steps to introduce a new Act in place of the Police Ordinance No. 16 of 1865.

title: Boom in illegal sand mining in Batticaloa – Rasamanickam
author: Author not found
Content: Illankai Tamil Arasu Kachchi (ITAK) MP Shanakiyan Rasamanickam said, illegal sand mining was taking place in irrigation canals, rivers, and agrarian lands in Vakaneri in the Batticaloa District. Rasamanickam said, he has brought this to the attention of officials, as the livelihood of farmers was at stake. He was speaking during an inspection tour of the area on Sunday (20). “Illegal sand mining is taking place in the areas which come under the purview of The Department of Forest Conservation. It has created suspicion among residents. Who is behind this sand mafia? There are two Ministers from the Batticaloa District and one is in charge of environmental affairs,” Rasamanickam said. “A large stretch of land used for cultivation has been taken over by The Department of Forest Conservation, claiming to be Government land, but natural resources are being exploited and illegal sand mining is taking place,” Rasamanickam added.  Rasamanickam said, ordinary citizens were arrested and fined Rs 20,000 for entering the forest. The illegally mined sand is stored on land belonging to The Department of Forest Conservation, Rasamanickam said. Rasamanickam queried whether The Department of Forest Conservation is behind this sand mafia, alleging that this may be why regional and district development committee meetings aren’t held. “Two Ministers representing the Batticaloa District must be responsible for illegal sand mining. Politicians in the district try to create divisions between Muslims and Tamils to gain mileage,” Rasamanickam said. By Naalir Jamaldeen

title: Govt to expedite investigations
author: Author not found
Content: The Government has decided to expedite investigations of those in the custody of Security Forces and under detention orders on the accusations of being involved with the LTTE and Easter Sunday Bombings in 2019. The President’s Office has directed the Ministries of Foreign Affairs and Justice to take the necessary steps to complete the investigations into the accused persons as soon as possible, file charges against those who can be charged in Court, rehabilitate those who should be rehabilitated, and release those who have not been charged. President Ranil Wickremesinghe, Senior Adviser to the President on National Security and President’s Chief of Staff Sagala Ratnayaka, and Foreign Minister Ali Sabry met Ministry of Justice officials last week to discuss about the matter and the decision was reached during that meeting. Ratnayaka has directed the officers to take necessary steps after consulting with the Attorney General about the relevant allegations. A senior government spokesperson said those found guilty will face charges before the end of the year.

title: SJB, SLFP, JJB TO VOTE AGAINST BUDGET
author: Author not found
Content: The main Opposition, Samagi Jana Balawegaya (SJB), Sri Lanka Freedom Party (SLFP), Jathika Jana Balawegaya (JJB) and the majority of the ‘independent’ MPs have decided to vote against Budget 2023 at Second Reading debate today (22). The Opposition Leader’s Office announced the SJB’s decision to vote against the second reading of Budget 2023. Meanwhile, the Central Committee of SLFP also decided yesterday evening to vote against Budget 2023. By Gagani Weerakoon & Methmalie Dissanayake

title: No decision to remove fuel QR system – Kanchana
author: Author not found
Content: Minister of Power and Energy Kanchana Wijesekara said no decision has been taken to remove the fuel management QR system from next month, as reported by certain media. In a tweet, Wijesekara said several media and social media users have claimed the QR system will be done away with from next week. These reports have no truth and no decision has been taken to remove the fuel management QR system. “The fuel management QR system will be continued until full fuel requirements can be fulfilled,” the minister said.
