title: Dilip stages shortest fast in history?
author: Author not found
Content: Samagi Jana Balawegaya (SJB) MP Dilip Wedaarachchi staged a fast in Parliament, yesterday (21), by sitting in the Well of the House, until his numerous demands were fulfilled, especially with regard to the problems faced by fisher folks. However, he got up no sooner than he announced his decision to fast, prompting a question if it is the shortest fast staged ever. Wedaarachchi, who was clad in black, walked towards the Well and sat on the floor, while making impulsive remarks on the problems faced by fishermen. He demanded immediate relief be provided to fisherfolk. “I will continue this fast until   relief is provided,” he said. The entire Chamber went wild following this act and both Government and Opposition MPs started shouting. MP Angajan Ramanathan, who was in the chair at the moment, requested Wedaarachchi to sit in his seat.  “We heard your agitations and solutions will be provided. Please go back to your seat,” Ramanathan said. After that, Wedaarachchi went back to his seat. BY Methmalie Dissanayake

title: Accountant goes to HRCSL over arrest by SLBFE
author: Author not found
Content: An accountant has lodged a complaint with the Human Rights Commission of Sri Lanka (HRCSL) on allegations of unlawful arrest, negligence of the employment agency and the SLBFE officials who forced her arrest.  Sundharalingam Baby Sharmila, accountant, filed a complaint (HO/4449/22) on 22 November with the HRCSL for unlawful arrest and detention overnight at Thalangama Police and being produced in the Maligakanda Magistrate’s Court based on the SLBFE inquiry into the travel agency, where she worked, failing to repatriate a domestic worker suffering from blood cancer in Dubai. The incident occurred while the agency’s owner was in Dubai. Sharmila wrote in the complaint that she has been working for a salary of Rs 30,000 as an accountant for three months at the foreign recruitment agency at Maligakanda that also serves as a travel and tours agency. According to her, the agency where she worked had sent a woman to Dubai on a tourist visa for domestic work and she has been ill with blood cancer and had wanted to return to Sri Lanka.   The ailing woman’s family had paid Rs 150,000 on 22 September to the agency but the agency did not repatriate the girl, hence the family had gone to the SLBFE against the agency owner. The domestic worker had left on 6 August 2022 but she was diagnosed with blood cancer and wanted to return. The accountant alleged that the agency had asked for Rs 800,000 from the family to repatriate her from Dubai. On 2 November 2022 the officials from the SLBFE bureau had visited the agency over the matter and warned the staff in absence of the agency owner. The accountant had informed the owner of the agency and his sister about the visit of the SLBFE officials but they had told the accountant that they have “taken care of the issue and not to worry and continue to work. They had reassured her that everything has been done by a bureau officer and told her to work without fear. However on 14 November around five officers from the SLBFE, including a woman officer, had walked forcefully into the agency and removed some documents and forced the woman accountant to go with them. She said one of the officers had threatened her saying that he will smash her face and to shut up when she asked why are they taking her to the Police. The accountant was locked up in a room at the SLBFE from 3 pm until 8 pm   and handed over to the Thalangama Police where she was remanded until next day morning.  On the morning of 15 November the SLBFE officials took her to their office and made her stay until 3 pm and then produced her at the Maligakanda Police (her case number is B 33226). The owner of the agency, Mohamed Ifthikar and his sister Ifthikar Pathima have been questioning the accountant as to what she had told the SLBFE and the Police and never came to forward to represent her over the incident, she told Ceylon Today.  Instead of giving any information on how to resolve the issue they had verbally abused her over the phone. Following the ordeal, the accountant from Batticaloa, on 16 November complained to the HRCSL to take action against the SLBFE and the owner of the agency over unlawful arrest. It is dubious how the SLBFE was informed over the sick woman, who went on a visit visa to Dubai. It is alleged that the SLBFE at the Bandaranaike International Airport charged the SLBFE fee from workers whether they go on job visa or visit visa. By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: Woman suspect allowed bail
author: Author not found
Content: Colombo Additional Magistrate Keminda Perera yesterday allowed bail, in three sureties in Rs 300,000 each, to suspect Asha Dissanayake, who was produced before him by the CID. The suspect has been charged with sending female migrant workers to Oman to be engaged as sex workers, under the pretence of providing them with jobs. The CID told the Court that their probe had revealed that the suspect had sent six female migrant workers to Oman to be used as sex workers. They informed Magistrate Perera that further investigations are currently being conducted to ascertain details with regard to places used as residences by the suspect as well as to ascertain her identity. Hence, the CID urged the Court to issue an order for the incarceration of the suspect. A group of Lawyers, headed by Niroshan Siriwardena appeared on behalf of the suspect. He told the Court that his client had been employed at a firm in Oman, as its translator for a period of 21 years and stressed that while she had gone to work in 2019, she had fallen sick prompting her to return home the following year. The Counsel added that it had come to their attention that when his client had been planning to leave for Oman, the Court had ordered to impound her passport. Attorney Siriwardene mentioned that the suspect is only the translator of her firm and observed that his client had not committed any offence. He then remarked that the suspect, via her lawyers, had surrendered to the CID through her own volition and that afterwards she had been arrested by the CID and produced in Court. The lawyers requested the Court to enlarge their client on bail. The Court then released the suspect on bail and fixed further hearing of the case to 1 December. By Hansi Nanayakkara

title: Consumer goods decaying at Customs – Nimal
author: Author not found
Content: Minister of Ports, Shipping and Aviation, Nimal Siripala de Silva claimed that consumer goods, such as rice, tins of salmon and turmeric are decaying in the warehouses at the Customs for many years and it is unacceptable given the current economic situation in the country. Speaking in Parliament yesterday (21), De Silva said that he witnessed this while visiting the Customs warehouse recently and apart from that, clothes have been decaying in the Customs for the past 20 years due to an ongoing case. He said these items rot in a warehouse while the citizens of the country are facing difficulties. He added the Customs Ordinance should be changed according to the needs of the time to prevent such issues from arising. BY Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: Amaraweera orders blacklisting of organic fertiliser supplier
author: Author not found
Content: Minister of Agriculture Mahinda Amaraweera instructed the National Fertiliser Secretariat to immediately blacklist an organic fertiliser manufacturing company that supplies liquid organic fertiliser packed in plastic bottles. The National Fertiliser Secretariat has prohibited packaging of liquid organic fertiliser in plastic bottles as pathogens could spread by the use of such packaging method. Amaraweera thereby instructed to blacklist the said company for their failure to follow protocols and to not make ant payment to that company. ‘’The organic fertiliser required for paddy cultivation is now supplied by manufacturers through Farmers’ Service Centres with no Government intervention and the Secretariat will test three organic fertiliser samples of each product and if it is found that such fertiliser is of inferior quality, the company will be blacklisted and the government has decided not to pay the related amount regardless of how much they have sold,’’ he said. ‘’All necessary measures will be taken to ensure that there is no substandard fertiliser in the market as this could affect the quality of the harvest,’’ Amaraweera said adding that further investigations will be conducted to track down such acts and such companies will be similarly blacklisted. Further Amaraweera instructed the Secretariat to investigate allegations of an organic fertiliser company selling fertiliser with high concentration of sand. BY Faadhila Thassim

title: Teachers defy dress code
author: Author not found
Content: A group of female teachers from several schools throughout the island reported to work yesterday (21) in comfortable and modest attire, breaking the traditional dress code rule set for them. They wore outfits such as Kurta, long skirts and blouses etc, instead of traditional saree and osari. They claimed that due to the current economic crisis, wearing a saree is a costly affair. Meanwhile, Ceylon Teachers’ Union (CTU) General Secretary Joseph Stalin told Ceylon Today that the relevant decision was not influenced by any teachers’ Union, but was done according to the right of the Teachers as per the Circular 5/2022 related to dress codes of employees in public administration. He added according to the Circular 5/2022 related to public administration no one can deny their rights. Stalin stated that yet the majority of teachers wear the saree and if they are comfortable with it they can continue to do so, yet the ones who want to wear other comfortable attire have the lawful right to do. Stalin earlier wrote to the Education Ministry requesting to permit female teachers to wear modest and comfortable attire to schools as per the circular 5/2022 related to dress codes of employees in public administration. Following that, a group of Buddhist monks vehemently opposed permitting female teachers to report to work in modest attire other than saree. Education Minister Susil Premajayantha also did the same in Parliament. By Nabiya Vaffoor

title: Probe launched into using Ambulance to visit astrologer
author: Author not found
Content: An investigation has been launched into an official, who had transported a group of health service officers in an ambulance to meet an astrologer, the Southern Province Health Service Director Chandima Sirithunga said. He said this particular official had transported five officers in an ambulance to meet a person at Batapola, who is reputed in the Province as a palm reader, in the afternoon of 17 November. He added that an immediate probe will be conducted into the misuse of a State vehicle and stated that if an offence had been committed those guilty of it will be duly punished. According to the Director, the driver of the van when questioned, had stated that he had transported a stock of medicines to the Nindana Maha Vidyalaya. However, when inquired from the principal of the school G.H.I. Fonseka, she had mentioned that on the day in question no medicine stocks had been transported to her school by an ambulance. When inquired from the doctor in charge of the ambulance, at the hospital, he barked at this correspondent saying to mind his own business and not to poke his finger into unnecessary matters. By Dhamsari Liyanage – Balapitiya

title: Opposition raises concern over NPC Chair welcoming Basil
author: Author not found
Content: The Opposition raised concerns in Parliament over the National Police Commission (NPC) Chairman Chandra Fernando and another NPC member M.P.P. Perera being among those who welcomed former Minister Basil Rajapaksa. While claiming that the 21st Amendment to the Constitution proposes Independent Commissions, the Opposition questioned as to how the Government intends to establish Independent Commissions while the Chief of such a commission is involved in welcoming a former minister. Several Opposition MPs raised concerns in Parliament yesterday on the ‘VIP’ treatment provided to former Finance Minister Basil Rajapaksa upon his arrival in Sri Lanka last Sunday (20).  Samagi Jana Balawegaya (SJB) MP Nalin Bandara said that such individuals are an obstruction to the establishment of Independent Commissions and the development of Sri Lanka.  Meanwhile, speaking to the media yesterday (21), Chandra Fernando refuted the allegations that he went to welcome Rajapaksa. “I was at the BIA when I heard Basil Rajapaksa had arrived in the island. I heard some people had gathered there to spark clashes. That was why I went there. I am not biased towards anyone because it is not suitable for my post,” Fernando said. BY Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: HRCSL calls for report from Health Secy
author: Author not found
Content: The Human Rights Commission of Sri Lanka (HRCSL) called for a comprehensive report, before 30 November, from the Health Secretary, with regard to suspension of services of the President of the Medical and Civil Rights Professional Association (MCRPA),Dr. Chamal Sanjeewa, who made statements on child malnutrition in the Hambantota District. This follows a complaint lodged against him and the Secretary of Public Administration for violating the “constitutional right of a government official to speech,” which led to the suspension of Dr. Sanjeewa. The HRCSL has asked Health Secretary Janaka Sri Chandragupta to file the report by 30 November 2022, prior to a probe into the complaint. They have called for the submission of all relevant documentation with regard to the issue. The MCRPA President filed a complaint against the Secretaries of Health and Public Administration late last week accusing the duo of violating the constitutional right of government officials to speech by issuing circulars. Recently, circulars were issued by the Secretary of the Ministry of Health and the Secretary of the Ministry of Public Administration restricting the right of speech of government officials. According to them even the use of social media was prohibited to State officials. Dr. Sanjeewa in his complaint observed that the constitutional right to speech of the citizens of this country could not be challenged by institutional circulars or even the Establishment Code. MCRPA Secretary Dr. Jayaruwan Bandara and President Dr. Sanjeewa also accused the Health Ministry’s Flying Squad of being biased when conducting disciplinary investigations and called for an investigation against the Health Ministry’s Secretary.  Dr. Sanjeewa vehemently pledged that his union would not allow any politician to act arbitrarily or intimidate government officials through their actions. By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: Conservationists raise concern
author: Author not found
Content: While raising concerns over the construction of the Moragoda Police Station, obstructing an elephant corridor in the area, the Biodiversity Conservation and Research Circle (BCRC) of Sri Lanka said this would only further aggravate human-elephant conflict (HEC) in the area. In a letter to the Secretary of the Ministry of Wildlife and Forest Resources, Convener of the Biodiversity Conservation and Research Circle of Sri Lanka, Supun Lahiru Prakash noted that the Police Station is proposed to be built in about a one-acre slot of the ten-acre land belonging to the Moragoda Beat office of the Ritigala range, of the Department of Wildlife Conservation. He stated that the Moragoda Police operations took place in a private building thus far, on a rental basis and the relevant building is proposed to be constructed blocking the said elephant corridor, which is reported to consist of a large number of elephants. Prakash noted that if the said elephant corridor is blocked, it could result in an aggravated HEC in several adjoining areas He added that such construction, in a backdrop where the Department of Wildlife Conservation (DWC) has decided to restore 16 elephant corridors, raises the concern as to whether new elephant corridors will be demarcated in ignorance of the actual areas that are construed as elephant corridors over the years. He thereby requested to take relevant measures to allocate a separate land for such purpose. Copies of the letter were also sent to the Secretary of the Ministry of Defence, Secretary of the Ministry of Public Security and the Director General of the DWC. BY Faadhila Thassim

title: Consumer goods decaying at Customs – Nimal
author: Author not found
Content: Minister of Ports, Shipping and Aviation, Nimal Siripala de Silva claimed that consumer goods, such as rice, tins of salmon and turmeric are decaying in the warehouses at the Customs for many years and it is unacceptable given the current economic situation in the country. Speaking in Parliament yesterday (21), De Silva said that he witnessed this while visiting the Customs warehouse recently and apart from that, clothes have been decaying in the Customs for the past 20 years due to an ongoing case. He said these items rot in a warehouse while the citizens of the country are facing difficulties. He added the Customs Ordinance should be changed according to the needs of the time to prevent such issues from arising. BY Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: Amaraweera orders blacklisting of organic fertiliser supplier
author: Author not found
Content: Minister of Agriculture Mahinda Amaraweera instructed the National Fertiliser Secretariat to immediately blacklist an organic fertiliser manufacturing company that supplies liquid organic fertiliser packed in plastic bottles. The National Fertiliser Secretariat has prohibited packaging of liquid organic fertiliser in plastic bottles as pathogens could spread by the use of such packaging method. Amaraweera thereby instructed to blacklist the said company for their failure to follow protocols and to not make ant payment to that company. ‘’The organic fertiliser required for paddy cultivation is now supplied by manufacturers through Farmers’ Service Centres with no Government intervention and the Secretariat will test three organic fertiliser samples of each product and if it is found that such fertiliser is of inferior quality, the company will be blacklisted and the government has decided not to pay the related amount regardless of how much they have sold,’’ he said. ‘’All necessary measures will be taken to ensure that there is no substandard fertiliser in the market as this could affect the quality of the harvest,’’ Amaraweera said adding that further investigations will be conducted to track down such acts and such companies will be similarly blacklisted. Further Amaraweera instructed the Secretariat to investigate allegations of an organic fertiliser company selling fertiliser with high concentration of sand. BY Faadhila Thassim

title: Teachers defy dress code
author: Author not found
Content: A group of female teachers from several schools throughout the island reported to work yesterday (21) in comfortable and modest attire, breaking the traditional dress code rule set for them. They wore outfits such as Kurta, long skirts and blouses etc, instead of traditional saree and osari. They claimed that due to the current economic crisis, wearing a saree is a costly affair. Meanwhile, Ceylon Teachers’ Union (CTU) General Secretary Joseph Stalin told Ceylon Today that the relevant decision was not influenced by any teachers’ Union, but was done according to the right of the Teachers as per the Circular 5/2022 related to dress codes of employees in public administration. He added according to the Circular 5/2022 related to public administration no one can deny their rights. Stalin stated that yet the majority of teachers wear the saree and if they are comfortable with it they can continue to do so, yet the ones who want to wear other comfortable attire have the lawful right to do. Stalin earlier wrote to the Education Ministry requesting to permit female teachers to wear modest and comfortable attire to schools as per the circular 5/2022 related to dress codes of employees in public administration. Following that, a group of Buddhist monks vehemently opposed permitting female teachers to report to work in modest attire other than saree. Education Minister Susil Premajayantha also did the same in Parliament. By Nabiya Vaffoor

title: Gammanpila allowed to go abroad
author: Author not found
Content: Colombo High Court Judge Namal Balalle yesterday (21) granted approval for Pivithuru Hela Urumaya (PHU) Leader Udaya Gammanpila to go overseas from 23 to 29 November. The MP’s passport had been impounded by the High Court in connection with a lawsuit filed against him over the criminal misappropriation of a sum of Rs 21 million. Attorney-at-Law Inoka Perera, appearing on behalf of the MP, requested Judge Balalle, via a motion, to temporarily lift the foreign travel ban imposed on her client as he has to be involved in a religious event during the said time period. Accordingly the Court temporarily liftede the overseas travel ban and ordered the Registrar to convey its decision to the Controller of the Department of Immigration and Emigration. The former minister has been indicted before the High Court on four counts and on charges of criminal misappropriation of the said sum, by forging the signature of an Australian national from 26 September 1996 to 21 September 1997, while proceeding to illegally sell shares of a firm owned by the foreigner, via a forged Power of Attorney 19 years ago. BY Hansi Nanayakkara

title: Drugs awareness programme in Kotagala
author: Author not found
Content: A drug and drug addiction awareness programme, initiated by the Kotagala Traders Association and the Kotagala Police, for school childrten studying in the Kotagala area, was held on 20 November. This was conducted with the goal of arresting traders and drug racketeers who use drugs and sell drugs to school children and to rescue students who are addicted to drugs. Principals and teachers from Kotagala’s main schools and estate schools, who took part in the discussion, expressed concern that a large number of students in their schools are addicted to various drugs. Such students were identified during the discussion and they were barred from class. As a result, the principals and teachers made requests to save other students from drug use and to carry out the project with the support of their parents. The principals stated that due to the country’s economic crisis, there is a lack of attendance in classes from 6th to 11th grades in the main schools and estate schools, and that these students are also drug addicts. Pushpa Viswanathan, President of Kotagala United Traders Association and Assistant Superintendent of Police, Nuwara Eliya District, led a preliminary discussion on the programme’s implementation at the Kotagala Sri Muthu Vinayakar Hindu Temple Hall on that day. Several school principals, teachers, city traders, clergymen, vehicle drivers, public and private officials, parents, well-wishers, and Police were present. Furthermore, the principals informed that certain pharmacies in Kotagala town sell drugs to school students, and that students who have purchased drugs come to school and consume them in secret. Measures will be taken to free students from this drug addiction, protect the community, and appoint committees to investigate the matter, based on the opinions expressed by principals, teachers, and well-wishers. The Nuwara Eliya District Assistant Superintendent of Police also made a request to avoid drugs. Photo and text by K. Kishanthan

title: A remarkable beginning for the first-year U’grads from Japura Marketers
author: Author not found
Content: X-Universe is an event, organised by the University of Sri Jayewardenepura Marketing Management Association, targeting the first-year undergraduates of the Faculty of Management Studies and Commerce. All the arrangements are in progress for the event on 24 November in the University premises. X-Universe, exclusively offered by Japura Marketers, is a blend of several activities which tests physical strength, mental ability, aesthetic skills, and creativity of participants. Only about 1,400 of the best performing students of the Advanced Level Commerce stream would be privileged enough to enter the Faculty of Management Studies and Commerce of University of Sri Jayewardenepura, which is one of the leading and well recognised Management faculties in the South Asian region. Unfortunately, due to Covid-19 most of them were restricted to the virtual environment. “We believe that X-Universe would serve as an ideal platform for them to cover up all the excitement they have been missing all this time. The objective of X-Universe is to develop skills such as leadership, team building and confidence of first year undergraduates and to provide them with a platform to create stronger bonds while conveying the vibe of undergraduates to the community. X-Universe comprises of 6 sessions in total, The University said in a statement. It added, ‘nine groups will participate and each will have 15 members. ‘Fly pool’ is a game associated with a swimming pool and would pave the opening to the event. It would be followed up by various adventurous, fun, and brainstorming games. Next in line is ‘Star Kitchen’, a vibrant cooking game. It is not just a cooking game, but a whole cooking experience where they would be provided with the chance to prepare delicious meals for their team members. To spice up the competition we decided to include a Carrom tournament. We didn’t miss to provide a platform to all the intelligent souls out there to test their cognitive abilities. “We have got them covered with ‘Tele Brain’, a general knowledge competition. Another very special segment is ‘Galaxy Walk’ which adds a whole new level of diversification to this event. Here is the chance to all the active and adventurous souls to test their physical strength. “Finally, to sum up this amazing event we have ‘Tone Comet’, a Talent show! We invite all the aesthetic souls out there to perform and bring out their inner superstars. X- Universe is one of newest and unique initiatives from the second years of the Marketing Management Department gifted to the first years and with no doubt this would be a major addition to all of our reel of university memories. There is a lot happening behind the screen to make this event a success and all their efforts are highly appreciated. As a prestigious department we are not only focusing on academics but also on co-curricular activities as we believe in producing all-round graduates to the country. This is not only an opportunity for the participants to showcase their skills but also for the organisers too, to come out of their comfort zones while discovering their hidden talents and to gain corporate exposure which would definitely help them to succeed in the corporate world. The Japura marketeers are working day and night and eagerly waiting till 24th to witness the most glamorous event of the University history. We are ready, are you?”

title: ACUTE DEARTH OF TEACHERS IN CP
author: Author not found
Content: Central Province Governor Lalith U. Gamage said there is an acute shortage of school teachers for various subjects within the Province. He said according to statistics tabulated by his office there is currently a shortage of around 33,000 teachers in the Province. The Governor made these remarks while participating in an education seminar held at Pallepola recently. He added that he intends to hold discussions in this regard with the Education Minister and to absorb around 13,000 teachers to the cadre to cater to the Central Province by January next year. By Priyantha Polwatta – Ukuwela

title: Cargills ‘Sarubima’ empowers the next generation of Sri Lanka’s farmer families
author: Author not found
Content: Cargills, with its far-reaching farmer out-grower network and continuous investments in building sustainable markets, has been able to uplift thousands of farmers across the country. By investing in collection centres, which enable direct collection from the farmer and the introduction of refrigerated trucks and improved logistics, the Cargills agri value chain has established itself as one of the most successful in the country. Some of its key achievements include minimising post-harvest loss of fruit and vegetables and eliminating middlemen from the supply chain which ensure a lower price to consumers while ensuring higher prices for farmers. In addition to purchasing milk and agri produce at a guaranteed price, Cargills has improved the productivity, quality and sustainability of farmers’ production, thereby enhancing rural livelihoods and transforming traditional farmers to Agri-Entrepreneurs. In 2008, Cargills established a farmer welfare fund ‘Sarubima’ in Thanamalwila, by contributing 50 cents for every kilogramme of produce purchased from farmers to launch an educational scholarship programme for farmers’ children who excel in Grade 5, Ordinary Level and University Entrance exams. This contribution has continued to date. Furthermore, a part of the fund was allocated for community development projects including, providing access to safe drinking water and building children’s playgrounds in rural schools to name a few. This year, the Cargills’ Sarubima fund will be awarding 774 scholarships worth Rs 25 million to farmer children who have excelled in studies. The awardees include 194 students at Grade 5, 375 at Advanced Level, 158 at university and 47 for Vocational Training. In addition, 32 community development projects have been planned, which include health camps and eye camps for farmers, and water supply and sanitary facility projects urgently required by selected rural schools and hospitals. Since the inception of the fund, over 2,500 scholarships have been awarded to farmer children and over 100 community projects have been undertaken which include water purification projects, school libraries and upgrading sanitary facilities in rural schools. In 2014, the Sarubima Fund was extended to all Cargills vegetable, fruit, and milk collection centres, benefiting over 20,000 agri and dairy farmers across the country. In 2018, Cargills Sarubima took a step towards national agriculture development with the start of the Agriculture Modernisation Project. This project is a model for climate-smart, profitable, and environment-friendly production of a range of GAP certified fresh produce. ‘Sarubima’ is a reflection of the Cargills commitment to empowering rural agri and dairy farmers by creating sustainable markets, building up capacity and nurturing the next generation of farmers. If the soil is not rich and fertile, a good harvest cannot be reaped from that soil. Similarly, for sustainable agriculture, farmers must take care of the soil, nurture it, and conserve it for future generations– Sarubima. Pic by J. Weerasekara

title: Opposition staging ‘media stunt’ –Dy Speaker
author: Author not found
Content: Deputy Speaker Ajith Rajapakse claimed that several Opposition MPs are staging a ‘media stunt’ inside the House, pretending that they are against cultivating cannabis for export, while they actually appreciate the President’s budget proposal. Participating in the Second Reading of Appropriation Bill 2023 yesterday (21), the Deputy Speaker said, he was ear dropping and he heard some Opposition MPs appreciating the proposal to cultivate cannabis for export, in the Parliament canteen and upon returning to the Chamber they criticised that proposal. Rajapakse said that it is not possible to face the current challenges with such ‘double standards’. “Everyone here (in Parliament) should be responsible, even though they might have different opinions, because this budget was proposed during a difficult time. Therefore, everyone should support the Government’s programme that would move the country forward,” he said. BY Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: Two sisters remanded for swindling Rs 120M
author: Author not found
Content: The CID arrested two sisters in Navanthurai, Jaffna for defrauding Rs 120 million using fake bank documents. The Police Media Spokesman said the suspects, aged 30 and 34 years were remanded. Preliminary investigations revealed that they had received Rs 120 million through 23 bank accounts from a Sri Lankan living in Norway from January to June 2021. The sisters had been projecting that their deceased father was a rich businessman and had financial assets including gold jewellery worth more than one billion rupees. They had said they were working on resolving legal issues to release the funds. The Sri Lankan living in Norway had later realised that both of them had been cheating him. The Police Spokesman said that both the sisters were arrested based on his complaint. The arrested duo was in possession of numerous forged documents, including letters signed by various government officials, bank managers, lawyers and village officials. They also had bank books and bank slips. Police are investigating whether some other people are involved in this racket. Meanwhile, both the sisters have been remanded until 1 December after being arraigned in the Jaffna Magistrate’s Court. The CID is conducting further investigations. By T. Pratheepan – Jaffna

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: President assures his support to expand Scout movement
author: Author not found
Content: President Ranil Wickremesinghe yesterday (21) assured that he would provide the necessary assistance to expand the scouting movement by increasing its membership to 200,000 covering all nine provinces by 2024.  The President also mentioned that he would seek the support of the Ministry of Education and the Ministry of Youth Affairs for this purpose. The Sri Lanka Scout Association officially conferred the title of Chief Scout and Patronus to President Wickremesinghe at the President’s Office, where he made these comments. The Scout Commissioner, Attorney-at-Law Janaprith Fernando, commissioned and presented the Scout Scarf and the appointment certificate to President Wickremesinghe. A report on the progress of the Scout Movement was also presented to the President. The President further stated that he expects to get the full support of the Scout Movement for the 75th Independence Day Celebration. He invited the Scout Movement to join the environment-related programmes which are being held with the intervention of the President’s Office and headed by President’s Adviser on Climate Change  Ruwan Wijewardena.The commemorative medal for the 60th anniversary of the Homagama District Branch, affiliated to the Sri Lanka Scout Association, was presented to the President by Girl Guide Potaka Thitulu Kathya. The related commemorative souvenir was also presented to the President. Deputy Chief Commissioner M.S.S. Muheed, Executive Committee Chairman  Ransiri Perera and other officers, including Homagama District Scout  Commissioner Dr. Anil Perera, New District Commissioner K. A.  Chandrapadma, Assistant District Commissioner Suranga Handapangoda and  others participated in this event.

title: SLBFE BUSTS ROMANIA JOB RACKET
author: Author not found
Content: In another job scam, Sri Lanka Bureau of Foreign Employment (SLBFE) officials apprehended three Sri Lankans and an Italian national yesterday (20) at a hotel in Badulla town, for carrying out recruitment interviews, claiming that they would be offered jobs in Romania on Facebook. The three Sri Lankans arrested, along with the 58-year-old Italian, are 62, 47, and 35-year-old residents of Badulla and Neluwa. Investigating officers said, there were no documents or passports to confirm the identity of the Italian national, who is said to be married to a Belarusian woman. Meanwhile, while the interview  was being conducted, two decoys were present where would-be aspirants handed over Rs 5,000 in cash along with medical and police reports to the interviewer. Participants were asked to bring these reports along with their NICs. Following the interview, a Sri Lankan suspect informed the foreigner that they needed to provide a bio data form along with Rs 5,000 to get a job in Romania and that following the receipt of the work permit they had to pay Rs 1.5 million. When the Sri Lankan suspect was asked to whom the money should be given, he said that it should be given to an office run by the Italian in the hotel and that he would deposit it in the required bank account. However, the interviewees said they had to borrow money to fulfil the financial commitments so that they would get employment in Romania and said a payment of Rs 1.5 million should be made in Sri Lanka. According to the investigating officers, the suspects were arrested for conducting an illegal interview with would-be aspirants who were ready to leave although they did not have much money with them. The suspects were apprehended by Sarath Wimalawira, Idunil Pushpakumara, Wasantha Ekanayake, and Madhushan Wijewardena of the SLBFE’s Investigation Unit. The suspects are scheduled to appear in the Badulla Magistrate’s Court on 21 November. BY Nishantha Gunawardena – Badulla

title: Kanchana to present proposal today
author: Author not found
Content: Minister of Power and Energy Kanchana Wijesekera will present the proposal for monthly fuel price revision to Cabinet today (21). He said, beginning next month, fuel prices will be revised on a monthly basis. “The fuel price formula takes effect on the first and fifteenth of each month. To avoid losses, fuel distributors did not order fuel on the fourteenth or thirteenth. As a result, we decided to revise prices monthly. We will inform everyone about increases or decreases at midnight,” he said. Wijesekera added that officials from the Ceylon Petroleum Corporation will be authorised to implement the fuel price formula monthly. By Thameenah Razeek

title: Relatives of missing persons stage protest in Vavuniya
author: Author not found
Content: Relatives of those who went missing during the 30-year separatist war protested in front of the Vavuniya District Secretariat during President Ranil Wickremesinghe’s visit to Vavuniya and demanded an international investigation to find those who went missing during the war. When Police officers in Vavuniya proceeded to evacuate the protesters, a heated situation erupted. When the President arrived for the district development progress review meeting at the district secretariat, relatives of the missing persons demanded immediate solutions to their problems, raising black flags and showing photographs of the missing persons. This was President Wickremesinghe’s first visit to the Northern Province since taking office. BY Shashi Kumar – Mullaitivu

title: Offered jobs in Poland but stranded in Azerbaijan
author: Author not found
Content: Panadura Police Criminal Investigation Unit has arrested a manager of an Ayurvedic pharmaceutical company in the Gampaha District for duping eight individuals with job offers in Poland, charging Rs 10 million and transporting them to Azerbaijan. According to Police, the suspect was apprehended after a resident of Negombo lodged a complaint with Panadura SP Samantha Vedage. According to Police, the suspect has been involved in human trafficking with an Azerbaijani agent and eight victims have been identified so far. It is claimed that the eight victims were told they would be given jobs in Poland and Rs 750,000 had been charged from each in Sri Lanka and they told to take Rs 1.5 million in dollars. The victims had been taken to Azerbaijan and once they reached there, the agent disappeared without a trace once the dollars were handed over to that country’s agent. It is reported that the victims suffered for months in Azerbaijan. This time around eight people had fallen victim to the ruse. An official in charge of investigations said complaints in this regard could be made to the Panadura SP’s  office. The suspect, a 34-year-old resident of Wadduwa, Morontuduwa was scheduled to be produced before the Panadura Magistrate. BY SumithRanawaka (Pothupitiya) and Bimal Jayasinghe (Colombo)

title: Human trafficking kingpin arrested at BIA
author: Author not found
Content: The main suspect involved in human trafficking to Oman was arrested by Immigration Officers at the BIA on 19 November on an order issued by the Negombo Magistrate. Manager of the Special Investigation Unit of the Sri Lanka Foreign Employment Bureau (SLBFE), Kapila Karunaratne said, Mohammad Rizvi Mohammad Infaz, a 44-year-old suspect, led this human trafficking ring by posing as the Third Secretary of the Presidential Secretariat. According to investigations conducted by the SLBFE, the suspect flew young women to Oman via a foreign employment agency in Maradana and several other foreign employment agencies islandwide. Victims brought to Abu Dhabi, Dubai, and other Middle Eastern countries on tourist visas cross the border and are bussed to Oman, where they are auctioned off as prostitutes for amounts ranging from Rs 1 million to Rs 2.5 million. A large number of young women who were victims of these cases are kept in reception centres at Sri Lankan Missions in Abu Dhabi, Dubai, and Oman, it is learnt. The suspect was remanded until 24 November after being produced before Negombo Acting Magistrate Primal Amarasinghe. Meanwhile, a local agent linked to the main suspect was also arrested. The agent was arrested following complaints by persons who returned to Sri Lanka recently. The arrest was made by the CID on 19 November for his involvement in the racket where local women were flown to the Middle East with the promise of jobs. The suspect is a 45-year-old resident of Puwakpitiya, Avissawella. He was remanded until 1 December by the Fort Magistrate. By Aloka Kasturiarachchi and T.K.G. Kapila (Katunayake)

title: Husband, wife duo in foreign job scam
author: Author not found
Content: In another job scam, a husband and wife duo have been arrested for defrauding thousands of rupees from residents in the Yakkala and Gampaha areas. Yakkala Police arrested the couple while they were staying in a rented house in Dematagoda. Nine complaints had been lodged alleging the couple defrauded people in the Yakkala and Gampaha areas. Police investigations reveal the suspects had defrauded money promising employment in Dubai. BY Thilak Priyadarshana Liyanage – Yakkala

title: Economic recovery is a painful process – Dr. Weerasinghe
author: Author not found
Content: Central Bank Governor, Dr. Nandalal Weerasinghe said, if the economy had been managed by knowledgeable persons, Sri Lanka will not be in this situation. Dr. Weerasinghe said, he believes the people will understand the difficult decisions that must be made to get out of the present economic crisis. Participating in a ceremony to commemorate the 100th anniversary of Matara Rahula College, he stressed that in addition to managing the economy, he believes that if decision-makers and policy-makers selected the right person for the right job, we could have avoided the present predicament. “Countries will develop only when the right person is in the right place. It will not be successful in a society where untapped talent is unable to advance competitively based on their abilities. We are living in extremely difficult times. It is not easy to recover from the economic crisis. Difficult choices must be made. They are, however, unpopular decisions. When difficult decisions are made, some people will suffer. Decision-makers will be blamed,” he said. Further, he said no matter how many accusations are levelled, if the decisions they make are correct, they are doing the right thing. “Even if there are difficulties in the short term, I hope that people will understand. Even if it is difficult, it’s the right thing. It is hoped that by doing so, we will recover as soon as possible and, somehow, return the country to normalcy, giving everyone a better future,” he said. By Thameenah Razeek

Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Prasanna annoyed by ‘kaputa’ comment
author: Author not found
Content: Chief Government Whip Prasanna Ranatunga lost his cool after SJB MP Niroshan Perera said ‘Kaputa’ is expected to canvass support for Budget 2023 to get it passed in Parliament withtwo-thirds majority. Speaking in Parliament on 19 November, Ranatunga said, referring to MPs as ‘Kaputa’ is degrading. He also said the MP who made the claim used to follow the ‘Kaputa’ for a time. “Fathers and relatives of some MPs who are speaking here today were in this Parliament previously and if they had fulfilled their responsibilities, the country won’t be in this situation,” he added. Ranatunga said this after MP Perera said there is news that the ‘Kaputa’ will return to Sri Lanka soon to help win the Budget. By Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: Rajitha hails cannabis cultivation move
author: Author not found
Content: Former Health Minister Dr. Rajitha Senaratne said, the budget proposal to cultivate cannabis for export as medicine was a positive move. Speaking in Parliament during the Second Reading of the Budget on 19 November, Dr. Senaratne claimed, as Health Minister, he submitted a Cabinet paper to enable the Security Forces to cultivate cannabis and export it as medicine. “However, it was not approved due to various objections including the then President saying that it was not in keeping with Sri Lankan culture. Cannabis was directly connected to Sri Lankan culture and was banned during British colonisation as the latter introduced tobacco,” he said. “Sri Lanka could earn around USD 4M to USD 5M through cannabis export,” Senaratne said. BY Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: Thera slams cannabis cultivation in SL
author: Author not found
Content: The Government is now focused on resolving issues that have arisen around cannabis, which has put student education in Sri Lanka in jeopardy, Director of Gelioya Vidyapathi Pirivena Ven. Galaha Siri Shantha Thera of theSri Lanka Ramanna Maha Nikaya said. He said the Government was engaged in an issue that will destroy education in Sri Lanka. He was referring to the on-going debate on cannabis cultivation. The Thera was speaking following a ceremony yesterday (20) at Gelioya, Veluvanarama, Sucharithwardena Dhamma School. He said today the discourse centred on cannabis. “The world recognises that our country has a high literacy rate. What will happen though is that our country’s future of 4.3 million students and 0.2 million pre-school children is in jeopardy. Some schoolchildren’s books, stationery, and educational equipment have increased by 500 per cent. So, how could parents get their children to school? Two weeks ago, it cost only Rs 4,000 to buy books for a first-year student but now it has increased by leaps and bounds,” he said. He said today, the books cost a staggering Rs 12,000. He said a pair of shoes that could be purchased for between Rs 1,000 and Rs 1,500 now costs Rs 5,000. He also said nowadays children could not afford to bring lunch and walk home instead of taking the bus. “When the people are suffering, cultivating marijuana has become the Government’s main discourse today. People are blindfolded and given a topic to discuss. According to ministers, the price of schoolbooks has not increased as a result of the cess tax. We want these ministers to come out of those AC rooms and see what the real situation is,” he said. BY K.L. Suraweera – Kandy

title: President on inspection tour of North
author: Author not found
Content: President Ranil Wickremesinghe, who is on an observation tour of the Northern Province, visited the Mannar District yesterday (20). The aim of this visit was to investigate problems faced by the people of Mannar and to discuss solutions to address issues. He visited Mannar city, inspected renovation work carried out on the Mannar Dutch Fort. The President also visited Nadukuda fishing village and engaged in a cordial discussion with the fishing community, and inquired about the issues they face. The Head of State was briefed about the issues faced by residents of the small fishing village. He assured them that prompt action would be taken to provide solutions. The President also inspected the area where the Mannar wind power plant is being constructed and looked into the future activities of the wind power plant. He spoke to area residents and inquired into their wellbeing. Minister of Fisheries and Aquatic Resources Douglas Devananda, Minister of Power and Energy Kanchana Wijesekara, Northern Province Governor Jeevan Thiagarajah, Minister of State for Urban Development and Housing, Kader Masthan, President’s Secretary Saman Ekanayake and a group of government officials accompanied the President

title: Rajapaksas responsible for missing audit reports – Sirisena
author: Author not found
Content: Former President Maithripala Sirisena claimed that the Rajapaksas wilfully misplaced forensic audit reports on the Bond scam in 2007. He said when the Bond scam took place during his presidency, the Presidential Commission of Inquiry (PCoI) into Treasury Bond scams comprised Supreme Court judges and that while giving the report, they concluded that something more than this had occurred since 2007. Sirisena made these remarks while attending the ‘Crisis, Budget, and Future’ Budget conference hosted by the SLFP at the Mahaweli Centre. “After the commission informed us that something else had occurred since 2007, we felt it was necessary to conduct a forensic audit on this. Because there were no suitable people in Sri Lanka, they were brought in from other countries and asked to conduct this forensic audit. I told them to start working right away,” he said. He said after that, a retired economist Dr. Kumaraswamy made international calls for forensic audits, and three companies responded. He said three sectors had been delegated to three companies. “That report came out about a year after I left office. As you may recall, the Government that was elected after 2019, launched a major media campaign claiming that the three forensic audit reports were false. Rajapaksa dismissed all three reports. I have no idea where those records are now,” he claimed. By Thameenah Razeek

title: Malaysia ex-PM Mahathir loses seat in first election defeat in 53 years
author: Author not found
Content: KUALA LUMPUR: Malaysia’s veteran leader Mahathir Mohamad suffered his first election defeat in 53 years on Saturday in a blow that could mark the end of a seven-decade political career. Mahathir, 97, who served as Malaysia’s prime minister for more than two decades in two stints, failed to retain his parliamentary seat in the Langkawi island constituency, coming in fourth in a five-cornered fight. The seat was won by Mohd Suhaimi Abdullah, a candidate from the Perikatan alliance, which is led by another former prime minister, Muhyiddin Yassin. It was Mahathir’s first election loss since 1969. Mahathir leads a coalition that has vowed to take down the incumbent Barisan Nasional government over corruption allegations. But his alliance is not considered a key contender, with Barisan facing two other major coalitions – Muhyiddin’s bloc and another led by Mahathir’s long-time rival Anwar Ibrahim. Mahathir told Reuters in an interview this month he would retire from politics if he lost. “I don’t see myself being active in politics until I’m 100-years-old,” he said. “The most important thing is to transfer my experience to the younger leaders of the party.” (Reuters)

title: Seven-year Glyphosate ban lifted
author: Author not found
Content: Secretary of the Ministry of Agriculture Gunadasa Samarasinghe handed over the Gazette lifting the seven-year ban on Glyphosate to the Government Printer. The Ministry of Agriculture has decided to lift the ban on Glyphosate, which has had a significant impact on weed control of crops such as rice, maize, tea, and rubber. Secretary Samarasinghe said the gazette was handed over to Department of Government Printing with the signature of Minister of Agriculture Mahinda Amaraweera. Amaraweera decided to lift the Glyphosate ban after receiving numerous inquiries from various sectors, including farmers’ representatives, agricultural experts, and agronomists. Glyphosate was banned in Sri Lanka for the first time in 2015 without the implementation of any alternative weed control measures, according to a ministry statement, and it was later banned in tea and rubber cultivation in 2018. “However, some individuals illegally imported substandard Glyphosate by sea and sold it at high prices islandwide. As a result, further Glyphosate ban enforcement is pointless. Furthermore, harvests were reduced because there was no alternative method for weed control in the agricultural sector. Thus, efforts were made to lift the Glyphosate ban, which had been in place since 2015,” he said.

title: Stationery prices unaffected by Cess Tax – Siyambalapitiya
author: Author not found
Content: State Minister of Finance Ranjith Siyambalapitiya said the Cess Tax proposed in the 2023 Budget does not apply to stationery items and equipment used by schoolchildren. During a special statement in Parliament on 19 November, he addressed concerns raised about the increase in stationery prices as a result of the Cess Tax revision. He emphasised that the prices of imported textbooks, notebooks, pencils, erasers, and paper materials used to make notebooks have not been revised as a result of the Cess Tax revision, which came into effect on 15 November. According to the State Minister, the Cess Tax is imposed based on the import value when substitutes for imported items are produced locally. The Cess Tax on imported ballpoint pens, shoes, and bags has been adjusted to reflect the present USD exchange rate. Thus, the prices of these imported items are likely to rise. However, the prices of locally produced stationery items have not been raised, Siyambalapitiya said. By Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: Navy arrests 14 Indian fishers
author: Author not found
Content: The Navy arrested 14 Indian fishermen and seized an Indian trawler on 17 November for illegally entering the Jaffna Vethilakeni coast. The Indian fishermen were arrested while fishing on Vethilakeni beach by officers from the Northern Naval Command and the Coast Guard. The Navy handed over the Indian fishermen, their vessels, and fishing gear to the Milady Fisheries Inspectorate for onward legal action. The Navy has seized 30 fishing vessels with 228 Indian fishermen on board who illegally entered Sri Lankan waters from January to November 2022. By Shashi Kumar – Mullaitivu

title: Train schedules to be revised
author: Author not found
Content: The Department of Railways has decided to revise train schedules and impose speed limits on trains. The decision was made during a discussion with State Minister Lasantha Alagiyawanna following complaints received regarding train derailment. Thus, it has been decided to impose speed limits on dilapidated sections of railway tracks. General Manager of Railways, W.A.D.S. Gunasinghe said the decision to impose speed limits was made with the safety of the public and property in mind. Several train derailments have been reported in recent days as a result of faults in the railway track system. The new train schedules will be announced soon. By Thameenah Razeek

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Writ application fixed for support
author: Author not found
Content: The Writ application, seeking an order disqualifying State Minister of Tourism Diana Gamage from holding office as a Parliamentarian, was fixed for support, with notice to all parties, on 28 November. This was when the application filed by Social activist Oshala Herath was taken before Court of Appeal Judges Sobhitha Rajakaruna and Dhammika Ganepola Friday (18). Attorneys-at-Law Hafeel Farisz with Nishika Fonseka, instructed by Attorney-at-Law Gayan Darshan, appearing on behalf of the petitioner, noted that the matter should be considered as one of extreme emergency as the decisions made by Gamage in her capacity as an MP are illegal. The Petitioner sought an order in the nature of a Writ of Quo Warranto, requiring Gamage to show by what authority she claims to hold office and continues to function as a Member of Parliament of Sri Lanka. Further, a mandate in the nature of a Writ of Quo Warranto declaring that the Gamage is disqualified to be an MP was also sought. It was also stated in the Petition that Gamage is a British citizen and had concealed the fact that she was a British citizen, while stating that she is also not a Sri Lankan citizen. Further, the petitioner noted that Gamage had on several occasions used her British Passport to apply for and obtain visas to visit Sri Lanka. The Petitioner also noted that Gamage had furnished forged Birth Certificates and an invalid National Identity Card to apply for a Sri Lankan Passport and that at the time of signing her nomination papers and the holding of the 2020 General Election and taking oaths as a Member of Parliament, she was not a citizen of Sri Lanka. It was thereby stated that Gamage continues to hold office as a Member of Parliament without being a citizen of Sri Lanka. By Faadhila Thassim

title: SLFP Budget vote decision on 24 November
author: Author not found
Content: The Sri Lanka Freedom Party (SLFP) will decide whether to vote in favour of or against the Budget 2023 at the Central Committee (CC) meeting on 24 November. General Secretary of the SLFP Dayasiri Jayasekara said, their CC meeting will be held with all present and then a final decision on whether or not to support the Budget will be made. Previously, the SLFP charged that Finance Minister Ranil Wickremesinghe’s budget 2023 speech was the same old grandiloquence that Sri Lankans had heard for decades, with no relief for the people or the economy. Jayasekara said, the biggest problem for 22 million Sri Lankans, who expected some breathing space from the budget 2023, in their unending struggle for survival, is how to endure further burdens, misery and sufferings for another full year until the end of 2023 as requested by Wickremesinghe. BY Thameenah Razeek

title: Ashoka seeks help
author: Author not found
Content: Wathukarage Ashoka Thilakaratna (33) lives in Pussathota Grama Niladhari Division of the Waligepola Pradeshiya Sabha, Rathnapura. When Ashoka was 7 years old, he was hit by a speeding motorcycle while on the way to school. He was thrown off the road and hit a rock, sustaining injuries around his eyes. He was treated by General Practitioners at the Government hospitals in Pallebedda and Rathnapura, but his condition had not been properly diagnosed. Specialist doctors at the General Hospital Colombo later found that the road accident had caused Ashoka to develop a nervous system disorder. “About six months after the incident, I awoke one morning to find that I had lost my eyesight completely. The doctors told me that I will probably never see again and advised me to take medication on a regular basis. They advised me to hold out hope that things will improve at some point in my life. I continued to take the medication, but I gradually became weaker and weaker, and I can no longer walk. However, the doctors say that if I stop taking the medication, the condition will worsen,” he said. Ashoka appeals that donors make financial contributions to his account at People’s Bank, Godakawela, with the name Wathukarage Ashoka Thilakaratna and Account Number 245-2001-2005-6034. Ashoka can be reached on mobile number 0774277975.

title: Body found in well
author: Author not found
Content: The body of a 32-year-old man was found yesterday (20) in an agrarian well near the Mootthanayinar Kovil in the Navali area in the Jaffna District , Manipay, Police said. Police added that the victim was identified as Navaratnam Suresh, a resident of Anaikkoddai area in Jaffna. Police believe that the victim may have fallen into the well while being under the influence of liquor. The body was taken to the Teaching Hospital, Jaffna and was handed over to relatives following a post-mortem, police added. By Naalir Jamaldeen

title: English education must be given priority – Premajayantha
author: Author not found
Content: Progress in technology necessitates learning English as an international language in addition to one’s mother tongue, Minister of Education Dr. Susil Premajayantha said. He said, if such a measure is not adopted, the class gap in the rapidly advancing society will widen, and the world of future jobs will be limited to only a certain group of people. Speaking further, he also said, endless struggles will ensue and will become a common occurrence. Dr. Premajayantha expressed these views at the inauguration of the training programme for trained consultants to train teachers at the National Institute of Education to commence the use of the English language for Grade One students from March 2023. “About 450 consultants have been selected covering the whole island following  residential training, the teachers who teach the First Graders in all schools will be trained by the consultants”, he said. Further, the Minister said that although free education was provided in Sri Lanka and English education was provided, the main problem was that there was no systematic development in this regard. “Today, even countries that are similar to Sri Lanka in terms of Gross Domestic Product (GDP) have progressed in terms of education”, he claimed. With the long-term systematic development, countries like Finland have gone further and maintained a good student-teacher-parent support, having full faith in the teacher, and maintaining a positive education that measures skills in the continuous assessment system with less exam burden, Dr. Premajayantha said. He said, the dependence of every profession is based upon updating. Accordingly, the Minister said, when students come to the 5th Grade, they will be trained to communicate in English without any fear in society Focus should be on giving priority to communication by discarding unnecessary phrases, pronunciation, rules and ideologies, he said. Dr. Premajayantha further said that from the first term of 2023, the programme to use the English language based on practical activities will be implemented. The programme was chaired by the Minister of Education and the Additional Secretary of the Ministry of Education H. U. Premathilaka, Maharagama National Institute of Education Director General Sunil Jayantha Navaratne, English and Foreign Language Unit Education Director Nimali Anusha Pathirana and other ministry officials were also present. (AK)

title: Prasanna likens ‘Aragalayites’ to Prabhakaran
author: Author not found
Content: Those who were involved in the ‘Aragalaya’ are similar to ‘Prabhakaran,’ as the persons who could not obtain power democratically misused the ‘Aragalaya’ to gain power, Chief Government Whip, Minister Prasanna Ranatunga alleged. While saying that “system change” must be done democratically, Ranatunga said, the Aragalayites attempted to change the system through murder and arson. Speaking in Parliament during the second reading debate of Budget 2023 on 19 November, Ranatunga added that some Opposition members are attempting to blame the Government for the country’s insolvency, and that the focus should be on getting the country out of the crisis rather than finger-pointing. “We are prepared to resign from ministerial positions if we are asked to do so today. However, someone must accept responsibility, and because no one has accepted the challenges, we are working toward success while being chastised by citizens,” he said. By Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: COPE, COPA, COPF members appointed
author: Author not found
Content: Speaker Mahinda Yapa Abeywardena informed Parliament that six MPs have been nominated by the Selection Committee to serve in the Committee on Public Accounts (COPA), Committee on Public Enterprises (COPE) and Committee on Public Finance (COPF). Accordingly, MP Prasanna Ranaweera and MP Velu Kumar were appointed to COPA while MP Dayasiri Jayasekara and MP Sudarshana Denipitiya were appointed to COPE, the Speaker informed on 19 November. MP Nalaka Godahewa and MP U.K. Sumith Udukumbura were appointed to COPF. (AK)

title: Basil to return on Sunday
author: Author not found
Content: Former Finance Minister Basil Rajapaksa is scheduled to return to Sri Lanka on Sunday (20), SLPP General Secretary MP Sagara Kariyawasam confirmed.  Rajapaksa is reported to have left America on the night of 17 November. Kariyawasam, speaking to Ceylon Today, said the mobilisation of the SLPP, which has already started, will be expedited with the arrival of the Rajapaksa. Kariyawasam added the future political activities of the party will also be discussed with him. BY Tharaka Samman

title: Elephant census planned for next year
author: Author not found
Content: Plans are afoot, by the Agriculture and Wildlife Ministry, to conduct a new countrywide census on elephants next year. According to Parliament sources, the decision was taken at the first Ministerial Consultative Committee meeting on Wildlife and Forest Resources Conservation held at the Parliament Complex recently. It has been decided to conduct a complete census of elephants as a part of a long-term programme to reduce the human-elephant conflict.  The last such census in Sri Lanka was conducted in 2011. The MPs who were present at the meeting pointed out that the human elephant conflict was turning worse and serious with each passing day. There had been incidents of human elephant conflict in various areas, including the Anuradhapura, Polonnaruwa, Ratnapura and Ampara Districts. It was revealed at the meeting that there were 16 main elephant corridors in the country and most of them have currently been blocked.  As a result of that, elephants arriving in villages has increased. The obstacles blocking the elephant corridors would be removed as one of the measures to reduce incidents of conflict between elephants and humans. A number of reasons, including the reduction of elephant habitats and the significant increase in elephant population, have led to the human-elephant conflict. Minister of Agriculture and Minister of Wildlife and Forest Resources Conservation Mahinda Amaraweera, Deputy Speaker Ajith Rajapaksha, Leader of the Opposition Sajith Premadasa, State Ministers Siripala Gamlath, Shantha Bandara, Thenuka Vidanagamage, Sivanesathurai Chandrakanthan, Diana Gamage, Rohana Dissanayake, Chamara Sampath Dasanayake, Vijitha Berugoda, Mohan Priyadarshana de Silva, a group of  MPs including Kins Nelson, Kapila Athukorala, Kumarasiri Ratnayake, and government officials were also present at this meeting. By Gagani Weerakoon and Aloka Kasturiarachchi
