title: No plans to restructure domestic debt – Govt
author: Author not found
Content: Putting speculations on plans to restructure domestic debt to rest, State Minister of Finance Shehan Semasinghe, yesterday (17) said the Government has no plans to restructure domestic debt. Semasinghe took to Twitter and emphasised that the Government has not taken any decision to restructure domestic debt as negotiations of treatments on external debt are still being discussed with external bilateral and commercial creditors. He said the Government has no intention to impose any treatment on domestic debt which will have adverse impact on the domestic banking sector, insurance sector and superannuation funds. “Government has not taken any decision to restructure domestic debt as negotiations of treatments on external debt are still ongoing with external bilateral and commercial creditors,” Minister Semasinghe said in the tweet. “Sri Lanka Government has no intention to impose any treatment on domestic debt which will have adverse impact on domestic banking sector, insurance sector and superannuation funds. “There is no basis for recent speculation announced on restructuring domestic debt,” he added. By Gagani Weerakoon

title: Indian Oil’s women executives visit Sri Lanka
author: Author not found
Content: ‘Aarohi’ (which means to ascend) initiative of Indian Oil Corporation Limited (IOCL) aims at all-round development, especially leadership qualities of an identified group of women at the middle management level. It is a pioneering effort and Indian Oil’s Commitment to develop unique strengths in middle management level especially to enhance the leadership quality among promising women leaders, so that they can ascend into significant leadership roles & contribute to the organisation through performance excellence. This year the batch of Aarohi 4.0 consisting of 14 Women Officials from IOCL visited Sri Lanka with the purpose of understanding the operations of Lanka IOC and interacting with entire team of LIOC which has been relentlessly pursuing the objective of meeting the energy needs of the beautiful Island nation at all times. During their 5 day-visit, the group travelled across the length and breadth of the country including visit to Trincomalee Terminal facilities. At Trincomalee terminal, the group visited various facilities including Lower & Upper Tanks Farms, Oil Jetty, Lube Blending & Grease Manufacturing Plant which also involved fruitful interactions with terminal employees of LIOC with visitors displaying plenty of inquisitiveness & enthusiasm. Details on some of the strategic steps & way forward towards business excellence were also apprised to the group. An Industrial visit was organized at Army School of Logistics (ASL), Clappenburg, Trincomalee with the kind assistance of Sri Lankan Army, wherein the participants were briefed on the various modalities and importance of Logistics in the smooth functioning of National Safety and Security. The Aarohi team also visited LIOC’s Head office at Colombo and had a lively interaction with all HO employees. LIOC employees also gained valuable insight into various new initiatives being undertaken by Indian Oil Corporation in India specially pertaining to female employees. The visitors were highly appreciative of the significant presence of female workforce in LIOC Head Office. The vibrant interaction has opened new channel of communication between IOCL and LIOC employees which is likely to be beneficial for both the organisations with better exchange of ideas and best practices. The visiting group also had the pleasure of meeting His Excellency Gopal Baglay, the High Commissioner of India to Sri Lanka who warmly welcomed the entire group and shared with them the several positive strategic initiatives that Government of India has undertaken and intends to undertake with an aim to strengthen the socio-political relationship between India & Sri Lanka. His Excellency also appreciated the IOCL’s unique initiative to organise a visit of the women officials to Sri Lanka which is a sign of further strengthening the mutual admiration between the two countries. Aarohi team was enthralled by the fascinating landscapes unfolding the mesmerizing natural beauty of the Island nation as they visited Tooth Relic temple, Sigiriya Rock, Gangaramaya temple, Lotus tower, Pinnawala Elephant Orphanage apart from several other prominent locations enroute their travel destinations. The entire team was overwhelmed with their wonderful experience at Sri Lanka contrary to the apprehensions and expressed their desire to plan another visit along with their family and friends at the earliest opportunity.

title: Speaker announces SC determination
author: Author not found
Content: Speaker Mahinda Yapa Abeywardena informed Parliament yesterday (17) that the Supreme Court has determined that the Inland Revenue (Amendment) Bill as a whole is not inconsistent with the provisions of the Constitution. He was conveying the determination of the Supreme Court on the petition challenging the Inland Revenue (Amendment) Bill. “On an overall consideration of the provisions of the Bill, the Supreme Court held that subject to the amendments, as proposed by the Attorney-General, being moved at the Committee Stage of the Bill in Parliament, the Bill as a whole is not inconsistent with the provisions of the Constitution. I order that the Determination of the Supreme Court be printed in the Official Report of today’s (17), proceedings of the House,” the Speaker announced. BY Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: Cabinet to be briefed on SL women being trafficked into ME
author: Author not found
Content: Minister of Justice, Prison Affairs and Constitutional Reforms Dr. Wijeyadasa Rajapakshe said trafficking of Sri Lankan women to the Middle East will be brought to the notice of the Cabinet. Rajapakshe was responding to concerns that were raised in Parliament yesterday (17) by SJB MPs Hector Appuhamy and Kavinda Jayawardena. Jayawardena stressed that 12 women have been taken to Abu Dhabi and later to Oman to hold a public auction at a festival. Media reports stated that these women were sold at the auction, he said. “It can be a mother or a sister in our country. Government’s attention must be paid to the issue and a programme should be implemented in this regard to prevent such unfortunate incidents. MP Appuhamy said, “No information was reported in relations to the girls who were taken to Oman on tourist visas. This is a serious problem. We keep hearing about such incidents where individuals are being taken to Dubai and other foreign countries on tourist visa.” In response Minister Rajapakshe said, they had been receiving information on certain employment agents who are engaged in trafficking of Sri Lankan women. Accordingly, the matter will be referred to the relevant ministries and to the Cabinet, he said. BY Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: Dayasiri claims DLB to spend Rs 3,700 per plate at event
author: Author not found
Content: SLFP General Secretary, MP Dayasiri Jayasekara, requested an investigation into the monies spent on a ‘Sanwardana Abhiman’ event scheduled for 19 November by the Development Lotteries Board (DLB). According to Jayasekara, the DLB is planning to spend Rs 3,700 for a plate of food at the event. He also claimed that the National Lotteries Board (NLB) lost Rs 600 million because the ‘Govisetha’ lottery was not printed on 57 occasions. Speaking in Parliament yesterday (17), Jayasekara requested State Minister of Finance Ranjith Siyambalapitiya look into the matter. Responding to these revelations, State Minister Siyanbalapitiya said he will launch an investigation and take the necessary steps. BY Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: CDB here to discuss debt-related issues
author: Author not found
Content: A delegation from the China Development Bank (CDB), a major financial supporter of Sri Lanka’s development, is currently in the country to hold talks with the Government on the debt-related issues. Yesterday (17) they met State Minister of Finance Shehan Semasinghe and discussed debt-related issues, sources said. According to the Chinese Embassy the communication with the CDB has been there since April this year. Over the crucial financial status of the country, the International Monetary Fund had recommended that Sri Lanka should talk to its international creditors to restructure the loans they had given Sri Lanka, in order to obtain a nearly three billion USD bailout for the country. China is one among the countries that has been pushed to restructure its loan facility to Sri Lanka and President Ranil Wickremesinghe has put in efforts to hold talks with India and China to rescue Sri Lanka from the current  crisis. The CDB’s last loan to Sri Lanka was USD 500 million in 2021 and prior to that USD 1.4 billion. Minister Semasinghe was not available when an effort was made to inquire about the total amount of loans obtained from the CDB.  On 10 November, Semasinghe tweeted that he had a detailed discussion at the World Bank Budget support and Development Policy Operation (DPO) Preparatory Mission kick-off meeting between the government officials and the members of the World Bank. By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: Sajith challenges Govt to hold polls
author: Author not found
Content: While noting that there are no constitutional obstacles to hold an election, Opposition Leader Sajith Premadasa stressed that the only barrier is the Government’s fear of the election results. He said taking the Government to the polls is like bathing a rabies-infected dog. Premadasa raised concerns in Parliament yesterday (17), challenging the Government to hold an election if they have a ‘spine’. He also outlined the Articles of the Constitution concerning holding an election and requested that the country should not be misled about the dissolution of Parliament, as the Premier stated on 16 November that it is not possible to hold a general election in the middle of the term under the Sri Lankan Constitution. According to Premadasa, the President has the authority to dissolve Parliament on a motion from the Legislature. He claimed that the Prime Minister is misleading the citizenry by claiming that Parliament cannot be dissolved in the middle of a term under the Sri Lanka Constitution. In response to Premadasa, Prime Minister Dinesh Gunawardena said, “I believe the matter mentioned by the Leader of the Opposition is an answer based on ambiguous facts. I responded to Dr. Harsha de Silva, the Opposition’s first speaker. In his parliamentary speech, he mentioned a provision in the American Constitution. I responded to his statement by saying that such a possibility is not provided for in Sri Lanka’s Constitution,” he said. BY Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: Elephant census planned for next year
author: Author not found
Content: Plans are afoot, by the Agriculture and Wildlife Ministry, to conduct a new countrywide census on elephants next year. According to Parliament sources, the decision was taken at the first Ministerial Consultative Committee meeting on Wildlife and Forest Resources Conservation held at the Parliament Complex recently. It has been decided to conduct a complete census of elephants as a part of a long-term programme to reduce the human-elephant conflict.  The last such census in Sri Lanka was conducted in 2011. The MPs who were present at the meeting pointed out that the human elephant conflict was turning worse and serious with each passing day. There had been incidents of human elephant conflict in various areas, including the Anuradhapura, Polonnaruwa, Ratnapura and Ampara Districts. It was revealed at the meeting that there were 16 main elephant corridors in the country and most of them have currently been blocked.  As a result of that, elephants arriving in villages has increased. The obstacles blocking the elephant corridors would be removed as one of the measures to reduce incidents of conflict between elephants and humans. A number of reasons, including the reduction of elephant habitats and the significant increase in elephant population, have led to the human-elephant conflict. Minister of Agriculture and Minister of Wildlife and Forest Resources Conservation Mahinda Amaraweera, Deputy Speaker Ajith Rajapaksha, Leader of the Opposition Sajith Premadasa, State Ministers Siripala Gamlath, Shantha Bandara, Thenuka Vidanagamage, Sivanesathurai Chandrakanthan, Diana Gamage, Rohana Dissanayake, Chamara Sampath Dasanayake, Vijitha Berugoda, Mohan Priyadarshana de Silva, a group of  MPs including Kins Nelson, Kapila Athukorala, Kumarasiri Ratnayake, and government officials were also present at this meeting. By Gagani Weerakoon and Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: Wellawatta-Fort lower track closed for repairs till Monday
author: Author not found
Content: The Coastal Railway’s lower track between Wellawatta and Colombo Fort will be closed till Monday (21), Deputy General Manager of Railways Gamini Seneviratne said. Meanwhile, the Sri Lanka Railway Station Masters’ Union (SLSMU) said, there will be more train delays and cancellations in the coming days. At least ten train services on the coastal line were cancelled yesterday (17), due to repairs on a broken train bridge and the temporary closure of the line between Wellawatta and Colombo Fort. Train services on the coastal line between Slave Island and Kollupitiya were delayed yesterday due to the repairs. Trains on dual tracks will use the single track between Fort and Wellawatte stations and trains travelling from the coastal line to the main line and the Puttalam line may be delayed. Meanwhile, a Kandy-Colombo Express train derailed yesterday morning between Peradeniya and Pilimatalawa Stations, bringing the total number of train derailments this year to 44. The train derailed at 4:47 a.m., disrupting train services on that line, the SLSMU said. The last compartment of the express train had some wheels off the track. Trains between Badulla and Colombo have also been delayed as a result. BY Thameenah Razeek

title: Court extends Diana’s overseas travel ban
author: Author not found
Content: Colombo Chief Magistrate Nandana Amerasinghe yesterday extended the foreign travel ban issued on State Minister of Tourism Diana Gamage until 15 December. The State Minister’s overseas travels were initially barred by the Colombo Chief Magistrate on 11 November over a complaint challenging the veracity of her identity documents including the birth certificate, the NIC and the passport. The complaint had been filed by a social activist. Speaking on behalf of the State Minister, President’s Counsel Sarath Jayamanne said an outside party that is not directly involved in the proceedings of the case had obtained the overseas travel ban against his client. Stating that an outside party cannot obtain such orders, the PC requested the Court to lift the ban imposed on his client. However, President’s Counsel Rienzie Arsekularatne, who appeared on behalf of the plaintiff and the lawyers representing the SJB General Secretary, raised objections to this request. The Chief Magistrate, while informing that a decision on the request would be delivered at the next hearing, extended the foreign travel ban on the State Minister until then. Previously, Colombo Chief Magistrate Amarasinghe had issued notice to the CID asking to submit a report on the investigations into the matter. Notice was issued after taking into account the submissions filed through a motion by a group of lawyers. They had urged the Court to inquire from CID whether State Minister Gamage has dual citizenship in the UK and Sri Lanka and the progress of investigations so far. BY Hansi Nanayakkara

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Wasantha Mudalige ordered to be remanded
author: Author not found
Content: Colombo Additional Magistrate T.N.L. Mahawatta yesterday (17) remanded IUSF Convener Wasantha Mudalige and member Ven. Galweva Siridhamma Thera till such time instructions are received from Attorney General Sanjay Rajaratnam. The duo were detained by the TID at their Tangalle Old Prison premises, under the Provisions contained in the PTI, for close to three months before being produced in Court following a decree to that effect from the Supreme Court. The two suspects were arrested by the Fort Police last August in connection with the anti-Government Aragalaya (Protest) Movement that was staged at Galle Face Green. By Hansi Nanayakkara

title: S African President drops in after G20 Summit
author: Author not found
Content: South African President Cyril Ramaphosa arrived in Sri Lanka for a short visit on 16 November after attending the G20 Summit. He met President Ranil Wickremesinghe at the Katunayake Air Force Base for discussions on bilateral issues. The discussions focused on further strengthening bilateral relationships aiming at economic cooperation and investment, expanding tourism in Sri Lanka and receiving South African assistance, guidance and counselling in setting up a credible truth-seeking mechanism to achieve a lasting reconciliation among communities. The two State leaders exchanged mementos.  Minister of Foreign Affairs Ali Sabry, President’s Secretary Saman Ekanayake, Senior Adviser to the President on National Security and Chief of Staff to the President Sagala Ratnayake and senior officials from both countries were present during this occasion.

title: If Speaker consents MPs’ assets could be published – Kiriella
author: Author not found
Content: If Speaker Mahinda Yapa Abeywardena gives his consent, the assets and properties of all MPs could be published, Chief Opposition Whip, SJB MP Lakshman Kiriella told Parliament yesterday (17). Participating in the Second Reading debate on Budget 2023, Kiriella said that his Party demands that assets of all MPs should be declared. “My colleague Eran Wickremaratne too, raised this issue in the House during this debate on the other day. We demand that all MPs should declare their assets. The MPs themselves must do so voluntarily even if the Speaker fails to give the ruling to that effect. Now, many MPs have submitted their assets declarations to the Speaker. The purpose of this submission is not to keep the Speaker informed. The Speaker could publish these declarations. So far that has not been done,” he said. The Transparency International Sri Lanka (TISL) called all MPs and asked them to send their asset declarations.  “Sadly only 15 out of 225 MPs had done so. There is no use in pointing fingers at that and this MP for corruption while the MPs are reluctant to declare the assets they have. We must set an example by displaying our asset declarations in a place where the public could see them. If the Speaker agrees we could upload our asset declarations on Parliament web site,” Kiriella said.

title: Those who obtained loans can negotiate with banks to get relief – CBSL Governor
author: Author not found
Content: Governor of the Central Bank of Sri Lanka Dr. P. Nandalal Weerasinghe stated in Parliament that customers who have been inconvenienced due to the increase in the interest rates, charged for the loans obtained under variable interest rates in the past, are able to get relief by negotiating with the bank. The Governor stated this when MPs inquired about the aforementioned at the Ministerial Consultative Committee on Finance, Economic Stabilisation and National Policies held on Wednesday (16), in Parliament chaired by State Ministers of Finance  Ranjith Siyambalapitiya and Shehan Semasinghe. The Members of Parliament pointed out that due to the increase in interest rates, the entire income of some creditors has to be paid for loan installments.  The CBSL Governor said that customers can pay only the relevant interest for a grace period in consultation with the bank. He added that instructions have been given to the banks in this regard. Also, the CBSL Governor said that the average inflation, which was at a value of 70 per cent two months ago, has now decreased to 66 per cent and the food inflation which was at 95 per cent  has decreased to 85 per cent. He further stated, with the existing fiscal policies, this figure is expected to reach 4-5 per cent by the end of next year. Furthermore, according to the conditions of the International Monetary Fund, a new act has been drafted to make the Central Bank an independent institution and the necessary work is being done, the CBSL Governor added. Furthermore, the committee drew attention to the difficulty in exchanging dollars for rupees by banks. State Ministers of Finance Ranjith Siyambalapitiya asked the CBSL Governor about the issue to which the Governor responded saying that the Central Bank has not given any advice that would cause such delays. Semasinghe also said, according to a report of the Department of Public Enterprises, 22 out of 126 institutions have not submitted their annual reports for more than five years and some institutions have delayed the submission of annual reports for about seven years. Accordingly, the State Minister said, since he will be working with the International Monetary Fund in the future, he instructed the heads of the institutions to submit the annual reports within the stipulated time. Opposition Leader Sajith Premadasa, Members of the Committee MPs Jagath Kumara Sumithraarachchi, Sahan Pradeep Withana and Parliamentarians Secretary to the Treasury/Ministry of Finance, Economic Stabilization and National Policies K. M. Mahinda Siriwardana, officials representing the Ministry and institutions affiliated to it were present at the Committee meeting.

title: Ten busted with heroin in A’pura
author: Author not found
Content: The Anuradhapura CID arrested ten people for drug offences. A raid was conducted in Anuradhapura on 16 November based on information received by the CID. As a result, four suspects were arrested with over 14g of heroin in a house in Pubudupura. Police said one suspect fled the scene during the raid. The arrested suspects are between the ages of 26 and 51 and are residents of Pubudupura and Anuradhapura. However, when the suspects were brought to the Police Station, six relatives of the suspects had pelted stones at the Police and one officer was admitted to the Anuradhapura Hospital for injuries. These individuals were arrested for obstructing Police duties, being members of an illegal assembly and for injuring a Police officer. The arrested relatives are between the ages of 23 and 54. The suspects were scheduled to be produced before the Anuradhapura Magistrate’s Court yesterday (17). Anuradhapura CID is conducting further investigations. BY Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: GMOA says some Budget proposals ‘problematic’
author: Author not found
Content: The Government Medical Officers’ Association (GMOA) said although the 2023 Budget included many proposals that will have a positive impact on Sri Lanka’s free healthcare service and free education, their in-depth studies revealed that some proposals are problematic and could have an overall negative impact on the free healthcare and higher education. Secretary of the GMOA, Dr. Haritha Aluthge noted yesterday (16) that it was more important to be able to practically-implement proposals rather than announcing policies and proposals that cannot be executed. He said that over Rs 321 billion had been allocated to the State health sector through this year’s Budget, so it is essentials the funds are used to solve issues the health service is currently facing – a priority being given to resolving the acute shortage of medicines. “It is the responsibility of the authorities to use the funds efficiently and effectively by fixing the inefficiency and complications, facing the procurement process and eliminating fraud and corruption in the pharmaceutical sector. He noted that the proposal to set up a new medical faculty under Uva Wellassa University in addition to the existing State medical faculties is a positive suggestion. “Thereby it was proposed that the Provincial General Hospital, Badulla as well as General Hospital Polonnaruwa should be upgrade to Teaching Hospitals to raise the quality of healthcare in this country”. The proposal to re-implement ‘paid wards’ in State hospitals have raised questions among the public as even at the moment the concept has been implemented; adhering to certain limitations at National Hospital, Colombo. However, it is highly doubtful as to whether efforts are underway to undermine Sri Lanka’s free health service by this specific proposal as paid wards are being expanded even in base hospitals. Dr. Aluthge observed. Speculations are rife as to whether this is a furtive attempt to privatise the free healthcare system, he said. Dr. Aluthge said the GMOA is of the view that the current economic crisis and food crisis have increased the level of malnutrition among vulnerable population groups. “The Budget for 2023 has identified this situation and in an attempt to address it, an allocation of Rs 500 million was portioned out to further strengthen existing nutritional supplement programmes. However, it would be most effective if those programmes were implemented targeting vulnerable population groups and areas they live in”. BY Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: President Hikes Cesses on Several Items
author: Author not found
Content: President and Finance Minister Ranil Wickremesinghe has hiked the cess applicable for a number of items ranging from a minimum of Rs 2.50 a kilo in respect of cement imports to a maximum of Rs 22,400 or 15 per cent per unit,  whichever is more, in respect of the import of air-conditioners to protect Sri Lanka’s Spartan foreign reserves. The items covered in this regard also include shrimps, prawns, yoghurt, butter, cheese, curd, cut flower, onion, lettuce, carrot, cucumber, pea, gherkin, capsicum, asparagus, spinach, olives, potato, sweet corn, cigarettes lighters, ballpoint pens, broom, toothbrush, spectacle, used bicycles, electric lamps, generator, washing machine, door bells, tables, kitchen and other household items, glassware, ceramic ware, umbrellas, artificial flowers, hats, tyres, candles, soaps, shaving foam, soft drinks, soups, ice cream, sauces, tea, fruit juices, oranges, cherries, strawberries, jams, and a host of other import items. The enhanced cesses were applicable from 15 November. Wickremesinghe in this respect issued gazette number 2306/15 dated 14 November. By Paneetha Ameresekere

title: Total Rs 14.51M imposed as fines on 61 Jaffna traders
author: Author not found
Content: A total of Rs 14.51 million in fines was imposed by Court on 61 traders in the Jaffna District, the officer in charge of Jaffna District Consumer Affairs Authority, S. Vijitharan, said yesterday (17). The traders had been charged with failure to display the price tags on the products or commodities, selling goods above the stipulated price, changing the price label on the goods to cheat the people and selling bread below the recommended weight, according to Vijitharan. The Jaffna District CAA officials have been on the alert to ensure that the goods are sold at reasonable prices, as recommended by the Government and have planned to conduct more raids on business establishments in the coming days, Vijitharan added. By Naalir Jamaldeen

title: Import duties hiked to protect foreign reserves
author: Author not found
Content: President and Finance Minister Ranil Wickremesinghe raised customs import duties on a range of items to protect the country’s sparse foreign reserves, starting from a minimum of 15 per cent or Rs 100 for a pair of spectacle frames, to a maximum of Rs 400,000 or 15 per cent, whichever is more in respect of the import of per unit used chassis with wheels. Among some of the other imports covered under this hike are yoghurt,  butter, cheese, guitar strings, spectacle cases, used bicycles, “cut” portions of motor-vehicles, onions, pears, rice, oats, pastas, potatoes, eggs cashew nuts, cherries, tomato juice, fruit juice,  soft drinks, tobacco, cigarettes and motor-vehicle lubricants. The above import duties were effective from Tuesday (15). Wickremesinghe, in this regard has issued Gazette No. 2306/14 dated 14 November. BY Paneetha Ameresekere

title: Wijeyadasa vows to promote communal harmony
author: Author not found
Content: Certain politicians have prompted controversies between different communities, Minister of Justice, Prison Affairs and Constitutional Reforms, Dr. Wijeyadasa Rajapakshe said. Rajapakshe said this has resulted in a gap between communities and has interfered with the unity within the country, adding thereby that measures should be taken to avoid such occurrences in the future.  He said, this following a meeting with Panchalingam Kandiah from the Canadian Tamil Congress, where the Congress handed over a letter to the Minister. While stating that several measures to address the issues of the people in the North have been taken, he added that further steps will also be taken to complete the operations of the Office on Missing Persons by the end of 2023 December. Rajapakshe also pledged to enhance the peace and reconciliation process, adding that Sri Lankans will be treated in an equal and in discriminatory manner while accommodating all Diaspora to have a platform to initiate and develop their business activities in any preferred area. By Faadhila Thassim

title: Mid-day meal for students from next year
author: Author not found
Content: Education Minister Susil Premajayantha said the national programme to provide a mid-day meal for schoolchildren will begin in January and will cover all schools in the country. Previously, the Minister admitted in Parliament that local schoolchildren were not getting enough food, and that the Government had increased funding for the mid-day meal programme. “With this progress, the national programme will be launched in January, covering all educational zones in the country focusing on four goals. The main goals will be providing mid-day meals to students, counselling, curbing student indiscipline, vocational training and guidance,” he said. He raised these concerns yesterday at an event held at Prince College in Kotahena. The pilot project was launched where dry rations were distributed. He said, education transformation will go beyond the new education reforms to reduce the burden of examinations and managing existing resources and will begin in January next year. Accordingly, the school mid-day meal programme, counselling, curbing indiscipline among students and the vocational training guidance programmes were implemented. BY Thameenah Razeek

title: Hirunika abducting youth case on 30 Jan
author: Author not found
Content: Colombo High Court Judge, Amal Ranaraja yesterday ordered the hearing of testimony in the case filed against Ex-MP Hirunika Premachandra to be taken up on 30 January next year. The former SJB MP has been accused of abducting a youth, detaining him against his wishes and threatening him. Judge Ranaraja ordered witnesses to be present in Court on the said date to testify. Defence Counsel Ashan Fernando stated that as the defence needs sufficient time to analyse the two video evidences submitted by the prosecution, trial proceedings should be deferred. DSG Janaka Bandara informed the Judge that already trial proceedings have been delayed for various reasons since 2016. Taking submissions into consideration, the Court stated that the case will be heard for the last time on 30 January, 2023 and instructed all parties to be present in Court on that date. The Attorney General  indicted Premachandra and seven of her aides before the High Court on charges of kidnapping a youth who was employed at a textile shop in the Dematagoda area on 21 December and  intimidating him. By Hansi Nanayakkara

title: Muthu Raja to stay at Dehiwala Zoo
author: Author not found
Content: The decision to return Muthu Raja Elephant from Thailand to its country of origin as it was reported to have been abused and neglected at the Kande Viharaya Temple, Aluthgama has been overturned by the Ministry of Wildlife and Forest Resources Conservation. The elephant was a donation from Thailand to former President Chandrika Bandaranaike Kumaratunga and was later donated to the Kande Viharaya Temple, Aluthgama.  Due to the mistreatment of the elephant at the temple, Thailand ambassador in Sri Lanka entrusted the elephant to the National Zoological Gardens, Dehiwala. Although the elephant was to be flown back to Thailand yesterday (16), Minister of Wildlife and Forest Resources Conservation, Mahinda Amaraweera instructed the Secretary to the Ministry Chandra Herath to keep the elephant back. The Department of National Zoological Gardens agreed to keep the elephant in the Dehiwala Zoo stating that the elephant was presently in good condition and will be taken care of.

title: DMT launches trial licence programme
author: Author not found
Content: Department of Motor Transport (DMT) Commissioner General Nishantha Anuruddha said a pilot project to provide driving licences for light vehicles to people with total hearing impairment began yesterday (16). He claimed that the Cabinet recently approved a request made by the Sri Lanka Central Federation of the Deaf for about 40 years, and the first programme was launched in the Gampaha District. If the programme is successful, nearly 300,000 members of the Sri Lanka Central Federation of the Deaf across the island will be able to obtain driver’s licences in the future. He also stated that the DMT has begun a programme to provide driver’s licences to all citizens of the country, which will be implemented throughout the island in the future. BY Mithun Jayawardena

title: IGP offers unconditional apology
author: Author not found
Content: The IGP yesterday (16) offered an unconditional apology before the Supreme Court for the failure to pay the salary arrears of former Sub-Inspector Sugath Mendis, as per the interim order issued by the Court. Mendis was arrested and produced in the Gampaha Magistrate’s Court on purported allegations that he falsely introduced certain weapons and fabricated false evidence to frame a false case against and arrest former Deputy Inspector General of Police Vass Gunawardena. In a subsequent Fundamental Rights Petition filed on behalf of Mendis by Attorney-at-Law Lilanthi De Silva on 22 March, it was noted that Mendis was interdicted by way of a letter without pay, adding that no preliminary investigation was conducted prior to the purported letter of interdiction. The Petitioner said, he has not yet been given reasons despite the continuous prejudicial treatment unduly meted out to him contrary to the law and that the infringement of his fundamental rights is continuous and increasingly detrimental. The Petitioner also sought an interim order directing the respondents to take immediate steps to effect payment of the Petitioner’s salary and entitlements until the hearing and final determination of the application. Thereby, when the case was taken up before Justices Priyantha Jayawardena, Mahinda Samayawardana, and S. Thurairaja on 18 May, Court issued an interim order for the payment of salary to Mendis since the day the Petition was filed. However, due to the failure to comply with the interim order, a Motion was filed stating that the respondents, including the IGP had failed to comply with the interim order and have thereby committed Contempt of Court. Accordingly, the Court issued notice on the IGP and four others to appear in Court yesterday (16) to show cause for the failure to follow the interim order. Additional Solicitor General Nerin Pulle and Additional Solicitor General Chethiya Gunasekera appearing on behalf of the IGP and four others apologised to Court and said the failure was unintentional and that steps will be taken to provide the requisite relief to Mendis. The Supreme Court bench comprising Justices Priyantha Jayawardena, Mahinda Samayawardana, and S. Thurairaja further instructed the Attorney General to look into the matter and see whether full relief can be granted by the next date. Hearing of the case is to resume on 12 December. By Faadhila Thassim

title: UK to send SL asylum seekers to Rwanda
author: Author not found
Content: Three Sri Lankan asylum seekers stranded on Diego Garcia, a remote island in the British Indian Ocean Territory, or BIOT, are expected to be transported to Rwanda for medical treatment, the British Foreign Office told The New Humanitarian. More than 200 Sri Lankan asylum seekers, mostly ethnic Tamils claiming to have faced persecution by the Sri Lankan Government, arrived on Diego Garcia in five successive boats starting in October 2021. Dozens have since returned to Sri Lanka on flights arranged by BIOT authorities, while others have returned to their boats and sailed farther across the Indian Ocean to Réunion Island, the French overseas department. Confirming news of the medical move in an emailed response to The New Humanitarian, the UK Foreign, Commonwealth and Development Office said the “migrants” would be returned to BIOT after their treatment was complete. The medical transfers are adding to fears that British authorities could seek to deport the Sri Lankan asylum seekers to Rwanda under an offshore processing deal then-Prime Minister Boris Johnson concluded with the Rwandan Government in April. title: Manhunt on for Poonthottam escapees
author: Author not found
Content: Vavuniya Police said a search operation has been launched to apprehend inmates who escaped on November 15 while being rehabilitated at the Vavuniya Poonthottam Rehabilitation Centre. Vavuniya Police and the Army were conducting joint searches since the evening of 15 November, but have yet to locate the suspects. People addicted to various types of drugs in the Northern Province are being rehabilitated at the Poonthottam rehabilitation centre under the supervision of the Army in accordance with court orders. However, five suspects escaped on 15 November, during the time allotted for sports training. The suspects are drug addicts between the ages of 22 and 32 who live in the Northern Province.  Vavuniya Police are on a manhunt to find them. BY Shashi Kumar – Mullaitivu

title: Mannar Bishop calls on President
author: Author not found
Content: Bishop of Mannar, Reverend Dr. Fidelis Lionel Emmanuel Fernando and several others met President Ranil Wickremesinghe at the Presidential Secretariat yesterday (16). The President was briefed on several issues in Mannar including land issues. The President promised prompt solutions. Discussions also focussed on providing the required facilities for pilgrims visiting the Madu Shrine. Rev. Fr. Joyce Peppi Sosai Santia, Rev. Fr. Antony Sosai, and several others including MP – (Dr.) Kavinda Jayawardana participated in the meeting.

title: Islandwide raids to combat human trafficking
author: Author not found
Content: Public Security Minister, Tiran Alles, and Labour and Foreign Employment Minister, Manusha Nanayakkara, held a round of discussions yesterday (16) to implement a programme to carry out islandwide raids to combat human trafficking. Senior officials of the Immigration Department, Police Department and the Sri Lanka Bureau of Foreign Employment (SLBFE) took part in the discussion. An agreement was reached on the need to investigate individuals involved in human trafficking, to carry out raids throughout the island and take action against those involved in human trafficking, regardless of who they are.  It has also been decided to hold an officer-level progress review every two weeks regarding the progress of measures taken against those involved in human trafficking. Based on the information received by the SLBFE regarding Sri Lankans involved in human trafficking both domestically and abroad, raids are being carried out continuously but now these raids are to be fast tracked. Meanwhile, it has also been decided to implement a programme to educate the public about human trafficking. By Nabiya Vaffoor

title: Implement Singapore -SL FTA immediately – President
author: Author not found
Content: President Ranil Wickremesinghe instructed relevant officials to implement the Singapore-Sri Lanka Free Trade Agreement (FTA) immediately. He issued these instructions during a discussion held at the Presidential Secretariat yesterday (16). The existing problems in this regard were discussed at length and the President highlighted the need to provide prompt solutions. President’s Secretary Saman Ekanayake, Senior Economic Adviser to the President Dr. R.H.S. Samaratunga, Attorney General Sanjay Rajaratnam, Secretary to the Ministry of Trade, Commerce and Food Security S.T. Kodikara, and Heads of line institutions were present at this discussion.

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: IGP offers unconditional apology
author: Author not found
Content: The IGP yesterday (16) offered an unconditional apology before the Supreme Court for the failure to pay the salary arrears of former Sub-Inspector Sugath Mendis, as per the interim order issued by the Court. Mendis was arrested and produced in the Gampaha Magistrate’s Court on purported allegations that he falsely introduced certain weapons and fabricated false evidence to frame a false case against and arrest former Deputy Inspector General of Police Vass Gunawardena. In a subsequent Fundamental Rights Petition filed on behalf of Mendis by Attorney-at-Law Lilanthi De Silva on 22 March, it was noted that Mendis was interdicted by way of a letter without pay, adding that no preliminary investigation was conducted prior to the purported letter of interdiction. The Petitioner said, he has not yet been given reasons despite the continuous prejudicial treatment unduly meted out to him contrary to the law and that the infringement of his fundamental rights is continuous and increasingly detrimental. The Petitioner also sought an interim order directing the respondents to take immediate steps to effect payment of the Petitioner’s salary and entitlements until the hearing and final determination of the application. Thereby, when the case was taken up before Justices Priyantha Jayawardena, Mahinda Samayawardana, and S. Thurairaja on 18 May, Court issued an interim order for the payment of salary to Mendis since the day the Petition was filed. However, due to the failure to comply with the interim order, a Motion was filed stating that the respondents, including the IGP had failed to comply with the interim order and have thereby committed Contempt of Court. Accordingly, the Court issued notice on the IGP and four others to appear in Court yesterday (16) to show cause for the failure to follow the interim order. Additional Solicitor General Nerin Pulle and Additional Solicitor General Chethiya Gunasekera appearing on behalf of the IGP and four others apologised to Court and said the failure was unintentional and that steps will be taken to provide the requisite relief to Mendis. The Supreme Court bench comprising Justices Priyantha Jayawardena, Mahinda Samayawardana, and S. Thurairaja further instructed the Attorney General to look into the matter and see whether full relief can be granted by the next date. Hearing of the case is to resume on 12 December. By Faadhila Thassim

title: UK to send SL asylum seekers to Rwanda
author: Author not found
Content: Three Sri Lankan asylum seekers stranded on Diego Garcia, a remote island in the British Indian Ocean Territory, or BIOT, are expected to be transported to Rwanda for medical treatment, the British Foreign Office told The New Humanitarian. More than 200 Sri Lankan asylum seekers, mostly ethnic Tamils claiming to have faced persecution by the Sri Lankan Government, arrived on Diego Garcia in five successive boats starting in October 2021. Dozens have since returned to Sri Lanka on flights arranged by BIOT authorities, while others have returned to their boats and sailed farther across the Indian Ocean to Réunion Island, the French overseas department. Confirming news of the medical move in an emailed response to The New Humanitarian, the UK Foreign, Commonwealth and Development Office said the “migrants” would be returned to BIOT after their treatment was complete. The medical transfers are adding to fears that British authorities could seek to deport the Sri Lankan asylum seekers to Rwanda under an offshore processing deal then-Prime Minister Boris Johnson concluded with the Rwandan Government in April. Deportations from mainland Britain under the Rwanda deal – after arrivals on boats from France surpassed 40,000 in 2022, up more than 10,000 from 2021 – have been stalled for months amid challenges by UK Courts, as well as the refusal of several airlines to carry out the removals. (The New Humanitarian)

title: Public deceived into bringing Rajapaksa regime – Harshana
author: Author not found
Content: Samagi Jana Balawegaya (SJB) claimed the people were deceived into bringing back a Rajapaksa regime, three years ago, on a day like, yesterday (16) in November 2019. Addressing the media, yesterday (16), SJB MP Harshana Rajakaruna said, 6.9 million people of this country were cheated, where racism and bigotry were stirred up Muslim hatred was created and the people were deceived into bringing back a Rajapaksa regime. He further said, because of these rulers, the entire country has gone bankrupt and was suffering as a result. “We have heard of small businesses going bankrupt but what has happened now is unimaginable. Three years ago, the people of this country were cheated into electing a group that bankrupted the country, but the culprits are still at large. Gotabaya Rajapaksa who led the country into bankruptcy, is now enjoying the perks with State vehicles, the security of a well-appointed house, all at the expense of public money,” he added. Rajakaruna further said, they had called for a Parliamentary Select Committee to ask the Speaker to investigate as to who bankrupted this country. “It could be a politician, it could be Gotabaya, Mahinda, Basil Rajapaksa or State officials of the likes of  Ajith Nivard Cabraal and P.B. Jayasundara. But the question is who bankrupted the country in this way. We remind President Ranil Wickremesinghe that these things cannot be forgotten,” he added. Rajakaruna further said, those who were and are in power just want to sell off all the assets of the country and stay in power until they die. By Nabiya Vaffoor

title: Economic crisis put to the backburner – Anura Yapa
author: Author not found
Content: MP Anura Priyadarshana Yapa said, the Budget presented by Finance Minister Ranil Wickremesinghe was similar to a ‘concept paper’ as the Government has failed to explain the gravity of the economic crisis. Speaking during the Second Reading of the Budget yesterday (16), the MP told Parliament that some concepts are expected to be achieved by 2025 and some others even beyond. He queried as to how the economy could be revived based only on concepts. Yapa said, the country had become bankrupt as economic decisions have been taken sans supervision over the years. “The price of goods has soared where most families cannot afford thus putting their lives at risk. State employees have been jeopardized, since loan interest rates have gone up”, he said. He added that people had to face various issues due to an unexpected decision to ban chemical fertiliser. BY Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: Principal, Millaniya Police Inspector, sergeant enlarged on bail
author: Author not found
Content: Colombo Additional Magistrate Keminda Perera yesterday ordered the principal of the school in Millaniya, an inspector and a sergeant attached to the Millaniya Police Station remanded on charges of assaulting several students, to be enlarged on bail. The suspects were produced before Additional Magistrate Perera, who ordered to them to be released on two personal bails of Rs 1 million each. During Court proceedings, NCPA officers told the Additional Magistrate that some parents of the assaulted students were reluctant to refer them to a JMO. The case will be taken up again on 18 January, 2023. The NCPA launched an investigation into the incident which was reported recently, where a group of Grade 5 students from a school in Millaniya were subject to inhumane beating for allegedly stealing money from a  teacher’s wallet. Several Grade 5 students were brutally punished by the teacher and principal and were handed over to the local Police. Parents had alleged that students were taken away by police officers who intimidated them by threatening to subject them to electric shock treatment and assaulted them while inside the police jeep, and then dropped the students back in school. BY Hansi Nanayakkara

title: Tea exports down 4% to USD 1B
author: Author not found
Content: Tea export earnings in the first 10 months of the year declined by 4.03 per cent (USD 44.70 million) to USD 1.06 billion (FOB) year-on-year (YoY) and export volumes fell by 10.33 per cent (24.37 million kilos) to 211.61 million kgs in the same period, Forbes and Walker Tea Brokers data released on Monday (14) showed. However, tea export prices gained for the sixth consecutive month to last month (October 2022), aided by high oil prices, accelerating by 3.99 per cent (USD 0.22) to average at USD 5.74 per kg (‘free on board’ (FOB)), to set a new record. “When oil prices rise, tea prices increase, but when oil prices fall, tea prices too decline,” Ceylon Chamber of Commerce Chairman Vish Govindasamy told this newspaper recently. Consequently, the ‘FOB’ price of a kg of tea accelerated by 26.43 per cent (USD 1.20) to a record high USD 5.74 per kg (FOB) last month, beating the previous record of USD 5.52 per kg (FOB) established in only in the month of September 2022. Nonetheless, tea export volumes fell for the sixth consecutive month to last month, scarred by President Gotabaya Rajapaksa’s six-month chemical fertiliser export ban from April 2021 to November 2021, declining by 28.08 per cent (5.34 million kgs) YoY to 24.34 million kgs last month. Subsequently, tea export earnings last month declined by 1.29 per cent (USD 1.42 million) to USD 109.07 million (FOB) YoY.  Tea export earnings were Sri Lanka’s third largest foreign exchange (FX) earner for two consecutive years to last year (2021), Central Bank of Sri Lanka (CBSL) data showed. According to Forbes, Iraq has remained the No. 1 major importer of Sri Lanka Tea with an increase of 16 per cent in imports YoY for January-October 2022. Russia secured second position with a total of 20.66 million kgs, though, a nine per cent decrease YoY for January-October 2022. UAE sits in third place with a total of 18.32 million kgs followed by Türkiye, Iran, Azerbaijan, and Libya, respectively during the period January-October 2022, it said. However, a significant decrease in imports is reported from Türkiye (55 per cent), Iran, (14 per cent), China (18 per cent), Chile (15 per cent), Syria (21 per cent), Japan (15 per cent), and Jordan (27 per cent), YoY, said Forbes. Meanwhile, a notable increase in imports is recorded from Azerbaijan (12 per cent), Germany (eight per cent), USA (six per cent) and Poland (15 per cent) YoY, it added. ‘FOB’ means the price of the goods when boarded in a vessel for export at the exporter’s port. ‘CIF’ or ‘cost, insurance, and freight’ means the price of goods, after being received at the importer’s port. By Paneetha Ameresekere

title: HNBGI unveils refurbished Jaffna Branch
author: Author not found
Content: HNB General Insurance Limited (HNBGI) recently declared open its refurbished Jaffna Branch. The Company’s’ Chief Executive Officer, Executive Committee members, Staff and other distinguished guests including Customers participated on this day. The branch is conveniently located at No. 131, R.R. Building, Manipay Road, Jaffna, a spacious location to transact with a number of facilities to its customers, so that they could obtain a General Insurance policy that suits their need.  Sharing his views, Chief Executive Officer of HNBGI, Sithumina Jayasundara stated, “The opening of this refurbished branch is a part of the overall business strategy facilitated to focus on offering a wider range of solutions with more sophisticated facilities to cater to the diverse needs of the modern customers in the Northern region. In addition, our aim has always been to enhance our presence with more glamour and modernity. Whilst the company is focused on developing various digital platforms to serve the customer, we are also uplifting the look and feel of our branch network, so that customers could avail themselves of our services in a more sophisticated and elevated atmosphere.” Jayasundara also stated that the expansion and refurbishment of the branch network will continue as a development plan of the business into the future as well so that in order that the company could be able to provide a more wholesome service proposition.  Commenting at the opening, Chief Business Officer- Branch Network and Personal Lines/General Manager Jude Benjamin said, “We strive to offer our customers in the Northern Region as well as those across the island more convenient services continuously. We also make every effort to deliver an exceptional and convenient service, which will enable our clientele to enjoy the ambience in this newly refurbished branch”.

title: NEH initiates project to curb blindness due to diabetes
author: Author not found
Content: The National Eye Hospital initiated a project to curb blindness due to diabetes using the latest technology. Consultant Eye Surgeon National Eye Hospital (NEH) Dr. Kapila Banduthilaka explained that diabetic patients coming for treatment to hospital would be registered and given a date to return after being examined. He said patients would be given a gentle reminder with regard to the next date of their visit at least one week ahead with a short message to their mobile phones. A special programme organised by NEH under the slogan ‘Let us prevent blindness due to diabetes’ to mark  ‘World Diabetes Day,’ got off the ground. Dr. Banduthilaka, lamented that the lack of continued treatment at the appointed time had been identified as the main reason for Sri Lankans losing their sight due to diabetes. This measure would be taken to curb incidents such as this. The programme would be implemented in other districts depending on its success, he said, noting that a major network provider would support the programme. By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: Hospital leaves X-Ray machine idle for months
author: Author not found
Content: Informed sources said that a newly purchased X-Ray machine has been left unused for 12 months at Polpithigama Hospital. Locals say the X-Ray machine was purchased after the Polpithigama Regional Hospital was upgraded to a Base Hospital. But they alleged that the machine has not been used to date, hindering efficient service being provided to scores of patients visiting the hospital. BY Nandana Kelegama – Polpithigama

title: Kandy water purification plant still to see light of day
author: Author not found
Content: The failure to implement the Kandy Water Purification Project where Rs 22 billion had been incurred has gone to waste, so said Kandy Senior Municipal Councillor Vipula Ranasinghe. He said the project was funded by the Japanese Government but so far the project has not got off the ground. Ranasinghe added that the Japanese Government has temporarily halted pumping finances for the project. BY K. L. Suraweera -Kandy

title: Governor assures solutions for Meemure land issues
author: Author not found
Content: Central Province Governor Attorney Lalith U. Gamage recently addressed a meeting on resolving traditional agricultural land issues facing the residents of the Meemure Village. The village is situated within the World Heritage Site of Knuckles Mountain Range. Addressing the gathering, the Governor said no one has the right to encroach State-owned lands illegally and necessary legal support to resolve land issues and release the lands back to the Meemure people will be provided in due course. The meeting was convened at the Sri Sudenarama Temple at Meemure on 15 November. BY D. Wanniarachchi – Kandy

title: Stock market falls to three-and-a-half-month low
author: Author not found
Content: The stock market fell to three-and-a-half-month low, declining for the third consecutive market day to yesterday (16), complemented by sustained uncertainty coupled with a high interest rate regime, underpinned by record-high inflation. Consequently, the stock market, yesterday over Tuesday, saw the ASPI declining by 2.47 per cent to 8,087.04 points and the S&P SL 20 Index by 3.19 per cent to 2,464.20 points on a Rs 1.63 billion turnover. Market indices last made lower figures than these on 2 August and 1 August, with values of 7,907.52 (ASPI) and 2,445.09 (S&P SL 20 Index) points, respectively. A high interest rate regime is inimical to the growth of the stock market. This is because in such an environment, investors would prefer to invest their money in the fixed income market rather than in the stock market, that is, to the detriment of the latter. However, a silver lining was the stock market enjoying net foreign inflows (NFIs) for the second consecutive market day to yesterday, with yesterday’s figure being Rs 137.4 million in secondary market trading, thereby increasing NFI in secondary market trading in the calendar year to date to Rs 16.2 billion. The number of shares traded yesterday was 69.46 million. By Paneetha Ameresekere

title: Wildlife Park turning into waste dump – Environmentalists
author: Author not found
Content: Several environmentalists have urged the authorities to take immediate measures to protect the Randenigala, Rantembe Wildlife Park as it is one of the country’s most picturesque attractions for both local and foreign tourists. The wildlife park is situated near the Mahiyangana, Kandy Road between Theldeniya and Hasalaka Towns. The activists say that serious environment damage has been caused to the park recently by garbage dumping, which is causing untold harm to the native flora and fauna. BY Sunil Ihalagedera – Hasalaka
