Content: HNB General Insurance Limited (HNBGI) recently declared open its refurbished Jaffna Branch. The Company’s’ Chief Executive Officer, Executive Committee members, Staff and other distinguished guests including Customers participated on this day. The branch is conveniently located at No. 131, R.R. Building, Manipay Road, Jaffna, a spacious location to transact with a number of facilities to its customers, so that they could obtain a General Insurance policy that suits their need.  Sharing his views, Chief Executive Officer of HNBGI, Sithumina Jayasundara stated, “The opening of this refurbished branch is a part of the overall business strategy facilitated to focus on offering a wider range of solutions with more sophisticated facilities to cater to the diverse needs of the modern customers in the Northern region. In addition, our aim has always been to enhance our presence with more glamour and modernity. Whilst the company is focused on developing various digital platforms to serve the customer, we are also uplifting the look and feel of our branch network, so that customers could avail themselves of our services in a more sophisticated and elevated atmosphere.” Jayasundara also stated that the expansion and refurbishment of the branch network will continue as a development plan of the business into the future as well so that in order that the company could be able to provide a more wholesome service proposition.  Commenting at the opening, Chief Business Officer- Branch Network and Personal Lines/General Manager Jude Benjamin said, “We strive to offer our customers in the Northern Region as well as those across the island more convenient services continuously. We also make every effort to deliver an exceptional and convenient service, which will enable our clientele to enjoy the ambience in this newly refurbished branch”.

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Hospital leaves X-Ray machine idle for months
author: Author not found
Content: Informed sources said that a newly purchased X-Ray machine has been left unused for 12 months at Polpithigama Hospital. Locals say the X-Ray machine was purchased after the Polpithigama Regional Hospital was upgraded to a Base Hospital. But they alleged that the machine has not been used to date, hindering efficient service being provided to scores of patients visiting the hospital. BY Nandana Kelegama – Polpithigama

title: Murdered MP Athukorala’s family given Rs 9.025M
author: Author not found
Content: President Ranil Wickremesinghe handed over a sum of Rs 9.025 million, donated by Members of Parliament, to the wife of Amarakeerthi Athukorala, the former Polonnaruwa District MP of the Sri Lanka Podujana Peramuna, who was killed on 9 May. Deputy Speaker Ajith Rajapaksa handed over the relevant cheque to the President at the ruling party’s group meeting held yesterday at the Parliament Complex and the President presented the cheque to the family of Amarakeerthi Athukorala. Around 183 Members of Parliament donated money for this purpose. Deputy Speaker Rajapaksa said, that the ‘Madiwela Mithuro’ club comprising MPs from the ruling party in the Madiwela MP quarters complex commenced collecting these funds for Athukorala, it was a special incident where the ruling party, as well as the Opposition MPs, had contributed to it. The President was also requested to arrange for Athukorala’s family to receive the pension entitled to MPs, in the same manner, that former MP Keerthi Abeywickrama, who was killed in a grenade attack in Parliament, was given the pension. Prime Minister Dinesh Gunawardena and former Prime Minister Mahinda Rajapaksa were also present on this occasion.

title: Citizens should be ready to bear the brunt – Dr. Weerasinghe
author: Author not found
Content: Central Bank Governor, Dr. Nandalal Weerasinghe said as Sri Lanka seeks relief from external creditors to achieve the sustainability of its public debt, all of us as citizens should be ready to bear the brunt. He said this while addressing a post-Budget conference held at the Central Bank Auditorium yesterday (15). He said some people make different statements regarding the suspension of the country’s external debt servicing, but the external creditors were ready for it long before Sri Lanka officially announced the debt standstill on 12 April. He pointed out that when Sri Lanka temporarily suspended its external debt servicing last April, the country’s total foreign reserves fell to USD 20 million and the country’s credit rating was also in a dire situation. He pointed out that at that time, the Government had no option but to suspend debt servicing on a temporary basis until the country’s total debt was restructured and debt sustainability was restored. For this reason, the Central Bank Governor, said Budget proposals and other economic reform proposals should be implemented to start earning critical foreign exchange to build Sri Lanka’s debt sustainability and ensure that it does not return to crisis. President Ranil Wickremesinghe said in his Budget speech on Monday that the Sri Lankan economy can be turned around by the end of 2023 by following the Budget policies with a long-term vision that is not limited to the recommendations of the International Monetary Fund (IMF). Sri Lanka signed a staff-level agreement with the IMF in early September, but must secure sufficient financial assurance from bilateral creditors, including China and India, to secure disbursements. “The next critical step is to get financial assurance and the IMF programme and additional financial support, so that Sri Lanka can finally get back on a growth path,” Weerasinghe said. He reiterated the need to reform loss-making public enterprises in Sri Lanka. Treasury Secretary Mahinda Siriwardana said at the same event that stabilising the economy remains a challenge and that the private sector should play its role in assisting the Government to recover from the crisis. He said, the Government will appoint a presidential committee to monitor and ensure timely implementation of the Budget proposals. Siriwardana also said, Sri Lanka should make a case for cost-based consolidation, not just to rationalise public spending, but also to reduce the size of government and increase taxes. “Increasing income and reducing expenditure should go hand in hand,” Siriwardana said. “On the other hand, there is no point in generating revenue if there is no control on the expenditure side.” He said, a freeze on State sector hiring was ordered in April and strict expenditure control was demanded from State line ministries. “This is the time to act responsibly,” Siriwardana said. We are watching closely and we are seeing results.” However, he said, public services had to be maintained in the short term and taxes had to be raised. He said, the present conditions are painful for businesses as well as the public in general. Siriwardana said, Sri Lanka now has a public sector of 1.4 million people and a presidential commission will review the public sector. Siriwardena also said, the Ministry of Finance is trying to control expenditure and stop money printing. “We need to stop Central Bank financing,” he said. “We should stop printing money and contribute to reducing inflation from the Ministry of Finance.” The Central Bank Governor also said Sri Lanka should stop relying on credit assistance for its funding needs and implement measures to bring in foreign exchange. Addressing chronic fiscal and current account deficits, raising more revenue, and keeping sovereign debt at a reasonable level will all be critical, he said. “The economy cannot be reformed overnight. It is a painful process. The next challenge is to implement the Budget proposals according to a timeline,” the CBSL Governor said. By Ishara Gamage

title: Siyambalapitiya lauds President’s budget
author: Author not found
Content: State Minister of Finance Ranjith Siyambalapitiya emphasised that 2023 Budget is not a ‘futile document,’ while rejecting allegations of ‘international influences’ that shaped the parameters of the budget. He also said each MP’s income tax file should be opened. State Minister added that President Ranil Wickremesinghe was able to consolidate democracy and strengthen the economy to some extent because he accepted the challenge and presented his plan for the country. During the second reading of the budget yesterday (15), Siyambalapitiya said after the ‘Aragalaya,’ Parliament was threatened by an informal group. He claimed that democracy was confirmed because President Wickremesinghe accepted the challenge. “The current Finance Minister presented this budget at a difficult time. He accepted the budget challenge just as he accepted the challenge of the country,” he said. Responding to claims that the Government has not looked into social security, the Minister said, Rs 852 billion has been allocated for public welfare in Budget 2023, which is 10.8 per cent from the State expenditure. Siyambalapitiya also told Parliament that the families which had appealed for relief would be provided an allowance from April next year. BY Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: Hirunika et al given bail
author: Author not found
Content: Colombo Chief Magistrate Nandana Amerasinghe yesterday released on bail ex-MP Hirunika Premachandra and 14 others who were charged with taking part in a protest near Cinnamon Gardens and obstructing Police. Bail was set at Rs 10,000 in cash and a surety in Rs 5 million each. The Magistrate also ordered the suspects, to report to the Cinnamon Gardens Police on the last Sunday of every month. Cinnamon Gardens Police, along with officers from the CCD, prosecuted. The CCD told the Court that the probe conducted into the incident had revealed that the suspects had flouted Provisions contained in Sections of the Penal Code, Section 59 (2) of Thoroughfares Ordinance and Sections 77 (3) and 84 (1) of the Police Ordinance via their actions. The Counsel appearing for the suspects stated that their clients had convened at Independence Square to take part in a street drama. They stated that at that point one of their clients had been arrested by the Police and that when the rest of their clients had visited the Police Station to look into the plight of their colleague, they too had been arrested. Hence, they argued that as their clients had been arrested over bailable offence they should be enlarged on bail. Taking the submissions into consideration Magistrate Amerasinghe ordered the suspects to be released on bail and fixed further hearing of the case to 15 February next year. BY Hansi Nanayakkara

title: JJB warns of more businesses collapsing
author: Author not found
Content: The Jathika Jana Balawegaya (JJB) yesterday (15) in Parliament lamented the projected tax policy of the Government for 2023 given that many businesses have already collapsed. JJB MP Vijitha Herath participating in the second stage debate on Budget 2023 said that businesses have collapsed and the economy is in doldrums. “It is wrong to slap more taxes on businessmen at such a time. It brings to mind the old Sinhala adage ‘Gahen wetuna minihata gona enna wage’ (falling from the tree only to be gored by a bull),” he added. Budget 2023 proposals are nothing but a double whammy on the people living under terrible economic hardships, he said. “The Government says it would sell off unprofitable public ventures. We demand to know the logic behind earmarking the Sri Lanka Insurance Corporation to be sold. The insurance corporation made a profit of Rs 11 billion last year. On what grounds the insurance corporation has been listed among loss making public ventures for the restructuring,” the MP queried. He said, the Government is now trying to give away profit-making public ventures with the hope of getting hold of a huge chunk of funds which could be pumped to solve some of the temporary problems. BY Gagani Weerakoon and Aloka Kasthuriarachchi

title: Crop loss due to wild animals Rs 54B a year
author: Author not found
Content: Agriculture Minister Mahinda Amaraweera said crop damage caused by wild animals is estimated to be Rs 54 billion each year, based on Ministry of Agriculture estimates. Wild elephants, monkeys, peacocks, porcupines, giant squirrels and wild boars are among the animals that cause the most crop damage. Six of these animals, other than wild elephants, have been added to the list of crop-damaging animals. The Hector Kobbekaduwa Agricultural Research and Training Institute prepared a special report on crop damage caused by wild animals and these facts were revealed in that report.

title: Govt gearing up to oppress masses – Prof. Piyadasa
author: Author not found
Content: Senior Vice President of the SLFP, Prof. Rohana Lakshman Piyadasa said when analysing the 2023 Budget proposals, it is increasingly clear that the Government is geared to launch a severe oppression of the masses during the next 12 months. He said, this was evident with the allocation of a staggering amount of funds towards the Defence Ministry via the Budget proposals which were tabled in Parliament by the President on 14 November in his capacity as the Finance Minister. Prof. Piyadasa was speaking during a media briefing convened in Kandy on 15 November. He warned that continued oppression of the people will have consequences. He asked the Government to be prepared to face the wrath of the masses during the next election. He added that the Budget on the whole does not entail any proposals aimed at providing relief to the oppressed masses. By K.L. Suraweera – Kandy

title: Gammanpila questions setting up 11 new State institutions
author: Author not found
Content: Pivithuru Hela Urumaya (PHU) Leader, MP Udaya Gammanpila said Budget 2023 has created 11 State institutions and comes with increased maintenance costs, which he claimed will exacerbate the present crisis. He said maintaining one of the world’s largest public sectors is one of the primary causes of Sri Lanka’s economic crisis. Speaking to the media yesterday, he said, the Government, which has been lecturing Parliament about its existence for several months, has created 11 new Government institutions in Budget 2023. “These 11 institutions are not members of non-permanent committees, presidential commissions, presidential task forces, or new institutions formed by the merger of existing institutions.” As a result, the Presidential Commission for Public Sector Reform, the Agency for External Trade, the New Department for Cinnamon Industry Development, the National Development Committee, the Board of Graduate Status Certification and Accreditation, the Uva Wellassa University Faculty of Medicine, the Historical Research Institute, the Institute of State Revenue Management, the Data Protection Authority, the Microfinance Regulatory Authority, and the University on Climate Change have all been established,” he said. He added that when establishing new institutions, new directors, director generals, and support staff should be appointed, and other facilities should be provided. He stressed that, in light of the massive financial crisis, the Government should collaborate with existing institutions. “For example, the University Grants Commission could delegate the functions that the Board of Graduate Status Certification and Accreditation is expected to perform. The work that the Microfinance Regulatory Authority is expected to do can be delegated to the Central Bank of Sri Lanka. Creating new institutions without doing the work of existing institutions will exacerbate the present crisis,” he said. By Thameenah Razeek

title: “What’s the point if they don’t even investigate?”
author: Author not found
Content: Minister of Justice, Prisons Affairs and Constitutional Reforms Wijeyadasa Rajapakshe yesterday (15) questioned in Parliament the usefulness of maintaining the Commission to Investigate Allegations of Bribery or Corruption (CIABOC), claiming that it has failed to investigate complaints received from the public. Participating in the second reading stage debate on Budget 2023, the minister said, he had made four to five complaints to CIABOC but none of them has been investigated. “What is the use of such a commission for the country if it does not investigate complaints? After my complaints, the commission summoned me for my statements. Each time I was questioned for three to four hours to record my statements as complaints in writing. They spent hours questioning me regarding the complainant. Yet they have not been able to investigate any of those complaints,” the Minister said. BY Gagani Weerakoon and Aloka Kasthuriarachchi

title: Kopay Police trailing chain snatching duo
author: Author not found
Content: A woman lodged a complaint with the Jaffna Kopay Police Station yesterday (15) regarding two men on a motorcycle who stole her gold chain. According to Kopay Police, the incident occurred yesterday around 6.30 a.m. in G.P.S Lane in Jaffna’s Kalliyankadu area, as the victim was returning home after worshipping at a nearby temple. The suspects are still at large, and the Kopay Police is conducting additional investigations based on CCTV footage. Kopay Police said that thefts and such incidents are on the rise in the region and added that they are taking all necessary actions to bring the wrongdoers before the law and thwart such attempts while protecting the people in their Police division. BY Naalir Jamaldeen

title: BRANDIX TO HOST SUSTAINABILITY SUMMIT FOR 2ND CONSECUTIVE YEAR
author: Author not found
Content: Brandix Apparel Ltd. is gearing up to host its much-anticipated Sustainability Summit for 2022. Held for the second consecutive year, Brandix intends to focus this year’s iteration on discussions, encompassing varied aspects of Environmental, Social and Governance (ESG) through this virtual summit. Taking place on Tuesday, 22 November 2022 from 5:30 p.m. to 7:00 p.m. (IST), the virtual platform will bring together experts who will speak on pressing issues that we face in our world, with specific focus on manufacturing industries. Each of the speakers bring a wealth of knowledge in policies and initiatives at global, national, or organisational levels towards sustainable development, the risks that would be faced with insufficient focus on this crucial area, and the rewards that can be gained with steps forward. This year’s panel of international speakers are devoted to true sustainable development and include, Claire Kells, Snr Manager Corporate Engagement – UN Global Compact; Ruby Ojha, Snr Environmental and Social Development Specialist – International Finance Corporation (IFC), a member of the World Bank Group; and Tejas Sampat, Snr Director, Corporate Responsibility (SA) and Global Sustainability (Offshore) – PVH Corp. The panellists will be backed by members of the Team from Brandix, namely, Akila Fernando, DGM, Group Engineering and Vinura Jayewardene, Group Sustainability Engineer, who will draw from examples of the organisation’s own sustainability framework anchored to the pillars of Air, Water and Earth. In Brandix’s own social and environmental sustainability journey that spans over a decade and a half, significant milestones have been reached. These include the plant in Batticaloa, Sri Lanka being recognised as the world’s first Nett Zero Carbon Apparel Manufacturing facility in 2019. This was not the first time the company broke new ground – In 2008, it’s factory in Seeduwa, Sri Lanka became the World’s first LEED Platinum certified facility under the US Green Building Council, and today the Group has multiple other LEED certified facilities across Sri Lanka and India. The lessons learnt and rewards will interest those in the manufacturing sphere. Brandix also works with the objective to make each location where it establishes its facilities, a better place than it was when we arrived, through enhancing the living conditions and wellbeing of the community, mapped to the pillars of Provide, Educate and Engage. In Sri Lanka, its flagship initiative of Water Projects has provided access to clean water for drinking and household needs to over a quarter of a million people, whilst in India, free eye camps screen patients and extend medical support and spectacles, with over 35,000 beneficiaries to date. With attendance figures exceeding 1,000s for last year’s summit, Brandix is confident that this year too, a global community oflike-minded participants who strive to make an impact on our environment and society, will come together once again. It is expected that the Summit will unlock the power of sustainable growth through championing efforts to address critical issues, and to drive true impact across many industries. Brandix extends the invitation to all those interested to follow their social media platforms for more details on this summit, and to join the discussion, listen to experts in the field and share views, as they unlock the power of sustainable growth. The efforts of Brandix to conduct such an event of this scale reflects its work to move from commitments to actions and is parallel to its belief of caring for the people, communities in which it operates and the planet. Yet another significant depiction of this commitment is the company’s pledge to be Nett Zero Carbon across all manufacturing facilities in Sri Lanka by 2023, and all facilities in India by 2025. About Brandix Group Brandix are a pioneer in Sri Lanka’s Apparel industry, who develop, manufacture and market end to end apparel solutions for world renowned brands. The company operates with the purpose to deliver Inspired solutions through Inspired people, with a team that is over 60,000 strong, across nine countries including India, Bangladesh, Haiti and the United Kingdom. On a journey to be the most sustainable apparel manufacturer in the South Asian region, Brandix embeds real change across every point of its operations as they care for the planet and the communities in which they serve. In Sri Lanka, Brandix is honoured to have been adjudged ‘Exporter of the Year’ for the 7th consecutive time at the Presidential Export Awards 2020/21. The company is also proud to share that their plant in Batticaloa was recognised as the world’s first Nett Zero Carbon Apparel Manufacturing facility in 2019. To learn more about Brandix and its 50-year long journey please visit www.brandix.com.

title: Ocean surveying Cabinet Subcommittee formed
author: Author not found
Content: A Cabinet Subcommittee on ocean surveying has been formed, chaired by Ports and Aviation Minister Nimal Siripala de Silva, according to Fisheries Minister Douglas Devananda. Minister Devananda revealed this when he met with officials from the National Aquatic Resources Research and Development Agency (NARA) to discuss and find quick solutions for issues at the agency. The meeting also included Consultant to the Minister S. Thavarasa and other officials from the Fisheries Ministry. Devananda added that attention has been focused on ocean survey, the responsibility of which has been vested on NARA by the Minister.  “We have planned to submit detailed reports of ocean surveys carried out by NARA to the cabinet subcommittee while NARA has to submit their project plan to the subcommittee besides the responsibilities vested on them in connection with ocean surveying according to the Parliamentary Act passed when NARA was established,” Minister Devananda added. BY Naalir Jamaldeen

title: Expectations of high rates at today’s Rs 80B T Bill auction
author: Author not found
Content: Government of Sri Lanka’s (GoSL’s) at least theoretical money printing borrowing costs (MPBCs) accelerated by 5.89 per cent (Rs 8,380.48 million) to Rs 150,677.45 million at Monday’s (14 November) trading led by selling pressure of Treasury (T) Bills and T Bonds in secondary market trading, to invest in today’s (Wednesday 16 November) Rs 80 billion T Bill auction on expectations of high yields due to record-high inflation. GoSL’s face value (FV) MP debt decreased by 0.67 per cent (Rs 21,956 million) to Rs 3,242,285.13 million (Rs 3.2423 trillion) on Monday led by swaps between the GoSL and Central Bank of Sri Lanka (CBSL), thereby marginally defraying demand-pull inflationary pressure. GoSL’s FVMP debt has been over Rs 3 trillion for a record consecutive 89 market days to Monday due to a sustained lack of revenue. Market liquidity increased by Rs 73,048 million (USD 200.96 million), led by the settlement of the above mentioned swaps on Monday. Conversions are based on the value of the administered and benchmark official ‘spot’ fixed at Rs 363.50 to the US dollar on Thursday (10 November). Swaps between GoSL and CBSL are foreign reserves-neutral. Market was short for a record 290 market days to Monday, though this shortfall fell by 10.12 per cent (Rs 51,092 million) to Rs 453,655 million, nevertheless causing sustained rate pressure. Meanwhile, GoSL’s highest to the 294th highest FVMP debt has been recorded in the 294 consecutive market days to Monday.  CBSL, which administers daily open market operations (OMO), lacks transparency. GoSL’s FVMP debt is equivalent to the totality of CBSL’s T Bill and T Bond holdings. MP is the exclusive right of CBSL. GoSL’s MPBCs are prorated to the outcome in secondary market trading of T Bills and T Bonds on the reference day. ‘Spot’ trades are settled after two market days from the date of transaction. CBSL, the steward of GoSL debt and its foreign reserves deals in ‘spot.’ The ‘spot’ is administered to minimise GoSL’s foreign debt in rupee terms and lower the cost of ‘essential’ imports, while ‘essential’ imports are met from the country’s foreign reserves and not from the market, to prevent further depreciative pressure on the rupee, as Sri Lanka is an import-dependent economy.  By Paneetha Ameresekere

title: Extortion racket targets Nachchaduwa Fisheries Harbour
author: Author not found
Content: Fishermen using the fisheries harbour at the Nachchaduwa River claim that an organised group has started to demand protection money from them recently. They say that it has become impossible for them to continue their livelihood due to this situation. A local fisherman said that the secretary and chairman of a certain fisheries union are among the organised gang who continue to extort money. He also added that an official attached to the Fisheries Corporation is part of this gang. Those who don’t pay up are not allowed to go fishing, he said. BY Ananda Karunadasa – Anuradhapura

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: BRANDIX TO HOST SUSTAINABILITY SUMMIT FOR 2ND CONSECUTIVE YEAR
author: Author not found
Content: Brandix Apparel Ltd. is gearing up to host its much-anticipated Sustainability Summit for 2022. Held for the second consecutive year, Brandix intends to focus this year’s iteration on discussions, encompassing varied aspects of Environmental, Social and Governance (ESG) through this virtual summit. Taking place on Tuesday, 22 November 2022 from 5:30 p.m. to 7:00 p.m. (IST), the virtual platform will bring together experts who will speak on pressing issues that we face in our world, with specific focus on manufacturing industries. Each of the speakers bring a wealth of knowledge in policies and initiatives at global, national, or organisational levels towards sustainable development, the risks that would be faced with insufficient focus on this crucial area, and the rewards that can be gained with steps forward. This year’s panel of international speakers are devoted to true sustainable development and include, Claire Kells, Snr Manager Corporate Engagement – UN Global Compact; Ruby Ojha, Snr Environmental and Social Development Specialist – International Finance Corporation (IFC), a member of the World Bank Group; and Tejas Sampat, Snr Director, Corporate Responsibility (SA) and Global Sustainability (Offshore) – PVH Corp. The panellists will be backed by members of the Team from Brandix, namely, Akila Fernando, DGM, Group Engineering and Vinura Jayewardene, Group Sustainability Engineer, who will draw from examples of the organisation’s own sustainability framework anchored to the pillars of Air, Water and Earth. In Brandix’s own social and environmental sustainability journey that spans over a decade and a half, significant milestones have been reached. These include the plant in Batticaloa, Sri Lanka being recognised as the world’s first Nett Zero Carbon Apparel Manufacturing facility in 2019. This was not the first time the company broke new ground – In 2008, it’s factory in Seeduwa, Sri Lanka became the World’s first LEED Platinum certified facility under the US Green Building Council, and today the Group has multiple other LEED certified facilities across Sri Lanka and India. The lessons learnt and rewards will interest those in the manufacturing sphere. Brandix also works with the objective to make each location where it establishes its facilities, a better place than it was when we arrived, through enhancing the living conditions and wellbeing of the community, mapped to the pillars of Provide, Educate and Engage. In Sri Lanka, its flagship initiative of Water Projects has provided access to clean water for drinking and household needs to over a quarter of a million people, whilst in India, free eye camps screen patients and extend medical support and spectacles, with over 35,000 beneficiaries to date. With attendance figures exceeding 1,000s for last year’s summit, Brandix is confident that this year too, a global community oflike-minded participants who strive to make an impact on our environment and society, will come together once again. It is expected that the Summit will unlock the power of sustainable growth through championing efforts to address critical issues, and to drive true impact across many industries. Brandix extends the invitation to all those interested to follow their social media platforms for more details on this summit, and to join the discussion, listen to experts in the field and share views, as they unlock the power of sustainable growth. The efforts of Brandix to conduct such an event of this scale reflects its work to move from commitments to actions and is parallel to its belief of caring for the people, communities in which it operates and the planet. Yet another significant depiction of this commitment is the company’s pledge to be Nett Zero Carbon across all manufacturing facilities in Sri Lanka by 2023, and all facilities in India by 2025. About Brandix Group Brandix are a pioneer in Sri Lanka’s Apparel industry, who develop, manufacture and market end to end apparel solutions for world renowned brands. The company operates with the purpose to deliver Inspired solutions through Inspired people, with a team that is over 60,000 strong, across nine countries including India, Bangladesh, Haiti and the United Kingdom. On a journey to be the most sustainable apparel manufacturer in the South Asian region, Brandix embeds real change across every point of its operations as they care for the planet and the communities in which they serve. In Sri Lanka, Brandix is honoured to have been adjudged ‘Exporter of the Year’ for the 7th consecutive time at the Presidential Export Awards 2020/21. The company is also proud to share that their plant in Batticaloa was recognised as the world’s first Nett Zero Carbon Apparel Manufacturing facility in 2019. To learn more about Brandix and its 50-year long journey please visit www.brandix.com.

title: Ocean surveying Cabinet Subcommittee formed
author: Author not found
Content: A Cabinet Subcommittee on ocean surveying has been formed, chaired by Ports and Aviation Minister Nimal Siripala de Silva, according to Fisheries Minister Douglas Devananda. Minister Devananda revealed this when he met with officials from the National Aquatic Resources Research and Development Agency (NARA) to discuss and find quick solutions for issues at the agency. The meeting also included Consultant to the Minister S. Thavarasa and other officials from the Fisheries Ministry. Devananda added that attention has been focused on ocean survey, the responsibility of which has been vested on NARA by the Minister.  “We have planned to submit detailed reports of ocean surveys carried out by NARA to the cabinet subcommittee while NARA has to submit their project plan to the subcommittee besides the responsibilities vested on them in connection with ocean surveying according to the Parliamentary Act passed when NARA was established,” Minister Devananda added. BY Naalir Jamaldeen

title: A REFORM BUDGET 2023
author: Author not found
Content: President Ranil Wickremesinghe, presenting a reforms-filled Budget 2023, in his capacity as the Minister of Finance, aimed at making the Government less of a burden on the Treasury, told Parliament yesterday the Government would make reforms to change the economy, going beyond the IMF recommendations. He also revealed the plans to appoint Presidential Commissions to review the public service and Tax policy. The presidential commission will review the public service which was consuming most taxes. The Presidential commission on tax will also make recommendations on a revenue authority. The government will also restructure SriLankan Airlines, Sri Lanka Telecom, Sri Lanka Insurance and Waters Edge through a State enterprise reform unit. The proceeds will be used to strengthen foreign reserves, he said. President Wickremesinghe said that the Board of Investment (BOI) and Export Development Board (EDB) would be merged. The Employees Trust Fund (ETF) law would be reformed. The Information Communication Technology Agency (ICTA) would be dissolved. Soldiers who had served for over 18 years would also be given the opportunity to retire on a voluntary basis, he said. The government plans to reform labour laws for an export-oriented economy, the President said. “Labour laws have to be reformed for an export-oriented economy. There are also independent contractors.” The Government would bring a comprehensive law to regulate labour, he said. The President said, that the long-term development of the country (2023-2048) should be based on correct decisions and not popular decisions. “To ensure a better future for the youth of our country, let’s create a new economy tailored to meet the expectations of the youth through a new approach that goes beyond traditional protests, struggles, and strikes, the President said. President Ranil Wickremesinghe assured that the commencement of a new journey, ensuring the lifestyles that the society is familiar with, will not fall to a lower level again. Instead of a lifestyle tailored to per capita income, an economy tailored to the lifestyles of the youth. A new economic foundation should be prepared to match the new trends of the world, he said President Wickremesinghe said, socio-economic transformation should be done taking into account global phenomena, paying special attention to climate change. The President said, the necessary legislative amendments and new Bills for economic transformation would be presented to Parliament soon. It is expected to achieve a high economic growth rate of 7%-8% through the social market economy based on reforms and modernisation.  Excerpts from his speech: “A glimmer of hope on emerging from the economic abyss is currently visible as a result of the strenuous and difficult actions we have adopted during the past few months. After the era of waiting in queues for days and protesting in various occupied places, our sufferings have been eased to some extent and we have reached an era where our peace of mind is much settled. “Negotiations with the International Monetary Fund are currently in progress. We are in dialogue with India and China on debt restructuring. We are confident that these discussions will lead to positive outcomes. “Inflation could be controlled to some extent due to the actions taken in the recent past. Similarly, the rupee is strengthening. We expect to sustain these developments. I am confident that by moving along the same path, we will be able to stabilise the economy within the next year. “But we cannot be satisfied with that. We must start a new journey. “Presenting the Interim Budget proposals last August, I mentioned that the purpose of the interim budget proposals is to lay the basic foundation for transforming the economic pattern that has existed so far in our country. I mentioned there, that the process of building a new economy suitable for the modern world would be started through the budget proposals 2023. “Seventy-five years after independence, can we be satisfied with the status quo? Where did we go wrong? How did we go wrong? “Let’s look back. Let’s take off the colored political glasses. Why did we get it wrong? Where did we go wrong? Did we get things wrong? Or did we got things wrong? Today, our country has several main revenue generating sectors. One is the plantation economy. Next is Free Trade Zones. Garment industry, Tourism and foreign employment. Looking at those, after independence, we have been able to create only a few avenues for the country to earn foreign income. Beyond that, why have we not yet been able to create large-scale foreign income generating sectors? This is something we should think about carefully. “Over the past period, have we been excited and happy for things that will work for the future, or for things that can be seen on the surface for the moment? People were happy when successful private businesses were nationalised. People were happy when free rice was given. Governments that took such “Because of this, we were satisfied with installing an electric lamp on the street. But we did not think deeply about increasing the electricity generation. “Is the long-term development of a country based on popular decisions? Or the right decisions? In many cases, popular decisions were taken instead of correct decisions in our country. Even today many people try to make popular decisions. “What was the result of this popular ruling tradition? To build a relief economy and a relief mentality across the country. People are used to getting concessions. Governments do not work to create opportunities for people to develop. Only to provide relief. “Reminiscing the nineteen fifties, Lee Kuan Yew once mentioned the following. “In Singapore I followed the hard, but right path. Sri Lanka’s Bandaranaike followed the popular path.” “There is no future for the country by continuing on this popular path. There is no prosperity for the country by giving concessions while being in debt to others. So, let’s get out of this situation now. Let’s change our thinking patterns. “So, let’s think anew. Let’s create innovative approaches to move the country forward. Through this budget, we are trying to lay the new foundation of the Sri Lankan economy that can create that force. “Here, I would like to outline some of the main points that we will focus our attention on. Due to the economic crisis we faced in the recent times, the whole country faced many difficulties… couldn’t put the food on the plate for the day. Jobs were in jeopardy. Income was lost. Businesses collapsed. It has not yet been possible to completely get rid of all those difficulties. People faced such difficulties with the hopes of rebuilding the country in their hearts. All of us made those commitments and are still making commitments with the aim of reviving the country. The benefits of the new economy we are building must be equitably shared among all those who are committed to the country. Equal opportunities should be created for all. It is not an economic system that makes only a small group of society rich, but an economic system that elevates the entire society. “When Sri Lanka was a low-income economy, the basic necessities of life enjoyed by the people were minimal. But been elevated to a middle-income economy, standard of living also naturally rose. This is a normal situation. It is the same even at home. As the household income level rises, the standard of living rises. “In preparing the new economic base, we should focus on the lifestyles that the society is familiar with. A new journey must be started so that these lifestyles do not fall to a lower level again. “Especially today’s youth who deal with the world on a technological basis expect their lifestyles to rise day by day. Therefore, it is necessary to create a way of life that stimulates lifestyles that rise day by day through the new economic base. “Therefore, means of livelihood that we should be creating is not that suits the current level of per capita income, a way to raise per capita income to match the lifestyles that young people aspire to. “In this system we focus on taking care of poor and vulnerable groups. It is necessary to examine whether all sections of the society are receiving equitable benefits through health services and free education that is currently provided as well as other welfare programs. And these services should be made more efficient. Maximum benefits should be obtained from the resources spent for this purpose. “If we forget that we are facing a huge economic crisis, we won’t have a way forward. It is by realising the current situation, we need to prepare the way forward. Therefore, in the midst of this crisis, it is important to pay special attention to how our welfare programmes could be implemented more effectively. Parallel to this, entrepreneurs in the private sector should be promoted. Private entrepreneurs in our country continued to grow from the mid-19th century to the mid-1950s. But with the nationalisation of their businesses, private entrepreneurship in Sri Lanka almost completely collapsed. As a result of the open economy introduced in 1977, there were again private entrepreneurs, but they were not adequately provided with the necessary facilities. “Many people in the country did not look at entrepreneurs with a good attitude. Entrepreneurs who contribute to the country’s economy were considered villains. In most of the tele dramas produced in Sri Lanka, the village shopkeeper (‘Mudalali’) was portrayed as an evil character. From the small entrepreneur in the village to the large-scale entrepreneurs, everyone was treated as exploiters. “We must change this situation. Private entrepreneurs should be encouraged. New entrepreneurs should be created. All the necessary facilities should be provided to them. A policy environment should be created to make their work more effective. “While encouraging private sector entrepreneurs, we should focus on regulating economic activities, investing in infrastructure, correcting market failures and maintaining law and order. “I would like to define the new economy that we are going to build as a social market economy, or an “open economic system of social protection”. “In this new economy, we focus on three main things: “An export oriented competitive economy, an environmentally friendly green and blue economy and a digital economy. “Creating such a new economic foundation is a challenging task. Such a new economy cannot be created merely by making changes in the tax system. New sources of revenue should be found. New areas should be identified. Massive economic reforms and restructuring should be carried out. “We hope to base two unique points here; the first – economic reforms and reorganisation and the second – economic modernisation. “Re-examination of the country’s resource base as well as the reorganisation of them is also important here. Education, health, agriculture and marine resources, industry, trade and investment, defence, foreign relations, etc., must all be modernised. We should carry out this socio-economic transformation taking into account the global phenomena. In particular, a special attention should be paid to climate change. “We will soon present the new legislations and legal amendments to the Parliament that are necessary for economic transformation. It is essential to establish a common social agreement for economic management as well as between various parties involved in the industrial and social relations system. Legislature, executive, judiciary, professional groups, mass media, religious groups and various social organisations should be involved for this. This common unity is extremely important to maintain long-term social harmony and to move towards without rapid economic growth without collisions. We expect to achieve following goals, initially through the social market economy or social-security-open-economy that we are creating. – High economic growth of 7 to 8 percent. – Increasing international trade as a percentage of GDP by more than 100 percent – Annual growth of USD 3 billion from new exports from 2023 to 2032 – Foreign direct investment of more than US$ 3 billion in the next 10 years – Creating an internationally competitive workforce with high skills in the next ten years “In order to achieve these goals, we need to create a competitive and high-performance modern economy. A modern, export-oriented, competitive economy led by the private sector…a private sector-led, export-oriented, competitive modern economy. We are starting our journey for that in 2023 with this budget. By the year 2048, which marks 100 years of independence, the background for the new approach and new work order to make Sri Lanka a developed country will be prepared by these budget proposals. “But these budget proposals are different from traditional budget proposals. We are often used to get reductions in prices of goods, salary increases concessions etc. through budget proposals. We would like to see budget proposals that appear to be relief on the surface even if it means indebtedness to the world. We lost our way because of taking that popular route. Now we can no longer go down wrong paths and despair. “If we build the future through the foundation we create through this budget, we will be able to enjoy a comfortable economic environment by the end of 2023. The benefits of that economy will flow to throughout the country. “The economic reforms we are bringing are not limited to the reforms agreed upon with the International Monetary Fund. The economic reforms proposed by the International Monetary Fund are limited to economic stabilisation only. We are doing these reforms and reorganisations to build a new economy. It is a need of the country. Something that the country needed for a long time, a role that many Governments have opted to ignore with popularity in mind. We will play that role for the country.”

title: Those responsible for Easter attacks will pay – Cardinal
author: Author not found
Content: Archbishop of Colombo Malcolm Cardinal Ranjith warned that those responsible for the 2019 Easter attacks would suffer the consequences of their actions, according to Buddhist Teachings. Addressing the gathering during a ceremony held to hand over the houses at St. Antony’s housing project in Bollatha, Ganemulla, Cardinal Ranjith said, Buddhism speaks about the ‘Ditta dhamma wedaniya karmaya’, therefore those responsible for the 2019 Easter attacks would suffer the repercussions of their doings. “You are wrong if you think that the law could be twisted in your favour, act like heroes in the future and wash your hands off. He accused the Attorney General’s Department of being devoid of their sense of smell sight or hearing and therefore doing nothing to execute the recommendations of the Easter Attack Presidential Commission Report. “Although the former President pledged to ensure a free and transparent investigation he called me and asked as to how he could carry out all that had been recommended in the Report once he received it. “Now a herd of deaf elephants have entered the scene and it is quite apparent that there is no point in playing the violin to them,” he lamented.   By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: Nearly 500 youth visit Parliament for Budget
author: Author not found
Content: Nearly five hundred youth, including schoolchildren, visited Parliament yesterday (14) to listen to President Ranil Wickremesinghe’s Budget speech, Serjeant-at-Arms Narendra Fernando said. According to Fernando, this is the first time in the history of Parliament that the youth community and schoolchildren have been given the opportunity to observe the presentation of the Budget. Senior students, including prefects of several schools in the Western Province and nearly a hundred young persons representing the youth Parliament of the National Youth Services Council, were among them. In addition, a group of young persons, representing the National Youth Corps, was also present to witness the Budget debate. Following witnessing the budget debate, they also joined in a tour around Parliament.

title: SJB claims six SLPP MPs joined their fold
author: Author not found
Content: The Samagi Jana Balawegaya (SJB) yesterday (14), announced that a group of six Sri Lanka Podujana Peramuna (SLPP) parliamentarians have joined them to support Opposition Leader Sajith Premadasa. Official SJB sources said, MP Anura Priyadarshana Yapa, Chandima Weerakkodi, John Seneviratne, Jayaratne Herath, Sudarshani Fernandopulle and Priyankara Jayaratne have joined SJB. Calling an immediate special meeting, yesterday (14), Premadasa officially announced that the six MPs had joined the Samagi Jana Sandhanaya (SJS). “I would like to thank former President Chandrika Bandaranaike, who intervened and helped in this regard. I would like to express my gratitude for coming together to work in union to build the country. This unity is extremely important to work more strongly and collectively in the future,” added Premadasa. Meanwhile, on behalf of SJB, its General Secretary MP Ranjith Maddumabandara also welcomed the six MPs who joined them. Meanwhile, addressing the meeting, Anura Priyadarshana Yapa noted that they have come together as a result of several discussions held for a long time and they will contribute to building the SJB as a strong force. Meanwhile, speaking to Ceylon Today, Sudarshani Fernandopulle, yesterday (14), denied joining the SJB or SJS. “I met the general Opposition group including the leader of the Opposition to discuss the common tasks of the Opposition that should be performed for the people as an Opposition in general at the time of presenting the budget proposal for the year 2023 and a consensus was reached to fulfil the common tasks of the Opposition in the parliament. I declare with responsibility that I did not join any alliance. Therefore, I declare that the media reports that I have joining SJS are misleading and devoid of truth,” she confirmed through an official statement. Fernandopulle noted that MP John Seneviratne and Priyankara Jayaratne weren’t even present at the discussion. “Priyankara Jayaratne was not even in the country and John Seneviratne wasn’t present at the discussion. I’m not sure about the news circulating that they also joined SJB or SJS. But i cannot make any statement regarding them,” she added. She repeatedly confirmed that she is an independent member, who was present at the occasion just to discuss about the 2023 Budget as a general Opposition member, not to join to SJB or any alliance. BY Nabiya Vaffoor

title: CPC making Rs 126 profit on litre of 95 Octane
author: Author not found
Content: Ceylon Petroleum Corporation is currently making a profit of Rs 126.49 on a litre of 95 octane and Rs 22.71 on 92 octane according to the most recent petroleum sales reports. According to the reports, the Corporation earnsRs 36.50 per litre of Lanka Super Diesel and 89 cents per litre of Lanka Auto Diesel. However, Kerosene generates a profit of Rs 2.10 for the CPC. Kanchana Wijesekera, Minister of Electricity and Energy has said, these profits have been recorded in accordance with the most recent price revision.

title: Cabinet approves cancelling Coal ‘spot’, ‘term’ tenders
author: Author not found
Content: Minister of Power and Energy Kanchana Wijesekara said, on the recommendation of the Tech and the Procurement Committees, the Cabinet of Ministers had approved the cancellation of the Spot and Term Tenders for Procurement of Coal. In a tweet, he said, both were cancelled as none of the bidders have met the qualification criteria and complied with Tender guidelines, which are major deviations. Accordingly, approval was given to the Procurement Committee to Call for Proposals from prospective suppliers and Government to Government Proposals, on a long term Credit Basis. He said requirements for the months of November and December will be fulfilled by advancing the last years Term Tender Coal Supplies.

title: A budget of taxes, debt and sales – AKD
author: Author not found
Content: JJB Colombo District MP Anura Kumara Dissanayake says that the 2023 Budget, tabled in Parliament by the Finance Minister, could be described as one standing on three pillars namely taxes, debt and sales. He made this remark when asked for his views on the new budget presented to the House by the President yesterday, in his capacity as the Finance Minister. The MP added that the President, in the first part of his Budget presentation, had engaged in a confession detailing the repercussions the country had been forced to put up with due to his ill-timed economic policies. By Anurada Herath

title: Wajira confident 135 MPs will support Budget
author: Author not found
Content: UNP MP Wajira Abeywardene says that he was confident that around 135 MPs will back the 2023 budget proposals, which were tabled in the House by the President, in his capacity as the Finance Minister, yesterday. He stated that most of the Opposition MPs, out of the 134 MPs who had supported the UNP Leader in his quest to become the President, during the vote in Parliament last July, would be compelled to continue to back the President. Abeywardene added that when it comes to the third reading of the budget and its final vote, the current Opposition will more or less cease to exist and opined the entire House could come to a stage of supporting all endeavours of the President. By Amith Gamage

title: Presentation on promotion
author: Author not found
Content: Volume 7 on Promoting Employment, Investment, Tourism, Education, Agriculture, and Foreign Policy was presented to Dinesh Weerakkody, Adviser to the President, at the Finance Ministry.

title: Ukuwela Sanasa bank accused of misappropriation
author: Author not found
Content: The Ukuwela Sanasa Bank Money Depositors Union said the management of Sanasa Bank at Ukuwela had misappropriated a sum of Rs 10 million belonging to depositors. Central Province Cooperatives Commissioner Amila Navaratne said he has lodged a complaint with the CID over the misappropriation of a sum, running into millions of rupees at the Sanasa Bank at Ukuwela, which is controlled by the Central Province Cooperatives Department. The Ukuwela Sanasa Bank Money Depositors Union charged that the management of the Bank had also not taken any measures towards the repayment of the misappropriated sum belonging to its depositors. BY K. L. Suraweera – Kandy

title: President taking steps to overcome economics crisis – Wajira
author: Author not found
Content: UNP Chairman MP Wajira Abeywardena claimed yesterday (14) that the budget presented in Parliament by President Ranil Wickremesinghe, as Finance Minister, is an initiative to transform Sri Lanka into a giant developed nation by 2048. “President Wickremesinghe has taken steps to overcome the country’s current economic crisis. Everyone must collaborate with him and work together until his objectives are met. When he was chastised, the President invited everyone to work together for the sake of the country’s future. Even when his house was set ablaze, the President was thinking about the future of this country,” Abeywardena pointed out. He was addressing the media at Sirikotha in connection with the budget 2023, the President had presented in Parliament and the timely action he had taken to resolve the prevailing economic crisis in the country. “On the concept of President Wickremesinghe a national council has been established to resolve the prevailing economic crisis in the country. Any political party can make their proposals and recommendations to it. It is a national responsibility of leaders of every political party in the country,” Abeywardena said. He added that two political parties had recently claimed that they have the plans and mechanisms to rebuild the collapsed economy of this country. If so they can produce it to the national council. The country wouldn’t gain any prosperity by making oral statements without having any proper plan. The situation of the country has been totally changed today every issue is being solved one by one under the administration of  President Wickremesinghe. The plans required to rebuild the country are being implemented successfully, Abeywardena said. He expressed confidence that the people of this country will be able to get fuel and gas without any shortage as necessary arrangements have been made through the budget. By Naalir Jamaldeen

title: Dinesh lauds China’s contribution to food security
author: Author not found
Content: Prime Minister Dinesh Gunawardena said China’s success in eradication of poverty, rural upliftment and ensuring food security has been exemplary. “Sri Lanka wishes to thank you for your magnanimous contributions to the efforts of my country as well as other developing nations towards achieving food security,” he said, virtually addressing the International Forum on Hybrid Rice Assistance and Global Food Security in Beijing last weekend. The Forum focused on China’s hybrid rice varieties that could revolutionise global food production and ensure food security. The Prime Minister expressed deep appreciation to the People’s Republic of China and Foreign Minister Wang Yi, who chaired the Forum, for the efforts taken on behalf of the people of the world who are affected by the food scarcity. Pointing out that such Forums go a long way to enhance efforts towards food security through coordinated action, he expressed confidence that the Forum would come up with useful plans that would ensure global food security and speed up achieving the 2030 Sustainable Development Goals. China’s partnership towards food security in Sri Lanka has a long history as Rubber-Rice Agreement between the two countries were signed way back in 1951, Premier Gunawardena said and recalled how the socialist leaders of Sri Lanka fought for the recognition of China, which was resisted by the pro-British Government, which ruled the country after independence in 1948. The socialist leaders used every available forum to highlight this demand, The leader of Mahajana Eksath Peramuna (MEP) Phillip Gunawardena, who attended the 4th Food & Agriculture Organisation (FAO) Regional Meeting for Asia and the Far East, held in 1959 in Tokyo as Minister of Agriculture & Food, urged the FAO to give membership to China. He ridiculed the West-dominated FAO for denying membership to China. “This Conference is being held without China, the biggest producer of rice in the world. Considering that, Ceylon earnestly proposes to the FAO to have China as a full member”, Phillip Gunawardena said.

title: Four CID officers under probe over gold robbery
author: Author not found
Content: An investigation has been launched against four officers of Peliyagoda Criminal Investigation Division over an alleged theft of gold. It was revealed that these Police officers had detained several individuals, who had gold items in their possession, on suspicion of selling gold items brought in from a foreign country. Despite this, the Police officers had released the suspects and the gold items due to a lack of evidence. The individuals, however, had filed a complaint against the Police officers, claiming that several gold items were missing. When contacted Police Media Spokesperson SSP Nihal Thalduwa confirmed that a sub-inspector, a sergeant and two constables have been suspended in connection with the incident. He said that the Peliyagoda Criminal Investigation Division is currently conducting investigations and on the receipt of the results ,steps will be taken against the four. BY Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: Rat fever hits Galle
author: Author not found
Content: Epidemiologist Dr. Eranda Hettiarachchi says that there has been a sudden steep increase in patients who have been stricken with rat fever (leptospirosis) in the Galle District. He said the disease has already shown signs of ravaging the District and observed that in the past month a total of 378 patients had been detected with rat fever. Dr. Hettiarachchi added that to date 11 deaths have also been recorded. He advised the public to be wary of the rapid spread of the disease and to seek immediate medical attention if they show symptoms of the disease. BY Farhan Nizamdeen – Galle

title: Ali invites all Muslim politicians to unite
author: Author not found
Content: General Secretary of United Peace Alliance (UPA) Hassan Ali invited all Muslim politicians, including those who represent the Eastern Province Muslims in Parliament to rally under the banner of unity and demand that the authorities grant people in the province their rights and privileges. “Nearly 62,000 acres of land have been lost to Muslims in the province. The Muslim community is divided due to regionalism and a variety of other factors. Muslim politicians must learn from their fellow communities about unity. Our villages have been separated into islands. This situation must be remedied. The Muslim community’s rights and privileges can only be won if their voices are raised collectively,” Ali said. He met village level organisers of the Party at a private guest house in the Kalmunai area to discuss the current political situation in the country as well as other issues the Muslim community was confronted with today. “The corrupt in the society were cheating the people giving them false promises. The Muslim politicians must get rid of such practices and work in unity taking the existence and future of Muslim community into consideration,” and  We have to fight together for the sake of our future generation”, Ali said. BY Naalir Jamaldeen

title: CEB Makes Rs 378M Generation Profit
author: Author not found
Content: Ceylon Electricity Board (CEB), due to the availability of cheap hydroelectricity, made an electricity generation profit of Rs 377,811,600 (Rs 378 million) on Sunday (13), yesterday’s (14) CEB data showed. Sri Lanka consumed a total of   30.97 Giga Watt hours (GWh) of electricity on Sunday, according to the CEB. Their splits being CEB Hydro (23.79 GWh), CEB Coal (5.22 GWh), private sector (PS) Mini Hydro (1.28 GWh), CEB Wind (O.09 GWh), PS Biomass (0.20 GWh), PS Solar (0.21 GWh), PS Wind (0.06 GWh) and CEB Fuel Oil (0.12 GWh). According to the Central Bank of Sri Lanka’s (CBSL) 2021 Annual Report, the cheapest source of electricity generation to the CEB last year was CEB Hydro at a cost of Rs 1.67 a kilo Watt hour (kWh) or per one unit of electricity. Other generation costs in ascending order  were CEB coal (Rs 10.68); CEB Wind,  PS Biomass, PS Mini Hydro  and PS  Wind bunched together (Rs 16.22), Independent Power Producers’ (IPP’)/PS Fuel Oil (Rs 30.35) and CEB Fuel Oil (Rs 32.03), respectively. However, on Saturday, no IPP’/PS Fuel Oil was consumed by CEB to generate electricity. According to CBSL, CEB’s average tariff rate last year was Rs 16.37 a unit.  The above calculations, based on last year’s costs data, discount CEB’s transmission and distribution losses estimated at 8.72 per cent last year and CEB’s 75 per cent tariff hike effective from 9 August 2022. By Paneetha Ameresekere

title: H’tota Port now one of the busiest
author: Author not found
Content: The CEO of the Hambanthota Port, Johnson Liu, says that the Port has rapidly emerged as one of the busiest harbours in the South Asian region within a short time span. He said that the Port had also created a new record by limiting the unloading time of goods to 57 per cent from the ship MV P. Yanbu. He noted that transporting of Marine Gas Oil –MGO and Very Low Sulfur Fuel Oil –VLSFO at the same time to a vessel had also been overseen at the Port. BY D. N. Jayasekera – Mattala

title: Cancellation of last bus leaves commuters in the lurch
author: Author not found
Content: Commuters charged that following the sudden cancellation of the last bus, leaving from the Nuwara Eliya bus depot to Hatton at 6.45 p.m. scores have been inconvenienced. These commuters alleged that the last private bus leaving for Hatton from Nuwara Eliya at the aforesaid time had been abruptly stopped leaving many high and dry. They said bus unions trot out various excuses for the sudden cancellation of the last bus plying to the said destination daily and they urged the SLTB officials to intervene in the issue and provide some relief to them. BY Neeta Pathma Kumari – Norwood

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Ukuwela Sanasa bank accused of misappropriation
author: Author not found
Content: The Ukuwela Sanasa Bank Money Depositors Union said the management of Sanasa Bank at Ukuwela had misappropriated a sum of Rs 10 million belonging to depositors. Central Province Cooperatives Commissioner Amila Navaratne said he has lodged a complaint with the CID over the misappropriation of a sum, running into millions of rupees at the Sanasa Bank at Ukuwela, which is controlled by the Central Province Cooperatives Department. The Ukuwela Sanasa Bank Money Depositors Union charged that the management of the Bank had also not taken any measures towards the repayment of the misappropriated sum belonging to its depositors. BY K. L. Suraweera – Kandy

title: President taking steps to overcome economics crisis – Wajira
author: Author not found
Content: UNP Chairman MP Wajira Abeywardena claimed yesterday (14) that the budget presented in Parliament by President Ranil Wickremesinghe, as Finance Minister, is an initiative to transform Sri Lanka into a giant developed nation by 2048. “President Wickremesinghe has taken steps to overcome the country’s current economic crisis. Everyone must collaborate with him and work together until his objectives are met. When he was chastised, the President invited everyone to work together for the sake of the country’s future. Even when his house was set ablaze, the President was thinking about the future of this country,” Abeywardena pointed out. He was addressing the media at Sirikotha in connection with the budget 2023, the President had presented in Parliament and the timely action he had taken to resolve the prevailing economic crisis in the country. “On the concept of President Wickremesinghe a national council has been established to resolve the prevailing economic crisis in the country. Any political party can make their proposals and recommendations to it. It is a national responsibility of leaders of every political party in the country,” Abeywardena said. He added that two political parties had recently claimed that they have the plans and mechanisms to rebuild the collapsed economy of this country. If so they can produce it to the national council. The country wouldn’t gain any prosperity by making oral statements without having any proper plan. The situation of the country has been totally changed today every issue is being solved one by one under the administration of  President Wickremesinghe. The plans required to rebuild the country are being implemented successfully, Abeywardena said. He expressed confidence that the people of this country will be able to get fuel and gas without any shortage as necessary arrangements have been made through the budget. By Naalir Jamaldeen
