title: President to present Budget 2023 today
author: Author not found
Content: President Ranil Wickremesinghe, in his capacity as the Finance Minister, will present Budget 2023 to Parliament today (14). It is aimed at creating long-term, stable economic growth. Budget 2023 has given special attention to sectors of the capital market, export, labour and digital economy. It is expected to achieve the budget targets through the social market economy. This year’s Budget will focus on providing social welfare benefits to the people who need them most and create a policy environment to build the private sector as the driving force of the country’s economy. Through Budget 2023, building a new economy tailored for the new world has been initiated to create a programme to ensure a decent country for the youth.

title: EPF LOSES RS 5B IN DEFUNCT GRAND HYATT PROJECT
author: Author not found
Content: The losses incurred by the Employees Provident Fund (EPF) investing in the now abandoned Grand Hyatt Colombo project have mounted to a thumping Rs 5 billion. A latest report compiled by the Auditor General’s Department on investments made by the EPF in listed and unlisted companies, revealed the country’s largest social security scheme has invested Rs 5,000 million in the Grand Hyatt Colombo project, with no profit made so far. According to the report, EPF has also incurred a loss of Rs 205.49 million as a result of ‘The Finance’ company’s licence being cancelled. Similarly, the report revealed the fund received no benefit from investing Rs 5,000 million, or 53 per cent of unlisted company equity investment in 2013, in the construction of Canwill Holdings (Pvt) Ltd, which is part of the Grand Hyatt Colombo project. Construction work of the hotel complex had not been completed by 27 December 2021 as planned. Although eight years had passed, the EPF has not received any benefit from the investment, the audit report pointed out. Meanwhile, the audit report reveals that 15,000 cards were purchased for Rs 12.61 million in 2008 for the purpose of issuing new ID cards and re-registration to EPF members, but the cards were never used. Similarly, the report states that two of the 35 machines purchased for Rs 17.67 million have been removed, and no appropriate measures have been taken for the remaining 33 machines. BY Amila Abeyrathne

title: Bad weather kills six, injures six
author: Author not found
Content: Inclement weather experienced in various parts of the country for over 12 days since 31 October to Thursday (10) killed six and injured a further six, the Disaster Management Centre (DMC) said yesterday (13). Three deaths were reported from Bandarawela, Haliella and Lunugala in the Badulla District on 31 October, 2 November, 3 November due to heavy rain, high wind and rain and heavy rain respectively. Meanwhile, two deaths were reported from the Kandy District on 1 November and 5 November due to drowning (Deltota, Kandy) and Rattota (wall collapse) respectively. The other death was reported from Seruwila, Trincomalee, 2 November, where the victim was struck by lightning, DMC said. The six injuries were reported from Kolonna, Ratnapura (two) due to flooding on 9 November; another two from Rambukkana, Kegalle on 7 November, lightning; one from Gangawata Koralaya, Kandy, 5 November, a flood victim and the other from Seruwila, Trincomalee, struck by lightning last Wednesday (9). Bad weather experienced during this period also impacted 916 families comprising 3,281; while displacing another 29 families (a total of 107 people). Ratnapura comprising 19 families encompassing 58 persons), Kegalle (44 and 182), Badulla (139 and 552), Kandy (36 and 118), Jaffna (305 and 1,025), Mullaitivu (five and 18), Mannar (one and four), Kilinochchi (50 and 157), Trincomalee (10 and 31), Batticaloa (117 and 406), Hambantota (13 and 61), Matara (16 and 67), Puttalam (102 and 353) and Colombo(two and nine). The breakdown of the displaced were Badulla 11 families comprising 48 people, Matale (four and 13), and Jaffna (14 and 46). Bad weather destroyed one house (Matale) and damaged another 198 in the reference period, DMC said. The District wise breakdown of the damaged houses were 16 (Ratnapura), 32 (Kegalle), 51 (Badulla), 40 (Kandy), 14 (Matale), one (Jaffna), five (Mullaitivu), one (Mannar), eight (Trincomalee) and one (Batticaloa). Inclement weather also damaged two critical infrastructure works located at Hambantota, DMC added. BY Paneetha Ameresekere

title: Unused lands should be cultivated – PM
author: Author not found
Content: Prime Minister Dinesh Gunawardena said, the State machinery should be more interested in making use of the opportunities provided via laws like the Land Reforms Act and the Agricultural Services Act to release land for cultivation. He urged Government officials to guide anyone who is interested.       “The Land Reform Commission should take immediate steps to cultivate the uncultivated lands currently held by the Mahaweli Authority and estate companies. The time has come for everyone to come together to end hunger in the country. No cultivable Government land should be left uncultivated. Officials cannot object or disturb cultivation in those lands. These lands are the inheritances of the people,” he said. Speaking at a Ratnapura District meeting on food security and nutrition held at the District Secretariat, he said after the collapse of the Kandyan Kingdom in 1815, the imperialists took possession of prosperous lands in many areas in the upcountry including the Ratnapura District. “Most of the lands that are now under the Government and estate companies are the inheritances that were stolen from those people. The people are asking to cultivate the heritage that was taken away from them to appease the hunger of the country today. This earth can make us self-sufficient with food. We should create an environment to instil confidence in agriculture for new youth entrepreneurs through that. Officials should always provide all support for that. We have to overcome enormous economic challenges that have arisen,” he said. Speaking further he also said Food safety is prioritised in many areas of programmes implemented by the Government. He said the Government has re-established the programme of providing fertiliser, seeds and other materials through the Government’s intervention. “Increasing the amount of cultivated land compared to last season, diverting uncultivated lands to cultivation, returning uncultivated lands for cultivation should be the ultimate goal achieved. We consider this opportunity as one of the main opportunities that the whole country can use for short-term and long-term programmes to win foreign exchange for the country. No need to wait for industries to come. Agriculture can be converted into an industry by producing crops that have a high demand. Until our goal is achieved, we must implement the cultivation of crops for food as well as for exports. We have been able to transform the most difficult time in respect of the economy into change,” he concluded.

title: Uththara Saubhagaya event ends in chaos
author: Author not found
Content: A group of youth from Kandy hooted MPs Wimal Weerawansa and Vasudeva Nanayakkara while they were leaving the Uththara Saubhagaya political event. After the conclusion of the meeting, which MPs Weerawansa and Nanayakkara, as well as a group of politicians who quit the Government attended, a group of Kandy youth staged a vehement protest against them. The youth hooted the politicians as they exited the hall, resulting in a heated situation between the two factions. However, while the youth were protesting, Weerawansa left the hall with his bodyguards and drove off in his vehicle, but due to the tense situation, Nanayakkara, Prof. Tissa Vitarana and others were unable to leave. While the tense situation continued, Nanayakkara and Prof. Vitarana left amidst loud opposition with police protection being afforded to them. The heated exchange lasted about 15 minutes, during which time Police officers present stood aside and watched silently. By K.L. Suraweera – Kandy

title: Farmers to get 7.5M litres of diesel free
author: Author not found
Content: During a discussion at the Kurunegala District Secretariat, Agriculture Minister Mahinda Amaraweera insisted that the Ministry of Agriculture had received 10.6 million litres of diesel from China and that 7.5 million litres would be given to farmers for free. The Minister said the sale of agro-chemicals illegally imported will be banned and this year’s harvest is expected to be successful. Various political groups and organisations, as well as a section claiming to be farmers are working to discourage the farming community from cultivating, he said. State Minister D.B. Herath and Public Affairs Minister Shantha Bandara, along with the Secretary of the Agriculture Ministry, Kurunegala District officials in charge of agriculture and wildlife participated. BY Ravindu Sooriyabandara – Kurunegala

title: SDIG Tennakoon orders immediate probe
author: Author not found
Content: SDIG Western Province Deshabandu Tennakoon has initiated an investigation against the Panadura South Police Chief Inspector and his team after they were caught on camera physically harassing a group of female protesters. Accordingly, an investigation has commenced into the incident and steps will be taken in this regard, Police Spokesman SSP Nihal Thalduwa said. The incident occurred in Panadura when five individuals who participated in a march on 12 November demanding the release of Inter-University Students Federation (IUSF) convener Wasantha Mudalige and Convener of the Inter-University Bhikku Federation (IUBF), Ven. Galwewa Siridhamma Thera. However, the group of individuals was arrested and later released on Police bail. BY Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: School attendance drops to 80%
author: Author not found
Content: The percentage of children attending school has decreased from 95 per cent to 80 per cent on a daily basis, due to the inability of the parents to provide food and purchase books and stationery items, Prof. P.P.A.W. Athukorala, Senior Lecturer at Peradeniya University’s Department of Economics and Statistics said. He said, prior to the economic crisis, the attendance was recorded at 95 per cent, but this has now dropped to 80 per cent across the island. He noted that attendance now has been recorded at 80 per cent on Mondays and 75 per cent on Fridays. When considering the Western Province in particular, only 75 per cent of students attend school but now it has decreased between 70 – 71 per cent.  “It has been found that the children are absent due to transportation and food supply issues. Children also face difficulties in buying books that are needed for their educational purposes in schools. Parents and the children are finding it difficult to buy the basics. These are the main reasons that the children do not want to go to school,” he said.   BY Thameeenah Razeek

title: TB cases increasing, mostly in Colombo – Expert
author: Author not found
Content: By the end of the first two quarters of 2022, 4,000 Tuberculosis (TB) patients had been reported across the country, with Colombo District accounting for 20 – 25 per cent of the cases diagnosed, according to Consultant Community Physician Dr. Onali Rajapaksa. She stated that in comparison to the previous two years, there has been a significant increase in Tuberculosis (TB) in the country, with the majority being reported in the Colombo District. “This is a significant increase, particularly when compared to 2020 and 2021. Approximately two-thirds of these are reported from Colombo Municipal Council area. The increase in TB is being attributed to the increased traffic in these areas as well as a lack of ventilation. Aside from these, drinking alcohol and smoking are also risk factors for tuberculosis,” she added. She described TB symptoms as a cough lasting more than two weeks, a slight fever, weight loss, chest pain and difficulty in breathing. See a doctor right away if you or anyone else noticed these symptoms, she said. BY Thameenah Razeek

title: Train derailments up this year
author: Author not found
Content: Sri Lanka Station Masters’ Union (SLSMU) said, there has been an increase in derailments this year when compared to previous years. There had been 29 derailments of passenger trains in 2020, 34 in 2021 and 41 derailments in 2022 to date. Furthermore, train operations are hampered due to derailments in the Dematagoda, Maligawatta, Colombo, Kolonnawa and Orugudawatta railway yards, according to SLSMU General Secretary Kasun Chamara. He said there were 38 derailments in those yards in 2020, 48  in 2021, and 31 so far in 2022. He noted that at the moment, the Railway Department is finding it impossible to obtain railway tracks. “The former General Manager of Railways cancelled the tender that was submitted at the time the relevant parts were to be obtained. However, the tender has been called again by the Minister of Transport and the intervention of the current General Manager of Railways and it is expected that Sri Lanka will receive the goods by March. However, due to the dilapidation of the railway lines, the relevant authorities have taken steps to impose various speed limits on all lines, such as 10 kmph, 20 kmph, and 40 kmph, at certain points, where derailing has occured” he said. Furthermore, he stressed that due to the imposition of these speed limits, train delays occur on a regular basis and this situation has harmed the operation of the coastal railway in particular. “We also believe that this situation arose as a result of the arrival of engines unfit for use on Sri Lanka’s railway lines. So far 296 railway gate wreckages have been reported In the 2020, there were 284 in 2021 and 274 in 2022. Furthermore, the number of accidents caused by vehicle collisions with trains at crossings has been reported to be 58  in 2020 and 2021, with 42 this year,” he said. BY Thameenah Razeek

title: UNP to take PS member to task
author: Author not found
Content: The UNP will take action against Sashi Hettiarachchi, a Local Government representative who protested in front of the Chinese Embassy in Colombo demanding China restructure Sri Lanka’s debt, according to Party General Secretary Palitha Range Bandara. “The United National Party has nothing to do with the protest organised by Pradeshiya Sabha Member Shashi Hettiarachchi. Our party believes in diplomacy, and the Government is working to resolve debt issues with… China through diplomatic ties,” said Range Bandara. In a statement, he said debt restructuring is a matter for the Minister of finance and not the Pradeshiya Sabha member. “The party will soon decide how to handle the Pradeshiya Sabha member. In Sri Lanka, debt restructuring is not a matter for any political party or individual. It is a project undertaken by the Ministry of Finance on behalf of the Sri Lankan Government. We do not participate in any diplomatic intervention by the Finance Ministry as a party. After being elected as people’s representatives in any party, their actions should be extremely responsibleand they should also keep in mind that arbitrary behaviour is not the way to advance of society, but prejudice,” he said

title: Three children die in Sooriyawewa boat accident
author: Author not found
Content: In a tragic turns of events, a boat carrying seven children and an eight-month-old infant capsized in Mahawelikada Aruva in Sooriyawewa, killing three children. The three victims, who were from Kurunegala, had travelled to Sooriyawewa with their relatives for an alms giving for their late grandfather, who had died by drowning three months ago. While the parents were busy preparing for the alms giving, the children had gone down to the lake with one of their cousins on 12 November. The cousin had rowed the boat with eight individuals including an eight-month-old infant. The group had taken pictures on the boat, but the vessel had capsized suddenly. The youth who was rowing the boat had saved himself along with the eight-month-old, while three other children were saved by a group of locals. Police launched a joint search operation with the Navy to look for the three missing children. The body of a 10-year-old was recovered on the same day and the bodies of the other two were recovered yesterday (13). The victims were aged 10, 16, and 18, and two of them were siblings. BY Aloka Kasturiarachchi and D.N. Jayasekara – Maththala

title: Bad weather kills six, injures six
author: Author not found
Content: Inclement weather experienced in various parts of the country for over 12 days since 31 October to Thursday (10) killed six and injured a further six, the Disaster Management Centre (DMC) said yesterday (13). Three deaths were reported from Bandarawela, Haliella and Lunugala in the Badulla District on 31 October, 2 November, 3 November due to heavy rain, high wind and rain and heavy rain respectively. Meanwhile, two deaths were reported from the Kandy District on 1 November and 5 November due to drowning (Deltota, Kandy) and Rattota (wall collapse) respectively. The other death was reported from Seruwila, Trincomalee, 2 November, where the victim was struck by lightning, DMC said. The six injuries were reported from Kolonna, Ratnapura (two) due to flooding on 9 November; another two from Rambukkana, Kegalle on 7 November, lightning; one from Gangawata Koralaya, Kandy, 5 November, a flood victim and the other from Seruwila, Trincomalee, struck by lightning last Wednesday (9). Bad weather experienced during this period also impacted 916 families comprising 3,281; while displacing another 29 families (a total of 107 people). Ratnapura comprising 19 families encompassing 58 persons), Kegalle (44 and 182), Badulla (139 and 552), Kandy (36 and 118), Jaffna (305 and 1,025), Mullaitivu (five and 18), Mannar (one and four), Kilinochchi (50 and 157), Trincomalee (10 and 31), Batticaloa (117 and 406), Hambantota (13 and 61), Matara (16 and 67), Puttalam (102 and 353) and Colombo(two and nine). The breakdown of the displaced were Badulla 11 families comprising 48 people, Matale (four and 13), and Jaffna (14 and 46). Bad weather destroyed one house (Matale) and damaged another 198 in the reference period, DMC said. The District wise breakdown of the damaged houses were 16 (Ratnapura), 32 (Kegalle), 51 (Badulla), 40 (Kandy), 14 (Matale), one (Jaffna), five (Mullaitivu), one (Mannar), eight (Trincomalee) and one (Batticaloa). Inclement weather also damaged two critical infrastructure works located at Hambantota, DMC added. BY Paneetha Ameresekere

title: Unused lands should be cultivated – PM
author: Author not found
Content: Prime Minister Dinesh Gunawardena said, the State machinery should be more interested in making use of the opportunities provided via laws like the Land Reforms Act and the Agricultural Services Act to release land for cultivation. He urged Government officials to guide anyone who is interested.       “The Land Reform Commission should take immediate steps to cultivate the uncultivated lands currently held by the Mahaweli Authority and estate companies. The time has come for everyone to come together to end hunger in the country. No cultivable Government land should be left uncultivated. Officials cannot object or disturb cultivation in those lands. These lands are the inheritances of the people,” he said. Speaking at a Ratnapura District meeting on food security and nutrition held at the District Secretariat, he said after the collapse of the Kandyan Kingdom in 1815, the imperialists took possession of prosperous lands in many areas in the upcountry including the Ratnapura District. “Most of the lands that are now under the Government and estate companies are the inheritances that were stolen from those people. The people are asking to cultivate the heritage that was taken away from them to appease the hunger of the country today. This earth can make us self-sufficient with food. We should create an environment to instil confidence in agriculture for new youth entrepreneurs through that. Officials should always provide all support for that. We have to overcome enormous economic challenges that have arisen,” he said. Speaking further he also said Food safety is prioritised in many areas of programmes implemented by the Government. He said the Government has re-established the programme of providing fertiliser, seeds and other materials through the Government’s intervention. “Increasing the amount of cultivated land compared to last season, diverting uncultivated lands to cultivation, returning uncultivated lands for cultivation should be the ultimate goal achieved. We consider this opportunity as one of the main opportunities that the whole country can use for short-term and long-term programmes to win foreign exchange for the country. No need to wait for industries to come. Agriculture can be converted into an industry by producing crops that have a high demand. Until our goal is achieved, we must implement the cultivation of crops for food as well as for exports. We have been able to transform the most difficult time in respect of the economy into change,” he concluded.

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: CEB Makes Rs 407 M Generation Profit
author: Author not found
Content: Ceylon Electricity Board (CEB), due to the availability of cheap hydroelectricity, made an electricity generation profit of Rs 407,439,300 (Rs 407 million) on Saturday (12 November), CEB’s yesterday’s (Sunday 13 November) data showed. Sri Lanka consumed a total of   34.48 Giga Watt hours (GWh) of electricity on Saturday, according to the CEB. Their splits being CEB Hydro (25.01 GWh), CEB Coal (7.44 GWh), private sector (PS) Mini Hydro (1.15 GWh), CEB Wind (O.18 GWh), PS Biomass (0.17 GWh), PS Solar (024 GWh),  PS Wind (0.11 GWh) and CEB Fuel Oil (0.18 GWh), respectively. According to Central Bank of Sri Lanka’s (CBSL’s) 2021 Annual Report, the cheapest source of electricity generation to the CEB last year was CEB Hydro at Rs 1.67 a kilo Watt hour (kWh) or per one unit of electricity. Other generation costs in ascending order  were CEB coal (Rs 10.68);CEB Wind,  PS Biomass, PS Mini Hydro  and PS  Wind bunched together (Rs 16.22), Independent Power Producers’ (IPP’)/PS Fuel Oil (Rs 30.35) and CEB Fuel Oil (Rs 32.03), respectively. However, on Saturday, no IPP’/PS Fuel Oil was consumed by CEB to generate electricity. According to CBSL, CEB’s average tariff rate last year was Rs 16.37 a unit.  The above calculations, based on last year’s costs data, discount CEB’s transmission and distribution losses estimated at 8.72 per cent last year and CEB’s 75 per cent tariff hike effective from 9 August 2022. BY Paneetha Ameresekere

title: Premajayantha says English education to be enhanced from 2023
author: Author not found
Content: The Minister of Education Dr. Susil Premajayantha instructed the National Institute of Education (NIE) to find out whether there are grammatical errors in English medium school textbooks. He also said, steps will be taken from 2023 onwards to strengthen spoken English from the first grade. Accordingly, the Minister said, that all arrangements have been made to train approximately 13,500 teachers in first and second grades of government schools in all provinces on 18 and 19 November. The Minister said these in response to a request made by MP Vasudeva Nanayakkara urging to prioritise English for school students in a way that suits future needs. Furthermore, the request to provide opportunity to students in Tamil schools to study in the Sinhala medium if they opt to do so was also considered at a recent committee meeting. The MPs also pointed that students in Tamil schools in Sinhala-majority areas are interested in learning in the Sinhala medium.  At present, drugs are spreading very rapidly in schools, so the members were of the opinion that urgent measures should be taken to prevent it, and the chairman mentioned that measures have already been taken. There was a discussion about universities teaching certain courses in English only and the Chairman of the University Grants Commission, Prof. Sampath Amaratunge, said that at present, even in Arts faculty, studies are conducted in English. Member of Parliament Hon. Vasudeva Nanayakkara said that there is a need for teachers who can teach in both Sinhala and English languages. The request made by the Member of Parliament Hon. Madhura Withanage to pay attention to a complaint received regarding an irregularity in the appointment of a headmistress to Visakha Vidyalaya Colombo was discussed at length. The officials present explained in detail the principal recruitment procedure and the changes made to it in the past. Furthermore, the request made by Member of Parliament Hon. Upul Mahendra Rajapaksha to provide a portion of land belonging to the Faculty of Education in Siane for the sports activities of Vidyaloka Maha Vidyalaya was also considered.

title: RE also dominates electricity sector for 105 consecutive days
author: Author not found
Content: Cheap and clean renewable energy (RE) led by “Ceylon Electricity Board (CEB) Hydroelectricity” and aided by record daily power cuts since last year (2021), provided over 50 per cent or more of Sri Lanka’s electricity demand for 105 consecutive days to Saturday (12 November), Ceylon Electricity Board’s (CEB’s) yesterday’s (Sunday, 13 November 2022) data showed. The present reference period where RE dominated Sri Lanka’s electricity landscape for 105 consecutive days begins on 31 July 2022. Further, out of the total of 316 calendar days that have transpired in the calendar year to Saturday, RE was responsible for providing 50 per cent or more of Sri Lanka’s electricity needs in 155 (49.05 per cent) of those days, CEB statistics further showed. Such a phenomenon last took place at least four years ago in 2018. In the prior period this year, i.e. before the reference 105 consecutive day period to Saturday, Sri Lanka’s electricity sector was dominated by the more expensive and dirty fossil fuels (FFs). RE comprises CEB Hydroelectricity, CEB Wind, Private Sector (PS) Biomass, PS Solar, PS Mini Hydro and PS Wind, respectively. FFs comprise CEB Coal and Fuel Oil and PS/Independent Power Producers’ (IPP’) Fuel Oil, respectively. According to Central Bank of Sri Lanka’s (CBSL’s) 2021 Annual Report, the cheapest source of electricity generation to the CEB last year was CEB Hydro at Rs 1.67 a kilo Watt hour (kWh) or per one unit, followed by CEB coal (Rs 10.68);CEB Wind, PS Biomass, PS Mini Hydro and PS  Wind bunched together (Rs 16.22), (IPP’/PS Fuel Oil (Rs 30.35) and CEB Fuel Oil (Rs 32.03), respectively. Meanwhile, of the total electricity, i.e. 34.48 Giga Watt hours (GWh) generated on Saturday, RE was responsible for 77.90 per cent (26.86GWh) and FFs 7.62GWh (22.10 per cent) of electricity generation respectively.  Meanwhile, “CEB Hydro” dominated Sri Lanka’s electricity landscape on Saturday, being responsible for 25.01GWh of electricity generated on that day. 25.01GWh is equivalent to 72.53 per cent of total electricity generated on Saturday and 93.11 per cent of total RE electricity generated on that day. CEB Hydro comprises the Laxapana, Mahaweli and Samanala hydro complexes. Meanwhile, on Saturday Laxapana generated 6.67GWh of electricity equivalent to 26.67 per cent of total CEB Hydro generated on that day, data showed. Meanwhile, Mahaweli generated 15.62GWh of electricity equivalent to 62.46 per cent of CEB Hydro and 45.30 per cent of total electricity generated on that day and Samanala, comprising both Samanala Wewa and Kukule Ganga Hydro Electric Power projects (HEPPs),2.71GWh or 10.84 per cent of total ‘CEB Hydro’,. In related developments, ‘Mahaweli Hydro’ comprises Victoria, Randenigala, Rantanbe, Kotmale and Upper Kotmale Hydroelectric Power Projects (HEPPs), respectively. Victoria, Randenigala, Rantanbe and Kotmale HEPPs were built during the J.R. Jayewardene era after obtaining grant and concessional aid from the West. Upper Kotmale, conceptualised during the Jayewardene era was built during the Mahinda Rajapaksa era after obtaining concessional Japanese aid. Samanala, comprising Samanala wewa conceptualised during the Jayewardene era was built during the Ranasinghe Premadasa era after obtaining concessional aid from Japan and Kukule Ganga conceptualised during the Premadasa era was built during the Chandrika Bandaranaike era after obtaining concessional aid from Japan. Laxapana, built during the D. S. Senanayake with Sri Lanka’s own money was subsequently extended after obtaining concessional World Bank aid. BY Paneetha Ameresekere

title: President poised to fulfil duties beyond IMF recommendations – Sagala
author: Author not found
Content: President expects to fulfil the responsibilities for the people far exceeding the recommendations made by the International Monetary Fund (IMF), Senior Adviser to the President on National Security Sagala Ratnayake said.                He said that Sri Lanka could ensure its development through an export-oriented industry. “The Government has already commenced the programme to increase foreign investments and create a conducive background for developing export-oriented industries. The Government has laid the foundation in setting the background to ensure the leaders of the country are responsible for the country’s economy, within a legal framework,” he said. Ratnayake made this observation while laying the foundation stone for a new boatyard of the Northwest Marine Lanka Pvt. Ltd. at the Dikowita Fisheries Harbour, Wattala. He commended the private sector’s contribution in reinvigorating the economy at a time when the country is experiencing repercussions of inconsistent fiscal management policy in the past.

title: Illegal gem mining causes untold damage to Horton Plains – Warden
author: Author not found
Content: Large-scale illegal gem mining in the Bogawanthalawa Maha Eliya Reserve was causing untold damage to both the environment and to the Horton Plains, so said  Warden P. B. Dayaratne. Approximately 25 acres of land in the reserve have been destroyed. This area comes under the purview of the Bogawanthalawa Police Division. According to reports, a group of gem smugglers in Hatton, Bogawanthalawa, Norwood, Balangoda, and Ratnapura carry out illegal gem mining, employing approximately 200 people per day. Many water sources in Keselgamu Oya, he claims, have also been destroyed. It has been reported that those engaged in illegal gem mining have even temporarily constructed small huts in the reserve and carry out gem mining when they stay over in the reserve, according to Dayaratne. Dayaratne said, during a raid carried out by  officials on 12 November three people who were engaged in unauthorised gem mining were arrested while the other suspects fled inside the reserve,. An operation was launched to apprehend the suspects. He said, if steps are not taken to stop illegal gem mining that is causing great environmental damage and destroying water sources in the Reserve, it may have a significant impact on the Castlereagh Reservoir, so, raids will continue in the reserve. BY Neeta Pathma Kumari – Bogawanthalawa

title: Police bust rupees-to-dollar racket in Jaffna
author: Author not found
Content: Four suspects were arrested by the Jaffna Police over a dollar scam and financial fraud. The suspects were arrested on Wednesday (9) following a special operation by the Jaffna Police and the Police STF based on complaints of financial fraud. According to Police, the suspects had defrauded individuals from several areas promising them dollars in exchange for rupees.  The suspects had also promised to sell vehicle spare parts cheap. Investigations revealed that after the victims arrive at the agreed location the suspects rob the money and flee the scene. They are reported to have taken Rs 2.5 million and Rs 1.8 million from two individuals in Jaffna and Rs 1,080,000 from another individual in Galle. The Police said the suspects had been involved in robberies in Jaffna, Anuradhapura, Colombo, Kalutara, Galle and Matara. They have been identified as residents of Trincomalee, Talawakelle and Anuradhapura, aged between 33 – 53 years.  Following the arrest, the Police seized USD 825 and Rs 2.8 million from the suspects.   The suspects have been remanded until 22 November after being produced before the Jaffna Magistrate’s Court on 10 November. BY Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: Suspect in illegal liquor business apprehended
author: Author not found
Content: Ja Ela Police said the Police Special Task Force turned over an individual who had long been involved in illegal liquor brewing on 12 November. According to Ja Ela Police, a team of STF officers led by Police OIC (Special Operations) S. D. P. N. Deshapriya, attached to the Gonahena STF Camp Special Operations Unit, raided a house on the Minuwangoda Road after receiving information from the Gonahena Police Special Task Force (STF) where an individual who had long been involved in illegally brewing liquor was residing. BY S. S. H. Lunuwila – Wadduwa

title: AVIATION UNIT NO. 8 CONTINGENT PASSING OUT PARADE
author: Author not found
Content: The Passing Out Parade of the No. 8 Contingent of Aviation Unit under the United Nations Multidimensional Peacekeeping Mission in Central African Republic (MINUSCA) was held on 11 November at SLAF Base Katunayake. Commander of the Air Force, Air Marshal Sudarshana Pathirana took the salute of the parade which was commanded by Wing Commander Kanchana Liyanarachchi, the Deputy Contingent Commander of the 8th Contingent. This Heli-deployment comprises of 20 Officers and 89 Airmen which is scheduled to proceed to Central Africa Republic by first week of December. During the parade three servicemen namely, Flight Sergeant G. H. Kumara, Leading Aircraftman W. M. S. M. Jayasooriya, Leading Aircraftman O. A. A. Darmasiri were honoured with insignia of Load Master by the Commander of the Air Force. The Commander addressed the parade troops and said “UN Headquarters has appreciated the Sri Lanka Air Force aviation contingents deployed in the Central African Republic due to the display of bravery, service professionalism and devotion to duty of our service personnel”. This achievement of the Sri Lanka Air Force speaks volumes of the trust and confidence commanded by the entire military forces of Sri Lanka and would go a long way in boosting the Nation’s image further in the international arena. Besides, this endeavour would bring substantial economic gains to the country as well, he added. The Parade was followed by a socialising event attended by the Chief of Staff and members of the Air Force Board of Management, officers, other ranks of the 8th Contingent along with their family members.

title: Army distributes dry ration packs
author: Author not found
Content: An extension to the Army Chief’s conceptual notion to distribute dry ration packs to soldiers and civil employees got to a start at Panagoda Sri Bodhirajaramaya on 12 November, headed by Lieutenant General Vikum Liyanage, Commander of the Army.       Organised jointly by the Security Force Headquarters – West (SFHQ-West) and the Army Seva Vanitha Unit (ASVU), the project distributed 250 dry ration packs, consisted of rice, dhal, potatoes, onions, chili powder and flour among selected families living in Homagama area at first after inviting the beneficiaries to the temple premises. Ven. Bodagama Chandima Nayake Thera, Vice Chancellor at Nagananda International Buddhist Centre sponsored the stock of dry rations, appreciative of the services rendered by Army and civil employees employed by the Army.  Troops of the Security Force Headquarters – West in collaboration with the Commander’s Secretariat and the Army Seva Vanitha Unit under the supervision of Major General D.M.K.D.B. Pussella, Commander SF-West arranged the distribution project.  Chief Guest, Lieutenant General Liyanage moved to the Panagoda Army Cantonment gymnasium where another group of 200 Army and civil employees serving the Army Cantonment at Panagoda were given relief dry ration packs to mitigate economic hardship. The Army Seva Vanitha Unit gave rice packets under the instructions of Janaki Liyanage, President, ASVU. Janaki Liyanage, Brigadier General Staff, Brigadier K.V.N.P. Premaratne RSP USP psc and Brigadier Admin and Quartering, Brigadier D.A. Amarasekara USP of SFHQ (West), Senior officers, officers and other ranks participated in the event.

title: Defence allocation increased to aid exports – President
author: Author not found
Content: President Ranil Wickremesinghe emphasised the importance of having increased defence allocations as the country is looking at an economy that will be highly competitive and export-oriented. Acknowledging that there may be questions raised as to why the Government is focusing so much on the armed forces, and why the Government is looking at Defence 2030, he said that if not, the country will not have a future. “None of us want the armed forces to go to war or to fight anywhere. That is not what we have to do to defend the country. But we are living in a different world from what we were born into. When we were born, there was no tussle for the Indian Ocean. At one stage, no one wanted it. Today it is not so. If we are to survive, the skills, the security skills, Strategic Studies, all that has to be utilised,” he added. The President said, the country cannot have an export-oriented industry unless it has the freedom of navigation. “If goods cannot be moved around, and the freedom of navigation is interrupted, what will happen,” he queried?  “In 2021, we saw what happened when people could not move out of our country and goods could not be transported either by land or sea,” he said. The President highlighted the significance of preparing the armed forces to face future threats while addressing the General Convocation of the Kotelawala Defence University (KDU). He said, the security and strategic skills of the armed forces should be utilised, if the country wants to survive. President Wickremesinghe said, the country’s future depends on its ability to get goods across under situations where the environment we are in will not be one controlled by us. “The actions of other people will impact us in Sri Lanka so we have to use political skills, our diplomatic skills and our military skills to ensure that our right of navigation, the right to come into Sri Lanka and go by sea and by air is not interrupted in any way. So, all these three skills are necessary.  That is why if you are building a country you must also look at the future,” he said. The President commended the KDU for having attained their mark in the civilian streams, where he noted that many prefer to enter the KDU rather than a normal university. To carry that forward, the President said that he had instructed the Ministry of Finance and the Secretary of Defence to look at starting another campus of the KDU mainly for civil subjects, in Kurunegala. He explained that the reason for selecting Kurunegala was because that was the constituency that was represented by Sir John Kotelawala in 1931. Hence, he said that it is appropriate that the people of Kurunegala should get the benefit and the Treasury had already been instructed to set aside monies to upgrade the hospital in Kurunegala to a teaching hospital as well. This, he noted will make Wayamba one of the two Districts in Sri Lanka where there is more than one teaching hospital which is good for the people. “But more than the civilian studies, we also have to look at the future, the future of our country, the future of our security and what role the university is going to play there. I have noted that the KDU has increased their endeavours to ensure that middle-level officers and senior-level officers also receive postgraduate education, either through this institution or the National Defence College (NDC) where many other one-star officers and two-star officers also benefit from it. That is necessary. We should go further. One of the objectives of the Defence University is to ensure that the top leadership and the middle leadership are all educated and their level of leadership is increased so that you have one of the best Military Leaderships in the region,” he said. The President stressed that this is a task that has to be fulfilled.

title: Title not found
author: Author not found
Content: Date:  The Jaffna District Disaster Management (DMC) has established two emergency hotline numbers to assist the public in case of worsening inclement weather conditions. T.N. Sooriyarajah, Assistant Director of the Jaffna District DMC, stated on Friday (11) that the hotline numbers 0773957894, 117, and 0212117117 can be called for assistance. The public in disaster prone areas, predominantly with high-flooding risk, have been advised to be vigilant, exercise caution and be prepared to evacuate in case of bad weather. The DMC District office is closely monitoring the situation and DMC officials, Police and Tri-Forces are on standby to carry out relief missions and evacuations, Sooriyarajah added By Naalir Jamaldeen Popular

title: PM, OPPOSITION LEADER AND SPEAKER WILL HAVE TO QUIT – PRESIDENT
author: Author not found
Content: President Ranil Wickremesinghe, while insisting that the setting up the Constitutional Council (CC) is a must, in Parliament yesterday (10), asserted that if failed to appoint three civil society representatives, all three – Prime Minister, Opposition Leader and the Speaker — must resign, as it is a clear display of not commanding the confidence of the House. “If there is opposition to three civil society nominees by the PM, Opposition Leader and the Speaker all three must resign. It shows PM does not command the confidence of the ruling party, the Opposition leader of the opposition and the Speaker of both parties,” he opined.  In his special statement to Parliament, he said there is one issue and that is the appointment of civil members to the Constitutional Council, adding that they are nominated by the Prime Minister and the Opposition Leader and attested by the Speaker. “As MP Lakshman Kiriella spoke on the 17th Amendment to the Constitution, I would like to say that the 17th Amendment, 19th and the 21st Amendments were passed by both the Government side and the Opposition. We have to set up the Constitutional Council. There is seemingly one issue which is not an issue about the appointment of Civil members to the Constitutional Council,” he said. He asked how Parliament could oppose them and if they did, the Prime Minister and the Opposition Leader would have no support of the Government side and the Opposition side and the Speaker would not have the support of the entire Parliament. “It is a scenario in which all three should resign. It was the same practice with the 19th Amendment. It’s a procedural event. So, let us have their names. I told the Prime Minister too. Let’s talk it over with the Speaker and get three names. If the Tamil parties nominate, after identifying those who are not members of the SJB, we could solve the issue of the civil nominees. Last time we made appointments from the Tamils as well as Women. This time we could make representation from Muslims and if there are no such candidates, we can allow a female again. After that, all the commissions could be appointed soon and could continue smoothly. Therefore, I request all to assist in this endeavour,” he said. Meanwhile, he also said the IMF Managing Director promised to assist Sri Lanka. He said there is nothing to worry about it and therefore, the discussion with China and India is only needed. “China asked us to commence talks after their party convention. Now talks have commenced. I request both countries to finalise it by the end of December. I thank the Chief Opposition Whip for stating that they would boycott the debate, if they do not know about these matters. So the Government side and the Opposition could pass it,” he said.

title: CID to probe ‘ragging’
author: Author not found
Content: The CID has been assigned to investigate the complaints filed over the incidents of ‘ragging,’ Police said. The Police yesterday (10) said the above decision has been taken according to an order of the IGP. The IGP has issued directives to all senior Police Officers by asking to forward the complaints received at the Police stations to the CID for investigation. By Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: No major issue with food security in SL next year – President
author: Author not found
Content: President Ranil Wickremesinghe saiad even though 20 to 30 million Africans are affected by food scarcity, COP27 has not made space to discuss about it, even though there will be a large number of deaths in the Horn of Africa. He said Sri Lankans have gone through problematic stages regarding food security and thanked the countries that helped. “We won’t have a major issue with food security during next year, hopefully. But Africa is pretty bad, 20 to 30 million people will be affected. There will be a large number of deaths in the Horn of Africa. There is no aid or assistance. It was not discussed. Now, in addition some of them can’t grow food and others can’t get fertiliser to grow food, they haven’t the money, so we have to help them. Secondly, they are affected, especially by the fact that most are in debt. So, in my view, we should give those countries that are having serious problems with food scarcity, the same terms that the IMF gave to Ukraine. Ukraine was fighting a war with Russia. These people are fighting a war for survival,” he said. He said therefore, they should ask the West to give the same support that was given to Ukraine. President Wickremesinghe said to avoid impacts of climate change in the next 20-30 years, South Asian countries should go to COP28 and lock horns with the G20 on the 1.5 °C target by 2050. In a special statement to Parliament yesterday (10), he said according to the Secretary-General of the United Nations, in the next 20-30 years the situation will become more serious. “We listened to the Pakistani Prime Minister and we studied the situation where the melting of the Himalayas affected Pakistan. But not only that, Nepal says it is going to affect them, it is going to affect India where the Ganges runs, and it is going to affect Bangladesh because the Ganges and the Brahmaputra rivers both flow through Bangladesh. It is going to affect Myanmar because the Irrawaddy River and the San Win rivers flow through Myanmar. It is going to affect the Maldives, which will go underwater and it is going to affect us because part of our Western Coast will go underwater. Even places like Kanyakumari on the tip of South India will go underwater. That is the threat that all of us are facing. But there is no major response on this by world powers,” he said. Further, he said they have to be ready to discuss it with like-minded countries. He said both the Sri Lankan Minister of Foreign Affairs and Minister of Environment can do that. “But those countries are waiting and Sri Lanka has to join them. We must, as far as possible, support it, and on some occasions take the lead on this issue.”

title: Pradeep Wijewardana’s family donates Rs 200,000
author: Author not found
Content: The family of Pradeep Wijewardana donated a sum of Rs 200,000 to the ‘Deegawapiya Trust Fund’ at the Defence Ministry premises on 9 November. Defence Secretary, General Kamal Gunaratne, who is also the Author of the ‘Deeghawapi Aruna Trust’ and ‘First Trustee’ received the donation from Sakunthala Kodagoda (wife) and their son Chris Wijewardana.  The Wijewardana family, who are involved in the restoration of Deegawapiya Stupa, had also donated a sum of Rs 100,000 on 27 September and contributed to this noble cause.  Deegawapiya, a place visited by Lord Buddha, is regarded as one of the most sacred ancient religious sites among the sixteen places of worship of Buddhists. The expedited restoration process which commenced under General Gunaratne’s guidance has witnessed much progress. The process is funded by the ‘Deegawapiya Aruna Trust Fund’ which is generously supported by philanthropists. Plans are afoot to restructure the Sacred Stone-Paved Precincts (Salapathala Maluwa), a fully-fledged Pilgrim’s Rest House (Vishrama Shalawa), and also to create a charming environment by planting saplings of Sal (shorea robusta) and ironwood within the premises. Those who are eager to witness the former glory of Deegawapiya Stupa and to extend their generous support can get further details via the Deegawapiya website www.deegawapiya.lk, email: [email protected], or contact 011 2430860-78.

title: Budget compiled within IMF recommendations – President
author: Author not found
Content: President Ranil Wickremesighe yesterday (10) acknowledged in Parliament that the Budget proposals for 2023 had been compiled within the framework of an economic programme recommended by the International Monetary Fund (IMF). He was responding to Opposition MPs’ query on the Budget. “What we will focus on in the Budget is whether to increase direct taxes or indirect taxes and on controlling State expenditure. This will be the framework of the Budget and it will also reflect the economic targets set by the IMF,” he said. Responding to a question, raised by the Chief Opposition Whip Lakshman Kiriella, on whether the programme which the government had agreed with the IMF would be presented to the House before the Budget, the President said it will be presented after the next round of discussions are completed.  “It won’t be too long as we have to get into tri-party agreements with debtors,” he said. The basis of the discussions with the debtors is to see whether the debt would be written off or whether Sri Lanka would be given more time to settle them, he added. The President requested the Speaker, Prime Minister and the Leader of Opposition to expedite the appointment of a Constitutional Council. “The Prime Minister, Speaker and the Leader of Opposition will have to agree on the names of three civil members who will represent the Constitutional Council. This is just a matter of three names and will not be time consuming. It will be possible to appoint Independent Commissions after the Constitutional Council is finalised and formed,” he said. Also, he said he would meet the MPs representing North and the East soon to discuss the issues pertaining to them. He assured that the legislations pertaining to the Truth and Reconciliation Commission, the Counter Terrorism Bill and the Anti-Corruption Bill will be presented to the House in February next year.

title: WB Chief assures support to SL
author: Author not found
Content: World Bank Group President David Malpass met President Ranil Wickremesinghe on 8 November in Sharm el-Sheikh, Egypt on the sidelines of the COP27 Climate Change Conference. President Malpass and President Wickremesinghe discussed the challenging macroeconomic and social situation in Sri Lanka and the urgent need to stabilise the economy. President Malpass emphasised the importance of timely and effective resolution of the ongoing debt crisis and encouraged President Wickremesinghe to continue engaging with Sri Lanka’s official bilateral and private sector creditors to promptly agree on debt restructuring. Further, President Malpass and President Wickremesinghe discussed ways to improve the efficiency of public expenditures and necessary reforms to state-owned enterprises, particularly given the large size of the public sector in Sri Lanka. President Malpass affirmed the World Bank Group’s (WBG) support to the Sri Lankan people in rebuilding their economy and creating a foundation for sustainable private sector-led growth through IDA concessional financing, technical assistance, and policy advice. In addition, President Malpass and President Wickremesinghe discussed opportunities to improve agriculture production and value chains, including through effective programmes supporting fertiliser use, as well as Sri Lanka’s large potential in the service sector, including tourism and education. Finally, President Malpass and President Wickremesinghe also spoke about climate change and the financing needs of developing countries to pursue impactful adaptation and mitigation investment.

title: World population to reach 8B on 15 Nov – UN
author: Author not found
Content: The United Nations estimated this week that the world’s population will reach eight billion on 15 November and that India will replace China as the world’s most populous nation next year. In a report released on World Population Day, the UN also said global population growth fell below one per cent in 2020 for the first time since 1950. According to the latest UN projections, the world’s population could grow to around 8.5 billion in 2030. That number will jump to 9.7 billion in 2050 and a peak of around 10.4 billion during the 2080s. It is forecast to remain at that level until 2100. The report says more than half the projected increase in population up to 2050 will be concentrated in just eight countries: Congo, Egypt, Ethiopia, India, Nigeria, Pakistan, the Philippines and Tanzania. The report, “World Population Prospects 2022,” puts the world’s population at 7.942 billion now and forecasts it will reach 8 billion in mid-November.

title: Ali Sabry appoints special officer to settle issues
author: Author not found
Content: Minister of Foreign Affairs Ali Sabry appointed a special officer, attached to the Ministry, to settle the issue that had arisen in regard to the contaminated Chinese organic fertiliser shipment imported by Sri Lanka in 2021 for which a sum of 6.7 million USD was paid by the Sri Lankan Government.  Minister of Agriculture Mahinda Amaraweera previously requested President, at a Cabinet Meeting, to obtain the support of Sabry to solve the issue in a manner that would not damage the long-term friendly relations between Sri Lanka and the Chinese Government. Accordingly, a discussion was held yesterday (10), and Sabry appointed a special officer of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and informed the officials of the Ministry of Agriculture to provide all necessary support to that officer.

title: Teen arrested for assaulting meter reader
author: Author not found
Content: A 17-year-old was arrested by Payagala Police for brutally assaulting a water meter reader. According to hospital sources, N.W.M. Kamal Lasantha, a meter reader attached to the National Water Supply and Drainage Board’s Payagala regional office, was admitted to the Kalutara Teaching Hospital and is being treated in Ward No. 32. The victim water meter reader was in the business of issuing water bills in North Payagala. Police say the assault occurred after a lengthy discussion over the meter reader writing 607 units instead of 601 on the water bill of the suspect’s house. According to a statement given to the Police by the meter reader, he fell to the ground after being attacked by the suspect. Payagala Police are conducting investigations. BY Bimal Jayasinghe (Colombo) and Sumith Ranawaka (Pothupitiya)

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Parliament security beefed up for Budget
author: Author not found
Content: Special security measures will be implemented in Parliament in light of the presentation of Budget 2023 by the Finance Minister on 14 November, Speaker Mahinda Yapa Abeywardena announced in Parliament yesterday (10). The Speaker informed the House that security arrangements will be made similar to the previous year. Further, the entire Parliament building, including the MPs’ rest rooms and wardrobes will be searched today (11). In addition, when the Budget is presented in Parliament on 14 November, the public gallery will be limited to diplomats. As the Parliament car park will be closed, the vehicles of MPs will be directed to designated car parks, and the Speaker requested MPs to be accompanied by a driver if possible. The Speaker also informed if the MPs decide to drive, then drivers belonging to the parliamentary staff will be deployed at the entrance to drive the vehicles to the designated car park. By Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: Thai Tusker Muthu Raja to return home
author: Author not found
Content: Muthu Raja, the tusker gifted by Thailand to Sri Lanka, will be flown back to Thailand soon. The tusker was allegedly abused and neglected at the Kande Viharaya Temple, Aluthgama, prior to being brought to the National Zoological Gardens in Dehiwela two days ago. In 2001, the tusker was gifted to the Sri Lankan Government by the Queen Mother of Thailand, Rajawongse Sirikit Kitiyakara. The Thai Government thought that he would carry the sacred tooth relics at the Kandy Esala Perahera. “But the Sri Lankan Government placed him under the custody of the Aluthgama Kande Viharaya. The Sri Lankan Government didn’t take any action so we got the Thai Government to intervene,” rally for Animal Rights and Environment (RARE) Panchali Magdalena Panapitiya told Ceylon Today. She said, “we asked the Thai Government to stop the abusing of Muthu Raja. They sent vets and we are very happy about that. Muthu Raja has gone through a lot of suffering and abuse in his life. So we want Muthu Raja to be retired. We want him to be sent to a sanctuary that practices positive reinforcement for the interacting with other elephant,” Panapitiya said. A place where there will be no bull hooks and shouting at the elephant, she said. “We can only request the Thai Government to consider this. If the Thai Government allows Muthu Raja to be kept in Sri Lanka then he should be sent to the Safari Park in Hambantota which is a suitable place. If the Zoo Department wants, we as Private citizens and Animal Welfare Organisations can create a fence to keep Muthu Raja in an enclosure without chains,” Panapitiya explained. She says at present these fences are not available at Ridiyagama and if he is in an enclosed area he can be kept chain-free even during the musth period. “We can bring down foreign experts to teach our staff and our mahouts how to take care of Muthu Raja by using positive reinforcement. But this choice is not in our hands. It is with the Thai government. So we hope that Muthu Raja will be retired in this manner and left free of abuse and suffering,” Panapitiya said.    National Zoological Gardens Director General Dr. Thilak Premakantha told Ceylon Today that Muthu Raja was brought to the Dehiwela Zoo on the instructions of the Thai Embassy. “I was not given a date as to when Muthu Raja will be taken from the Dehiwela Zoo,” Dr Premakantha said.   By Risidra Mendis

title: ‘Ice’ included in Dangerous Drugs Amendment Act
author: Author not found
Content: Minister of Justice, Prisons Affairs and Constitutional Reforms Dr. Wijeyadasa Rajapakshe said new types of dangerous drugs have been included in the Poisons, Opium and Dangerous Drugs Amendment Act. Speaking in Parliament yesterday (10) he said at the time when the Poisons, Opium and Dangerous Drugs Act was passed, the dangerous drug called ‘Ice’ (crystal methamphetamine) was not included. He emphasised that Ice has been included in this amendment act. “Several important matters have been included in this bill. New dangerous drugs that were not available at the time of the passing of this bill have been introduced to society today. At present, society has become deluged with these drugs. Ice was not mentioned in the act,” he stressed. The Minister added that Ice is a very dangerous drug and they sought the opinion of specialist doctors about it. He said it destroys the brain cells of users. By Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: VAT Bill not inconsistent with Constitution
author: Author not found
Content: Speaker Mahinda Yapa Abewardena yesterday informed the House that the Supreme Court has determined that the Value Added Tax (VAT) (Amendment) Bill, in its entirety, is not inconsistent with the Constitution subject to the amendments proposed by the Deputy Solicitor General being moved at the Committee Stage. He told Parliament that the Bill was challenged in the Supreme Court. The proposed amendments are (i) Clause 3 — The insertion of the following proviso in Section 10 (1) — “Provided further, for the purposes of paragraph (vii), the requirement for the registration shall rise from the date on which this Amendment Act comes into operation.” (ii) Clause 4(1) – the reference to “September 30, 2022” to be deleted and substituted with “November 30, 2022”. (iii) Clause 4(2) – the reference to “October 1, 2022” to be deleted and substituted with “December 1, 2022”.

title: Russian Literature Festival on 30 November
author: Author not found
Content: The Russian Literature Festival, organised by the Colombo Russian House and the Russian Literature Circle, will be held on 30 November at 3.00 p.m. at the Colombo Russian House Auditorium. This year’s theme of the festival is the centenary of the birth of the great Dagestani poet Rasul Gamsatov. On that occasion, for the first time in history, a ‘Russian poetry night’ will be held, and Dr. W.A. Abeysinghe, Ariyawansa Ranaweera, Karunaratne Amarasinghe, Dr. Sunil Wijesiriwardena, Karunathilaka Handunpathirana, Tanuja Dharmapala, Dayaratne Dalawella, Amal Shantha Munindradasa, Felix Fernando, Sudharma Subashini will perform their poetry recitals. Poet Dr. Ratna Sri Wijesinghe, Buddhadasa Galappatti, Nandana Weerasinghe, Mahin de Prasad Mas Imbula and musician Nadika Guru will contribute their comments. Kavi Sadedewa is chaired by Chulananda Samaranayake. Simultaneously, the first secretary of the Russian Embassy in Sri Lanka, Director of the Russian House in Colombo Maria L. Mrs. Popova will be present. The Executive Council of the Russian Literature Circle has also decided to present the once-in-a-lifetime ‘Leo Tolstoy Award’ to two literary men Pasan Kodikara (posthumously) and Mahinda Senarath Gamage for their great work in popularizing Russian literature in this country. Colombo Russian House and Russian Literature Circle extend an open invitation to all Russian literature lovers who wish to participate in this event.

title: Private hospital in Panadura under probe
author: Author not found
Content: The Panadura Health Medical Officer said a complaint has been received against a private hospital, regarding an incident in which the ECG machine’s leads (wires) were incorrectly attached to the chest of a patient and the ECG was obtained. A woman named Irangani Samarasinghe, a resident of Panadura Fonseka Road, is said to have filed a complaint. According to the report, the woman had gone to a Panadura private hospital on 8 November for an ECG test, due to chest pain and the doctor of the same hospital’s Outpatient Department (OPD) informed her that she does not have any medical condition. However, because the woman’s son was unsure about the ECG test, she was referred to another doctor. According to the complaint, the leads (wires) of the ECG machine attached to the patient’s body were attached to the wrong places during an ECG test, and the test was performed. When one of the sons complained to the hospital, the head nurse called the health worker who took the ECG and confirmed that the ECG was taken incorrectly, when inquiring about how the machine was operated. In response, Panadura Health Medical Officer Dr. Mohammad Ishmi said a complaint about the incident had been received. “However, I lack the authority to investigate this. The complaint was forwarded to the Kalutara District Director of Health Services,” he said. Meanwhile, a Panadura health official noted that an investigation is underway into an incident, where a into a school teacher who went to this hospital two months ago, to be treated for a skin disease, had her face burnt with acid instead of a cream. BY Sumith Ranawaka (Pothupitiya) and Bimal Jayasinghe (Colombo)

title: HRCSL proposes increasing members to seven
author: Author not found
Content: The Human Rights Commission of Sri Lanka (HRCSL) has sent revised recommendations, for the amendment to the Human Rights Commission of Sri Lanka Act No. 21 of 1996, to Minister of Justice, Prison Affairs and Constitutional Reforms Dr. Wijeyadasa Rajapakshe. Amongst the main recommendations to the amendment is that the Commission should comprise seven members as opposed to the existing provision of five. Further, the HRCSL recommended that in the provision relating to the recommendations to the appointment of members to the Commission, the Constitutional Council and the Prime Minister shall have at least one Commissioner from each minority group, up to a minimum of three Commissioners being represented in the Commission. It was further recommended to amend the Act in a manner that every member of the Commission shall hold office for a period of five years as opposed to the existing three years. The HRCSL also recommended that the chairperson shall be a person of eminence and integrity who has distinguished him or her selves in public or professional life, has knowledge or practical experience in, matters relating to human rights and who is not a member of any political party and that all vacancies of the members of the Commission, including the Chairperson, to be publicly advertised. It was also recommended to amend the Act to include the appointment of Special Rapporteurs and thematic sub-committees to exercise powers of the Commission as may be delegated to them. Further the removal of “monitor the welfare of persons detained either by a judicial order or otherwise, by regular inspection of their places of detention, and to make such recommendations as may be necessary for improving their conditions of detention” and substitution by “monitor the welfare and rights of persons detained either by a judicial order or otherwise, by regular inspection of all places of detention, and to make such recommendations as may be necessary for improving their conditions of detention,’’ was recommended by the HRCSL. According to the recommendations, the commission shall issue interim recommendations pending the final recommendation on the complaint, to prevent an imminent infringement of a fundamental right. They also recommended that where a respondent has failed to implement the recommendations set forth by the Commission, he must inform the Supreme Court as to the reasons for his failure to do so by way of a submission. BY Faadhila Thassim

title: STF arrest four fraudsters in Jaffna
author: Author not found
Content: STF Officers attached to the Jaffna STF camp arrested four individuals wanted by the Jaffna Police in connection with financial fraud. According to the STF, the suspects were found in a house on C. Ponnambalam Road in Jaffna. STF Intelligence Officers found Rs 2.8 million and USD 825 hidden in this house, as well as a car parked at the premises. The suspects are 33, 35, 55, and 50 years old and are residents of Anuradhapura, Trincomalee, Dahaiyagama, and Watagoda. Jaffna Police are conducting further investigations. By S.S.H. Lunuwila – Wadduwa

title: SLPP Media unit, three others directed to provide video footage
author: Author not found
Content: The Court of Appeal yesterday (10) directed the Sri Lanka Podujana Peramuna (SLPP) media unit and three other media entities to provide video footages of an SLPP media conference, in which the Minister of Water Supply Sanath Nishantha had allegedly made a controversial statement about the Judiciary. This was when the Contempt of Court Petitions filed against Nishantha were taken up before Court of Appeal Judges N. Bandula Karunarathna and R. Gurusinghe. The Petitions were filed by Lawyers Vijith Kumar and Priyal Sirisena and the Judicial Service Association of Sri Lanka (JSASL). It was stated in the Petitions that Nishantha, who spoke at a media conference, held at the SLPP party headquarters on 23 August, had expressed critical views on the manner in which the Magistrates acted in granting bail to the suspects involved in the ‘Aragalaya’ protest movement and, added that the MP has damaged the honour and the image of the Judiciary. The petitioners further charged that Nishantha has committed contempt of Court through the aforementioned act, adding that it is a punishable offence in accordance with Article 105 (3) of the Constitution. Accordingly, the petitioners requested the Court to issue an order to summon before the Court the original video clips of the concerned press conference which were aired by several private television channels. Furthermore, the petitions also requested the Court to issue an interim order for Nishantha to refrain from making any statements that may be in contempt, in the future. Moreover, the petitioners sought an order to be issued to the Attorney General to file a charge sheet against the respondent, charging him with contempt of Court and a summons to be issued to the concerned MP to appear before the Court and further to question why he should not be punished. In addition, the petitioners requested that a hearing of the petition be held and Nishantha be charged with contempt of Court under Article 105 (3) of the Constitution. When the case was taken up yesterday (10), the Attorney General informed Court that the charge sheet has not been completely drafted as original footage of the said press conference is required. Thereby Court directed the relevant media units to provide the video footages. Accordingly, the case was fixed for 12 December. BY Faadhila Thassim

title: 6.3M Lankans ‘hungry’-CBSL
author: Author not found
Content: Nearly one third of Sri Lanka’s population comprising 6.3 million people is food-insecure, Central Bank of Sri Lanka (CBSL) in a publication released on Wednesday (9) said. The publication titled ‘Recent Economic Developments: Highlights of 2022 and Prospects for 2023’ further said this highlights significantly worsening nutrition outcomes as official statistics were already signalling issues pertaining to malnutrition, especially stunting, wasting, and underweight in children below the age of five, as early as 2016. In addition to nutritional status, the present economic crisis is also likely to have worsened other disparities that were already prevalent even prior to the Covid-19 pandemic, such as access to health and education infrastructure and the asset base of households, CBSL warned. Although more recent national statistics on poverty remain unavailable, there had been a level shift in the district poverty lines over the years, the shift observed between March 2022 and June 2022 is significant with the escalation in prices of all food commodities during this period, CBSL said. For instance, when considering recent poverty line data, in August 2022, the national poverty line stood at Rs 13,460, registering a significant year to date (YTD) increase of 70.1 per cent compared to 2021. Meanwhile, the district poverty line of Colombo, Gampaha, Kalutara, Kegalle and Nuwara Eliya exceeded Rs 14,000 in August 2022, reflecting the disproportionate impact of inflation on cost of living in urban areas, in comparison to Rs 13,004 and Rs 12,870 as observed in rural districts such as Kilinochchi and Moneragala, respectively, CBSL further said. “Well-targeted interventions of sufficient quantity and quality are of utmost importance to help preserve and improve the productive capacity of households over the medium run,” it added. Meanwhile, the share of the population living below the poverty line in 2019 stood at 14.3 per cent, the CBSL publication further said. CBSL further said three years ago in 2019, 3.04 million individuals were living below the poverty line. This was on the eve of the Covid-19 pandemic and the present economic crisis, it said. Prior to the above crises, year 2019 data also highlights the presence of significant disparities across the sectors as well, with poverty levels in the estate sector remaining high at 33.8 per cent in comparison to 15.0 per cent in the rural sector and 6.0 per cent in the urban sector, it warned. The ‘Household Income and Expenditure Survey 2019’ (HIES) 2019, apart from the above findings, also revealed that approximately one in six Sri Lankans was multidimensionally poor and experience deprivations across 42 per cent of selected weighted indicators, it said. The national multidimensional poverty headcount ratios in 2019 were also relatively high at 16.6 per cent in rural areas and 51.3 per cent in estate areas. The people in the estate sector experienced the highest level of deprivation. Among the districts, the lowest incidences of multidimensional poverty were in Colombo (3.5 per cent) and Gampaha (5.1 per cent), whereas the highest was in Nuwara Eliya (44.2 per cent). These poverty statistics from 2019 highlight the vulnerability of a significant share of the population to poverty even before the Covid-19 pandemic. (PA)
