title: Ten injured as buses collide
author: Author not found
Content: Ten passengers were injured in an accident, involving two private buses, near Pelwadiya along the Ratnapura – Embilipitiya road yesterday (10) morning, Ratnapura Police said. They added that a bus running from Embilipitiya to Ratnapura collided head on with a bus travelling from Ratnapura to Deniyaya.  The injured, who were rushed to Teaching Hospital Ratnapura, left for home after receiving Out Patients Department treatment. Ratnapura Police are conducting further inquiries after having recorded statements from the passengers. BY Naalir Jamaldeen

title: Australian HC meets Justice Minister
author: Author not found
Content: A meeting between Minister of Justice, Prison Affairs and Constitutional Reforms Dr. Wijeyadasa Rajapakshe and the new Australian High Commissioner to Sri Lanka Paul Stephens took place at the Ministry of Justice. The Minister informed the High Commissioner about the legal reforms that are being conducted to improve the quality of the judicial system and about the mediation programme in Sri Lanka, which has been established to solve the problems of the common people through their own method by reducing the number of cases referred to the Courts. The Minister also said that he gratefully remembers the support provided by the Australian Government, in the face of the economic crisis, by providing medicines and other essential goods. Rajapakshe explained to the High Commissioner about the special mobile services provided for the people of the Northern Province and the High Commissioner expressed his appreciation for the welfare programmes carried out for the people of the Northern Province, including the release of land held by the Security Forces for the benefit of the common people. Wasantha Perera, Secretary of the Ministry of Justice, joined the discussion.

title: Russian Literature Festival on 30 November
author: Author not found
Content: The Russian Literature Festival, organised by the Colombo Russian House and the Russian Literature Circle, will be held on 30 November at 3.00 p.m. at the Colombo Russian House Auditorium. This year’s theme of the festival is the centenary of the birth of the great Dagestani poet Rasul Gamsatov. On that occasion, for the first time in history, a ‘Russian poetry night’ will be held, and Dr. W.A. Abeysinghe, Ariyawansa Ranaweera, Karunaratne Amarasinghe, Dr. Sunil Wijesiriwardena, Karunathilaka Handunpathirana, Tanuja Dharmapala, Dayaratne Dalawella, Amal Shantha Munindradasa, Felix Fernando, Sudharma Subashini will perform their poetry recitals. Poet Dr. Ratna Sri Wijesinghe, Buddhadasa Galappatti, Nandana Weerasinghe, Mahin de Prasad Mas Imbula and musician Nadika Guru will contribute their comments. Kavi Sadedewa is chaired by Chulananda Samaranayake. Simultaneously, the first secretary of the Russian Embassy in Sri Lanka, Director of the Russian House in Colombo Maria L. Mrs. Popova will be present. The Executive Council of the Russian Literature Circle has also decided to present the once-in-a-lifetime ‘Leo Tolstoy Award’ to two literary men Pasan Kodikara (posthumously) and Mahinda Senarath Gamage for their great work in popularizing Russian literature in this country. Colombo Russian House and Russian Literature Circle extend an open invitation to all Russian literature lovers who wish to participate in this event.

title: Private hospital in Panadura under probe
author: Author not found
Content: The Panadura Health Medical Officer said a complaint has been received against a private hospital, regarding an incident in which the ECG machine’s leads (wires) were incorrectly attached to the chest of a patient and the ECG was obtained. A woman named Irangani Samarasinghe, a resident of Panadura Fonseka Road, is said to have filed a complaint. According to the report, the woman had gone to a Panadura private hospital on 8 November for an ECG test, due to chest pain and the doctor of the same hospital’s Outpatient Department (OPD) informed her that she does not have any medical condition. However, because the woman’s son was unsure about the ECG test, she was referred to another doctor. According to the complaint, the leads (wires) of the ECG machine attached to the patient’s body were attached to the wrong places during an ECG test, and the test was performed. When one of the sons complained to the hospital, the head nurse called the health worker who took the ECG and confirmed that the ECG was taken incorrectly, when inquiring about how the machine was operated. In response, Panadura Health Medical Officer Dr. Mohammad Ishmi said a complaint about the incident had been received. “However, I lack the authority to investigate this. The complaint was forwarded to the Kalutara District Director of Health Services,” he said. Meanwhile, a Panadura health official noted that an investigation is underway into an incident, where a into a school teacher who went to this hospital two months ago, to be treated for a skin disease, had her face burnt with acid instead of a cream. BY Sumith Ranawaka (Pothupitiya) and Bimal Jayasinghe (Colombo)

title: HRCSL proposes increasing members to seven
author: Author not found
Content: The Human Rights Commission of Sri Lanka (HRCSL) has sent revised recommendations, for the amendment to the Human Rights Commission of Sri Lanka Act No. 21 of 1996, to Minister of Justice, Prison Affairs and Constitutional Reforms Dr. Wijeyadasa Rajapakshe. Amongst the main recommendations to the amendment is that the Commission should comprise seven members as opposed to the existing provision of five. Further, the HRCSL recommended that in the provision relating to the recommendations to the appointment of members to the Commission, the Constitutional Council and the Prime Minister shall have at least one Commissioner from each minority group, up to a minimum of three Commissioners being represented in the Commission. It was further recommended to amend the Act in a manner that every member of the Commission shall hold office for a period of five years as opposed to the existing three years. The HRCSL also recommended that the chairperson shall be a person of eminence and integrity who has distinguished him or her selves in public or professional life, has knowledge or practical experience in, matters relating to human rights and who is not a member of any political party and that all vacancies of the members of the Commission, including the Chairperson, to be publicly advertised. It was also recommended to amend the Act to include the appointment of Special Rapporteurs and thematic sub-committees to exercise powers of the Commission as may be delegated to them. Further the removal of “monitor the welfare of persons detained either by a judicial order or otherwise, by regular inspection of their places of detention, and to make such recommendations as may be necessary for improving their conditions of detention” and substitution by “monitor the welfare and rights of persons detained either by a judicial order or otherwise, by regular inspection of all places of detention, and to make such recommendations as may be necessary for improving their conditions of detention,’’ was recommended by the HRCSL. According to the recommendations, the commission shall issue interim recommendations pending the final recommendation on the complaint, to prevent an imminent infringement of a fundamental right. They also recommended that where a respondent has failed to implement the recommendations set forth by the Commission, he must inform the Supreme Court as to the reasons for his failure to do so by way of a submission. BY Faadhila Thassim

title: STF arrest four fraudsters in Jaffna
author: Author not found
Content: STF Officers attached to the Jaffna STF camp arrested four individuals wanted by the Jaffna Police in connection with financial fraud. According to the STF, the suspects were found in a house on C. Ponnambalam Road in Jaffna. STF Intelligence Officers found Rs 2.8 million and USD 825 hidden in this house, as well as a car parked at the premises. The suspects are 33, 35, 55, and 50 years old and are residents of Anuradhapura, Trincomalee, Dahaiyagama, and Watagoda. Jaffna Police are conducting further investigations. By S.S.H. Lunuwila – Wadduwa

title: SLPP Media unit, three others directed to provide video footage
author: Author not found
Content: The Court of Appeal yesterday (10) directed the Sri Lanka Podujana Peramuna (SLPP) media unit and three other media entities to provide video footages of an SLPP media conference, in which the Minister of Water Supply Sanath Nishantha had allegedly made a controversial statement about the Judiciary. This was when the Contempt of Court Petitions filed against Nishantha were taken up before Court of Appeal Judges N. Bandula Karunarathna and R. Gurusinghe. The Petitions were filed by Lawyers Vijith Kumar and Priyal Sirisena and the Judicial Service Association of Sri Lanka (JSASL). It was stated in the Petitions that Nishantha, who spoke at a media conference, held at the SLPP party headquarters on 23 August, had expressed critical views on the manner in which the Magistrates acted in granting bail to the suspects involved in the ‘Aragalaya’ protest movement and, added that the MP has damaged the honour and the image of the Judiciary. The petitioners further charged that Nishantha has committed contempt of Court through the aforementioned act, adding that it is a punishable offence in accordance with Article 105 (3) of the Constitution. Accordingly, the petitioners requested the Court to issue an order to summon before the Court the original video clips of the concerned press conference which were aired by several private television channels. Furthermore, the petitions also requested the Court to issue an interim order for Nishantha to refrain from making any statements that may be in contempt, in the future. Moreover, the petitioners sought an order to be issued to the Attorney General to file a charge sheet against the respondent, charging him with contempt of Court and a summons to be issued to the concerned MP to appear before the Court and further to question why he should not be punished. In addition, the petitioners requested that a hearing of the petition be held and Nishantha be charged with contempt of Court under Article 105 (3) of the Constitution. When the case was taken up yesterday (10), the Attorney General informed Court that the charge sheet has not been completely drafted as original footage of the said press conference is required. Thereby Court directed the relevant media units to provide the video footages. Accordingly, the case was fixed for 12 December. BY Faadhila Thassim

title: 6.3M Lankans ‘hungry’-CBSL
author: Author not found
Content: Nearly one third of Sri Lanka’s population comprising 6.3 million people is food-insecure, Central Bank of Sri Lanka (CBSL) in a publication released on Wednesday (9) said. The publication titled ‘Recent Economic Developments: Highlights of 2022 and Prospects for 2023’ further said this highlights significantly worsening nutrition outcomes as official statistics were already signalling issues pertaining to malnutrition, especially stunting, wasting, and underweight in children below the age of five, as early as 2016. In addition to nutritional status, the present economic crisis is also likely to have worsened other disparities that were already prevalent even prior to the Covid-19 pandemic, such as access to health and education infrastructure and the asset base of households, CBSL warned. Although more recent national statistics on poverty remain unavailable, there had been a level shift in the district poverty lines over the years, the shift observed between March 2022 and June 2022 is significant with the escalation in prices of all food commodities during this period, CBSL said. For instance, when considering recent poverty line data, in August 2022, the national poverty line stood at Rs 13,460, registering a significant year to date (YTD) increase of 70.1 per cent compared to 2021. Meanwhile, the district poverty line of Colombo, Gampaha, Kalutara, Kegalle and Nuwara Eliya exceeded Rs 14,000 in August 2022, reflecting the disproportionate impact of inflation on cost of living in urban areas, in comparison to Rs 13,004 and Rs 12,870 as observed in rural districts such as Kilinochchi and Moneragala, respectively, CBSL further said. “Well-targeted interventions of sufficient quantity and quality are of utmost importance to help preserve and improve the productive capacity of households over the medium run,” it added. Meanwhile, the share of the population living below the poverty line in 2019 stood at 14.3 per cent, the CBSL publication further said. CBSL further said three years ago in 2019, 3.04 million individuals were living below the poverty line. This was on the eve of the Covid-19 pandemic and the present economic crisis, it said. Prior to the above crises, year 2019 data also highlights the presence of significant disparities across the sectors as well, with poverty levels in the estate sector remaining high at 33.8 per cent in comparison to 15.0 per cent in the rural sector and 6.0 per cent in the urban sector, it warned. The ‘Household Income and Expenditure Survey 2019’ (HIES) 2019, apart from the above findings, also revealed that approximately one in six Sri Lankans was multidimensionally poor and experience deprivations across 42 per cent of selected weighted indicators, it said. The national multidimensional poverty headcount ratios in 2019 were also relatively high at 16.6 per cent in rural areas and 51.3 per cent in estate areas. The people in the estate sector experienced the highest level of deprivation. Among the districts, the lowest incidences of multidimensional poverty were in Colombo (3.5 per cent) and Gampaha (5.1 per cent), whereas the highest was in Nuwara Eliya (44.2 per cent). These poverty statistics from 2019 highlight the vulnerability of a significant share of the population to poverty even before the Covid-19 pandemic. (PA)

title: Navy foil Kendu leaves smuggling attempts
author: Author not found
Content: In another foiled attempt, the Navy seized over 2448kg of smuggled Kendu Leaves in the Duwa area, Negombo during a search operation on 8 November along with two lorries, a dinghy two suspects were apprehended. Meanwhile, in a search operation carried out by the SLNS Parakrama of the Western Naval Command, on a tip-off received by naval intelligence, two lorries parked in the Duwa area were searched on 8 November. Nearly, 1,590kg of Kendu Leaves packed in 48 packages were found in the lorries which were meant for distribution. Two suspects alleged to be involved in the act were apprehended. A further search in the Duwa lagoon area also led to 26 more packages containing about 867. 2kg of Kendu leaves being found stashed in a dinghy.  The suspects held in this operation were identified as residents of Negombo, aged 28 and 41. The suspects along with the vehicles, dinghy and about 2449kg of Kendu Leaves were handed over to the Customs Preventive Office – Katunayake. (NV)

title: How did confidential IMF Agreement leak?
author: Author not found
Content: Committee on Public Finance (COPF) Chairman Dr. Harsha de Silva yesterday (9) questioned in Parliament as to how the ‘confidential’ Staff Level Agreement with the IMF is in the hands of some ‘random people’ in committees appointed by the President, when the Agreement hasn’t been presented to Parliament yet. Dr. de Silva said he obtained the document but will not be tabling it in the House as there could be allegations that he revealed sensitive economic information. “I have the agreement with me right now. You must be wondering how I obtained it. Although the Government is yet to present the agreement to the House, this is already in hands of some members in the committees appointed by the President. This is a bad precedence. This is how the Sugar scam happened. It is very dangerous that some random people have such sensitive details while the Government is delaying presenting it to Parliament,” he asserted. The MP said the agreement has details on increasing taxes including VAT, income tax and excise tax in coming years. At this juncture, State Minister of Finance Ranjith Siyambalapitiya requested Dr. de Silva not to read the document further as it could create controversy among the public. “I told you that I will not divulge information and will not table this in the House. But I have to raise this question. You (the Government) are delaying tabling this in Parliament. Then how come some people can have it already? This is very dangerous. Sugar scam happened because someone got to know that taxes would be reduced before others. It was like a lottery to them. In this situation how can you be so sure that same thing would not be repeated?” he queried.

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: SL confirms second monkeypox case
author: Author not found
Content: The second case of monkeypox was detected in Sri Lanka yesterday (9). The Medical Research Institute (MRI) confirmed that the second patient is a Sri Lankan citizen who returned to the country from Dubai. According to the MRI, the patient had been admitted to the National Institute of Infectious Diseases (NIID) while the MRI had received samples for testing. The patient presented with fever, body pain, and a rash. The Institute said, it had testing methods approved by the World Health Organisation (WHO) and used a real-time PCR machine to diagnose patients, also a donation from the WHO. The first case of the viral infection was detected last week, while health authorities have warned that there were possibilities of more cases arriving from overseas. By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: 24% to be recovered as income tax – Siyambalapitiya
author: Author not found
Content: Steps will be taken to recover 24 per cent of Rs 16 billion loss incurred to the State due to the ‘Sugar Scam’ in 2020 as income tax from relevant companies under the existing laws, State Minister of Finance Ranjith Siyambalapitiya said in Parliament yesterday (9). The State Minister, who presented the report on ‘Sugar Scam’ prepared by the Commissioner General of Inland Revenue based on the Auditor General’s report, said, 10 such companies who had benefited from reducing Special Commodity Levy on imported sugar from Rs 50 to 25 cents have been identified. The tax reduction was in effect for three months from 14 October 2020. Siyambalapitiya said, one of the 10 companies had imported 45 per cent of the total sugar imports during that period. The sugar imports of the said company had increased by 1,220 per cent during those three months compared to the previous year. Also, by importers withholding benefits of tax reduction, the revenue loss to the State is estimated to be Rs 17.7 billion, Siyambalapitiya said. By Methmalie Dissanayake and Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: Delimitation Committee won’t allow delaying polls – Gammanpila
author: Author not found
Content: The National Delimitation Committee will not allow the elections to be postponed, according to Pivithuru Hela Urumaya (PHU) Leader MP Udaya Gammanpila. When asked whether the Government would postpone the election, he said, the proposal made by the committee should be passed through a parliamentary bill. “If the Bill is passed before the election, the election will be postponed. So claiming that the elections will be postponed because of delimitation committee is incorrect. It takes about a month to bring such a Bill to Parliament and have it passed. Domestic and international pressure is exerted on the Government in this case. Because Sri Lanka is now living under the grace of foreign countries, we must listen to what they have to say,” he explained. In addition, he noted the number one condition of foreign aid is not debt restructuring or state apparatus restructuring, which means holding elections immediately and establishing democracy. “As a result, the Government will only be able to postpone elections for two months. We remind the Government that holding elections at the appropriate time is better,” he said. When asked if a group of the opposition is saying they will join the Government, Gammanpila noted that rumours of switching sides usually start in November when the budget is close. BY Thameenah Razeek

title: Govt unwilling to change policies – Sajith
author: Author not found
Content: Opposition Leader Sajith Premadasa said even though the policies of the International Monetary Fund (IMF) have changed, it is regrettable that the harsh policies of the Government have not changed. While demanding that the pledges made to the IMF should be disclosed to the public, Premadasa added that the Government has no plan to rebuild the country. Speaking in Parliament yesterday (9), Premadasa also said, children are starving and fainting in schools due to malnutrition and the Government is taking action against individuals who expose these incidents. Premadasa further said, despite the present situation, the Government is attempting to get MPs from different political parties to cross over and no one from the SJB will join the “autocratic government.” “The Government is full of political envy and hypocrisy and is unable to rebuild this country. Ministers are presenting an illusion that the country will be built by shrinking the economy,” he claimed. By Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: Work on West Terminal gets off the ground
author: Author not found
Content: Minister of Ports, Shipping and Aviation Nimal Siripala de Silva initiated construction work on the West Terminal of the Colombo Port. Indian High Commissioner to Sri Lanka, Gopal Baglay participated as a special guest. The project is expected to cost 789 million US dollars. Adani Group has invested 51% while John Keels has a 34% stake and Sri Lanka Ports Authority(SLPA) has 15%. The length of the jetty is said to be 1,400 metres, total terminal area is 65 hectares and container capacity is three million. An 800-metre jetty will be constructed where 18 automatic terminal cranes will be installed under the first phase. This terminal will be constructed in two phases. Speaking at a ceremony yesterday, the Minister praised the Indian Government for its support to solve the economic crisis that Sri Lanka is facing. He said, on completion of the project, a large number of youth will get job opportunities and SLPA’s earning capacity will increase where more foreign exchange will flow into the country. Indian Envoy Baglay said, the friendship between the two countries will be further strengthened by this project and extended his good wishes for the project. K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, Secretary to the Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation, Keith D., Chairman of SLPA were present. Deputy HC of India – Vinod Jacob, CEO Adani Port – Dredge, Captain Anmesh Avyankar, Deputy Chairman John Keels Holdings – Gihan Kure, CEO Colombo West International Terminal Pvt Ltd (CWIT (Pvt) Ltd) – Harikrishnanam Sundar and a large number of invitees participated.

title: National Grid to get 2800 MW by 2026 – Kanchana
author: Author not found
Content: After six months of planning, Ceylon Electricity Board (CEB) officials have devised a strategy to integrate more than 2800 MW of renewable energy (RE) into the national grid between 2022 and 2026. This was revealed following a discussion held with the CEB Board and Sustainable Energy Authority (SEA) and Minister of Power and Energy Kanchana Wijesekara. In a tweet, he said, this will enable the CEB and SEA to accommodate and accelerate many projects. He stated, more than 170 projects out of 226 which had provisional approval, 48 projects that had Energy Permits, Identified Large scale projects, tendered projects which had obtained tenders and rooftop solar capacity will be accommodated. “Also discussed transmission and grid development needed for other projects,” the tweet stated.

title: Lacuna in teacher training leads to child abuse – Gammanpila
author: Author not found
Content: Pivithuru Hela Urumaya (PHU) Leader Udaya Gammanpila blamed teachers for not being trained in child psychology, which results in child abuse in schools. He said when more teachers graduated the less training they received. Speaking to the media yesterday (9), Gammanpila raised these facts in the context of three children being harassed by teachers, Principal of a primary school and police officers, for allegedly stealing a teacher’s purse. He stated that incidents like this occur all over the country and that there is a need to find answers as to why these incidents are more common today than in the past. “In the early days, Principals did not go to the police to lodge complaints about students. School issues were resolved within the school. Back then, Principals even solved issues students faced at home. Why is it that what was done then, is no longer being practised today? You cannot become a Science or Mathematics teacher, simply because you have a Degree in these disciplines. Education is a distinct subject. It is possible to become a teacher after studying subjects such as child psychology, teaching methods, communication and group management. Before being sent to a school as a teacher, despite being a graduate, he or she was sent to Mirigama, Giragama, or Katukurunda Teacher Training College and underwent training for two or three years before being sent to the classroom,” he said. Further, he pointed out that earlier as the number of teachers increased, so did training. He emphasised that if someone already had a Degree and passes the competitive examination, he or she was sent to a school for a few weeks of training. “She would not have gone to the police if the Principal involved in the abuse case had been trained in the proper manner. Earlier Principals, determined whether or not a child had stolen the purse based on their expressions and responses,” he said. BY Thameenah Razeek

title: Majority of unemployed youth from estate sector
author: Author not found
Content: A sample survey of a cross section of young Sri Lankan persons conducted by Asian Development Bank Institute (ADBI) said a majority of unemployed youth (48 per cent) were from the estate sector. The study titled ‘Strengthening Active Labour Market Policies to Drive an Inclusive Recovery in Asia’ and released on  Monday (8), further said out of the total sample, 13 per cent of unemployed youth belonged to the urban sector and 39 per cent to the rural sector. “These figures reflect the severity of the unemployed youth problem in the rural and estate sectors that lack infrastructure facilities for better education and training,” the report said. The study which targeted vocational training in Government of Sri Lanka (GoSL)-run vocational training institutes (VTIs) further said the majority of unemployed youth were aged between 15 and 18. “Most unemployed youth in Sri Lanka are from low-income families who benefit from the main poverty alleviation programme Samurdhi,” the publication said. “Most left school education and did not try to find any employment. Similarly, the second-highest percentage of unemployed youth belonged to the age group 19-22. Most of these youth have been searching for employment opportunities for more than one year. The lowest percentage (20 per cent) of unemployed youth belonged to the 23-25 years age category,” the study said. Majority of the unemployed youth (34 per cent) have been educated up to Grade 10 or Grade 11. “Mainly, they are unable to continue their education because of failing the G.C.E. O/L Examination. About seven per cent of responders had only primary education,” the ADBI report said. “Financial difficulties, personal problems, the inability to find a nearby school, poor infrastructure facilities (especially transportation) and failure of the G.C.E. O/L Examination primarily cause dropouts from school education,” it added. Nonetheless, a significant percentage of youth (28 per cent) have been educated until the end of school education, it said. “However, they do not have enough qualifications to enter higher education institutions such as universities. Only eight per cent of youth have completed diploma courses in private institutions related to Computer and English knowledge,” the report further said. It further said the sample size comprised 804 persons of whom 533 persons were employed after following courses in Government-run vocational training institutes from 2017-2019 and the balance, between the ages of 15-25 were unemployed and lived within the vicinity of GoSL-run VTIs. Out of the total sample, 39.2 per cent were females, it said. By Paneetha Ameresekere

title: Nuwara Eliya District hospitals in need of specialists
author: Author not found
Content: Several doctors said there are a number of top vacancies for healthcare professionals in the Nuwara Eliya District which has one of the highest proportions of people with malnutrition in the country. The doctors said that presently two base hospitals, 26 regional hospitals, 12 primary hospitals and 14 health medical offices are being overseen by the Nuwara Eliya District Health Services Director Office. But they asserted that several top positions in the aforesaid institutions have been vacant for some time causing inconveniences. Hence they stressed that it is vital that the vacant posts are filled with qualified medical professionals to provide an efficient service to the district. BY Neeta Pathma Kumari – Norwood

title: UN fetes Lankan Blue Helmets in Mali
author: Author not found
Content: United Nations (UN) Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in Mali (MINUSMA), General Officer Commanding Eastern Headquarters, Brigadier General Stefan Anderson pinned the ‘Excellence in MINUSMA Sector East’ Badge on Sri Lanka Army members and praised them for their excellent duty under challenging circumstances. This took place at the Sri Lankan Combat Convoy Company (CCC) base camp in Mali. In the past six months, tribal terrorist groups in Mali have intensified their fierce internecine violent acts targeting their rivals as well as UN troops serving in the landlocked country, SLA said. Similarly, their brutal and fierce terror attacks have posed a formidable threat to all UN troops deployed for peace-keeping missions, it further said. (PA)

Only eight per cent of youth have completed diploma courses in private institutions related to Computer and English knowledge,” the report further said. It further said the sample size comprised 804 persons of whom 533 persons were employed after following courses in Government-run vocational training institutes from 2017-2019 and the balance, between the ages of 15-25 were unemployed and lived within the vicinity of GoSL-run VTIs. Out of the total sample, 39.2 per cent were females, it said. By Paneetha Ameresekere

title: Nuwara Eliya District hospitals in need of specialists
author: Author not found
Content: Several doctors said there are a number of top vacancies for healthcare professionals in the Nuwara Eliya District which has one of the highest proportions of people with malnutrition in the country. The doctors said that presently two base hospitals, 26 regional hospitals, 12 primary hospitals and 14 health medical offices are being overseen by the Nuwara Eliya District Health Services Director Office. But they asserted that several top positions in the aforesaid institutions have been vacant for some time causing inconveniences. Hence they stressed that it is vital that the vacant posts are filled with qualified medical professionals to provide an efficient service to the district. BY Neeta Pathma Kumari – Norwood

title: UN fetes Lankan Blue Helmets in Mali
author: Author not found
Content: United Nations (UN) Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in Mali (MINUSMA), General Officer Commanding Eastern Headquarters, Brigadier General Stefan Anderson pinned the ‘Excellence in MINUSMA Sector East’ Badge on Sri Lanka Army members and praised them for their excellent duty under challenging circumstances. This took place at the Sri Lankan Combat Convoy Company (CCC) base camp in Mali. In the past six months, tribal terrorist groups in Mali have intensified their fierce internecine violent acts targeting their rivals as well as UN troops serving in the landlocked country, SLA said. Similarly, their brutal and fierce terror attacks have posed a formidable threat to all UN troops deployed for peace-keeping missions, it further said. (PA)

title: Much-needed Cardiology Unit opened
author: Author not found
Content: A Cardiology Unit was set up at Akkaraipattu Base Hospital and was opened by former Minister and Leader of National Congress A.L.M. Athaullah in the presence of medical professionals and well-wishers, following the assumption of Cardiologist, Dr. M.A. Nawshard Ali. Athaullah also opened the ward of the unit and registered the first patients. Earlier, heart patients from Pottuvil and Kalmunai had to visit either Batticaloa or Ampara General Hospital for consultation and treatment. In addition to spending large sums of money, they also had to undergo untold hardship. The untiring efforts of the Hospital Development Society of Akkaraipattu Base Hospital with the assistance of former Minister Athaullah proved invaluable in completing the unit. Former Minister Athaullah was the Chief Guest at the ceremony presided over by the President of the Hospital Development Society, Dr. M.A.M. Rakeesthu. Akkaraipattu Mayor Athaulla Ahamed Zackie and Akkaraipattu Pradeshiya Sabha Chairman M.S. Razick were the Guests of Honour. Medical Superintendent of the Hospital, Dr. Paul Roshan, Kalmunai Regional Director of Health Services, Dr. I.L.M. Rifas, and Medical Officers also participated in the event. Further, an ambulance gifted by the Health Department was handed over to Dr. Paul Roshan. Meanwhile, a well-wisher named A.L. Abdul Gaffoor, Treasurer of the Addalaichenai Jummah Mosque Board of Trustees gifted a consignment of orthopaedic devices and equipment to Orthopaedic Surgeon Dr. M.R. Ahamed Nihaj, who assumed duties on this day. By M.A.P. Deen – Ampara Correspondent

title: Review team to be appointed – Secy Gen Parliament
author: Author not found
Content: Secretary General of the Parliament Dhammika Dasanayake said that a special committee consisting four members will be appointed to further study and make recommendations regarding establishing three standing committees. This was decided at the Committee on Parliamentary Business held on Tuesday (8). Accordingly, the Committee on Banking and Financial Services, the Committee on Ways and Means, the Committee on Economic Stabilisation is expected to be established as new standing committees. Accordingly, the Minister of Foreign Affairs Ali Sabry, MP Dr. Harsha de Silva, M.A. Sumanthiran and Sagara Kariyawasam were appointed to this special committee, the Secretary General said. The Committee is bestowed with the task of analysing whether the functions of the existing standing committees, namely the Committee on Public Enterprises, the Committee on Public Accounts and the Committee on Public Finance overlap with these new standing committees and make necessary recommendations for reconsideration if necessary. By Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: IOM screening 303 rescued SL boat people
author: Author not found
Content: The International Organization for Migration (IOM), a United Nations agency, is screening the group of Sri Lankan Tamils who tried to flee from Sri Lanka in a Myanmar-flagged vessel to reach Canada, Ministry of Foreign Affairs Additional Secretary South Asia, B. Kandeepan said. The 303 persons who were on an arduous sea journey allegedly to reach Canada were rescued by Singaporean authorities when their boat began to sink off the coast of Vietnam. They were later sent to Bung Tan in Vietnam, where they are sheltered at present. According to the Foreign Ministry official, they were screened in group and will be screened individually before deciding the next step. Apparently, the entire group of Sri Lankan Tamils from the North and East had refused to leave the shores of Vietnam, however, they were “convinced” to return toSri Lanka. As the screening process is ongoing, the final outcome will be known later on, said the official. He confirmed that all of them are from Sri Lanka. The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MFA) in its official statement also said they are continuing to monitor the progress of the Sri Lankan passengers who were rescued and bought to the Port of Vũng Tàu in Vietnam on 8 November. The MFA informed the Sri Lanka Navy that they had received information about a vessel carrying approximately 303 persons believed to be Sri Lankans which was in distress in waters between Philippines and Vietnam on 7 November. The Sri Lanka Navy having contacted the vessel, informed that the crew had abandoned the vessel with the passengers onboard. On the initiative of the MFA in coordination with the Sri Lanka Navy and the Sri Lanka Missions in the Philippines, Singapore, and Vietnam together with the regional Maritime Rescue Coordination Centres (MRCC) based in Singapore, the rescue efforts were coordinated. Subsequently, the Japanese-flagged vessel, ‘Helios Leader,’ having been contacted by the Singapore MRCC, rescued the passengers from the distressed vessel. The passengers were handed over to Vietnamese authorities at Vũng Tàu Port in South Vietnam. The Ministry of Foreign Affairs continues to work closely with the Sri Lankan Missions in the Philippines, Singapore, Vietnam, and IOM for early repatriation, once the screening process and other formalities are completed. By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: Navy, Coast Guard seize over Rs 137 M worth cannabis
author: Author not found
Content: The Navy and Coast Guard seized Kerala cannabis weighing over 458kg worth over Rs 137 million at a street value along with two suspects and the dinghy used in the act in northern waters. Meanwhile, the Navy seized over 5479kg of Kerala cannabis in 2022 and the gross street value of the stock is over Rs 1,643 million along with the said apprehension. However, a coordinated operation carried out by the Sri Lanka Navy and Sri Lanka Coast Guard in the sea area southeast of the Delft Island, Jaffna in the wee hours of 9 November, led to the seizure of 458kg of Kerala cannabis in 18 packages from the dinghy.  Coast Guard Craft CG 402 attached to the Northern Naval Command, searched a suspicious dinghy in the sea area southeast of the Delft Island on 9 November.   The suspects held in this operation were identified as residents of Mandaitivu and Nachchikuda, aged 37 and 44. The suspects along with Kerala cannabis and dinghy will be handed over to the Delft Police for onward legal action. (NV)

title: Seed prices unregulated – COPA
author: Author not found
Content: It was revealed at the Committee on Public Accounts (COPA) that there was no regulatory system for vegetable seed prices in Sri Lanka. COPA met in Parliament on Tuesday (8) under the chairmanship of MP Kabir Hashim. A discussion was held at COPA on producing vegetable seeds locally. Several parties including the officials of the Ministry of Agriculture were present at the meeting. It was also discussed that though the ‘State Policy on Seed and Planting Material Industry’ was prepared in 1997, it was not published in the Gazette even as at 1 January, 2021. Further, regarding the Seed Act No. 22 of 2003, there was a discussion at length and attention was drawn that necessary amendments had not been made. It was disclosed that there were several institutions in the private sector that are allowed to import seed and that the Act does not include a system to control seed prices being imported by these institutions. The members of the committee pointed out that it was a serious situation and it was the domestic vegetable farmer that faced the music as a result and that this was a mafia. Therefore, they said, a system should be put in place to control the situation and enable the domestic vegetable farmer to buy vegetable seed at an affordable price. They said, providing locally produced vegetable seed to the domestic vegetable farmers was unsatisfactory. In response, officials present elaborated that government departments including the Department of Agriculture was working to produce more local vegetable seed at a subsidised price, but pointed out that certain seeds required different climatic conditions and such seed was imported. Therefore, few private institutions have been allowed to import such seeds. Officials said, hybrid seeds were produced using technology as it could not be produced otherwise. Officials also pointed out that it takes about 10 years to carry out research to produce certain seeds.  COPA Chairman called for a report on obstacles to seed production. A report on obstacles to recruitment, a report containing three years of information on the percentage of locally produced seeds and the percentage of imported seeds as per seed demand as well as a report on how seed prices can be controlled through the regulation of the Act and Policy within two weeks. By Methmalie Dissanayake

title: Saudi agrees to offer more jobs for Lankans
author: Author not found
Content: Saudi Arabia has expressed its willingness to recruit more Sri Lankans for construction and health sectors and raise the minimum wage of Sri Lankan domestic workers employed in the Kingdom following the first official bilateral discussion held on 8 November between the Minister of Foreign Employment and Labour Manusha Nanayakkara and Eng. Ahmad bin Sulaiman Al Rajhi, the Minister of Human Resources and Social Development of Saudi Arabia. A number of jobs in the construction sector, which were only open to Philippine and Bangladeshi nationals for some time, are to be opened to Sri Lankan skilled workers with the new agreement. During discussions, Al Rajhi agreed to appoint two bilateral committees to coordinate the recruitment of Sri Lankan in the construction and health sectors in Saudi Arabia. He also agreed to appoint a consultative committee to make recommendations within 30-days with regards to alleviating existing irregularities in recruiting Sri Lankan domestic workers. Al Rajhi also agreed to further increase the minimum wage currently paid to the Sri Lankan workers. The recommendations in this regards are to be presented within 30 days as well. More priority will be also given to those who have expertise in sectors with surplus of employees in Sri Lanka. Attention was drawn to the fact that employment contracts are only in Arabic and English. Both parties agreed to look into problems faced by domestic workers and take relevant actions within 30 days, as well as other issues with regards to recruitment fees and related costs. It was also decided to close down around 400 employment agencies that have committed wrongdoings. (NV)

title: Principal, two policemen remanded
author: Author not found
Content: NCPA yesterday informed Colombo Additional Magistrate Keminda Perera that a Police Inspector attached to the Millaniya Police had given a statement saying that the Principal of the Horana, Millaniya Primary School had physically assaulted a student in his presence. This came to light, when the case filed against the Principal of a school in Millaniya, Horana and two policemen, who were allegedly involved in physically abusing three Grade 5 students of the school was taken up for hearing. The Police Inspector had told NCPA officers that due to the severity of the assault, the student had landed on the police jeep. The Additional Magistrate, stated that he was ordering the fourth suspect in the case, the Principal of the school to be remanded as by her conduct she had failed to provide adequate protection to students under her care and mercilessly assaulting them over a minor offence. The Magistrate then ordered the first and second suspects in the trial, the two police officers, to also be remanded in this connection, as they too had failed to protect the children concerned and had proceeded to subject them to electric shocks having assaulted them with batons whilst in the jeep. The three suspects were identified, as R. P, Samarasiri Rajapaksa (Police Inspector of Millaniya), Police Sergeant T. Don Jayantha (Millaniya Police) and the principal of the said school G. I. Don Vineetha Raji Gammanpila, respectively. The NCPA stated that on 2 November, the class teacher identified as Nishani had complained to the Principal over the misplacement of her wallet. She had then summoned seven students to the principal’s office, while two of them were assaulted by the class teacher and the Principal, after which they had summoned the Millaniya Police. According to the NCPA, before summoning the Police, the class teacher and the principal, had forced two of the students to kneel from 8.30 a.m. to 1.45p.m. The NCPA told Court that they had so far recorded statements from nine students with regard to the incident. They informed Court that upon the students being handed over to the Police, officers had then proceeded to assault the children, with batons before subjecting them to electric shocks. The NCPA stated that the parents of the one of the assaulted students had subsequently lodged a complaint with them, before which the assaulted child had been admitted to the Horana Base Hospital with injuries. Taking the submissions into consideration, Additional Magistrate Perera, ordered the three suspects to be imprisoned till 16 November, having considered the extreme severity of their actions and the offences committed by them. He then ordered the driver of the police jeep, to be enlarged on surety bail of Rs 300.000, considering the fact that he had acted only as the driver of the vehicle and not been involved in the actions of the rest of the suspects. He also ordered the fifth suspect in the case, the Deputy Principal to be released on two surety bail of Rs 750.000 each. By Hansi Nanayakkara

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Australian Tamil attacked with swords in Jaffna
author: Author not found
Content: A Jaffna-born Tamil man, now an Australian citizen was attacked with swords by a gang of three, Ceylon Today learns. The 42-year-old Australian, a native of the Pandatharippu area, was seriously injured yesterday (9). The victim is a devotee of the Murugan temple in Pandatharippu and has been sending funds for the shrine’s management. He had recently met the Northern Province Governor requesting him to find a solution over alleged financial corruption linked to the temple. After a few days, three men had arrived at the home of the Australian and called him out for a talk. They had then attacked him with swords and threatened him not to interfere with the administration of the temple. The critically injured man was admitted to the Jaffna Teaching Hospital. Ilawalai Police are investigating the incident. By T. Pratheepan

title: 191 new recruits graduate STF boot camp
author: Author not found
Content: The passing out parade of the 81st Basic Apprentice Training Course of the Special Task Force (STF) was held yesterday (9) afternoon at the Kalutara Katukurunda STF Training School under the patronage of Minister of Public Security Tiran Alles. A total 191 STF personnel passed out at the ceremony. STF Commandant DIG Varuna Jayasundara, Katukurunda Training School Director SSP Atula Ratnayake and a large number of officers and family members participated in this event. By Pothupitiya Sumit Ranawaka

title: Public Security Minister undertakes official visit to Singapore
author: Author not found
Content: Minister of Public Security Tiran Alles undertook an official visit to Singapore at the invitation of Minister for Home Affairs and Law of Singapore K. Shanmugam from 25-29 October 2022. The delegation participated in a briefing session, arranged by the Ministry of Home Affairs and the Central Narcotics Bureau (CNB) on Singapore’s legal frameworks in maintaining public order and combating drugs. Minister Shanmugam provided an overview of the legal frameworks and the amendments introduced in recent years in both these areas. The two sides also had useful exchanges on lessons learnt in the operational aspects of the related legislation and amendments in a separate session which was joined by Minister of State for Home Affairs Sun Xueling and senior officials from Singapore. The Minister’s programme in Singapore also included an interaction with the officials of the Immigration and Checkpoints Authority (ICA) during which a briefing was provided on the transformation and digitalisation plans of ICA documentation and included a tour of the Identity Authentication and Documents Analysis (IADA) Lab. The two sides exchanged views on present measures being adopted at immigration checkpoints in Singapore and the process that was undertaken during the establishment of the ICA in 2003 to merge the Singapore Immigration & Registration (SIR) and the checkpoint operations of the Customs & Excise Department (CED) to meet emerging security challenges. The Singapore Police Force officials provided a detailed overview of criminal investigation, intelligence, and operational aspects of their work including on the special operations command. A visit to Changi Airport was also organised where a briefing was provided on Singapore’s latest border security measures. Minister Shanmugam hosted Minister Alles and delegation to lunch at the conclusion of the visit where matters of mutual interest were discussed. The delegation accompanying the Minister included the Controller General of Immigration and Emigration, senior officials from the Sri Lanka Police and Special Task Force, the High Commissioner of Sri Lanka to Singapore and senior officials of the High Commission. The High Commission of Sri Lanka in Singapore coordinated the visit with the support of the Ministries of Home Affairs and Foreign Affairs of Singapore, and the Ministry of Public Security of Sri Lanka.

title: Cardinal slams ‘lackadaisical’ arrests, detentions
author: Author not found
Content: Colombo Archbishop Malcolm Cardinal Ranjith expressed his surprise at the “lackadaisical manner” in which people were being arrested and detained under various allegations while those taken in with reference to the Easter Sunday Bombings were being recommended for release by the Attorney General’s Department without a sense of seriousness.   “It made the whole exercise appear to be a drama enacted to mislead the public. The Sri Lankan Catholic Church hoped that in light of what our leaders are doing to those who are struggling to achieve a true sense of democracy and justice for the victims of the Easter Attacks even at the risk of being persecuted, the United Nations Human Rights Council (UNHRC) took due notice of this and steps to get those responsible to follow internationally accepted norms and procedures to ensure a sense of freedom and justice in this country,” Cardinal Ranjith said in a special statement. He accused the Government for its abusive and unjustified use of the Prevention of Terrorism Act, to arrest civil society leaders and those engaged in peaceful resistance to such policies. He also accused the Government of suppressing freedom of speech, expression, and holding peaceful protests. “We cannot accept in any way the unjust arrest and detention of the Convenors of the Inter University Bhikku Federation and Inter University Students’ Federation, Ven. Galwewa Siridhamma Thera and Wasantha Mudalige, The duo had been kept in detention for over 75 days in an unjust manner sans clear accusations and are now reported to be in ill health,” he said. The Colombo Archdiocese also slammed the Government for wasting Rs 90 million on appointing a Presidential Commission to investigate the Easter Attacks in 2021 and storing the findings in the Parliamentary Library. Spokesman for the Colombo Archdiocese, Fr. Cyril Gamini Fernando, reading out the statement of Cardinal Ranjith, further added that public funds wasted on preparing a report on Easter Sunday Attacks in 2019 would have been better spent on penning a book. Speaking to the media at the Colombo Archbishop’s House, he said, the Government should have spent the Rs 90 million on hiring a journalist or author to write an investigative book on the 21 April 2019, Easter Attacks and making it available in all libraries, rather than appointing a Presidential Commission to investigate the attacks and then letting its report rot in the Parliamentary Library. “The Presidential Commission performed its task and submitted a report which had enough evidence to act on,” he said, accusing the Government and the Attorney General’s Department of wilfully avoiding acting on the Commission’s report. He alleged that it only appears to be yet another act of corruption and fraud which drove the country towards its present bankrupt situation. “There are certain confidential facts which have been marked as ‘X’ in the commission report indicating that they should not be publicised. But that does not mean that the findings in the remaining five volumes should not be publicised as well. The Attorney General has shown that his establishment is not independent by his failure to implement recommendations given by the Presidential Commission. He should reveal to the public as to why he is unable to implement those recommendations,” Fr. Fernando stressed. By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: Culprits should be severely dealt with – CTSU
author: Author not found
Content: The Ceylon Teachers’ Service Union (CTSU) has demanded the maximum possible punishment for the teacher, principal, and Police Officers involved in the beating and electrocution of three Grade 5 students at Millaniya Primary School in Horana. Speaking at a media briefing held yesterday (8) at the Vocational Training Centre in Dehiwala, CTSU General Secretary Mahinda Jayasinghe said, the Police have no right to intervene in school disciplinary action under any circumstances. “In this incident, it is claimed that the Police beat and electrocuted these 10-year-olds. We demand that the authorities punish the wrongdoers to the full extent of the law,” he added. Jayasinghe requested teachers and principals to be patient no matter how often dips in discipline occur in schools. “In the past period, various incidents related to the punishment of schoolchildren were reported. Recently, there were reports from Hatton and Millaniya Primary School in Horana,” he added. He added that the CTSU condemns a teacher or principal punishing a child mentally or physically. By Nabiya Vaffoor

title: Education Minister assures impartial probe
author: Author not found
Content: Samagi Jana Balawegaya MP Kavinda Jayawardena demanded an impartial investigation regarding the incident of Police assaulting several students at a school in the Western Province. He also said the culprits should be punished and justice meted out. MP Jayawardena added, “We learnt from the news that students were beaten for allegedly stealing a purse. They were beaten by the Police with batons and the students complained that they were given electric shocks. If this is the case, an investigation must be done immediately.”  Sri Lanka Podujana Peramuna MP Jagath Kumara also said that if some are trying to bury the future of the country there won’t be hopes for a new day. “Therefore, investigations should be conducted into the school including the principal and the Police and adequate measures must be taken against the culprits”. Minister of Education Susil Premajayantha responded that an investigation will be conducted by the National Child Protection Authority and an independent investigation will be conducted as per the instructions of the Secretary of the Ministry of Education, and that the Parliament will be informed about the report. BY Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: P’naruwa District Secy will be questioned – PM
author: Author not found
Content: No State employee can suppress or insult the dignity, not just of a child, but also anyone else, Prime Minister Dinesh Gunawardena insisted while responding to a question raised by Samagi Jana Balawegaya (SJB) MP Rohini Wijeratne in Parliament yesterday (8) regarding the Polonnaruwa District Secretary disclosing information about a 13-year-old pregnant girl and apologising for the mistake. MP Wijeratne questioned what steps would be taken against the District Secretary as the 13-year-old could be traumatised. The PM said, the Government has called for an explanation from the District Secretary and necessary steps will be taken. “The District Secretary has been informed to clarify the facts immediately. We will take necessary steps. No State employee can suppress or insult the dignity of any individual, including children,” he added. BY Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: Create regulatory body before licensing casinos – Harsha
author: Author not found
Content: Before granting licences to start casinos, Samagi Jana Balawegaya MP Dr. Harsha de Silva demanded the establishment of a casino regulatory body in the country. He said unlike other countries, the Ministry of Finance is trying to issue licences to start up gambling businesses. Dr. de Silva speaking in Parliament yesterday (8) about the proposal presented to MPs by the Minister of Finance requesting permission to start casinos, said that if the Government wants to grant licences to start casinos, they can, but there should be a regulatory authority. He added that the Finance Minister is trying to issue casino licences and this is not done in any other country where there is good governance. “There was a law which said that one has to pay 100 dollars to enter a casino. No one who runs a casino took 100 dollars. They didn’t even pay income tax. In the end, the people were taxed and also all those taxes were increased. The problem is not in setting up casinos. If casinos are set up, there should be an institute that regulates them. It is from that institute that licences should be given,” he said. BY Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: Amaraweera says CID called in to investigate
author: Author not found
Content: While noting that he has given full liberty to relevant authorities to take necessary action, Minister of Agriculture and Wildlife and Forest Resources Conservation Mahinda Amaraweera yesterday (8) in Parliament said, the CID will be called in to investigate the infamous Yala incident. The Minister also said, that he has also called for an interim report on the incident where some 30 jeeps were driven recklessly inside Yala National Park while disturbing and threatening local wildlife. Amaraweera also vouched that all the culprits will be brought to justice. The Minister said this in response to Samagi Janabalawegaya MP Mayantha Dissanayake who asked if the Minister is planning to make a special statement about the incident as his reputation was tainted by the heavy media exposure. Minister Amaraweera said the Yala, incident happened while he was abroad and that he informed the IGP and the Ministry Secretary to take appropriate measures. “As a result, several vehicles along with a group of individuals have already been taken into custody in connection to the incident, and they will not be able to evade the law. Actions will be taken against the suspects regardless of who they are or how well they are connected. Investigations in this regard are still underway,” he said. MP Weerasumana Weerasinghe asked what measures have been taken so far. “You directly intervened and made a number of statements about this incident and very little positive measures have been taken. Only six vehicles have been taken into custody out of 30 vehicles. Also, only the drivers have been arrested instead of the real culprits. Amaraweera responded, “We have given full authority to relevant officers to enforce the law. It is being enforced according to the law of the country and I have requested an interim report. They are taking CCTV footage of some vehicles and looking for information. And we are ready to go further and inform an agency like the CID to investigate this”. BY Gagani Weerakoon and Aloka Kasturaiarchchi

title: Govt clinging to power like Somali pirates – AKD
author: Author not found
Content: JJB Leader Anura Kumara Dissanayake yesterday (8) likened the Ranil Wickremesinghe Government to a group of Somali pirates who had captured a ship. Moving a motion for debate during the adjournment of the House, Dissanayake said the Government should hold Local Authorities Elections by 20 March 2023. “What we have today is not a government of people’s mandate. If you really care about the people’s mandate, the Government should hold elections. We hope the National Elections Commission will hold elections on time without being trapped by various snares set by the Government to postpone elections. We also tell former Elections Commissioner Mahinda Deshapriya that all know that the Government is trying to delay the elections by raising an issue of delimitation and ask him not to be complicit in this crime of depriving people of their franchise,” Dissanayake said. He said, the statistics made available to the public by government agencies, international organisations, as well as the media showed a very dangerous situation. As per the latest UNICEF report, 5.7 million people including 2.3 million children need immediate humanitarian assistance. He said, history shows that governments that choose suppression as their mode of governance had been consigned to the dustbin by people. “We demand the Government to tell the world for what reason they are detaining Inter University Students’ Federation Convenor Wasantha Mudalige and Inter University Bhikkhu Federation Convenor Ven. Galewela Siridhamma Thera.” “This suppression by the Government against people will further isolate us in the international community. There is massive social unrest owing to poverty and the Government’s inability to solve the unemployment crisis. In the face of uprisings, people’s anger, and protests, the Government continues to appoint ministers and make use of suppression to hold onto power and keep on stealing. Our country being held by this makeshift government is akin to a ship held by a group of Somali pirates,” Dissanayake said. By Gagani Weerakoon and Aloka Kasturiarachchi
