Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Culprits should be severely dealt with – CTSU
author: Author not found
Content: The Ceylon Teachers’ Service Union (CTSU) has demanded the maximum possible punishment for the teacher, principal, and Police Officers involved in the beating and electrocution of three Grade 5 students at Millaniya Primary School in Horana. Speaking at a media briefing held yesterday (8) at the Vocational Training Centre in Dehiwala, CTSU General Secretary Mahinda Jayasinghe said, the Police have no right to intervene in school disciplinary action under any circumstances. “In this incident, it is claimed that the Police beat and electrocuted these 10-year-olds. We demand that the authorities punish the wrongdoers to the full extent of the law,” he added. Jayasinghe requested teachers and principals to be patient no matter how often dips in discipline occur in schools. “In the past period, various incidents related to the punishment of schoolchildren were reported. Recently, there were reports from Hatton and Millaniya Primary School in Horana,” he added. He added that the CTSU condemns a teacher or principal punishing a child mentally or physically. By Nabiya Vaffoor

title: Education Minister assures impartial probe
author: Author not found
Content: Samagi Jana Balawegaya MP Kavinda Jayawardena demanded an impartial investigation regarding the incident of Police assaulting several students at a school in the Western Province. He also said the culprits should be punished and justice meted out. MP Jayawardena added, “We learnt from the news that students were beaten for allegedly stealing a purse. They were beaten by the Police with batons and the students complained that they were given electric shocks. If this is the case, an investigation must be done immediately.”  Sri Lanka Podujana Peramuna MP Jagath Kumara also said that if some are trying to bury the future of the country there won’t be hopes for a new day. “Therefore, investigations should be conducted into the school including the principal and the Police and adequate measures must be taken against the culprits”. Minister of Education Susil Premajayantha responded that an investigation will be conducted by the National Child Protection Authority and an independent investigation will be conducted as per the instructions of the Secretary of the Ministry of Education, and that the Parliament will be informed about the report. BY Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: CEB Makes Rs 333M Generation Profit
author: Author not found
Content: Ceylon Electricity Board (CEB) was free from using the expensive fuel oil for power generation in only the fourth day after 85 days on Monday (7) due to CEB’s cheap hydroelectricity dominating Sri Lanka’s power sector, CEB data from yesterday (8) showed. Consequently, CEB made a generation profit of Rs 332,946,600 (Rs 333 million) on Monday. Sri Lanka consumed a total of 28.68 gigawatt hours (GWh) of electricity on Monday, according to the CEB. Their splits being CEB Hydro (17.56 GWh), CEB Coal (7.91 GWh), CEB Wind (O.61 GWh), Private Sector (PS) Solar 0.24 GWh, PS Biomass (0.23 GWh), PS Mini Hydro (1.77 GWh), and PS Wind (0.36 GWh), respectively. According to Central Bank of Sri Lanka’s (CBSL’s) 2021 Annual Report, the cheapest source of electricity generation to the CEB last year was CEB Hydro at Rs 1.67 a kilowatt hour (kWh) or per one unit. Other generation costs in ascending order were CEB coal (Rs 10.68), CEB Wind, PS Biomass, PS Mini Hydro and PS Wind bunched together (Rs 16.22), Independent Power Producers’ (IPP’)/PS Fuel Oil (Rs 30.35) and CEB Fuel Oil (Rs 32.03), respectively. According to CBSL, CEB’s average tariff rate last year was Rs 16.37 a unit. The above calculations, based on last year’s costs data by CBSL, discount CEB’s transmission and distribution losses estimated at 8.72 per cent last year and CEB’s 75 per cent tariff hike effective from 9 August 2022. Meanwhile, the other three days in the reference period where CEB was fuel oil free were on 14 October, 17 October, and 23 October, respectively. The first day of the current 85-day reference period in question begins on 15 August 2022. By Paneetha Ameresekere

title: Heroin users on the rise – Police
author: Author not found
Content: At the request of Ceylon Today, the Police Media Unit in Colombo said 178,289 cases involving heroin-related charges were filed in the country between 2019 and 31 October 2022 and 177,599 persons were accused of heroin-related charges. During the same period, all of the accused were arrested with 54,862 kilogrammes of heroin, ganja, ice, and other synthetic drugs. According to the Police, there were over 50,000 heroin-related cases between 2020 and 2021, and heroin is the most used drug. During the same period, the Police filed 111,899 ganja-related cases, and 159,667 people were accused of possessing ganja. In the same period, the number of cases involving ice and synthetic drugs was 25,222 and 25,155, respectively. By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: Sri Pada season to start 7 December
author: Author not found
Content: Chief Incumbent of the Sri Pada Raja Maha Viharaya, Ven. Bengamuwe Dhammadinna Thera, said the pilgrimages to Sri Pada Mountain will start with the dawn of the Unduwap Full Moon Poya Day next month. He said the annual pilgrimage to the holy site will begin from 7 December onwards for the 2022-2023 season. He made this statement during a meeting on 8 November held with Nuwara Eliya District Secretary Nandana Galaboda on details pertaining to the start of the Sri Pada season. The Thera added that increased facilities will be provided to devotees and visitors with the assistance of both the State and private sector during the pilgrimage season which is set to last till the dawn of the Vesak Full Moon Poya Day next May. BY Neeta Pathma Kumari – Norwood

title: ‘Ice’ peddler arrested in Kalmunai
author: Author not found
Content: Periya Neelavanai Police said yesterday (8), an individual who was distributing crystal methamphetamine (Ice) to students for an extended period had been arrested by STF personnel attached to the Kalmunai STF camp. Periya Neelavanai Police added that following a tip-off received to Kalmunai STF camp of an individual peddling Ice, a group of STF personnel raided a location on Almanar Road in Periya Neelavanai Police Division and arrested him. The suspect is a 28-year-old resident of Maruthamunai 2 area and 4.35 grams of Ice was seized. Later, the suspect was handed over to Periya Neelavanai Police. By Naalir Jamaldeen

title: Southern LG bodies given Rs 4,800 – Governor
author: Author not found
Content: Governor of the Southern Province Dr. Willie Gamage said a sum of Rs. 4,800 had been provided to cover stamp costs, Court fees and fines for 49 Local Government (LG) bodies under the purview of the Southern Province in the past three-year period. He stated that the Court fees and fines that are owed to the LG bodies are being deposited on 16th of each month. He added that presently such costs are covered 100 per cent by his Office. BY Kamal Wijehewa – Galle

title: Bust of pioneer Lankan Envoy unveiled in New Delhi
author: Author not found
Content: A bust of Sir D.B. Jayatilaka, first Representative of Sri Lanka to India was unveiled at the Sri Lanka High Commission in New Delhi on 7 November. The bust of the late envoy was commissioned by the High Commission in a bid to commemorate the 80th Anniversary of Sri Lanka sending her first Representative to India in 1942. A few former High Commissioners of India to Sri Lanka, family members of two former Indian High Commissioners to Colombo and two Deputy High Commissioners of India who had served in Sri Lanka joined Sri Lanka’s High Commissioner to India Milinda Moragoda in unveiling the bust at a ceremony held at the High Commission premises. Former High Commissioners of India to Sri Lanka, Ambassadors Gopal Krishna Gandhi, Alok Prasad, Ashok K. Kantha, Y.K. Sinha and Dr. Ritu Chhatwal, daughter of former High Commissioner S.J.S. Chhatwal and Madurendra Nath Jha, son of former High Commissioner N.N. Jha as well as Ambassador Mohan Kumar and Deputy National Security Adviser of India Ambassador Vikram Misri who had served as Deputy High Commissioners at the High Commission of India in Colombo were present on the occasion. Well-known Indian author, A.S. Bhasin, who had written a five-volume monumental book on India-Sri Lanka relations, also attended this event.   The unveiling of the bust of Sir D.B. Jayatilaka marked the latest of a series of activities organised by the High Commission to commemorate the 80th Anniversary of Sri Lanka sending her first Representative to India. Earlier, in February, the High Commission named its Chancery Building after Sir D.B. Jayatilaka and in August, a portrait of the latter was unveiled at the High Commission. The bronze bust of Sir D.B. Jayatilaka symbolises the important role that he played by laying the foundation for modern Indo-Lanka relations. The project was funded by the India-Sri Lanka Foundation. The bust was made by prominent Indian sculptor Gautam Pal of Kolkata who was also present at the unveiling ceremony.

title: Exposed clay pits killing people in Kalutara – PS member
author: Author not found
Content: Sri Lanka Podujana Peramuna Kalutara Pradeshiya Sabha (PS) member, Nilantha Chandralal, said that 26 lives have been lost due to the recklessness of clay smugglers and negligence of officials in the Kalutara District. During a meeting of the Kulatara PS convened under its Chairman Sanjeewa Ariyaratne he said that those engaged in the industry have failed to cover clay pits after digging them in areas such as Nugagoda, Kapuhena and Dediyawela. He charged that scores of people who had fallen into the massive unprotected pits had lost their lives to date. He urged officers from the Geological Survey and Mines Bureau and environmental activists to look into the matter and provide a solution to protect lives. BY Sumith Ranawaka – Pothupitiya

title: PRINCIPAL, TWO POLICE OFFICERS REMANDED
author: Author not found
Content: The Principal of a school in Millaniya, Horana and two Police officers who were involved in physically abusing three Grade 5 students were ordered to be remanded till 16 November by Colombo Additional Magistrate Keminda Perera. Five suspects were arrested and produced in Court yesterday (8) by the National Child Protection Authority (NCPA). Another teacher and a Police officer who drove the Police jeep were released on two personal bails. The NCPA arrested five suspects for assaulting three Grade 5 students with batons, taking them out of school in a jeep and subjecting them to electric shocks. The Judicial Medical Officer, who examined the children, confirmed that they were brutally beaten and tortured. The NCPA launched an immediate investigation after receiving information on 3 November from a private informant about the attack that took place on 2 November. The investigations revealed that a school teacher’s purse had been stolen after a break-in at a classroom. As there were suspicions that the three Grade 5 students had been involved, the principal had informed the Police. It was also revealed, during the investigations, that the principal and a teacher had beaten up the students and locked them in the school library before calling the Police.

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: NBRO issues warnings to eight districts
author: Author not found
Content: With the prevailing inclement weather conditions the National Building Research Organisation (NBRO) issued Level One – Yellow Watch and Level Two – Amber Watch landslide early warning alerts to 20 Divisional Secretariat (DS) divisions in eight districts. Alerts have been issued to Badulla, Kandy, Kegalle, Kurunegala, Matale, Matara, Moneragala and Nuwara Eliya districts until further notice. Level Two – Amber Watch landslide early warning alerts have been issued to Passara DS Division and surrounding areas in the Badulla District and Gangawata Korale and Udadumbara DS Divisions and surrounding areas in the Kandy District. Level One – Yellow Watch landslide early warning alerts have been issued to Hali-ela and Lunugala DS Divisions and surrounding areas in the Badulla District, Medadumbara and Pathadumbara DS Divisions and surrounding areas in the Kandy District,Deraniyagala, Ruwanwella,Dehiowita, Mawanella and Yatiyantota DS Divisions and surrounding areas in the Kegalle District, Rideegama DS Division and surrounding areas in the Kurunegala District, Ukuwela and Ambanganga Korale DS Divisions and surrounding areas in the Matale District, Kotapola and Pasgoda DS Divisions and surrounding areas in the Matara District and Bibile DS Division and surrounding areas in the Moneragala District. People living in other hilly areas experiencing heavy showers have been advised of possible landslides. They have been asked to evacuate to safe places after informing the nearest Police and the Disaster Management Centre (DMC) if they notice landslide signs such as slanting trees, telephone and electric posts, sudden appearance of muddy water, springs from the highland, cracks on walls, floors and the ground in neighbouring areas and in close proximity. Meanwhile the Meteorology Department predicted that showers or thundershowers can be expected over most parts of the country today(9) afternoon or night. Heavy showers above 100mm can be expected at some places in the country. The Met Department further predicted that showers can be expected in the Eastern Province and Polonnaruwa and Mullaitivu Districts in the morning. The public should be cautious of possible temporary heavy winds and lightning strikes and exercise cautiousness to minimise damage caused by temporary localised heavy winds and lightning strikes. By Naalir Jamaldeen

title: President proposes ‘Int’l Climate Change University’ in SL
author: Author not found
Content: Pointing out that capacity building is vital for climate action to be successful, President Ranil Wickremesinghe said it is his desire to establish an international climate change university in Sri Lanka. He said the university will be a higher learning, multi stakeholder institution which strengthens people’s capacities. The President said that he has already held discussions with the Commonwealth Secretariat and the Asian Development Bank in this regard and looks forward to receiving the support and endorsement of the international community. President Wickremesinghe met Na Kyung- Won, Special Presidential Envoy for Climate and Environment and Head of the Korean delegation, on the sideline of COP27 in Egypt on 7 November. While appreciating efforts taken by Sri Lanka to address climate change challenges, Na Kyung- Won also commended measures taken to reduce carbon emissions despite the country already having a low carbon emission rate.

title: 317 Lankans rescued, sheltered in Vietnam
author: Author not found
Content: A Japanese-flagged ship transporting cars alerted authorities that a Myanmar-flagged ship suspected of carrying 317 Sri Lankan Tamils en route to Canada was in distress and Singapore authorities rescued them before sending them to Bung Tan in Vietnam yesterday (8). The distressed boat was spotted on 7 October between Vietnam and Philippine waters, according to Foreign Ministry Public Diplomacy Division Director General Sithara Khan, and those rescued were sheltered in a place called Bung Tan in Vietnam. She added that the Maritime Rescue Coordination Centre in Colombo sought assistance from Singapore, Vietnam and the Philippines to rescue them. Khan went on to say that they are still trying to figure out who the migrants are and whether they are all from Sri Lanka. She also stated that the Sri Lanka Consular General will be on the ground in Bung Tan to gather information and report to the Sri Lankan Mission in Hanoi. However, Ceylon Today was able to gather voice recordings sent across where one of the boat people is heard speaking in Tamil saying that there were 317 people on board and that they were sailing as refugees to Canada, but the boat began to sink as rough sea water began to flood their large vessel. They are suspected to be persons from the Northern and Eastern provinces who are facing untold hardships due to the economic crisis. According to the man, there were approximately 50 women and children as well as, many elderly people on board the vessel. “We are refugees and we want to get to Canada, and please spread the word around,” the man said in the recording. When the boat began to sink, the distress signal attracted the attention of a Japanese ship that was nearby in the middle of the sea. “We don’t want the news to reach Sri Lanka.” Our families will be very concerned about us. They’ll be scared,” the man pleaded, adding that they’re all from Sri Lanka. He also stated that they know no one in Canada and that they can sail on a Myanmar flagged vessel. According to the man, those who organised the journey to Canada abandoned them when they were sheltered in Vietnam, saying he was going out to buy food. By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: Rs 9M in licence fees, taxes owed to Galle MC
author: Author not found
Content: The National Audit Office (NAO) says the payment of trade licence fees and industrial taxes which are owed by the Galle Municipal Council (MC) had increased by 167 per cent during the past year compared to 2018. A total of 2,107 lawsuits had been filed from 2018 to 2021 concerning the non-payment of trade licence fees and industrial taxes to the Galle MC. An audit inquiry showed by the end of the past year, from those lawsuits, a sum of Rs 9,073,813 is owed to the Galle MC. The inquiry has also drawn the attention of the Galle MC over the non-payment of the aforesaid fees and taxes as per the Municipal Councils Ordinance. By Kamal Wijehewa – Galle

title: 16 elephant corridors to be reopened in 2023
author: Author not found
Content: The reopening of 16 elephant corridors threatened by human activity will begin in 2023, Minister of Agriculture and Wildlife and Forest Conservation Mahinda Amaraweera said. He has decided to halt human settlement and cultivation of elephant corridors, which is the primary source of conflict between wild elephants and humans, and to prepare all elephant corridors so that wild elephants can travel safely next year. He said the Department of Wildlife Conservation emphasises that Sri Lanka presently has 16 elephant corridors, all of which are threatened by human activity. “These issues have affected elephants attacking villages and people as a result of illegal settlement of people in elephant corridors, the construction of houses and various business places, and the use of them for cultivation. As a result, I directed the Ministry of Wildlife and Forest Conservation to begin the process of reopening all elephant corridors to wild elephant movement in the first month of next year,” he said. In addition, he said, as part of the first phase, it is proposed to free three elephant corridors where human-elephant conflicts are raging, and the Government will take steps to evict people who are illegally residing in or near the elephant corridors, provide them with suitable lands for cultivation and settlement, and compensate them. “By freeing the elephant corridors, we can find a solution to human-elephant conflicts. In addition, a number of other joint programmes have been proposed. Other programmes, such as preventing cattle releases into sanctuaries and wildlife parks, removing unauthorised cattle sheds in parks, building electric fences, and implementing an integrated work order, will begin early next year,” he said. Further, he said, human-elephant conflicts have increased due to the neglect of wild elephant habitats during the construction of large reservoirs, as well as the failure to implement decisions proposed to protect wild elephants there. The minister also said, they are working to find solutions to all of these problems.

title: SLMMF hosts 71st Media Workshop
author: Author not found
Content: The Sri Lanka Muslim Media Forum (SLMMF) hosted its 71st media workshop for students at the auditorium of Al-Hikma National College in Keselwatta, Colombo 11 on 7 November. 120 A/L and O/L students took part in the workshop held under the title “Media in the 21st Century”. Lectures were delivered on print, electronic media and emphasised on the role of journalists and their responsibilities. The workshop was chaired by SLMMF President Furkhan Bee Ifthkhar with the participation of immediate past President Senior media personality Al-haj N.M. Ameen, senior members of SLMMF Thaha Musammil and M.A.M. Nilam. Secretary of SLMMF Sihar Aneez, Assistant Treasurer Naalir Jamaldeen, Shamila Sheriff, Assistant Secretary Shadhique Shihan were also present at the workshop. Assistant Director of Sri Lanka Broadcasting Corporation (SLBC) Tamil News Division trainer Junaid M.Haris and Producer of SLBC Muslim Service and Media trainer Ishfahan Sabdeen delivered lectures under the title “Social media platforms”. Media personal Ashraff A.Samad delivered lecture regarding TV shoot while journalist Ash Sheik Jemsith delivered lecture on lingual abilities to write an error free news story. More than 120 students took part in the workshop. The workshop was arranged by Al-Hikma National College Principal and Poet Mullai Mushrifa and Prof. M.A.M. Rameez Abdullah, Professor in Tamil Department, Faculty of Arts and Culture, South Eastern University. The chief guests, Political Affairs in charge of the Indian High Commission in Colombo Banu Prasadh, Thinakaran Editor in Chief Thinakaran Varamanjari Senthil Velavar presented the certificates to students who took part in the workshop. By Naalir Jamaldeen

title: Akkaraipattu beach clean-up well received
author: Author not found
Content: Akkaraipattu Sunrise Sports Club’s monthly beach clean-up on the theme ‘Let’s clean the beach and maintain physical and mental health’ is progressing well, with the support of the public. This programme, scheduled for every first Saturday of the month, lasts an hour (6:45 a.m. to 7:45 a.m.) with the participation of volunteers of the Sunrise Sports Club headed by M.H. Jeinudeen. Beachgoers also participate in the initiative. Speaking at the last shramadana, President Jeinudeen said keeping the beach neat and tidy is everyone’s responsibility. He urged parents to ensure that children don’t litter the beach. “People’s negligence results in environmental pollution. Let’s unite to create a healthy society,” he added.  Finally, he requested the participants to participate in the next beach clean-up on 5 November. Text and Pix By M.A.P. Deen – Ampara

title: Monkeypox still a public health emergency
author: Author not found
Content: The Health Ministry warned that there was a possibility of more monkeypox cases entering the country. Specialist, Epidemiology Unit, Dr. Chinthana Perera, addressing a virtual discussion on Monday (7) night said although patient numbers have receded globally, monkeypox was still present and the public health emergency situation slapped on it had still not been lifted. Therefore, there was a high possibility of more patients arriving in the country.    “We have been able to manage the patient that sought medical attention by referring him to a State hospital, but there are possibilities of more patients arriving in the country,” he warned. There might even be asymptomatic patients. Dr. Perera said, it was important that all Medical Officers of Health (MOHs) and consultant community units should be vigilant to prevent a spread of the zoonotic infection, especially if patients were asymptomatic. “There are possibilities of a further spread in the viral disease for another year or two. Therefore, there is a high risk of the infection spreading, till such time that the disease is eradicated globally,” he added. By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: PRESIDENT URGES UN SECY GEN TO SUMMON ALL AGRI MINISTERS
author: Author not found
Content: President Ranil Wickremesinghe urged the Secretary-General of the UN, as the head of COP27, to summon a meeting of Ministers of Agriculture of all the countries, to assess the food requirements for 2023 and 2024 and submit a report on the food situation. “We must act fast, otherwise, the damage caused to the political and social structures of countries will be irreparable. At COP28, it is of utmost importance that we compile a medium-term plan to ensure global food security,” he said. The President also emphasised the need to work closely with the multilaterals, sources of funding and the need to formulate a sustainable debt relief plan immediately, to ensure global food security. The President further stated that it is essential to finalise this plan by February 2023 and it should be implemented by the end of the first quarter of 2023, if not the damage caused to the political and social structures of countries will be irreparable. He also highlighted the urgent need of compiling a medium-term plan to ensure global food security at COP28. President Ranil Wickremesinghe made these remarks while participating at the Round Table discussion on ‘Food Security’ at the on-going COP-27 Conference on Climate Change, in Sharm El Sheikh, Egypt. “There are nearly one billion people who are suffering from hunger today, and according to the IMF, over 300 million people’s livelihoods are in danger. Countries affected fall into two categories, 1. Countries where food is no longer available. These countries either have no means to buy food due to rising costs or are unable to produce their own food. 2. Countries which traditionally had an adequate food supply but now find these sources of food out of reach due to rising costs. There was a time when Sri Lanka had no fertiliser and was unable to produce our own food. However, the successful food security programme is a combined mechanism for food security and the recently accessible fertiliser stocks that was made possible thanks to the international community. Nevertheless, there is a sizeable group who do not have the economic resources to access food. All must ensure that food is made available to countries that fall within these two categories. Secondly, they require financial assistance to provide food for their populations.” Common to both categories is the rising levels of debt servicing. The increasing cost of debt has meant that it is more difficult for the developing countries to ensure affordable food for the total population. The IMF estimates that the food and fertiliser price shock, coupled with the rising costs of debt servicing, will add USD 9 billion to the food import bills of the 48 worst affected countries. This means that a resolution to the debt crisis is needed to tackle both these categories. “Currently we are seeing that there is no overall plan to address this situation and no focal point. The UN together with COP and the FAO, the World Food Programme, the World Bank, and the IMF, must form that focal point. I urge the Secretary-General of the UN and Egypt, as the head of the COP27, to call a meeting of the Ministers of Agriculture of all countries to assess the food requirements of 2023 and 2024 and submit a report on the food position. Working together with the multilaterals, sources of funding and a sustainable debt relief plan must be formulated. It is essential that this plan is finalised by February 2023 and taken up for implementation by the end of the first quarter of 2023.”

title: AG’s approval sought in writing – EC
author: Author not found
Content: Chairman of Election Commission Nimal Punchihewa said a document seeking the Attorney General’s (AG) advice on holding Local Government elections will be sent today (8). He said local government authorities will be advised to declare elections after consulting with the AG. He said, in light of the performance of the five-member National Delimitation Committee, the Election Commission has decided to seek the advice of the AG on arrangements for holding Local Government elections. This matter was thoroughly discussed at a recent Election Commission meeting, and the commission decided to seek the AG’s advice. The Election Commission currently has the legal authority to conduct local government elections; however, the commission believes that the recently appointed National Committee for Delimitation of Local Government Divisions has had an impact on those activities. However, Punchihewa said it is critical to seek the AG’s advice in this regard. BY Thameenah Razeek

title: Politically bankrupt groups disrupted protest – SJB
author: Author not found
Content: The Samagi Jana Balawegaya (SJB) alleged a conflict situation was created during the joint protest held in Colombo by the Inter-University Students’ Federation (IUSF) and Frontline Socialist Party (FSP) supporters. SJB National Organiser MP Tissa Attanayake and MP Rajitha Senaratne expressed their opinion about the incident saying that it is ridiculous for a group of people, who have not contributed to the country’s politics, to hoot the Opposition Leader. Attanayake, addressing a press conference, noted that the SJB participated in support of the protest as a symbolic gesture, not to create a conflict situation. “When a group of people tried to end the peaceful protest by clashing with the Police on the way, there was a conflict of opinion among the people who participated,” Attanayake added. Meanwhile, Senaratne said that some people believe that the struggle is great but only one group has the full claim for it. He said, the extremists have worked to destroy the struggle so far and because of that the struggle has weakened today. He also said, political stooges, who are present in various places, did not do anything for the politics of the country, but it is they that hooted at a leader like Sajith Premadasa. “The IUSF is spreading extremism by neglecting all 225 MPs, they also spread these types of ideologies to schools without any problem,” he added. Senaratne further said, saving the young generation, who are involved in such extremism, is a big responsibility of SJB and they are constantly intervening for it. By Mithun Jayawardena

title: No vaccine for monkeypox yet – MRI
author: Author not found
Content: While measures are being taken to treat symptoms of monkeypox, there is currently no vaccine to provide immunity for the disease, Consultant Virologist Medical Research Institute (MRI), Dr. C.J.S. Jayamaha clarified. Dr. Jayamaha when contacted said yesterday (7) clarifying statements issued by certain parties with vested interests said the vaccine is still being developed against the zoonosis viral infection.  He noted that the smallpox vaccine is 30 per cent to 70 per cent effective in preventing monkeypox. However with smallpox being globally eradicated in 1979 the vaccine is still being produced in minor quantities by a very few labs. He noted that although smallpox is similar to chickenpox, the two diseases are from different virus families. Of the seven suspected cases tested by the MRI for monkeypox, three had been diagnosed with chickenpox. “What needs to be noted by the public however, is that while the MRI has a consultant virologist, the World Health Organisation (WHO) approved required reagents and staff to perform real time PCR testing to detect monekypox. The Consultant Virologist urged the public to assist the health services by seeking immediate medical attention – especially if they had arrived from aboard with fever, skin rash in the buttocks, genital area and the body. Meanwhile, the Convenor of Media Committee, Consultant Community Physicians Sri Lanka (CCPSL), Dr. Naveen D. Zoysa, explained that although monkeypox had first been detected in African Countries like Congo it spread to countries like the U.S. and Europe. But it was only declared a public health emergency in July 2022. He said that fever, headache, swelling of the lymph glands, skin lesions, blisters or wounds and muscle pain are symptoms for monkeypox. The virus disease is contracted by close association, during which the person comes into contact with a patient’s wounds or nasal secretions.  By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: President calls for report on Kandakadu clash
author: Author not found
Content: President Ranil Wickremesinghe has called for a full report into the clash that occurred at the Kandakadu Treatment and Rehabilitation Centre on 6 November. Following discussions with Justice Minister Wijeyadasa Rajapakshe, he also said steps needed to be taken to prevent such incidents from occurring again. Later, the situation at the Kandakadu Treatment and Rehabilitation Centre was brought under control. Director-Rehabilitation/ Post Rehabilitation Assistant Branch Brigadier Priyankara Vidanagamage said at least 520 inmates are under Army and Police accountability, while those who were not involved in clashes and were transferred to the Senapura Centre were also returned to the centre later, he added. However, 37 inmates are still reported missing. At least five inmates were injured when two groups clashed at the Kandakadu Treatment and Rehabilitation Centre, Vidanagamage said. He said a tense situation continues at the centre and that the Police and Army have been called in for assistance. He said the clash was between two groups of inmates which included more than 500. “About 547 inmates were involved in the clash. However, we are waiting till the Police arrive at the scene to check whether the remaining are in the premises or out,” he said. Speaking further, Brigadier Vidanagamage said on 6 November night at the Kandakadu Rehabilitation Centre, an argument between two inmates escalated into a clash between two groups and there was a tense situation. He said at that time, inmates from both sides threw stones at each other and they used objects in the environment to attack each other. A search operation had been launched to apprehend the escapees. BY Thameenah Razeek

title: Rs 6B worth heroin seized, 10 arrested
author: Author not found
Content: A special operation conducted by the Navy in coordination with the Police Special Task Force (STF) and Police Narcotics Bureau (PNB) off Hambantota, led to the interception of a local fishing trawler carrying over 331kg of heroin, worth approximately Rs 6 billion and the arrest of 10 persons. The drug-carrying trawler and the suspects were brought to the Galle Harbour, yesterday (7) morning and will be handed over to the PNB for onward legal action. Including the latest seizure, the Sri Lanka Navy has held drugs with a gross street value of over Rs 22.5 billion during operations in 2022. Meanwhile, Sri Lanka Navy spokesman, Captain Indika de Silva, confirmed that the operation was conducted 10 nautical miles off great basses light house in the seas off Hambantota. De Silva said that they apprehended 300 parcels of heroin weighing approx 1 kg each, and during the operation, two fishing boats, one multiday vessel and one dinghy boat had also been taken into custody. The 300 packages of the substance were stuffed in 12 sacks which had been concealed in the trawler. The Navy nabbed six locals aboard and the fishing trawler used for this illegal act on 5 November. The Navy, PNB and STF also held a dinghy, which is suspected to have been made ready to fetch the stock of narcotics from mid-sea and arrested another four suspects involved in the land-network of this racket, in an operation mounted off Nillwella and its beach area on 6 November. Meanwhile, the PNB is conducting further operations in search of more suspects in connection with this illegal act.  The suspects held in this operation were identified as residents of Hambantota, Kottegoda, Dikwella and Mahamadala, who are from 31 to 62 years of age.  The special operation was mounted by the Offshore Patrol Vessel SLNS Wickrama II, based on a coordinated intelligence operation of the Police Special Task Force, Police Narcotics Bureau and Navy Intelligence. By Nabiya Vaffoor

title: President purposely delaying polls – Bimal
author: Author not found
Content: JVP National Organiser, Bimal Rathnayake, said the Government will be washed away if an election is held. Ratnayake claimed that Ranil Wickremesinghe, who became President by default, is purposefully delaying the election. “They are now trying to delay the election by bluffing. Is that something we have to agree on? Ranil Wickremesinghe changed the number of members in the Local Government from 4,000 to 8,000. A delimitation commission is currently in operation, as it was in 2018. Rs 1 billion has been spent. He became President through charity and postponing the election. The people are not pleased with the Presidential Election, the Regional Council Election, the Provincial Council election or even Parliament. As a result, it is a mystery how such a country can run,” he said. BY Anuradha Herath

title: Scheduled fuel price increases could create queues – Petroleum Dealers
author: Author not found
Content: Joint Secretary of the Petroleum Dealers’ Association Kapila Naotunna said price increases on the first and fifteenth of each month will cause more fuel queues in the country. He said fuel station owners have been delaying orders in anticipation of a decrease in prices. However, after Minister of Energy Kanchana Wijesekera clarified that the fuel price revision scheduled for 1 November would not take place, fuel station owners took steps to place orders for fuel. As a result, the Ministry stated that fuel supply has now returned to normal. The fuel price revision method has not changed according to the price formula by the Ministry of Power and Energy. The Ministry confirmed that the formula will continue to be used because revisions should be made based on price fluctuations in the global market. Meanwhile, the President of the All Ceylon Three Wheeler Drivers Trade Union expressed satisfaction with the increase in the three-wheeler fuel quota. The increased fuel quotas for professional three-wheelers went into effect yesterday (7), in the Western Province. In this regard, the fuel quota system update has been in effect since midnight on 6 November. It was recently decided to raise the fuel quota for three-wheelers from five to ten litres, which will be implemented islandwide in stages. BY Thameenah Razeek

title: Agrarian Service Centres to give discounts for Maha
author: Author not found
Content: Given the high prices in the open market, the Ministry of Agriculture has taken steps to distribute insecticides and herbicides required for the Maha season via Agrarian Service Centres. During Maha Season, the Ministry intends to distribute insecticides and herbicides needed for paddy cultivation and other crops through Agrarian Service Centres located islandwide. In this regard, Agriculture Minister Mahinda Amaraweera met with all private agrochemical companies who agreed to the work arrangement. The Minister said, this step is being taken to help farmers because insecticides and herbicides are currently being sold at exorbitant prices. As a result, the Department of Agrarian Development will buy insecticides and herbicides for paddy and other crops from the private sector with Department of Agrarian Development funds and sells them to farmers at a five or six per cent discount, depending on the discount offered by the companies. “Insecticides and herbicides can be purchased at the island’s 566 Agrarian Services Centres. A portion of the proceeds from the sale will be donated to the appropriate farmer organisations,” he said.

title: Happy with increased quota, but will not reduce fares
author: Author not found
Content: The All Island Three-Wheeler Drivers’ Union, expressed its appreciation for the increase in fuel quota for three-wheelers but confirmed that they will not reduce fares. The union’s president Lalith Dharmasekara noted that they will consider reducing fares once the Government decides to increase the quota from 10 litres to 30 litres.  “We are glad that the Government has decided to increase the fuel quota allocated for three-wheelers from 5 litres to 10 litres, and are now regulating the three wheelers sector. Nearly 9,000 three-wheelers within the Western Province have been registered via the website www.wptaxi.lk,” he added.   The increased fuel quota for passenger transport three-wheelers in the Western Province came into effect yesterday (7). The QR data system was updated on 6 November midnight. By Nabiya Vaffoor

title: NCPA to interrogate principal, teacher and three cops
author: Author not found
Content: A Principal, a teacher and three Police officers will be summoned to the National Child Protection Authority (NCPA) today (8) for extensive questioning regarding the torturing of three Grade 5 students at Gungamuwa Kanishta Vidyalaya in Raigama, Horana. Among these officers are a Police Inspector, a sergeant, and a constable from the Millaniya Police. Chairman of the NCPA Udaya Amarasinghe said, they were summoned because they should be interrogated thoroughly before proceeding to court. Meanwhile, the Chairman said, the jeep, which had already been taken into custody by the NCPA as evidence, had been inspected and a wire allegedly used to give electric shocks to the students was discovered. An investigation into a complaint received by the NCPA revealed that at the request of the principal, a team of Police officers beat three Grade 5 students with batons and later took them out of the school in a jeep to be given electric shocks on 2 November. Amarasinghe said, the Judicial Medical Officer who examined the children confirmed that they were brutally beaten and tortured. He said, he received the news about the attack on 3 November from a private informant and had immediately launched investigations. BY Vineetha M. Gamage

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Holidays cause fuel shortage at CEYPETCO sheds
author: Author not found
Content: Due to the long weekend and the bank holiday, which prevented Petroleum dealers from depositing money, more than 75 per cent of CEYPETCO fuel distributing stations across the country had not placed orders for fuel stocks, the Petroleum Dealers’ Association said. A spokesman for the association pointed out that if the fuel-on-cheque facility was still available, this problem would not have occurred. He said even petroleum dealers are having difficulty finding the money to be deposited a day ahead, adding that, no dealer will issue any cheque that will bounce, nor will he issue any further dated cheques to purchase fuel. When queried about this, from the Ministry of Power and Energy, a spokesman said the dealers purposely did not order fuel stocks in order to show that there was a fuel shortage in order to fulfil their other desires. He said if the dealers wanted fuel today, they needed to deposit money on Friday because of the long weekend ahead. BY Thameenah Razeek

title: Lab-grown red blood cells to be transfused for first time
author: Author not found
Content: Manufactured red blood cells were grown from stem cells from donors. The red blood cells were then transfused into volunteers in the RESTORE randomised controlled clinical trial. This is the first time in the world that red blood cells that have been grown in a laboratory have been given to another person as part of a trial into blood transfusion. If proved safe and effective, manufactured blood cells could in time revolutionise treatments for people with blood disorders such as sickle cell and rare blood types. It can be difficult to find enough well-matched donated blood for some people with these disorders. Chief Investigator Professor Cedric Ghevaert, Professor in Transfusion Medicine and Consultant Haematologist at the University of Cambridge and NHS Blood and Transplant, said: “We hope our lab grown red blood cells will last longer than those that come from blood donors. If our trial, the first such in the world, is successful, it will mean that patients who currently require regular long-term blood transfusions will need fewer transfusions in future, helping transform their care.” The RESTORE trial is a joint research initiative by NHS Blood and Transplant and the University of Bristol, working with the University of Cambridge, Guy’s and St Thomas’ NHS Foundation Trust, NIHR Cambridge Clinical Research Facility and Cambridge University Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust. It is part-funded by a National Institute for Health and Care Research (NIHR) grant. Professor Ashley Toye, Professor of Cell Biology at the University of Bristol and Director of the NIHR Blood and Transplant Unit in red cell products, said: “This challenging and exciting trial is a huge stepping stone for manufacturing blood from stem cells. This is the first-time lab grown blood from an allogeneic donor has been transfused and we are excited to see how well the cells perform at the end of the clinical trial.” The trial is studying the lifespan of the lab grown cells compared with infusions of standard red blood cells from the same donor. The lab-grown blood cells are all fresh, so the trial team expect them to perform better than a similar transfusion of standard donated red cells, which contains cells of varying ages. Additionally, if manufactured cells last longer in the body, patients who regularly need blood may not need transfusions as often. That would reduce iron overload from frequent blood transfusions, which can lead to serious complications. The trial is the first step towards making lab grown red blood cells available as a future clinical product. For the foreseeable future, manufactured cells could only be used for a very small number of patients with very complex transfusions needs. NHSBT continues to rely on the generosity of donors. Co-Chief Investigator Dr Rebecca Cardigan, Head of Component Development NHS Blood and Transplant and Affiliated Lecturer at the University of Cambridge, said: “It’s really fantastic that we are now able to grow enough red cells to medical grade to allow this trial to commence. We are really looking forward to seeing the results and whether they perform better than standard red cells.” Two people have so far been transfused with the lab grown red cells. They were closely monitored and no untoward side effects were reported. They are well and healthy. The identities of participants infused so far are not currently being released, to help keep the trial ‘blinded’. The amount of lab grown cells being infused varies but is around 5-10mls – about one to two teaspoons. Donors were recruited from NHSBT’s blood donor base. They donated blood to the trial and stem cells were separated out from their blood. These stem cells were then grown to produce red blood cells in a laboratory at NHS Blood and Transplant’s Advanced Therapies Unit in Bristol. The recipients of the blood were recruited from healthy members of the NIHR BioResource. A minimum of 10 participants will receive two mini transfusions at least four months apart, one of standard donated red cells and one of lab grown red cells, to find out if the young red blood cells made in the laboratory last longer than cells made in the body. Further trials are needed before clinical use, but this research marks a significant step in using lab grown red blood cells to improve treatment for patients with rare blood types or people with complex transfusion needs. John James OBE, Chief Executive of the Sickle Cell Society, said: “This research offers real hope for those difficult to transfuse sickle cell patients who have developed antibodies against most donor blood types. However, we should remember that the NHS still needs 250 blood donations every day to treat people with sickle cell and the figure is rising. The need for normal blood donations to provide the vast majority of blood transfusions will remain. We strongly encourage people with African and Caribbean heritage to keep registering as blood donors and start giving blood regularly.” Dr. Farrukh Shah, Medical Director of Transfusion for NHS Blood and Transplant, said: “Patients who need regular or intermittent blood transfusions may result develop antibodies against minor blood groups which makes it harder to find donor blood which can be transfused without the risk of a potentially life-threatening reaction. This world leading research lays the groundwork for the manufacture of red blood cells that can safely be used to transfuse people with disorders like sickle cell.  The need for normal blood donations to provide the vast majority of blood will remain. But the potential for this work to benefit hard to transfuse patients is very significant.” (University of Cambridge)

title: Over 222,000 have left SL for jobs abroad – ADBI
author: Author not found
Content: In the wake of the current economic crisis, over 222,000 people had left the country for foreign employment, of which approximately 30 per cent were skilled workers, from January–September 2022, Tokyo based Asian Development Bank Institute (ADBI). in a report released yesterday (7) said. The report titled ‘Strengthening Active Labour Market Policies to Drive an Inclusive Recovery in Asia’,  further said, “It is to be noted that this number is likely to be higher when considering those who have permanently migrated amid these circumstances. Another facet of this issue that is yet to be fully investigated and/or explored is the exodus of workers, especially skilled workers, since the beginning of 2022 in the wake of the current economic crisis. As the majority, if not the entirety, of these workers would have benefited from the ‘free education and health’ system, such migration is an irreparable loss to the economy in terms of the high levels of investment made which the economy has not reaped. While this exodus is triggered by the loss of macroeconomic stability, this trend of departures can cause a vicious cycle of worsening instability as continued outward migration will result in the continuous dwindling of skill availability and the economy’s potential, leading to further deterioration of macroeconomic stability, which can trigger another round of accelerated labour exits and so on. Further, as Sri Lanka’s labour market provides little leeway for attracting foreign talent from elsewhere, this outward labour migration will likely hinder the recovery process in the near term and the subsequent progress of the economy into a middle-income one in the medium run. The onset of the Covid-19 pandemic, followed by an unprecedented economic crisis since early 2022 has further exacerbated many of these existing fragilities and is likely to have created a segment of new poor, due to the significant share of informal sector and low occupational category workers, while suffering from potential learning poverty in the medium term because of issues relating to access to quality education amid the challenges of COVID-19 and the economic crisis. ” It further said,“As the Government of Sri Lanka (GoSL) sets off on a path of fiscal consolidation, this might be an opportune moment for it to revisit the effectiveness of the provisioning of free universal education and healthcare and to identify means of ensuring that the benefits of such investments accrue to the economy.  Accordingly, to address the several multi-faceted issues prevailing in the Sri Lankan labour market, a concerted effort by all stakeholders, ranging from the GoSL to education sector policymakers, private and public sector education providers and practitioners, and even employers, is needed for Sri Lanka to continue to reap the benefits of the expensive investments that have been made thus far and thereby the existing human capital base of the country. Urgent and focused policy measures are imperative to safeguard this key resource of the economy which will be pivotal to the country’s recovery process in the near-to medium run and thereby the prevention of any scarring of the human capital base.” ADBI is the ADB’s think tank. BY Paneetha Ameresekere

title: Severe measures to avoid mishaps underway -Northern Governor
author: Author not found
Content: President of the Jaffna District Bus Owners’ Association, Vinayakamurthy Sajinthan, said that all long-distance private buses will start from the newly built bus station for long-distance services from today (8). The arrangement was acknowledged by the Mayor of Jaffna as well. Vinayakamurthy said that all minibuses and private buses operating in the Jaffna District will commence from the bus station from today morning. Commenting on many bus accidents in the region, Northern Province Governor Jeevan Thiagarajah said that measures have been taken to check route permits of long-distance buses plying on the A9 road every day. “Regarding the accidents, I have asked the Police and other parties for an investigation report on the recent accident where three persons were killed.” He also added that they have had a conversation with the Chairman of the National Transport Commission and have taken some decisions regarding how to avoid accidents. The arrangements are to check the route clearance of all Jaffna to Colombo buses and other distant destinations at one place within the Northern Province. He also said that bus drivers driving on the A9 road will be given a 10 minute break.   In addition, authorities are allowed to carry out inspections to confirm the quality of all long-distance buses at the end of every month. “We are also going to impose time restrictions for travel from Vavuniya to Jaffna. Therefore, all matters have been discussed with the Chairman of the National Transport Commission and a decision has been reached. By implementing these matters soon, accidents caused by buses in the North can be reduced,” he said. By T Pratheepan – Jaffna correspondent

title: Kalkudah Police arrest six burglars
author: Author not found
Content: Kalkudah Police arrested six people yesterday (7) for various burglaries in Kalkudah, Santhiveli and other areas in the Kalkudah Police Division. The arrests were made by Kalkudah Police on Sunday (6) evening based on complaints provided by the victims. According to Kalkudah Police OIC C.I. Chandana Vithanage, Police recovered a large amount of burgled items based on information revealed by the suspects during interrogation. Twelve water pumps, one motorcycle, one bicycle, two electric fans, an electronic scale and gold jewelry are among the stolen items. The Kalkudah Police are conducting further inquiries while questioning the detained suspects and will produce them in Court following preliminary investigations.

title: Katina Pinkama Ceremony of Sandahiru Seya held in Anuradhapura
author: Author not found
Content: The Katina Pinkama Ceremony of Sandahiru Seya in the sacred city of Anuradhapura was held on 3and 4 November. The noblest annual religious ceremony, held under the auspices of the Defence Secretary, General Kamal Gunaratne (Retd), was also attended by Commander of the Navy, Vice Admiral Nishantha Ulugetenne. The arrangements of this monastic tradition preserved and observed by Buddhists was organised by a Board of Trustees of Sandahiru Seya, comprising personnel from armed services. Commencing the rituals of this meritorious event, Defence Secretary placed the Katina robe at MahaViharaya in Anuradhapura and performed associated rituals, on 3 November. In the same evening, the Chief Incumbent of Sri Dalada Viharaya in Kindalegama, Medawachchiya and the Deputy Principal of Kebithigollewa Central College, Rajakeeya Panditha Waththegama Sumana Thera conducted a Dharma Deshana at the Sandahiru Seya premises. On the morning of 4 November, the Katina robe was brought by a colourful procession from Maha Viharaya to Sandahiru Seya and it was offered in pious sentiments. Meanwhile, the morning alms were offered to Maha Viharaya and mid-day alms were offered to 30 members of MahaSangha including Atamasthanadhipathi, Chief Incumbent of Ruwanweliseya temple and Chief Sanghanayake of Nuwara Kalaviya Most Ven. Pallegama Hemarathana Thera. Chief of Defence Staff, General Shavendra Silva, Commander of the Army, Lieutenant General Vikum Liyanage, Commander of the Air Force, Air Marshal Sudarshana Pathirana, officers and other ranks from tri-services and a group of Buddhist devotees were also present during this occasion.

title: President meets delegates, envoys at COP27
author: Author not found
Content: President Ranil Wickremesinghe met delegations across the world and special Presidential Envoys while attending the COP27 conference in Egypt yesterday (7). President Wickremesinghe had a bilateral meeting with Borut Pahor, President of the Republic of Slovenia yesterday. He also held discussions with Na Kyung-Won, Special Presidential Envoy for Climate and Environment, Head of the delegation from the Republic of Korea. He then met the US Special Presidential Envoy for Climate, John Kerry.

title: President flies to Egypt to attend COP27
author: Author not found
Content: President Ranil Wickremesinghe left the island yesterday (6) for Egypt to participate in the COP27 Conference on Climate Change, which is scheduled to be held from 6 to 18 November in Sharm El Sheikh, Egypt. President Wickremesinghe is scheduled to address the conference on Climate Change issues in Sri Lanka and around the world, on 7 and 8 November. Concurrently, President Wickremesinghe will attend the Global Food Security Forum and the World Leaders’ Forum. Upon his arrival in Egypt, Cairo, President Wickremesinghe met United Nations Secretary-General, António Guterres. The President briefed the Secretary-General on the Government’s plans on the National Environmental Policy. The Secretary General recalled memories of his first visit to Sri Lanka in 1978. At COP27, countries come together to take action towards achieving the world’s collective climate goals as agreed under the Paris Agreement and Convention. Building on the outcomes and momentum of COP26 in Glasgow last year, nations are expected to demonstrate at COP27 that they are in a new era of implementation by turning their commitments under the Paris Agreement into action. Minister of Environment Naseer Ahamed, Senior Advisor to the President on Climate Change Ruwan Wijewardene, President’s International Affairs Director Dinouk Colombage and the President’s private secretary, Sandra Perera accompany the President.

title: Vedda Chief wants National List Seat for community rep
author: Author not found
Content: Vedda Chief Uruwarige Wanniyalaaththo urged that an indigenous representative be appointed to Parliament on the National List. He said, there were over 500,000 indigenous people in the Badulla, Moneragala, Ampara, Batticaloa, Trincomalee, and Polonnaruwa Districts. He said indigenous people in Australia were represented in Parliament and indigenous people held high positions in Nepal. He expressed these concerns to the media in Dambana. Further, he said for the first time in our country, an indigenous representative was elected as a Pradeshiya Sabha member. “She is my daughter-in-law and lives in Hennanigala. Our people, who have the distinction of being the first and oldest owners of this country, continue to lack parliamentary representation. I have been talking for quite some time. A proposal was also made to the Government to discuss issues which we face. After a week or two, there were discussions in this regard but later faded into oblivion,” he said. He said there were representatives to talk about the race they belong to as well as those who represent various religions. “However, people like us, the country’s original owners, have no one to talk about our problems. Currently, the Ministry of Culture looks into our issues but this Ministry does not solely handle our issues but has to deal with other issues as well,” he said. By Thameenah Razeek

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture.
