Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Vedda Chief wants National List Seat for community rep
author: Author not found
Content: Vedda Chief Uruwarige Wanniyalaaththo urged that an indigenous representative be appointed to Parliament on the National List. He said, there were over 500,000 indigenous people in the Badulla, Moneragala, Ampara, Batticaloa, Trincomalee, and Polonnaruwa Districts. He said indigenous people in Australia were represented in Parliament and indigenous people held high positions in Nepal. He expressed these concerns to the media in Dambana. Further, he said for the first time in our country, an indigenous representative was elected as a Pradeshiya Sabha member. “She is my daughter-in-law and lives in Hennanigala. Our people, who have the distinction of being the first and oldest owners of this country, continue to lack parliamentary representation. I have been talking for quite some time. A proposal was also made to the Government to discuss issues which we face. After a week or two, there were discussions in this regard but later faded into oblivion,” he said. He said there were representatives to talk about the race they belong to as well as those who represent various religions. “However, people like us, the country’s original owners, have no one to talk about our problems. Currently, the Ministry of Culture looks into our issues but this Ministry does not solely handle our issues but has to deal with other issues as well,” he said. By Thameenah Razeek

title: Crooks still remain and are given a safe haven – AKD
author: Author not found
Content: Although a systemic change was promised, wrong economic policies, corruption and crooks still remain and are given a safe haven, so said Jathika Jana Balawegaya Leader, Anura Kumara Dissanayake. Dissanayake said the people called for a systemic change, however, nothing has really changed as far as the Government is concerned. He said the Government was still following the same old policies and corruption was rampant as before. Speaking at the JJB Ambalantota convention on Saturday (5) Dissanayake said the JJB’s intention was to transform the country by initiating a change in the economy, politics and social culture. He emphasized that JJB members do not misuse power and take advantage of the citizens.  Dissanayake said the citizens of the country need an organised political culture and not politics where clowns ruled the roost. BY Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: Three Children Subjected to Assault, Electric Shocks
author: Author not found
Content: An investigation into a complaint received by the National Child Protection Authority (NCPA), has revealed that at the request of the principal of a school in Raigama, Horana, a team of Police officers had assaulted three Grade 5 children with batons, put them in a jeep, took them out of the school and subjected them to electric shocks. NCPA Chairman Udaya Amarasinghe said yesterday (6), the Judicial Medical Officer who examined the children, stated that they were brutally beaten and tortured. He said he received information on 3 November from a private informant about the attack that had taken place on 2 November and immediately launched an investigation into the incident. The Chairman also stated that so far, investigations have revealed that a school teacher’s purse had been stolen after a classroom had been broken into. As there were suspicions that the three Grade 5 students had been involved, the Principal had informed the Police. According to Amarasinghe, it was also revealed, during the investigations, that the principal and a teacher had beaten up a group of Grade 5 students and locked them in the school library before calling the Police. The Chairman said statements were taken from the beaten children as well as other Grade 5 students. They had said they were beaten in the library room by the principal and another teacher and that the Police came and assaulted three of those who were locked up. They were taken out of the school in the jeep, a wire inside the jeep was placed under their bare feet and they were given electric shocks, according to reports. Amarasinghe also said the NCPA’s Police unit is conducting additional investigations and that once the investigations are completed, the three Policemen will be arrested and charged with brutal torture. BY Vineetha M. Gamage

title: Litro gas prices increase
author: Author not found
Content: The price of a 12.5kg domestic cylinder of Litro LP gas increased by Rs 80, 5kg by Rs 30, and 2.3kg by Rs 15. According to a statement issued by the Litro Gas Company, the new price of a 12.5kg domestic cylinder of Litro LP gas will be Rs 4,360, while the 5kg cylinder will be priced at Rs 1,750. With the new price revisions, the price of a 2.3kg cylinder of Litro gas will rise to Rs 815. Litro Gas prices are revised in the first week of the month based on a pricing formula, in accordance with price fluctuations in the world market.

title: France extends possibility of training SLCG
author: Author not found
Content: French Embassys Deputy Head of Mission Aurelien Maillet and its Technical Military Cooperating Officer Jean-Baptiste Trouche at a meeting with Sri Lanka Coast Guard (SLCG) Director General, Rear Admiral Pujitha Vithana on Friday (4) expressed the possibilities of extending training and capacity-building for the enhancement of inter-agency cooperation and interaction with SLCG, SLCG on a posting on its website on Saturday (5) but dated Friday, said. The meeting took place at SLCG Rear Headquarters, Wellawatte. Vithana in this discussion explained SLCG’s commitment to deter human smuggling, counter narcotic operations, and take action against illegal, unreported, and unregulated (IUU) fishing, an illegal action, anathema under GSP+ laws. He also explained to the visiting delegation challenges faced in conducting these operations. Vithana emphasised the plan of working closely with the French Embassy, SLCG further said. (PA)

title: Restoring religious places, part of nation building – Defence Secy
author: Author not found
Content: Defence Secretary General Kamal Gunaratne said as part of nation building, restoration of religious places was also carried out whenever possible. Addressing a gathering at the Palatuwa Baudodaya Pirivena in Matara on 4 November, he said restoration work of the Mihindu Maha Seya in Mihintale, both Deegawapiya and Neelagiriya Stupa restoration projects in the Eastern Province and the construction of the Sandahiru Seya premises in Anuradhapura were some of the work that was being carried out. General Gunaratnewas speaking at the opening ceremony of the Shrine Hall and unveiling the Buddha Statue at the Palatuwa Baudodaya Pirivena in Matara. Malwattu Chapter Anunayaka, Most Ven. Dr. Niyangoda Dharmakeerthi Sri Sangarakkitha Vijithasirit here declared open the newly constructed ‘Shrine Hall’ and unveiled the Buddhastatue of the Pirivenaon the invitation of the Chief Incumbent Ven. Gatamanne Gunananda Thera. Speaker Mahinda Yapa Abeywardena and Governor of the Southern Province Willy Gamage were also present. The Chief Prelate Ven. Gunananda Thera conducted religious observances. Chief Incumbent of the Pepiliyana Sunethra Devi Pirivena Ven. Prof. Medagoda Abhayatissa Thera presided over the religious sermon. The Defence Secretary said the Sri Lanka Army provided technical expertise and labour. The Maha Sanga, philanthropists, members of the organising committee, devotees, residents and students were also present at the event.

title: Predatory insect to counter White Fly menace – CRI
author: Author not found
Content: The Coconut Research Institute (CRI) has found a predatory insect to control the White Fly (Sudu Massa), an invasive insect that harms coconut cultivation, CRI Chairman Malraj Peiris told a recent media briefing at the Institute. The insect was being carefully studied and the CRI believes that using this insect to control the spread of the white fly insect will be possible in the near future. The Chairman also said, CRI officers from the Govijana Sewa were visiting coconut plantations to advise on how to reduce the spread of the white fly insect. According to reports, the new insect, which was found in the Kegalle area, is mostly found in the Wet Zone. Meanwhile, White Fly infestation occurs in the Kegalle, Kurunegala, Kalutara, Colombo, Kandy, Ratnapura, and Gampaha Districts. It has even caused damage in several areas of the Puttalam District. “Because this insect lays its eggs in the under surface of the coconut leaf, the secretions it produces spread throughout the coconut leaf and severely impair photosynthesis. This has a negative impact on coconut production. Other plants in coconut lands, where the insect is common are also severely impacted by the insect,” he said. Fruits such as bananas, guavas, pomegranates, and flowers have faced the brunt of the infestation. The CRI requested some people to cut down coconut trees where there was severe infestation to prevent further crop damage. Villagers were seeking advice from relevant agricultural service centres, he said. The Chairman said, the CRI could be contacted on 1928 or WhatsApp number 070-4001928 in the event advice was needed. BY Prasad Purnamal – Chilaw

title: Four ministries to remain under President
author: Author not found
Content: The President’s Secretary has issued an Extraordinary Gazette stating that four ministries will remain under the purview of President Ranil Wickremesinghe. Accordingly, the Gazette issued by the Secretary to the President, Saman Ekanayake states, the Ministries of Finance, Technology, Investments Promotion, Women’s Affairs and Social Empowerment will remain under the President. The Gazette notifies that the President, having consulted with the Prime Minister, under Article 44(3) of the Constitution of the Democratic Socialist Republic of Sri Lanka, has determined that the ministerial portfolios indicated above should be in his charge. In addition to these four ministries, the Ministry of Defence is also under the President.

title: RE dominates electricity sector for 98 consecutive days
author: Author not found
Content: Cheap and clean renewable energy (RE) led by Ceylon Electricity Board (CEB) Hydroelectricity provided over 50 per cent or more of Sri Lanka’s ‘electricity demand’ for 98 consecutive days to Saturday (5 November) Ceylon Electricity Board’s (CEB’s)  6 November data showed. The reference period where RE dominated Sri Lanka’s electricity landscapes in the present era begins on 31 July 2022. Further, out of the total of 309 calendar days that have transpired in the calendar year to Saturday, RE was responsible for providing 50 per cent or more of Sri Lanka’s electricity needs in 148 (47.90 per cent) of those days, CEB statistics further showed. Such a phenomenon last took place at least four years ago in 2018. In the interim period prior to the reference 98-day period to Saturday, Sri Lanka’s electricity sector was dominated by the more expensive and dirty fossil fuels (FFs). RE comprises CEB Hydroelectricity, CEB Wind, Private Sector (PS) Biomass, PS Solar, PS Mini Hydro and PS Wind, respectively. FFs comprise CEB Coal and Fuel Oil and PS/Independent Power Producers’ (IPP) Fuel Oil, respectively. According to Central Bank of Sri Lanka’s (CBSL’s) 2021 Annual Report, the cheapest source of electricity generation to the CEB last year was CEB Hydro at Rs 1.67 a kilo Watt hour (kWh) or per one unit, followed by CEB coal (Rs 10.68); CEB Wind, PS Biomass, PS Mini Hydro and PS  Wind bunched together (Rs 16.22), (IPP’/PS Fuel Oil (Rs 30.35) and CEB Fuel Oil (Rs 32.03), respectively. Of the total electricity, ie 34.02 Giga Watt hours (GWh) generated on Saturday, RE was responsible for 71.11 per cent (24.19 GWh) and FFs 9.83 GWh (28.89 per cent) respectively.  Meanwhile “CEB Hydro” dominated Sri Lanka’s electricity landscape on Saturday, being responsible for 21.41` GWh of electricity generated on Saturday. 21.41 GWh is equivalent to 62.93 per cent of total electricity generated on Saturday and 88.51 per cent of total electricity generated on that day. CEB Hydro comprises the Laxapana, Mahaweli and Samanala hydro complexes respectively. Meanwhile on Saturday Laxapana generated 6.39 GWh of electricity equivalent to 29.85 per cent of CEB Hydro. Meanwhile, Mahaweli generated 13.34 GWh of electricity equivalent to 62.31 per cent of CEB Hydro and Samanala 1.68 GWh (7.85 per cent), respectively. In related developments, “Mahaweli Hydro” comprises Victoria, Randenigala, Rantanbe, Kotmale and Upper Kotmale Hydroelectric Power Projects (HEPPs), respectively. Victoria, Randenigala, Rantanbe and Kotmale HEPPs were built during the J.R. Jayewardene era after obtaining grant and concessional aid from the West. Upper Kotmale, conceptualised during the Jayewardene era, was built during the Mahinda Rajapaksa era after obtaining concessional Japanese aid. Samanalawewa, conceptialised during the Jayewardene era, was built during the Ranasinghe Premadasa era after obtaining concessional aid from Japan and Kukule Ganga, conceptualised during the Premadasa era, was built during the Chandrika Bandaranaike era after obtaining concessional aid from Japan. Laxapana, built during the D. S. Senanayake with Sri Lanka’s own money was subsequently extended after obtaining concessional World Bank aid. BY Paneetha Ameresekere

title: Farmers to get 50kg urea per ha
author: Author not found
Content: The Ministry of Agriculture has decided to provide farmers with 50 kg of urea fertiliser per hectare. Agriculture Minister Mahinda Amaraweera has directed Ministry Secretary Rohana Pushpakumara to consider a request made by farmers’ representatives. In a statement, the minister said, previously only 40 kg of urea fertiliser was to be applied per hectare, and the circular will be issued on Tuesday. Meanwhile, Amaraweera facilitated the delivery of fertiliser to warehouses in Batticaloa, Ampara, and Trincomalee, saying the entire amount of urea required for paddy cultivation had been provided. Ceylon Fertilizer Company Limited provided 180 metric tonnes of urea fertiliser to farmers in the Batticaloa District yesterday, while Colombo Commercial Fertilizers Ltd provided 125 metric tonnes. Further, the minister said the Government has taken all steps to ensure that fertilisers, insecticides, and herbicides are available for paddy cultivation this year. The Minister also said President Ranil Wickremesinghe agreed with all the proposals to provide farmers with relief. The minister handed over a batch of fertiliser to the Batticaloa Governor yesterday.

title: Arizona election workers face midterm threats
author: Author not found
Content: Election workers in Arizona’s most fiercely contested county faced more than 100 violent threats and intimidating communications in the run-up to Tuesday’s midterms, most of them based on election conspiracy theories promoted by former President Donald Trump and his allies. The harassment in Maricopa County included menacing emails and social media posts, threats to circulate personal information online and photographing employees arriving at work, according to nearly 1,600 pages of documents obtained by Reuters through a public records request for security records and correspondence related to threats and harassments against election workers. Between July 11 and Aug. 22, the county election office documented at least 140 threats and other hostile communications, the records show. “You will all be executed,” said one. “Wire around their limbs and tied & dragged by a car,” wrote another. The documents reveal the consequences of election conspiracy theories as voters nominated candidates in August to compete in the midterms. Many of the threats in Maricopa County, which helped propel President Joe Biden to victory over Trump in 2020, cited debunked claims around fake ballots, rigged voting machines and corrupt election officials. Other jurisdictions nationwide have seen threats and harassment this year by the former president’s supporters and prominent Republican figures who question the legitimacy of the 2020 election, according to interviews with Republican and Democratic election officials in 10 states. The threats come at a time of growing concern over the risk of political violence, highlighted by the Oct. 28 attack on Democratic House Speaker Nancy Pelosi’s husband by a man who embraced right-wing conspiracy theories. In Maricopa, a county of 4.5 million people that includes Phoenix, the harassment unnerved some election workers, according to previously unreported incidents documented in the emails and interviews with county officials. A number of temporary workers quit after being accosted outside the main ballot-counting center following the Aug. 2 primary, Stephen Richer, the county recorder who helps oversee Maricopa’s elections, said in an interview. One temporary employee broke down in tears after a stranger photographed her, according to an email from Richer to county officials. The unidentified worker left work early and never returned. (Reuters)

title: Egg prices spike in Hatton
author: Author not found
Content: Traders in Hatton claim that the control price of eggs has risen because egg farm owners do not provide an adequate supply to meet demand and released eggs in the market above the control price. Due to the increase in egg prices, traders claim that consumers are also hesitant to purchase eggs. On other days, the traders stated that they received egg stocks from egg farm owners and that the current situation has hampered their business due to a shortage of eggs. BY Neeta Pathma Kumari – Norwood

title: President emphasises need to liberalise service sector
author: Author not found
Content: The President emphasised on the need to gradually liberalise the service sector to attract foreign direct investment (FDI) to the country and to take steps to gain membership in the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP). He said this during his meeting with the officers of the National Trade Negotiation Committee at the Presidential Secretariat recently. The President instructed the officers at length about free trade negotiations as well as the future outlook of international trade and on aligning policy priorities in this regard. He further said, in parallel to the expansion of international trade activities, the Government will implement a Trade Adjustment Programme to support the local industries to further adjust with competition. “Access to regional and global supply chains and re-engagement with the global economy to enhance export and export-oriented FDI is an element of the Government’s economic reform programme to revitalise the domestic economy. Accordingly, while further penetrating into the main export markets of USA and Europe, the Government is presently engaged in an effort to establish comprehensive free trade agreements targeting large and emerging economies to increase exports,” he said. For this purpose, the Government has set up a National Trade Negotiation Committee and the main task of this committee is to revive the negotiations of free trade agreements with strategic importance to India, China, and Thailand markets where large FDI and export potential is prevalent and local industries affected by the economic crisis can obtain capital inputs, raw materials, and intermediate goods at a lower cost.

title: Landslide warnings for 19 DS divisions
author: Author not found
Content: The National Building Research Organisation (NBRO) yesterday issued landslide warnings covering 19 Divisional Secretariat Divisions (DSDs) and their surrounding areas in seven districts. The districts and their respective DSDs were Badulla: Haliella, Lunugala and Passara; Kandy: Medadumbara, Pahathadumbara, Madadumbara and Gangawatakorale; Kegalle: Ruwanwella, Deraniyagala, Dehiowita, Yatiyantota and Mawanella; Kurunegela: Ridigama; Matale: Matale, Rattota, Ukuwella and Ambanganga Korale; Monaragala: Bibile and Nuwara-Eliya: Ambagamuwa. title: Predatory insect to counter White Fly menace – CRI
author: Author not found
Content: The Coconut Research Institute (CRI) has found a predatory insect to control the White Fly (Sudu Massa), an invasive insect that harms coconut cultivation, CRI Chairman Malraj Peiris told a recent media briefing at the Institute. The insect was being carefully studied and the CRI believes that using this insect to control the spread of the white fly insect will be possible in the near future. The Chairman also said, CRI officers from the Govijana Sewa were visiting coconut plantations to advise on how to reduce the spread of the white fly insect. According to reports, the new insect, which was found in the Kegalle area, is mostly found in the Wet Zone. Meanwhile, White Fly infestation occurs in the Kegalle, Kurunegala, Kalutara, Colombo, Kandy, Ratnapura, and Gampaha Districts. It has even caused damage in several areas of the Puttalam District. “Because this insect lays its eggs in the under surface of the coconut leaf, the secretions it produces spread throughout the coconut leaf and severely impair photosynthesis. This has a negative impact on coconut production. Other plants in coconut lands, where the insect is common are also severely impacted by the insect,” he said. Fruits such as bananas, guavas, pomegranates, and flowers have faced the brunt of the infestation. The CRI requested some people to cut down coconut trees where there was severe infestation to prevent further crop damage. Villagers were seeking advice from relevant agricultural service centres, he said. The Chairman said, the CRI could be contacted on 1928 or WhatsApp number 070-4001928 in the event advice was needed. BY Prasad Purnamal – Chilaw

title: Four ministries to remain under President
author: Author not found
Content: The President’s Secretary has issued an Extraordinary Gazette stating that four ministries will remain under the purview of President Ranil Wickremesinghe. Accordingly, the Gazette issued by the Secretary to the President, Saman Ekanayake states, the Ministries of Finance, Technology, Investments Promotion, Women’s Affairs and Social Empowerment will remain under the President. The Gazette notifies that the President, having consulted with the Prime Minister, under Article 44(3) of the Constitution of the Democratic Socialist Republic of Sri Lanka, has determined that the ministerial portfolios indicated above should be in his charge. In addition to these four ministries, the Ministry of Defence is also under the President.

title: RE dominates electricity sector for 98 consecutive days
author: Author not found
Content: Cheap and clean renewable energy (RE) led by Ceylon Electricity Board (CEB) Hydroelectricity provided over 50 per cent or more of Sri Lanka’s ‘electricity demand’ for 98 consecutive days to Saturday (5 November) Ceylon Electricity Board’s (CEB’s)  6 November data showed. The reference period where RE dominated Sri Lanka’s electricity landscapes in the present era begins on 31 July 2022. Further, out of the total of 309 calendar days that have transpired in the calendar year to Saturday, RE was responsible for providing 50 per cent or more of Sri Lanka’s electricity needs in 148 (47.90 per cent) of those days, CEB statistics further showed. Such a phenomenon last took place at least four years ago in 2018. In the interim period prior to the reference 98-day period to Saturday, Sri Lanka’s electricity sector was dominated by the more expensive and dirty fossil fuels (FFs). RE comprises CEB Hydroelectricity, CEB Wind, Private Sector (PS) Biomass, PS Solar, PS Mini Hydro and PS Wind, respectively. FFs comprise CEB Coal and Fuel Oil and PS/Independent Power Producers’ (IPP) Fuel Oil, respectively. According to Central Bank of Sri Lanka’s (CBSL’s) 2021 Annual Report, the cheapest source of electricity generation to the CEB last year was CEB Hydro at Rs 1.67 a kilo Watt hour (kWh) or per one unit, followed by CEB coal (Rs 10.68); CEB Wind, PS Biomass, PS Mini Hydro and PS  Wind bunched together (Rs 16.22), (IPP’/PS Fuel Oil (Rs 30.35) and CEB Fuel Oil (Rs 32.03), respectively. Of the total electricity, ie 34.02 Giga Watt hours (GWh) generated on Saturday, RE was responsible for 71.11 per cent (24.19 GWh) and FFs 9.83 GWh (28.89 per cent) respectively.  Meanwhile “CEB Hydro” dominated Sri Lanka’s electricity landscape on Saturday, being responsible for 21.41` GWh of electricity generated on Saturday. 21.41 GWh is equivalent to 62.93 per cent of total electricity generated on Saturday and 88.51 per cent of total electricity generated on that day. CEB Hydro comprises the Laxapana, Mahaweli and Samanala hydro complexes respectively. Meanwhile on Saturday Laxapana generated 6.39 GWh of electricity equivalent to 29.85 per cent of CEB Hydro. Meanwhile, Mahaweli generated 13.34 GWh of electricity equivalent to 62.31 per cent of CEB Hydro and Samanala 1.68 GWh (7.85 per cent), respectively. In related developments, “Mahaweli Hydro” comprises Victoria, Randenigala, Rantanbe, Kotmale and Upper Kotmale Hydroelectric Power Projects (HEPPs), respectively. Victoria, Randenigala, Rantanbe and Kotmale HEPPs were built during the J.R. Jayewardene era after obtaining grant and concessional aid from the West. Upper Kotmale, conceptualised during the Jayewardene era, was built during the Mahinda Rajapaksa era after obtaining concessional Japanese aid. Samanalawewa, conceptialised during the Jayewardene era, was built during the Ranasinghe Premadasa era after obtaining concessional aid from Japan and Kukule Ganga, conceptualised during the Premadasa era, was built during the Chandrika Bandaranaike era after obtaining concessional aid from Japan. Laxapana, built during the D. S. Senanayake with Sri Lanka’s own money was subsequently extended after obtaining concessional World Bank aid. BY Paneetha Ameresekere

title: Farmers to get 50kg urea per ha
author: Author not found
Content: The Ministry of Agriculture has decided to provide farmers with 50 kg of urea fertiliser per hectare. Agriculture Minister Mahinda Amaraweera has directed Ministry Secretary Rohana Pushpakumara to consider a request made by farmers’ representatives. In a statement, the minister said, previously only 40 kg of urea fertiliser was to be applied per hectare, and the circular will be issued on Tuesday. Meanwhile, Amaraweera facilitated the delivery of fertiliser to warehouses in Batticaloa, Ampara, and Trincomalee, saying the entire amount of urea required for paddy cultivation had been provided. Ceylon Fertilizer Company Limited provided 180 metric tonnes of urea fertiliser to farmers in the Batticaloa District yesterday, while Colombo Commercial Fertilizers Ltd provided 125 metric tonnes. Further, the minister said the Government has taken all steps to ensure that fertilisers, insecticides, and herbicides are available for paddy cultivation this year. The Minister also said President Ranil Wickremesinghe agreed with all the proposals to provide farmers with relief. The minister handed over a batch of fertiliser to the Batticaloa Governor yesterday.

title: President emphasises need to liberalise service sector
author: Author not found
Content: The President emphasised on the need to gradually liberalise the service sector to attract foreign direct investment (FDI) to the country and to take steps to gain membership in the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP). He said this during his meeting with the officers of the National Trade Negotiation Committee at the Presidential Secretariat recently. The President instructed the officers at length about free trade negotiations as well as the future outlook of international trade and on aligning policy priorities in this regard. He further said, in parallel to the expansion of international trade activities, the Government will implement a Trade Adjustment Programme to support the local industries to further adjust with competition. “Access to regional and global supply chains and re-engagement with the global economy to enhance export and export-oriented FDI is an element of the Government’s economic reform programme to revitalise the domestic economy. Accordingly, while further penetrating into the main export markets of USA and Europe, the Government is presently engaged in an effort to establish comprehensive free trade agreements targeting large and emerging economies to increase exports,” he said. For this purpose, the Government has set up a National Trade Negotiation Committee and the main task of this committee is to revive the negotiations of free trade agreements with strategic importance to India, China, and Thailand markets where large FDI and export potential is prevalent and local industries affected by the economic crisis can obtain capital inputs, raw materials, and intermediate goods at a lower cost.

title: 107 M coconuts lost to wild animals
author: Author not found
Content: Minister of Agriculture Mahinda Amaraweera said a survey found that 107 million coconuts are lost to monkeys and giant squirrels each year. He said, research by the Hector Kobbekaduwa Agrarian Research and Training Institute has shown this. The Minister was speaking at a recent meeting held at the Dambulla Divisional Secretariat. The purpose of this discussion was to address issues that have arisen as a result of human activities in the Sigiriya Forest Reserve, crop damage by wild animals, and resolving the human-elephant conflict. A proposal was also submitted to resolve the human-elephant conflict. It was emphasised that people living in the vicinity of the Sigiriya Forest Reserve should not be evicted, that they should be allowed to continue cultivation, but new settlements shouldn’t be permitted. Amaraweera said he had received the most recent research report on crop damage by wild animals. The Minister expressed concern about the continuing human-elephant conflict. “All 16 elephant sanctuaries have been forcibly occupied by people and because of their settlements or cultivations, the human-elephant conflict is worsening,” he said. The Minister also said three elephants will be released next year and the Government will have to spend large sums of money to resolve this problem.

title: Bad weather kills six
author: Author not found
Content: Bad weather experienced in various parts of the country has so far killed six, injured one, and impacted 210 families comprising 809 people, the Disaster Management Centre (DMC) said yesterday (6). The period covered comprised eight days beginning from 29 October and ending on 5 November. DMC further said, inclement weather in the review period destroyed one house, damaged 142 others, and displaced 11 families comprising 48 people. District-wise breakdown of the dead were three from Badulla and one each from Kandy, Matale, and Trincomalee. The deaths in Badulla took place over two days from Monday to Tuesday (31 October-1 November) and the cause of their deaths was “heavy rain and wind.” The deceased were from Bandarawela, Hali-Ela, and Lunugala, all located in the Badulla District. The single death from Kandy was due to drowning that took place at Deltota (Kandy) on Tuesday. The death at Rattota, Matale took place on Saturday (5 November) due to a collapsed wall and the single death from Seruwila, Trincomalee took place on Wednesday (2 November) because of lightning. The single injured victim was hit by lightning in Seruwila on Wednesday. Meanwhile, the district-wise breakdown of those impacted by bad weather were Ratnapaura 38 families comprising 128 people, Kegalle 21 families and 90 people, Badulla 111 and 440, Kandy four and 15, Nuwara Eliya 14 and 59, Jaffna 18 and 61, Mullaitivu one and five and  Trincomalee three and 11. In related developments, a house was destroyed by a flash flood in Jaffna on Friday (4). In like developments, the district-wise breakdown of the damaged houses were  Ratnapura (34), Kegalle ( 18), Badulla (71), Kandy (four), Nuwara Eliya (eight), Jaffna (five) and Mullaitivu and Trincomalee, one each. In similar developments, the 11 families comprising 48 people who were displaced were all from Badulla. Lightning, cutting failure, and landslides were the cause of their displacement. They were from Ella and Passara, both located in Badulla. The incidents took place over two days from Monday to Tuesday (31 October and 1 November). They have been housed in two safety locations located in Ella and Passara. By Paneetha Ameresekere

title: Ten more flee to India due to economic crisis
author: Author not found
Content: In another case of people fleeing Sri Lanka due to the economic crisis in the country, ten more Lankans have reached Dhanushkodi in Tamil Nadu’s Ramanathapuram District in the early hours of Saturday. They were accommodated at the refugee camp in Ramanathapuram after being interrogated at the Mandapam Police Station. The refugees are M. Jayakumar (45) from Mannar District, his wife Yogeshwari (39), their daughters Tamilmathi (22) and Kanimathi (15), R. Pushpam (64) and her son Prabakar (43) from Mullaitheevu, R. Justin (42), his wife Ausiyu (36) and their children Anshika (3) and Anjitha (three months). Speaking to the media in Dhanushkodi, Justin said, “With skyrocketing prices following the economic crisis, jobs became scarce. Feeding children and dependents became impossible.” Justin said he and his family members, including two toddlers and his wife Ausiya, decided to sell their silverware and a gold chain to a pawnbroker to raise money for their travel expenses to reach Dhanushkodi. Another refugee, Pushpam, said that she too had no option but to pay money to the boatman and reach Dhanushkodi. “Jobs are not available after the crisis, and even if we get a job, we are not even able to buy 100 gm sugar. I have a 43-year-old son who is mentally unstable and life was miserable. I somehow sold all my belongings, raised Rs 50,000 as the boatman’s fee and reached Dhanushkodi,” Pushpam said. The refugees are now settled at the Mandapam rehabilitation camp in Dhanushkodi. The total number of refugees from Sri Lanka who have reached the camp has now touched 199. (IANS)

title: No fuel price revision this week
author: Author not found
Content: Minister of Power and Energy Kanchana Wijesekara said there will be no fuel price revision this week. He said that non-placement of orders by dealers, anticipating a price reduction, has led to fuel stations drying up. In a tweet he said the Ceylon Petroleum Corporation (CPC) and the Lanka IOC both have ample stocks to fulfil requirements guaranteed by the National Fuel Pass. “I request dealers to place orders for their requirements,” he said. Meanwhile, long queues near fuel stations were reported from several areas as fuel station owners have not placed orders amidst rumours of a price reduction. BY Thameenah Razeek

title: Opposition Leader being booed during protest is awkward – Range Bandara
author: Author not found
Content: UNP General Secretary Palitha Range Bandara claimed it was quite embarrassing to see the country’s Opposition Leader being jeered by protesters at an anti-Government protest march in Colombo. He stated that Opposition Leader Sajith Premadasa should be wary of his conduct in public henceforth. Bandara added that the Opposition Leader must also bear in mind not to tarnish the image of the esteemed portfolio he holds and noted that he must ensure it is not demeaned in the eyes of the public. The UNP General Secretary also emphasised that neither the President nor his party condones the actions of a few protesters who booed Premadasa when he took part in the protest on 2 November. By Amith Gamage

title: Education Minister demands report within 24 hours
author: Author not found
Content: Education Minister Susil Premajayantha has ordered education authorities to submit an immediate report, strictly within 24 hours, on the incident where the Principal of Mahinda College, Galle has allegedly violated the right to education of a child. Accordingly, a team of officials who visited the Zonal Education Office in Galle has recorded statements from the victim student and his grandfather, while, another team had visited Mahinda College for a separate investigation. They have also obtained information from the officials of the Probation and Childcare Department. Student’s grandfather lodged complaints with Galle Police HQI Office and the National Child Protection Authority (NCPA) against the Principal of Mahinda College, Galle that he violated instructions given by Court with regard to a student who is a victim of child abuse. The complainant said that when he took his grandson to school on 31 October, security guards did not permit the student to enter school. The grandfather had taken his grandson to school on the instructions of Galle Chief Magistrate, Pavithra Sanjeewani Pathirana. By Bingun Menaka Gamage

title: Red alert from President to Speaker
author: Author not found
Content: President Ranil Wickremesinghe has informed Speaker Mahinda Yapa Abeywardena that Parliament is slow in implementing proposals to bring far-reaching systematic changes and failing which he would opt for a referendum. In a letter to the Speaker, the President pointed out that although the formation of the National Assembly has been concluded to bring far-reaching systematic changes, satisfactory progress has not been made with regard to other proposals. The establishment of a National Assembly and the appointment of three committees related to public finance and banking were proposed under far-reaching systematic changes. In addition, it was also proposed to appoint the Banking and Financial Services Committee, the Economic Stabilisation Committee and the Committee on Ways and Means related to banking affairs, as well as to delegate five youth representatives for the Sectoral committees and to establish the Parliamentary Budget Office. President Ranil Wickremesinghe has expressed that although 17 parliamentary sectoral committees should be established as indicated by these proposals; chairpersons have not been designated to them and the criteria for selecting youth representatives for this purpose has yet to be prepared. The President further stated that these proposals can be implemented when next year’s budget is implemented and consequently the reforms expected by the Government will be achieved immediately. The drafted Bill for the Parliamentary Budget Office has also been approved by the Cabinet and the President has informed the Speaker that he intends to present it to the Parliament after consulting with party leaders and certification by the Attorney General.

title: Russia’s Azur Air arrives with 335 passengers
author: Author not found
Content: Azur Air, Russia’s largest charter airline, landed flight ZF611, carrying 335 passengers from Venukovo, Moscow, Russia, at the Bandaranaike International Airport (BIA) yesterday (3) at 9.54 a.m. and was welcomed with a water salute. Earlier, Azur Air announced the suspension of all international flights in the wake of Russia’s invasion of Ukraine. However, before starting its operations to Sri Lanka, Azur Air stated that they would keep an eye on fuel supply from 22 September onwards as the Sri Lankan Government assured it would provide full refuelling facilities at BIA. Azur Air will also have three direct flight operations from Russia through its major cities Venukovo, Tolmachevo, Krasnoyarsk and St. Petersburg and would fly to Sri Lanka every Thursday, Friday and Saturday. In the meantime, Sri Lanka Tourism announced that Air France will resume flights to Sri Lanka and the first flight would land at the BIA today (4). Few more airlines like Edelweiss, Air France, KLM Airlines, Swiss Air and the Royal Dutch will resume flights to Sri Lanka this month, the Sri Lanka Tourism Development Authority noted. Sri Lanka recorded 31,828 tourist arrivals for the first 24-days of October, compared to 29,802 for the entire month of September. By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: SC WANTS PROGRESS REPORT WITHIN TWO WEEKS
author: Author not found
Content: The Supreme Court yesterday (3) ordered the Attorney General to submit a report within two weeks, on the progress in obtaining compensation for the fire that broke out in the MV X-Press Pearl ship. This was when the Petitions, filed in connection with the damage caused by the MV X-Press Pearl ship fire, were taken before Supreme Court Justices S. Thurairaja, Achala Wengappuli and Mahinda Samayawardhena. Counsel Hemali Kularatne, making submissions yesterday (3), informed Court that her clients, who are fishermen and whose livelihood was immensely affected by the fire that broke out on the ship, have not been compensated to date. Court thereby ordered to expedite the procedure adopted to obtain compensation, while ordering the Government to involve at least two representatives per petitioner of the MV X-Press Pearl case, to represent the committees appointed to obtain compensation. Further, Court also ordered the Attorney General to facilitate meetings held for such purpose. The MV X-Press Pearl ship entered Sri Lankan waters on 19 May 2019 and a fire broke out on the ship on 20 May following a nitric acid leak that rapidly spread across the containers in the ship and its bridge. Due to the intensity of the spread of fire, and strong winds, the inferno could not be contained and on 2 June, the ship sank together with hazardous and noxious substances affecting the environment and the livelihood of fishermen, following which compensation was sought from the owner of the ship for the damage caused. BY Faadhila Thassim

title: “We don’t stand with spineless leaders”
author: Author not found
Content: JVP General Secretary Tilvin Silva stressed that his Party did not attend the protest march staged in Colombo on Wednesday (2) as they cannot stand together with those who are ‘spineless’. Silva charged that Opposition Leader Sajith Premadasa is one such politician and noted that he has further underscored this fact through his conduct in Parliament. Therefore, Silva questioned what democracy could be ushered here by standing alongside politicians of the calibre of the Samagi Jana Balawegaya (SJB) Leader. By Anurada Herath

title: Diana’s petition fixed for 2 March
author: Author not found
Content: The petition filed by MP Diana Gamage, challenging the decision taken by the Samagi Jana Balawegaya (SJB) to expel her from the Party, was re-fixed for 2 March 2023 by the Supreme Court yesterday (3).               The SJB Working Committee, in October 2021, unanimously decided to expel Gamage from the SJB. The decision came after Gamage voted in favour of the 20th Amendment to the Constitution which was passed in Parliament with a two-thirds majority. This was followed by Gamage filing a Petition before the Supreme Court, where she observed that she was expelled without an inquiry being conducted and thereby seeking an order declaring such decision null and void. Eleven persons, including the Leader of the Opposition Sajith Premadasa and the General Secretary of the Party were named as respondents to the Petition. BY Faadhila Thassim

title: Imran Khan shot during protest march
author: Author not found
Content: Imran Khan, Pakistan’s cricketing hero-turned-politician who was wounded in a gun attack on Thursday (3), has showed no sign of stepping aside from politics since his ouster as Prime Minister in April. The 70-year-old was wounded when a man opened fire on his convoy as he was leading a protest march to Islamabad to demand a snap election. He had been pushed out of the premiership amid public frustration at high inflation, rising deficits and endemic corruption Khan had promised to stamp out. Khan was driven from office by what an aide at the time called a judicial coup by the Supreme Court, which overturned his decision to dissolve Parliament and ordered lawmakers to return to the lower chamber. Defections from his ruling coalition meant he lost the “no confidence” vote that followed. That put him among a long list of elected Pakistani Prime Ministers who have failed to see out their full terms – none has done so since independence in 1947. In 2018, the cricket legend who led Pakistan to its only World Cup win in 1992, had rallied the country behind his vision of a corruption-free, prosperous nation respected abroad. But the firebrand nationalist’s fame and charisma were not enough. Ironically for a politician once criticised for being under the thumb of the powerful military establishment, his ouster came amid signs of worsening relations between him and army chief General Qamar Javed Bajwa. The military, which has an outsized role in Pakistan having ruled the country for nearly half of its history and won control over some of its biggest economic institutions, has said it remains neutral towards politics. (Reuters)

title: HC fixes Pre-Trial Conference for 9 December
author: Author not found
Content: Colombo High Court Judge Damith Thotawatta, yesterday (3), fixed 9 December 2022 for the Pre-Trial Conference, of the lawsuit against Health Minister Keheliya Rambukwella and former Chairman of the State Pharmaceuticals Corporation (SPC) Jayampath Heenkenda. The Minister and the former SPC Chairman, have been charged before the High Court with causing a loss of revenue to the State, by forcing the SPC officials to pay Rambukwella’s monthly telephone bill, amounting to over Rs 200,000, while he had been functioning as the then Minister of Mass Media. When the case was called yesterday, the Commission to Investigate Allegations of Bribery or Corruption (CIABOC) sought approval from Judge Thotawatta, to amend the indictments filed previously against the two accused. However, President’s Counsel Kalinga Indatissa PC, appearing for the two defendants, informed that the defence was opposed to any amendments being introduced to the indictments which had been already filed. The Attorney General has indicted the Minister and the former SPC Chairman, before the High Court and over the said offence, which has been committed from 15 March to 14 April 10 years ago and thereby committing an act of corruption via their actions. By Hansi Nanayakkara

title: Karapitiya hospital angiogram machine breaks down
author: Author not found
Content: Scores of patients suffering from heart ailments have been inconvenienced due to the malfunction of the angiogram machine at the Karapitiya Teaching Hospital. The hospital sources claimed that even conducting urinary catheter tests have been halted due to the breakdown. They added that heart patients arriving at the hospital from far off areas such as Embilipitiya, Moneragala and Bibile has been severely affected. The Karapitiya Teaching Hospital is the sole hospital in the entire Southern Province catering to heart patients. When contacted, the hospital’s director Dr. S.P.U.M. Ranga stressed that Rs 30 million is needed to repair the machine. BY Kamal Wijehewa – Galle

title: BY Kamal Wijehewa – Galle
author: Author not found
Content: Minister of Labour and Foreign Employment Manusha Nanayakkara, left to South Korea to discuss foreign employment opportunities for Sri Lankans. The demands of Sri Lankan workers employed in South Korea will also be discussed with the Korean Government. During the visit, attention will be paid to new fields open for Sri Lankan workers with discussions to be held with potential employers. In particular, bilateral discussions regarding the labour sector are scheduled to be held with representatives of the Seoul government. Further, attention will be paid on how labour laws have been prepared in South Korea as well as measures taken to use labour resources in an economically effective manner which Sri Lanka can learn from. By Nabiya Vaffoor

title: Several places hit by fuel shortage
author: Author not found
Content: Long queues were seen at fuel stations in Matara, due to an acute shortage of fuel in the area. The fuel stations located at Godagama, Matara, Pamburana, Kumaratunga Mawatha in Walgama and Polhena have closed down. However, petrol and diesel were being unloaded at fuel stations from yesterday (3) afternoon. Most fuel station owners refused to make any comments to the Media, but some claimed they had not placed fresh orders due to a rumour that the Government is planning to reduce fuel prices. BY Uadaya Ranaweera – Matara

title: SC orders Petitioners to submit written submissions
author: Author not found
Content: The Supreme Court yesterday (3) ordered Petitioners to submit written submissions in connection with the eight Petitions challenging the Inland Revenue (Amendment) Bill today (4). The Petitioners noted that the Bill is inconsistent with the provisions of the Constitution and with the Rule of Law and… …is directly prejudicial to the interests of the welfare and safety of the people, the right to life, the national economy, public health, national security and law and order. Another argument made by the Petitioners is that proposed changes in the tax regime would drastically impact the public officers, specially, high-ranking public servants, Judges and officers of the Attorney General’s Department. President’s Counsel Romesh de Silva appearing on behalf of a petitioner yesterday (3), observed that the remuneration paid to Judicial officers should not be affected in any manner observing that it is essential for Judicial officers to be adequately remunerated to ensure independence of the Judiciary.  Answering to the submissions made by the Deputy Solicitor General, that the Bill does not particularly target Judicial officers, Silva pointed out that the remuneration of Judicial officers cannot be diminished, even through taxation, adding that Bill seeks to reduce the salaries of Judicial officers, but attempting to justify it on the basis that it is not targeted. The petitioners stated thereby that certain provisions of the amendment are inconsistent with the Constitution; it cannot be enacted into law except if approved by the People at a Referendum in addition to a two-thirds vote of the whole number of the members of Parliament. BY Faadhila Thassim

title: HC fixes Pre-Trial Conference for 9 December
author: Author not found
Content: Colombo High Court Judge Damith Thotawatta, yesterday (3), fixed 9 December 2022 for the Pre-Trial Conference, of the lawsuit against Health Minister Keheliya Rambukwella and former Chairman of the State Pharmaceuticals Corporation (SPC) Jayampath Heenkenda. The Minister and the former SPC Chairman, have been charged before the High Court with causing a loss of revenue to the State, by forcing the SPC officials to pay Rambukwella’s monthly telephone bill, amounting to over Rs 200,000, while he had been functioning as the then Minister of Mass Media. When the case was called yesterday, the Commission to Investigate Allegations of Bribery or Corruption (CIABOC) sought approval from Judge Thotawatta, to amend the indictments filed previously against the two accused. However, President’s Counsel Kalinga Indatissa PC, appearing for the two defendants, informed that the defence was opposed to any amendments being introduced to the indictments which had been already filed. The Attorney General has indicted the Minister and the former SPC Chairman, before the High Court and over the said offence, which has been committed from 15 March to 14 April 10 years ago and thereby committing an act of corruption via their actions. By Hansi Nanayakkara

title: Customs seizes drug package worth Rs 50M
author: Author not found
Content: Sri Lanka Customs seized a stock of methamphetamine pills worth Rs 50 million at the Central Mail Exchange. According to the Customs Spokesperson and Director of Customs, Sudattha Silva, a total of 4,956 methamphetamine pills weighing up to 2kg were seized. The contraband was discovered hidden inside a parcel sent via post from Germany. According to the documents found inside the parcel, the drugs were sent to an Angoda resident and mentioned as personal items. The foreign mail parcel was subjected to a special inspection based on the suspicion of Assistant Customs Superintendent, who was attached to the postal assessment section of the Sri Lanka Customs and was engaged in the duty of inspecting parcels sent from abroad to Sri Lanka by post. The contraband has been turned over to officers from the Police Narcotics Bureau for further investigations. By Nabiya Vaffoor

title: Parliamentary course introduced in Jaffna Uni
author: Author not found
Content: The recently initiated short course on parliamentary functions and procedures by Parliament for Universities was introduced to undergraduates of the University of Jaffna. The inauguration was held on 31 October at the University of Jaffna. Vice-Chancellor of the University of Jaffna, Professor S. Srisatkunarajah thanked  Parliament for arranging such a course and spoke to undergraduates on the importance of taking such course. Senior officials of the Parliament Secretariat provide the material to resource persons from the Department of Media Studies – Faculty of Arts, University of Jaffna. Director of Legislative Services and Acting Director of Communications, Janakantha Silva, Director Administration, G. Thatchanarany and Manager Media Nimmie Hathiyaldeniya were present at the inauguration. The Dean of the Faculty of Arts, Prof. K. Suthakar who addressed the gathering  requested that the course be conducted for Political Science undergraduates. Dr. S. Raguram, Professor of Media Studies and Head of Department of Media Studies, Lecturers of the Media Faculty, Poonkulali Sreesangithanan, Anutharshi Gabilan, Jude Dinesh Koduthor were also present. The course intends to cover Democracy and Parliamentary System, Legislative Process of Parliament, Evolution of the Parliamentary System, Parliamentary Committee System, Parliament and the Public, Code of Conduct for the Members of Parliament, Standing Orders, Correlation for Public Service Process and Women’s Representation. It includes four lectures and a study tour around Parliament. Meanwhile,  Parliament in collaboration with the University of Colombo initiated the Course in Colombo University to educate final year students of the Department of Political Science and Public Policy of the University, and give them an insight into the working of Parliament.

title: Canadian business community to assist Sri Lanka
author: Author not found
Content: The Canadian business community has agreed to support the development of Sri Lanka’s economy to overcome the economic crisis, a release from Parliament stated. A group of Canadian business leaders met Speaker of Parliament Mahinda Yapa Abeywardana yesterday (03) in Parliament and said that they hope to increase Canada’s friendship with Sri Lanka and also expressed their desire to support young entrepreneurs in Sri Lanka to build their enterprises Speaker Abeywardana, addressing the delegation, said that they will work expeditiously to bring about the development of the country. He showed that the support of Canada’s business leaders is also important for this purpose and pointed out the need for cooperation between the two sides. Furthermore, the Speaker told the delegation that an Overseas Sri Lankan Coordination Secretariat, to help expatriates, is in the process of being established in Sri Lanka and the necessary discussions are currently underway and that he hopes to get the support of each party for the purpose of economic development. Minister of Education and Leader of the House Dr. Susil Premajayantha was also present at this event and he pointed out the need to increase the friendship between the two countries. He also pointed out the need to involve the Canadian business community in the new programmes that are expected to be established to develop the school system in this country. The Secretary-General of Parliament, Dhammika Dasanayake, addressing the delegation, stated that efforts are being made to increase youth participation in parliamentary affairs. He further mentioned that the necessary changes in the Standing Orders are currently being made for this purpose. Furthermore, Dasanayake also elaborated on the historical and geographical importance of the Parliament while having a friendly conversation with the Canadian Member of Parliament, Rachel Thomas, who was present as part of the delegation.

title: THE UNDERWORLD IS MUCH IN CREATIVE WRITING
author: Author not found
Content: Hell has three gates: lust, anger and greed.   – Bhagavad Gita Why have I selected to write about the underworld or hell this Saturday? A scary, weird, ghastly subject that causes goosebumps on one’s skin? Because the best book of fiction in the English using and speaking ‘wide world’ is about underworld characters, and worse, those who have been done in and given seven days to find out who did them in. Yes, I have  Shehan Karunatilaka’s   Booker Prize winning  novel The Seven Moons of Maali Alameida in mind. His protagonist wakes up and discovers; he had been murdered and is now – in the first scene – in the underworld with other ‘dead folk’, politically killed persons like Dr Rajini Thiranagama killed in Jaffna by the LTTE in 1989; who registers ‘new dead’ in the underworld. Maali is hinted as thinly veiled Richard de Soyza – reporter, dissident and homosexual. I am wading through the book. I said wading, as opposed to devouring with great interest as the underworld is not my cuppa tea and certainly not dead roaming around looking for their assailants. But it is a great book and highly praised by all the eminent judges and critics. I’ll move from Shehan’s novel to the backdrop of his story. I cannot write about his novel as I am still at the beginning of it. The Underworld The underworld is also known as the netherworld or hell. It is a supernatural world of the dead in very many religions and myths and is thought to be below the world of the living. It has been believed in by every civilisation. Customs and traditions were present, like certain rites had to be performed for the dead to enter the underworld; persons of status were specially dressed to retain their high class ‘down below’. Another concept that persisted was that the dead had to be guided or led or taken over an obstacle, usually a waterway, to reach his/her destination. Thus, the crossing of the Styx in Greek mythology, a river with five tributaries. The Underworld was divided into Tartarus – reserved for worst offenders; the Elysian Fields – for the most excellent persons; the Fields of Mourning – those hurt by love, and Asphodel Meadows  for ordinary persons. It is stated that the descent to the Underworld ‘is the single most important myth of Modernist authors.’ Thus, Shehan is not only a Modernist but also following a certain style or rite of passage, if I may term it thus. Much about the underworld was written by Homer in his Odyssey and Virgil in Aeneid. The former is an epic in which the story of Odysseus, King of Ithaca, sets out to return home after winning the Trojan war and is led out of his way to face adventure after adventure and comes through a hero. Homer was Greek of course and wrote his epic in the 7 century BC.  Aeneid is also an epic poem by the Roman, Virgil, in 24 to 10 BC that details the flight of Aeneas, a Trojan, after the defeat of Troy; he ends up in Italy and is the ancestor of the Romans. Both Buddhism and Christianity have ‘Hell’.  We call it Apaya.  The Christians believe in Heaven where the God is, and all good people go there to enjoy eternal life; the truly evil are pulled down to ‘Hell’. Buddhists have several ‘Heavens’.  Where ‘Hell’ is, is a puzzle since underground is the centre of the Earth, all molten fire. Heavens are believed to be planets that the Buddha envisaged. Personally, these concepts are too difficult for me to fathom. My belief is that Hell and Heaven are on this earth, as circumstances or your past Karma that decree your birth and life. Best left aside and concentrate on following the Dhamma to lead silvath lives.  The Buddha himself said that speculation and worrying about unfathomable topics is a waste of time and energy.   Khalil Gibran noted that Hell is not in torture; Hell is an empty heart. Thus, be kind, good, generous and have plenty of metta and ‘Hell’ will be of no consideration, unless of course, you are a modernist novelist! Kumari

title: SL Navy welcomes its latest addition in Colombo
author: Author not found
Content: The Sri Lanka Navy (SLN) welcomed the latest addition to its expanding fleet, the offshore Patrol Vessel P 627 which arrived in Colombo on the morning of 2 November from the US port of Seattle. State Minister of Defence Premitha Bandara Tennakoon graced the occasion as the chief guest and Defence Secretary General Kamal Gunaratne was the guest of honour. The US Ambassador to Sri Lanka, Julie Chung was also present at the occasion. The new vessel was acquired in October last year (26 Oct 2021) after being formally handed over by the US Coast Guard. It set sail on 3 September (2022) after going through refurbishments to suit the operational needs of the SLN. The State Minister and the Defence Secretary were received by the Commander of the Navy Vice Admiral Nishantha Ulugetenne on their arrival at the Colombo Harbour. As the ship with its given Pennant no, P627 gracefully entered home port, it was given a traditional Naval welcome including a ‘Water Salute’ while the naval band played in the background. After docking at the pier the ship’s commanding officer Captain Lanka Dissanayake made the traditional report to the navy commander and extended invitation to the ship. Accompanied by the navy commander the State Minister and Defence Secretary along with the US ambassador boarded the ship and made an inspection visit. They were briefed on the facilities and operational capabilities of the ship by the navy commander and the ship’s commanding officer. The commanding officer also presented the distinguished guests mementos to mark the occasion.      The former US Coast Guard ship Douglas Munro is the second Hamilton Class High Endurance Cutter, received by the SLN. It is 115m in length and could carry 187 personnel. With a maximum speed of 29 knots it has the endurance of 14,000 nautical miles at cruising speed. It is equipped with weapon systems and modern machinery that suit SLN’s operational requirements. Sailing across the Pacific and Indian oceans, the US made cutter P 627 had made history by making the longest-ever sea voyage by a vessel in SLN’s history. The ship made several stopovers including Honolulu in Hawaii, Apra in Guam, Manila in Philippine and Changi in Singapore for replenishment and services on her way home from Seattle. The initial crew of about 130 had also undergone training while the ship was undergoing upgrades.  Chief of Defence Staff, Commanders of the Army and Air Force, senior Ministry officials, tri forces officers, members of the diplomatic corps, and distinguished invitees were also present at the occasion.

title: Sathosa slashes prices on five food items
author: Author not found
Content: Lanka Sathosa has taken steps to reduce the prices of five essential food items. Accordingly, the prices of white sugar, wheat flour, sprats, local tinned fish and red lentils have been reduced. The price of a kilogram of white sugar has been reduced by Rs. 22, the price of a kilogram of wheat flour has been reduced by Rs 96, the price of a kilogram of sprats has been reduced by Rs 200, the price of local canned fish has been reduced by Rs 105 and the price of a kilogram of red lentils has been reduced by Rs 17. BY Thameenah Razeek

title: 13 suspects remanded so far
author: Author not found
Content: Thirteen suspects out of the 14, who were arrested for the death of Police Sergeant following an assault during a tense situation in Kebithigollewa, have been remanded until 10 November. Additionally, Kebithigollewa District Judge and Magistrate Kasun Dissanayake ordered the Police to arrest and produce… …other suspects responsible for the death of the Sergeant. The 14th suspect was detained for 24 hours for further questioning. The Magistrate also ordered the Police to present a progress report from the investigations. A group of locals blockaded the road with burning tires in protest following the death of a villager in a wild elephant attack on the afternoon of 31 October in Kebithigollewa. The Police Sergeant attached to Kebithigollewa Police, who went to investigate the matter with several other officers, died after being assaulted by group of people. BY Upali Ananda – Anuradhapura

title: HRCSL summons Royal College principal
author: Author not found
Content: The Human Rights Commission of Sri Lanka (HRCSL) has summoned the Principal of Royal College, Colombo to record a statement over a complaint of inhumanely physically attacking a student. In a statement, the HRCSL said according to the complaint, two teachers have allegedly beaten Grade 11 student in an inhumane manner. The student was later admitted to the National Hospital of Sri Lanka (NHSL), Colombo and received treatment.  Following the compliant, HRCSL has decided to summon the Principal of the school and the two teachers who allegedly physically attacked the student, to record statements.

title: Monks oppose teachers wearing comfortable attire
author: Author not found
Content: A group of Buddhist monks vehemently opposed the request of Ceylon Teachers’ Union (CTU) Secretary General Joseph Stalin to grant female teachers the option of wearing suitable, comfortable clothes when attending school. Addressing the media, Nugegoda Nalandaramaya Chief Incumbent Ven. Thiniyawala Palitha Thera said Sri Lanka is a country with a 2,600-year-old Buddhist culture and identity. “Buddhist monks, military personnel, Police, school teachers and students have unique uniforms. As required by the CTU Secretary and non-Government organisations (NGOs), they cannot change the uniforms of teachers or students in the country. “If that happens, there is bound to be a great disaster,” Ven. Palitha Thera said. Ven. Palitha Thera noted that even in the Old Testament of the Bible, it is clearly said that women’s clothes should be used for women and men’s clothes for men and that should not be changed, and it is an insult to God. “Therefore, ignoring this custom could be very disastrous to this country and its culture,” he said. Hence, I do not believe Education Minister Susil Premajayantha would allow changing the uniforms of the teachers and students as per the wishes of external sources, Ven. Palitha said. He added, the minister would not take any actions to ruin the culture and identity of the country. Meanwhile, Chief Incumbent of Sri Jayewardenepura Kotte Sri Naga Viharaya in, Rajakeeya Panditha Wathurawila Siri Sujatha Thera also noted that since it is the nature of children to be attracted to the visible things teachers should be careful with their attire. “Since, it is the nature of children to be attracted to the visible things as well as to follow the role models they meet, in the school system, children will naturally follow the class teacher or teacher who is the closest figure to the child. So, teachers as guides should display a very careful behaviour in their role as teachers,” Siri Sujata Thera stated. Siri Sujata Thera stated, “Stalin should remember that this is a Sinhala Buddhist country and we cannot look up to western cultures and try to influence people to follow them. He said if lady teachers are allowed to come to school in comfortable and suitable clothes, the children will not be able to see the exemplary teacher character in the teachers who come to school dressed in different styles. Meanwhile, Sabaragamuwa University Chancellor, Ven. Prof. Kumburugamuwe Vajira Thera noted that teaching service is a unique service beyond the professional level. Vajira Thera said that in the culture of Sri Lanka, which has a long history nourished by Buddhism, teachers are worshiped as gods, and teachers cannot be told to come to school wearing whatever clothes they want, just as monks cannot be told to wear whatever clothes they want. Vajira Thera commenting on previous trade union action on salary anomalies said that the opportunistic trade unions make these god-like teachers walk on the streets and make them look like vagrants. The monks noted that the circular issued in this regard by the Public Administration Ministry on 27 September, does not apply to teachers at all. By Nabiya Vaffoor

title: Cop killed in Kebithigollewa promoted
author: Author not found
Content: The Police Sergeant who passed away after being assaulted by a group of individuals following a tense situation in Kebithigollewa was posthumously promoted to the rank of Sub Inspector. The Police Media Division said, the IGP promoted the late Angampodige Sunil from the post of Sergeant to Sub Inspector with effect from last Monday (31). A group of villagers had protested by blocking the road and burning tyres after an individual was killed by a wild elephant on 31 October afternoon in Kebithigollewa. The Police Sergeant attached to Kebithigollewa Police who went to investigate the matter with several other Police Officers was attacked by a group of residents and later succumbed to his injuries. The Police said, the funeral of the deceased officer will take place today (3) at Wariyapola Public Cemetery with Police honours. By Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: N-Eliya Hospital throws out Rs 5M worth expired drugs
author: Author not found
Content: Chairman of Talawakelle-Lindula Urban Council Chandana Pradip Gunathilaka said the Ministry of Health-controlled District Hospital Nuwara Eliya has handed over a stock of expired drugs worth approximately Rs 5 million to the Talawakelle-Lidula Municipal Council for destruction. The Chairman noted that around two months ago, the on-site medical officer at the hospital’s district clinic took a stock of waste and expired drugs from the chest unit to the incinerator at the waste yard in Talawakelle’s Holyrood area, which is controlled by the Municipality, and handed it over to the Municipality’s Public Health Inspector. The medical officer in charge of the hospital’s district clinic in a request to the Municipal Council on 16 September 2022 stated that if any charge has been incurred, the Chairman of Talawakelle-Lindula Urban Council agrees to pay the amount to the Municipal Council. According to Gunathilaka, the stock of medicine was handed over to be destroyed on Saturday (29 October), and because it was impossible to destroy the expired stock of medicine and waste due to a lack of petroleum and an increase in fuel prices, they were piled in his municipality’s garbage yard. By Neeta Padmakumari

title: COPF to re-consider ban on bathware imports
author: Author not found
Content: The Committee on Public Finance (COPF) said approving the Gazette Notification to temporarily suspend the import of bathware was unfair by the consumer. The Committee was of the view that the Extraordinary Gazette Notification 2296/30, under the Import and Export (Control) Act No. 1 of 1969 should be re-considered as to whether such approvals were fair by the consumer. This issue was discussed at the Committee on Public Finance which met under the chairmanship of Dr. Harsha de Silva. The Gazette was published to temporarily suspend the import of sanitary fixtures and bathware items such as squatting pans and wash basins. Further, the Committee also took into consideration the market monopoly due to the banning of tile imports. They said, since imports in this regard have been suspended, it was the consumer who was at the butt end with increasing prices due to the inability to meet demand. Accordingly, the Committee recommended that the Ministry of Finance submit a report in this regard.

title: Protest lacks lustre
author: Author not found
Content: A protest march against the conduct of the Government was held yesterday (2) with the participation of Opposition political parties, trade unions, and civil society organisations. The march began at 2:00 p.m. in front of Elphinstone Theatre, Maradana, with several demands including the release of student activists Wasantha Mudalige and Ven. Galwewa Siridhamma Thera. When the protesters tried to pass Maradana Road, Orabipasha Mawatha, Technical Junction, and Olcott Mawatha and reach Pettah, the Police set up roadblocks near Floating Market and closed one road. A tense situation arose, as politicians refused to approach the roadblocks and protesters showed their displeasure. In the end, only UNP MP Mujibur Rahuman remained with the protesters and other politicians including Opposition Leader Sajith Premadasa were seen leaving the protest. By Mithun Jayawardena and Savani Sheashadhi
