title: Display MRP of five products in English
author: Author not found
Content: The Consumer Affairs Authority (CAA) directed importers to display the maximum retail price (MRP) of five products on their labels in English, effective 1 November. The CAA also advised importers to display the brand name and the registered address of the importer clearly on the pack or the container of each product in English at the port of entry. Thus, the above details should be displayed on packets or containers of chewing gum, chocolates, biscuits, cakes, and toilet soaps. “Confectionery items including chewing gum under the HS Code No. 1704, chocolates under the HS code No. 1806, biscuits under the HS code No. 1905, cakes under the HS code No. 1905, and toilet soap under the HS code No. 3401 should display the above details,” the Gazette Notification said. By Nabiya Vaffoor

title: Political maturity low among voters – EC Chief
author: Author not found
Content: Chairman of the Election Commission Nimal Punchihewa said though the country’s literacy rate is high its political knowledge is at an all-time low. Punchihewa added that even if financial fraudsters such as Thilini Priyamali, who is currently remanded, she would be voted into Parliament overnight if she contests in an election after being released. He mentioned that voters’ political maturity is at such a low that those in the fields of arts, sports, modelling and even those who are released after being imprisoned will poll high preference votes if they contest an election. BY K. L. Suraweera – Kandy

title: Thico case suspects further remanded till 16 November
author: Author not found
Content: Colombo Fort Magistrate Thilina Gamage yesterday (2) ordered owner of Thico Group Private Ltd Thilini Priyamali and her business partner Isuru Bandara, who have been remanded on charges of defrauding businessmen of millions of rupees, to be further remanded till 16 November. The Magistrate also ordered Ven. Borelle Sirisumana Thera who was arrested on 1 November and produced in Court yesterday by the CID on charges of aiding and abetting Priyamali’s activities to also be imprisoned till the aforesaid date. The CID told Court that inquiries conducted into the incident had revealed that the suspect monk had visited the house of the plaintiff and had coaxed him to give money to Priyamali. They stated that the plaintiff had handed over a sum of Rs 750 million to the suspect since 2001 to be invested in well-known firms. The plaintiff has stated in his complaint that the money had been accrued by him by selling seven of his vehicles, his properties and from his fixed deposits. The CID informed Court that the suspect monk having visited the plaintiff’s house had gone into a trance and had coaxed him to deposit his monies with the suspect.. They told Magistrate Gamage that the probe into the incident had revealed that the suspect monk had also obtained cash running into millions and several brands of perfumes from the plaintiff. The Fort Magistrate showing a photograph as evidence then inquired from the monk as to the actions resorted to by the latter. Counsel appearing for the suspect monk then mentioned that his client had visited the house of the plaintiff to bless the business transactions taking place between Thilini Priyamali and the plaintiff. He then insisted that his client had also blessed the cash that had been exchanged between Priyamali and the plaintiff. By Hansi Nanayakkara

title: Bathiudeen released from case
author: Author not found
Content: Colombo Fort Magistrate Thilina Gamage yesterday (2) ordered former Minister Rishad Bathiudeen, who was charged in the case filed against him of aiding and abetting suicide cadres behind the 2019 Easter Sunday carnage, to be released from the case. The Fort Magistrate gave this order on the orders of the Attorney General, Sanjay Rajaratnam. He added that as charges filed against the suspect cannot be maintained further and as per advice received from the Attorney General, he was ordering the release. The CID arrested the former Minister on 24 April last year. The MP was detained by the CID for a period of 111 days, as per Provisions of the Prevention of Terrorism Act. Accordingly, on 10 August last year, the suspect was produced for the first time before the Fort Magistrate and ordered to be incarcerated, till the conclusion of the trial. The Court then ordered the suspect to be enlarged on bail, on 14 October last year. By Hansi Nanayakkara

title: Principal prevents student from entering school
author: Author not found
Content: Complaints have been lodged with Galle Police Headquarters and the National Child Protection Authority (NCPA) against the Principal of Mahinda College, Galle that he violated instructions given by Court with regard to a student who is a victim in a child abuse case. The complaint was filed by the student’s grandfather. The complainant said that when he took his grandson to school on 31 October, security guards did not permit the student to enter school. The latter had taken his grandson to school on the instructions of Galle Chief Magistrate, Pavithra Sanjeewani Pathirana . The child attended Mahinda College, Galle for 10 years since Grade 1 and was placed under probationary care when he became a victim of sexual assault. As a result, he could not go to school for a few days. Following a complaint made by lawyer Ajith Kumara to the Galle Chief Magistrate that the Principal of Mahinda College, Galle had violated the student’s right to education, the Principal was summoned to Court on 28 October. However, he did not appear before Court and sent an Assistant Principal on his behalf and presented a report with regard to the student claiming that the student had misused social media. The Chief Magistrate said, although she could give an Order to permit the student to continue his education, this did not call for such an Order. Therefore, the Chief Magistrate ordered the school to protect the right to education of the student and provide a report on 11 November. However, the principal has prevented the student from entering the school premises even after instructions from Court. Prior to Court instructions, Director – National Schools, Kithsiri Liyanage also instructed the principal on 19 October in writing to permit the student to attend school. However, the Principal has violated all instructions, the complaint stated. By Bingun Menaka Gamage

title: Hotel owner fined Rs 10,000
author: Author not found
Content: Galle Additional Magistrate, Lakmini Vidanagamage imposed a fine of Rs 10,000 on the owner of a hotel situated close to a well- known school in Galle for selling egg buns mixed with human excrement at the hotel.  The suspect is a resident of Richmond Hill in Galle. Following a raid conducted by Galle PHI officers, a sample of the egg buns kept for sale was sent to the Kalutara National Health Laboratory for testing and test results confirmed that the egg buns were mixed with human excrement. BY Farhan Nizamdeen – Galle and S. Deeyagahage – Ahangama

title: Motorists report major fuel shortage in Hatton
author: Author not found
Content: Several owners of motor vehicles in Hatton say there has been an acute shortage of fuel at local Ceypetco and LIOC fuel stations since 31 October. They said, there has been a shortage of fuel since Monday afternoon and this has severely hampered daily commutes and businesses. Especially three-wheeler drivers say that the on-going fuel shortage in and around Hatton has dealt a blow to their livelihood. When contacted, owners of fuel stations noted that they had not placed fresh orders for fuel in light of information that the Government was planning to reduce fuel prices shortly. BY Neeta Pathma Kumari – Norwood

title: JMO report released
author: Author not found
Content: Ruwan Nanayakkara, Galle Judicial Medical Officer (JMO) attached to the Karapitiya Teaching Hospital said the two persons who were shot dead by unidentified motorcycle gunmen in Thiranagama, Hikkaduwa had died of gunshot wounds to the stomach and brain. These details were made public following the post-mortem on the two victims. According to the JMO, the victim who had ridden the motorcycle took three bullets to his stomach while the pillion rider’s body was riddled with seven bullets. By Kamal Wijehewa – Galle

title: MCPA President suspended by HSC – PSC
author: Author not found
Content: The Health Service Committee Public Service Commission (HSC-PSC) has interdicted the President of the Medical and Civil Rights Professional Association of Doctors (MCPA) Dr. Chamal Sanjeewa for making alleged statements to the Media.  The MCPA vehemently condemned the move by the HSC-PSC to interdict Dr. Sanjeewa.   MCPA Secretary, Dr. Jayaruwan Bandara yesterday (2) accused the HSC-PSC for taking such a decision against a President of a registered trade union movement, on the grounds of making statements based on scientific facts. In a letter copied to the President, the Ministers of Health and Labour, all MPs, Secretaries to the Ministries of Health and Labour, the International Labour Office, Human Rights Commission and the United Nations Human Rights Office Sri Lanka, he said, the MCPA had been successful in creating awareness regarding the prevailing situation in Sri Lanka among parliamentarians and top officials. The breakdown of food security in the country, food shortages, nutritional conditions of the general public, medicinal drug shortages, the spike in cost of pharmaceuticals and the poverty levels of the people affected by the economic crisis of  country.  “We realised that certain parties saw the MCPA as a threat to their incompetence,” he lashed out.  This also supports the Government’s strategy to hunt down trade unions, the MCPA Secretary alleged. “In keeping with the provision of the basic constitution of the trade union movement, the MCPA and its President have only been educating the general public and government officials about the matters taking place in the country, and setting straight the existing shortcomings and securing the people’s right to life instead of covering up the mistakes of the government, its politicians and officials”. Dr. Bandara urged authorities to call for a proper probe into the allegations against Dr. Sanjeewa before taking such a harsh decision. The Secretary of the HSC- PCS responding to a letter sent by the Health Secretary on 6 October  approving the Dr. Sanjeewa’s interdiction in according to Section 31:1:15 of Chapter XLVIII. By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: SLN takes over offshore patrol vessel P627
author: Author not found
Content: The recent addition to the Sri Lanka Navy (SLN) fleet, offshore patrol vessel P627 docked into the Colombo Port on 2 November 2022, following a two- month journey from the port of Seattle, across the Pacific and Indian ocean This is  recorded as the longest sea voyage of 10,656 nautical miles (19,734km). Commander of the Navy, Vice Admiral Nishantha Ulugetenne, Defence Secretary, General Kamal Gunaratne, U.S. Ambassador to Sri Lanka, Julie Chung, State Minister of Defence, Pramitha Bandara Tennakoon and General Shavendra Silva, Chief of Defence Staff welcomed the P 627 into the shores of Colombo. Navy Media Spokesman, Captain Indika De Silva said the Navy had a tremendous responsibility of safeguarding Sri Lankan waters which in comparison to the land mass was much more and P627 will be of able assistance in surveillance endeavours. “Rescue and operation area of the sea that comes under SLN is 27 times more than the land capacity, and the Exclusive Economic Sea Zone is seven times larger than the land capacity. The P627 patrol vessel will be of immense help to protect marine resources in this vast area, curbing illegal arrivals and protecting our  maritime space from resource exploitation,” Captain De Silva said. He added that the vessel’s name will be made known at the inauguration ceremony and suggestions according to SLN tradition were already selected and sent to the Navy and political dignitaries, for selection to be made. Meanwhile, Commanding Officer of the P 627, Captain Lanka Disanayake also spoke about vessel.  SLN officially took delivery of the EX-United States Coast Guard Cutter, USCGC Douglas Munro, aka P 627 provided by the United States, on 26 October 2021. Subsequently, she was designated with the Pennant Number P627 in the SLN Fleet and underwent modernisation to suit the operational needs of the Sri Lanka Navy. The ship departed for Sri Lanka from the Port of Seattle, on 3 September 2022.  The P627, the second ‘Hamilton Class High Endurance Cutter’ is 115 metres in length and capable of attaining a maximum speed of 29 knots with an endurance of 14000 NM at cruising speed. Further, theP627 has been designed for 187 crew and equipped with state-of-the-art weapons and machinery. The P627 on its way to Colombo made port calls at Honolulu in Hawaii, Apra in Guam, United States, Manila in Philippine and Changi in Singapore for replenishment and services. SLN received SLNS Samudura aka P621 and Gajabahu aka P 626 the Offshore Patrol Vessels from the U.S. Coast Guard on previous occasions to strengthen and develop partnerships to overcome common maritime challenges at sea. The delivery of P627 is considered as a symbol of further consolidation of such partnerships and camaraderie. By Nabiya Vaffoor

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Cannot issue edicts to media – Fort Magistrate
author: Author not found
Content: Colombo Fort Magistrate Thilina Gamage turned down a request of Thilini Priyamali’s Counsels yesterday (2) to issue an order to mainstream media, to prevent them from disseminating degrading and harmful information related to their client; as such exposures could have a detrimental impact on their lawsuit. They made this request to Court, when the lawsuit filed against Priyamali, who has been charged with defrauding billions of rupees, from wealthy businessmen, professionals and top politicians was called up. However, the Magistrate explained that he has no authority as per the law, to issue edicts to the media both electronic and print, on the type of content that should be either published or aired and what should not be carried. A group of lawyers headed by Counsel Dasun Nagashena, looked into the interests of suspect Priyamali. By Hansi Nanayakkara

title: Floods in Jaffna force 32 to seek refuge
author: Author not found
Content: Floods in Sandilipay, Jaffna, forced 32 persons belonging to 11 families to seek refuge at the Kakaitivu Fisheries Society Building, Jaffna, the Disaster Management Centre (DMC) said yesterday (2). One house was also damaged in the incident, it added. The incident, spilt over two days, beginning on Monday (31 October) and ended on the following day Tuesday (1), said DMC. Meanwhile, heavy rains, landslides, strong winds, cutting failures, fire, lightning, falling rocks and trees experienced in various parts of the island over three days since the beginning of this week on Sunday and ending two days later on Tuesday, impacted a total of 91 families comprising 340 people, killing one and damaging 67 houses, including at Sandilipay, in the reference period, DMC further said. The impacted districts were Ratnapura and Kegalle comprising the Sabaragamuwa Province and Badulla, Kandy, Nuwara Eliya and Jaffna districts. District-wise breakdown of the impacted persons and houses were Ratnapura: Thirty-two families comprising 109 persons and 28 houses, Kegalle: Nineteen families comprising 80 persons together with 18 houses, and Badulla: Thirteen families comprising 51 persons and 11 houses, respectively. In related developments, Bandarawela in Badulla also recorded the solitary death registered thus far, a victim of a landslide that took place on Monday. Besides these, the other victims were the above reported from Jaffna. By Paneetha Ameresekere

title: Excessive rice imports last two years – COPF
author: Author not found
Content: It was disclosed at the Committee on Public Finance (COPF) that rice had been imported in excess and mixed for the purpose of sale during the last two years. This was discussed at the committee meeting chaired by Dr. Harsha de Silva on Tuesday (1). The committee members directed attention regarding importing rice in excess and mixing for the purpose of sale. Also, given the import of raw materials required for the production of animal feed is a concern, it was noted that the egg and poultry industry is in a dire state and therefore, the price of eggs and poultry has increased. The Regulations under the Import and Export (Control) Act mentioned in the Gazette Extraordinary Notification No. 2297/79 was also considered at the Committee meeting. This intends to extend the period for import of essential food items under an open account system. The committee paid attention on what basis rice, maize, and other items were imported. The Committee expressed its displeasure at the absence of any data in this regard and recommended to the authorities to submit a report with clear data within two months.

title: Kesbewa town to be developed
author: Author not found
Content: Minister of Housing and Urban Development, Prasanna Ranatunga, said as a part of the Kesbewa Urban Development Plan,  the Kesbewa town is to be developed under the slogan ‘Kesbewa City Green Section’ enabling the masses to experience physical and mental happiness. Meanwhile, seven Urban Development Gazette Notifications are also scheduled to be published this year incorporating 273 urban development areas.  The Development Plan was discussed on the sidelines of World Cities Day under the aegis of the Minister. The UDA is slated to Gazette 29 city development plans during the course of the year, the minister said. By Anuradha Herath

title: EU alarmed over recent use of PTA
author: Author not found
Content: The European Union (EU) expressed concern about the recent use of the Prevention of Terrorism Act (PTA), whereas Sri Lanka assured that the PTA had been invoked only in cases of extreme necessity.  The Sixth Meeting of the European Union-Sri Lanka Working Group on Good Governance, Rule of Law and Human Rights was held on 28 October, where the EU delegation further noted Sri Lanka’s update on the release of PTA detainees in 2021-2022, and encouraged the release of long-term PTA detainees who have not been charged, to which Sri Lanka expressed its strong commitment to prepare a comprehensive legislative proposal to replace the PTA in accordance with the Constitution, and in line with international norms and best practices, with a view to its finalisation in 2023. The EU acknowledged the steps taken by Sri Lanka in March 2022 to revise the Prevention of Terrorism Act (PTA) and pointed to the need for further action in line with its commitments. The Working Group was updated on the GSP+ monitoring process and its requirements. The EU encouraged tangible progress by Sri Lanka on its GSP+ commitment. Also, Sri Lanka and the EU reaffirmed the importance of engaging civil society and giving it the necessary space to function in all its diversity. The EU expressed its readiness to continue supporting Sri Lanka in this process. The two sides discussed the situation of minorities and the respective measures taken to address hate speech. They also exchanged views on the legislative and other measures taken to protect the rights of women and children, and action taken to advance labour rights including the elimination of child labour. The EU reiterated its call to decriminalise same sex relations and noted the Private Member’s Bill in this regard. The statement further said, the two sides discussed cooperation in the UN Human Rights Council, including treaty bodies, special procedures and the universal periodic review process. The EU encouraged Sri Lanka to continue its engagement with the Human Rights Council and its mechanisms. The EU welcomed progress in the Justice Sector Reform Programme funded by the EU, which will further improve access to justice and enhance human rights. Sri Lanka appreciated the support extended by the EU in this regard. The Working Group meeting took place in the context of regular bilateral interactions between Sri Lanka and the European Union (EU). The full-day proceedings provided for a cordial exchange of views and experiences. The two sides discussed the recent developments in Sri Lanka and the EU and the implementation of relevant action and legislative initiatives regarding the promotion and protection of human rights. Sri Lanka briefed the EU on progress in reconciliation. The EU reaffirmed its commitment to support Sri Lanka’s efforts to successfully overcome the present unprecedented economic crisis, including the necessary reforms and social protection measures, which would mitigate the adverse impact of the crisis and lead the country towards sustainable growth and prosperity. Sri Lanka and the EU reiterated the importance of social, economic, and political inclusion through justice and reconciliation in the advancement of human rights. Sri Lanka apprised the EU of the 21st Amendment to the Constitution, which is aimed at strengthening democratic governance and independent oversight of key institutions, public scrutiny, as well as anti-corruption measures, with the reestablishment of the Constitutional Council and Independent Commissions. In this context, the two sides discussed the importance of the separation of powers and checks and balances, and the ongoing work of independent institutions. The Working Group was also updated on the electoral reform process. In this context, the EU recalled the work of the 2019 EU election observation mission. The two sides reiterated the importance of the democratic freedoms of opinion and expression, and the rights to freedom of peaceful assembly and association. The Working Group was co-chaired by Varuni Muthukumarana, Director General Europe, Central Asia, EU and Commonwealth, Ministry of Foreign Affairs of Sri Lanka and Rensje Teerink, Deputy Director and Head of South Asia Division, European External Action Service. (SRM)

title: Govt has done its best to revive economy – PM
author: Author not found
Content: Prime Minister Dinesh Gunawardena said, as the Government has done its best to revive the economy, the country’s biggest hurdles will be overcome in the next few months. The Prime Minister said this during the 77th Anniversary meeting of the All Ceylon Harbour and Dock Workers’ Union in Colombo on Tuesday (1). The Prime Minister further said, the Harbour and Dock Workers’ Union has made an invaluable contribution to the labour regulations, judicial regulations, and parliamentary regulations on behalf of the working people. “The battles that started in 1946 led to a unique revolution. With everyone’s support, everything started to change due to the actions taken by other fraternal trade unions. This kind of history is not being written for trade unions today. It is not properly established. These rights were won through difficult periods. The eight-hour working day, overtime allowances, pensions, health insurance, and facilities at the workplaces were won through battles,” he said. Speaking further, he said today a union marking its 77th Anniversary is a very rare occurrence. He said it is because they stood for justice and fairness. “This association is alive and well because it did not stand for favouritism. We have faced a very difficult period recently. The port functioned even during the pandemic. Our brothers continued the service with great care on behalf of our country. The Government has done its best to revive the economy. The country’s biggest hurdles will be overcome within the next few months. For that, all citizens should unite,” he said.

title: 10 new members to be added to SLFP’s CC
author: Author not found
Content: Propaganda Secretary of the SLFP Thisara Gunasinghe said 10 new members would be appointed to its Central Committee (CC) shortly. He noted that these appointments would fill up the recent vacancies that have opened in the party’s CC. Recently, the party Chairman axed several party seniors from CC membership and a few other posts they had held in the party after they took up Ministerial and State Ministerial portfolios with the Government in violation of a collective decision taken by the CC not to accept any Government posts. Among the expelled CC members were MPs Mahinda Amaraweera, Nimal Siripala de Silva, Ranjith Siyambalapitiya, Lasantha Alagiyawanna, Chamara Sampath Dassanayake Jagath Pushpakumara, Shantha Bandara and Dr. Suren Raghavan. By Savani Sheashadhi

title: SL High Commission in UK celebrates Deepawali
author: Author not found
Content: The High Commission of Sri Lanka in London held its annual Deepawali celebrations. The Sri Lankan community in Britain attended the event on 28 October 2022, held at the High Commission premises.  Celebrations commenced with Hindu religious observances led by Visveswara Sarma Kurukkal, who invoked blessings on those present as well as on Sri Lanka and its people. High Commissioner, Saroja Sirisena said the cultural aspects of Deepavali bring joy and happiness to all Sri Lankans alike, and with that in mind the High Commission and the Sri Lankan community in Britain created a glimpse of this colourful Festival. She added that it was a pleasure to see the diverse mosaic of Sri Lankans present at the celebrations, and invited them to join hands with Sri Lanka to overcome the prevailing economic challenges. The event included a Bharatha Natyam performance by  award-winning dance guru, Kalasuri Thivya Sujen, Bharatha Natyam artiste, Niranshana Sureshkumar and students of Usha Raghavan, Director of Kalasagara from the UK, Preeti Mahenthran, Dheekshana Chandrasekar, Shreya Warrier and Akshadha Murali presented their dance. The performers were given tokens of appreciation by the Sri Lankan envoy and Kanagaratnam Rajamenon, MD Leaf Hotels Group in Kent who sponsored the celebrations. The concluding remarks were delivered by Deputy High Commissioner, Samantha Pathirana. Attendees were served with a  traditional Northern Sri Lankan dinner.

title: Toxic smoke sends 39 to hospital in Panadura school
author: Author not found
Content: Panadura South Police stated that 39 persons from Royal College, Panadura including 36 students had been hospitalised after inhaling a poisonous smoke yesterday (2). Students from Grade 4 to 5 along with their teachers and a mother of a student had been admitted to hospital. Following the incident, scores of parents had removed their children from school premises while those infirmed had been rushed to the Panadura Base Hospital on ambulances and private vehicles. According to initial inquiries by Police, the poisonous smoke had emanated from a fire behind the school. They added that two drug addicts in the area had set fire to the pile of wires and tyres to retrieve and sell copper and scrap metal. Police said, the two suspects had fled the area and investigations have been launched to arrest them. BY Sumith Ranawaka – Pothupitiya

title: FUTA slams Government’s crackdown on protests
author: Author not found
Content: The Government is currently engaged in a systematic attempt to suppress the truth, protect corrupt officials as well as politicians and are granting favours to a selected cabal of crony capitalists that it favours, the Federation of University Teachers Associations (FUTA) alleged. FUTA also said, while the Government wants people to believe that it is effectively managing the economy and that the country is on the road to recovery, the facts and opinions of experts tell a different story. Issuing a statement, Rohan Laksiri, General Secretary of FUTA said, “Hundreds of people have been arbitrarily arrested and the Police have tried to indiscriminately block any form of protest in Colombo, and the Prevention of Terrorism Act (PTA) has been used to arbitrarily detain student activists”. FUTA demanded that the Government listen to the people and allow them to exercise their right to peaceful protest. FUTA also stood in solidarity with political parties, student organisations, trade unions and civil society organisations that staged a protest in Colombo yesterday (2), against State repression and arbitrary use of the PTA. “People do not want this corrupt political culture to continue. They are demanding change and the protest on 2 November is an indication that the “Aragalaya’ is rising again”, he said. (AK)

author: Author not found
Content: The recent addition to the Sri Lanka Navy (SLN) fleet, offshore patrol vessel P627 docked into the Colombo Port on 2 November 2022, following a two- month journey from the port of Seattle, across the Pacific and Indian ocean This is  recorded as the longest sea voyage of 10,656 nautical miles (19,734km). Commander of the Navy, Vice Admiral Nishantha Ulugetenne, Defence Secretary, General Kamal Gunaratne, U.S. Ambassador to Sri Lanka, Julie Chung, State Minister of Defence, Pramitha Bandara Tennakoon and General Shavendra Silva, Chief of Defence Staff welcomed the P 627 into the shores of Colombo. Navy Media Spokesman, Captain Indika De Silva said the Navy had a tremendous responsibility of safeguarding Sri Lankan waters which in comparison to the land mass was much more and P627 will be of able assistance in surveillance endeavours. “Rescue and operation area of the sea that comes under SLN is 27 times more than the land capacity, and the Exclusive Economic Sea Zone is seven times larger than the land capacity. The P627 patrol vessel will be of immense help to protect marine resources in this vast area, curbing illegal arrivals and protecting our  maritime space from resource exploitation,” Captain De Silva said. He added that the vessel’s name will be made known at the inauguration ceremony and suggestions according to SLN tradition were already selected and sent to the Navy and political dignitaries, for selection to be made. Meanwhile, Commanding Officer of the P 627, Captain Lanka Disanayake also spoke about vessel.  SLN officially took delivery of the EX-United States Coast Guard Cutter, USCGC Douglas Munro, aka P 627 provided by the United States, on 26 October 2021. Subsequently, she was designated with the Pennant Number P627 in the SLN Fleet and underwent modernisation to suit the operational needs of the Sri Lanka Navy. The ship departed for Sri Lanka from the Port of Seattle, on 3 September 2022.  The P627, the second ‘Hamilton Class High Endurance Cutter’ is 115 metres in length and capable of attaining a maximum speed of 29 knots with an endurance of 14000 NM at cruising speed. Further, theP627 has been designed for 187 crew and equipped with state-of-the-art weapons and machinery. The P627 on its way to Colombo made port calls at Honolulu in Hawaii, Apra in Guam, United States, Manila in Philippine and Changi in Singapore for replenishment and services. SLN received SLNS Samudura aka P621 and Gajabahu aka P 626 the Offshore Patrol Vessels from the U.S. Coast Guard on previous occasions to strengthen and develop partnerships to overcome common maritime challenges at sea. The delivery of P627 is considered as a symbol of further consolidation of such partnerships and camaraderie. By Nabiya Vaffoor

title: Cannot issue edicts to media – Fort Magistrate
author: Author not found
Content: Colombo Fort Magistrate Thilina Gamage turned down a request of Thilini Priyamali’s Counsels yesterday (2) to issue an order to mainstream media, to prevent them from disseminating degrading and harmful information related to their client; as such exposures could have a detrimental impact on their lawsuit. They made this request to Court, when the lawsuit filed against Priyamali, who has been charged with defrauding billions of rupees, from wealthy businessmen, professionals and top politicians was called up. However, the Magistrate explained that he has no authority as per the law, to issue edicts to the media both electronic and print, on the type of content that should be either published or aired and what should not be carried. A group of lawyers headed by Counsel Dasun Nagashena, looked into the interests of suspect Priyamali. By Hansi Nanayakkara

title: Floods in Jaffna force 32 to seek refuge
author: Author not found
Content: Floods in Sandilipay, Jaffna, forced 32 persons belonging to 11 families to seek refuge at the Kakaitivu Fisheries Society Building, Jaffna, the Disaster Management Centre (DMC) said yesterday (2). One house was also damaged in the incident, it added. The incident, spilt over two days, beginning on Monday (31 October) and ended on the following day Tuesday (1), said DMC. Meanwhile, heavy rains, landslides, strong winds, cutting failures, fire, lightning, falling rocks and trees experienced in various parts of the island over three days since the beginning of this week on Sunday and ending two days later on Tuesday, impacted a total of 91 families comprising 340 people, killing one and damaging 67 houses, including at Sandilipay, in the reference period, DMC further said. The impacted districts were Ratnapura and Kegalle comprising the Sabaragamuwa Province and Badulla, Kandy, Nuwara Eliya and Jaffna districts. District-wise breakdown of the impacted persons and houses were Ratnapura: Thirty-two families comprising 109 persons and 28 houses, Kegalle: Nineteen families comprising 80 persons together with 18 houses, and Badulla: Thirteen families comprising 51 persons and 11 houses, respectively. In related developments, Bandarawela in Badulla also recorded the solitary death registered thus far, a victim of a landslide that took place on Monday. Besides these, the other victims were the above reported from Jaffna. By Paneetha Ameresekere

title: Excessive rice imports last two years – COPF
author: Author not found
Content: It was disclosed at the Committee on Public Finance (COPF) that rice had been imported in excess and mixed for the purpose of sale during the last two years. This was discussed at the committee meeting chaired by Dr. Harsha de Silva on Tuesday (1). The committee members directed attention regarding importing rice in excess and mixing for the purpose of sale. Also, given the import of raw materials required for the production of animal feed is a concern, it was noted that the egg and poultry industry is in a dire state and therefore, the price of eggs and poultry has increased. The Regulations under the Import and Export (Control) Act mentioned in the Gazette Extraordinary Notification No. 2297/79 was also considered at the Committee meeting. This intends to extend the period for import of essential food items under an open account system. The committee paid attention on what basis rice, maize, and other items were imported. The Committee expressed its displeasure at the absence of any data in this regard and recommended to the authorities to submit a report with clear data within two months.

title: Kesbewa town to be developed
author: Author not found
Content: Minister of Housing and Urban Development, Prasanna Ranatunga, said as a part of the Kesbewa Urban Development Plan,  the Kesbewa town is to be developed under the slogan ‘Kesbewa City Green Section’ enabling the masses to experience physical and mental happiness. Meanwhile, seven Urban Development Gazette Notifications are also scheduled to be published this year incorporating 273 urban development areas.  The Development Plan was discussed on the sidelines of World Cities Day under the aegis of the Minister. The UDA is slated to Gazette 29 city development plans during the course of the year, the minister said. By Anuradha Herath

title: EU alarmed over recent use of PTA
author: Author not found
Content: The European Union (EU) expressed concern about the recent use of the Prevention of Terrorism Act (PTA), whereas Sri Lanka assured that the PTA had been invoked only in cases of extreme necessity.  The Sixth Meeting of the European Union-Sri Lanka Working Group on Good Governance, Rule of Law and Human Rights was held on 28 October, where the EU delegation further noted Sri Lanka’s update on the release of PTA detainees in 2021-2022, and encouraged the release of long-term PTA detainees who have not been charged, to which Sri Lanka expressed its strong commitment to prepare a comprehensive legislative proposal to replace the PTA in accordance with the Constitution, and in line with international norms and best practices, with a view to its finalisation in 2023. The EU acknowledged the steps taken by Sri Lanka in March 2022 to revise the Prevention of Terrorism Act (PTA) and pointed to the need for further action in line with its commitments. The Working Group was updated on the GSP+ monitoring process and its requirements. The EU encouraged tangible progress by Sri Lanka on its GSP+ commitment. Also, Sri Lanka and the EU reaffirmed the importance of engaging civil society and giving it the necessary space to function in all its diversity. The EU expressed its readiness to continue supporting Sri Lanka in this process. The two sides discussed the situation of minorities and the respective measures taken to address hate speech. They also exchanged views on the legislative and other measures taken to protect the rights of women and children, and action taken to advance labour rights including the elimination of child labour. The EU reiterated its call to decriminalise same sex relations and noted the Private Member’s Bill in this regard. The statement further said, the two sides discussed cooperation in the UN Human Rights Council, including treaty bodies, special procedures and the universal periodic review process. The EU encouraged Sri Lanka to continue its engagement with the Human Rights Council and its mechanisms. The EU welcomed progress in the Justice Sector Reform Programme funded by the EU, which will further improve access to justice and enhance human rights. Sri Lanka appreciated the support extended by the EU in this regard. The Working Group meeting took place in the context of regular bilateral interactions between Sri Lanka and the European Union (EU). The full-day proceedings provided for a cordial exchange of views and experiences. The two sides discussed the recent developments in Sri Lanka and the EU and the implementation of relevant action and legislative initiatives regarding the promotion and protection of human rights. Sri Lanka briefed the EU on progress in reconciliation. The EU reaffirmed its commitment to support Sri Lanka’s efforts to successfully overcome the present unprecedented economic crisis, including the necessary reforms and social protection measures, which would mitigate the adverse impact of the crisis and lead the country towards sustainable growth and prosperity. Sri Lanka and the EU reiterated the importance of social, economic, and political inclusion through justice and reconciliation in the advancement of human rights. Sri Lanka apprised the EU of the 21st Amendment to the Constitution, which is aimed at strengthening democratic governance and independent oversight of key institutions, public scrutiny, as well as anti-corruption measures, with the reestablishment of the Constitutional Council and Independent Commissions. In this context, the two sides discussed the importance of the separation of powers and checks and balances, and the ongoing work of independent institutions. The Working Group was also updated on the electoral reform process. In this context, the EU recalled the work of the 2019 EU election observation mission. The two sides reiterated the importance of the democratic freedoms of opinion and expression, and the rights to freedom of peaceful assembly and association. The Working Group was co-chaired by Varuni Muthukumarana, Director General Europe, Central Asia, EU and Commonwealth, Ministry of Foreign Affairs of Sri Lanka and Rensje Teerink, Deputy Director and Head of South Asia Division, European External Action Service. (SRM)

title: Local Monks on Pindapatha to pay electricity bills
author: Author not found
Content: Chief Incumbent of the Sri Bharathi Temple in Peradeniya Ven. Ambaliyadde Sangharathana Thera said, the Monks at the temple have been forced to seek Pindapatha to collect sufficient funds to pay the temple’s increased electricity tariffs. The Chief Incumbent said, increased electricity bills has forced Buddhist Monks to beg for cash from devotees and the general public as they have no other alternative. Ven. Sangharathana Thera stated that the Ceylon Electricity Board should intervene immediately in this issue and provide some relief to temples or else the day would not be far when Monks would have to carry out religious events in darkness. BY Ravindu Sooriyabandara – Kurunegala

title: SL unable to fully procure required fuel – Kanchana
author: Author not found
Content: Sri Lanka is still struggling to afford international fuel prices and is unable to fully procure the country’s requirements, Power and Energy Minister Kanchana Wijesekera said. The cash-strapped country is still seeking financial assistance from oil-producing countries, but has yet to secure any aid apart from an existing deal with India, Wijesekera said yesterday (1) on the sidelines of the ADIPEC Conference in Abu Dhabi. Sri Lanka’s financial crisis has been stretching on for months, impeding its ability to pay for food and fuel. “It’s very difficult for us to access Letters of Credit or give any other guarantees on payments,” he said. The country is expecting a diesel cargo from China to arrive by the end of November, which will help meet its needs for several months, he said. Sri Lanka is seeking to privatise its oil industry, but has yet to make a deal, he added. It earlier implemented a national fuel management programme that helped reduce consumption by 40 per cent, and is also still in discussions with the International Monetary Fund for financial aid, he said.Imports of Russian oil and fuel are also still under consideration. “It doesn’t matter where it’s coming from, as long its affordable for Sri Lanka,” he said. Wijesekera said, Sri Lanka was expecting a diesel shipment from China that will possibly arrive by the end of November, as his country faces a deep financial crisis. (Bloomberg and Reuters)

title: ‘Traitors’ bringing anti-Govt protesters today – Wajira
author: Author not found
Content: UNP Chairman MP Wajira Abeywardena alleged yesterday (1) that those who are bringing people to Colombo today (2) for a protest march against the Government are ‘traitors’. Abeywardena noted that there is a rapid increase in tourist arrivals compared to early this year. This type of irresponsible moves by politicians, to fulfil their narrow political agendas, will further worsen the situation in the country, he stressed. “A meeting was held, in connection with receiving the assistance from the International Monetary Fund, chaired by Senior Advisor to the President Sagala Ratnayake and Dr. Samaratunge on 28 October. Following that another special discussion has been scheduled for tomorrow (3). The people of this country must give at least one year for the present Government until targets are achieved,” he said. MP Abeywardena made these remarks while addressing the Media at Sirikotha. By Naalir Jamaldeen

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Sajith signs joint declaration with TUs
author: Author not found
Content: Opposition Leader Sajith Premadasa signed a joint declaration yesterday (1) with trade unions, against the Government’s repression, at the Opposition Leader’s office. Premadasa said the Samagi Jana Balawegaya (SJB) will participate in the protest march scheduled today (2) with Opposition Parties, civil society organisations and trade unions. Addressing the trade union representatives, Premadasa said the Rajapaksa family are the founders of repression. “Some people allege that the SJB will hijack the protest march, but I assure that the SJB will give their 100 per cent support to the march. We will not hijack anything. We should fight against repression of this Government together,” he said. Premadasa added that the protest march will be peaceful. By Nabiya Vaffoor

title: AI to be added to Grade 10 syllabus – Premajayantha
author: Author not found
Content: The Education Ministry anticipates that artificial intelligence (AI) will be introduced as a Grade 10 subject in schools next year. Minister of Education Susil Premajayantha said Sri Lanka’s education system needs to advance with the use of technology. He added that teachers will have to undergo special training to utilise technology in their lessons. “According to the most recent UNESCO reports, artificial intelligence will be taught in the tenth grade next year, in a context where we need to move beyond an education reform. All teachers should receive technology training and the education system should be transformed beginning with the school. We face a challenge in protecting children from various social activities, particularly in semi-urban and urban areas,” he said. Premajayantha further said, a workshop has been launched with the participation of teachers from all 144 schools in Colombo to prevent various practices such as bringing unhealthy food to school. Teachers and trained counsellors from Divisional Secretariat offices will provide advice. By Thameenah Razeek

title: No foreign trips for MPs during Budget
author: Author not found
Content: The Government has decided not to grant approval for Ministers, State Ministers, and Government MPs to travel abroad during the Budget debate 2023. Cabinet approved Prime Minister Dinesh Gunawardena’s proposal that Ministers should not travel abroad during Sitting Days of Parliament and during the Budget debate except in the case of a medical emergency or very urgent work of the Government. The Budget Speech (Second Reading of the Appropriation Bill) will be delivered on 14 November 2022 while its Second Reading Debate will be from 15 November to 22 November 2022. The Committee Stage Debate will be held from 23 November 2022 to 8 December 2022 and voting will take place on 8 December 2022. By Thameenah Razeek

title: Declining prices, high tax and poor quality of tea
author: Author not found
Content: Aside from tea prices being on the decline since October, the tea industry is facing a new burden with high interest rates of more than 30 per cent, which will have a direct impact on production costs, according to the Tea Factory Owners Association (TFOA), which has called on the Government to intervene before the situation worsens. The association’s chairman Lionel Herath said that tea manufacturers are penalised by the authorities for everything, regardless of their direct involvement. The chairman further stated that the association’s general meeting held on Monday (31 October) highlighted that the agriculture industry has been exempted from tax for decades, despite the fact that the new tax policy includes agriculture industries, which also needs to be explored by government authorities, because of various setbacks in the tea industry due to many reasons in the past. He also pointed out that since October 2022, tea prices have been declining, and warned that expenditure on production costs could exceed sales averages for producers, resulting in a massive trading loss. He also highlighted a myriad of challenges including the very high and increased electricity bills, high cost of fuel, firewood, packing materials, fertiliser etc. “We hope tea prices will prevail to offset the high cost of production until the country’s economic situation reaches normalcy.” He also pointed out that the main raw material for tea production is quality green leaf but unfortunately, due to many reasons such as high cost, lack of fertiliser in the past, there is a severe shortage of green leaf which has caused a drastic decline in leaf quality resulting in a higher percentage of low-price grades. “Legislation clearly defines the green leaf and all parties concerned should adhere to the Tea Control Act and Tea Board Act. But regrettably, when speaking about green leaf quality, the authorities always pass the ball to the tea factory owners. But we feel that green leaf quality should be monitored at the grower’s farm gate and any corrective action should be taken at the farm level,” he said. By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: Firms supplying low-quality fertiliser to be blacklisted
author: Author not found
Content: Companies supplying organic fertiliser found to be of inferior quality will be blacklisted and if the fertiliser has already been supplied, no money will be paid, Minister of Agriculture Mahinda Amaraweera said. He said, at present, 10 companies have been approved by the National Fertiliser Secretariat to issue organic fertiliser, adding that it is the responsibility of the Secretariat to test three samples of each type of fertiliser while distributing them through the Agrarian Services Centres. Amaraweera said, committees chaired by the District Secretary in each district will also be appointed to ensure the quality of organic fertiliser. “The respective production companies should be responsible for distributing the organic fertiliser to the relevant Agrarian Service Centres as well as promoting them to the farmers while it is the responsibility of farmers to choose the required fertiliser,” he said. Amaraweera added that the Government will provide a 50 per cent subsidy or a sum of Rs 20,000 to farmers to buy organic fertiliser. He said, this during a discussion held with organic fertiliser manufacturing companies to make arrangements to supply organic fertiliser for paddy cultivation. (FT)

title: Landslide kills one
author: Author not found
Content: The Disaster Management Centre (DMC) yesterday (1) reported one death and one injury due to a landslide in Bandarawela that took place on the previous day Monday (31). In related developments, the National Building Research Organisation (NBRO) yesterday issued landslide warnings covering 19 Divisional Secretariat divisions (DSDs) in eight districts. They are – Badulla District: Bandarawela, Ella and Passara DSDs and surrounding areas, Kandy: Ganga Ihala Korale DSD and surrounding areas, Kegalle: Ruwanwella, Deraniyagala, Dehiowita and Yatiyantota DSDs and surrounding areas, Kurunegala: Ridigama DSD and surrounding areas, Matara: Kotapola DSD and surrounding areas, Monaragala: Medagama and Badalkumbura DSD and surrounding areas, Nuwara Eliya: Ambagamuwa and Nuwara Eliya DSDs and surrounding areas and Ratnapura: Ratnapura, Elapatha, Nivithigala, Kalawana and Kuruwita DSDs and surround areas, respectively. Meanwhile, DMC further said, due to various environmental disasters caused by strong winds, landslides and cutting failures, 18 houses were damaged impacting 61 people belonging to 21 families in two consecutive days to Monday. The impacted districts were the Badulla, Ratnapura, and Kandy Districts, respectively. The district-wise breakdown of the damaged houses and impacted people were 19 families comprising 65 people and 17 houses in Ratnapura, a family of four in Bandarawela, Badulla and damages to a house belonging to an individual at Ganga Ihala Korale, Kandy, respectively. By Paneetha Ameresekere

title: Court instructs CIABOC to respond
author: Author not found
Content: President’s Counsel Kalinga Indatissa yesterday (1) raised initial objections before three separate Benches of the Colombo High Court, stating that the lawsuits filed against ex-Minister Johnston Fernando and two others cannot be further maintained, as there were no Provisions in the law to do so. Fernando and two others have been charged before the High Court with having caused a loss of revenue to the State via the forced use of labour from Lanka SATHOSA for political work, other than their official duty. Three lawsuits filed by Commission to Investigate Allegations of Bribery or Corruption (CIABOC) against the three accused, namely Fernando, former Chairman of Lanka SATHOSA Eraj Fernando and former Director Mohammad Zakeer, were convened separately, before High Court Judges Namal Ballale, Navaratne Marasinghe and ManjulaThillakaratne, respectively. Counsel Indatissa told the Judges that when filing a bribery case the necessary Provisions have to be adhered to, as per the Bribery Act. He then alleged that ahead of filing such lawsuits, the Commissioners of CIABOC have to give an order or issue an edict, to conduct initial inquiries and he noted that the Commissioners had never issued such orders, to sleuths of the Bribery Commission. By Hansi Nanayakkara

title: GoSL assessing restructuring domestic debt
author: Author not found
Content: Government of Sri Lanka (GoSL) is assessing the possibility of restructuring its domestic debt, the Finance Ministry in a document released on Monday (31 October) said. “This does not mean however that strict comparability of treatment will necessarily apply between external and domestic creditors, even more so given that certain domestic creditors are to be ring-fenced for financial stability or social reasons,” the document titled “Q&A ‘for’ Investor Presentation,” further said. Nonetheless, it also said, “We are still assessing precisely, with the assistance of our debt advisers and the IMF team, the impact certain reforms of the domestic financial sector may have on our fiscal accounts and growth estimates. Yet, we want to reassure our external partners that this topic is being looked at with an open mind, and by reference to the principle of fair and equitable treatment of all creditors.”  The foreseen fiscal adjustment should allow the country to bring the primary surplus at 2.3 per cent by 2025 from a primary deficit of 5.7 per cent in 2021, which corresponds to an eight percentage point fiscal consolidation effort in four years, the Ministry document/report also said. “As per the original Budget submitted to Parliament on 12 November 2021, the primary deficit for 2022 was estimated at 2.8 per cent of GDP. But now it’s estimated to shoot up to four per cent,” the Finance Ministry said. The target for next year 2023 is a primary deficit of 0.7 per cent, it added. The report further said that revenue measures to support fiscal consolidation and annual budget for 2023 in line with the IMF’s USD 2.9 billion assistance programme is being targeted, the introduction of formula-based price adjustments for fuel and electricity is in line, the introduction of a new Central Bank Act and amendments to the Banking Act to enhance Central Bank of Sri Lanka (CBSL) powers and measures to support prices and financial sector stability are also to be targeted. “Government of Sri Lanka (GoSL) is committed to adopting a new Central Bank Act that will further strengthen the autonomy of the CBSL and to refrain from any monetary financing,” it added. “IMF is considering both liquidity and solvency indicators to assess Sri Lanka’s debt situation. These targets will be dealing with our overall debt-to-GDP trajectory and levels, our yearly gross financing needs and foreign exchange (FX) denominated debt service expressed as a percentage of GDP. The indicative targets assigned to Sri Lanka were determined by the IMF staff team in accordance with the new Sovereign Risk and Debt Sustainability Framework for Market Access Countries. These targets cannot be publicly disclosed at this stage but will become public once the USD 2.9 billion facility is approved by the IMF Board,” the Finance Ministry further said. “We have started to share information on our IMF programme parameters and debt sustainability assessment in more details with the advisers to bondholders on a confidential basis under Non-Disclosure Agreements (NDA),” it added. BY Paneetha Ameresekere

title: Kebithigollewa rages after man dies in elephant attack
author: Author not found
Content: A Police Sergeant succumbed to injuries after being assaulted by a group of individuals following a tense situation in Kebithigollewa. The Kebithigollewa Police OIC and four Police officers had gone to Rambakapuwewa to investigate a death following a wild elephant attack on 31 October. At the time of their arrival, at least 150 people had blockaded the road with burning tyres and were harassing passing motorists. However, when the Police approached the crowd to investigate the situation, a group had attacked the Police OIC and a Sergeant who tried to block the attackers. The OIC had fired warning shots in the air to control the crowd but the Sergeant sustained critical injuries following the brutal assault. The victim was rushed to the Kebithigollewa Hospital and was transferred to the Anuradhapura Teaching Hospital for further treatment. However, while he was being taken to Anuradhapura hospital his health had turned critical and he was admitted to the Madawachchiya Hospital where he was pronounced dead on admission. The deceased was Angampodige Sunil, a 54-year-old father of two from Wariyapola. The individual who was attacked by a wild elephant was a 48-year-old named Baddaralage Gunasinghe, a resident of Rambakepuwewa. Gunasinghe had taken a bus from Kebithigollewa town to his house but had gotten off at the Rambakepuwewa junction and was walking a short distance to his village when a wild elephant attacked and killed him at around 7.20p.m. on 31 October. After the death of the villager, the locals had blocked the Kabithigollewa-Padawiya main road at Rambakepuwewa and started a protest against the Wildlife Department and the KabithigollewaPolice. The protesting villagers said, “When the elephant came to the village in the morning, no one from the Police or the Wildlife Department came even though we made phone calls requesting them to drive the elephant away. And now that a person is dead, they have come to see what happened.” Following the heated situation, 15 persons were arrested in connection with the death of the sergeant. The suspects are aged 20 to 30 and are residents of Rambakepuwewa. Among the suspects is a monk who served in the Army for a time before deserting. Police are conducting further investigations into the incident. BY Aloka Kasturiarachchi and Percy Kuroneru – Anuradhapura
