title: SL consumers in dire straits – NCE
author: Author not found
Content: Citizens will be subjected to a further 36 per cent taxation from November onwards as announced by the Inland Revenue Department, which may result in another catastrophe, the National Chamber of Exporters of Sri Lanka (NCE) said. The NCE said, Sri Lankan consumers are sinking, with over 50 per cent of households unable to afford essential food items. The quality of life of an average Sri Lankan is fast declining. According to a latest report released by the University of Peradeniya, 42 per cent of Sri Lankan households or 9.6 million people are in poverty. In a statement, the NCE pointed out that considering the fact that any Government should be given a considerable period of time to bring back a fraught economy to normalcy, ruling parties must come up with immediate solutions to address the most perilous issues at hand. “The time is right to implement robust economic drives, including implement mass agriculture to ensure food safety, control corruption, establish political stability, and importantly to sign Free Trade Agreements with countries like Singapore, Malaysia, and China and penetrate on the existing FTAs with India and Pakistan for improved bilateral relations and harness support from neighbouring countries. As IMF has very clearly pointed out, we have to focus on stringent implementation of clear policies and work tirelessly with one vision to bring Sri Lanka back to its glory,” he said. The NCE urged the President and the Cabinet to provide solutions immediately which is the need of the hour, regardless of who is in power. “The NCE is committed to support the authorities to engender change in rebuilding our economy through exports,” they said. Also, the NCE made a special appeal to the Government to take prompt action in reconciling all affected areas of the country. The IMF has detailed measures to help Sri Lanka restore macroeconomic stability and debt sustainability whilst safeguarding financial stability. In this context, eradicating corruption by political, state, and other parties are also mandatory to unlock Sri Lanka’s growth potential. Also, establishing stronger and strategic relations with other countries will definitely support Sri Lanka in its path to recovery, they said.

title: 24,935 families food insecure in Galle District
author: Author not found
Content: Galle District Secretary Shantha Weerasinghe said, they have identified 24,935 families who are food insecure in the District. He said, out of these families, 805 children suffer from malnutrition. The District Secretary observed that there were 1,818 pregnant women in these families as well. According to Weerasinghe, the highest number of families who are food insecure have been reported from the Madampagama Divisional Secretariat and the number stands at 2,234. The least number of families from the District have been reported from the Hikkaduwa Divisional Secretariat and the number is 233.  By Kamal Wijehewa – Galle

title: Mangrove cultivation, zoning in the works – Devananda
author: Author not found
Content: Fisheries Minister Douglas Devananda said yesterday (31), that steps will be taken to establish mangrove sensitive zones across the country in collaboration with foreign investors. Environmentalists and experts of aquatic resources who conducted surveys on marine resources ascertained that the mangrove ecosystem, which is a sensitive biodiversity hotspot near lagoons and river estuaries, have been badly damaged as a result of human activity. It has also severely impacted fish breeding, Devananda said. The Minister added that he has planned to start a mangrove cultivation programme in collaboration with foreign investors who he recently met at the Fisheries Ministry in Maligawatta, Colombo. They had agreed to invest in mangrove cultivations in an area of nearly 40 acres near lagoons as well as river estuaries across the country. It is said that more than 400 jobs will be created once this project is implemented. By doing so, the fish breeding habitats can be developed and soil erosion at lagoons and river estuaries can be prevented, according to Devananda. By Naalir Jamaldeen

title: EU-funded project hands over 70 laptops to Development Officers
author: Author not found
Content: The EU-funded ‘Supporting Effective Dispute Resolution (SEDR)’ project amplified its support to the Mediation Boards Commission (MBC) through the provision of 70 laptops to enhance the administrative functions of the Development Officers (Mediation) islandwide. Minister of Justice Dr. Wijeyadasa Rajapakshe, Secretary Mediation Boards Commission Priyanath Perera, Chairperson Mediation Boards Commission, Commissioners of the Mediation Boards Commission Justice Yapa, Deputy Head of Delegation of the European Union to Sri Lanka and the Maldives Lars Bredal and Country Director British Council Sri Lanka Maarya Rehman participated in the event. SEDR is a four-year access to justice project implemented by the British Council, in partnership with The Asia Foundation (TAF), and funded by the European Union (EU). The EUR 7 million project is part of the EU’s over arching STRIDE (Strengthening Transformation, Reconciliation and Inclusive Democratic Engagement) Programme in Sri Lanka. SEDR’s Result Area 4 includes an activity to support the administrative functions of mediation boards through the provision of IT equipment. This is with the objective of supporting newly appointed Development Officers to collate data. Under SEDR’s Result Area 1, significant work has already been done to enhance the MBC’s website and building a mediation database to help the MBC function more seamlessly and to be able to monitor progress. The website will help with public awareness and will increase much needed access to mediation, which is more cost-efficient and sustainable when compared with litigation. Speaking at the event, Deputy Head of Delegation of the European Union to Sri Lanka and the Maldives Lars Bredal said, “The EU stands with Sri Lanka in its efforts to ensure everyone has access to justice. As digitalisation plays an increasingly important role in all facets of modern society, it is relevant to the functioning of the justice system, as it allows for improved access and delivery of justice services. We hope the provision of this equipment will be instrumental in facilitating and strengthening the work of the officers of the MBC.” An ICT Needs Assessment survey of 235 MBC staff, including the new cadre of Development Officers (DOs) – Mediation – was completed in the second half of 2021, and a training needs analysis was also done by a consultant hired by SEDR. The scope and focus of the ICT equipment to be procured was made with agreement between the MBC, Ministry of Justice (MOJ) and SEDR joint committee being that the best option was the provision of 70 laptops. The British Council IT team completed the task of installing software (Windows 10) on these laptops, which also all come with SEDR-branding and carrier bags. As part of the distribution process of these laptops, SEDR will work in close liaison with the MBC and MOJ to design and present an online basic orientation training session, to ensure the 70 new users are enabled to obtain maximum benefit from both the new ICT hardware and software. SEDR will furthermore support an additional online training session for new users, specifically focussing on how best to use the new equipment as part of the MBC’s new online mediation database/platform.

title: Opanayake farmers left high and dry
author: Author not found
Content: Farmers residing in several villages in and around Opanayake in Ratnapura say due to a scarcity of fertiliser, their cultivations have been badly affected. They said they are finding it difficult to look after their families as a result. According to farmers, cultivations in villages such as Udawela, Akarella, Udagama, Delwala, Ranwalakanda, and Hela Colony have been severely affected owing to lack of fertiliser. Therefore, they urged the authorities to intervene and supply fertiliser expeditiously, as they are unable to make a living. By Priya – Godakawela

title: Firms supplying low-quality fertiliser to be blacklisted
author: Author not found
Content: Companies supplying organic fertiliser found to be of inferior quality will be blacklisted and if the fertiliser has already been supplied, no money will be paid, Minister of Agriculture Mahinda Amaraweera said. He said, at present, 10 companies have been approved by the National Fertiliser Secretariat to issue organic fertiliser, adding that it is the responsibility of the Secretariat to test three samples of each type of fertiliser while distributing them through the Agrarian Services Centres. Amaraweera said, committees chaired by the District Secretary in each district will also be appointed to ensure the quality of organic fertiliser. “The respective production companies should be responsible for distributing the organic fertiliser to the relevant Agrarian Service Centres as well as promoting them to the farmers while it is the responsibility of farmers to choose the required fertiliser,” he said. Amaraweera added that the Government will provide a 50 per cent subsidy or a sum of Rs 20,000 to farmers to buy organic fertiliser. He said, this during a discussion held with organic fertiliser manufacturing companies to make arrangements to supply organic fertiliser for paddy cultivation. (FT)

title: Landslide kills one
author: Author not found
Content: The Disaster Management Centre (DMC) yesterday (1) reported one death and one injury due to a landslide in Bandarawela that took place on the previous day Monday (31). In related developments, the National Building Research Organisation (NBRO) yesterday issued landslide warnings covering 19 Divisional Secretariat divisions (DSDs) in eight districts. They are – Badulla District: Bandarawela, Ella and Passara DSDs and surrounding areas, Kandy: Ganga Ihala Korale DSD and surrounding areas, Kegalle: Ruwanwella, Deraniyagala, Dehiowita and Yatiyantota DSDs and surrounding areas, Kurunegala: Ridigama DSD and surrounding areas, Matara: Kotapola DSD and surrounding areas, Monaragala: Medagama and Badalkumbura DSD and surrounding areas, Nuwara Eliya: Ambagamuwa and Nuwara Eliya DSDs and surrounding areas and Ratnapura: Ratnapura, Elapatha, Nivithigala, Kalawana and Kuruwita DSDs and surround areas, respectively. Meanwhile, DMC further said, due to various environmental disasters caused by strong winds, landslides and cutting failures, 18 houses were damaged impacting 61 people belonging to 21 families in two consecutive days to Monday. The impacted districts were the Badulla, Ratnapura, and Kandy Districts, respectively. The district-wise breakdown of the damaged houses and impacted people were 19 families comprising 65 people and 17 houses in Ratnapura, a family of four in Bandarawela, Badulla and damages to a house belonging to an individual at Ganga Ihala Korale, Kandy, respectively. By Paneetha Ameresekere

title: Court instructs CIABOC to respond
author: Author not found
Content: President’s Counsel Kalinga Indatissa yesterday (1) raised initial objections before three separate Benches of the Colombo High Court, stating that the lawsuits filed against ex-Minister Johnston Fernando and two others cannot be further maintained, as there were no Provisions in the law to do so. Fernando and two others have been charged before the High Court with having caused a loss of revenue to the State via the forced use of labour from Lanka SATHOSA for political work, other than their official duty. Three lawsuits filed by Commission to Investigate Allegations of Bribery or Corruption (CIABOC) against the three accused, namely Fernando, former Chairman of Lanka SATHOSA Eraj Fernando and former Director Mohammad Zakeer, were convened separately, before High Court Judges Namal Ballale, Navaratne Marasinghe and ManjulaThillakaratne, respectively. Counsel Indatissa told the Judges that when filing a bribery case the necessary Provisions have to be adhered to, as per the Bribery Act. He then alleged that ahead of filing such lawsuits, the Commissioners of CIABOC have to give an order or issue an edict, to conduct initial inquiries and he noted that the Commissioners had never issued such orders, to sleuths of the Bribery Commission. By Hansi Nanayakkara

title: GoSL assessing restructuring domestic debt
author: Author not found
Content: Government of Sri Lanka (GoSL) is assessing the possibility of restructuring its domestic debt, the Finance Ministry in a document released on Monday (31 October) said. “This does not mean however that strict comparability of treatment will necessarily apply between external and domestic creditors, even more so given that certain domestic creditors are to be ring-fenced for financial stability or social reasons,” the document titled “Q&A ‘for’ Investor Presentation,” further said. Nonetheless, it also said, “We are still assessing precisely, with the assistance of our debt advisers and the IMF team, the impact certain reforms of the domestic financial sector may have on our fiscal accounts and growth estimates. Yet, we want to reassure our external partners that this topic is being looked at with an open mind, and by reference to the principle of fair and equitable treatment of all creditors.”  The foreseen fiscal adjustment should allow the country to bring the primary surplus at 2.3 per cent by 2025 from a primary deficit of 5.7 per cent in 2021, which corresponds to an eight percentage point fiscal consolidation effort in four years, the Ministry document/report also said. “As per the original Budget submitted to Parliament on 12 November 2021, the primary deficit for 2022 was estimated at 2.8 per cent of GDP. But now it’s estimated to shoot up to four per cent,” the Finance Ministry said. The target for next year 2023 is a primary deficit of 0.7 per cent, it added. The report further said that revenue measures to support fiscal consolidation and annual budget for 2023 in line with the IMF’s USD 2.9 billion assistance programme is being targeted, the introduction of formula-based price adjustments for fuel and electricity is in line, the introduction of a new Central Bank Act and amendments to the Banking Act to enhance Central Bank of Sri Lanka (CBSL) powers and measures to support prices and financial sector stability are also to be targeted. “Government of Sri Lanka (GoSL) is committed to adopting a new Central Bank Act that will further strengthen the autonomy of the CBSL and to refrain from any monetary financing,” it added. “IMF is considering both liquidity and solvency indicators to assess Sri Lanka’s debt situation. These targets will be dealing with our overall debt-to-GDP trajectory and levels, our yearly gross financing needs and foreign exchange (FX) denominated debt service expressed as a percentage of GDP. The indicative targets assigned to Sri Lanka were determined by the IMF staff team in accordance with the new Sovereign Risk and Debt Sustainability Framework for Market Access Countries. These targets cannot be publicly disclosed at this stage but will become public once the USD 2.9 billion facility is approved by the IMF Board,” the Finance Ministry further said. “We have started to share information on our IMF programme parameters and debt sustainability assessment in more details with the advisers to bondholders on a confidential basis under Non-Disclosure Agreements (NDA),” it added. BY Paneetha Ameresekere

title: Kebithigollewa rages after man dies in elephant attack
author: Author not found
Content: A Police Sergeant succumbed to injuries after being assaulted by a group of individuals following a tense situation in Kebithigollewa. The Kebithigollewa Police OIC and four Police officers had gone to Rambakapuwewa to investigate a death following a wild elephant attack on 31 October. At the time of their arrival, at least 150 people had blockaded the road with burning tyres and were harassing passing motorists. However, when the Police approached the crowd to investigate the situation, a group had attacked the Police OIC and a Sergeant who tried to block the attackers. The OIC had fired warning shots in the air to control the crowd but the Sergeant sustained critical injuries following the brutal assault. The victim was rushed to the Kebithigollewa Hospital and was transferred to the Anuradhapura Teaching Hospital for further treatment. However, while he was being taken to Anuradhapura hospital his health had turned critical and he was admitted to the Madawachchiya Hospital where he was pronounced dead on admission. The deceased was Angampodige Sunil, a 54-year-old father of two from Wariyapola. The individual who was attacked by a wild elephant was a 48-year-old named Baddaralage Gunasinghe, a resident of Rambakepuwewa. Gunasinghe had taken a bus from Kebithigollewa town to his house but had gotten off at the Rambakepuwewa junction and was walking a short distance to his village when a wild elephant attacked and killed him at around 7.20p.m. on 31 October. After the death of the villager, the locals had blocked the Kabithigollewa-Padawiya main road at Rambakepuwewa and started a protest against the Wildlife Department and the KabithigollewaPolice. The protesting villagers said, “When the elephant came to the village in the morning, no one from the Police or the Wildlife Department came even though we made phone calls requesting them to drive the elephant away. And now that a person is dead, they have come to see what happened.” Following the heated situation, 15 persons were arrested in connection with the death of the sergeant. The suspects are aged 20 to 30 and are residents of Rambakepuwewa. Among the suspects is a monk who served in the Army for a time before deserting. Police are conducting further investigations into the incident. BY Aloka Kasturiarachchi and Percy Kuroneru – Anuradhapura

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Govt using PTA to suppress people – Watagala
author: Author not found
Content: Jathika Jana Balawegaya Attorney-at-Law Sunil Watagala alleged that the Government is attempting to prosecute individuals under the Prevention of Terrorism Act (PTA), as attempts to suppress people using the Public Property Act and Archaeological sites of National Importance Act failed. Watagala said, instead of providing essential food items, fuel, and other commodities at an affordable price, the Government has chosen to suppress people, in a way that they cannot seek bail. Speaking to the media on Monday (31 October), at JVP Headquarters Watagala, he queried what student leader Wasantha Mudalige had done to be detained under the PTA. He said, he attempted to visit Mudalige at the Terrorist Investigation Division (TID), but was not granted access. “How can this country be democratic, if a lawyer cannot visit a suspect in custody?” he questioned. By Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: Ketagalara residents severely inconvenienced
author: Author not found
Content: Residents in Ketagalara, Waraketiara in the Embilipitiya Divisional Secretariat have been severely inconvenienced, as the National Water Supply and Drainage Board (NWSDB) has suspended pumping water to the tank near Udawalawa South Canal. Many residents who are farmers cannot sustain their cultivation as a result. They alleged that of late the NWSDB has started to charge a monthly fee of Rs 4,000 to 5,000 to release water to the Udawalawa Tank. They said, they are struggling to pay such a high water bill, as their harvest does not fetch enough revenue. Hence, they urge the authorities to intervene and provide relief. By Sena Gamage – Embilipitiya

title: Court recalls notices issued on Police duo
author: Author not found
Content: Colombo Fort Magistrate Thilina Gamage yesterday (1) recalled the notices, previously issued by him, on ASP Nalin Dilruk and Senior Inspector of Police Roshan Dias, to appear before him on 8 November. The two Police officers have been charged with interfering with a protest march that had proceeded from the Galle Face Green to the Hulftsdorp Court complex, on 9 October. The Fort Magistrate recalled the notices, having considered submissions produced by Senior State Counsel Samindra Wickrema, on behalf of the Attorney General. The Court had noticed Dilruk and Dias, on 28 October, to be present in Court on 8 November, based on submissions made by President’s Counsel Saliya Peiris, who charged that the actions of the two Police officers had flouted the Fundamental Rights of citizens guaranteed by the Constitution. By Hansi Nanayakkara

title: international Airlines Flying to SL Drop to 17
author: Author not found
Content: Although there were 41 international airlines flying to Sri Lanka prior to the Covid-19 pandemic, that number has now reduced to 17 due to factors such as the fuel crisis, pandemic and shortage of aviation staff, the Civil Aviation Authority of Sri Lanka (CAASL) said. Currently, there is a shortage of traffic controllers, as most have sought overseas jobs and the remaining staff is ‘over-worked’, it is learnt. Meanwhile, Cabinet approval has been received to sell 49 per cent of SriLankan Airlines’ catering and ground-handling operations, but is yet to obtain Parliamentary approval, Ceylon Today learns. The Government decided to sell holdings to foreign investors or form a joint venture in August 2022, but there isn’t a favourable environment to sell the stakes in SriLankan Airlines’ ground handling and catering services, despite the fact that these two institutions are profitable. While SriLankan continues to make losses in terms of revenue, the idea of selling a 49 per cent stake has not progressed, according to the Civil Aviation Authority of Sri Lanka. It was also discovered that numerous airlines had stopped using Sri Lankan airspace, for which they were paying in dollars, due to a number of reasons, one of which was the failure of flights, like Cathay Pacific, which mainly carried Chinese tourists to Sri Lanka. According to CAASL statistics, the profit it made after tax in 2020 was Rs 216 million much lower than the profit after tax in 2019 which was Rs 1.3 billion. By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: Three Sailors feted for their honesty
author: Author not found
Content: Navy Commander Vice Admiral Nishantha Ulugetenne on Friday (28 October), commended three sailors for refusing a bribe of Rs 100,000 to release three fishers involved in illegal fishing off the coast of Jinnapuram, Pulmoddai, Trincomalee on Wednesday (26 October), the Navy said. The sailors commended were Master Chief Petty Officer, H.M.S. Kumara, Leading Seaman D.P.G.A.N. Jayasena and Able Seaman S.D.D.L.T. Dissanayake, respectively. All three sailors belonged to Navy’s Special Boat Squadron (SBS), Navy Spokesman Captain Indika de Silva told this newspaper. The Navy said, the SBS patrol apprehended three fishers together with their dinghy for ‘blast’ fishing, an illegal form of fishing activity. Two other fishers who saw their fellow fishers arrested had offered the bribe for their release, which was turned down by the sailors. All five suspects together with their two dinghies and the Rs 100,000 bribe were handed over to the Fisheries Inspector, Kuchchaveli, for legal action, the Navy said. At a ceremony held at Sri Lanka Navy Headquarters, Colombo to fete these three sailors, Ulugetenne heaped praised on them for their honesty and devotion to duty, disregarding any personal gain, the Navy said. He also awarded letters of commendation to the trio who prevented an illegal act, while up-keeping the dignity of the noble service. (PA)

The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: CTU lobbies to amend dress code for female teachers
author: Author not found
Content: Ceylon Teachers’ Union (CTU) has made a special request to the Education Ministry regarding the dress code of female school teachers. CTU General Secretary Joseph Stalin in a statement said yesterday (31 October) that considering the ‘Public Administration Circular No: 05/2022 issued on 27.09.2022’, school teachers, especially female teachers too should be allowed to wear modest and appropriate attire, other than Saree and Osari. “The circular states that public officers should be allowed to dress in appropriate and modest attire as to preserve the dignity of the public service, when arriving at their offices to perform duties. Further, the attire should be applicable for field duties as well. However, the circular’s guidelines haven’t been applicable for schoolteachers,” he added. Stalin said, owing to the current economic crisis in the country many female teachers cannot afford to purchase ‘Saari’ and ‘Osari’. “They also travel a lot longer in public transport and in two-wheeler vehicles, which makes it uncomfortable for them. Even we have observed that it is much easier for teachers to function and take care of the kids, wearing comfortable and modest attire other than sari,” he added. By Nabiya Vaffoor

title: Wild jumbos besiege towns, villages – Locals
author: Author not found
Content: Wild elephants which had been destroying crops in border villages, in the Ampara District, are now entering towns and semi-urbanised areas.  Locals say that elephant herds are now invading villages even before sunset. As a result, local farmers have been vacating their houses during the night for safety and they return home in the morning. Alimnagar and Sinnamullaithivu in Akkaraipattu, Palamunai in Addalachennai, Veliverian field in Sainthamaruthu and Varipathanchennai in Irakkamam are the worst affected areas. A few days ago, two elephants entered a paddy mill by breaking the parapet walls. They ransacked bags of paddy stored there. The watcher escaped miraculously from the grip of the elephants as he was awake at that time. This is the second time within a month that an elephant had entered the mill, the owner said. On the same day, elephants ruined many plantations in Sinnamullaithivu and flattened the parapet walls of a mosque and the walls of the muaddin’s (mosque caretaker) room. Fortunately the muaddin was not in his rooms at the time, or he would have been trampled by elephant.  Villagers have complained to the Divisional Secretaries and the Wildlife Department officials. Villagers also say that chasing the elephants into the jungles won’t work as the animals return to inhabitated areas and that officials should take concrete steps to protect residents or they will have to leave the area and their livelihoods. BY M.A.P. Deen – Ampara

title: Bakery products down by Rs 10
author: Author not found
Content: The price of bakery products, including a 450g loaf of bread, has been reduced by Rs 10, the All Island Bakery Owners’ Association (ACBOA) said yesterday (31 October). ACBOA President N.K. Jayawardena said, the organisation is considering revising prices of all bakery products, following the reduction of wheat flour prices, but noted that they are not receiving flour for the prices reported in the Media. Following a special discussion yesterday, Jayawardena said that the price of bakery products was reduced with effect midnight yesterday. “Though media claimed the price of a kilogramme of wheat flour was reduced to Rs 250 it was only applicable for the purchases of more than 25MT. There are only limited number of bakeries that make such large purchases. A majority of bakeries are conducting their operations on a small scale,” he pointed out. But, many bakery owners do not get the benefit of wheat flour price reduction, he stressed. By Nabiya Vaffoor

title: Three Sailors feted for their honesty
author: Author not found
Content: Navy Commander Vice Admiral Nishantha Ulugetenne on Friday (28 October), commended three sailors for refusing a bribe of Rs 100,000 to release three fishers involved in illegal fishing off the coast of Jinnapuram, Pulmoddai, Trincomalee on Wednesday (26 October), the Navy said. The sailors commended were Master Chief Petty Officer, H.M.S. Kumara, Leading Seaman D.P.G.A.N. Jayasena and Able Seaman S.D.D.L.T. Dissanayake, respectively. All three sailors belonged to Navy’s Special Boat Squadron (SBS), Navy Spokesman Captain Indika de Silva told this newspaper. The Navy said, the SBS patrol apprehended three fishers together with their dinghy for ‘blast’ fishing, an illegal form of fishing activity. Two other fishers who saw their fellow fishers arrested had offered the bribe for their release, which was turned down by the sailors. All five suspects together with their two dinghies and the Rs 100,000 bribe were handed over to the Fisheries Inspector, Kuchchaveli, for legal action, the Navy said. At a ceremony held at Sri Lanka Navy Headquarters, Colombo to fete these three sailors, Ulugetenne heaped praised on them for their honesty and devotion to duty, disregarding any personal gain, the Navy said. He also awarded letters of commendation to the trio who prevented an illegal act, while up-keeping the dignity of the noble service. (PA)

title: TNA will back President to fix ‘National Problem’ – Sampanthan
author: Author not found
Content: If President Ranil Wickremesinghe strives to resolve Sri Lanka’s ethnic issues, his name would be written in gold in the country’s history, said Tamil National Alliance (TNA) Leader and MP R. Sampanthan. He stated that the TNA wants a permanent solution to the ‘National Problem’ through the enactment of a new Constitution and insisted that it is not impossible if Wickremesinghe too toes that line. The former Opposition Leader mentioned that if the President takes an honest initiative to solve the National Problem, the TNA would pledge its utmost support. Sampanthan made these remarks in response to the President’s statement that the National Problem would be solved through a new Constitution. By D.L. Jayakody

title: Two shot dead in Hikkaduwa
author: Author not found
Content: Two persons were gunned down in Thiranagama, Hikkaduwa yesterday (31 October), Police said. They were pronounced dead on admission to the Karapitiya Teaching Hospital. Police claimed the victims were believed to be the killers of Roshan de Silva alias Kata Roshan. According to Police, the two victims, who were travelling on a motorcycle, were shot at by unidentified gunmen. Police said, the victims were arrested and produced before Court for hacking to death a person (Kata Roshan) on 20 December 2020. Incidentally, Kata Roshan had been accused of hacking to death another individual in Meetiyagoda previously and police suspect yesteday’s incident was a result of continuous revenge act between the two gangs. They had then been remanded but were released on bail several days ago. At the time of the shooting, the two were on their way to appear before the Galle Magistrate’s Court. The Police said, the victims had sustained 17 gunshots. The victims were identified as 47-year-old and 26-year-old residents of Hikkaduwa. Hikkaduwa Police is conducting further investigations to arrest the killers. BY Kamal Wijehewa – Galle, Farhan Nizamdin – Galle and S. Diyagahage – Ahangama

title: Ven. Mahalakotuwe Thera wants monks barred from contesting polls
author: Author not found
Content: The Chief Sanganayaka of Matale, Ven. Mahalakotuwe Wimaladhamma Thera, says that he had requested the  Anunayake of the Malwathu Chapter, of the Sri Dalada Maligawa, Ven. Dimbulkumbure Sri Saranankara Wimaladhamma Thera, to urge the Mahanayaka Theras of the Malwathu, Asgiriya and Amarapura Chapters, to enact laws to prevent members of the Buddhist Clergy from contesting national elections. Ven. Wimaladhamma Thera revealed this during an event held at the Sri Sumana Sama Temple in Ukuwela recently. He stated that the Mahanayaka Theras should urgently take a firm decision to bar Buddhist Monks from contesting Presidential, Parliamentary, PC and LG Polls, or else warned it would be to the detriment of the Buddha Sasana. He added that members of Clergy from other faiths do not venture into party politics unlike Buddhist Monks and that the Buddha had never preached that the Maha Sangha could be actively involved in politics. The Thera observed that the duty of Buddhist monks 24/7 is to spread the Dhamma and to proffer sound advice to the masses to rid the society of its present day ills rather than hanker after materialistic joys. BY Priyantha Polwatta – Ukuwela

title: Fisheries sector facing plethora of issues – Piyal
author: Author not found
Content: State Minister of Fisheries Piyal Nishantha de Silva claimed that there are many serious problems in the fisheries sector besides the fuel price issue. State Minister de Silva made these claims while participating in a special programme to promote fisheries activities in the Kalutara District on 28 October. He added that the increasing price of fuel is another major problem that fishermen are facing today. “Such a situation has arisen as result of the prevailing economic crisis. But, I am confident that a solution can be found to the rising cost of fuel when the economy is back to normal. There are still so many outstanding issues in the fisheries sector. These issues must be resolved as soon as possible. Due to the organisational inefficiency at certain fishery harbours, the fishermen are facing a number of difficulties. I plan to resolve every one of them by visiting district by district,” the State Minister said. The special programme was held at Beruwela Ama Hotel chaired by State Minister Piyal Nishantha de Silva and the officials of Fisheries Ministry. Various issues the fishermen in the Kalutara District facing were discussed there. Progressive reports of projects implemented by the Department of Fisheries and Aquatic Resources, Ceylon Fisheries Corporation, Ceylon Fishery Harbours Corporation, National Aquaculture Development Authority of Sri Lanka and National Aquatic Resources Research and Development Agency (NARA) were presented to the State Minister. Meanwhile, he also stressed the necessity of every institution coming under the Fisheries Ministry and working together to resolve the issues of fisheries sector. By Naalir Jamaldeen

title: Landmine found in waste soil
author: Author not found
Content: Mannar Police found a landmine in a tractor trailer transporting waste soil in Pappamoddai, in the Mannar District yesterday (31 October). Police added that the tractor was transporting waste soil from the Pappamoddai area to a cemetery in the Savalakkaddu near the Mannar Town. A worker at the site who found the landmine had immediately alerted the authorities. Police had rushed to secure the area and had defused the landmine with the help of the STF after receiving Court approval. By Naali Jamaldeen

title: Witness remanded for false testimony
author: Author not found
Content: Colombo High Court Judge Amal Ranaraja yesterday (31 October) remanded the fourth witness, who had provided false testimony in the bribery case against former General Secretary of the Laggala Pradeshiya Sabha (PS) Samantha Pradeep Ranasinghe. The former PS General Secretary has been charged before the High Court with soliciting a bribe of Rs 100,000 from a contractor, to release approved cheques for the construction of a road. The Judge said, he was ordering for the fourth witness in the trial to be named as a suspect, in cognizance of the fact, that he had provided false testimony during the course of the case proceedings and based on submissions made by the prosecution. Hence, the fourth witness, identified as K. G. Gunathilaka, who had worked as the driver of the cab, utilised by the accused former General Secretary, was remanded. The Commission to Investigate Allegations of Bribery or Corruption (CIABOC) had indicted the accused on four counts, before the High Court and for having violated Provisions contained in the Bribery Act. By Hansi Nanayakkara

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: New agri insurance pension scheme inaugurated
author: Author not found
Content: The Agricultural and Agrarian Insurance Board inaugurated a new Agricultural Insurance Pension Scheme with effect from yesterday(31 October).  The inauguration took place at the Hector Kobbekaduwa Agrarian Research and Training Institute, under the patronage of Minister of Agriculture, Wildlife and Forest Resources Conservation Mahinda Amaraweera. More than 59 new pensioners were awarded insurance beneficiary certificates.   “In 2018, insurance ofRs 40,000 per acre was provided free of charge to farmers for damages to six types of crops, and arrangements were made to provide a sum of Rs 100,000 as compensation,’’ Amaraweera said. He added, there were requests from famers to increase the sum and accordingly, instructions were given to the Agricultural and Agrarian Insurance Board to provide an insurance policy ofRs 500,000 per acre by charging a small premium. Amaraweera noted thereby that the insurance system will commence soon. (FT)

title: PM demands Speaker for immediate probe
author: Author not found
Content: Prime Minister Dinesh Gunawardena urged the Speaker Mahinda Yapa Abeywardena for an immediate inquiry into the incident where a Police Sergeant was killed after being hit by a parliament bus driven by an intoxicated driver. The incident occurred when the staff returning after a get-together held in Negombo. Speaking to Ceylon Today, the Prime Minister said that the incident should not be taken lightly and requested the Speaker to commence an investigation through an independent and impartial professional who has no ties with Parliament. He said, those who approved the use of Parliament vehicles for the said party should take the whole responsibility for the incident. Both the Leader of the House and the Chief Opposition Whip should look into the incident as well, the PM said. Speaking further, the PM said, it is wrong to use Parliament vehicles for get-togethers when the Government has issued a circular to conserve electricity, fuel and other resources during the country’s economic crisis. Meanwhile, the driver of the bus is still missing and several Police teams have been deployed to search for him. BY J.T. de Silva and Anuradha Herath

title: Govt defending itself against lawsuit – Finance Ministry
author: Author not found
Content: The Government is vigorously defending itself on a plaint filed by a foreign bank to recover the credit extend by that bank to the GoSL, the Finance Ministry said yesterday (31 October). The Ministry in a document titled “Q&A ‘for’ Investor Presentation” further said, “On 21 June 2022, Hamilton Reserve Bank (HRB) filed a lawsuit against Sri Lanka in the New York Federal Court. HRB alleges that it has accelerated a series of bonds that were due in July 2022 (the “July 2022 Bonds”) and that it holds more than 25 per cent of the aggregate principal amount of the July 2022 Bonds. HRB is seeking full payment of the principal and interest on the July 2022 Bonds and an order barring Sri Lanka from paying other debts in the meantime. Sri Lanka is vigorously defending itself in this action. The July 2022 Bonds were issued in July 2012.” The document also said that debt owed to The Asian Clearing Union amounted to USD 1,917 million as of end June 2022, It  further said that certain amounts on Sri Lanka Development Bonds ( SLDBs) equivalent to USD 96 million, i.e., both principal and interest, were settled in  Sri Lanka rupees shortly after the implementation of  stopping foreign debt repayments as an interim debt policy, “as these limited amounts were still consistent with Central Bank of Sri Lanka’s (CBSL’s) monetary objectives at that time.” It further said, “Given the current debt situation, Sri Lanka currently relies on domestic financing and a few limited external sources of financing such as some emergency credit lines from key international partners for essential imports. Given the current scarcity of external sources of financing and the necessity to ensure a swift economic recovery, the Government is doing their utmost efforts to have the envisaged USD 2.9 billion IMF programme approved as soon as possible, which in turn will enable Sri Lanka to access much needed new financings from the IMF, other international financial institutions (IFIs) and some official bilateral partners.” It also said that garment exports in particular, thus far have seen good results and are expected to sustain this performance up to 2024. BY Paneetha Ameresekere

title: CID ordered to probe forged appointment letters
author: Author not found
Content: Colombo Chief Magistrate Nandana Amerasinghe yesterday (31 October) ordered the CID to probe the incident, where seven appointment letters for jobs, containing the signature and letterheads of the former Secretary of the Ministry of Youth Affairs and Sports, had been forged. The Chief Magistrate gave this order, based on submissions made by the CID. The CID informed Magistrate Amerasinghe, that they had commenced an inquiry into the alleged incident, based on a complaint lodged by the former Secretary to the said Ministry Anurada Wijekoon. The CID added that they are currently probing the incident, based on Provisions contained in Sections 400, 454 and 456 of the Penal Code. By Hansi Nanayakkara

title: Halting of ‘Green Card’ jeopardises specialist training
author: Author not found
Content: Specialist training of local doctors is being further jeopardised with the stopping of the ‘Green Card’. Doctors would not be issued the ‘Green Card’ till further notice, after Health Secretary Janaka Sri Chandaraguptha issued instructions to the Deputy Director General (Medical Services) in this regard.  In a letter, copied to Director Tertiary Health Care Services, Chandraguptha, said that the Health Ministry was unable to pay medical practitioners going abroad for foreign training the living allowance they were paid every two months, air ticket fee and other money which needed to be reimbursed due to the current economic and the forex crises. The Health Ministry Secretary, explaining said that the manager of the Travel Section, in a leading State bank in the country, had emailed the Expenditure Section and notified that the bank was unable to open the ‘Green Card’ for those doctors going for foreign training and that the bank’s top management and issued instructions in this regard. “He had also noted that those doctors who had been paid their living allowance in August 2022 had also been paid the allowance in September as well in keeping with the top level instructions they had received,” the Health Ministry Secretary said.  “Taking into consideration these factors, it would not be possible to open the ‘Green Card’ for doctors going for foreign training in the future,” he lamented noting that thereby the Health Ministry was unable to pay medical officers the living allowance while training abroad. He urged the Deputy Director General to take note of the instructions and put temporary halt to the specialist training being given to them.         By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: Inflation decelerates after 12 months
author: Author not found
Content: The increase in overall inflation in Colombo for the first time after 12 months decelerated last month (October 2022), falling to 66 per cent year on year (YoY), from 69.8 per cent in the previous month September 2022, Census and Statistics Department (CSD) data released yesterday (31 October) showed. The fall was aided by food inflation also decelerating for the first time after 12 months last month, slowing down to 85.6 per cent, from 94.9 per cent in September 2022 and non-food inflation to 56.3 per cent, from 57.6 per cent in September 2022. The combination of food and non-food inflation makes up overall inflation. Among some of the commodity price hikes responsible for the YoY rise in food inflation to last month was the retail price of dried chilies increasing by 185.03 per cent (Rs 1,177.19) to Rs 1,813.42 a kg;   retail price of an egg by 164.67 per cent (Rs 31.05) to Rs 49.91; beetroot by 163.14 per cent (Rs 232.08) to Rs 374.34 as kg; capsicum, up 153.54 per cent (Rs 495.44) to Rs 818.13 a kg; ash plantains up 145.28 per cent (Rs 269.41) to Rs 454.84 a kg; tomatoes, up 134.28 per cent (Rs 201.89) to Rs 352.24 a kg. The retail price of a kg of chicken up by 129.12 per cent (Rs 829.7) to Rs 1,472.29 a kg; retail price of a kilo of red rice increasing by 117.97 per cent (Rs 121.65) to Rs 224.68; ,sprats by 116.43 per cent (Rs 1,051.42) to Rs 1,954.46 a kg; red nadu rice by 111.86 per cent (Rs 130.57) to Rs 247.30;  ash plantains, up 106.93 per cent (Rs 139.66) to Rs 270.27 a kg; sugar by 106.48 per cent (Rs 143.89) to Rs 279.02 a kg and beetroot up by 102.4 per cent (Rs 285.63) to  Rs 564.54 a kg, respectively. Among the commodities that spurred non-food inflation YoY to last month was the retail price of a litre of kerosene up 341.56 per cent (Rs 263) to Rs 340; diesel, up 283.58 per cent (Rs 315.53) to Rs 426.79 a litre; petrol, up 160.71 per cent (Rs 252.73) to Rs 410 a litre and LP gas, up 117.63 per cent (Rs 2,529.02) to 4,679.02 per domestic cylinder of gas, respectively. BY Paneetha Ameresekere

title: Colombo Chief Magistrate’s Court short-staffed
author: Author not found
Content: The Colombo Chief Magistrate’s Court Lawyers’ Association has written to the Minister of Justice regarding a shortage of staff at the Colombo Chief Magistrate’s Court. The Colombo Chief Magistrate’s Court Lawyers’ Association observed, in the letter, that the Colombo Chief Magistrate’s Court, which consists of nine Additional Magistrate Courts, has a large number of cases and due to the lack of staff, there has been difficulties in maintaining the judicial affairs properly. They also noted that the issues will further aggravate as eleven staff members are due to take maternity leave in the next two weeks. The Association also requested to pay attention to the lack of housing for a large number of the staff. BY Hansi Nanayakkara

title: As Party Congress ends, China releases data on weak growth
author: Author not found
Content: A day after China’s Communist Party Congress wrapped up, China unexpectedly released delayed economic data, which showed weak growth prompting markets to plunge, media reports said. Last week, China’s National Bureau of Statistics delayed the release of GDP and other economic indicators. However, the Bureau did not give any explanation why it was postponed from the scheduled date, 18 October, the Washington Post reported. If released on the scheduled date, the release would have coincided with the much-anticipated Communist Party Congress meeting in Beijing which saw Chinese President Xi Jinping securing an unprecedented third term on the top post. The bureau on Monday (31), reported that the GDP grew 3.9 per cent between July and September of this year which is below the Chinese Government’s annual target of “around 5.5 per cent.” “China’s official economic data are political first, economic second. Last week’s delay in the release of these numbers and then the curiously upbeat GDP figures at the close of the Party Congress underscored this point yet again,” said Shehzad Qazi, managing director at China Beige Book, which collects and analyzes data on China’s economy, reported Washington Post. Following the data release, Hong Kong’s Hang Seng Index plunged 6 per cent to levels not seen since the 2008 financial crisis. Meanwhile, the Shanghai Composite and the Shenzhen Composite indexes both fell by about two per cent. Xi Jinping’s tightened political control in China has posed several challenges to his leadership as the communist nation is facing a dark economic picture while economic and social inequality continue to increase. The crisis in China due to stringent lockdowns has triggered hopelessness among the country’s masses and has only added to the political challenges for Xi Jinping. Nathan Levine and Johanna Costigan, writing in Nikkei Asia further said the control in China, since the days of Mao Zedong has been maintained by what he famously described as “the gun” (the military), “the pen” (propaganda) and “the knife” (the internal security apparatus). China is one of the last places in the world still enforcing stringent zero-Covid measures. The heavy-handed approach has seen dozens of neighbourhoods across Shenzhen identified as “high-risk areas,” and placed under strict lockdown orders. In the last two years, while the rest of the world rose to the occasion and meandered its way through the global health crisis, China has clung to its futile attempt at feigning control over an impossible situation. Many people have been unemployed and underemployed, especially in service industries, due to the repeated lockdowns in different parts of the country. (ANI)

title: Court orders temple to not disturb area residents
author: Author not found
Content: The Colombo Chief Magistrate’s Court yesterday (31), ordered Ven. Uduwe Dhammaloka Thera to use loudspeakers at the Alanmathiniyaramaya Temple in a manner that would not cause any disturbance to the residents in the area. This was when the public nuisance case filed by the Centre for Environmental Justice (CEJ) together with the residents in the area and Sri Lanka’s High Commissioner to India Milinda Moragoda, was taken up before Court. They stated that the use of loudspeakers between 5.00 a.m. and 6.00 a.m. at the Alanmathiniyaramaya Temple has caused them disturbance. Court thereby held that the use of loudspeakers between 5.00 a.m. and 6.00 a.m. has in fact resulted in public nuisance and thereby ordered the respondent to only use loudspeakers in a manner that would not cause any disturbance to the residents. By Faadhila Thassim

title: “Go to Court if my SL citizenship is in doubt”
author: Author not found
Content: State Minister of Tourism Diana Gamage challenged MP Udaya Gammanpila to go to Court if he has a doubt about her Sri Lankan citizenship. In response to a claim made by Gammanpila that Gamage is not a Sri Lankan citizen, but a British citizen, Gamage said anyone, including Gammanpila, who believes she is not a Sri Lankan citizen can challenge her citizenship status in Court. The State Minister said, not only Gammanpila but some other lawyers also have made similar claims about her citizenship on various platforms. She said, they could go to Court if they have suspicions on her citizenship. BY Thameenah Razeek
