title: Unconsulted decisions led to setbacks in agro production – CSL
author: Author not found
Content: The Croplife Sri Lanka (CSL) says that decisions taken without proper consultation from experts in 2020-2021 period had led to large setbacks in the agriculture industry of late. Revealing the results of a survey conducted during the final quarter last year, the CSL says that the entire cost of crop production had spiked by 67 per cent while the harvest had reduced by 54 per cent due to decisions taken by the Government. They say that the cost factor at all levels of agriculture production had increased by 45 per cent. These details had come to light following a seminar conducted by the CSL in Colombo on 28 October. It was attended by several experts in the agriculture field along with State and private sector stakeholders. Speaking to the Media, CSL Chairman Chamenda Wijerathna stated that the Government’s decision to suspend the import of pesticides and various fertiliser varieties has had a debilitating effect on the entire agriculture industry. He noted that although the Government had reversed its decisions at the 11th hour, its negative impact on the industry would be felt for some years to come. He also pointed out that scores of inferior products had begun to infiltrate the market due to the previous ban, which has complicated the issue for those engaged in the industry. Wijerathna  added that the CSL in consultation with the Pesticides Register General are in the process of introducing quality pesticide products to protect farmer livelihoods.

title: MPs’ INSURANCE TO GET 500% BUMP
author: Author not found
Content: Plans are afoot to increase legislators’ medical insurance by 500 per cent as per a decision reached at the House Committee meeting held recently. Speaker Mahinda Yapa Abeywardena decided to forward a proposal to Cabinet, requesting to increase MPs’ medical insurance by 500 per cent. The proposal to Cabinet is to increase the value of a parliamentarian’s medical insurance from Rs 200,000 to Rs 1 million. Many MPs have informed the Speaker that the insurance amount is insufficient, as all medical expenses have increased due to the country’s economic situation. The proposal will be presented to Cabinet shortly.  By Anuradha Herath

title: Dr. Jasinghe elected VP of GGGI Assembly
author: Author not found
Content: Dr. Anil Jasinghe was elected as Vice President of the Assembly and Vice Chair of the Council of the Global Green Growth Institute (GGGI). Dr. Jasinghe will serve in these two positions for two years in addition to being the Secretary of Environment. The 11th Session of the Assembly and 15th Session of the Council of the Global Green Growth Institute (GGGI) was held on 27 October in Seoul, South Korea. Former UN Secretary-General Ban Ki-moon is the President of the Assembly and Chair of the Council of GGGI. GGGI’s governance structure includes an Assembly, a Council, and the Secretariat. “We are greatly honoured to be elected to this important position within the GGGI Assembly and Council. Sri Lanka looks forward to playing an active role and to collaborate with all other GGGI members. Sri Lanka will soon sign a Host Country Agreement with GGGI to strengthen our relations. Further, President Ranil Wickremesinghe has prioritised tackling climate change,” Dr. Jasinghe said.

title: ‘Community Kitchen’ programme gathers momentum
author: Author not found
Content: The President’s Media Division (PMD) joined the ‘Community Kitchen’ programme, to support the people affected by the food shortage. The PMD staff and the Community Kitchen programme run the Rajagiriya Community Service Centre. On 28 October, they provided a meal to the needy. More than 400 needy people attended the event. The Welfare Association of the PMD provided financial assistance. The intention is to spread the  ‘Community Kitchen Concept’ at public and private corporate level, a source said. With the recent introduction of the multi-sectoral joint mechanism toempower rural economic revitalisation centres to ensure food security and nutrition as envisaged by President Ranil Wickremesinghe, there was a wide discussion in society about the Community Kitchen Concept, he added. The aim of the concept is to gear for the upcoming food crisis, as well as to prepare a nutritious meal as a group and support those suffering from the food shortage. Director General of President Media Division Dhanushka Ramanayake, Senior Assistant Secretary to the President Sudhira Nilanga Withana, Director Editorial Piyasena Disanayaka, Director of Photography Misha Gunawardena, President of the Welfare and Sports Association of President Media Division Deputy Director, Deepti Pramita Adhikari, other Directors and staff members attended the event.

title: Govt to appoint special committee
author: Author not found
Content: The Government will appoint a committee to see how best to integrate the Upcountry Tamils further into the Sri Lankan Society, President Ranil Wickremesinghe said. He further said, although some Upcountry Tamils had integrated successfully into Sri Lankan society, some have failed, and steps will be taken to assist them to do so.  President Wickremesinghe said, this at the occasion of accepting a consignment of medicines donated by the Pondicherry Union Territory and people of India on the request of Ceylon Workers’ Congress (CWC) at the Presidential Secretariat yesterday (30). The President said he will ensure the development of schools in the plantation sector while the Ministry of Health will take over hospitals in the plantation sector and assured development in both these areas in the near future. “Now the Government is also encouraging building of houses and handing over lands to Upcountry Tamils. Steps will be taken to review the plantation economy that could be affected by people leaving the plantation areas after completing their education. More and more educated persons are leaving the plantation sector,” he said. Speaking further, he said the Government has to find jobs for them as well as for Sinhalese and Muslims who resettle. The Government also has to look at the future of the groups that will continue to live in the plantation sector and how to improve the plantation economy, as they cannot be allowed to live at subsistence level. “These issues will be gradually rectified in the coming years as the Government resolves the ethnic problem in Sri Lanka. The Government will take further steps to ensure that Upcountry Tamils will have the same facilities as other people in the country as realised and worked on under late President J.R. Jayewardene’s tenure,” he said.    Wickremesinghe also requested all leaders of the Upcountry Tamils to join in this endeavour to ensure that all benefits of Sri Lankan citizenship are enjoyed by the people in the Upcountry. The consignment of medicines was officially handed over to the President by Secretary General of the Ceylon Workers’ Congress (CWC) and Parliamentarian Jeevan Thondaman in memory of the late Saumyamoorthi Thondaman who passed away 23 years ago on 30 October. The consignment of medicines was later handed over to Health Minister Keheliya Rambukwella. The President also appreciated the service rendered by late Thondaman and said he was one of the most outstanding leaders of the 20th century in Sri Lanka, as through nonviolence he achieved citizenship for all the people of Indian Origin who stayed back after the Sirima-Shastri Pact. The President said he (Thondaman) got citizenship for some people who should have left under the Sirima-Shastri Pact, but decided to stay in Sri Lanka. Secretary to the President Saman Ekanayake, a representative from the Indian High Commission, and several members of CWC including Senthil Thondaman were present at the occasion.

title: India and SL are two sides of the same coin – President
author: Author not found
Content: President Ranil Wickremesinghe said India and Sri Lanka are two sides of the same coin and both countries have their differences in culture and religion. “However, there are commonalities. ‘Diwali’ is one of the commonality that all enjoy.” The President was addressing the gathering at the Diwali celebrations organised by Colombo Expats Cultural Association (CECA) at the Kingsbury Hotel on 29 October. Diwali is an occasion that brings family and friends together. The President commended CECA for organising such an event and he also appreciated their commitment and assistance towards Sri Lanka during these tough times to light up the lives of underprivileged children.  High Commissioner of India to Sri Lanka Gopal Baglay, First Lady Prof. Maithree Wickremesinghe, Senior Adviser to the President on National Security and President’s Chief of Staff Sagala Ratnayake, Secretary to the President Saman Ekanayake, CECA President Capt. A. Banerjee, and several other officials attended the event.

title: US-Sri Lanka ties further strengthened
author: Author not found
Content: President Ranil Wickremesinghe said measures have been taken to strengthen the 74-year-old ties between the United States and Sri Lanka, adding that the support rendered by the U.S. whenever Sri Lanka was in difficulty would never be forgotten.  He was speaking at the official opening of the new building of the U.S. Embassy in Colombo on 28 October. Expressing his views on diplomatic relations and mutual understanding between the U.S. and Sri Lanka during the separatist war, the President also recalled with gratitude the support given by the U.S. under the leadership of George Bush in 2001 during his tenure as Prime Minister. The President also recalled the support given by the US government led by Bill Clinton to help Sri Lanka recover from the tsunami disaster in 2004 and said if not for President Joe Biden’s intervention, Sri Lanka would not have had a success of the Maha season.    President Wickremesinghe said he appreciated the support rendered by the U.S. to prepare the first monetary law and the establishment of the Central Bank which was included in the 74-year US-Sri Lanka partnership. Having experienced such a long and cordial relationship, Sri Lanka and the U.S. will work as close friends in the future as well, the President said adding that the U.S. and Sri Lanka were inseparable partners and will forge ahead to preserve peace and democracy. “When I became the Deputy Minister of Foreign Affairs in 1977, it was an important era when President Ronald Reagan, Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher and Prime Minister Nakasone gave me the support together with Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew and Prime Minister Malcolm Fraser.  It was a turning point that contributed to the last geopolitical changes which took place in 1989 with the collapse of the Soviet Union.  I remember in 1993 when I went to the UK it was because Vice President Al Gore wanted me to sign an agreement including Sri Lanka to the internet. Imagine what would have happened had I not gone and didn’t sign. I is a long standing friendship. I also must mention the help given by President George W. Bush when I was Prime Minister in 2001. We have not forgotten the assistance that has been rendered so far and as Prime Minister I had your assistance to restore democratic principles and uphold the rule of law and freedom of expression,” he said, Wickremesinghe said, Sri Lanka was committed and will not move away from that. “The two countries will always be together. This new building is a symbol of a new era in where the relationship will develop. When the Indian Ocean is the focus of attention, and how fast geopolitics is changing,  we will have to carry out our new relationship and work together as in the past., I have no doubt that we will respect each other and work closely to uphold peace and democracy,” he said.

title: I have a clean record – Sirisena
author: Author not found
Content: Despite the fact that the internal audit division is mandated to check former Presidents’ homes, former President Maithripala Sirisena complained that no such officer had visited his home in the past three and a half years to carry out any checks. He said, they were responsible to check purchasers to the home, what is in the house, and what was brought to the house recently. “Reports circulate that televisions in the President’s official residences in Kataragama and Anuradhapura had gone missing. I do not want to take ‘broken’ televisions from official residences because I do not have the financial means or the policy to do so. I am comfortable speaking in front of a crowd of 100,000 people. I challenge anyone to prosecute me if during my tenure as a Minister or President I have committed irregularities,” he said. Further, Sirisena said if someone is carrying out his job honestly, that person could go wherever he or she wants. He said working instinctively and having a love for the public should be maintained at all times. He said it was a futile exercise to go after people and finding out the reason for all the wrong things that have hapened.  “Our only concern is how we will pull the country from the disaster it is facing. Those not involved in any type of corruption should be given the reigns, if the country is to be revitalised. Public representatives who enter Parliament commit 70 per cent of the corruption during their tenure. No ordinary citizen is in favour of what Parliament is doing,” he said. Sirisena said Parliament and the common man were at logger heads. He also said if at least 100 educated MPs came to Parliament, it would not take long to revive the country. BY Thameenah Razeek

title: Police to get most vehicles held by Customs
author: Author not found
Content: The Government is looking forward to handing over to the Police the majority of the vehicles that are being held at Customs due to various legal reasons. According to a spokesman for the State Ministry of Finance, the Government previously decided to release some vehicles that had been held at Customs due to various legal issues. He said State Minister of Finance Ranjith Siyambalapitiya had previously directed the Sri Lanka Customs to provide a report on how to release these vehicles from Customs, and that after receiving the report, it was decided to give the majority vehicles to the Police Department. He also noted that there are 450 vehicles that are not being released by Sri Lanka Customs due to various legal issues. “The ministry directed that the Court proceedings be completed as soon as possible and that the vehicles be released. We needed to find a way to get these vehicles released from the Director General (DG) of Customs as soon as possible. We received the report and decided to turn the majority over to the Police. The IGP, Customs DG, and State Minister will return to the location and consider which vehicles will be taken,” he said. When asked what types of vehicles are in the lot, the spokesman said there are cars, construction vehicles and the majority of them vehicles were assembled. BY Thameenah Razeek

title: JJB claims they can build country
author: Author not found
Content: JJB National Executive Member Dr. Nalinda Jayatissa said, now that the JJB has won the people’s attention, the SJB and SLPP have begun attacking them on stage on a regular basis. He said, if the other parties need proof of the people’s attraction, an election should be held rather than targeting the JJB on various platforms. He said the JJB is establishing the constituencies, with the goal of building the country, by covering almost all sectors and making the maximum contribution from each region to the national economy. He was addressing the Kalutara District Bandaragama Constituency gathering on 29 October. An election should be held right away to accomplish this, he said, claiming that by taking control of the country, the JJB can build it through a planned economy. “Our export income and Vietnam’s export income were the same in 1994. Their export revenue in August 2022, on the other hand, is USD 31 billion. Nonetheless, our country’s annual export income is USD 12 billion. We, in the Jathika Jana Balawegaya, are ready to build the country from this situation,” Dr. Jayatissa said. BY Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Thihagoda Police shooting victim undergoes brain surgery
author: Author not found
Content: The 15-year-old child, who was seriously injured in the Police shooting in Thihagoda, Matara has undergone two surgeries and is receiving treatment in the intensive care unit of the Karapitiya Teaching Hospital, according to Director Karapitiya Hospital, S.P.U.M. Ranga. He said the 15-year-old was shot in the head and required brain surgery. The Director said the victim was not in the best of health. Four people, including the 15-year-old child, were travelling in a three-wheeler when two Police officers in civilian clothes shot at them in Naimbala, Thihagoda as they did not heed Police orders to halt. BY Kamal Wijehewa – Galle

title: SI remanded, Police launch internal probe
author: Author not found
Content: The Sub-Inspector who was arrested over the shooting incident at Thihagoda, Matara in which a 15-year-old boy received critical injuries, was remanded, by the Matara Magistrate Court, till 4 November. Police Spokesman SSP Nihal Thalduwa said, the suspect appeared in Court on 29 October. Meanwhile, the Police have launched an internal investigation into the actions of the Sub-Inspector. An internal preliminary investigation is being conducted by a team of Police officers led by an Assistant Superintendent of Police, according to SSP Thalduwa. The children in the three-wheeler were between the ages of 14 and 15, according to the spokesman, and nearly six people were in the three-wheeler. “The three-wheel driver did not have a driver’s licences. That is why they tried to flee when they saw the cops. Therefore, we ask parents not to allow their children to engage in illegal behaviour,” he added. BY Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: Schoolgirls get ‘ICE’ from beauty salons – NDDCB
author: Author not found
Content: There is a high risk of schoolgirls obtaining Methamphetamine Crystals (ICE) from beauty parlours, according to the National Dangerous Drugs Control Board (NDDCB). NDDCB Assistant Counsellor Lakmee Nilanka said, statistics show that ICE is widely used in the Kurunegala District. She revealed this while participating in an awareness programme, organised by the Kuliyapitiya Excise Office, to prevent schoolchildren from becoming drug addicts. According to investigations, the drug addicts obtained their drugs from beauty salons and they are currently being treated. She suggested that the Government and other authorities focus on the spread of ICE outside of Colombo.

title: Children’s homes in bad shape – Geetha
author: Author not found
Content: State Minister of Women and Child Affairs Geetha Kumarasinghe revealed that Children’s Homes in the country were in poor condition and were not child-friendly. She said there were officers in each DS Division and they should keep an eye on minors who were being mistreated and report such incidents. They should visit homes during their off times and keep track of the situation. Kumarasinghe said she has requested President Ranil Wickremesighe to alter the age limit of children left behind when mothers go abroad, from two to five years. She was speaking at a programme in the Galle District to empower officials relating to the nutrition of children. She said while the previous rule stated that mothers could travel abroad once their children reached the age of five, this was changed to two years due to a proposal presented by some ‘moron’. “We must keep in mind that children are more valuable to the country than dollars. If the law relating to mothers who go abroad leving children under two years is not repealed, our children, mothers, and the country will surely perish. I have made four recommendations to the President. One is to raise the age limit. The second to set up separate District Courts to handle cases involving women and children. The thirdl is for each DS division to have at least one child care centre. We should use all our energy to implement this scheme,” she said. BY Gunapala Iraththanawalli – Ratgama

title: Excise revenue on the decline – Siyambalapitiya
author: Author not found
Content: Citing a World Health Organisation report on alcohol consumption in Sri Lanka, State Minister of Finance Ranjith Siyambalapitiya said while the liquor industry in Sri Lanka grew by 95 per cent between 2004 and 2016, the legalised liquor industry had only grown by 50 per cent. Siyambalapitiya revealed this while speaking at the annual council meeting of excise officers. He claimed that as opposed to this, the illicit liquor industry had grown 300 per cent and this was not brewed in the depths of the forests. He said those with excise licenses brewed illicit liquor and excise revenue was decreasing as a result of illicit liquor production. Siyambalapitiya claimed that businessmen use various methods to disrupt excise revenue, adding that before the British conquered Sri Lanka in 1810, excise revenue provided 7.6 per cent of State revenue. He said even at that time, the British National Commissioner General of Inland Revenue of Sri Lanka said businessmen earn more from this than the country can earn in taxes. Excise Commissioner General M.G. Gunasiri and other officials attended the event.

title: 4-year-old succumbs to injuries
author: Author not found
Content: The 4-year-old child, who was injured in a shooting at Yakkalamulla, succumbed to injuries yesterday (30), Police said. The victim had been receiving treatment at the Karapitiya Hospital since 19 October. One person was killed and two were injured, following a shooting in Karuwalagala, Yakkalamulla on 19 October, Police said. According to Police, the three persons were shot at by three suspects while they were in their house. The suspects had used an 84mm firearm. The suspects also stole a motorcycle parked in the vicinity. The victims were critically injured and were admitted to the Karapitiya Hospital. The suspects fled the scene. A 34-year-old victim was pronounced dead on admission, while a 30-year-old victim was transferred to the Matara Hospital. The 4-year-old was among the victims. Police said one of the suspects was enlarged on bail by the Elpitiya Magistrate, on charges of aiding and abetting a murder in 2019. Police are conducting further investigations to arrest the suspects. BY Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: Premier expresses regret over lethargy of Fishery officials
author: Author not found
Content: Prime Minister Dinesh Gunawardena expressed regret over Fisheries Ministry officials being lethargic in preventing prohibited elements being used while fishing. Pointing out that measures have been taken to prevent the use of such gear in the seas of the Southern Province, the MP queried from officials as to why there was a delay in preventing such action in other sea areas as well. Ministry officials however said they were working to prevent the means of obtaining explosives and had roped in the Police and Navy to expand raids on those involved in prohibited fishing methods. The Premier advised the Minister of Fisheries to submit a report regarding the use of explosives. He was at a discussion with Fisheries Minister Douglas Devananda at the Prime Minister’s Office. MP Yadamini Gunawardena also highlighted the damage caused to dolphins and blue whales by explosives in the sea around Kalpitiya and Puttalam. Due to this, the marine ecosystem is severely damaged and affects the development of the fishing industry. Many tourists visit Sri Lanka to watch dolphins since they can be seen in the ocean around Sri Lanka, he said. The Prime Minister instructed discussions with the fishermen regarding the harm caused to the ocean system and the country’s economy including the agreements reached in this regard. Devananda said the report will be handed over to the Prime Minister in two months and then submitted to Cabinet. State Minister of Home Affairs Ashoka Priyantha, Secretary of the Fisheries Ministry, InduRathnayake, many senior officials of the Fisheries Department and Nara Institute were present at the discussion.

title: ECT construction must stick to schedule
author: Author not found
Content: Minister of Ports, Shipping and Aviation Nimal Siripala de Silva directed officials of the Sri Lanka Ports Authority (SLPA) to speed up the construction of the East Container Terminal (ECT) of the Port of Colombo, which has been hampered by late payments, and complete the project on time. The Minister gave these instructions following an inspection tour of the ECT. At a meeting where SLPA’s Management officials, Project Engineers, Operation Officials, trade union representatives and staff of several other sectors participated, the Minister urged that suggestions should beused productively. He said the reason for the inspection was to identify delays and the recent slowing down of construction work and resolve them. “I was made aware that delays were due to the dollar crisis in the country which has affected on time payments. I am pleased with the construction already completed and the progress achieved so far amidst these issues. We are taking measures to resolve the matter. I am confident that with such measures, the project could be completed on time. I would instruct the SLPAto expedite the process,” he said. Silva said he will consider proposals brought in by trade unions and expedite the purchase process for the three gantries that have been ordered.  The Minister said the gantries will be set up at the completed section of the terminal and will help to expand operations.  “The terminals are set up in prime locations of the Port.  It is a resource not only to the Sri Lanka Ports Authority but also to the country as a whole. We can generate immense foreign revenue with the correct utilisation of this terminal. A 570m quay bund of the ECT which commenced under the   Colombo Port Expansion Project has already been completed and currently a 440m quay facility is available to handle mega scale container vessels. The terminal has a depth of 18 to 20 metres, enabling easy operation of mega container carriers. The project is scheduled to be completed in January 2025.

title: Canteen, poultry owners reduce prices
author: Author not found
Content: The All-Island Canteen Owners’ Association (AICOA) has decided to reduce the price of a packet of rice and curry and other food items by 10 per cent from today (1). AICOA President Asela Sampath said the price reduction follows the price reduction of several commodities, including flour and chicken. Meanwhile, the All Island Poultry owners’ Association said, the price of a kilo of chicken has been reduced by between Rs 250 and 300. Now a kilo of chicken can be sold at between Rs 1,080 and 1,250. According to the Essential Food Commodity Importers & Traders Association, a kilo of wheat flour has been reduced from Rs 320 to Rs 298. Asela Sampath requested Consumer Affairs Authority to ensure that adequate food stocks are available in the market at concessionary rates and also to make sure to maintain a cup of plain tea to Rs 30. AICOA has been trying their best to provide the benefit of raw product price reductions to the consumers. That is why price of kottu was reduced by Rs 50 following the price reduction of wheat four in the market, Sampath added. By Nabiya Vaffoor

title: FORGED DOCUMENTS RACKET BARED, TWO ARRESTED
author: Author not found
Content: Two persons who prepared and sold forged documents by operating two presses in Ward Place, Colombo 7 were arrested, Police said. The arrests were made by the Central Anti-Corruption Unit in Panadura – Walana on 29 October and the suspects were later handed over to the Borella Police. The suspects were identified as 47-year-old and 64-year-old residents of Colombo 7. Further, the Police seized forged birth certificates, Gramasewa certificates, Open University certificates, student performance indicators, water bills, bank pass books, Ordinary and advanced level result sheets, 73 fake rubber stamps, two driving licences and four computers. Borella Police are conducting further investigations. BY Aloka Kasturiarachchi

Content: Minister of Ports, Shipping and Aviation Nimal Siripala de Silva directed officials of the Sri Lanka Ports Authority (SLPA) to speed up the construction of the East Container Terminal (ECT) of the Port of Colombo, which has been hampered by late payments, and complete the project on time. The Minister gave these instructions following an inspection tour of the ECT. At a meeting where SLPA’s Management officials, Project Engineers, Operation Officials, trade union representatives and staff of several other sectors participated, the Minister urged that suggestions should beused productively. He said the reason for the inspection was to identify delays and the recent slowing down of construction work and resolve them. “I was made aware that delays were due to the dollar crisis in the country which has affected on time payments. I am pleased with the construction already completed and the progress achieved so far amidst these issues. We are taking measures to resolve the matter. I am confident that with such measures, the project could be completed on time. I would instruct the SLPAto expedite the process,” he said. Silva said he will consider proposals brought in by trade unions and expedite the purchase process for the three gantries that have been ordered.  The Minister said the gantries will be set up at the completed section of the terminal and will help to expand operations.  “The terminals are set up in prime locations of the Port.  It is a resource not only to the Sri Lanka Ports Authority but also to the country as a whole. We can generate immense foreign revenue with the correct utilisation of this terminal. A 570m quay bund of the ECT which commenced under the   Colombo Port Expansion Project has already been completed and currently a 440m quay facility is available to handle mega scale container vessels. The terminal has a depth of 18 to 20 metres, enabling easy operation of mega container carriers. The project is scheduled to be completed in January 2025.

title: Aussie ships depart after successful Naval Exercise with SLN
author: Author not found
Content: The two Royal Australian Navy (RAN) ships HMAS Adelaide and HMAS Anzac departed the island on 26 October 2022 after a successful Passage Exercise (PASSEX) conducted with SLNS Sayurala and SLNS Sindurala of the Sri Lanka Navy. The duo of RAN ships arrived at the port of Colombo on 25th October for engagements with the Sri Lanka Navy, as part of Indo-Pacific Endeavour 2022.  On their departure, Sri Lanka Navy bade customary farewell to the RAN ships in compliance with naval traditions, at the Port of Colombo. The exercises conducted between the ships of Royal Australian Navy and Sri Lanka Navy comprised manoeuvring, Replenishment at Sea (RAS), Communication, helicopter landing and steam past off Colombo. Exercises of this nature will enhance mutual cooperation between the two Navies and invariably pave the way for successful conduct of maritime operations with regional partners in future. The Two ships arrived at the Port of Colombo on 25 October 2022. On their arrival, the visiting ships were welcomed by the Sri Lanka Navy in accordance with naval tradition. Indo-Pacific Endeavour (IPE) began in 2017 as an activity coordinated by the Australian Defence Force to strengthen Australia’s engagement and partnerships with regional security forces. Thus, this year’s IPE will return to Southeast and South Asia, consolidating partnerships with 14 countries such as Timor-Leste, Vietnam, the Philippines, Laos, Cambodia, Thailand, Brunei, Malaysia, Singapore, Indonesia, Sri Lanka, Bangladesh, the Maldives and India. Accordingly, two of the Royal Australian Navy ships taking part in IPE arrived in Colombo. Commodore Mal Wise of Royal Australian Navy is the Commander Joint Task Force for Indo-Pacific Endeavour 2022. The visiting ship HMAS Adelaide which is a 230m-long Landing Helicopter Dock (LHD) is commanded by Captain SJ Watters. She also has 08 ship-borne attack helicopters and 543 crew members. Similarly, HMAS Anzac which is a 118m-long Frigate is commanded by Commander DM MCPHERSON. She is manned by a crew of 119 and the ship also possesses a ship-borne attack helicopter. Meanwhile, Commander Joint Task Force for Indo-Pacific Endeavour 2022, Commodore Mal Wise called on Commander of the Navy, Vice Admiral Nishantha Ulugetenne at Navy Headquarters on 25 October. They exchanged views on matters of bilateral importance and mementoes were also exchanged to mark the occasion.

title: Nearly 2.4M applicants for State welfare benefits
author: Author not found
Content: The Welfare Benefits Board said nearly 2.4 million applicants, who had applied for State welfare benefits, are currently registered in the Welfare Benefits Data System. The information of around 70 per cent of the target group has been fed into the system, the remaining 30 per cent of the applications have been filed in the Divisional Secretariat Offices and all the Divisional Secretaries are currently working to feed them into the system as soon as possible. The Welfare Benefits Board stated that the second phase of the programme, which is the information census, to be conducted at the homes of the applicants, is scheduled to commence in November. The programme was implemented on the directives of President Ranil Wickremesinghe under the theme ‘Don’t let anyone be left out’.

title: Qatari Envoy meets HRCSL Chair
author: Author not found
Content: Ambassador of Qatar to Sri Lanka, Jassim bin Jaber J.B. Al-Sorour visited the Human Rights Commission of Sri Lanka (HRCSL) on 26 October and met its Chairperson, Justice Rohini Marasinghe and other officials of the Commission.  The Qatari Ambassador said he was very impressed with the HRCSL’s efforts. He also promised to connect with the Chairperson of the Global Alliance of National Human Rights Institutions (GANHRI) and the Chairperson of the Qatar National Human Rights Commission, Maryam Abdullah Al Attiyah. (SRM)

title: Sapugaskanda shutdown chokes diesel power plants
author: Author not found
Content: Owing to the defunct state of the Sapugaskanda Oil Refinery, several diesel power plants are not functioning at full capacity, complicating the country’s electricity crisis, Ceylon Today learns. According to a top Ceylon Electricity Board (CEB) official, the Kelanitissa Power Station started lowering its output about three weeks ago. He explained that the national grid had lost 165 MW leading to a crisis in the power sector. The CEB official also added that the Kerawalapitiya Yugadanavi Plant have already suspended for want of sufficient diesel and naphtha. By Chamara Amerasuriya

title: Recover funds of Lankans named in Pandora Papers – Sajith
author: Author not found
Content: Opposition Leader Sajith Premadasa said the best solution to resolving the forex crisis is to recover the funds of Sri Lankans cited in the Pandora Papers. Addressing a Samagi Jana Balawegaya (SJB) gathering at Wellawaya yesterday (27), he said obtaining loans from China, India, the United States and the European Union is not a permanent solution for the economic and debt crisis in the country. “The main contributing factor to the medicine shortage is the dollar shortage. Although the country’s stolen assets and resources must be recovered, the current government cannot be trusted on this,” he added. Premadasa added that all funds that have been stolen by those in power will be recovered under a government led by the SJB. “Although the current government said that more dollars are needed, taxes have been imposed on export industries such as the travel industry, information technology, clothing, etc., which earn dollars. This tax policy will discourage the export sector. We do not approve this tax policy. The industries that could bring more dollars to the country should be given relief and encouraged more,” he pointed out. By Nabiya Vaffoor

title: WB provides 60 ambulances for Health Sector
author: Author not found
Content: The Sri Lanka Covid-19 Emergency Response and Health Systems Preparedness Project, funded by the World Bank, provided the Ministry of Health with 60 new ambulances. This was handed over to health institutions on Wednesday (26) at the Ministry of Health premises, with the participation of Minister of Health Keheliya Rambukwella. The cost of an ambulance given to improve the physical resources of the country’s health system is Rs. 24.4 million, and the total cost of ambulances is Rs 1.464 billion. Ambulances were provided by the Minister of Health to 11 hospitals and the Regional Director of Health Services’ offices. The Ministry of Health has provided ambulances to Thalassaemia Care Centre at Rehabilitation Hospital Ragama, Apeksha Hospital Maharagama, Colombo East Base Hospital (CEBH) Mulleriyawa, Colombo North Teaching Hospital Ragama, Kalubowila Hospital, De Soysa Maternity Hospital, National Hospital – Kandy and Colombo, Kegalle, Kandy and Ratnapura Regional Directors of Health Services.

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: BASL wants CC nominations to be unbiased
author: Author not found
Content: The Bar Association of Sri Lanka (BASL) called upon the President, Prime Minister, Speaker of Parliament, Leader of the Opposition, and all political parties represented in Parliament, to ensure the integrity of nominations to the Constitutional Council (CC) and to ensure that such nominations are devoid of partisanship and in a manner that will inspire public confidence. The BASL said that the 21st Amendment to the Constitution does not completely restore the status quo which prevailed prior to the 20th Amendment to the Constitution and does not place adequate checks and balances on the powers of the Executive President. The BASL noted that the necessity to amend the Constitution arose as a result of the public outcry that sprang up throughout the country in response to the present economic crisis, adding that it has been perceived that the causes of the crisis included the lack of checks and balances on the powers of the Executive including the Executive Presidency. ‘’The BASL in its previous statements on the 22nd Amendment Bill highlighted the shortcomings of the Bill and of the danger that the nominations of a majority of members to the Constitutional Council will be controlled by the party or parties in the Government, resulting in it lacking independence and consequently affect the independence and integrity of the offices and institutions to which appointments will be made through the Constitutional Council,’’ the BASL observed.  Nevertheless, now that the 21st amendment is enacted into law, it is essential that the Constitutional Council, which is to be appointed there under and the Independent Commissions, which will be reconstituted thereafter, be independent, impartial and be institutions which will help restore confidence in Sri Lanka and its Institutions, they said. (FT)

title: Appropriation Bill to Parliament on 14 November
author: Author not found
Content: The Appropriation Bill 2023 will be presented to Parliament on 14 November, for the Second Reading. This was decided by the Committee on Parliamentary Business, which met under the chairmanship of Speaker Mahinda Yapa Abeywardena yesterday (27). Accordingly, President Ranil Wickremesinghe as the Minister of Finance, Economic Stabilization and National Policies will deliver the opening speech of the Second Reading of the Appropriation Bill on 14 November at 1.30 p.m. The debate on the Second Reading of the Appropriation Bill will begin on 15 November and the vote on it has been scheduled for November 22 November at 5.00 p.m. The debate on the Committee Stage of the Appropriation Bill will begin on 23 November and the vote will be held on 8 December 8 at 5.00 p.m. Accordingly, Parliament is scheduled to meet on all other days of the week except for Sundays and Poya Days from 14 November to 8 December. The Secretary General of Parliament said that it was decided not to allot time for Questions for Oral Answers on the days of the budget debate. Thus, on 9 December from 9.30 a.m. to 5.30 p.m., 50 questions are set aside for Questions for Oral Answers. The budget debate will be held from 9.30 a.m. to 5.30 p.m. and the time from 5.30 p.m. to 6.00 p.m. is reserved for Questions or motions at the Adjournment Time. The Parliament will convene on 8 November and on that day from 10.30 a.m. to 5.00 a.m., according to the motion brought by the Jathika Jana Balawegaya (JJB), the Motion at the Adjournment Time by the Opposition, regarding the current situation of the country, is scheduled to be held. On 9 November from 10.30 a.m. to 5.00 p.m. Order under the Value Added Tax Act, Two Notifications under the Excise Ordinance, Order under the Finance Act, Regulations under the Foreign Exchange Act are scheduled to be passed. On 10 November from 10.30 a.m. to 5.00 p.m. the Small Claims Courts’ Procedure, Small Claims Courts’ Procedure, Small Claims Courts’ Procedure, Civil Procedure Code (Amendment), Kandyan Marriage and Divorce (Amendment), Poisons, Opium and Dangerous Drugs (Amendment), Code of Criminal Procedure (Amendment), Children and Young Persons (Amendment), Dangerous Animals (Amendment) and Rules under the Prisons Ordinance, Three Regulations under the Fisheries and the Aquatic Resources Act to be presented by the Minister of Justice are scheduled for Second Reading.

title: Tourist arrivals up 50% in 2022 – Akila Viraj
author: Author not found
Content: Tourist arrivals in 2022 have increased by 50 per cent, compared to the first few months of 2021, UNP Deputy Leader Akila Viraj Kariyawasam said. Speaking to the media on Wednesday (26), Kariyawasam said Sri Lanka is in the 12th place among the safe countries to visit and it is good news for the country. “Tourist arrivals remained at a very low level last year. As a result of shortages of gas, electricity, and other burning issues, we were in a precarious position. However, now the country is becoming prosperous, the issues are being resolved gradually, and the economic and living conditions of people are improving,” he said. Kariyawasam said many countries are facing economic crises. “The UK has had three Prime Ministers in two months. Many other countries are going through similar situations,” he added. Speaking further, Kariyawasam said all possible measures have been taken to provide adequate fertiliser stocks to farmers during the upcoming cultivation season. “Gas prices will be further reduced in the first week of November. Many criticised President Ranil Wickremesinghe for shouldering the responsibility while having only one seat in Parliament, but now the President has proved that he can takea timely action to resolve the crises in the country,” he said. By Naalir Jamaldeen

title: Agriculture Dept gets new DG
author: Author not found
Content: Director General of the Department of Agriculture, Dr. Ajantha de Silva, who prevented the entry of tainted organic fertiliser from China, retired and was succeeded by H.M.J. Ilangakoon Menike, who was the Additional Director General of the Department of Agriculture. She assumed duties on 10 October. Dr. de Silva assumed duties on 2 August 2021, when the country was embroiled in a heated debate over fertiliser issues. He vehemently objected the controversial Chinese organic fertiliser ship and refused to grant a permit for its entry. He told Ceylon Today that he was retiring, but hopes to work with an international agricultural institution in the future.   By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: Poaching Indian trawler seized
author: Author not found
Content: Sri Lanka Navy (SLN) and Sri Lanka Coast Guard (SLCG) in a joint operation seized a poaching Indian trawler together with seven Indian fishers off Delft Island on Wednesday (26), SLN said. The seized trawler together with its crew of seven Indian fishers was brought to the Kankesanthurai Harbour, from where they will be handed over to the Myladi Fisheries Inspector for onward legal action.  (PA)

title: Nepal IBS founder donates Rs 100M in medicines
author: Author not found
Content: A consignment of medicine worth over Rs 100 million, donated by the founding President of the International Buddhist Society (IBS) of Nepal, in Lumbini, Ven. Nepalaye Maitri Thera, was officially handed over to Senior Advisor to the President on National Security and President’s Chief of Staff Sagala Ratnayake, at the Presidential Secretariat, yesterday morning (27). The stock of medicines was donated on the request of the International Association of Lions Clubs – District 306C2-Balangoda Lions Club. The consignment of medicines was subsequently handed over to the Balangoda Base Hospital. Health Services Director of Sabaragamuwa Province Dr. Kapila Kannangara, Medical Superintendent Dr. Iresha Pathirage and former President of the International Lions Club 306 C 2 Lion Lasantha Gunawardena, A. P. Jagathchandra, W. K. N. Wijesuriya, Sunil Obeysekera, Lion Saman Kumara Hettiarachchi and several others were present at this occasion.

title: AG pledges to formulate regulations
author: Author not found
Content: The Attorney General yesterday (27) gave the Court of Appeal an undertaking that steps will be taken to promptly formulate regulations prohibiting the use of Mycotoxins that are harmful to the human body in coconut oil and other food items. This was when the Petition filed by Ven. Medille Pangaloka Thera against the importation of coconut oil containing aflatoxin was taken up before the Court of Appeal bench of Justice Sobhitha Rajakaruna and Justice Dhammika Ganepola. Additional Solicitor General Sumathi Dharmawardena informed Court that laws will be formulated to avoid the inclusion of Mycotoxins in the composition of food. Dharmawardena also said as the relief sought by the petitioner has been provided, the proceedings of the case can be terminated, to which the lawyers representing the petitioner informed Court that the decision as to whether the Petition will be withdrawn will be communicated to Court on 15 November. By Faadhila Thassim

title: Ministers, MPs not under Bribery Act – Defence Counsel
author: Author not found
Content: Initial objections were raised before Colombo High Court Judge Navaratne Marasinghe yesterday (26) by lawyers for defendant, former Minister Wimal Weerawansa. This was in connection with the lawsuit filed against the NFF MP by CIABOC where they have charged him with unlawfully accruing a sum in excess of Rs 75 million while functioning as a Minister and thereby flouting Provisions in Sections of the Bribery Act. President’s Counsel Shavendra Fernando, representing the former Minister, told Judge Marasinghe that though charges had been filed against his client by the Bribery Commission, pertaining to the Bribery Act, such charges can only be brought against State workers and not against Cabinet Ministers or MPs. He opined that as his client does not fall under the category of State Officer he urged the Judge to issue an order to invalidate the charges brought against the MP concerned and to dismiss the lawsuit filed by the prosecution. Additional Solicitor General, Ayesha Jinasena sought a fresh date from Court to produce written submissions related to initial objections raised by the defence. Further hearing of the case was then deferred to 28 November. BY Hansi Nanayakkara

title: Justice Ministry initiates mobile service
author: Author not found
Content: A mobile service has been launched, by the Minister of Justice, Prison Affairs, and Constitutional Reforms, to address problems faced by Sri Lankans who left the country, lived as refugees and then eventually came to Sri Lanka in order to resolve their issues. Public officials attached to the institutions such as the Ministry of Defence, the Consular Division of the Ministry of External Affairs, the Resettlement Division of the Ministry of Urban Development and Housing, the Department of Registration of Persons, Department of Immigration and Emigration, the Registrar’s General Department, the Land Commissioner General’s Department and the Provisional Land Commissioner’s Office have been asked to join the programme which is scheduled to be held on 31 October and 1 November 2022. The Justice Ministry said they have received information that nearly 12,500 Sri Lankan refugees, belonging to over 7,000 families, have returned to Sri Lanka from India and are now in the Northern Province service. The Ministry of Justice noted that the mobile services and relief intended to be provided to the Sri Lankan refugees, who returned from India, would be  to resolve issues relating to citizenship, resolving issues encountered in the registration of births, marriages, deaths and obtaining certificates, providing services relating to obtaining and altering National Identity Cards and issuing duplicates for missing Identity Cards, providing relief and resolving issues pertaining to lands and resettlement. On 31 October and 1 November, with the participation of Dr. Wijayadasa Rajapakshe PC, Minister of Justice, Prison Affairs and Constitutional Reforms, Secretary to the Ministry including Heads of Departments and officials of the Departments coming within the purview of the Ministry of Justice and other relevant public institutions the mobile service will be launched. The venue would be the District Secretariat of Jaffna on October 31 from 9.00 a.m. to.4.00 p.m. and on 1 of November, it would be from 9.00 a.m. to.4.00 p.m. at the Skills Development Centre, Kilinochchi. Additionally, the following public institutions, coming within the purview of the Ministry of Justice such as the Prison Affairs and Constitutional Reforms, Office of Reparation Matters pertaining to payment of compensation to those who have disadvantage by war and other disasters and filling in of necessary documentations, Office of Missing Persons, matters pertaining to complaints of received from families of missing persons and inquiries into their disappearance and the Mediation Boards Commission Raising awareness regarding Special Mediation Boards relating to lands will also be present. By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: Scrap present Constitution – Vitarana
author: Author not found
Content: Mmbers of the  Lanka Sama Samaja Party (LSSP) were absent during the vote in Parliament for the 22nd Amendment to the Constitution as they had to attend a meeting regarding the N. M. Perera building. “We do not support this or any amendments to the Constitution that introduced the Executive Presidency. Even in this amendment, they are attempting to reduce the executive power of the President and give it to the Prime Minister. The LSSP demands that the Government scrap the entire Constitution and replace it rather than amending it the whole time,” Tissa Vitarana said. Addressing the media, LSSP General Secretary MP Prof. Tissa Vitarana said he has been unfairly attacked by some media outlets for not voting in Parliament on the 22nd Amendment on 21 October. “I participated in all the debates and discussions that were held in Parliament regarding the 22nd Amendment and I even spoke to many parliamentarians, and I believed that many ruling party and opposition party parliamentarians would vote in favour of the 22nd Amendment. As a result, I attended the N.M. Perera Centre meeting that was held on the same day to discuss the  future of the building. We decided to sell half of the N.M. Perera Centre land and use the proceeds to renovate the N.M. Perera Centre,” he added. Vitarana added that he did not see the point in voting when the LSSP has been vocal in its opposition to the Constitution since its inception. Vitarana also noted that the LSSP believes that the 10 MPs in Parliament who have dual citizenship should resign immediately. He stated that they could not work for both countries objectively. Vitarana also discussed many major issues confronting the country, such as inflation and a lack of medicine. BY Nabiya Vaffoor

title: Ex-soldier detained for questioning over drugs
author: Author not found
Content: Based on information revealed by a suspect who was arrested while in possession of over 6 grams of heroin, a live grenade, made in a foreign country and locally manufactured flintlock-type firearm, were found hidden near the Sedawatta Kelani Bridge. Police stated that the suspect was arrested on 21 October by the Colombo Crimes Division.  The suspect is a 31-year-old resident of Sedawatta, Wellampitiya. The Police said that he was produced before the Maligakanda Magistrate’s Court and was detained for seven days for questioning. Further investigations revealed that the suspect is a former army personnel and he is involved in large-scale drug trafficking and organised crime. He is allegedly involved in collecting money linked to the drug network of an organised criminal who is currently abroad, Police said. Investigations revealed that he had travelled to Dubai in March 2022 and returned to the island on 11 October using a fake passport. The Colombo Crime Division is conducting further investigations into the incident. BY Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: India votes to reject Russia’s demand for secret ballot on Ukraine
author: Author not found
Content: India voted to reject Russia’s demand for a secret ballot in the UN General Assembly on a draft resolution to condemn Moscow’s “illegal” annexation of four regions of Ukraine, with New Delhi favouring a public vote on the text along with over 100 other nations. The 193-member UN General Assembly on Monday voted on a motion by Albania that action on the draft resolution that would condemn Russia’s “illegal so-called referendums” and “attempted illegal annexation” of the Donetsk, Kherson, Luhansk, and Zaporizhzhia regions of Ukraine be taken by a recorded vote. Russia had demanded that the resolution be voted upon by secret ballot. Moscow’s demand for a secret ballot was rejected after 107 UN member states, including India, voted in favour of a recorded vote. Only 13 nations voted in favour of Russia’s call for a secret ballot while 39 abstained. Russia and China were among the countries that did not vote. After the motion to hold a recorded vote was adopted, Russia appealed against the ruling of the President of the General Assembly. A recorded vote on Russia’s appeal was held and India was among the 100 nations who voted against the challenge made by Moscow. Russia then sought reconsideration of the decision to adopt the motion submitted by Albania for a recorded vote. The General Assembly decided not to reconsider the motion after 104 nations, including India, voted against such a reconsideration, while 16 voted in favour and 34 abstained. Russia’s Permanent Representative Vassily Nebenzia said the UN membership had “become witnesses to an outrageous fraud in which the President of the General Assembly, unfortunately, played a key role.” “We were not given the floor to make a point of order (the indicator light at our seat is still on), our statement was distorted, and now UN Member States are being robbed of their right to express their opinion freely. “This is an unprecedented manipulation undermining the authority of the General Assembly and the United Nations as a whole. Of course, in such circumstances we opted to not take part in the vote,” he said. India last month had abstained while Russia vetoed a draft UN Security Council resolution tabled by the US and Albania to condemn Moscow’s “illegal referenda” and declared the annexation of four Ukrainian territories as invalid. The 15-nation UN Security Council had voted on the draft resolution on “Illegal So-Called Referenda in Ukraine,” hours after Russian President Vladimir Putin in a ceremony in the Kremlin had signed treaties to annex the Ukrainian regions of Luhansk, Donetsk, Kherson, and Zaporizhzhia. The resolution failed to get adopted as permanent UNSC member Russia vetoed it. Of the 15-nation council, 10 nations voted for the resolution and China, Gabon, India, as well as Brazil abstained. Following Russia’s veto, US Ambassador to the UN Linda Thomas-Greenfield vowed to continue to pursue accountability at the United Nations in the General Assembly, where every country has a vote. UN General Assembly President Csaba Korosi reconvened the emergency special session on Ukraine where a senior US Administration official had said the European Union, on behalf of a cross-regional drafting group of several dozen UN member states, was working on a resolution to be introduced in the assembly and considered at the emergency special session to condemn Russia’s actions as a clear violation of the UN Charter and the principles of sovereignty and territorial integrity. The draft resolution would repeat the demand that Russia withdraw its forces from Ukraine and from the war-torn country’s internationally recognised borders and cease its unprovoked war of aggression against Ukraine. The resolution would also call upon all states, international organisations, and United Nations specialised agencies not to recognise any alteration by Russia of the status of any or all of the Donetsk, Kherson, Luhansk or Zaporizhzhia regions of Ukraine, and to refrain from any action or dealing that might be interpreted as recognising any such altered status. The action in the UNGA came hours after Russia carried out strikes against multiple Ukrainian cities, including Kyiv where at least 10 people were killed and around 60 others wounded across Ukraine. In New Delhi, External Affairs Ministry Spokesperson Arindam Bagchi said the escalation of hostilities was in no one’s interest and noted that India stood ready to support all such efforts aimed at de-escalation of the situation. “India is deeply concerned at the escalation of the conflict in Ukraine, including the targeting of infrastructure and deaths of civilians,” he said, urging the immediate cessation of hostilities. India has not yet condemned the Russian invasion of Ukraine and maintained that the crisis must be resolved through diplomacy and dialogue. India has abstained on votes on the Ukraine conflict in the UN General Assembly and the Security Council. (Hindustan Times)

title: FM should negotiate refund with Chinese company – Agri Min
author: Author not found
Content: The Ministry of Agriculture said the USD 6.9 million paid for the organic fertiliser shipment from the Chinese company Qingdao Seawin Biotech Group Co. is a matter for the Foreign Ministry to resolve, and neither the Department of Agriculture nor the Ministry of Agriculture could intervene. Additional Secretary of the Ministry of Agriculture Mahesh Gammanpila, stated that they had negotiated with the Chinese company to provide liquid organic fertiliser to replace the shipment contaminated with Erwinia bacteria which was rejected by the Department of Agriculture’s National Plant Quarantine Service (NPQS) last year. However, the Chinese company rejected that decision. The granular organic fertiliser was not allowed to enter the country and was returned to China, which triggered controversies and a diplomatic dispute between Sri Lanka and the Chinese Embassy in Colombo. The Chinese mission stated that the NPQS final decision was a fabricated and refused to accept the returned shipment. The USD 6.9 million payment remains with the Chinese company, which even sued the NPQS in November for USD 8 million. The Chinese company demanded USD 8 million, claiming that the samples had been cleared before export and that the Sri Lankan authorities have read wrong test results. It is uncertain whether the Chinese would agree to refund USD 6.9 million paid for the rejected cargo of 90,000 MT of organic fertiliser, out of which 20,000 MT was sent back. By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: Foreign loans vital for governments to function – Bandula
author: Author not found
Content: While emphasising that every government that has come to power since Independence has taken foreign loans, Cabinet Spokesman Bandula Gunawardena said “No Government can function without foreign loans”. He said the main problem at the moment is the debt restructuring process, and that the Government is making special efforts and prioritising the process. Addressing the Cabinet media briefing yesterday, he said if the country is labelled as bankrupt, there will be no possibility to purchase gas, fuel, or machinery.  “The main issue that the country is currently dealing with is foreign debt payments. Every government since Independence has obtained foreign loans. It is difficult for a government to function without the assistance of foreign lenders. Our debt is being restructured, and the Central Bank of Sri Lanka, the Ministry of Finance, and other officials are working hard to achieve it,” he said. BY Thameenah Razeek

title: Don’t delay LG polls
author: Author not found
Content: People’s Action for Free and Fair Elections (PAFFREL) wrote to Prime Minister Dinesh Gunawardena yesterday (27) over the proposed amendments to the Local Authorities Elections Act. PAFFREL Executive Director Rohana Hettiarachchi requested Premier Gunawardena not to delay the conduct of Local Authorities Elections. “The Prime Minister led a Parliamentary Select Committee on Electoral Reforms which deliberated on a number of issues and tabled recommendations,” Hettiarachchi said, while emphasising that he also presented documents to the Committee to amend the electoral system. Hettiarachchi said the report of the committee was tabled only recently and now proposals have been made to appoint another committee. “This will undermine the Parliamentary Select Committee which was headed by the Prime Minister. We do not oppose the move to amend the electoral system or the decision to reduce the number of councilors in local government bodies. Yet, further delaying elections under the pretext of reforms is unacceptable,” he said in his letter. By Nabiya Vaffoor

title: Eng Ismail awarded IESL Life Membership
author: Author not found
Content: Engineer Jahfar Mohamed Ismail was awarded Honorary Life Fellow Membership of The Institution of Engineers, Sri Lanka (IESL) during the 116th Annual Session of IESL held at BMICH recently.  Chief Guest, Senior Professor Malik Ranasinghe, Chairman of the Information and Communication Technology Agency of Sri Lanka (ICTA) and Former Vice Chancellor, University of Moratuwa (third from right) are seen awarding the Honorary Life Fellow Membership Certificate to Engineer Ismail (left). The past and present Presidents of the institute were also present. (Pic by M.A.P. Deen – Ampara)

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Ex-soldier detained for questioning over drugs
author: Author not found
Content: Based on information revealed by a suspect who was arrested while in possession of over 6 grams of heroin, a live grenade, made in a foreign country and locally manufactured flintlock-type firearm, were found hidden near the Sedawatta Kelani Bridge. Police stated that the suspect was arrested on 21 October by the Colombo Crimes Division.  The suspect is a 31-year-old resident of Sedawatta, Wellampitiya. The Police said that he was produced before the Maligakanda Magistrate’s Court and was detained for seven days for questioning. Further investigations revealed that the suspect is a former army personnel and he is involved in large-scale drug trafficking and organised crime. He is allegedly involved in collecting money linked to the drug network of an organised criminal who is currently abroad, Police said. Investigations revealed that he had travelled to Dubai in March 2022 and returned to the island on 11 October using a fake passport. The Colombo Crime Division is conducting further investigations into the incident. BY Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: Scrap present Constitution – Vitarana
author: Author not found
Content: Mmbers of the  Lanka Sama Samaja Party (LSSP) were absent during the vote in Parliament for the 22nd Amendment to the Constitution as they had to attend a meeting regarding the N. M. Perera building. “We do not support this or any amendments to the Constitution that introduced the Executive Presidency. Even in this amendment, they are attempting to reduce the executive power of the President and give it to the Prime Minister. The LSSP demands that the Government scrap the entire Constitution and replace it rather than amending it the whole time,” Tissa Vitarana said. Addressing the media, LSSP General Secretary MP Prof. Tissa Vitarana said he has been unfairly attacked by some media outlets for not voting in Parliament on the 22nd Amendment on 21 October. “I participated in all the debates and discussions that were held in Parliament regarding the 22nd Amendment and I even spoke to many parliamentarians, and I believed that many ruling party and opposition party parliamentarians would vote in favour of the 22nd Amendment. As a result, I attended the N.M. Perera Centre meeting that was held on the same day to discuss the  future of the building. We decided to sell half of the N.M. Perera Centre land and use the proceeds to renovate the N.M. Perera Centre,” he added. Vitarana added that he did not see the point in voting when the LSSP has been vocal in its opposition to the Constitution since its inception. Vitarana also noted that the LSSP believes that the 10 MPs in Parliament who have dual citizenship should resign immediately. He stated that they could not work for both countries objectively. Vitarana also discussed many major issues confronting the country, such as inflation and a lack of medicine. BY Nabiya Vaffoor

title: SUMANTHIRAN COMES IN FOR SEVERE FLAK
author: Author not found
Content: Justice Minister Dr. Wijeyadasa Rajapakshe has requested Speaker Mahinda Yapa Abeywardena to appoint a Special Parliamentary Select Committee to probe the statement made by Illankai Tamil Arasu Katchi (ITAK) MP M.A. Sumanthiran regarding the Supreme Court during the debate on the 22nd Amendment Bill on 20 October. In a letter to the Speaker, Rajapakshe said, “During the speech, Sumanthiran said the determination of Supreme Court on the Amendment Bill was not according to the Law. He also said the Supreme Court changes its stance from time to time and therefore, it should be ‘sent home.’ This is indirectly saying that the determinations and the judgements of the Supreme Court should not be trusted and the existence of the Supreme Court was also unnecessary,” Rajapakshe said. Rajapakshe said the Select Committee should present its report to the House in three months after the first meeting. The Minister said, according to Standing Orders, without a proper proposal, one should not criticise the Courts or Judges. “This MP has tried to create a dispute between the Court and Parliament. He should not have made such a statement. Due to this, the trust of the people on the Judiciary has been damaged. Sumanthiran is a President’s Counsel and as such, he is setting a wrong precedent for society. He used MPs’ privileges as a shield. Due to such statements, people could begin to dislike all MPs, therefore, it could be considered as a violation of privileges of the other MPs,” he said. Therefore, I request the Speaker to appoint a Special Parliament Select Committee to probe the statement in question and to provide recommendations on the matter. The Justice Minister said, members and the chairpersons of the select committee should be appointed by the Speaker and the number of members should not exceed 21 as per Standing Order 101. The select committee should have the power to decide the quorum. It should also have the power to summon persons according to its opinions to obtain written and oral testimonies. The select committee should have the power to obtain service of the experts on the subject and it should have the power to present reports and continue the meetings despite prorogation or adjournment of the House, he added.

title: Siridhamma Thera down with dengue
author: Author not found
Content: Convener of the Inter-University Bhikku Federation (IUBF), Ven. Galwewa Siridhamma Thera who was hospitalised due to fever, had contracted dengue. Siridhamma Thera who was detained on a 90-day detention order in Tangalle was admitted to the Colombo National Hospital with fever on 25 October. Ven. Galwewa Siridhamma Thera, Wasantha Mudalige, and Hashantha Jeevantha Gunathilake were arrested on 18 August following a protest march in Colombo. The protest had been organised by IUSF against the current government led by President Ranil Wickremesinghe. They were detained for 90 days under the Prevention of Terrorism Act and Hashan Jeevantha was released after 50 days. BY Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: 435 murders reported in 2022 – Bandula
author: Author not found
Content: Cabinet Spokesman Bandula Gunawardena said 435 murders were reported in 2022. He said 521 murders were reported in Sri Lanka in 2021. In the weekly Cabinet briefing yesterday (26), Gunawardena said this is a large number of lives, and that the Government believes that every citizen should be entitled to a dignified death. Meanwhile, a committee headed by Prof. Ravindra Fernando was appointed to make recommendations for amendments to the existing laws, procedures, and practices regarding the conduct of post-mortems. The need for amending the Code of Criminal Procedure Act has been identified to provide for the application of the recommendations of the said committee. Cabinet approved the proposal to amend the Code of Criminal Procedure Act, presented by the Minister of Justice, Prison Affairs and Constitutional Reforms. By Thameenah Razeek

title: 21A promotes ‘tribalism’
author: Author not found
Content: Sri Lanka Podujana Peramuna (SLPP) General Secretary, Sagara Kariyawasam said he was absent in the House during the vote on the 22nd Amendment (now 21A), as certain provisions of the amendment promote tribalism and he is not in favour of the country moving backwards. He added that in a backdrop where countries are moving forward towards a global village, certain people in Sri Lanka are attempting to make Sri Lanka move backwards, adding that for example, the provision in the 22nd Amendment that seeks to exclude dual citizens from contesting in elections is a move towards tribalism. Kariyawasam said, when Rishi Sunak was appointed as the Prime Minister of UK, his nationality or religion was not taken into consideration, adding that Sri Lanka should learn from this example. Speaking further on the strength of the SLPP, Kariyawasam said, although certain party heads have changed, the party is strong and ready for any election. By Faadhila Thassim
