title: Bad roads lead to more accidents
author: Author not found
Content: The Malliappuwa rail gate-keeper on the Hatton-Nuwara Eliya main road said due to the dilapidated condition of the road, motorcycles and three-wheelers were involved in accidents on a daily basis. He said that due to the road caving in during heavy rains, it becomes quite slippery leading to vehicles facing mishaps on that stretch of road. The gate-keeper said several requests made to officials at the Norwood RDA Office to make the stretch of road. Upto now the requests have not been heeded. BY Neeta Pathma Kumari – Norwood

title: Ayurveda Day commemorated
author: Author not found
Content: To commemorate Ayurveda Day, Swami Vivekananda Cultural Centre organised an exhibition on the theme ‘Ayurveda Every day, Ayurveda Everywhere’ for the Sri Lanka Police Force on 22 October, 2022. The objective of the exhibition was to spread awareness about Ayurveda for better health and living. Acting High Commissioner of India to Sri Lanka, Shri Vinod K. Jacob was the Chief Guest at the exhibition. Conveying his greetings on Dhanteras and Deepavali, he highlighted the significance of Ayurveda as a holistic system of medicine, which promotes harmony of the body and the environment. SSP Athula Amarasinghe, Deputy Director of National Police Academy of Sri Lanka, was the Guest of Honour. Dr. Pathirage Kamal Perera, Professor in Ayurveda Medicine and Consultant Physician, Institute of Indigenous Medicine, University of Colombo, attended the event as the subject matter expert. Noting the role of diet, herbs, and spices in Ayurvedic treatment, he highlighted that the western medicinal science, including the WHO, is increasingly taking interest in Ayurveda to promote a holistic lifestyle. Distinguished Ayurveda experts,  Ruvi Rodrigio and Dr. Amila Wickramasinghe explained the various exhibits that were displayed during the exhibition. About 50 participants from the Sri Lanka Police force attended the exhibition. Ayurveda Day is celebrated every year on Dhanvantari Jayanti (Dhanteras), to commemorate the birth anniversary of Lord Dhanvantari, who is referred to as the ‘God of Ayurveda’ in Sushruta Samhita, an ancient Sanskrit text on medicine   and surgery. Dhanvantari Jayanti is also first of the five days celebration of Deepavali, the festival of light.  The Ministry of Ayurveda, Yoga, Naturopathy, Unani, Siddha, Sowa-Rigpa and Homoeopathy (AYUSH) of the Government of India and the Sri Lankan Ministry of Health, Nutrition and Indigenous Medicine have undertaken a number of initiatives for promotion of indigenous alternative medicine systems. After the outbreak of the Covid-19 pandemic, both the Ministries released guidelines that promote good health and hygiene as well as boost immunity to help combat the Corona virus.

title: Suspects released on two surety bails of Rs 500,000 each
author: Author not found
Content: Nine suspects involved in misbehaving inside the Yala National Park during the weekend were granted bail by the Tissamaharama Magistrate yesterday (26). The Tissamarahama Police arrested the nine suspects and impounded seven vehicles on October 25 evening. The suspects were released on two surety bails of Rs 500, 000 each. The next Court hearing is set for 9 December 2022. At the outset it was stated that on President Ranil Wickremesinghe’s instructions  to conduct an investigation into the Yala incident yesterday (26). Meanwhile, Secretary to the Ministry of Wildlife and Forest Resources Conservation, Chandra Herath has decided to appoint a three-member committee to conduct investigations in relation to the negligence of officials in the incident. According to Herath, investigations will be on the neglect of duty by these officials who assisted offenders to enter the park and misbehave being a disturbance to wildlife therein, the failure on the part of these officials to prevent the incident and inform higher officials of the incident.  He said, the committee will be appointed with the consultation of the Minister of Wildlife and Forest Resources Conservation, Mahinda Amaraweera. The Additional Secretary to the Ministry will be appointed as Chairman of the Committee. Previously, on the instructions of Amaraweera the said officials were interdicted until investigations are completed. Further, Herath sent a letter to the IGP yesterday (26), seeking the cooperation of the Sri Lanka Police to arrest those involved in the incident regardless of their status. In a video that was circulated on social media, a group of locals, who entered the Yala National Park on 23 October, were seen honking and sitting on the doors of vehicles, all of which are prohibited within the park. Amaraweera instructed the Director General of Wildlife, Chandana Sooriyabandara to conduct investigations into the incident and to initiate legal action. Meanwhile, Cabinet spokesman Bandula Gunawardena addressing the Cabinet said,  President Wickremesinghe had instructed to carry out an impartial investigation into the incident.   Yala Park Publicity Manager Hashini Sarathchandra told Ceylon Today, a final report on the tour guides who accompanied the 35 vehicles that ventured into the Park is being completed by the Yala Park, Uva Region Assistance Director of wildlife department, but no one has been suspended from their responsibilities as of yet. The Warden of Yala National Park Manoj Widyaratne filed the complaint over the safari riders’ bad behaviour as they were ruining the wildlife park and harming the wildlife habitat. According to information, several of those who entered the park in 35 vehicles had been walking inside the park, which is against park rules. Honking of horns and racing within the park was forbidden. The Yala Publicity Manager stated that they were not aware of the backgrounds of those arrested, but it is speculated that they had political clout and so acted the way they did. She also stated that, as previously reported, no Yala Park personnel or tour guide has been suspended as those involved were volunteer tour guides and one of them was a  tour guide, however, they stated that they did not follow park officials instructions and that several cars entered the park despite their warnings. title: Xi’s ‘Lovable’ China moving further out of reach
author: Author not found
Content: To commemorate Ayurveda Day, Swami Vivekananda Cultural Centre organised an exhibition on the theme ‘Ayurveda Every day, Ayurveda Everywhere’ for the Sri Lanka Police Force on 22 October, 2022. The objective of the exhibition was to spread awareness about Ayurveda for better health and living. Acting High Commissioner of India to Sri Lanka, Shri Vinod K. Jacob was the Chief Guest at the exhibition. Conveying his greetings on Dhanteras and Deepavali, he highlighted the significance of Ayurveda as a holistic system of medicine, which promotes harmony of the body and the environment. SSP Athula Amarasinghe, Deputy Director of National Police Academy of Sri Lanka, was the Guest of Honour. Dr. Pathirage Kamal Perera, Professor in Ayurveda Medicine and Consultant Physician, Institute of Indigenous Medicine, University of Colombo, attended the event as the subject matter expert. Noting the role of diet, herbs, and spices in Ayurvedic treatment, he highlighted that the western medicinal science, including the WHO, is increasingly taking interest in Ayurveda to promote a holistic lifestyle. Distinguished Ayurveda experts,  Ruvi Rodrigio and Dr. Amila Wickramasinghe explained the various exhibits that were displayed during the exhibition. About 50 participants from the Sri Lanka Police force attended the exhibition. Ayurveda Day is celebrated every year on Dhanvantari Jayanti (Dhanteras), to commemorate the birth anniversary of Lord Dhanvantari, who is referred to as the ‘God of Ayurveda’ in Sushruta Samhita, an ancient Sanskrit text on medicine   and surgery. After the outbreak of the Covid-19 pandemic, both the Ministries released guidelines that promote good health and hygiene as well as boost immunity to help combat the Corona virus.

title: Dual citizenship issue must be dealt with in Court
author: Author not found
Content: The matter of dual citizen MPs must be addressed by a Court of law, Cabinet Spokesman Bandula Gunawardena said yesterday (26). According to the 21st Amendment, he said it is impossible for dual citizens to be MPs and action must be taken through Court to resolve the issue. Fielding a question from the media, Gunawardena said, the Government does not have the authority to investigate and deal with the matter.  “It is said that there is a possibility of taking judicial action against dual citizenship holders in Parliament, and that the problem should be resolved by Court. We do not have a system in place to determine who is a dual citizen or not. Dual citizens are not permitted to serve in Parliament, according to the new Amendment. The Government cannot intervene in this,” he said. BY Thameenah Razeek

title: PSC discusses proposed Gender Equality Bill
author: Author not found
Content: The Parliamentary Select Committee (PSC) to look into and report to Parliament its recommendations to ensure gender equity and equality held discussions regarding the progress of drafting the proposed Bill titled ‘Gender Equality and Women’s Empowerment’ recently. This was followed by a presentation to review findings on the implementation of the multi sectoral National Action Plan to address Sexual and Gender-Based Violence (SGBV) 2016-2020. The meeting was chaired by Dr.Sudarshani Fernandopulle. PSC members agreed to send the draft of all recommendations to the expert committee assigned for the purpose, within two weeks. The PSC also acknowledged the progress of the implementation of the multi sectoral National Action Plan to address Sexual and Gender-Based Violence (SGBV) 2016- 2020 and directed and requested the Ministry of Women and Child Affairs to incorporate contextualised initiatives to the new plan. Opposition Leader Sajith Premadasa, State Ministers Geetha Kumarasinghe, Diana Gamage, Piyal Nishantha De Silva and MPs Chandima Weerakkody and Eran Wickramaratne, Chief of Staff and Deputy Secretary General of the Parliament Kushani Rohanadeera, officials and representatives representing relevant stakeholders were present at the meeting.

title: Continued incarceration of IUSF Convener unjustified
author: Author not found
Content: The Human Rights Commission of Sri Lanka (HRCSL) recommended refraining from extending the detention order issued against Convener of the Inter University Students’ Federation (IUSF), Wasantha Mudalige, and Convener of the Inter University Bhikku Federation (IUBF), Ven. Galwewa Siridhamma Thera, adding that any further Police investigations can be conducted without continued detention. The HRCSL reiterated that the arrest, detention, and continued incarceration of Mudalige and Ven. Siridhamma Thera under the Prevention of Terrorism Act (PTA) is unreasonable and unjustified. “A Director and Deputy Director of the HRCSL visited the said individuals to ascertain their well-being and Ven. Siridhamma Thera was found to be in poor health, and on 25 October, his condition was so serious that he had to be hospitalised,” HRCSL said. They added that under Section 9(l) of the PTA, where the Minister has reason to believe or suspect that any person is connected with or concerned in any unlawful activity, the Minister may order that such person be detained for a period not exceeding three months in the first instance, in such place and subject to such conditions as may be determined by the Minister. Any such order may be extended from time to time for a period not exceeding three months at a time, provided that the aggregate period of detention does not exceed twelve months. The HRCSL deems the investigations conducted into the “unlawful activity” purported to have been done by these detainees under the PTA to be unreasonable, unfair, vexatious, and wholly without justification, and asserts that the detainees in question can be prosecuted under general law. The HRCSL said, the detainees informed the Director and Deputy Director of the HRCSL who visited them that they have only been interrogated on a few occasions during the period of detention regarding their involvement in the recent civil unrest in the country. While stating that the HRCSL is yet to receive a progress report of the status of the investigation from the Terrorist Investigation Division (TID), they said, the treatment and harassment of the said detainees are made all the more unacceptable by the fact that it is a deterrent to the public at large to exercise their freedom of expression and peaceful assembly enshrined in the Constitution. (FT)

title: Third arrest made
author: Author not found
Content: Mt. Lavinia Divisional Criminal Investigation unit arrested a suspect who aided and abetted in the Rs 2 million robbery in Moratuwa.  The suspect is a 63-year-old resident of Moratuwa. Police said, a motorcycle used for the robbery and Rs 100,000 in cash were found in his possession. The robbery took place when an employee of a store in Moratuwa was taking over Rs 2 million from the store to be deposited in a Bank. According to a complaint made to the Moratuwa police the employee who went to deposit the money was waylaid, beaten and injured and the money was stolen. The Mt. Divisional Criminal Investigation unit conducted investigations and got on the trail of the suspect. Meanwhile, on 22 October, two suspects connected to the incident were arrested in Ratmalana. They are 45 and 50-year-old residents of Ratmalana and Mt. Lavinia. Police said, the two suspects were arrested along with a rented van used for the robbery, a motorcycle, a three-wheeler and a sharp weapon. Mt. Lavinia Criminal Investigation unit is conducting further investigations into the incident. BY Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: ACTWU slams high handed act of private bus operators
author: Author not found
Content: The All Ceylon Transport Workers’ Union(ACTWU) urged the Minister of Transport to put an end to private bus owners and employees harassing Sri Lanka Transport Board (SLTB ) employees attached to SLTB buses. In a letter addressed to Minister of Transport, Bandula Gunawardena, General Secretary of the union, Sepala Gamage referred to the incident where a conductor of bus number WP-8647 was brutally assaulted on October 2022. “The attack was carried out by employees of a travel group owned by a high profile politician. The conductor is currently receiving treatment at the Ratnapura Hospital as a result of the attack. Ratnapura Police has not initiated a formal investigation into the incident. Employees of the Ratnapura depot are engaged in trade union action, demanding that a formal investigation be conducted and the thugs be arrested,” the letter said. He condemned the assault by ‘private bus thugs’ and added that private buses  exist solely for profit. “We request the Minister to intervene in this matter and expedite the arrest of employees of the travel group that carried out this assault and is owned by a prominent politician who is in the Government. If action is not initiated and the culprits are not brought to book, SLTB employees will take to trade union action,” he said. (TR)

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Suspects released on two surety bails of Rs 500,000 each
author: Author not found
Content: Nine suspects involved in misbehaving inside the Yala National Park during the weekend were granted bail by the Tissamaharama Magistrate yesterday (26). The Tissamarahama Police arrested the nine suspects and impounded seven vehicles on October 25 evening. The suspects were released on two surety bails of Rs 500, 000 each. The next Court hearing is set for 9 December 2022. At the outset it was stated that on President Ranil Wickremesinghe’s instructions  to conduct an investigation into the Yala incident yesterday (26). Meanwhile, Secretary to the Ministry of Wildlife and Forest Resources Conservation, Chandra Herath has decided to appoint a three-member committee to conduct investigations in relation to the negligence of officials in the incident. According to Herath, investigations will be on the neglect of duty by these officials who assisted offenders to enter the park and misbehave being a disturbance to wildlife therein, the failure on the part of these officials to prevent the incident and inform higher officials of the incident.  He said, the committee will be appointed with the consultation of the Minister of Wildlife and Forest Resources Conservation, Mahinda Amaraweera. The Additional Secretary to the Ministry will be appointed as Chairman of the Committee. Previously, on the instructions of Amaraweera the said officials were interdicted until investigations are completed. Further, Herath sent a letter to the IGP yesterday (26), seeking the cooperation of the Sri Lanka Police to arrest those involved in the incident regardless of their status. She also stated that, as previously reported, no Yala Park personnel or tour guide has been suspended as those involved were volunteer tour guides and one of them was a  tour guide, however, they stated that they did not follow park officials instructions and that several cars entered the park despite their warnings. title: Govt must provide medical services24/7- CP Governor
author: Author not found
Content: Governor of the Central Province Lalith U. Gamage said it is the duty of the Government to further enhance the country’s medical services to cater to the public 24/7. He said, people who do not have any kind of relief either emotionally or physically in the current circumstances naturally become victims of various illnesses. The Governor also said people continue to survive whilst facing severe economic burdens. He was speaking at an event to inaugurate the  Cooperative Hospital chain in the Central Province on 25 October. Gamage said it is the duty of all politicians to set aside petty political differences and unite to alleviate the suffering of the public. BY K. K. Ariyadasa – Dambulla

title: Travel ban extended on Cabraal till 24 November
author: Author not found
Content: Colombo Additional Magistrate, Harshana Kekunawela yesterday (26) ordered to further extend the overseas travel ban imposed on former Governor of the CBSL Ajith Nivard Cabraal till 24 November. The Magistrate also ordered Cabraal to be enlarged on two surety bails of Rs 1 million each. This was after he appeared in Court, in connection with the lawsuit filed against him, where he has been charged with committing a Treasury Bonds scam, amounting to US$ 500 million. The former CBSL Governor was present in Court, when the case was called, after being noticed at the previous hearing. A private plaint has been filed via an affidavit against Cabraal, by former Governor of the Southern Province and a resident of Rajagiriya, Rajith Keerthi Tennakoon, pertaining to the aforesaid charge. According to the private plaint filed by Tennakoon, the former CBSL Governor, has been charged with flouting Provisions contained in Sections 388, 392 and 386 of the Penal Code, as well as Provisions contained in Section 56 (1) of the Registered Stock and Securities Ordinance No. 7 of 1937, via his actions. By Hansi Nanayakkara

title: Jaffna trade stall sealed
author: Author not found
Content: Officers of the Jaffna PHI Office sealed a trade stall in Jaffna on 25 October which had stored 6,000 kg of spoiled tamarind. The stock of tamarind was unfit for human consumption. They added that they had raided the trade stall at Jumma Mosque Road in Jaffna based on a tip-off. The officers also said legal action will be instituted against the owner of the trade stall. By Sashi Kumar – Mullaitivu

title: CA terminates FFSL term, overturns Sports Gazette notice
author: Author not found
Content: The proceedings of the case filed challenging the decision taken by the Ministry of Sports to reverse the Gazette issued extending the term of Federation of Sri Lanka (FFSL) were terminated by the Court of Appeal yesterday (26). This was when the Writ Application filed by Jaswar Omar Lebbe and Upali Hewage was taken before Court of Appeal Judges Sobhitha Rajakaruna and Dhammika Ganepola. The decision was taken on the basis that all parties agreed to terminate the case in view of the undertaking given by the Director-General of Sports, Amal Edirisooriya on 20 October before the Court of Appeal that the election of the FFSL will be held within 69 days. Additional Solicitor General Sumathi Dharmawardena, PC, appearing on behalf of Edirisooriya and the sports authorities, during the previous sitting, also informed Courts that a Selection Committee would be appointed within 14 days from 20 October, following which nominations will be called for the election of FFSL. Based on arguments put forward by intervening petitioners, the Additional Solicitor General further informed Court that those who would be a part of the said Selection Committee could not contest the election. Further, the Attorney General gave an undertaking yesterday (26), that the outstanding salaries of employees of the Federation will be paid. BY Faadhila Thassim

title: Jaffna fishermen demand increase in kerosene quota
author: Author not found
Content: A group of fishermen from the Jaffna District took part in a protest on 24 October demanding the immediate increase in the kerosene quota provided to them. These  fishermen charged that due to the inadequate nature of the monthly kerosene quota that is provided to them they are facing numerous hardships when engaging in their trade. They also warned that if the Government fails to increase the monthly kerosene quota that is offered to them the fishing industry in the Peninsula could face a severe crisis situation sooner than later. The protest was held at the Kakativu Jetty in Jaffna. BY Sashi Kumar – Mullaitivu

title: Pharmacy owners call for ‘Expire Policy’
author: Author not found
Content: The All Island Private Pharmacy Owners Association (AIPPOA) urged the Government to introduce an “Expire Policy,” to prevent the overstocking of pharmaceuticals. AIPPOA President, Chandika Gankanda when contacted yesterday (26) said the 1,200 generics had some 7,500 brand names times and switch to a different brand of the same generic depending on the benefit he or she receives for promoting it. It had resulted in pharmacies being overstocked with medicinal drugs worth millions of rupees that had passed their shelf life. Since 2015, the AIPPOA has asked for an “Expire Policy” to be introduced, so that pharmacies would be able to collect all drug stocks that were outdated and return it either to the agent of the pharma company to be returned to that particular drug manufacturer or the local manufacturer of the particular drug. Gankanda observed that the country could save dollars by controlling the number of drug brands of a single generic being imported. “With the inability to dispose of these drugs which have passed their shelf life to the environment, and the irregularity of the pharmacies being able to hand  over the expired drugs to the cement factory which incinerates those stocks, the only option is to allow them to accumulate.” These medicines are worth millions and end up being monetary wastage, which the country cannot afford at this juncture, the AIPPOA Chairman said. By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: No Policy to develop teacher quality in SL-ADB
author: Author not found
Content: There is no comprehensive and cohesive national policy on teachers’ professional development, Asian Development Bank (ADB) in a report released on Monday (24) said. The report titled ‘Challenges and Opportunities in Teacher Education Reforms’ further said that there should be cooperation and dialogue between policymakers, education institutions, and professional communities in this regard. ADB further said that all these stakeholders should share a common vision on teacher policy and on teaching and learning in general. A shared vision is a solid base for a teacher education curriculum, the document added. Such a policy should cover the continuous professional development (CPD) of pre-service and in-service teachers as well as their recruitment, deployment and retention, the report recommended.  There is also a need to eradicate gender disparities in recruitment, deployment and retention, ADB further said. ADB therefore recommended to “develop and implement of a national policy on professional development;”  “establish a professional council to support teacher development and introduce a national competency framework;” “utilise profiles in teacher licensing-” that would help ensure the quality of teachers’ performance, and their participation in CPD at different levels; “expand the use of ICT and online technology for teacher education,” “strengthen teacher education through school-based teacher development-”teachers can improve the quality of education through research, assignments, and other creative efforts to support “authentic” learning and “establish a systematic, countrywide mentoring network to support teacher education-”A mentoring network would make an important contribution to all these areas of teacher development, the ADB said. BY Paneetha Ameresekere

title: Social Security Levy added to electricity tariff
author: Author not found
Content: The Public Utilities Commission of Sri Lanka (PUCSL) has issued a clarification regarding how the Social Security Contribution Levy (SSCL) affects electricity bills. As per the Social Security Contribution Levy Act, electricity supply by Ceylon Electricity Board is subject to Social Security Contribution Levy. Thereby, the Ceylon Electricity Board will charge the said tax from 1 October 2022 on the purchase of electricity by the parties including consumers who receive electricity from the Ceylon Electricity Board. Explaining further, PUCSL Chairman, Janaka Ratnayake said, “Different parties in the electricity industry, including electricity consumers, have made inquiries about how the Social Security Contribution Levy will affect the electricity industry. As the electricity tariffs were revised recently, we suggested the Ministry of Finance to exempt electricity consumption from this levy.  The Ministry of Finance has informed us that according to the Act, the electricity supply of the Ceylon Electricity Board is subject to this levy. Therefore, the CEB will take steps to tax on the purchase of electricity from all parties who purchase electricity from the Ceylon Electricity Board from 1 October 2022.”

title: Egyptian Envoy calls on Speaker
author: Author not found
Content: Egyptian Ambassador to Sri Lanka Maged Mosleh paid a courtesy call on Speaker Mahinda Yapa Abeywardana in Parliament yesterday (26). Secretary-General of Parliament Dhammika Dasanayake was also present at this occasion. Ambassador Mosleh expressed his interest in reviving the Sri Lanka-Egypt Parliamentary Friendship Association. The Ambassador also said the two nations are completing 65 years of diplomatic relations. Further, the discussion between the Ambassador and the Speaker focused on several matters of mutual interest.

title: Fresh seafood to be made available islandwide
author: Author not found
Content: Fisheries Minister Douglas Devananda yesterday (26) said the programme to provide fresh seafood to consumers in a few districts will be expanded to other districts soon. To provide fresh seafood to consumers at a reasonable price, the Ceylon Fisheries Corporation (CFC) has been setting up fish outlets in several selected cities, Minister Devananda said. “The Government is aware that the low-income and middle-class families have been severely impacted due to the economic crisis and are facing difficulties in having nutritious food. We have taken every possible step to provide people with nutritious food,” Devananda said. The Minister also recalled the programme initiated by the CFC to distribute seafood islandwide during the Covid-19 pandemic. He said the CFC will introduce mobile seafood stalls in the future. The CFC has also opened fish stalls in Mirigama town and in Peliyagoda, Devananda added. By Naalir Jamaldeen

title: Speaker endorses three Bills
author: Author not found
Content: Speaker Mahinda Yapa Abeywardana signed Powers of Attorney Ordinance (Amendment), Wills Ordinance (Amendment) and Prevention of Frauds Ordinance (Amendment) Bills on Tuesday (25). Accordingly, the said three Bills will come into effect from 25 October 2022 as Powers of Attorney Ordinance (Amendment) Act No. 28 of 2022, Wills Ordinance (Amendment) Act No. 29 of 2022 and Prevention of Frauds Ordinance (Amendment) Act No. 30 of 2022.

title: MSD UNABLE TO PROCURE OVER 120 ESSENTIAL MEDICINES
author: Author not found
Content: The Medical Supplies Division (MSD) has collapsed to the point where it is unable to procure over 120 essential medicines and has left the Medical Research Institute (MRI) unable to conduct over 40 essential medical tests required for diagnosis and treatment of diseases, the Academy of Health Professionals (AHP) charged. According to AHP President, Ravi Kumudesh, those tests include Bence-Jones Protein test (used to check on multiple myeloma, a type of cancer), ANA test (test to detect antinuclear antibodies), Varcella IgG PCR, EBV PCR, BKV PCR, Pavo IgM PCR, Hepatitis A IgM, Hepatitis C Ab, Hepatitis B Antibody Profile, Hepatitis Anitigen and Hepatitis Co Antigen. In addition, there was a shortage of Vitamin B12, 8. Projesterone, Vitamin D, Cortizole (steroid hormone for your adrenal glands, the endocrine glands), and Cyclosphorine (to prevent organ rejection). However, interested parties were making use of the situation in the health service to obtain large-scale benefits by diverting medical testing and purchasing of medicinal drugs to the private sector. The Health Ministry does not attempt to prevent the situation and provide proper guidance. Several of its officials have become pawns of this system, he alleged. The AHP President said while it was possible to obtain funds from the Asian Development Bank (ADB), Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank (AIIB), World Bank, and the Indian Credit Line to support the purchase of essential medicines and laboratory reagents for the State health service, China had provided aid separately. But unfortunately, the health officials had failed to use any of this aid effectively or efficiently leading to this health crisis, he said. Furthermore, Kumudesh accused that service extension has been granted for ten top administrative officers of the Health Ministry who work for their personal gain by another year, ignoring the advice of several sections of health professionals’ unions.  By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: Three-wheeler fares to remain unchanged
author: Author not found
Content: Despite the weekly fuel quota for three-wheelers being increased with the President’s approval on 24 October, the Chairman of the All-Island Three-Wheeler Drivers’ Union (AITWDU) said three-wheeler fares will remain unchanged. AITWDU Chairman, Lalith Dharmasekara, earlier said they will reduce three-wheeler fares if the weekly fuel quota was increased to 20 litres. “If a different faction claims to have reduced three-wheeler fares, the rate at which it was reduced should be declared. Making a media statement that fares have been reduced is a publicity stunt. The increased fuel quota for three-wheeler tariff revision is insufficient, and it should be increased by at least 10 litres,” he said. Dharmasekara said, three-wheeler drivers presently charge Rs 100 for the first kilometre and Rs 120 for each additional kilometre. President Ranil Wickremesinghe instructed to increase the weekly fuel quota of 5 litres issued for passenger transport three-wheelers to 10 litres. As the first phase, the registration of passenger transport three-wheelers in the Western Province is scheduled to commence on 1 November. This was said during the discussion held between the President’s Senior Adviser on National Security and Chief of Staff to the President Sagala Ratnayake and three-wheeler drivers’ associations. Accordingly, from 6 November, 10 litres of fuel will be issued per week to all passenger transport three-wheelers in the Western Province. The registration of passenger transport three-wheelers will take place from 6 to 13 November, after which it is planned to issue the fuel quota to three-wheelers in other provinces. (TR)

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Enact legislation to identify dual citizen MPs
author: Author not found
Content: Pivithuru Hela Urumaya (PHU) Leader, MP Udaya Gammanpila emphasised the importance of enacting legislation requiring every MP to submit an affidavit stating that he/she is not a dual citizen, before taking office. He said unless an MP voluntarily declares their dual citizenship, there is no way to know the truth about the matter. In light of passing 22nd Amendment to the Constitution that prohibits dual citizens of the right to hold political office, he said, there are reports about 10 MPs who hold dual citizenship and they should resign immediately. “We should find out who those ten MPs are. When dual citizens were barred from becoming MPs in 2015, a billionaire in Sri Lanka approached me with a request. He told me there are 10 Tamil MPs who are dual citizens of Norway and Canada while a minister from the SLFP was a Swiss citizen. He said he will spend any amount of money to remove them from Parliament,” he said. No country was willing to provide him with information on dual citizen MPs, Gammanpila said. He said when one obtains citizenship of another country, one’s Sri Lankan citizenship is renounced. He added that if you do not inform the Government that you have become a citizen of another country, they or anyone else have no way of finding out. “It is said there are more than 10 dual citizens in Parliament now. But there is no way of finding out. Except for four members, the present Parliament was formed prior to the passage of the 22nd Amendment. That is why the so-called dual citizens have cheated their way into Parliament by hiding their dual citizenship. Thus, another method to identify dual citizens should be developed,” he said. He was speaking to the media yesterday (25). By Thameenah Razeek

title: Eran seeks to amend Assets Declaration Act
author: Author not found
Content: Samagi Jana Balawegaya (SJB) MP Eran Wickremeratne has submitted a Private Member’s Bill to Parliament, seeking to amend the Declaration of Assets and Liabilities Act to keep it in line with the obligations to disclose information under the Right to Information (RTI) Act.  In a statement, Wickremeratne noted that the Private Member’s Bill seeks to amend the Declaration of Assets and Liabilities Law No. 1 of 1975, at a time when the country has been demanding change and accountability through five key aspects. “First, it seeks to remove the archaic provisions within the Act to keep it in line with the obligations of disclosure of information under the Right to Information Act and the principle of maximum disclosure,” he stated. Wickremeratne said, this has been done with an eye to ensuring that there are proper safeguards, therefore, it does not provide for completely unfettered public access to asset declarations, but instead the Bill ensures that the proper privacy of the declarations are protected, in line with international norms on asset declaration transparency. “Second, the Bill ensures that electoral candidates will submit asset declaration’s with the nomination. It is a response to the current political concerns from society, and the call of the ‘Aragalaya’, that public representatives and officials provide proper disclosure of their wealth to increase transparency. Third, the Bill has included the president in the list of individuals to whom this law applies,” he added. Wickremeratne added that fourth, the Bill ensures that asset declarations are routinely examined and verified at a central authority- the Commission to Investigate Allegations of Bribery or Corruption (CIABOC). “This has never been done before, as asset declarations were only called for when there had been a complaint filed. The Bill has also introduced an online portal through which CIABOC can monitor and verify asset declarations to streamline the process. These amendments to the Act mean that officials cannot secretly amass large amount of wealth after coming into public office. Large increase in wealth will be subjected to proper explanation, as it should be,” he added. By Nabiya Vaffoor

title: Conducting raids serves no purpose – ACBOA
author: Author not found
Content: All Ceylon Bakery Owners’ Association (ACBOA) President, N.K. Jayawardena said conducting raids to detect low weight bread is absurd without providing solutions to the bakery industry. He said, several bakeries had been raided to investigate weight issues and that legal action had been taken against them. Speaking to the media yesterday, Jayawardena said, the Consumer Affairs Authority (CAA) had begun raiding bakeries to determine whether they adhered to the 450 g standard. “As a result, we ask the bakery owners to bake the 450 g bread and sell it to cover their costs. There is no price control mechanism for bread, and the bakery owners set their own selling price. These types of raids do not bring any solutions to the industry,” he said. Further, he said raided bakeries will continue to use the same method to pay their fines, otherwise there will be no way to sell bakery products due to the high cost of ingredients, including wheat flour. By Thameenah Razeek

title: Rishi Sunak takes office as new British PM
author: Author not found
Content: Rishi Sunak formally became Britain’s new Prime Minister on Tuesday after meeting King Charles at Buckingham Palace. Making a speech outside his Downing Street office, Sunak said he was not daunted by the scale of the challenge as he became Britain’s third Prime Minister in two months, pledging to lead the country through an economic crisis and rebuild trust in politics. The 42-year-old former hedge fund boss, who has only been in elected politics for seven years, has been tasked with bringing an end to the political infighting and radical changes in policy that have horrified investors and alarmed international allies. He warned that difficult decisions lay ahead as he looks to cut public spending and fix the “mistakes” that were made by Liz Truss during her short and chaotic tenure in Downing Street, just as the country slides into a recession. “I fully appreciate how hard things are,” he said outside the Prime Minister’s residence at Downing Street where he shunned the normal tradition of standing beside his family and cheering political supporters. “I understand too that I have work to do to restore trust, after all that has happened. All I can say is that I am not daunted. I know the high office I have accepted and I hope to live up to its demands.” Sunak, one of the richest men in parliament, is expected to slash spending to plug an estimated 40 billion pound ($45 billion) hole in the public finances created by an economic slowdown, higher borrowing costs and an energy support scheme. With his party’s popularity in freefall, he will face growing calls for an election if he ditches too many of the promises that helped elect the Conservative Party in 2019, when then leader Boris Johnson pledged to invest heavily. Economists and investors have welcomed Sunak’s appointment – Ryanair boss Michael O’Leary said, the adults had taken charge again – but they warn he has few options to fix the country’s finances when millions are battling a cost of living crunch. Sunak, who ran the Treasury during the COVID-19 pandemic, promised to put economic stability and confidence at the heart of the agenda. “This will mean difficult decisions to come,” he said, shortly after he accepted King Charles’s request to form a government. Sunak also vowed to put the public’s need above politics, in recognition of the growing anger at Britain’s political class and the ideological battles that have raged ever since the historic 2016 vote to leave the European Union. (Reuters)

title: Children below 12 years shouldn’t be ordained
author: Author not found
Content: All the Headquarters of Buddhist Nikayas must immediately intervene to protect the rights of novice monks (Samanera) in temples, Chancellor of University of Ruhuna, Ven. Dr. Akkuretiye Nanda Thera said, adding that minors below 12 years should not be ordained. The Ven. Thera also said a child is ordained in a Temple under the guidance of a senior monk as the teacher with the conviction that the older monks will take care of the novice monk. It is the duty of the senior monk to take care of the novice monk like a parent, he added. “There were immoral monks who engaged in wicked acts even during Lord Buddha’s time. That is why a code of conduct was introduced for monks. Even today, there are immoral monks, but there is no mechanism to monitor them. The Headquarters of Buddhist Nikayas do not perform that task,” the Ven. Thera said. “Novice monks too have child rights. If the senior monks follow the code of conduct, no abuses will be reported from temples,” he added. By Savani Sheashadhi

title: Sandya Ekneligoda’s FR Petition fixed for 18 Nov
author: Author not found
Content: The Fundamental Rights (FR) Petition filed by the wife of journalist Prageeth Ekneligoda, who disappeared in 2010, Sandya Ekneligoda, challenging certain recommendations made by the Presidential Commission appointed to inquire into incidents of political victimisation during the United National Front-led Government, was fixed for support on 18 November by the Supreme Court yesterday (25). This was when the Petition was taken up before Supreme Court Justices Vijith. K. Malalgoda, Achala Wengappuli, and Arjuna Obeyesekere. Sandya Ekneligoda filed the Petition against the recommendation made by the Presidential Commission to release Army Intelligence Officers from the case pertaining to the abduction and disappearance of Prageeth Ekneligoda case. Chairman of the Presidential Commission, retired Supreme Court Judge Upali Abeyratne and Commission members, Cabinet of Ministers, and Attorney General were among the respondents named in the Petition. The Attorney General had filed indictments in the High Court against nine Army Intelligence Officers attached to the Giritale Army Camp in connection with the Prageeth Ekneligoda case. By Faadhila Thassim

title: Four fishers go missing
author: Author not found
Content: Valaichchenai Fishery Harbour Manager G. Vijitharan said yesterday (24) that four fishermen, who went to sea on 17 September, are missing and no information on their whereabouts has been received as yet. According to Vijitharan, a search operation to find the fishermen is currently underway in the deep and shallow seas off the coast of Valaichchenai. He said the fishermen are members of the same family and live in Valaichchenai and Oddamavadi. Those missing are 62-year-old U. Hassan Ali, 34-year-old A. M. Muhajith, 33-year-old M. Rizvi and 32-year-old Irsadh, according to Vijitharan. When Ceylon Today contacted Hassan Ali’s grandson A. M. Mujahith, he said usually the fishermen would return to the shore in six or seven days. However, 37 days have passed since they left from the Valaichchenai Fishery Harbour, but they have not returned to the shore so far. The relatives of missing fishermen have filed a complaint with Valaichchenai Police in this connection, according to Mujahith. “We have brought this matter to the attention of Fisheries Ministry and have sought their assistance to find out the whereabouts of fishermen,” Vijitharan added. BY Naalir Jamaldeen

title: Don’t fall for ‘Eco Tablet’ – CPC
author: Author not found
Content: The Ceylon Petroleum Corporation (CPC) announced yesterday that the ‘Eco Tablet’ presently on the market is a deceptive campaign designed to mislead the public by claiming that the tablet would increase the octane number of petrol and reduce the amount of sulphur in fuel. The CPC said in a statement that the tablet is available in the market and that the CPC has not given any advice or approval to any organisation to combine with the fuel. CPC also clarified that it has notified the Consumer Affairs Authority that it plans to take legal action against the company over claims that diesel and petrol samples in the local market are low in octane without an approved laboratory test. The CPC also warned consumers not to fall for these deceptive advertisements. The corporation’s regional offices will conduct random checks on fuel stocks at CEYPETCO filling stations. “A number of laboratory tests were conducted by the corporation to determine whether the Eco Tablet product could improve the octane number of the fuel. As a result, both the refinery and the CPSTL laboratories tested the tablet. Furthermore, the same test was performed for all relevant types of fuel even without the use of the tablet,” the statement added.

title: President celebrates Deepawali
author: Author not found
Content: A special Deepawali celebration was held at the Presidential Secretariat on 24 October, under the patronage of President Ranil Wickremesinghe and Prime Minister Dinesh Gunawardena. This celebration organised by the Presidential Secretariat was held in a simple manner giving priority to Hindu rituals. During this celebration, President extended his warm greetings to all Hindu devotees. Ministers Douglas Devananda, Manusha Nanayakkara, MP Mano Ganesan representing the Samagi Jana Balawegaya (SJB), Senior Adviser to the President on National Security and Chief of Staff to the President Sagala Ratnayake, Senior Adviser to the President Akila Viraj Kariyawasam, United National Party General Secretary Palitha Range Bandara, former Ministers Daya Gamage, Anoma Gamage, former MPs R.Yogaraja, Colombo Deputy Mayor A.M. Iqbal, Colombo Municipal Councillors Jeraj Vishnuraj, Kanaka Ranjiran Branavan, Duminda Attigala, President of the Eksath Lakwanita Peramuna Shantini Kongahage, Presidential Trade Union Director General Saman Ratnapriya and several others were present on this occasion.

title: USD 2.9B IMF loan to be secured in mid-December
author: Author not found
Content: The Finance Ministry, in an update published on its website yesterday (25) affirmed that they expect to get IMF Board approval for a USD 2.9 billion loan by mid-December. It further said it expects to finalise Sri Lanka’s external debt restructuring with all of its creditors by the first half of next year. The Ministry further said, already the first batch of fiscal reforms to obtain debt sustainability is in place and those measures will be further complemented by new measures to be implemented vis-à-vis the 2023 budget to be presented next month. It further said, a key condition for the Government of Sri Lanka (GoSL) to obtain the IMF loan is to have corruption control measures in place, which measures the GoSL are currently working on. With reference to timelines pertaining to external debt restructuring, the Ministry said, they will also include the finalisation of the discussions with all creditors and executing the legal implementation of the agreements in questions with such creditors by the first half of next year. The Ministry also said, other expected outcomes for Sri Lanka’s debt restructuring process by the year end were: Engagement with official creditors in view of securing assurances to restore debt sustainability, preliminary information sharing with creditors under a non-disclosure agreement (NDA), and follow-up technical discussions with IMF Staff, notably on the debt sustainability analysis (DSA). Other year end objectives of the Ministry vis-à-vis Sri Lanka’s external debt restructuring and spilling over to the first half of next year were: Further pursuing information sharing efforts with all creditors, negotiations with private and official creditors on restructuring terms compliant with IMF DSA targets and comparable across the different creditor categories, and reaching agreements in principle with all creditors. By Paneetha Ameresekere

title: Crooked bakers face the music
author: Author not found
Content: Colombo District Secretary Pradeep Yasaratne said legal action has been instituted against seven bakeries in Piliyandala for selling loaves of bread which were below standard weight. A loaf of bread should weigh 450 g. He said a spate of complaints have been received with regard to selling of underweight bread from Colombo and its suburbs. Yasaratne said after exposés by the media, they had launched raids to arrest offenders. According to the Colombo District Secretary, raids had been conducted on suspect bakeries in Piliyandala, Kottawa, Pannipitiya, and Kesbewa on 24 October. Legal action was filed against noncomplying bakeries. By Vidyan Pathirana – Dehiwala

title: TNA welcomes release of Tamil detainees
author: Author not found
Content: The TNA welcomed the release of eight Tamil detainees who had been imprisoned for a long period and thanked former President Chandrika Bandaranaike Kumaratunga for agreeing to release some of those accused of attacking her while she was President.   TNA Spokesman, MP M.A. Sumanthiran said yesterday (25) in Jaffna, that several political prisoners were accused of attacking Kumaratunga while she was President, but she offered her consent to release them while Maithripala Sirisena was President, but that did not happen. “I know she granted her consent to former President Sirisena during the last government, and we are glad that it has taken effect,” he said. While welcoming their release, Sumanthiran also requested that the incumbent President release all political prisoners in the same manner. “We also request the President to immediately repeal the draconian Prevention of Terrorism Act (PTA). This is an urgent need and we think, even that must happen immediately,” he added. By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: Stray dogs hit by food crisis
author: Author not found
Content: Several stray dogs could be spotted in and around Naula town, searching for scraps of food when earlier they had been in the habit of receiving food from nearby hotels and bakeries. However, in the backdrop of economic crisis, these animals are struggling to find food due to closure of many hotels and bakeries. The bakery owners said even the number of consumers, who had visited hotels and bakeries to purchase food, had also dwindled and therefore it is difficult to provide food for stray animals now. BY I.A. Kumara – Naula

title: Convener of Bhikku Federation hospitalised
author: Author not found
Content: Convener of the Inter-University Bhikku Federation (IUBF), Ven. Galwewa Siridhamma Thera, who was detained on a 90-day detention order in Tangalle, was admitted to the Colombo National Hospital with high fever. The sister of Siridhamma Thera alleged that the Ven. Thera was suffering from high fever for about four days and the authorities had not taken any steps to provide medical care. Ven. Galwewa Siridhamma Thera, Wasantha Mudalige, and Hashantha Jeevantha Gunathilake were arrested on 18 August at a protest march in Colombo. The protest had been organised by IUSF against the Government led by President Ranil Wickremesinghe. President Wickremesinghe, as the Defence Minister, issued a Detention Order to detain and interrogate Convener of the Inter University Students’ Federation (IUSF) Wasantha Mudalige, Hashantha Jeevantha Gunathilake, and Ven. Galwewa Siridhamma Thera for 90 days under the Prevention of Terrorism Act (PTA). However, Hashantha Jeevantha Gunathilake was released after 50 days. By Dilanthi Jayamanne and Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: Plan to provide telecom facilities to Sabaragamuwa schools
author: Author not found
Content: A discussion was held recently at the Ministry of Technology on formulation of policies to grant telecommunication facilities to schools, which are devoid of it, within the Sabaragamuwa Province as well as to residents in the Province. The discussion was held on 19 October. During the initial round of this discussion it was decided to identify all schools which are in dire need of telecommunication facilities,  within the Sabaragamuwa Province and to draft a programme to supply such facilities forthwith. Among those involved in this discussion were State Minister of Technology Kanaka Herath, officials from the TRCSL, officers from Sri Lanka Telecom and Dialog Axiata.

title: Devotees in procession
author: Author not found
Content: A large number of devotees participated in the long procession to mark the Annual ‘Katina Cheevara Poojava’ of the Akkaraipattu Sri Vijayarama Temple on 22 and 23 October. The event held under the patronage of the Chief Incumbent of the temple Ven. Dewagoda Soratha Nayake Thera. (Pic by M. A. P. Deen – Ampara)

title: Saudi Envoy assures infrastructure support
author: Author not found
Content: Ambassador of the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia to Sri Lanka, Khalid Hamoud Nasser Aldasam Alkahtani assured Kalmunai Deputy Mayor Rahmath Munsoor that he will extend his fullest support to improve the infrastructure of the Kalmunai Al-Hamiya Arabic College. The Ambassador said he will implement special projects in the area focusing mainly on infrastructure to uplift the living conditions of underprivileged persons. Kalmunai Deputy Mayor Munsoor met Ambassador Alkahtani at the Royal Embassy of Saudi Arabia last week to invite him as chief guest for the graduation ceremony of Al-Hamiya Arabic College. The Ambassador accepted the invitation and said the Saudi Government had always supported Sri Lanka and will continue its humanitarian assistance to help overcome the economic crisis. Deputy Mayor Munsoor said the Eastern Province is blessed with beautiful tourist resorts in Pasikuda, Arugam Bay, and Nilaveli beaches and these tourist attractions should be further developed. The need to support the handloom village in Maruthamunai in Ampara District was also highlighted by Munsoor. By M.A.P. Deen–Ampara

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: USD 2.9B IMF loan to be secured in mid-December
author: Author not found
Content: The Finance Ministry, in an update published on its website yesterday (25) affirmed that they expect to get IMF Board approval for a USD 2.9 billion loan by mid-December. It further said it expects to finalise Sri Lanka’s external debt restructuring with all of its creditors by the first half of next year. The Ministry further said, already the first batch of fiscal reforms to obtain debt sustainability is in place and those measures will be further complemented by new measures to be implemented vis-à-vis the 2023 budget to be presented next month. It further said, a key condition for the Government of Sri Lanka (GoSL) to obtain the IMF loan is to have corruption control measures in place, which measures the GoSL are currently working on. With reference to timelines pertaining to external debt restructuring, the Ministry said, they will also include the finalisation of the discussions with all creditors and executing the legal implementation of the agreements in questions with such creditors by the first half of next year. The Ministry also said, other expected outcomes for Sri Lanka’s debt restructuring process by the year end were: Engagement with official creditors in view of securing assurances to restore debt sustainability, preliminary information sharing with creditors under a non-disclosure agreement (NDA), and follow-up technical discussions with IMF Staff, notably on the debt sustainability analysis (DSA). Other year end objectives of the Ministry vis-à-vis Sri Lanka’s external debt restructuring and spilling over to the first half of next year were: Further pursuing information sharing efforts with all creditors, negotiations with private and official creditors on restructuring terms compliant with IMF DSA targets and comparable across the different creditor categories, and reaching agreements in principle with all creditors. By Paneetha Ameresekere

title: Crooked bakers face the music
author: Author not found
Content: Colombo District Secretary Pradeep Yasaratne said legal action has been instituted against seven bakeries in Piliyandala for selling loaves of bread which were below standard weight. A loaf of bread should weigh 450 g. He said a spate of complaints have been received with regard to selling of underweight bread from Colombo and its suburbs. Yasaratne said after exposés by the media, they had launched raids to arrest offenders. According to the Colombo District Secretary, raids had been conducted on suspect bakeries in Piliyandala, Kottawa, Pannipitiya, and Kesbewa on 24 October. Legal action was filed against noncomplying bakeries. By Vidyan Pathirana – Dehiwala

title: Only a JJB Govt can end corruption – AKD
author: Author not found
Content: Jathika Jana Balawegaya (JJB) Leader Anura Kumara Dissanayake said, in order to build the country, a new Government, which could end corruption and fraud, was the urgent need and only the JJB was able to take on such a task. Addressing a gathering in Maharagama on 23 October Dissanayake challenged other political parties to give a guarantee they would end corruption and fraud. Dissanayake said that several foundations are needed to build a country. He said a new Constitution is needed for the country and also an effective public sector must be created. “To build a country, an effective public service must be built. The youth need to be rid of frustration. Small and medium enterprises are the economic engine of our country. We will form a government that deserves to be recognised by the world,” he emphasised. He also said that they would pay special attention to marine safety. “We need to build a country that is positively recognised by the world. We need to build an environment which is free from corruption to go forward. We need to build a country where the rule of law is established. Only the JJB can create such a country,” he said. BY Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: President Meets Board Members of the Indian CEO Forum
author: Author not found
Content: The Board Members of the Indian CEO Forum met President Ranil Wickremasinghe and had a very cordial and fruitful discussion, on the Sri Lankan economy, overcoming the present challenges of the companies operating in Sri Lanka and the way forward on investments in the field of IT, Education, Manufacturing, Hospitality, Tourism as well as Logistics considering the perfect location of the Island. The Board also updated the President on the progress and development of the current projects and challenges faced by Indian Companies. The discussion also focused on strengthening bilateral relationships between India and Sri Lanka.  The president also mentioned setting up a special desk to coordinate and take things forward. The Indian CEO Forum – Sri Lanka (ICF), is a registered body with membership constituted by Indian investment in Sri Lanka, Indian heads of multinational companies (MNCs), and Sri Lankan companies. It currently has 71 members contributing in providing gainful employment to thousands, providing best-in-class management, technical skills, and contributing substantiality to Sri Lanka’s foreign exchange earnings.  The members have made significant input and support to the Sri Lankan economy by way of bringing substantial investments into the country, export earnings, employment generation, and contribution to the Treasury through direct and indirect taxes, and taking the Sri Lanka brand to the outside world and making a significant contribution to the local economy. The objective of ICF is to promote economic growth in Sri Lanka through Indian investment, safeguard and strengthen existing economic co-operation, foster new economic ties between India and Sri Lanka, and provide an open forum for business leaders of Indian origin employed with Indian multinationals and Sri Lankan business organisations in Sri Lanka. ICF endeavors to showcase investment opportunities to Sri Lankan to potential new investments from India.

Content: Ananda College Old Boys’ Association (ACOBA) will hold the annual Olcott Oration, to commemorate Colonel Henry Steel Olcott, on 29 October at the Kularatne Auditorium, Ananda College at 4.45p.m. The oration will be delivered by Investment Banker cum Entrepreneur and PPP specialist Thilan Wijesinghe, who is the Founder /Executive Chairman of TWC (Pvt) Ltd. on the theme of ‘Bridging the Ideological Divide that Caused Sri Lanka’s Economic Situation’.

title: Fuel quota for three-wheelers to be doubled
author: Author not found
Content: President Ranil Wickremesinghe has instructed to increase the weekly fuel quota of five litres issued for professional passenger transport three-wheelers to 10. As the first phase, the registration of professional three-wheelers in the Western Province is scheduled to commence on 1 November. This was revealed during the discussion held yesterday (24) between the President’s Senior Adviser on National Security and Chief of Staff to the President Sagala Ratnayake and the professional three-wheeler associations. Accordingly, from 6 November, 10 litres of fuel per week will be issued to all three-wheeler passenger vehicles in the Western Province. The registration of passenger transport three-wheelers will commence from 6 to 13 November, after which it is planned to issue the fuel quota to three-wheelers in other provinces. Currently, there are 1.08 million three-wheelers in Sri Lanka, out of that, 400,000 are passenger transport three-wheelers, according to the three-wheeler associations. Around 300,000 three-wheelers have been registered with the Sri Lanka Police, and if it is not possible to register the three-wheelers in the entire island by 13 November, it was also decided to release the fuel quota for thethree-wheelers registered with the Police as an initial step. Provincial Governors and Provincial Road Transport Authority officials are also to be immediately notified about this decision.

title: COPE instructs Land Reform Act be updated
author: Author not found
Content: The Committee on Public Enterprises (COPE) recommended that the Secretary to the Ministry of Lands, Chulananda Perera, update the Land Reform Commission Act and take the necessary steps to restructure operations. Accordingly, the COPE recommended that a report be given within six weeks, based on the action taken in this connection. These recommendations were made when the COPE met in Parliament last week, under the chairmanship of Prof. Ranjith Bandara, to examine the Auditor General’s report for the year 2020 and the current performance of the Land Reform Commission. The COPE gave several recommendations to the commission and it was decided that the Land Reform Commission be summoned before the COPE again within three months to look into the implementation of those recommendations. The COPE observed the concerns in the transfer of land by the commission and thus the COPE Chairman recommended that a report containing detailed information about the transfer of land in the last 20 years should be submitted to the COPE within a month. The COPE also recommended setting up a task force to identify and estimate the value of land and recommended that the Secretary to the Ministry report to the COPE, within two weeks, the details of the responsibilities assigned to the task force. The COPE recommended the appointment of the Surveyor General or his representative as well as the Government Assessor or his representative to this task force. Furthermore, the COPE discussed the 2018 project to distribute 10,000 plots of land and Prof. Ranjith Bandara recommended that a detailed report on its progress be given to the committee. In particular, he recommended that the position of the 214 people recruited, on a temporary basis for this project, should be discussed with the management department and a definite final decision should be taken to include them in the approved number of employees and if necessary, they should be referred to the Cabinet for approval. Furthermore, the COPE recommended including the procedure of the Land Reform Commission in a national policy on land distribution and making necessary arrangements. The committee instructed updating the 50-year-old Land Reforms Commission Act to suit the present-day context. The missing files of the Land Reforms Commission were also taken into discussion and the COPE informed the commission to immediately submit them to the Auditor General. The COPE Committee also recommended that immediate action should be taken to resolve the existing issues regarding the beneficiaries identified earlier under the statutory assignments. The Auditor General’s opinion on the financial statements of this commission has been disclaimed for about 10 years, the notice was given to prepare the financial statements correctly and arrange for the annual reports to be tabled in the Parliament within three months. The committee recommended taking action against the alleged company to recover the amount of 17 million rupees paid to a private computer company for the creation and development of a fully integrated computer system and to take disciplinary action against the officials involved in the matter. Furthermore, it was also recommended taking legal action within two weeks to recover the amount of nearly 12 million rupees for the six acres of land assigned to a private company without a tax deed in Homagama. It was also instructed to inquire and report to the COPE committee regarding not making an agreement and charging 4% instead of 6% of the assessed value.

title: Geetha summons NCPA, Police Children’s Bureau
author: Author not found
Content: The National Child Protection Authority (NCPA) and the Police Children and Women’s Bureau (PCWB) have been summoned by State Minister of Women and Child Affairs Geetha Kumarasinghe, today (25), to inquire about steps that should be taken to address the increasing child abuse cases in the country. When contacted, Kumarasinghe said, following the discussion with those institutions she will be forming a committee to formulate concrete measures to overcome incidents of child abuse. She also alleged that the actions of the NCPA with regard to addressing child abuse had left much to be desired. Kumarasinghe observed that in light of incidents of child abuse escalating the NCPA will need to wake up from their deep slumber and take action to bring offenders to book while safeguarding the country’s children. By Mithun Jayawardena and Savani Sheashadhi

title: SLAF remember their fallen heroes
author: Author not found
Content: Sri Lanka Air Force (SLAF) held its Annual Religious Ceremony and an Almsgiving at Sri Dalada Maligawa on 22 and 23 October, under the patronage of SLAF Commander Air Marshal Sudarshana Pathirana. The event was held to commemorate SLAF personnel who made the supreme sacrifice. This event was organised by the Directorate of Welfare for the 12th consecutive year. Chairperson of SLAF Seva Vanitha Unit Charmini Pathirana participated on 22 October, when religious blessings were invoked on all ranks currently serving in the Air Force, those who made the supreme sacrifice in the defence of the motherland and their families. The Almsgiving for 71 Buddhist Monks was held on 23 October with participation of the Mahanayaka of Asgiriya Chapter, Ven. Warakagoda Sri Gnanarathana thera at Sri Dalada Maligawa. The SLAF Commander also called on the Mahanayaka Theras of the Asgiriya Chapter and the Malwathu Chapter where they gave their blessings to the Commander and all SLAF personnel. This year’s ceremony was attended by the members of the Air Force Board of Management, all Base Commanders and Commanding Officers, officers, other ranks and most importantly the family members of the war heroes who were killed in action.

title: Harshana appointed SJB LG Committee chair
author: Author not found
Content: Samagi Jana Balawegaya (SJB) MP Harshana Rajakaruna received the letter of appointment, as the Chairman of the Local Government Committee of the SJB, from the Opposition and SJB leader Sajith Premadasa on 21 October.

title: Northern Hindus mark Deepavali
author: Author not found
Content: Hindu devotees, in the Northern Province, marked the Deepavali Festival with deep reverence at Temples (Kovils) yesterday (24). The devotees who flocked to Kovils from early morning participated in religious observances with the main event being described as a festival of lights. The Hindu devotees commemorate the Deepavali Festival and offer prayers to the Sun to illuminate their path to prosperity, for darkness to make way for light and for wrongs to be righted. They also hope that they will be able to reap a rich harvest due to the prayers offered by them to Sun and that they will be able to sustain their businesses in the New Year. BY Sashi Kumar – Mullaithivu

title: Ginger growers stop harvesting
author: Author not found
Content: Farmers in Laggala stated that they had halted ginger harvesting in several villages, coming under the purview of the Mathale- Laggala Divisional Secretariat, due to their inability to obtain a decent price for their hard labour. They stated that in the past few years they had received a reasonable sum for their ginger harvest, but they lamented that thus far, during 2022, that has not been the case. Therefore they had been forced to halt the harvesting process forthwith. Farmers told this correspondent that due to ginger being imported to the country, those making a living out of the business in Laggala had been hard hit by and they urged the authorities to intervene and offer them a decent price to sustain their industry and livelihood. They also added that due to transport costs involved in supplying ginger to the Dambulla Economic Centre and due to a kilo of ginger being quoted at below Rs 100, they have decided to temporarily halt the process of harvesting ginger during the on-going season. BY I. A. Kumara – Naula

title: Farmers face hardships due to dilapidated road
author: Author not found
Content: The road from Elahera to Ambana, through which a majority of the vegetables are sent to the Dambulla Economic Centre, is dilapidated. Thereby, cultivaters face severe hardships in transporting their vegetables, farmers lamented. The area is under the purview of Naula Divisional Secretariat. The farmers stated that though the road from Elahera to Ambana had been patched up by successive Governments, the entire stretch of road has not been fully constructed, leading to many difficulties. They also added that not only the transporting of vegetables is affected, but even motorists using the road have been forced to face up to numerous hardships due to the untrustworthy condition of the road. BY I. A. Kumara – Naula
