title: PM stresses importance of enhancing professionalism
author: Author not found
Content: Prime Minister Dinesh Gunawardena stressed the importance of enhancing professionalism in the public and private sectors, for economic revival and praised the Institute of Supply and Material Management (ISMM), for its contribution to the economy by imparting required professional expertise to youth. Addressing the International Seminar held in Colombo yesterday (24), to mark the 50th Anniversary of ISMM, he urged the participants to explore ways and means of improving the supply chain to smoothen supply of requirements for growth of production. He praised the ISMM for the yeomen service rendered to Supply Chain Management Students to improve their lot by following these valuable courses for the betterment of the country’s economy. “The theme of the International Seminar, ‘Elevating the Economy through Innovative and Sustainable Supply Chain Solutions’ is most appropriate and timely as it could provide solutions to supply chain issues exacerbated due to the current unprecedented economic crisis,” he said. “ISMM, as you all know, has been the Pioneer in Supply Chain Education for the last five decades and has trained over thousand Diplomats in addition to the thousands of other successful students who followed Management and Certificate Level Programmes,” the Prime Minister pointed out. “Many of ISMM Diplomats are holding the highest positions in the Supply Chain Divisions of reputed organisations in Sri Lanka and worldwide. Supply Chain Professionals are contributing a very valuable service to enhance the economy of Sri Lanka. This is indeed a vital role they are executing in the field of Supply Chain Management, whether they are in Government or Private Sector Organisations,” Prime Minister Gunawardena said. Finance Secretary Mahinda Siriwardena delivered the keynote address. Minister of Mass Media Dr. Bandula Gunawardhana, Media Secretary Anusha Palpita, President of ISMM, Sarath Gamage, Founder Member, Past President of ISMM Gerry Hidelaratchi and other office-bearers of ISMM also were present at this occasion.

title: Give failed LRC fertiliser project to State agency – COPE
author: Author not found
Content: Parliament Watchdog, the Committee on Public Enterprises (COPE), instructed that the failed organic fertiliser project, initiated by the Land Reform Commission (LRC) at a cost of Rs 350 million, be transferred to a State agenacy that actually has knowledge about fertiliser products. This instruction was given when the Committee on Public Enterprises met in Parliament recently, under the chairmanship of Prof. Ranjith Bandara, to examine the Auditor General’s report for the year 2020 and the current performance of the Land Reforms Commission. It was reported that in July 2021, then Lands Minister S.M. Chandrasena had obtained Cabinet approval to spend Rs 700 million from the Land Reforms Commission for the government’s organic fertiliser project.  The then minister said the organic fertiliser would be sold to the Ministry of Agriculture and the proceeds from the sale will be cycled back to the production of fertiliser.

title: Trio accused of attempt on CBK’s life among eight pardoned
author: Author not found
Content: President Ranil Wickremesinghe has granted amnesty to eight Tamil prisoners, including the trio accused in the 1999 Town Hall bomb blast, in which former President Chandrika Bandaranaike Kumaratunga lost an eye. Before proceeding with the process of releasing these prisoners, President’s Secretary Saman Ekanayake had sought the approval of former President Kumaratunga on the advice of the President. The relevant arrangements were made after obtaining her consent. The President granted this amnesty according to Article 34 of the Constitution of Sri Lanka. As a result of several discussions between Tamil MPs and the President on several occasions, steps were taken to release these prisoners. Before their release, a preliminary investigation had been conducted on them with the intervention of the Ministry of Defence on the instructions of the President. This decision has been reached after consulting the Minister of Justice and through him the Attorney General about the consent report. Three of the Tamil prisoners, who were pardoned, were those accused of attempting to assassinate former President Chandrika Bandaranaike Kumaratunga. Accordingly, the four detainees with connections to the LTTE organisation, who were detained at the Colombo Magazine Prison, were released after their sentence was reduced. Two Tamil LTTE prisoners related to the organisation are to be released after the cases filed by them in the Court of Appeal are withdrawn and two more Tamil prisoners are to be released soon under the presidential amnesty. Three prisoners had been sentenced to 30 years in jail and had served 22 years, one prisoner who had been sentenced to 11 years and had served 14 years, one who has been sentenced to 10 years and had also served 14 years, two prisoners who were sentenced to five years but had served for14 years, were among those who received a presidential pardon. Another person who had been sentenced to 19 years in prison and had served 11 years of his sentence so far was also among those who were pardoned.

title: Solar eclipse today
author: Author not found
Content: A partial solar eclipse will be visible in Sri Lanka today (25), in most parts of the country at sunset, but will be best seen from Jaffna. Chandana Jayaratne, Professor of Physics, and Director of the Astronomy and Space Science Unit at the University of Colombo said in a statement that for the city of Jaffna, the partial eclipse begins at 5.27 p.m. and the maximum eclipse occurs at 5.46 p.m. with 8.8 % of the solar disk covered by the moon. Though the eclipse ends at 6.20 p.m. it can be observed only up to sunset due at 5.49 p.m. This eclipse will be visible in Jaffna for 22 minutes. The Northern part of Sri Lanka, from Anuradhapura to Jaffna, is the most suitable region to observe this eclipse, while this eclipse is not visible to the southern parts of Sri Lanka, he noted. For Colombo the beginning of the partial eclipse can be observed at 5.43 p.m. and the maximum eclipse at 5.49 p.m. with the moon covering about 1.6% of the solar disk. However, he added partial solar eclipse cannot be observed after 5.52 p.m. due to sunset. This eclipse will be visible to the Colombo area for about 9 minutes, Prof. Jayaratne said. Since this eclipse occurs when the sun is very dim near the western horizon close to sunset, it is fairly okay to observe the eclipse even without a solar filter.  He added that naked eye observations at the eclipse maximum time and afterward for a short period of fewer than 30 seconds will not cause any damage to the eyes.

title: Fmr CEA Chair refutes chalet allegations
author: Author not found
Content: Former Central Environmental Authority (CEA) Chairman Siripala Amarasinghe, who was sacked from his post last week, refuted allegations that a chalet is being built in the buffer zone, at the Knuckles forest reserve, by him and his son. Amarasinghe claimed that a chalet built in the Knuckles range was outside the buffer zone and he had the authorisation to build the chalet. The land in Pitawela, Atangwella, Ilukumbura, which he had bought 12 years ago was transferred by deed to his son in 2021, he said. Amarasinghe claimed the chalet will be made entirely of iron rods. He declared that because it was outside the safe zone, he would write to the President and other people to say that he was ‘not guilty’. He added, he had obtained permission from the National Building Research Organisation and from the Pradeshiya Sabha and not necessarily from the CEA. He said, he is waiting for approval from the Agrarian Services Committee to build the road to the chalet. Meanwhile, SLPP MP Wasantha Yapabandara said, there were numerous petitions relating to his two constructions in Kandy that require investigations. The MP told Ceylon Today that the government should verify if it is in the buffer zone or not, but he also stated that they had received petitions over two of the structures, namely in the Knuckles range and in Hantane, Kandy as well, as both were owned by the former CEA Chairman. The former Chairman of the CEA is accused of encroaching on the forest range, according to MP Yapabandara, who brought up the issue in the Parliament last week. He claimed that in addition to conflicts of interest, a number of other purportedly “approved” constructions are also allegedly being built in river beds with the approval of the CEA in various other places. However, the MP stated that the chalet is built on elevated man-made land and the road runs across a paddy field, for which he did not acquire authorisation from the Agrarian Services Committee. The MP wondered how Amarsinghe could build a chalet without such prior approval. Also, the SLPP MP stated that a construction project in Hantane owned by the former CEA chairman is in the process, but he has not received prior consent from the Hantana Protect Committee, and legal action has been already filed over this.  “There are several petitions against those two constructions and we want him to justify whether it is illegal or not, but we have the petitions,” the MP noted. The politician also alleged that there are constructions of hotels in the middle of the river, on the sandy mounds, which are visible to any, but the CEA has issued permission. “but how can that be” is a common question people ask. He pointed out there is one such hotel built in Hakinda, Gatambe and another resort named Escape in Gannoruwa river. The MP noted that environmental destruction is on the rise and the government should identify each of them and verify the legality of constructing such resorts in Sri Lanka.  By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: Gammanpila seeks names of MPs absent during 22A vote
author: Author not found
Content: Pivithuru Hela Urumaya (PHU) Leader MP Udaya Gammanpila has asked the Information Officer, at Parliament Secretariat, to provide him with a list of MPs who were absent during the voting on the 22nd Amendment to the Constitution. He said, the amendment, which was submitted to Parliament and passed as the 21st Amendment to the Constitution, on 21 October 2022, is an important Act for Sri Lanka. In a letter to the information officer, he said, the passage of the Act protected Sri Lanka from foreign interference by depriving dual citizens the right to hold political office. “If a Member of Parliament does not support the Bill, his patriotism will be called into question. The names of 44 MPs who did not vote were published in the media, but they were based on unofficial information. All MPs who did not vote in that election owe it to the people to explain why they were unable to attend parliament,” he said. In light of the foregoing, he requested that the information officer provide him in writing as soon as possible, in accordance with the provisions of the Freedom of Information Act No. 12 of 2016, a list of the names of all MPs who did not vote on the said 21st Constitution (Amendment) Act on 21 October 2022.

title: Rishi Sunak wins race to become UK’s new PM
author: Author not found
Content: Rishi Sunak will become the United Kingdom’s new Prime Minister after winning the ruling Conservative Party’s leadership contest triggered by the dramatic resignation of Liz Truss last week. Sunak’s win came days after Truss’ resignation following her disastrous tax cuts plans and policy U-turns plunged the markets into chaos. The unprecedented economic crisis drew a rare intervention from the Bank of England. Sunak’s only challenger, Penny Mordaunt, leader of the House of Commons and former defence minister, was reportedly backed by 30 MPs compared with nearly 150 supporting Sunak. “This decision is an historic one and shows, once again, the diversity and talent of our party,” Mordaunt said in a statement as she withdrew from the race just minutes before the winner was due to be announced. “Rishi has my full support.” “These are unprecedented times. Despite the compressed timetable for the leadership contest it is clear that colleagues feel we need certainty today,” she said. “They have taken this decision in good faith for the good of the country.” Sunak and Mordaunt had lost to Truss in an earlier race to appoint a new leader after then-Prime Minister Boris Johnson was forced to announce his resignation in July following a wave of scandals linked to parties entertained during the coronavirus lockdown. Sunak, a former finance minister, will be Britain’s first leader of colour and the first Hindu to take the top job. At 42, he’ll also be the youngest prime minister in more than 200 years. The multi-millionaire former hedge fund boss will be expected to launch deep spending cuts to try to rebuild Britain’s fiscal reputation, just as the country slides into a recession, dragged down by the surging cost of energy and food. He will also inherit a political party that has fractured along ideological lines, a challenge that damaged the fortunes of several former Conservative leaders. (AL Jazeera)

title: Inclement Weather Impacts 1,471 Families
author: Author not found
Content: Inclement weather on Sunday (23) impacted 1,471 families comprising 7,193 persons, the Disaster Management Centre (DMC) said yesterday (24). This comprised 1,316 families or 6,494 people impacted by floods at Kelaniya in the Gampaha District, 133 families comprising 621 people impacted by heavy rains, 15 families comprising 49 people from Mullaitiviu impacted by a flash flood at Puthukuddyiruppu and seven families comprising 29 people from the Galle District impacted by landslides (cutting failures), heavy rains and falling trees, it said. Meanwhile, those affected from Mullaitivu have been moved to a safer locality, though, not so the others, it said.  It further said that 30 houses and six small and medium enterprises (SMEs) were damaged due to inclement weather on Sunday. While all the damaged SMEs were located in Kalutara, the locations of the damaged houses were 23 from Kalutara and seven from Galle. Meanwhile National Building Research Orgnaisation (NBRO) yesterday issued landslide warnings covering 28 divisional secretariat divisions (DSDs) in five districts. They were  Yakkalamulla, Nagoda Baddegama, Akmeemana and Galle Four Gravets DSDs and surrounding areas in the Galle District; Agalawatta, Millaniya, Matugama Walallawita, Bulathsinhala, Dodangoda, Ingiriya and Palindanuwara DSDs and surrounding areas in the Kalutara District, Ruwanwella, Deraniyagala, Warakapola, Bulathkohupitiya, Dehiowita, Yatiyanthota and Mawanella DSDs and surrounding areas in the Kegalle District, Ambagamuwa DSD and surrounding areas in the Nuwara-Eliya District and Eheliyagoda, Ratnapura, Ayagama, Kiriella, Kuruwita, Nivithigala and Kalawana DSDs and surrounding areas in the Ratnapura District, respectively. In related developments, the Met Department, issuing their weather forecast for the 36 hours ending at 4:00 a.m. tomorrow (26) said that showers or thundershowers will occur at times in the Western, Sabaragamuwa, Central, NorthWestern and Northern Provinces and in the Galle and Matara Districts. Fairly heavy showers above 75 mm may be expected at some places in the Western and Sabaragamuwa provinces and in the Galle and Matara Districts, it further said. Showers or thundershowers may occur at several places in the Uva, Eastern and North-Central provinces during the afternoon or night, it added. The Department also said that temporary localised strong winds and lightning will take place during thundershowers. By Paneetha Ameresekere

title: Visitor fees to Wildlife parks hiked by 67-150%
author: Author not found
Content: The Cash strapped Government of Sri Lanka (GoSL) has increased visitor fees to key wildlife parks, such as Yala and Wilpattu, by 150 per cent for locals and by 67 per cent for foreigners. The new fees, effective since last month (September), means that a local adult who visits such parks during day time will now see his visitor fee hiked from the previous Rs 60 rate to Rs 150, a Rs 90 increase and from US$ 15 to $ 25 or their rupee equivalent, nonetheless, a $ 10 hike per foreign adult. Likewise foreign kids entering such wildlife parks will see the price of their tickets hiked by 88 per cent (seven dollars), ie from eight dollars to $ 15 or the rupee equivalent per child. Meanwhile a local child entering such a park will have to pay a fee of Rs 100 and a local student Rs 20 for a daytime visit. Meanwhile, an adult visitor from a SAARC country, making a daytime visit to such parks, will have to pay a visitor fee of US$ 20 and a ‘SARRC child’ $ 10. Parks where the above charges are applicable are Yala, Horton Plains, Uda Walawe, Minneriya, Pigeon Island, Wilpattu, Kaudulla, Lunugamvehera (Yala Region VI) and Adam’s Bridge, GoSL, extraordinary Gazette 2292/11, dated 8 August 2022, has notified. The above charges are applicable during the tourist season. Likewise, visitor entry to the ‘lesser’ wildlife parks have been hiked by 50 per cent for locals and by 20 per cent for foreigners during the tourist season.  Parks covered under the ‘lesser’ category are Wasgamuwa, Angammadilla, Maduru Oya,  Kumana, Chundikulam, Lahugala, Gal Oya, Bundala and Galway Island. Consequently, such rates previously applicable to local adults which were Rs 40 per person have been increased by Rs 20 to Rs 60, for ‘local children’the new rate applicable being Rs 30 and for students,Rs 20 per person.  For foreign adults, such fees have been increased by two dollars, ie from $ 10 to $ 12 or their rupee equivalent, and for ‘foreign children’ from five dollars to six dollars or their rupee equivalent, per person. Meanwhile, the applicable rates for visitors from SAARC countries are, adults ($ 10 per person or the rupee equivalent) and children (five dollars or the rupee equivalent). Meanwhile, offseason charges for daytime visitors to the lesser wildlife parks remain unchanged, while for the top notch parks such as Yala and Wilpattu, the revised daytime visitor charges are for foreign adults, $ 20 or their rupee equivalent per person, $ 10 or rupee equivalent per ‘foreign child’, $ 15 per SAARC adult and eight dollars per ‘SAARC child’. For locals, such applicable offseason charges are adults (Rs 120 per person), children (Rs 80) and students (Rs 20). BY Paneetha Ameresekere

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: 7,568 child abuse complaints in eight months
author: Author not found
Content: The National Child Protection Authority (NCPA) has received 7,568 complaints of child abuse in the first eight months of the year. According NCPA Chairman Chanaka Udyakumara Amarasinghe, the number of child abuse complaints includes sexual abuse, child labour, and child begging. He also said that over 8,700 children are currently on probation and that this is due to a variety of issues and problems. He explained, a disproportionate number of child abuse complaints are received from Gampaha, Anuradhapura, Kurunegala, Kandy, Ratnapura, and Matara Districts when compared to other areas in the country. He further noted that although the NCPA faced a few issues such as technical breakdowns in the hotline in the recent past, now it has been fixed and they often get complaints through the hotline. Meanwhile, recently, the NCPA initiated investigations into a number of incidents such as the alleged incident where Police had intervened to prevent the marriage of an underage child in the Angulana area in Moratuwa.  Complaints about child abuse can be made through the National Child Protection Authority hotline number – 1929. By Mithun Jayawardena

title: 22A will lead to exponential development
author: Author not found
Content: Chancellor of the Ruhuna University, Ven. Akuratiye Nanda Thera said President Ranil Wickremesinghe has set a valuable example to the world by passing the 22nd Amendment to the Constitution. He said this during a sermon of the Katina Maha Punyotsavaya of the Sedawatta, Veragoda Purana Viharaya, which was held under the patronage of President Wickremesinghe.  He also said the President is a philanthropic democratic leader and that this action to relinquish the dictatorial powers of the presidency to Parliament will lead to the development of the country. This annual Katina Pinkama was organised on the directives of Ven. Ambanwela Gnanaloka Thera, the Chief Incumbent of the Temple. The Katina Cheevaraya was brought to the Presidential Secretariat in a procession for staff members to pay their respects. President Wickremesinghe took part in the Katina Cheevara Pooja and offered alms to the monks. “Today, President Ranil Wickremesinghe is respected globally as a benevolent democratic leader. Today, the whole world is watching us. It is a very important process at a time when the President is preparing to start a new era in this country, by transferring his powers to Parliament in a democratic framework and having the 22nd Amendment passed with a two-thirds majority. It is very important because all the democratic institutions such as the International Monetary Fund and World Bank are watching us today. By February and March of 2022, the future of this country was looking bleak. The people were in a dilemma. At that challenging time, our President rose to the occasion and accepted it with the will and the blessings of the ruling party and the Opposition,” Ven. Akuratiye Nanda Thera further said. Ven. Nanda Thera added that the country was facing food shortages and food production was reduced due to lack of fertiliser. He said there were fuel queues and gas queues. “However, President Wickremesinghe took on all these challenges and won and today the people have been given some relief. Further, due to the constitutional amendment passed with a majority in Parliament, it has ensured a democratic society and by empowering the parliamentary committees, it has paved the way to render great service to the nation. Today, a number of organisations including the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank have promised the President to support Sri Lanka in overcoming these challenges,” he said.

title: People want system change – Sajith
author: Author not found
Content: Opposition Leader Sajith Premadasa noted that the people want a change in the system, not posts that were awarded as tokens of gratitude. Premadasa made the remarks while attending the Samagi Jana Balawegaya (SJB) Colombo Central Constituency Board meeting on 22 October. It was hosted by MP Mujibar Rahman. Premadasa said in order to save the country from the current crisis, the people are demanding a change in the system, not giving personal bounties based on their own will and that under the new system, a programme that prioritises economic, social, and human rights is required. “The sons and daughters of politicians in this country have always accepted the seats of their parents and although the Central Colombo seat is unique, in my political journey I went to a difficult province and learned about the people of that province and started my political journey spontaneously because I needed to prove something to the country and the people,” he added. He further said that the reason for the tragic fate of the country today is the result of the Rajapaksa’s division of race, religion, caste and class and breaking the country into pieces and creating hatred between races and religions. “This caste-religious discrimination was implemented starting from sterilisation and sterilisation operations and ending with cremation and burial. Today, even though various parties are shouting racism and bigotry, then everyone except the United People’s Force did not oppose it,” he added. Premadasa further claimed that with the 22nd Amendment, “Mola hatha” aka Basil Rajapaksa had lost his mind because he is going to run for the election again. He challenged him to contest from the Colombo District and said that Rajapaksa will be removed from the power step by step. BY Nabiya Vaffoor

title: Ensure better tomorrow for children
author: Author not found
Content: UNP MP Wajira Abeywardena said every parent has a duty to provide a prosperous future for their children. “If this goal is to be met, a stable policy framework, as proposed by President Ranil Wickremesinghe, must be developed as soon as possible,” he said. MP Abeywardena lamented that the people of this country had previously faced a severe crisis. Because the parents did not have a steady source of income, they struggled to feed their children. Today, the situation is gradually improving as a result of the President’s timely action, he said. Abeywardena was speaking at the 10th Anniversary of the Hansini Pitakum Karate Tournament, which was held at Sugathadasa Indoor Stadium. “Still, there are certain issues to be resolved. The President has taken necessary action to resolve them as soon as possible. Parents must act prudently to ensure a better tomorrow for their children. If people set aside their party differences, Sri Lanka can reach new heights,” Abeywardena said. “The youth staged anti-government protests. The Aragalaya should not lead to devastation. What was the outcome of the Aragalaya? It didn’t resolve the fuel crisis and bring down the cost of living. The Aragalaya and protests will impact the tourism industry,” Abeywardena added. If we are divided, it will impact the development of this country, he further said. By Naalir Jamaldeen

title: NSBM, SLIIT to be upgraded to national universities – President
author: Author not found
Content: President Ranil Wickremesinghe said, the Faculty of Engineering of the University of Colombo would be set up as a separate campus, while the National School of Business Management (NSBM) and the Sri Lanka Institute of Information Technology (SLIIT) would be upgraded as national universities. He also said the delay in the Sri Lankan university system at the commencement of courses would be avoided, enabling students to complete their studies within the stipulated duration. The President made this observation during a meeting with the Prefects of Royal College, Colombo held at the Presidential Secretariat on 22 October. The matters concerning Royal College as well as matters regarding the country’s education sector were discussed there, while the President answered the questions raised by the students on the measures taken by the government for the advancement of the education sector. The President made queries from the prefects on the university education, where the students brought the attention of the President to the vast difference between the duration to complete a degree in a foreign higher education institute and in a local university. The President agreed and assured that remedial action would be taken without delay. He also highlighted the value of education in a local university over foreign education. He also emphasised that the government has taken many steps to expand the educational opportunities for students who have qualified for higher education, following the completion of their school education. He added that measures have been taken to commence several new universities in Kurunegala and Batticaloa.  President Wickremesinghe raised the issue of ragging with the students during the meeting and said that it seemed that students who attend the universities from schools such as Royal College, Thurstan College, Ananda College and D.S. Senanayake College turn a blind eye when such ragging incidents happen, although a large number of students from these schools are within these universities. The President also pointed out that the students of those universities have a responsibility to bring ragging in universities to an end and the head prefects of those schools could perform that role while in school. He further said that university education is interesting but the rate of students suffering from physical and mental stress has increased due to ragging at universities and emphasized that he would take measures to solve the problem. He also appreciated the role played by the Board of Prefects of the Royal College in the development of the school and its reputation. Senior Advisor to the President on National Security and Chief of Staff to the President Sagala Rathnayake also participated in the event.

title: President pays last respects to Ven. Dr. Pallegama Sirinivasa Thera
author: Author not found
Content: President Ranil Wickremesinghe paid his last respects to Anuradhapura Atamasthanadhipathi, North Central Province Chief Sangha Nayake, Most Venerable, the late Dr. Pallegama Sirinivasa Thera, on Saturday, 22 October. The President visited the Bodhimaluwa Viharaya, where the remains of the Most Venerable Dr. Pallegama Sirinivasa Thera were placed and paid his last respects and also signed the condolence book. Subsequently, President Wickremesinghe visited the Most Venerable Pallegama Hemarathana Nayaka Thera, at the Ruwanweli Saya Viharaya and inquired about the last rites of the late Most Venerable Dr. Pallegama Sirinivasa Thera. Former Minister S.M. Chandrasena, Presidential Senior Adviser on National Security and Chief of Presidential Staff Sagala Ratnayake, United National Party Chairman Vajira Abeywardena, Secretary General Palitha Range Bandara and several others were also present.

title: “Ask the Supreme Court also to go home” – MP Sumanthiran
author: Author not found
Content: TNA MP M.A. Sumanthiran speaking during the debate on the 22nd Amendment in Parliament recently said the confidence people have in Government institutions have eroded and that the Supreme Court, just as much as Parliament, ‘swings like a pendulum’. “The Supreme Court has also swung like a pendulum. In the 19th Amendment bill they permitted various changes, and said that this doesn’t require a referendum but now the same Supreme Court says you require a referendum. It’s not only the Parliament that swings like a pendulum, it’s the Supreme Court also. Change that Supreme Court also. Ask them also to go home. If they can’t read and understand their own determination in the 19th Amendment, you are showing the country something when it is not, and that is potentially harmful because the confidence people have in these institutions have eroded and have been totally destroyed. When they find Parliament has also misled us, it leads us to think that some major reform has to take place. When there is no reform, they will only take to the streets.” MP Sumanthiran also pointed out that many MPs have voted in favour of all 17th, 18th, 19th, 20th and 22nd Amendments, which contradict each other.  “Many members of this House voted for the 17th Amendment to the Constitution. The same members voted for the 18th Amendment. Those very members voted for the 19th Amendment and for the 20th Amendment. And today, they are all ready to vote for the 22nd Amendment to the Constitution. They are like a pendulum. They swing from one end to the other. “What type of Parliament is this? No wonder that the country says to be done with these 225. Why is this 22nd Amendment coming today? It is coming because people in the country want a system change, not tinkering with the Constitution. Some tinkering happened from the 17th onwards, but this bill before this House today doesn’t even tinker with the Constitution. If it’s passed it will still retain all the powers of the executive presidency, which is an absolute fraud. In 1994, the presidential election manifesto said the executive presidency would be abolished within six months. Six months has still not come. “Every other candidate at every other presidential election comes to the people and says ‘I will abolish the executive presidency’. You are lying to the people saying this is the first step towards that and in fact none of the powers of executive president was taken away by this Bill. It is a big lie and a hoax to say that the executive branch will be abolished and we will pass this before that.” (NV)

title: Army Signal Corps Mark 79th Anniversary
author: Author not found
Content: The Signal Corps of the Sri Lanka Army, a prestigious regiment which is the pioneer of communication and information technology of the Sri Lanka Army, celebrated its 79th anniversary recently. On 19 October 1943, the Signal Corps was established as a detachment of the Ceylon Defence Force. In 1951, it was reconstituted, formed as part of the Field Engineer Regiment, and commenced communication operations as a Signal Squadron. Later in 1958, 1 Regiment Signal Corps was established and consisted of two squadrons called Headquarters Squadron and 1st Operational Squadron. After Sri Lanka became a republic in 1972, the ‘Lanka Signal Corps’ was renamed as Sri Lanka Signal Corps. Eight officers and 264 other ranks of the Sri Lanka Army Signal Corps, who actively contributed to operational signal duties in the face of 30 years of war, sacrificed their lives for the motherland. Lending priority to commemorating the signal corps war heroes who sacrificed their lives during the humanitarian operation, a war hero memorial ceremony was held on October 15 with the participation of their next of kin. The anniversary programme prioritised religious rites for all the officers, other officers and civil servants serving in the signal corps and all their families who were disabled during the war. Afterwards, the signal corps soldiers participated in the dhamma sermon and pirith chanting ceremony and a heel daana was offered to 15 bhikkhus the next day. Furthermore, a charity service was also held. Moreover, the anniversary parade was accorded with a Guard turnout and a guard of honour presented to the Chief Signal Officer of the Sri Lanka Army and present colonel of the Regiment, Major General H.M.L.D. Herath. BY Dilanka Gunathilaka

title: Bad weather to continue till 26 Oct
author: Author not found
Content: The persisting inclement weather conditions will continue until 26 October, the Department of Meteorology predicted yesterday (23).  The Met Department added that a low pressure area that had developed near the South-east Bay of Bengal and North and South areas of Andaman seas on 21 October had been stationing there yesterday evening.  It is feared that the low pressure zone could turn into a cyclone today (24). Most parts of the seas surrounding the island would remain severely turbulent. The Met Department has issued an amber alert warning in this connection. The cyclone is expected to move towards the North and East direction and to reach the shore of Bangladesh tomorrow (25). The wind velocity is expected to be 40 to 50 kilometres per hour (kmph) while expecting the wind velocity to be 60 to 70 kmph in the seas between the North and East latitude. The fishermen and other seafarers operating in the seas across the country, especially in the Eastern seas have been instructed to be vigilant and to exercise cautiousness as heavy showers and turbulent seas are expected. Meanwhile, the prevailing inclement weather has wreaked havoc in several districts across the country, claiming the lives of six persons, causing injury to three and affecting 4,933 persons from 1,298 families, the Disaster Management Centre sources said yesterday. The highest number of 1,210 persons, from 299 families, had been affected in Thimbirigasyaya and Kaduwela DS divisions in the Colombo District as a result of flash floods. Hambantota, Galle, Trincoomalee, Ampara, Kilinochchi, Kalutara, Gampaha, Colombo, Ratnapura, Kegalle, Kandy, Nuwara Eliya and Kurunegala District were among them. One person has been reported to have gone missing from Gangawata Korale Divisional Secretariat (DS) Division in the Kandy District. The DMC sources said that a total number of 116 persons from 31 families displaced from Kolonnawa, Thimbirigasyaya, Kaduwela and Colombo DS divisions in the Colombo District, due to cutting failure and flash floods have been accommodated in four safety centres. A total number of nine properties had been fully damage and 381 partially while 13 small and medium enterprises were damaged along with four infrastructure facilities, DMC sources added. Meanwhile, Senior Scientist of the Landslide Early Warning Centre, of the National Building Research Organisation (NBRO) Dr. K. P. G. Wasantha Senadeera yesterday said that with the prevailing inclement weather conditions, level two amber watch and level one yellow watch early landslide warning alerts have been issued to 20 DS divisions in five districts across the country. The Kalutara, Nuwara Eliya, Galle, Ratnapura and Kegalle districts are among them, according to Dr. Senadeera. He said that level two amber watch landslide early warning alerts have been issued to Dodangoda, Bulathsinhala, Ingiriya, Palindanuwara and Walallawita DS divisions and the surrounding areas in the Kalutara District and Ambagamuwa DS Division and the surrounding areas in the Nuwara Eliya District. Level one yellow watch landslide early warning alerts have been issued to Baddegama DS Division and the surrounding areas in the Galle District, Agalawatta, Matugama and Millaniya DS divisions and the surrounding areas in the Kalutara District, Bulathkohupitiya, Dehiowita,  Ruwanwella, Mawanella, Deraniyagala, Yatiyantota, Warakapola and Mawanella DS divisions and the surrounding areas in the Kegalle District and Kuruwita, Nivithigala, Eheliyagoda, Ratnapura and Kalawana DS divisions and the surrounding areas in the Ratnapura District, according to Dr. Senadeera. The people in other hilly areas receiving more rain and who are vulnerable to landslides have been asked to be vigilant and to exercise caution over possible landslides in those areas. They have been instructed to inform the relevant authorities with immediate effect if they notice any landslide signs such as slanting of trees, telephone and light posts, appearance of sudden muddy water and springs and cracks on the wall of buildings and floors as well as in the neighbouring areas. The Meteorology Department yesterday predicted that showers or thundershowers could occur at times in the Western, Sabaragamuwa, Central, North Western, and Northern Provinces today (24). While commenting on current nature of atmosphere, Duty Meteorologist Srimal Herath predicted that heavy showers above 100 millimetres can be expected at some place in Sabaragamuwa and Western Provinces and the Galle and Matara Districts. Duty Meteorologist Herath further predicted that showers or thundershowers could occur elsewhere over the island during the after-noon or night. He also cautioned the public of possible temporary heavy winds and lightning strikes advising to take adequate precautionary measures in the event of such circumstances to minimise the damages caused by temporary localised heavy winds and lightning strikes. By Naalir Jamaldeen

title: Southern districts flooded after heavy rains
author: Author not found
Content: The Galle District Disaster Management Centre (DMC)reported that many low-lying areas in the Galle District have been flooded due to heavy rains. The Hapugala area of the Galle Vakwella main road has been inundated. Meanwhile, rainwater flooded the Kahaduwatta and Hirimbura areas of the Galle Baddegama main road. The villages of Rathgama Devinigoda, Kuligoda, Haliwala Medewala in the Rathgama Pramadeshiya Secretariat Division have been inundated as a result of the heavy rains, effecting many villages. Parts of Madampagama and Akurala has also flooded. Rainwater has inundated many houses in Rathgama and Madampagama regional secretariats, according to Galle District Secretary Shanta Virasinghe. According to the District Secretary, efforts are being made to open the Madampagama estuary. Piumida Silva, Gingaga Irrigation Engineer, said the water level in Gingaga River has also increased due to heavy rains. She also stated that the water level in the Gingage-Baddegama water gauge had risen to 3.88 metres by 6 a.m. yesterday (23). According to Silva, there has been minor flooding in the Baddegama District, and many low lands have been flooded. She also stated that the water is receding due to the opening of the floodgates of the Mahmodara and Gingthota estuaries. According to the Irrigation Engineer, the Gingaga Irrigation Scheme has ten pumping stations, all of which have been used to remove water from the protected areas. She went on to say that the protected area encompasses approximately 120,000 acres, and that most of the water is currently removed by pumping stations. Many low-lying areas of the Gingaga valley have been flooded and Koratu cultivation have been severely impacted as a result. BY Kamal Wijehewa – Galle

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: “Ask the Supreme Court also to go home” – MP Sumanthiran
author: Author not found
Content: TNA MP M.A. Sumanthiran speaking during the debate on the 22nd Amendment in Parliament recently said the confidence people have in Government institutions have eroded and that the Supreme Court, just as much as Parliament, ‘swings like a pendulum’. “The Supreme Court has also swung like a pendulum. In the 19th Amendment bill they permitted various changes, and said that this doesn’t require a referendum but now the same Supreme Court says you require a referendum. It’s not only the Parliament that swings like a pendulum, it’s the Supreme Court also. Change that Supreme Court also. Ask them also to go home. If they can’t read and understand their own determination in the 19th Amendment, you are showing the country something when it is not, and that is potentially harmful because the confidence people have in these institutions have eroded and have been totally destroyed. When they find Parliament has also misled us, it leads us to think that some major reform has to take place. When there is no reform, they will only take to the streets.” MP Sumanthiran also pointed out that many MPs have voted in favour of all 17th, 18th, 19th, 20th and 22nd Amendments, which contradict each other.  “Many members of this House voted for the 17th Amendment to the Constitution. The same members voted for the 18th Amendment. Those very members voted for the 19th Amendment and for the 20th Amendment. And today, they are all ready to vote for the 22nd Amendment to the Constitution. They are like a pendulum. They swing from one end to the other. “What type of Parliament is this? No wonder that the country says to be done with these 225. Why is this 22nd Amendment coming today? It is coming because people in the country want a system change, not tinkering with the Constitution. Some tinkering happened from the 17th onwards, but this bill before this House today doesn’t even tinker with the Constitution. If it’s passed it will still retain all the powers of the executive presidency, which is an absolute fraud. In 1994, the presidential election manifesto said the executive presidency would be abolished within six months. Six months has still not come. “Every other candidate at every other presidential election comes to the people and says ‘I will abolish the executive presidency’. You are lying to the people saying this is the first step towards that and in fact none of the powers of executive president was taken away by this Bill. It is a big lie and a hoax to say that the executive branch will be abolished and we will pass this before that.” (NV)

title: Overall Inflation Accelerates to 73.7%
author: Author not found
Content: Countrywide inflation year on year (YoY) accelerated for the sixth consecutive month to 73.7 per cent last month (September 2022), from 70.2 per cent in the previous month (August 2022), Census and Statistics Department (CSD) statistics released on Friday (21), showed. Complementing these developments, both food and non-food inflation accelerated for the twelfth consecutive month to last month, with food inflation hitting a new record high of 85.8 per cent, YoY, up from 84.6 per cent in August and non-food inflation, continuing to soar past 50 per cent for the third consecutive month to last month, accelerating by 62.8 per cent from, 57.1 per cent registered in August 2022. Consequently a family’s living expenses, YoY to last month increased by Rs 34,953.06; compared to a negligible Rs 2,764.40 YoY increase a year ago in September 2021, up 1,164.40 per cent (Rs 32,188.66), since. The drivers of inflation were food inflation increasing by Rs 19,376.44 YoY last month and non-food inflation by Rs 15,576.62 during the same period. Food and non-food inflation make up overall inflation. The top seven YoY boost given to food inflation last month were led by a family’s rice budget increasing by Rs 3,501.22, milk powder (Rs 2,008.33), vegetables (Rs 1,598.85), fresh fish (Rs 1,554), bread (Rs 891.99), chicken (Rs 874.71) and dry fish (Rs 797.33). Meanwhile, the top seven non-food inflationary leaders eating into a family’s overall budget last month were the YoY increase in their petrol bill by Rs 1,512.85, bus fare (Rs 1,158.14), household maintenance material costs (Rs 1,063.45), health (Rs 937.72), clothing and footwear (Rs 878.86),  toilet soap (Rs 798.18) and electricity bill (Rs 730.16). The YoY increase in a family’s living expenses has been over Rs 30,000 for a record three months to last month, beginning with July 2022. BY Paneetha Ameresekere

title: Presidential pardon for eight ex-LTTE cadres
author: Author not found
Content: Eight ex-LTTE cadres, who had been in detention for a long period of time over their alleged involvement in LTTE activities, have received a Presidential pardon. According to Prisons Spokesman Chandana Ekanayake, this special pardon was granted in accordance with the powers granted to the President by Article 34 of the Constitution. As a result, four LTTE cadres held in Magazine Prison were released on 21 October. He stated that two other LTTE cadres would be released following the withdrawal of pending cases in the Court of Appeal. In addition, the other two cadres will be released once the rehabilitation process is completed. He stated that it was referred to the Attorney General and that he will follow the AG’s instructions. (TR)

title: Snatch thief killed in Police shooting
author: Author not found
Content: One person died when Police opened fire at two suspects who were on the run after snatching a necklace from a person in Negombo, Police said.  According to the Police, the two suspects had been riding a motorcycle and they had attempted to shoot at the Police.  However, the Police opened fire at the two suspects to restrain them. In the shooting, the two suspects were injured and admitted to hospital.  One of the suspects died on admission while the other is currently receiving treatment at the Negombo Hospital.  The two suspects are aged 22 and 25. BY Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: Duo arrested over Rs 2M robbery
author: Author not found
Content: Two suspects were arrested on 22 October for abducting, assaulting, and robbing a person in Moratuwa, Police said. An employee of a store in Moratuwa was robbed while he was on his way to a bank with over two million rupees in cash, Police said. The suspects had abducted the employee and assaulted him on 4 October. Mt. Lavinia Police arrested a 45-year-old and 50-year-old residents of Ratmalana and Mt. Lavinia on 22 October. A van, motorcycle, three-wheeler, and sharp weapons were also seized by the Police. Police are conducting further investigations. By Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: Police cautions against bathing in rivers, etc
author: Author not found
Content: Police requested the public to avoid bathing in rivers, waterfalls, reservoirs and the sea due to the prevailing weather condition. Issuing a statement, the Police Media Division requested the public to be cautious and take precautions when engaging in activities or trips near the rivers and waterfalls. They requested the public to act according to the instructions given by the lifeguards and community Police officers who are on duty near waterfalls, lakes, rivers and beaches. “The general public is requested to avoid drinking alcohol and bathing in the above mentioned places as much as possible, and especially to avoid sending children to those places and also to pay attention to the warning notice displayed in those places with care,” it was stated. BY Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: 43 nabbed over illegal migration attempt
author: Author not found
Content: Habaraduwa Police arrested 43 persons for attempting to leave for Australia illegally. The arrests were made by the Habaraduwa Police andSL Navy yesterday (23) while the suspects were staying in a hotel in Unawatuna. The suspects are residents of Jaffna, and included 33 men, seven women and three children. It was reported that the group had been staying at various places for about a month hoping to go to Australia from Pulmude. Accordingly, the group had taken a bus from Vavuniya and travelled to Unawatuna claiming that they were on a five-day trip. BY Farhan Nizamdin – Galle and S. Diyagahage – Ahangama

title: Xi Jinping secures third term in power
author: Author not found
Content: China wrapped up its twice-a-decade leadership reshuffle on Sunday (23), with Xi Jinping securing a third term as general secretary of the ruling Communist Party and packing the new Politburo Standing Committee with allies. The precedent-breaking third term for Xi secures his place as China’s most powerful leader since Mao Zedong, founder of the People’s Republic of China. Here are key takeaways from the 20th party congress: The new seven-man Politburo Standing Committee is made up entirely of Xi loyalists, including Shanghai party chief Li Qiang, who is on track to replace Li Keqiang as premier in March. Breaking with a tradition of factional checks and balances stretching back to Mao’s death in 1976, Xi installed a leadership configuration of loyalists at the extreme end of predictions. Some analysts had expected – or hoped for – the inclusion of a token member not allied with Xi. Three of the four new Standing Committee members owe their political rise to Xi, and the fourth is believed to be closely aligned with him. All but Guangdong party chief Li Xi worked under Xi in the 2000s, either in affluent Zhejiang province or in Shanghai. They were promoted during or after their time with Xi, a clear sign that they had earned his trust and benefited from his patronage. “It’s truly remarkable in the sense that it’s almost like a break from the past 40 plus years. Xi is the Chinese leader who really got to pick his own team,” said Dali Yang, professor of political science at the University of Chicago. “We see victory of (the) ‘Zhejiang army’ – persons close to Xi Jinping who shared career paths with him in that province – and the elimination of what little may have remained of other factions,” said Bates Gill, executive director of the Centre for China Analysis at the Asia Society Policy Institute in New York. Having packed his leadership team with allies, and with the party constitution amended to enshrine Xi’s authority and ideas as its “core”, Xi has an entirely free hand to make and implement policy, for better or worse. That means that if things backfire, it is harder to shift blame, analysts say. It also risks creating an echo chamber of group-think, where alternative voices aren’t heard and critical feedback is withheld. Yang Zhang, assistant professor in the School of International Service at American University, said Xi’s “autocracy may provoke stronger international pushback from the U.S.-led Western countries. All of these scenarios will make his third and likely fourth terms not as easy as expected.” Xi opened the congress with a speech indicating continuity in policy direction even as he rebranded his vision for the path ahead as “Chinese-style modernisation” and emphasised security in an increasingly dangerous world. Ja Ian Chong, a political scientist at National University Of Singapore, said the outcome of the party congress likely means more Chinese assertiveness in foreign policy and security. “So, probably more direct party-state direction of the economy,” Chong said. Alvin Tan, head of Asia FX Strategy at RBC Capital Markets in Singapore, predicted Xi’s harsh zero-COVID eradication strategy would like become “more entrenched”. Xi’s appointment to a third term was not his only breaking of the norms that long guided China’s elite politics. By excluding Li Keqiang and Wang Yang, both 67, from the party Central Committee and Standing Committee, Xi broke with the “seven-up/eight-down” rule that those aged 67 or under would remain for another five years. He also without explanation shrank the Politburo to 24 from 25 people – the odd number meant that there could be a tie-breaker on close votes. “With Xi practising ‘one-man-politics’, there’s no longer any need for a tie-breaker, everyone will vote according to what Xi wants,” said Alfred Wu, associate professor at the National University of Singapore. There is also no woman on the Politburo for the first time in 20 years. No woman has ever made it onto the Standing Committee. When Xi joined the Standing Committee in 2007, it was clear from his age and from the makeup of the committee that he was on track to replace Hu Jintao, who held China’s top post of party general secretary, once Hu’s second term ended in 2012. There has been no heir-apparent since Xi assumed power, and he kept it that way on Sunday. None of the Standing Committee newcomers are young enough to take over in 2027 and serve two terms after that under the norms of Chinese politics. The youngest is Ding Xuexiang, who is 60. The absence of a clear successor indicates that Xi may want to remain beyond three terms, increasing policy risk and unpredictability the longer he is in power, analysts say. The lack of a successor creates key-man risk – Xi is 69 – and undermines the orderly leadership transition norms that were put in place after the 1966-1976 Cultural Revolution to avoid a repeat of Mao’s struggles to hold power indefinitely. (Reuters)

title: Food banks to be set up in religious places
author: Author not found
Content: Steps have been taken to set up food banks and food exchange centres focusing on religious places to ensure food security and improve the nutritional status of the people. This was said at the Progress Review Meeting of the Food Safety and Nutrition Assurance Programme, which was held virtually under the chairmanship of Presidential Adviser on Food Security, Dr. Suren Batagoda. The programme will be implemented covering all 14,000 Grama Seva divisions in the island focusing on religious places at the District Secretariat and Divisional Secretariat level under the supervision of the Ministry of Buddhasasana and Religious Affairs. The food exchange centres set up in these areas will collect excess food from households and deliver them to foodbanks to be distributed among families facing food shortages. Also, through these food exchange centres, residents will have the opportunity to exchange their surplus food with residents of other areas who also have excess food, thereby preventing wastage. It was also discussed about enlisting the help of the clergy to make this programme a success, as they have a better understanding of the living conditions of the people in their areas. In addition to the instructions and provisions of the Circulars currently issued, the new Circular issued by the Ministry of Public Administration and Home Affairs, Provincial Councils and Local Government on how to prepare economic revival centres and their development plan was also discussed. District Secretaries and Planning Directors joined this discussion.

title: Three Jaffna residents flee to Dhanushkodi
author: Author not found
Content: Three of a family from Jaffna reached Indian waters on an illegal vessel in the early hours of Saturday. The Mandapam Police said Shanti, 42, wife of Jayam, and her son Ajanthan, 17, and daughter Surabi, 11, had hired a fibre boat at the Talaimannar jetty at 11:00 p.m. on Friday and reached the third islet, near Dhanushkodi, where they were stranded. On information from some fishermen, Police rescued them and took them to the Mandapam Police Station. The family members, who were looking tired, said they had sold all their belongings and paid the boatman to reach India after their attempts to survive in the island nation failed with the skyrocketing prices. “We have no job. Essential goods are either unavailable or highly priced,” Shanti said, adding that since they were unsure about when the economic crisis would come to an end, they fled the country. After investigations, Police handed them over to the Mandapam Rehabilitation Camp. According to camp sources, 185 people, including women and children from different parts of Sri Lanka, have been staying at the camp after reaching India illegally by sea. They are given food and shelter by the Tamil Nadu Government. One elderly woman died a month ago of age-related ailments, the sources added. (The Hindu)

title: Seven arrested taking pictures of Victoria Dam
author: Author not found
Content: Seven persons were arrested for recording videos and taking pictures, with a drone camera, in the high security zone of the Victoria Dam, without permission. The arrests were made by the Theldeniya Police on Saturday (22). The suspects were illegally taking pictures of the dam and the surrounding area without permission from the relevant authorities. They were arrested by the military deployed to the scene and handed over to the Police. All suspects are aged 31-32 years and have been identified as residents of Weligama and Dehiwala. BY Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: Itukama Fund Winds Up
author: Author not found
Content: A decision has been taken to wind up operations of the Itukama ‘Covid-19 Health and Social Security Fund’, which was established to provide relief to those affected by the Covid-19 pandemic, and Cabinet approval has been obtained for it. Secretary of the Fund, Dr. Tharaka Liyanapathirana notified the public that the ‘Covid-19 Health and Social Security Fund’ at the Bank of Ceylon, account number 85737373 was closed with effect from 18 October and requested the public not to donate to the fund any more. He also notified donors not to send cheques or money towards the fund.  The Secretary lauded donors who contributed to the fund, thanking them for making the islandwide programme a success. The fund had received a total of Rs  2,207,164,785.58 in donations. Out of this sum, Rs 1,997,569,456.56 had been used to provide facilities for PCR tests, conduct awareness programmes, quarantine activities, the national vaccination programme and to purchase beds for intensive care units and medicines. As of October 18, 2022, the sum remaining in the Covid Fund was Rs 216,877,431.05, which has been credited to the President’s Fund to provide for surgery and medical aid assistance.

title: Wijeyadasa complains to CID about Fb post
author: Author not found
Content: A complaint was lodged with the CID, by Minister of Justice Dr. Wijeyadasa Rajapakshe, regarding a post published on Facebook. The said Facebook post had alleged that the special treatment was being provided to a certain remand prisoner through the Minister. The Justice Minister, in a letter to the CID Director, said, such kinds of posts bring the entire law enforcement system, including the judiciary, into a state of ridicule and contempt.  “The false and malicious post, regarding a pending case, has caused severe prejudice to the entire legal system and warrants remedial action. It also affects the integrity of the judicial system and the criminal justice process in Sri Lanka. Since it refers to an on-going case in the Fort Magistrate’s Court, it tarnishes the legal system of Sri Lanka and creates a prejudice in the minds of the people at large,” Rajapakshe said. The Minister, therefore, called on the CID to conduct an inquiry into the matter and report it to the Fort Magistrate as soon as possible.

title: Schools to have uninterrupted water supply
author: Author not found
Content: The decision to interrupt the water supply to schools that have not paid water bills has been revised. This decision was reached based on instructions given by Minister of Education, Dr. Susil Premajayantha following a lengthy discussion held with the Chairman of the Water Supply Board. The Minister of Education also assured that measures will be taken to in future pay the bills and based on that, the Water Supply Board has decided not to disconnect water supply in any school until then.

title: Sirisena ordered to make submissions before 31 October
author: Author not found
Content: Colombo District Court Judge Poornima Paranagama on Wednesday (19) ordered former President Maithripala Sirisena, to make submissions to Court before 31 October. This was in connection with the lawsuit, filed by Minister of Ports, Shipping and Aviation Nimal Siripala de Silva, who has prayed the District Court, to issue an order to invalidate the arbitrary decision, taken by the SLFP, to remove him from his party posts. The District Court Judge gave this order, having perused a request made to her by President’s Counsel Faiszer Musthapha, who represented the respondent SLFP Chairman, when the case was taken up yesterday. A Counsel did not represent the second respondent, SLFP General Secretary Dayasiri Jayasekara and accordingly the Court, noticed the respondent concerned, to produce submissions also on the said date. The Minister via his lawsuit has informed the Court, that the SLFP had unilaterally convened a clandestine party meeting, on2 September. He said during that illegal discussion, the SLFP General Secretary, through new powers vested in him, had proceeded to remove the petitioner from his party posts, having amended the party constitution unlawfully. De Silva mentioned that a clandestine meeting, convened by the party has no legal power or approval to amend the party constitution, according to their own whims and fancies. Hence, the petitioner prayed the Court, to issue an order to the respondents concerned, preventing them from removing him from his party posts and to prohibit the respondents and their representatives from hindering his work at the party. By Hansi Nanayakkara

title: SLFP will support 22A – Sirisena
author: Author not found
Content: The Sri Lanka Freedom Party (SLFP) will support the 22nd Amendment to the Constitution, as it is a progressive amendment, on the part of the people, former President Maithripala Sirisena said yesterday (20). Speaking during the Parliamentary debate on the 22nd Amendment to the Constitution, Sirisena said the above decision does not strengthen the current Government. However, the 22nd Amendment is a good step from the people’s side, therefore, we will vote in favour of it, he said. While claiming that the U.K. Parliament has been ruling the country for hundreds of years without a written Constitution, Sirisena said that the Constitution of Sri Lanka has been amended twenty-two times, and most of the amendments were not made according to the needs of the people. “The issues faced by the people of the country would not be resolved by passing amendments alone. The government must give attention to resolve the current issues. We hope that the 22nd Amendment would strengthen democracy, public service and restructure corrupt State institution,” he said. BY Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: GCEC laws to be enacted – President
author: Author not found
Content: President Ranil Wickremesinghe emphasised that in order to encourage foreign investment, the laws that had been introduced under the Greater Colombo Economic Commission (GCEC) will be re-enacted to introduce an efficient system replacing the existing slow process. The President revealed this when addressing a gathering at the Mireka Tower Opening Ceremony, at Havelock City in Wellawatte yesterday (20), where he was the Chief Guest. The President also said, immediate measures are being taken to create an investment-friendly environmentin Sri Lanka and to create economic stability. The President further said, he had already appointed a committee to bring the Board of Investment (BOI), the Export Development Board (EDB) and the Sri Lanka Export Credit Insurance Corporation (SLECIC) together, onto one platform and establish one investment promotion agency to encourage foreign investment in Sri Lanka. He added that Sri Lanka needs to be made an investor-friendly country to attract foreign revenue and get out of the vicious cycle of foreign borrowing.

title: SJB to support 22A if implemented unchanged
author: Author not found
Content: If the contents of the 22nd Amendment to the Constitution are implemented without being changed according to personal preferences, the Samagi Jana Balawegaya (SJB) will support it, said Opposition Leader Sajith Premadasa. Speaking in Parliament yesterday (20) Premadasa said, his party will agree to support the 22nd Amendment, only on three conditions. In particular, the power of the President should be reduced to some extent, he said. Additionally, rules and regulations related to dual citizenship should remain unchanged. President has the power of dissolution for two and a half years and it should be implemented without any change, he said. Premadasa said, that they will only agree to the 22nd Amendment only if the above conditions are agreed by the government. He said, if anyone attempts to sabotage or change the mentioned requests, they would vote against the Bill. He also said, that as the Opposition they would not attempt to disagree with everything that government implies. He said that he will do his best for the people while staying in the Opposition. BY Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: Wheat flour down by Rs 25
author: Author not found
Content: The wholesale market price of a kilogramme of wheat flour has dropped by Rs 25. While confirming this, Nihal Seneviratne, the media spokesman for the Importers of Essential Materials Association, stated that a kilogramme of wheat flour costs Rs 265. He said, the price reduction went into effect on Wednesday (19).  Previously, the wholesale price of a kilogramme of wheat flour was Rs. 290, but it has been reduced by Rs 25.

title: Wijeyadasa complains to CID about Fb post
author: Author not found
Content: A complaint was lodged with the CID, by Minister of Justice Dr. Wijeyadasa Rajapakshe, regarding a post published on Facebook. The said Facebook post had alleged that the special treatment was being provided to a certain remand prisoner through the Minister. The Justice Minister, in a letter to the CID Director, said, such kinds of posts bring the entire law enforcement system, including the judiciary, into a state of ridicule and contempt.  “The false and malicious post, regarding a pending case, has caused severe prejudice to the entire legal system and warrants remedial action. It also affects the integrity of the judicial system and the criminal justice process in Sri Lanka. Since it refers to an on-going case in the Fort Magistrate’s Court, it tarnishes the legal system of Sri Lanka and creates a prejudice in the minds of the people at large,” Rajapakshe said. The Minister, therefore, called on the CID to conduct an inquiry into the matter and report it to the Fort Magistrate as soon as possible.

title: FR Petitions filed against attack on protesters
author: Author not found
Content: A Fundamental Rights (FR) Petition was filed before the Supreme Court yesterday (20) against the assault by Police on protesters during an anti-Government protest organised by the Socialist Youth Union on 24 September. The Petitions were filed by two Lawyers. They stated that notice was duly given in terms of Section 77(1) of the Police Ordinance No.16 of 1865 in regard to the said protest noting that the said assault resulted in a violation of fundamental rights. They noted however, that a large number of Police Officers barricaded the protesters’ way near the premises of the Ministry of Health, adding that when the Police was questioned as to why the protest was being blocked, they started firing water cannon which was followed by firing of tear gas without an explanation. The Petitioners said, thereafter the Police started attacking the protesters with batons, adding that six protesters, who sustained injuries due to the attack by Police had to be admitted to hospital. Further, they observed that the protest march was a peaceful and therefore there was no reasonable ground for the Police to apprehend any breach of the peace or obstruction of the day to day activities of the public and deprivation of the human rights of the public due to the said protest march. Among other, petitioners sought to grant compensation in sum of one million rupees and leave to proceed with the application. BY Faadhila Thassim

title: Agri Sector allays fertiliser fears
author: Author not found
Content: Secretary of the Ministry of Agriculture, Rohana Pushpakumara said measures have been taken to release urea required for paddy cultivation in the Maha season without any hindrance. He said fertiliser is provided in several stages for this Maha season, adding that the Department of Agriculture has recommended the use of 70 per cent chemical fertiliser and 30 per cent organic fertiliser for paddy cultivation this year.  “Generally, for  paddy cultivation, urea is applied 14 days after sowing or planting, the second phase is applied after four weeks and the third is applied between 42 and 45 days after sowing or planting the seedlings”, he said. Pushpakumara said however farmers were demanding to provide fertiliser for all three phases at once noting however that there was insufficient urea to provide farmers the entire requirement in one go.  “The urea required for the first phase has already been given to all Agrarian Development Centres. Apart from the Northern and Eastern Provinces, paddy cultivation for the Maha season has not yet commenced in other Districts, but urea fertiliser required for the first phase has already been sent to farmers”, he said Pushpakumara said at present, over 21,000 MT of urea purchased for paddy in the Yala season is available and 12,500 MT of fertiliser ordered for the Maha season will be delivered on 25 October and another 120,000 metric tons of urea will be delivered by 20 November.  “Therefore, not getting fertiliser for the second and third phases was out of the question, while 40,000 MT of MOP fertiliser (Muriate of Potash fertiliser) required will be received by the end of November,” Pushpakumara further said.

title: US Asst Secy of State calls on Ali Sabry
author: Author not found
Content: Visiting Assistant Secretary of State for South and Central Asian Affairs Donald Lu met Foreign Minister Ali Sabry among many others and discussed on the importance of economic reforms, accountability, and ways in which the United States and Sri Lanka can promote economic stability, regional security, human rights, and responsive, transparent, and inclusive governance. US Envoy Julie Chung tweeted that US diplomat Lu met Sri Lankan Government officials and community leaders to build on the support the US has provided Sri Lanka in ensuring a brighter future for all its citizens and also looks forward to continuing its long-standing partnership as democracies with shared interests and values. She also said for a strong civil society, it is critical for any democracy in serving and advocating for marginalised communities. Civil society leaders also met Lu to discuss present challenges and how they could work together to promote accountability and inclusive governance in Sri Lanka. Assistant Secretary Lu visited Sri Lanka from 17-19 October to discuss US-Sri Lanka relations and Sri Lanka’s economic situation. By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: Five teens saved from drowning
author: Author not found
Content: Sri Lanka Coastguard (SLCG) life savers, attached to the Life Saving post at Mt Lavinia beach, saved five children from drowning while bathing at sea on Sunday (16), the SLCG said. They added that the rescued, all boys, aged between 16 and 17 years, were residents of the Piliyandala and Bandaragama areas. SLCG, an adjunct of the Sri Lanka Navy, since the establishment of its Life Saving Division after the LTTE war ended on 18 May 2009, has thus far rescued a total of 1,768 persons, including 760 foreigners, in life saving operations conducted countrywide, it said. (PA)
