title: Indian trawler seized
author: Author not found
Content: Sri Lanka Navy (SLN) in anti-fisher poaching patrols, seized an Indian trawler together with three Indian fishers on Wednesday night (19), the Navy said yesterday (20). The operation took place in the Northern waters, off the Kovilan Lighthouse, Karainagar. SLN deployed a fast attack craft for this purpose. The seized trawler together with the three Indian fishers were brought to the Kankesanthurai Harbour and will be handed over to the Myladi Fisheries Inspector, Jaffna for legal proceedings, it said. (PA)

title: Health sector needs complete overhaul – MCPA
author: Author not found
Content: Doctors urged the National Council sub-committee, on identifying short and medium-term programmes related to economic stabilisation, to enhance the production of pharmaceuticals by regulating and increasing the efficiency of the National Medicines Regulatory Authority (NMRA), the State Pharmaceutical Corporation and the State Pharmaceutical Manufacturing Corporation (SPMC). President of the Medical and Civil Rights Professional Association of Doctors (MCPA), Dr. Chamal Sanjeewa said his outfit had written to the sub-committee, submitting several reforms to the health service. “Our trade union believes that there is a possibility to develop the health system in a practical manner at a time when the country is facing serious economic crisis,” he said. Dr. Sanjeewa said that his team was prepared to give any backing the sub-committee requires and the Health Ministry to formulate a practical programme to procure the medical drugs and consumables that are in short supply through discussions with the government of India. A legal method should be followed to expedite obtaining pharmaceuticals rather than following the time consuming traditional method of procuring pharmaceuticals through a tender procedure. The MCPA President said Medical tourism should be developed in collaboration with Ayurveda health care as soon as possible. He said foreign nationals could be invited to follow medical procedures in Sri Lanka with the development of select hospitals. Dr.Sanjeewa also proposed the formation of a committee comprising Health trade union activists rather than the current policy of the Health Ministry to work with only a select group of health trade unions. He said measures should also be taken to overcome corruption in the Health Ministry and streamline its administrative structure. Instead of appointing hospital administrators for political reasons, younger specialist medical administrators who could contribute towards the country’s development should be appointed, he observed. By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: Indonesian Buddhist Associations donate medical needs
author: Author not found
Content: The Buddhist Associations of Indonesia, namely the Indonesian Buddhists’ Representatives Association (WALUBI), Indonesian Theravada Buddhist Council (MAGABUDHI), Women Theravada Buddhist Group (WANDANI) and Theravada Youth Buddhist Association (PATRIA) donated medicines and medical equipment to a total value of USD 19,296.11 to the people of Sri Lanka in June and August 2022.  The Embassy dispatched the medicines to Sri Lanka in coordination with the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, Ministry of Health, Sri Lankan Airlines and Expolanka.   The donation was officially handed over to the Ambassador of Sri Lanka to Indonesia and ASEAN Yasoja Gunasekera at the Embassy premises. Accepting the donation, Ambassador Gunasekera expressed gratitude and sincere thanks to the Buddhist Associations of Indonesia for the generous gesture which is much needed for the people of Sri Lanka at this difficult time.  The Buddhist Associations of Indonesia is also in the process of coordinating with the National Cancer Institute (Apeksha Hospital) to donate medicines and medical devices which are specifically needed by the hospital.

title: Liz Truss quits as PM after just 45 days
author: Author not found
Content: Liz Truss has dramatically resigned as Prime Minister after just 45 days in the job. The PM said her successor will be elected in a Tory leadership contest, to be completed in the next week. Tory MPs urged Truss to go after her Government was engulfed by political turmoil, following the ditching of most of her economic policies. Truss was elected by the Tory membership in September, but she lost authority after a series of U-turns. In a brief speech outside Downing Street, Truss said the Conservative Party had elected her on a mandate to cut taxes and boost economic growth. But given the situation, Truss said: “I recognise that I cannot deliver the mandate on which I was elected by the Conservative Party.” (BBC)

title: Sabarullah Khan presents credentials to Sultan of Oman
author: Author not found
Content: The newly-appointed Ambassador Extraordinary and Plenipotentiary of Sri Lanka to the Sultanate of Oman, A. L. Sabarullah Khan presented his Letter of Credence to Sultan Haitham bin Tarik, of the Sultanate of Oman, on 18 October 2022 at Al Barakah Palace, Muscat. During the audience with the Sultan, immediately after the presentation of the credentials, the Ambassador conveyed greetings of the President of Sri Lanka. While referring to the cordial relations between Sri Lanka and Oman, the Ambassador expressed his gratitude for the continuous support of the Government of Oman to Sri Lanka including recent donation of medical items and affirmed to exert his utmost efforts in promoting the bilateral relations in multiple domains in a manner that serves the joint interests of both the countries. The Sultan welcomed the Ambassador, expressing his thanks for the greetings and best wishes of the President of Sri Lanka. The ceremony was attended by the Minister of Diwan of Royal Court, Foreign Minister, the Head of the Royal Protocols, the Commander of the Royal Guard of Oman and the Military Aides to the Sultan. The Ambassador was accompanied by Dilini Abeysekara, Counsellor of the Embassy and his Daughter. Ambassador Sabarullah Khan is a career diplomat, who joined the Sri Lanka Foreign Service in 1994. He earlier served in the Sri Lanka Missions in Amman, Bangkok, New Delhi, Riyadh, Jeddah, Abu Dhabi, Chennai and New York in various capacities. He last served as the High Commissioner of Sri Lanka to Nigeria. In the Foreign Ministry, he served in the Consular, Protocol, Economic Affairs and Political Affairs desks and last held the position of Additional Secretary.

title: President tries first locally grown green apples
author: Author not found
Content: The first harvest of a green apple plantation in Sri Lanka was presented to President Ranil Wickremesinghe yesterday (20) at the Presidential Secretariat. Farmer M.P. Lakshman Kumara has cultivated green apples on two acres of land in Thambuttegama, Galgamuwa. The President inquired about the plantation and said that he intends to visit the apple farm in the near future. Kumara told the President that the apple seeds were imported to Sri Lanka and planted following proper testing and that it is possible to popularise growing green apples locally as the seeds have been produced in a manner that they can be cultivated in any part of Sri Lanka. Having accepted the green apples presented to him, the President also made it a point to taste them.  Senior Presidential Adviser on National Security and Chief of Presidential Staff Sagala Ratnayake, former Minister of State Champika Premadasa and P.J. Asanka Lionel were present during this occasion.

title: NATIONAL POLICY FOR CHILDREN WITH SPECIAL NEEDS VITAL – CHILDREN’S CAUCUS
author: Author not found
Content: Parliament Children’s Caucus focused on the need to formulate a national policy to ensure the well-being of children with special needs in Sri Lanka. Views in this regard were expressed when the Caucus met in Parliament under the chairmanship of MP Rohini Kumari Wijerathna. Views and suggestions of members on future work of the Caucus regarding the well-being of children in this country also received special attention. Accordingly, it was decided to have extensive discussions with the Ministry of Women and Child Affairs and other affiliated institutions, Children and Women Bureau and representatives of the United Nations International Children’s Emergency Fund (UNICEF) and extensive discussions on the problems and proposals related to child care. Various fields relating to children in the country were also given attention whilst providing quality education to children, providing adequate health care, to make existing resources and officials more efficient, to identify environments before children get abused and implementing measures, ensuring access to nutrition and creating opportunities for children to develop their potential were also looked into. It was further emphasised that finding solutions to the problems of rural, urban and plantation children should be looked at individually. Caucus members agreed to work with State officials and non-governmental organisations related to children prioritising ideas and suggestions of provincial commissioners using new technology. They however, expressed their displeasure about the use of media in situations where children were directly affected and focused on the need to create a  programme and policy together with the relevant Minister. In addition, the need to create an awareness programme on child malnutrition was also discussed. MPs Velu Kumar, co-vice president of the Caucus, Thalatha Athukorala, Dr. Sudarshini Fernandopulle, K. Sujith Sanjaya Perera, Weerasumana Weerasinghe, Diana Gamage and Manjula Dissanayake were present at the meeting.

title: Pre-Trial Conference set for 30 November
author: Author not found
Content: Colombo High Court Judge Navaratne Marasinghe on Wednesday (19) fixed the Pre-Trial Conference, related to the case filed against former Fisheries Minister Dr. Rajitha Senaratne and two others, for 30 November. The three accused have been charged before the High Court, over the leasing of Modera Fisheries Harbour to a private firm, for a small sum and causing a loss of revenue to the State via their actions, during the previous UNF Government. When the case was taken up, the Counsel representing the former Minister sought Court’s approval to withdraw a motion. The Judge granted approval to the defence, to withdraw the motion and fixed the Pre-Trial Conference for the said date. Besides the SJB MP, the others named as accused in the case, are former Chairman of the Fisheries Corporation Upali Liyanage and its former Managing Director Neil Munasinghe. The Commission to Investigate Allegations of Bribery or Corruption (CIABOC) had indicted the three accused before the High Court, on five counts and for having flouted the Penal Code and Bribery Act, on 20 August 2020, over their actions which had been committed from 1 August to 1 November, eight years ago. The prosecution has also submitted 17 witnesses and 55 Court productions, to further substantiate the charges filed against the three accused. By Hansi Nanayakkara

title: Opposition Parties, FSP ink MoU
author: Author not found
Content: Opposition political parties in Parliament and the Frontline Socialist Party (FSP) signed a Memorandum of Understanding (MoU) to defeat the attempt by the Government to postpone the local government elections. The MoU was signed in accordance with the recent agreement of all the Opposition Parties. A discussion with regard to the matter was held in a Committee room at Parliament yesterday (20), and all the Opposition Parties in Parliament except Jathika Jana Balawegaya (JJB) participated in the discussion. The meeting was organised by ‘Nidahasa Janatha Sabhawa’. During the discussion, former President and SLFP Chairman Maithripala Sirisena said, all the Opposition Parties in Parliament decided to defeat the attempts of the Government not to hold Local Government elections within a Constitutional framework.

title: Australia sends back 183 Lankans
author: Author not found
Content: A total of 183 Sri Lankan nationals, who had been seeking asylum in Australia, were sent back, said Commander Maritime Border Command and Commander of Joint Task Agency Task Force, Operation Sovereign Borders, Rear Admiral Justin Jones. Rear Admiral Jones, who earlier participated in the Heads of Asian Coast Guard Agencies Meeting in Delhi, working with regional partners on civil maritime security, said these are from six irregular maritime ventures that attempted to reach Australia. Jones said the Sri Lankan nationals are trying to enter Australia in fishing boats which are not seaworthy. “It takes around 21 days to reach Australia from Sri Lanka,” he said. “We will stop any maritime people smuggling vessels seeking to reach Australia, and safely return those on board to their point of departure or country of origin, or if required, transfer them to a regional processing country,” Rear Admiral Jones said. “We are aware that several people were recently detained in Kerala for attempting to migrate illegally by boat. I commend the relevant authorities for their swift action, a vital step towards dismantling the criminal people smuggling trade,” Rear Admiral Jones added. (The New Indian Express)

title: Debris will be taken out of the country – Harbour Master
author: Author not found
Content: The salvage tug De Tian and Barge Ke Li of China’s Shanghai Salvage Company (SSC) entered the wreck site of the X-Press Pearl off the coast of Bopitiya yesterday (19) to remove the salvageable wreck from the country while the Government continues to hold discussions for compensation from the X-Press Pearl insurer for the environmental disaster it had caused. It was a US company that has hired the SSC to move out the piled up wreck from the sea which will be conducted using advanced technology and experienced divers.  The Chinese salvage was hired to remove wreckage from the sea and to move it out of the country. The two vessels arrived yesterday for the purpose, noted Sri Lanka Ports Authority Habour Master, Captain Nimal P. Silva. According to him, the salvage is expected to be completed before the next South West monsoon.     Shanghai Salvage Company (SCC) has been signed to remove the burned-out wreck of the X-Press Pearl last year. The Xpress Pearl caught fire in May 2021 off the coast of Sri Lanka, and the blaze spread through the vessel which eventually sank in shallow water. The ship now sits on the seabed with its superstructure visible above the waterline. The SCC has established a salvage team and has started to assemble the necessary equipment for the work, said vessel-owner X-Press Feeders, adding the plan was to make sure the removal is conducted safely, with no further pollution from the vessel. “The wreck removal team will be supported by response tugs on a 24-hour watch to deal with debris or forms of pollutants. Regular water sampling will be ongoing, with representatives of ITOPF and Oil Spill Response ready to respond immediately, if required,” said the company. When the ship went down, it spewed tons of plastic nurdles (raw plastic pellets), and drifts of the difficult-to-remove material washed up on beaches throughout the island’s west coast. Minister  Ali Sabry confirmed around 650 tonnes of pellets had been removed from Sri Lanka’s beaches thanks to 3,500 man-days of labour, when the coastal clean-up took place last year. By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: SriLankan bags two prestigious awards
author: Author not found
Content: SriLankan Airlines walked away with the prestigious ‘President’s Gold Award’ at the Golden Jubilee of the Maldives tourism industry and the ‘Visitors Choice – Airline of the Year’ award at the 6th South Asian Travel Awards (SATA). The President’s Gold Award was conferred in recognition of SriLankan’s outstanding service to the Maldivian tourism industry for half a century, whilst the winners of SATA were selected by a regional panel of judges and through votes cast online by passengers. The wins prove once again that SriLankan Airlines remains a powerhouse in commercial aviation in the region. The President’s Gold Award for Tourism was presented at the Golden Jubilee Gala of Maldivian Tourism held on 3 October. SriLankan Airlines was among a handful of recipients recognised for contributing exceptionally to develop tourism in the Maldives. Dimuthu Tennakoon, Head of Worldwide Sales & Distribution of SriLankan Airlines accepted the award from the President of the Maldives, Ibrahim Mohamed Solih. The South Asian Travel Awards have been endorsed by over 16 regional and international bodies, and aims to raise industry standards by recognising stellar organisations within the hospitality and travel trade in South Asia. Launched in 2016, SATA has grown steadily over the years attracting the participation of some of the biggest names in the trade from India, Sri Lanka, the Maldives, Bangladesh, Nepal, and Bhutan. Vice President of the Maldives, Faisal Naseem, Dr. Abdullah Mausoom, Maldivian Tourism Minister, and Ismail Hameed, SATA Chairman, were present at this year’s ceremony which took place on 29 September. Representing SriLankan Airlines at the event were Jayantha Abeysinghe, Regional Manager Sri Lanka & Indian Ocean, and Fawzan Fareid, Manager Maldives, who accepted the award on behalf of the airline. The two awards won by SriLankan Airlines is a testament to the airline’s strength and stability in South Asia. The airline currently operates 90 flights a week to nine cities across India, seven weekly flights each to Bangladesh and Pakistan, and five weekly flights to Nepal. SriLankan Airlines has also maintained a significant presence in the Maldives over the years, and is the only airline to operate to two destinations in the Maldives at present – Malé and Gan Island. The airline flies 23 times a week to the Maldives, providing easy connections to passengers from Europe and the Middle East via Colombo and has played a pivotal role in shaping the island country’s success as one of the most sought-after holiday destinations.

title: Holding ‘People’s Councils’ against Constitution – Susil
author: Author not found
Content: Referring to reports that certain parties were preparing to establish Mahajana Sabhas as an alternative Parliament, Leader of the House Susil Premajayantha yesterday (19) said according to the Constitution there was no legal provisions for holding such. Speaking in Parliament, Premajayantha said, according to media reports this Mahajana Sabha was or ‘People’s Council’ was similar to the local Parliament. “This entity violates the Constitution of Sri Lanka. In terms of the Constitution, Parliament is vested with legislative power. This power could not be transferred to any other entity,” he said. In response, Speaker Mahinda Yapa Abeywardena said, Premajayantha’s concern will be referred to the Parliamentary Privileges Committee. By Methmalie Dissanayake

title: Ven. Dr. Pallegama Siriniwasa Nayaka Thera passes away
author: Author not found
Content: Atamasthanadhipathi and Chief Sanghanayaka of the North-Central Province, Most Venerable Dr. Pallegama Siriniwasa Nayaka Thera passed away at the age of 69, while receiving treatment at a private hospital in Colombo, after a brief illness. The final rites will be conducted on Saturday (22) at 2:30 p.m. in Anuradhapura.  Ven Siriniwasa Nayaka Thera was born in 1953 and ordained at the Ruwanweli Maha Seya in Anuradhapura in 1968. President Ranil Wickremesinghe has directed the funeral to be held under State patronage. Wickremesinghe has instructed the Governor of the North-Central Province, Maheepala Herath and Minister of Buddhasasana, Religious and Cultural Affairs Vidura Wickramanayaka to coordinate arrangements. Wickremesinghe said, the Thera played a lead role and spent his monastic life meaningfully, dedicating himself to the welfare of the people of Rajarata as well as the whole country. BY K.K. Ariyadasa (Dambulla) and Amila Prabath (Anuradhapura)

title: Taxation Vital to Get IMF Assistance – President
author: Author not found
Content: Without implementing a new income tax scheme, Sri Lanka cannot get the assistance from the International Monetary Fund (IMF) and Sri Lankans will have to go back to the days where they were forced to stand in long queues to get essential goods, President Ranil Wickremesinghe warned yesterday (19). Addressing the nation last evening, Wickremesinghe elaborated that the tax scheme was introduced to achieve 14.5% – 15% gross domestic product (GDP) revenue by 2026.  “The Treasury and the IMF discussed the possibility of limiting taxation from those who have an income of Rs 200,000, but that was not possible. Eventually, income tax was levied on people earning over Rs 100,000. Today, this has become a huge problem in the country. I would like to point out that in this backdrop; we may not be able to achieve the desired goals without this tax system.  If we withdraw from this programme, we will not receive assistance from the IMF. If we don’t get IMF certification, we will not get the support of international institutions such as the World Bank, the Asian Development Bank and countries that provide support. If that happens, we will have to go back to the era of queues. We may have to face even tougher times ahead. We have to obtain these loans and go for the debt-restructuring programme. We are not doing these wilfully. We have to take certain decisions even reluctantly. However, we will reconsider these decisions periodically,” the President said. The President said after the meeting held between Sri Lanka and the IMF on debt restructuring programme on 7 October, another meeting was held under the leadership of the IMF with countries that had given loans to Sri Lanka and some private institutions that had also given loans. Over 75 persons participated directly or through zoom technology. The primary purpose of this was to come to a common platform with the three main countries that have granted loans to Sri Lanka, namely Japan, China and India, and discuss the next steps to be taken to provide these concessions. During this meeting, the IMF and Sri Lanka pointed out the need for a common platform. India and China have informed us that they will investigate further and provide answers. These two countries have also informed us that bilateral discussions may be required. Many other countries also participated in this meeting. It is notable that, an Assistant Secretary of the United States Treasury came here. All this was possible because we are implementing the decisions taken in consultation with the IMF “There is one thing about the income of the Government of Sri Lanka. In 2015, when the representatives of the IMF came to Sri Lanka, we were told of the need for a surplus in the primary budget. Therefore, we provided that surplus in 2017-2018. But it was reduced as a result of the 2019 Easter Sunday bombings. However, there were no serious issues. They were optimistic that we would be able to increase our revenue, to have a surplus in the primary budget,” he said “At the time, our income was between 14.5% – 15% of the Gross Domestic Product (GDP). However, we agreed that we can gradually increase this to 17%-18%. However, in November 2019, the country’s taxes were drastically reduced. Then the government revenue decreased to 8.5%. There, the International Monetary Fund declared that it is unable to provide aid because of these agreements. That year we lost around Rs 600-700 billion. Simultaneously, we had to face the Covid pandemic. These issues are the main factors that led to the collapse of Sri Lanka’s economy. The IMF notified us that we need to show a surplus in our primary budget. We agreed to it because we needed their support. The other factor is that it was decided to increase the country’s income from 8.5% to 14.5% of the GDP. It’s impossible to do it all at once. We have planned to increase the country’s income to 14.5% of the GDP by 2026.” Sri Lanka then printed money because our income decreased. During the past two years, Rs 2,300 billion has been printed. As a result, inflation has risen to 70% – 75%. Food inflation has increased even more.  These need to be controlled, but we also need to secure our income. Therefore, a new tax system was proposed during these discussions. The International Monetary Fund had notified that even the export industries are required to pay taxes, the President pointed out.  It was indicated especially in countries with an export economy, taxes are being paid. The IMF also pointed out that our primary export economy was the plantation industry. During British rule, taxes were charged from every plantation sector, including tea, coconut and rubber. Therefore, we decided that if we are to move towards that goal, we will have to pay taxes. The export sector has now questioned this move and if these facts are to be submitted to the IMF, we have discussed about carrying out an analysis, he said. “The second matter is individual taxes. We have obtained the majority of taxes through indirect taxing. Even the majority of the country’s people below the poverty line had no choice but to pay taxes indirectly.   Our direct tax revenue is 20%. About 80% is derived from indirect taxes. The IMF Fund had specific questions about it and they were of the view that the amount of tax obtained from direct taxes should exceed 20%. Otherwise, they noted that this would not be successful, as ordinary citizens would be forced to pay taxes.

title: Long-term fuel credit line in the pipeline
author: Author not found
Content: The Sri Lankan Mission in Moscow said “There is a possibility of obtaining a long-term credit line to procure fuel for Sri Lanka,” following a discussion held with the Russian Government on 17 October. In May this year, the Russian Foreign Ministry said Sri Lanka’s request for a USD 300 million credit line from Moscow for crude oil, gas, and coal “is being considered.” On 26 May, the Russian Foreign Ministry said Russia had received an appeal from Sri Lanka for help in overcoming the energy crisis. At the meeting on 17 October, Ambassador of Sri Lanka to the Russian Federation, Prof. Janitha A. Liyanage emphasised the significance of such a credit line to Sri Lanka to procure fuel, especially during these trying times. The mechanism of the said credit line and the modality to procure fuel from the Russian Federation were discussed at length with the Ministry of Finance of the Russian Federation. Timur Maksimov, Deputy Minister of Finance of the Russian Federation, Levan Jagaryan, and the Sri Lankan Envoy to Russia were present at the meeting. The Embassy is of the view that the credit line facility will play an important role in making adequate fuel supplies available to Sri Lanka at a competitive price in the months to come. By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: SC reissues notice on ex-President Gotabaya
author: Author not found
Content: The Supreme Court yesterday (29), instructed to re-issue notice on former President Gotabaya Rajapaksa with regard to the case on the disappearance of human rights activists Lalith Weeraraj and Kugan Muruganandan in 2011. This was when the appeal filed in relation to the case was taken up before Supreme Court Justices, E.A.G.R. Amarasekara, Yasantha Kodagoda and A.H.M.D Nawaz. The Jaffna Magistrate Court issued summons on Rajapaksa months before the Presidential Elections in 2019 in relation to the Habeas Corpus case filed against Rajapaksa over the disappearance of Weeraraj and Muruganandan. A motion was later filed by Rajapaksa and the Court of Appeal issued an interim order suspending the summons issued by the Jaffna Magistrate’s Court in September 2019 following which the summons issued by the Jaffna Magistrate was quashed by the Court of Appeal in November 2020. An appeal was later filed against the decision of the Court of Appeal to quash the decision of the Jaffna Magistrate’s Court to summon Rajapaksa and Attorney-at-law Nuwan Bopage appearing on behalf of the Appellant yesterday (19), observed that although notice was served on Rajapaksa to his residence in Mirihana, he failed to appear before Courts when the case was taken up on the basis that notice was not duly served. He added thereby that notice was re-issued noting however that he still failed to appear before Courts. Thereby, Court instructed the aggrieved party to re-issue notice to Rajapaksa returnable on 15 December. BY Faadhila Thassim

title: COPF, COPE should have powers to punish offenders – SLASA
author: Author not found
Content: The Sri Lanka Administrative Service Association (SLASA) proposed that the Committee on Public Finance (COPF) and the Committee on Public Enterprises (COPE) be given powers to recover the money lost to the State by the actions of State officials and politicians and also to enable them to be subjected to the judicial process and be punished. Discussions in this regard took place at the National Council Sub-Committee on Identifying Priorities in Formulating Short-, Medium- and Long- Term Policies which met in Parliament on Tuesday (18) under the chairmanship of MP Namal Rajapaksa. The SLASA attended the meeting held to obtain expert opinions for the National Council Sub-Committee on Identifying Priorities in Formulating Short-, Medium- and Long- Term Policies. Accordingly, the Association presented a proposal containing amendments related to the executive presidential system of the country, amendments related to the Council of Ministers and ideas and suggestions for the reforming of the public service. The sub-committee also discussed at length the need to amend the ordinances to remove the existing legal obstacles for upgrading the public service through digitisation, and the association pointed out that it would enable the creation of a more efficient public service which is an essential factor. The chairperson informed the SLASA to submit short-term amendment proposals related to updating the public service to the committee within two weeks.Rajapaksa pointed out that a national policy can be prepared fast after submitting the amendments to Parliament through the National Council. He also pointed out that through reforming the public service by way of a national policy, the services needed by the people can be provided quicker and with high efficiency. MPs Johnston Fernando and Sagara Kariyawasam were also present at the meeting.

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Wajira invites all parties to join National Council
author: Author not found
Content: UNP Chairman MP Wajira Abeywardena on 17 October invited the leaders of all political parties to join the National Council and work towards resolving the current political and economic crises. Abeywardena claimed that the children of the country were not able to receive proper school education since last 2020, due to the breakout of Covid-19 pandemic and the political situation that prevailed in the country. The people of this country couldn’t celebrate the Vesak, Poson and Christmas festivals and the younger generation lived amidst severe pressure, he said. The present Government has been given a great responsibility to protect the privileges and rights of people, younger generation and the school children while providing them a prosperous livelihood access. Party or other differences are irrelevant to reach this goal. All must stand as Sri Lankans and work in together in order to win the economic challenges, Abeywardena noted. Abeywardena made these remarks while addressing the media in Galle. “It is the bounden duty of every citizen to pay attention towards rebuilding the collapsed economy of this country. We are celebrating 75th anniversary of receiving independence from the Britain. The betterment of this country is more important than giving prominence to political parties. The Development of this country is more important than the development of an individual political party. MP Manusha Nanayakkara too joined with the Government with the same intention and the motive. Now he is holding a responsible Ministerial portfolio under the administration of President Wickremesinghe,” MP Abeywarena added. By Naalir Jamaldeen

title: Priyamali sought Rs 30M bail from a person
author: Author not found
Content: The CID yesterday informed Colombo Additional Magistrate Shilani Perera that the probe into Thilini Priyamali’s actions had revealed that she had sought a sum of Rs 30 million from an individual to get bail, having contacted him via an illegally obtained mobile phone. In separate cases, Priyamali and her alleged business partner Isuru Bandara were remanded until 2 November. Priyamali and Isuru Bandara were not produced in Court but were connected via Skype. Chief Police Inspector Jayantha Payagala, the OIC of the Special Investigations Unit (SIU), of the CID prosecuted. He said the CID having sought four search warrants had inspected areas such as Wattala, Kirupolana, the 34th Floor of the WTC and Chatham Street, as part of their investigations. He said having inspected the areas documents and digital items were seized. Chief Inspector Payagala told Magistrate Perera that from computers that had been seized from the KRISH office situated at the WTC, five hard discs had been misplaced. He explained that statements had also been recorded from employees, attached to seven firms owned by the suspect. He said the probe revealed that the suspect had operated a firm under the name of THICO Group of Companies, of which THICO Film, THICO Construction and THICO Gems, had been a part. SIU OIC said the inquiry had shed further light that though the suspect had no direct investments to sustain her business endeavours, she had still incurred a monthly sum of Rs 4.2 million to meet the salary requirements of her employees, as well as to pay bills of her firm. He said it had been found that the suspect’s firm spent  Rs 5.5 million to stage various promotional activities on behalf of her firm. since March this year. He then observed that the suspect had also incurred a payment of Rs 35 million, for a movie premier. Payagala pointed out that the monies were from cash she had swindled from millionaire businessmen and noted politicians. He said though she had spent such large sums of money, she had failed to earn any tangible profit from it. He said following the probe on the mobile phone seized from the suspect many messages and voice recordings had been analysed and contained information how the suspect had defrauded cash from well known businessmen and politicians, but to date such persons had failed to lodge any complaints against her. The OIC remarked that it was also questionable as to why they had failed to lodge any complaints against her to the CID. The CID stated that the suspect had maintained a bank account containing Rs 3000 million from January to June this year, while she had withdrawn that amount and spent it before her arrest. The prosecution said they had seized bank receipts from places that were searched. Hence the CID officer urged Court to issue an order to Banks to submit details with regard to how the suspect had come to both deposit and withdraw money from her accounts to expedite the probe. He explained that a few more suspects are due to be apprehended and said the suspect while being jailed had used three mobile phones and had given calls to 11 numbers via the three mobile phones. The prosecution observed that statements will also be recorded from those to whom the suspect had called. PC Maithri Guneratne appeared for the aggrieved party. He stated that his client,  had deposited Rs 226 million with the suspect. He then stated that though the CID had begun a detailed probe into the illegal financial activities of the suspect, it was still questionable, as to why the prosecution, had failed to initiate any form of action against Janaki Siriwardene, who had acted as an intermediary during the unlawful activities concerning the suspect. Guneratne PC alleged that to date, no legal action has been instituted against Siriwardene and queried as to why the prosecution, has thus far failed to apprehend her. He insisted that if the intermediary party had been arrested, the CID would be able to figure out, as to what had become of the monies that had been defrauded by the suspect. A group of lawyers, headed by Counsel Dasun Nagashena looked into the interests of the suspect. They maintained that those who had deposited money with their client had been highly esteemed people in society and from various walks of life. They also said it would be timely if the prosecution could also inquire, as to whether the businessmen and politicians, who had depositrd such sizeable amounts of cash, had paid taxes to date. They also said the prosecution had deceived Court stating that they had seized three cell phones from their client’s possession within her prison cell, when in reality they had only seized a single cell phone. By Hansi Nanayakkara

title: Landslide warnings for five Districts
author: Author not found
Content: With the persisting inclement weather, the National Building Research Organisation (NBRO) has issued level three evacuation level, level two amber and level one landslide early warning alerts to 29 Divisional Secretariat (DS) Divisions and the surrounding areas in five Districts, Senior Scientist of Landslide Early Warning Centre of NBRO Dr. K. P. G. Wasantha Senadeera said yesterday (19). The Kalutara, Kegalle, Nuwara Eliya, Ratnapura and Colombo Districts were among them, according to Dr. Senadeera. He said that level three red watch evacuation level landslide early warning alerts have been issued to Ingiriya, Walallawita, Palindanuwara and Bulathsinhala DS Divisions and the surrounding areas in the Kalutara District. Accordingly, level two amber watch landslide early warning alerts have been issued to Agalawatta, Matugama, Millaniya, Horana and Bandaragama DS Divisions and the surrounding areas in the Kalutara District, Ruwanwella, Dehiowita and Warakapola DS Divisions and the surrounding areas in the Kegalle District, Ambagamuwa DS Division and the surrounding areas in the Nuwara Eliya District and Kalawana, Ratnapura, Kiriella, Nivithigala, Ayagama, Elapatha, Kuruwita and Pelmadulla DS Divisions and the surrounding areas in the Ratnapura District, Dr. Senadeera said. The Senior Scientist said level one yellow watch landslide early warning alerts have been issued to Seethawaka and Padukka DS Divisions and the surrounding areas in the Colombo District. The people living in landslide prone areas and receiving heavy rains have been asked to exercise caution. If showers reach disaster level they have been asked to move to safer places after informing the relevant authorities including the Disaster Management Centre (DMC) and Police , Dr. Senadeera added. Meanwhile, the Meteorology Department yesterday predicted that showers or thundershowers can be expected in Western, Sabaragamuwa, Central, North Western, and Northern Provinces and Galle and Matara Districts, today (20). While commenting on the current atmospheric conditions Duty Meteorologist Kasun Pasqual predicted that heavy showers above 100 millimetres can be expected at some places in Western and Sabaragamuwa Provinces and Galle, Matara, Puttalam, Mannar, Killinochchi Districts. The Duty Meteorologist said, showers or thundershowers could elsewhere over the country in the afternoon or night.  Strong gusty winds are expected to be from 40 to 45 kilometres per hour (kmph) in the Western slopes of Central Hill Country and Southern Province. He also cautioned the public of possible heavy winds and lightning strikes and advising cautiousness to take adequate precautionary measures in the event of such circumstances to minimise the damages caused by localised temporary heavy winds and lightning strikes, the Duty Meteorologist added. By Naalir Jamaldeen

title: House heats up over English Only law education
author: Author not found
Content: A heated situation arose in Parliament yesterday (19) over making English compulsory for the entrance examination of Sri Lanka Law College following a query made by Samagi Jana Balawegaya (SJB) MP Hesha Withanage on the matter. In response, Justice Minister Dr. Wijeyadasa Rajapakshe said, the Council of Legal Education had informed that studies in Law School should be conducted in English. Minister of Foreign Affairs Ali Sabry said, they were attempting to groom students with a bright future where they do not have to back down, just because they did not know the English language. He questioned whether students were willing to pass out of Law College knowing English or pass out without the knowledge of the language and be limited to a small area. However, Opposition Leader Sajith Premadasa said, if they are attempting to teach English to students, it should commence from the nursery  and not when they are in College. He said, the education system in the country was outdated and that too should be modernised. BY Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: Sustained buying pressure on Treasuries
author: Author not found
Content: Government of Sri Lanka’s (GoSL’s) at least theoretical money printing borrowing costs (MPBCs) decreased for the second consecutive market day to Tuesday (18 October), with Tuesday’s fall being by 0.99 per cent (Rs 1,479.27 million) to Rs 148,120.88 million due to sustained buying pressure of riskless Treasury (T) Bills and T-Bonds  because of high yields offered by the latter. Market liquidity was uplifted by Rs 26,686.98 million (USD 73.49 million) led by the settlement of transactions between the GoSL and Central Bank of Sri Lanka (CBSL) on Tuesday. Conversions are based on the value of the administered and benchmark official ‘spot’ which was fixed at Rs 363.14 to the dollar on Friday. GoSL’s demand-pull inflationary face value money printing (FVMP) debt decreased by 0.52 per cent (Rs 16,833.98 million) to Rs 3,211,948.75 million (Rs 3.2119 trillion) on Tuesday, thereby marginally defraying demand-pull inflationary pressure and GoSL’s MPBCs. Market was short for a record 273 market days to Tuesday, though this shortfall fell for the third consecutive market day, with Tuesday’s decrease being by 1.95 per cent (Rs 9,85 million) to Rs 495,280 million, nonetheless causing  sustained rate pressure. GoSL’s highest to the 277th highest FVMP debt has been recorded in the 277 consecutive market days to Tuesday. GoSL’s FVMP debt has been over Rs 3 trillion for a record consecutive 72 market days to Tuesday due to a sustained lack of revenue. Transactions between CBSL and GoSL are foreign reserves neutral and CBSL which administers daily open market operations, lacks transparency. GoSL’s FVMP debt is equivalent to the totality of CBSL’s T-Bill and T-Bond holdings. MP is the exclusive right of CBSL. GoSL’s MPBCs are prorated to the outcome in secondary market trading of T-Bills and T-Bonds on the reference day. ‘Spot’ trades are settled after two market days from the date of transaction. CBSL, the steward of GoSL debt and its foreign reserves deals in ‘spot.’ The ‘spot’ is administered to minimise GoSL’s foreign debt in rupee terms and lower the cost of ‘essential’ imports, while ‘essential’ imports are met from the country’s foreign reserves and not from the market, to prevent further depreciative pressure on the rupee, as Sri Lanka is an import-dependent economy. By Paneetha Ameresekere

title: Six sailors rescued after 30 days in mid sea – SLN
author: Author not found
Content: Six navy personnel who went missing in mid-sea on 17 September, during a ‘special surveillance mission’ returned safely midnight on 18 October on the shores of Panama, a coastal village in the Eastern Province of Sri Lanka, located 126 kilometres south of Batticaloa and 12km south of Arugam Bay, according to the  Sri Lanka Navy. According to Navy spokesman, Captain Indika de Silva, the multi-day fishing craft deployed for the surveillance mission by Sri Lanka Navy (SLN), had drifted in the direction of South East Asia, roughly close to Indonesia, when the engine failed and the sailors lost communication. According to the sailors, they had fixed the engine and attempted to return to Sri Lanka when the radio communication suddenly worked. The men survived on fish and cooked on board the ship. Initially they had taken food for only two weeks when it began to run short. After 20 days of surviving in mid sea, the engine started working again, but after a few days, it broke down and lost communication. SLN spokesman stated that these statements were made by sailors and was their version.  According to Captain de Silva, the trawler remains in the sea while the SLN vessel rescued the sailors and brought them to Panama that night. SLN is further investigating. The sailors were later admitted for medical investigations. By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: Arugambay Clean Sri Lanka gifts bins to schools
author: Author not found
Content: Arugambay Clean Sri Lanka have been providing garbage bins to schools in tourist areas for proper management of solid waste and disposals in schools to protect and keep the environment clean. Under the scheme, Pottuvil Al- Kalam Maha Vidyalaya received a set of garbage bins from Arugambay Clean Sri Lanka recently. President of Clean Sri Lanka A. Muzammil attended the event along with Chief Guest Senior Research Scientist from Cefas UK and Pollution lead on OCPP in Sri Lanka, David Sivyer. He gifted   the bins to the Principal of the M. Firdouze. Marine Scientist and Pollution Lead on OCPP in India, Dr Danja Hoehn and Secretary Clean Sri Lanka, H.M.Imam  also attended. By M.A.P. Deen – Ampara

title: HRCSL slams Education Ministry
author: Author not found
Content: The Human Rights Commission of Sri Lanka (HRCSL) is to summon Education Ministry officials to inquire into complaints with regard to alleged malpractices taken place during the admission of students to several leading State schools in Colombo. Speaking to Ceylon Today, HRCSL Commissioner, Dr. Nimal Karunasiri said many students who seek to get admission in these schools do not get treated equally. “When enrolling students for Grade 7 or 8, they say that they only give admission to a pre-determined number of students, let’s say three students. However, we can see that these schools have given admissions to more than that, sometimes six students,” he said. Dr. Karunasiri further said, principals were aware of these scandals taking place in these schools. “We have found out that Principals in these schools cover these up with Circulars and protocols of their schools. National schools Education Directors, politicians and Education Ministry officials were also involved in these scandals by providing false information such as fake addresses and even fake birth certificates,” he added. Dr. Karunasiri further said, National Schools Education Directors also give numerous reasons and excuses to cover their mistakes. He said, though many complaints on human rights violations were lodged by various sectors, the HRCSL was severely hampered as it was short staffed and lacked the facilities to meet the demand, yet, they try their best to provide their services with the limited resources that is available. By Nabiya Vaffoor

title: Malnutrition affecting elderly – Moneragala PS member
author: Author not found
Content: Moneragala PS member W. M. P. Bandara stated that currently it was not only the younger generation but even elders were suffering from malnutrition due to the country’s worsening food crisis. He said the escalation of prices of essential items had caused the prevailing situation where many essential foods were beyond the reach of the common man. He said the Government must take serious note of the worsening economic downturn and address the issue so that the public could face the situation in one way or another. He was speaking at the monthly meeting of the Moneragala PS  held on 14 October. BY Nadun Gunathileka – Bibile

title: One killed, two injured in Yakkalamulla shooting
author: Author not found
Content: One person was killed and two were injured, following a shooting in Karuwalagala, Yakkalamulla yesterday (19), Police said. According to Police, the three persons were shot at by three suspects while they were in their house. The suspects had used a 84mm firearm. The suspects also stole a motorcycle parked in the vicinity. The victims were critically injured and were admitted to the Karapitiya Hospital. The suspects fled the scene. A 34-year-old victim was pronounced dead on admission, while a 30-year-old victim was transferred to the Matara Hospital. A 4-year-old was among the victims. Police said the deceased had been enlarged on bail by the Elpitiya Magistrate, on charges of aiding and abetting a murder in 2019.  Police are conducting further investigations. By Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Six sailors rescued after 30 days in mid sea – SLN
author: Author not found
Content: Six navy personnel who went missing in mid-sea on 17 September, during a ‘special surveillance mission’ returned safely midnight on 18 October on the shores of Panama, a coastal village in the Eastern Province of Sri Lanka, located 126 kilometres south of Batticaloa and 12km south of Arugam Bay, according to the  Sri Lanka Navy. According to Navy spokesman, Captain Indika de Silva, the multi-day fishing craft deployed for the surveillance mission by Sri Lanka Navy (SLN), had drifted in the direction of South East Asia, roughly close to Indonesia, when the engine failed and the sailors lost communication. According to the sailors, they had fixed the engine and attempted to return to Sri Lanka when the radio communication suddenly worked. The men survived on fish and cooked on board the ship. Initially they had taken food for only two weeks when it began to run short. After 20 days of surviving in mid sea, the engine started working again, but after a few days, it broke down and lost communication. SLN spokesman stated that these statements were made by sailors and was their version.  According to Captain de Silva, the trawler remains in the sea while the SLN vessel rescued the sailors and brought them to Panama that night. SLN is further investigating. The sailors were later admitted for medical investigations. By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan

title: Arugambay Clean Sri Lanka gifts bins to schools
author: Author not found
Content: Arugambay Clean Sri Lanka have been providing garbage bins to schools in tourist areas for proper management of solid waste and disposals in schools to protect and keep the environment clean. Under the scheme, Pottuvil Al- Kalam Maha Vidyalaya received a set of garbage bins from Arugambay Clean Sri Lanka recently. President of Clean Sri Lanka A. Muzammil attended the event along with Chief Guest Senior Research Scientist from Cefas UK and Pollution lead on OCPP in Sri Lanka, David Sivyer. He gifted   the bins to the Principal of the M. Firdouze. Marine Scientist and Pollution Lead on OCPP in India, Dr Danja Hoehn and Secretary Clean Sri Lanka, H.M.Imam  also attended. By M.A.P. Deen – Ampara

title: HRCSL slams Education Ministry
author: Author not found
Content: The Human Rights Commission of Sri Lanka (HRCSL) is to summon Education Ministry officials to inquire into complaints with regard to alleged malpractices taken place during the admission of students to several leading State schools in Colombo. Speaking to Ceylon Today, HRCSL Commissioner, Dr. Nimal Karunasiri said many students who seek to get admission in these schools do not get treated equally. “When enrolling students for Grade 7 or 8, they say that they only give admission to a pre-determined number of students, let’s say three students. However, we can see that these schools have given admissions to more than that, sometimes six students,” he said. Dr. Karunasiri further said, principals were aware of these scandals taking place in these schools. “We have found out that Principals in these schools cover these up with Circulars and protocols of their schools. National schools Education Directors, politicians and Education Ministry officials were also involved in these scandals by providing false information such as fake addresses and even fake birth certificates,” he added. Dr. Karunasiri further said, National Schools Education Directors also give numerous reasons and excuses to cover their mistakes. He said, though many complaints on human rights violations were lodged by various sectors, the HRCSL was severely hampered as it was short staffed and lacked the facilities to meet the demand, yet, they try their best to provide their services with the limited resources that is available. By Nabiya Vaffoor

title: Malnutrition affecting elderly – Moneragala PS member
author: Author not found
Content: Moneragala PS member W. M. P. Bandara stated that currently it was not only the younger generation but even elders were suffering from malnutrition due to the country’s worsening food crisis. He said the escalation of prices of essential items had caused the prevailing situation where many essential foods were beyond the reach of the common man. He said the Government must take serious note of the worsening economic downturn and address the issue so that the public could face the situation in one way or another. He was speaking at the monthly meeting of the Moneragala PS  held on 14 October. BY Nadun Gunathileka – Bibile

title: One killed, two injured in Yakkalamulla shooting
author: Author not found
Content: One person was killed and two were injured, following a shooting in Karuwalagala, Yakkalamulla yesterday (19), Police said. According to Police, the three persons were shot at by three suspects while they were in their house. The suspects had used a 84mm firearm. The suspects also stole a motorcycle parked in the vicinity. The victims were critically injured and were admitted to the Karapitiya Hospital. The suspects fled the scene. A 34-year-old victim was pronounced dead on admission, while a 30-year-old victim was transferred to the Matara Hospital. A 4-year-old was among the victims. Police said the deceased had been enlarged on bail by the Elpitiya Magistrate, on charges of aiding and abetting a murder in 2019.  Police are conducting further investigations. By Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: Eight Timor-Leste Troops Train in SL
author: Author not found
Content: Eight personnel from the Timor-Leste Defence Force together with 20 personnel from the Sri Lanka Coast Guard (SLCG) and Sri Lanka Navy (SLN) are currently undergoing a 12-day training course at the SLCG Advanced Training Centre (ATC), Kirinda, SLCG in a statement dated Sunday (16 October) said. This training course is the first ‘Visit, Board, Search, and Seizure’ (VBSS) course, it said. The course is being conducted by two UN Office on Drugs and Crime (UNODC) instructors, SLCG said. The training programme will be conducted in three phases, instructor course (seven days), VBSS advanced course (12 days), and VBSS boarding officer course (four days), SLCG said. Practical exposure will be given to trainees on board SLN’s fast attack craft, simulating a VBSS platform at Hambantota International Port (HIP) with assistance from the Southern Naval Command/HIP, the statement said. (PA)

title: Illegal manufacture of toddy raises concerns
author: Author not found
Content: State Minister of Finance Ranjith Siyambalapitiya said the illegal manufacturing of toddy has become a cause for concern. Steps should be taken to ensure the standard of toddy manufactured in Sri Lanka, he said. Siyambalapitiya was speaking at a meeting with the authorities and liquor licenceholders. The State Minister said the daily toddy consumption in Sri Lanka was about 160,000 litres. However, production was only about 45,000 litres. This has led to the production of moonshine, he added. Siyambalapitiya instructed the Commissioner General of Excise to report on revenue loss to the State due to liquor manufacturers having a freehold on wine stores.

title: Temple hierarchy lament over rising electricity bills
author: Author not found
Content: Chief Incumbent of the Vijayamangalarama Temple in Ruwanpura, Hatton Ven. Pannagamuwe Dayawansa Thera said the electricity bill for the temple for the past month was beyond their reach. The Thera said the bill was exorbitant and it was unfair by the Temple, despite taking measures to supply power to the CEB from a solar power system in the premises. He added that due to power being generated via solar power, the electricity bill during the past two-years was manageable, but lamented that the recent bill was exorbitant. The Thera said some 20-odd Temples in the Ambagamuwa PS had received exorbitant electricity bills and urged officials to intervene and provide relief to these temples. BY Neeta Pathma Kumari – Norwood

title: Probe constructions within Knuckles Reserve
author: Author not found
Content: MP Wasantha Yapabandara requested the Speaker to look into allegations of the Central Environmental Authority (CEA) Chairman and his son building a resort inside the Knuckles Forest Reserve. Speaking in Parliament yesterday (19), MP Yapabandara questioned the Minister of Environment about the construction. He said, “An allegation has been made that the Chairman of the CEA and his son are building a hotel in Rakkida, Matale which is an environmentally sensitive area of Knuckles Forest Reserve. Also, there is another allegation that a hotel will be built near the Katukollanda Canal, a branch canal of Thelgamu Oya, which mainly supplies water to the Moragahakanda Reservoir.” He said if the allegation turns out to be true, it will be a major threat to the environment. Therefore, investigations should be conducted to identify the owners. In response, Minister of Environment Naseer Ahmad said the issue is being investigated. He said once the reports are out, they will take action against the responsible parties. By Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: CFC to open more fish stalls
author: Author not found
Content: With a view of distributing fresh seafood items to consumers, the Ceylon Fisheries Corporation (CFC) has launched a programme to set up fish outlets across the country, including in Colombo and its surrounding areas. Fisheries Minister Douglas Devananda opened the first seafood outlet of CFC at Hospital Road, Kalubowila, Dehiwala yesterday (18) morning. The consumers in the region will be able to buy fresh seafood items according to their budget. Steps have been taken to open such stalls in busy cities across the country to provide the services of CFC in an efficient way. A total of 96 seafood stalls have already been set up in the busiest cities across the country, according to Minister Devananda. CFC Chairman Chathuranga Udawatte said seafood will be sold at reasonable prices here and cheaper than the prices prevailing in the open market. Fisheries Ministry Secretary Indu Ratnayake, CFC Managing Director Thushara Loku Kumara and Ministry officials were present at the opening ceremony. By Naalir Jamaldeen

title: Manhunt on to apprehend 40 year old
author: Author not found
Content: Point Pedro Police said yesterday (19) that a manhunt to apprehend a 40 year old suspect for sexually harassing a 66 year old woman had commenced. Police said the suspect is at large for more than 11 days. Police believe that the suspect would have been under the influence of narcotics at the time of the incident. Preliminary investigations revealed that the suspect had fled after attacking the victim’s 70 year old sister who came out of the house following the victim’s call for help. Meanwhile, the victim returned home after receiving treatment at the Point Pedro Base Hospital. The suspect is said to have served a four-month jail term for being a suspect in a murder case and for having narcotics in his possession, Point Pedro Police added. By Naalir Jamaldeen

title: Tea production Lowest in 26 years
author: Author not found
Content: Sri Lanka’s cumulative tea production in the nine calendar months to end September 2022 (last month) at 192.38 million kilos is the lowest since 1996, Forbes and Walker Tea Brokers in a report released yesterday (19) warned. This would be the lowest recorded for the period under review since 1996, where the country registered 188.40 million kgs in the corresponding nine-month period, it said. In the same period last year, the island recorded a total tea production volume of 234.72 million kgs, down 18.04 per cent (42.34 million kgs), year-on-year (YoY). Tea production is currently suffering from the ‘seven-month imported fertiliser ban’ imposed by Gotabaya Rajapaksa, the immediately preceding President, covering the period April 2021 to November 2021. The ban though since lifted, is still impacting the industry due to Sri Lanka’s foreign exchange crisis, made worse by the steepest depreciation of the rupee in absolute terms since independence in 1948. Meanwhile, 26 years ago in 1996, tea production was hit by a prolonged drought coupled with LTTE terrorism, which hit one of its peaks that year by launching a successful attack on the Central Bank of Sri Lanka (CBSL) on 31 January 1996 made worse by the deteriorating security situation, then, subsequently replete with curfews and movement restrictions which impacted tea production. Tea, for two consecutive years, that is, in 2020 and 2021, was Sri Lanka’s third largest foreign exchange earner, after remittances and garment exports, in that descending order, latest CBSL data showed.  (PA)

title: Shehan Karunatilaka Wins Booker Prize 2022
author: Author not found
Content: Sri Lankan author Shehan Karunatilaka won the Booker Prize on Monday for his second novel The Seven Moons of Maali Almeida, about a dead war photographer on a mission in the afterlife. Karunatilaka received the trophy from Queen Consort Camilla at the English language literary award’s first in-person ceremony since 2019. He also gets a 50,000 pound (USD 56,810) prize. Set in 1990, Sri Lanka during the country’s civil war, Karunatilaka’s story follows gay war photographer and gambler Maali Almeida, who wakes up dead. Time is of essence for Maali, who has “seven moons” to reach out to loved ones and guide them to hidden photos he has taken depicting the brutality of his country’s conflict. “My hope for ‘Seven Moons’ is that in the not too distant future… it is read in a Sri Lanka that has understood that these ideas of corruption, race baiting and cronyism have not worked and will never work,” Karunatilaka said in his acceptance speech. “I hope it is read in a Sri Lanka that learns from its stories and that ‘Seven Moons’ will be in the fantasy section of the bookshop and will… not be mistaken for realism or political satire.” This year’s shortlist of Booker Prize contenders included British author Alan Garner’s “Treacle Walker”, Zimbabwean author NoViolet Bulawayo’s “Glory”, “Small Things Like These” by Irish writer Claire Keegan, U.S. author Percival Everett’s “The Trees” and “Oh William!” by U.S. author Elizabeth Strout. “This is a metaphysical thriller, an afterlife noir that dissolves the boundaries not just of different genres, but of life and death, body and spirit, east and west,” judges chair Neil MacGregor said of Karunatilaka’s book. “It is an entirely serious philosophical romp that takes the reader to ‘the world’s dark heart’ – the murderous horrors of civil war Sri Lanka,” MacGregor added. “And once there, the reader also discovers the tenderness and beauty, the love and loyalty, and the pursuit of an ideal that justify every human life.” Past winners of the Booker Prize, which was first awarded in 1969, include Margaret Atwood, Salman Rushdie and Yann Martel. (Reuters)

title: Fmr SI gets 20 years RI for Rs 5,000 bribery
author: Author not found
Content: Colombo High Court Judge Adithya Patabendige yesterday (18), convicted a former Sub-Inspector (SI) attached to the Ahungalla Police, on charges of soliciting a bribe and sentenced him to 20 years of Rigorous Imprisonment while imposing a fine of Rs 20,000. The convict had been accused of seeking a bribe of Rs 5,000, to release items seized from a gambling centre and not to enforce the law against the suspects. The convict was identified as K.P. Kumara, a former SI attached to the Ahungalla Police Station. Judge Patabendige also ordered that the prison term imposed on the convict should be served for 10 years at a stretch and stated that the bribe sought by him, should be paid to the Court. The Commission to Investigate Allegations of Bribery or Corruption (CIABOC) had indicted the convict, on four counts before the High Court and on the aforesaid charges, thereby flouting Provisions contained in Sections of the Bribery Act via his actions, committed seven years ago. By Hansi Nanayakkara

title: Govt can earn over Rs 150M yearly – Bandula
author: Author not found
Content: If the lands belonging to Sri Lanka Railways are leased, the Government could earn between Rs 100 and 150 million per year, Cabinet Spokesman Bandula Gunawardena said. He said no lease fees are collected from those who have constructed buildings on land plots owned by the Sri Lanka Railways. He claimed that many buildings, including hotels, are being built on land owned by the Sri Lanka Railways and the building owners are not paying any fees. At the weekly Cabinet media briefing yesterday (18), Gunawardena said, the Sri Lanka Railways owns 14,000 acres of land, the majority of which is illegally taken by various individuals. “These lands were used to preserve the Sri Lanka Railways. Individuals, however, have encroached on it instead. For example, the coastal line from Kollupitiya to Panadura has many hotels. This is a violation of public property. If lease fees are collected, the Sri Lanka Railways may be restructured. This is just one example,” he explained. In addition, he said, other State Ministry buildings have been leased to various individuals for various purposes, based on political favouritism. He said, if the appropriate fee is collected from all of these, the Government will not face any major burdens and will be able to function smoothly. BY Thameenah Razeek

title: Kanchana warns CPC Unions
author: Author not found
Content: Minister of Power and Energy Kanchana Wijesekera warned that if any employee or trade union is found violating the essential services regulations and disrupting services, they will face immediate legal and disciplinary action. In a tweet, he said petroleum services have been declared essential for the past six months. Meanwhile, petroleum trade unions have announced that employees at Ceylon Petroleum Corporation (CPC) fuel distribution centres in Kolonnawa, Sapugaskanda and Muthurajawela went on strike yesterday (18) in protest against the Petroleum Bill that was passed in Parliament on the same day. The Petroleum Special Provisions (Amendment) Bill, which is expected to pave the way for petroleum industry liberalisation, was debated in Parliament yesterday (18). Accordingly, the Second Reading of the Petroleum Product Special Provisions (Amendment) Bill was passed with amendments. Seventy-seven votes were received in favour of the Bill and only 17 against. The vote was held after Chief Opposition Whip Lakshman Kiriella requested for a division This Bill provides for the importation, supply and distribution of fuel to parties other than the Ceylon Petroleum Corporation (CPC) and the Lanka Indian Oil Company (LIOC).

title: Budget 2023 presented to Parliament
author: Author not found
Content: The Appropriation Bill 2023 was presented to Parliament by Leader of the House Susil Premajayantha yesterday (18). The Bill provides for the service of the financial year 2023, to authorise the raising of loans in or outside Sri Lanka, for the purpose of such service; to make financial provisions in respect of certain activities of the Government during that financial year; to enable the payment by way of advances out of the Consolidated Fund or any other fund or moneys of or at the disposal of the Government, of moneys required during the said financial year for expenditure on such activities; to provide for the refund of such moneys to the Consolidated Fund and to make provisions for related matters.  The total Recurrent Expenditure for 2023 has been estimated to the tune of Rs 4,634 billion while total Capital Expenditure has been estimated at Rs 3,245 billion. According to the Bill, the highest amount has been allocated for the Ministry of Finance which is Rs 612 billion. Rs 410 billion has been allocated for Ministry of Defence and Rs 321 billion has been allocated for the Ministry of Health.

title: Cabinet approves Govt’s Rs 663B credit limit increase
author: Author not found
Content: In order to repay Government loans, the Cabinet of Ministers approved an increase of the Government’s credit limit by Rs 663 billion. President Ranil Wickremesinghe submitted the Cabinet proposal on Monday (17) and it was immediately approved by the Cabinet. Cabinet Spokesman Bandula Gunawardena said if the proposal is delayed, the entire Government will suffer the consequences of not being able to borrow money to settle the loans. He said yesterday (18), during the weekly Cabinet meeting the President submitted the proposal to the Cabinet of Ministers in his capacity as Minister of Finance, Economic Stabilisation, and National Policies. “The credit limit approved by the Parliament for the year 2022 was Rs 3,844 billion, but it was decided to increase the limit by Rs 663 billion taking into account the urgency of the payments that are scheduled to be settled,” the Minister said. BY Thameenah Razeek

title: Nepali among those trained in peacekeeping in SL
author: Author not found
Content: A Nepali military officer, together with a Sri Lanka Air Force (SLAF) officer and 31 student officers from the Sri Lanka Army (SLA), participated at the ‘Comprehensive Protection of Civilians’ (CPOC) course-2022 from 10 – 14 October 2022, the SLA, in a statement dated Monday (17), said. It was conducted at the SLA training centre for UN assignments, the Institute of Peace Support Operations Training Sri Lanka (IPSOTSL), Kukule Ganga, Ratnapura, the SLA further said. Representatives from the United Nations, US funded Global Peace Operations Initiative (GPOI) and the US Embassy provided advisory support for the course, it said. The lecture panel included GPOI organisation’s Colonel Gonzalo Mila (Rtd.) from Uruguay, Jens Anderson from Denmark and local instructors, namely Colonel B.D.T.D Jayarathne, Lieutenant Colonel M.L.N.U Liyanage  from the SL Armoured Corps (SLAC), Lieutenant Colonel M.S.R Mohamed from the SL Electrical and Mechanical Engineers (SLEME) and Major K.H.D Mendis from the SLA General Service Corps (SLAGSC),  the statement said. GPOI is a US Government-funded security assistance programme intended to enhance international capacity to conduct United Nations and regional ‘Peace Support Operations’ (PSOs) by building friendly foreign nations’ capabilities, capacities to train and sustain peacekeeping proficiencies, it said. The aim of this training package was to groom and equip officers of the Sri Lankan armed forces and also from other nations before being employed as UN contingent members, UN staff officers and UN military observers in e future deployments. Further, the studies highlighted the importance of protecting civilians when participating as UN peacekeeping members. Closing remarks were made by chief guest Brigadier C.A Rajapaksha, Commandant, Institute of Peace Support Operations Training Sri Lanka, the statement in conclusion said. (PA)

title: Dr. Charitha Herath nominated to COPE
author: Author not found
Content: Former Chairman of the Committee on Public Enterprises (COPE) Dr. Charitha Herath was nominated to serve in the COPE of Second Session of Ninth Parliament, following Dr. Harsha de Silva’s resignation. The Deputy Speaker announced in Parliament yesterday (18), that Dr. Herath will fill the vacancy which occurred after the resignation of MP Dr. Harsha de Silva. Dr. De Silva who was appointed a member of the Committee has taken a voluntary decision to step down from the COPE. Dr. De Silva announced his resignation on the grounds of holding the post of Chairman of the Committee on Public Finance (COPF) and the workload related to the COPF. Following this, the Opposition decided to propose Dr. Charitha Herath name to fill the vacancy in the COPE.  BY Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: Prophet Mohammed’s B’day celebrated in Beruwela
author: Author not found
Content: Prophet Mohammed’s birthday celebrations were held in Pasalthota Akkara, situated in Bentota, recently. The Milad un-Nabi was thus marked in the village which is 99 per cent Sinhala Buddhist. However, a noticeable feature was the majority Sinhala community had joined hands to mark Prophet Mohammed’s birthday early this month. The main religious event had been held under the aegis of Priest R. M. Silmy while the Mowlavi of the Sheik Usman Mosque at Davatagaha Faizal Hassan delivered the keynote address. BY B. M. Mukthar – Beruwela
