The Deputy Speaker announced in Parliament yesterday (18), that Dr. Herath will fill the vacancy which occurred after the resignation of MP Dr. Harsha de Silva. Dr. De Silva who was appointed a member of the Committee has taken a voluntary decision to step down from the COPE. Dr. De Silva announced his resignation on the grounds of holding the post of Chairman of the Committee on Public Finance (COPF) and the workload related to the COPF. Following this, the Opposition decided to propose Dr. Charitha Herath name to fill the vacancy in the COPE.  BY Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: DON’T PAY PARKING FEES FOR CMC UNDESIGNATED SLOTS – COMMISSIONER
author: Author not found
Content: Colombo Municipal Council (CMC), Municipal Commissioner J.M. Badranie Jayawardana advised the public not to pay a fee when they park on roads that have not been declared by the CMC for parking vehicles. She said, they have received information that unauthorised persons take money from those who park their vehicles on these unassigned roads. Speaking to Ceylon Today, yesterday (18) Jayawardana noted that there are 19 roads that do not have authorised representatives of the Colombo Municipal Council limits. “Usually about 7,000 parking slots have been named by the CMC. In these locations we have a board which has the information that it is an authorised parking spot along with the parking charges. But there are about 19 roads where we do not charge for parking, and we have received few complaints of the public being charged in these locations by using the names of the CMC authorised representatives or other institutions. They used to wear jackets similar to the CMC workers,” she added. “Based on that supervision, they are being dealt with by the Court and the Police. We will continue to deal with them in the future as well. After we assign a worker to a certain parking spot, we will inform the public about it. We will mention the name and phone number of the authorised agent in that area so that the public can get enough knowledge about it,” Jayawardana added. Jayawardana said if someone came across any illegal parking slot fee collection, they could complain to the nearest Police station or call 0112698529 to inform the CMC immediately. By Nabiya Vaffoor

title: New sea cucumber fingerlings breeding centre for Mannar
author: Author not found
Content: Fisheries Minister Douglas Devananda said, steps have been taken to build a new sea cucumber fingerlings breeding centre in Olaithoduvai, Mannar, in addition to the existing facility, in collaboration with private sector investors in India,. The Fisheries Minister expressed confidence that the proposed project will be able to supply enough sea cucumber fingerlings to aquaculture farmers in the region. The rural people will be able to earn enough money to improve their economic and living conditions while also contributing to resolving the country’s current foreign reserves problem. Minister Devananda added that he met a group of Indian investors, at Olaithoduvai in Mannar to discuss this matter and to take further decisions in connection with the establishment of proposed centre in consultation with them. Devananda also inquired from the Indian investors about their experience in this field and in connection with the establishment of sea cucumber fingerlings breeding centre using sophisticated modern aquaculture farming technology.  The Fisheries Minister said that at a time when the international demand for sea cucumber is high, holding discussions with the Indian investors in connection with the establishment of a sea cucumber fingerlings breeding centre, would be more beneficial to the Sri Lankan aquaculture industry, as a whole. By Naalir Jamaldeen

title: Isuru Bandara remanded
author: Author not found
Content: Colombo Additional Magistrate Shalani Perera yesterday remanded till today (19) Thilini Priyamali’s business partner, identified as Isuru Bandara. The CID urged the Court, not to enlarge the suspect on bail, as the probe into the case has still not been concluded. Taking the submissions into consideration, the Magistrate ordered the suspect to be remanded. By Hansi Nanayakkara

title: RESPIRATORY TRACT INFECTIONS AMONG CHILDREN ON THE RISE
author: Author not found
Content: An increase has been reported amongst paediatric patients with respiratory tract infections, due to the current weather, Consultant Paediatrician Lady Ridgeway Hospital, Dr. Seepal Perera said. Speaking to Ceylon Today yesterday (18),Dr. Perera said the floods, caused by inclement weather has resulted in increasing the number young patients seeking treatment for respiratory tract infections and wheezing.  Some of the patients have to be administered oxygen as a result, he said. Dr. Perera noted that the flood situation in several parts of the island and bad weather was also causing an increase in the number of young patients with diarrhoea, Dysentery and typhoid. Contaminated water and food were the main causes of these situations. The rains were also a harbinger to an increase in mosquito density and flies. There will definitely be an increase in the number of dengue patients. Therefore, caution should be applied in the provision of food and water, as children were more vulnerable than adults to intestinal infections. Well cooked food and boiled and cooled water should be provided to them, he said. Early detection of these infections is necessary. Children with abdominal infections could be given kanji (rice porridge), king coconut water, orange juice etc and not colas, he advised.    By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: State Asset Management Bill
author: Author not found
Content: The Cabinet approved the drafting of a State Asset Management Bill This was in order to introduce a new Act for the management of public assets, including appropriate provisions, so that provisions will be available to expand duties of the Comptroller General Office, which is under the purview of the General Treasury and to provide legitimacy to it as well as to prepare a national assets register and to introduce a central database related to State assets. The proposal submitted by the President, as the Minister of Finance, Economic Stabilisation and National Policies, instruct the Legal Draftsman to draft a Bill in order to introduce a new Act for the management of public assets. During the budget speech, delivered by the President for amending the Appropriation Bill for the Financial Year 2022, it was suggested to introduce several new Acts with the objective of strengthening the economy, enhancing the efficiency of the government service as well as productive management of government-owned resources and the requirement of revising provisions of several existing acts. Revision of the Ayurveda Act (Indigenous Medicine Act) The Cabinet granted approval to amend the Ayurveda Act, including appropriate provisions for expanding services of the Department of Ayurveda for the uplift of the indigenous medicine sector and activities such as establishment of Osu Uyana (medicinal gardens) for research purposes. The Cabinet proposal was submitted by the Minister of Health. The Ayurveda Act No. 31 of 1961 has been amended from time to time on several occasions previously and it has been recognised that the Act required to be amended further to cater to the requirements of the day so that sustainable development goals can be achieved. The Recovery of Possession of the Premises Given on Lease (Special Provisions) Act The Cabinet had given approval, on 27 September 2021, to the draft Bill to enact a new law in place of Recovery of Possession of the Premises Given on Lease (Special Provisions) Act. The Attorney General’s clearance has been received for the Bill prepared accordingly by the legal draftsman. The Cabinet approved the proposal presented by the Minister of Justice, Prison Affairs and Constitutional Reforms to publish the Bill in the Government Gazette and to table it in Parliament for approval consequently. (TR)

title: Prices of essentials down – Bandula
author: Author not found
Content: Cabinet Spokesman Bandula Gunawardena said the prices of many essential goods in the market have decreased. However, when asked why the prices of milk powder and wheat flour have not come down in the market, he said the Minister of Trade will address the issues regarding that at another press conference. He was responding to a question from the media at the Cabinet media briefing yesterday (18). “The essential food item prices were discussed at the Cabinet, and the Minister of Trade stated that market prices of many essential items have decreased,” he said. Accordingly, the price of a kg of lentils has decreased from Rs 685 to Rs 308, the price of a Nadu rice kg has decreased from Rs 220 to Rs 165, the price of a White Kekulu has decreased from Rs 210 to Rs 160, the price of a sugar has decreased from Rs 376 to Rs 275, and the price of wheat flour as also fallen from Rs 395 to Rs 275. BY Thameenah Razeek

title: US$ 8.6M Japanese grant to strengthen border management
author: Author not found
Content: Japan has provided a US$ 8.6 million grant to Sri Lanka and the Maldives, to strengthen border management against infectious diseases, such as Covid-19, covering the Colombo Airport and Colombo Port as well, Japan’s Embassy in Sri Lanka said yesterday (18). The signing ceremony in this connection was held at UN adjunct, IOM, at the latter’s headquarters in Geneva on Monday (17), an IOM official in Sri Lanka, speaking on the grounds of anonymity, told this newspaper yesterday. The majority of this grant aid is to Sri Lanka, the spokesperson added. Meanwhile, the Japanese Embassy statement further said, “UN adjunct International Organization for Migration (IOM), in partnership with relevant Ministries of the Government of Sri Lanka (GoSL) and the Government of Maldives launched a regional project ‘Strengthening Capacity of Border Control for Responding to Infectious Diseases in Southwest Asia’ in this regard on Monday.” With a grant of $ 8.6 million provided by the Government of Japan, the project intends to strengthen overall border management capacities in Sri Lanka and the Maldives to prevent the spread of infectious diseases that would otherwise impede the revitalisation of human mobility, it said.  The dramatic reduction in human mobility has been one of the most significant effects of the Covid-19 pandemic, the Embassy further said. This had major economic and social impacts in Sri Lanka and the Maldives which are heavily reliant upon income from international tourism, labour migration and business travel, it said. The border closures and associated restrictions disrupted regular trade exchanges and impacted migration flows as well as exposed border management agencies and cross-border communities to higher risks of infection, the statement said. As such the component of the project focusing on Sri Lanka will improve safety and security, and support process efficiency at primary points of entry (PoEs) to ensure more effective preparedness and proactive response to potential public health emergencies due to infectious disease outbreaks, the statement said. The project will thus help interventions at the Bandaranaike International Airport (BIA) at Katunayake and the Colombo Port in compliance with international health regulations with approximately 700 points of entry (PoEs) personnel and officers inSri Lanka, trained, in addition to the provision of improved infrastructure, the Embassy said. Designed to enable secure and safe operations at PoEs to augur international travel, boost traveller confidence and prompt a return to pre-pandemic levels of cross-border mobility, the project will address gaps in passenger processing and health screening systems at PoEs through a combination of new technology, infrastructure, procedures, training, and renovation works, the Embassy statement further said. This will streamline the management of traveller information, reduce waiting times, implement contactless processes and procedures by border control personnel. The project will also institute infection prevention measures and emergency response modalities and guarantee the safe disposal of potentially hazardous medical waste at PoEs, resulting in a safe environment for staff, travellers and crew while reducing harmful environmental and health impacts. Travellers and other personnel working at the PoEs will be the main beneficiaries of this initiative, aside from the airport and seaport workers and officials. Health Ministry’s Director General of Health Services Dr. Asela Gunawardena speaking of the project said, “This will strengthen infrastructure facilities and mobility of border health staff at the points of entry (PoEs), enhancing the country’s health security, whilst providing services on par with international standards, which will further enhance the implementing provisions of the International Health Regulations 2005 (IHR 2005).” Airport & Aviation Services Sri Lanka Chairman, Major General (rtd.) G. A. Chandrasiri said, “The ongoing pandemic and the resultant impact on the aviation sector makes this project timely and critical.”  He further said, “the holistic approach to focus on coordination with all border management agencies and the sustainability of interventions will strengthen our border security, compliance with international health regulatory requirements at the borders and enhance  ‘passenger experience’ at BIA.” Speaking on the timeliness of the project, Japan’s Ambassador to Sri Lanka Hideaki Mizukoshi said, “As Sri Lanka has been actively attracting international tourists and expects to see an increase in the number of tourists in the future, strengthening border control capacity to prevent outbreaks of infectious diseases and ensure the safety of staff and travellers is a  meaningful initiative that will contribute significantly to economic recovery from the current economic crisis and further economic growth in Sri Lanka, where tourism is one of the main industries.” IOM Sri Lanka and the Maldives Mission Chief, Sarat Dash said, “Designed on the lessons learnt from the Covid-19 pandemic, this project is anchored to IOM’s strategy on migration and sustainable development and will support Sri Lanka and the Maldives to respond to future disease outbreaks and health threats.” He added, “IOM will work closely with its host government partners to harness the development benefits of migration while ensuring a hassle-free and dignified process for international travellers, including the migrant population.” (PA)

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: ‘Jana Sabha’ gets Cabinet go-ahead
author: Author not found
Content: The Cabinet of Ministers approved the acceptance of the proposed People’s Council system, also known as Jana Sabha, as a fundamental policy. The Cabinet also approved the establishment of the National People’s Council Secretariat, as the national level independent central institution, for establishing the People’s Councils system. The proposal was presented to Cabinet by President Ranil Wickremesinghe. Addressing the weekly Cabinet media briefing yesterday (18), Cabinet Spokesman Bandula Gunawardena said it has been revealed that due to the gap between the centre of governance and the people, representative democractic institutions that have been operating in Sri Lanka do not pay enough attention to the public opinion when policy making. He said, since the people’s real issues are not adequately addressed, social criticism is arising in this regard. Based on this, it has also been seen that opinions and objections against representative democracy are emerging in the society. “Under that situation, a strong mechanism, where public officials and the common people can discuss rural issues together, determine what should be done to address their concerns, is much needed. By doing so, we can prevent public oppression happening through an organised mechanism,” he said. Gunawardena also said, the ‘National Movement for a Just Society’ has accordingly presented a concept paper on People’s Council system with an independent institutional structure where public participation can be ensured for the formulation of public policies. “The concept paper also proposed the establishment of the National People’s Council and Village People’s Councils to cover every Grama Niladhari Division in the Island,” he said. BY Thameenah Razeek

title: Inauguration of the IESL’s 116th Annual Sessions
author: Author not found
Content: The hundred and sixteenth annual sessions of the Institution of Engineers Sri Lanka (IESL) was held on 14 October 2022 at the BMICH Main Hall. This marks the ceremonial inauguration of a new session.  The main highlight of the annual sessions is the official handing over of the mantel of presidency to the incoming president for the session 2022/23, Eng. Dr. Kamal Laksiri. Prof. Malik Ranasinghe,   Chairman, Information and Communication Technology Agency graced the occasion as the Chief Guest, while Renuka M. Weerakone, Director General, BOI participated as the guest of honour. Keynote speech was delivered by Dr. Sanjiva Weerawarna, Founder and CEO, WS02. The programme was streamed live via online platforms where foreign delegates from engineering institutions participated along with the members of the institution from overseas chapters from Australia, New Zealand and Qatar. Certificates were bestowed upon members of the institution who were transferred to the class of Honorary Life Fellow, Honorary Life Member and Fellow. Further certificates were handed over to members who became International Professional Engineers and awards were given to winners of IESL competitions and Junior Inventor of the Year competition winners.

title: Fuel quota for tuk to be increased in two weeks
author: Author not found
Content: The fuel quota for three-wheelers will be increased within the next two weeks, Minister Kanchana Wijesekera informed Parliament yesterday (18). He said that steps are being taken to register three-wheelers engaged in public transportation services. “Data from the Department of Motor Traffic shows 1.1 million registered three-wheelers, while in reality only 350,000 three-wheelers are in operation as per vehicles registered with the Provincial and Local Government bodies. Provincial Councils have been instructed to register three-wheelers operating as public transportation, while such registrations were conducted at Police stations earlier as well”, the Minister said. The registered vehicles must be entered into the Fuel Pass QR system which will take around one to two weeks, he explained. He made this statement in response to a question raised by MP Mujibur Rahuman. BY Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: Milk cheaper than water in Batticaloa
author: Author not found
Content: The milk producers in the Batticaloa District lamented yesterday (18), they receive a very low price for their nutritious fresh milk when compared with the price of one litre of water. “At a time when one litre of water is sold at Rs 160 we receive just Rs 110 per litre of milk. We are unable to increase the milk production and the dairy industry in the district has been severely impacted as a result,” K. Gnanasekaran, a member of Pillayar Dairy Farmers Association, in Ganeshapuram, Mandoor said. Pasupathy Ramakrishnan, a dairy farmer in the Mayilathamadu, Batticaloa said that the dairy farmers in the region had cows with 10 to 20 litre milk capacity. Following the hike in prices of livestock feed and medicines, they sell the animals as they are unable to bear the maintenance cost. “Milk production was dropping drastically in the region. We collected nearly 500 litres of milk from our farm. We are able to collect less than 200 litres now. Our dairy farmers are wondering whether to continue or stop breeding dairy cattle”, Ramakrishnana said. He said, there was no any difficulty in geting livestock feed. One tractor of hay is sold at Rs 15,000, one kilo of bran is sold at Rs 120 and livestock medicines were skyrocketing. However the price of fresh milk remains at low level. At this juncture increasing the milk production seems to be a difficult task. In the event the Government fails to help the dairy farmers, the dairy industry will vanish from the region very soon, he added. Rasaiah Suresh, a dairy farmer in Kiran, in Eravur, said that when the Government instructed them to increase milk production in order to meet the national demand, the dairy farmers bought dairy cows taking loans from finance companies. As they were not receiving reasonable price for milk they are struggling to pay off those loans. “The livelihood of dairy farmers has totally collapsed. A stipulated price of one litre of fresh milk must be set at Rs 200 or we will have to take to the road with our cattle to stage protests,” Suresh said. “The Government must reduce the price of livestock feed and medicines taking the critical situation of dairy farmers into consideration. Then we will be able to increase the milk production. If not we would have to stop dairy cow breeding. If we stop breeding, the Government must recommend an alternative livelihood mode for us,” Suresh added. By Naalir Jamaldeen

title: Doctors’ retirement age increased by one year
author: Author not found
Content: The Cabinet approved the recommendation to extend doctors’ retirement age by one year. Accordingly, doctors who have completed 63 years of age will retire on 31 December. Doctors who have completed 62 years at present will retire on completion of 63 years, doctors who have completed 61 years will retire on completion of 62 years, doctors who have completed 60 years will retire on completion of 61 years and those who have completed 59 now will retire on completion of 60 years.  Cabinet Spokesman Bandula Gunawardena said, however, those who are 59 years old, should retire by the age of 60. He said, even though there was a policy decision made on sending the State employees on retirement at the age of 60, it was decided not to do so and to increase the retirement age for three sectors. The age of retirement of employees in State-owned Enterprises (SOE) was earlier raised to 60 years with effect 1 January 2023. This follows the Cabinet approving a proposal presented by President Ranil Wickremesinghe, as the Minister of Finance, Economic Stabilization and National Policies. BY Thameenah Razeek

title: Prophet Mohammed’s B’day celebrated in Beruwela
author: Author not found
Content: Prophet Mohammed’s birthday celebrations were held in Pasalthota Akkara, situated in Bentota, recently. The Milad un-Nabi was thus marked in the village which is 99 per cent Sinhala Buddhist. However, a noticeable feature was the majority Sinhala community had joined hands to mark Prophet Mohammed’s birthday early this month. The main religious event had been held under the aegis of Priest R. M. Silmy while the Mowlavi of the Sheik Usman Mosque at Davatagaha Faizal Hassan delivered the keynote address. BY B. M. Mukthar – Beruwela

title: Nepali among those trained in peacekeeping in SL
author: Author not found
Content: A Nepali military officer, together with a Sri Lanka Air Force (SLAF) officer and 31 student officers from the Sri Lanka Army (SLA), participated at the ‘Comprehensive Protection of Civilians’ (CPOC) course-2022 from 10 – 14 October 2022, the SLA, in a statement dated Monday (17), said. It was conducted at the SLA training centre for UN assignments, the Institute of Peace Support Operations Training Sri Lanka (IPSOTSL), Kukule Ganga, Ratnapura, the SLA further said. Representatives from the United Nations, US funded Global Peace Operations Initiative (GPOI) and the US Embassy provided advisory support for the course, it said. The lecture panel included GPOI organisation’s Colonel Gonzalo Mila (Rtd.) from Uruguay, Jens Anderson from Denmark and local instructors, namely Colonel B.D.T.D Jayarathne, Lieutenant Colonel M.L.N.U Liyanage  from the SL Armoured Corps (SLAC), Lieutenant Colonel M.S.R Mohamed from the SL Electrical and Mechanical Engineers (SLEME) and Major K.H.D Mendis from the SLA General Service Corps (SLAGSC),  the statement said. GPOI is a US Government-funded security assistance programme intended to enhance international capacity to conduct United Nations and regional ‘Peace Support Operations’ (PSOs) by building friendly foreign nations’ capabilities, capacities to train and sustain peacekeeping proficiencies, it said. The aim of this training package was to groom and equip officers of the Sri Lankan armed forces and also from other nations before being employed as UN contingent members, UN staff officers and UN military observers in e future deployments. Further, the studies highlighted the importance of protecting civilians when participating as UN peacekeeping members. Closing remarks were made by chief guest Brigadier C.A Rajapaksha, Commandant, Institute of Peace Support Operations Training Sri Lanka, the statement in conclusion said. (PA)

title: Sara Jasmine’s third DNA report given to authorities
author: Author not found
Content: The report of the third DNA test to confirm the death of Sara Jasmine, alias Pulasthini Mahendran has been concluded and presented to the relevant authorities, Ceylon Today reliably learns. According to an official at the Government Analyst’s Department, the DNA report has been submitted to the Police and the Court system. However, he did not disclose the outcome of the report.      The investigators intend to re-examine the DNA to determine whether the remains of Sara, an Islamist extremist and member of Zahran Hashim’s terror group, are among those who died inside the Sainthamaruthu safe house raided on 26 April 2019. Sara Jasmine is wife of Atchchi Muhammadu Muhammadu Hasthun, the suicide bomber responsible for the Katuwapitiya St. Sebastian’s Church bombing on 21 April 2019. Just days after the Easter Sunday Attacks, several persons, including children, were killed in a bomb explosion inside a house in Sainthamaruthu, Kalmunai on 26 April. Mohamed Rilwan, one of Zahran Hashim’s brothers detonated the bomb. Despite the fact that 17 people died in the explosion, the DNA samples taken from the bodies on two occasions did not match Pulasthini’s mother. There were suspicions that Sara Jasmine had fled to India, following a testimony of a witness before the Presidential Commission of Inquiry (PCoI) on Easter Sunday Attacks, who claimed she could have tipped off Indian intelligence about the impending attack. The remains of those killed in the Sainthamaruthu bomb blast in 2019 were exhumed on 27 April, following an order from the Kalmunai Magistrate’s Court. The remains buried at the Ampara cemetery were exhumed in the presence of the Ampara Magistrate, the Judicial Medical Officer (JMO), and Police Officers involved in the initial investigations, as well as the Government Analyst. By Mithun Jayawardena

title: Petrol, diesel prices dropped
author: Author not found
Content: The prices of 92 Octane Petrol and Auto Diesel were reduced from 9:00 p.m. yesterday (17). The Ceylon Petroleum Corporation (CPC) in a statement said the price of 92 Octane Petrol was reduced by Rs 40 per litre and the new price is Rs 370 per litre. The price of Auto Diesel was reduced by Rs 15 per litre and the new price is Rs 415 per litre. Minister of Power and Energy Kanchana Wijesekera meanwhile added that, however, the prices of other petroleum products will remain the same. Meanwhile, the Lanka Indian Oil Company (LIOC) has also announced that it will reduce its fuel prices in line with the price reduction of CPC. (TR)

title: Allow law students to sit exams in preferred language
author: Author not found
Content: Pivithuru Hela Urumaya (PHU) Leader, MP Udaya Gammanpila urged Minister of Justice, Dr. Wijeyadasa Rajapakshe to repeal the rule that law students must take their exams in English rather than their preferred languages, Sinhala or Tamil. He claimed that a former Justice Minister brought a regulation to take away students’ right to write Law College exams in their mother tongue, despite the fact that proceedings in Magistrate’s Courts, District Courts, and High Courts throughout Sri Lanka are conducted in either Sinhala or Tamil. “Only the Court of Appeal and the Supreme Court hold hearings in English. If this is the case, why are the Law College exams only given in English? If only English-speaking lawyers are born, our people will be powerless. An ordinary citizen who does not speak English will be unable to verify whether the information he provided to the lawyer will be presented in the same way in Court,” he said. Further, he said the fate of the people of the country during the British imperialist period is depicted in an Englishman’s novel, Baddegama, written by Leonard Woolf. “On that day, Silindu in the novel was sentenced to death following a Court proceeding conducted in English. Silindu is not only unaware of why he was sentenced to death, but he is also unaware that he was sentenced to death. We are requesting that the Justice Minister repeal this unjust regulation by instructing the Government not to subject innocent people in this country to the fate of Silindu during the British colonial era,” he urged. By Thameenah Razeek

title: Hold LG Elections before 20 March – AKD
author: Author not found
Content: Local Government Elections must be held before 20 March 2023, urged Jathika Jana Balawegaya (JJB) Leader Anura Kumara Dissanayake. Addressing the JJB District Council in Dompe, Gampaha on 16 October, Dissanayake alleged that the President is attempting to find a way to postpone the election once more. The political culture in Sri Lanka must be changed and it cannot be done alone. Therefore, JJB must be the strongest people’s movement in the country, he added. “The previous elections were held to overthrow the then Premier and now President Ranil Wickremesinghe, the mastermind of the Central Bank bond scam and to bring justice to the people who lost their lives in the Easter Sunday Attacks. However, the same person who lost the election against the Rajapaksas became the President. The current political system is dysfunctional and it must be changed,” Dissanayake reiterated. By Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: Up Over 150% to Rs 13,460 by Aug
author: Author not found
Content: Sri Lanka’s monthly official poverty line (OPL) increased for the sixteenth consecutive month to August 2022, increasing by 2.45 per cent (Rs 322) to Rs 13,460 month-on-month (August 2022 over July 2022), Census and Statistics Department (CSD) data released on Friday (14 October) showed. In the previous month (July), this monthly figure (OPL) was Rs 13,138. In the 16-month period beginning from April 2021 to August 2022, Sri Lanka’s OPL has increased by over twofold or by more than 150 per cent (Rs 8,297) to Rs 13,460 led by a depreciated rupee, fuel shortages, scarred harvests and import bans and controls, official data further showed. The last time OPL declined was 16 months ago since August 2022, that is, April 2021 over March 2021, where the OPL fell by a negligible 0.01 per cent (Rs 4) to Rs 5,177, before increasing since. The OPL in March 2021 was Rs 5,181.   By Paneetha Ameresekere

title: Draft ‘Rehabilitation’ Law would spur abuse – HRW
author: Author not found
Content: The Government should withdraw a draft law that would give the authorities broad powers to detain people in military-run “rehabilitation” centres, placing them at great risk of abuse, Human Rights Watch said yesterday (17). The Bureau of Rehabilitation Bill, submitted to Parliament on 23 September, would allow the compulsory detention in centres of “drug dependant persons, ex-combatants, members of violent extremist groups and any other group of persons.” The Bureau of Rehabilitation Bill would establish a new administrative structure controlled by the Defence Ministry to operate “rehabilitation” centres staffed by military personnel. The proposed law, which human rights advocates have already challenged in the Supreme Court, does not describe the basis for being sent for “rehabilitation,” but other recent government policies provide vague and arbitrary powers to forcibly “rehabilitate” people who have not been convicted of any crime. “The Sri Lankan Government’s proposed ‘rehabilitation’ efforts appear to be nothing more than a new form of abusive detention without charge,” said Meenakshi Ganguly, South Asia Director at Human Rights Watch. “The Rehabilitation Bill would open the door widely to more torture, mistreatment, and endless detention.” The Sri Lankan Government has previously used coercive “rehabilitation” centres to enable arbitrary detention and torture. Following the war, which ended in 2009, thousands of people whom the Government identified as members of the defeated separatist LTTE were detained in military-run “rehabilitation” centres, where some were allegedly tortured and subjected to other abuses, including sexual violence. The current Bill seeks once again to “rehabilitate” “ex-combatants” 13 years after the war ended. The Rehabilitation Bill is the latest measure in a long history of laws, such as the Prevention of Terrorism Act (PTA), that authorise arbitrary detention and torture in Sri Lanka. The law could be used to target minority communities or anti-government protesters whom President Ranil Wickremesinghe has labelled “extremists.” Under the Rehabilitation Bill, which would allow prolonged detention without judicial oversight, government officials would be protected from criminal liability for their actions if they act “in good faith.” The Bill also empowers officials to use undefined “minimum force” to “compel obedience” from detainees. Another provision provides that an official who “without reasonable cause” strikes, wounds, ill-treats, or wilfully neglects anyone under rehabilitation can be punished by up to 18 months in prison, suggesting that there might be a “reasonable cause” to harm detainees. International law absolutely prohibits torture, and other cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment. The Rehabilitation Bureau Bill and the proposed amendment to anti-narcotics legislation are only the latest measures in President Wickremesinghe’s assault on fundamental rights, Human Rights Watch said. An attempt to use the Official Secrets Act to restrict public gatherings in the capital, Colombo, was withdrawn earlier in October amid widespread objections that the action was unlawful. On 6 October, the United Nations Human Rights Council adopted a resolution expressing concern at the human rights situation in Sri Lanka and mandating enhanced UN monitoring, as well as renewing a mandate for the UN to collect and analyze evidence of past human rights violations for use in future prosecutions. “President Wickremesinghe is pursuing abusive and repressive policies that make it difficult for Sri Lanka’s international partners to wholeheartedly back desperately needed economic measures,” Ganguly said. “Foreign governments should make clear that they will support the urgent needs of the Sri Lankan people, but they will also take action through targeted sanctions and other measures against those committing serious human rights violations.”

title: ‘Mahinda Nite’ to be held 5 November
author: Author not found
Content: Mahinda Nite 2022 organised by the Mahinda College, Galle Old Boys’ Association (OBA) Colombo will be held on 5 November 2022, at the Bougainvillea Ballroom, Galadari Hotel, Colombo. The event is held to raise money for the Mahinda College OBA Colombo Scholarship Fund and provide financial aid to students who have made special contributions at national and international level in sports and studies. Entertainment and music will be provided by Vision with Damayantha with guest performances by Mariazelle Goonetilleke and Mahesh Senanayaka as the compere. The Mahinda College OBA was started by Henry Woodward Amarasooriya in 1947 and some of the others who have committed to the development of the association are Professor M.B. Ariyapala, Vincent Panditha, Albert Edirisingha, Somasiri Ambawatta, Professor Vinee Vitharana, Edvin Ariyadasa, Professor Nandadasa Kodagoda, Dr. A.T. Ariyarathna, Dr. W.J. Wimaladharma, Lal de Alwis, Oliver Goonathilaka and Guinness Record holder W.B. Benet.

title: Gajaba Regiment marks 39th Year
author: Author not found
Content: The Gajaba Regiment (GR), one of the illustrious regiments in the Sri Lanka Army, was formed as an Infantry Regiment on 14  October 1983 after the amalgamation of the 1 Rajarata Rifles and 1 Vijayabhu Infantry Regiment. The late Major General Vijaya Wimalarathna was the founder and father of this prestigious regiment. They initiated grooming infantrymen with determination and bravery to eradicate the ruthless LTTE from the motherland. These veterans, with their motto “unity is strength” are commemorating their 39th anniversary today (14). Last 39 years of their proud history, they passed several special milestones, including expansions of battalions and military operations against terrorists at Kokilai (1985), Trincomalee, Kilinochchi, Vavuniya, Omanthai, Puliyankulam, Kanagarayankulam, Mankulam and several other Northern areas. Among them, operation Vadamarachchi (1987) is an unforgettable highlight in the chronicles of both 1 and 3 GR battalions and much more, including the last humanitarian operations. 175 Officers and 4,075 Other Ranks of this veteran regiment’s family were sacrificed during the operations conducted to gain Sri Lanka’s territorial integrity and sovereignty. Among them, Lieutenant K.W.T. Nissanka, Captain P.N. Punsiri, Major W.M.I.S.B. Walisundara, and Warrant Officer II Gunasekara MBG were awarded  the Parama Weera Wibhushana (PWV) for their bravery in action. The regiment produced one Executive President and two Army Commanders. Presently the regimental centre is located in Saliyapura, Anuradhapura. The Commander of the Army, Lieutenant General Vikum Liyanage is the present Colonel of the Regiment while Brigadier Vishavajith Vidyananada is the Centre Commandant. To mark the 39th anniversary of the veterans, an all-night pirith chanting followed by alms giving to the monks to offer merit to fallen and wounded war heroes was undertaken recently in Saliyapura.  Floral tributes to fallen war heroes and a military parade to the commander of the Army was also held with the participation of family members of fallen war heroes, regimental council members, members of Seva Vanitha Unit, officers and Other Ranks. BY Nisal Rukshan

title: Akkaraipattu builds research centre in honour of late academic
author: Author not found
Content: The Marhoom M.I.M. Mohideen Research and Documentation Centre in Akkaraipattu was ceremonially opened recently by Chairman of the Governing body of the Marhoom M.I.M. Mohideen Research Centre (MRDC), Engineer Joufer Ismail. The centre was established on the efforts of late M.I.M. Mohideen’s colleagues, contemporaries and relatives. Mohideen is a well-known researcher, famous writer and a reputed analyst in Sri Lanka. Akkaraipattu – 2 and 3 Common Road where he was born has been named as “Marhoom M.I.M. Mohideen Road” and a signboard was unveiled by Ismail. The centre is equipped with books authored by Mohideen and also includes his articles, interviews, research materials, magazines, video footage of peace talks he took part in and reading material of many other international conferences he attended. “The centre is open to the general public. Those who want to use the materials and copy them can do so free of charge,” the centre’s executive officer Shiraaj Mashoor said. BY M.A.P. Deen (Ampara)

title: 2023 Appropriation Bill to Parliament today
author: Author not found
Content: The Appropriation Bill 2023 is scheduled to be presented to Parliament today (18). This was decided at the Committee on Parliamentary Business held under the chairmanship of Speaker Mahinda Yapa Abeywardena. Accordingly, an hour (9:30 a.m. – 10:30 a.m.) has been allocated for the answers to Oral Questions from today (18) to 21 October. Also, a vote is scheduled to be held at the end of the debate on the Second Reading on 22nd Amendment to the Constitution Bill on 21 October. It was decided to hold the debate on the Second Reading of the Petroleum Products (Special Provisions) (Amendment) Bill from 10:30 a.m. to 5:00 p.m. today (18). Thereafter, time has been allotted from 5:00 p.m. to 5:30 p.m. for the Motion at the Adjournment Time brought in by the Government, Secretary-General of Parliament Dhammika Dasanayake said. The Committee also decided to debate 6 Bills presented by the Ministry of Justice on 19 October from 10:30 a.m. to 5:00 p.m. Accordingly, Poisons, Opium and Dangerous Drugs’ (Amendment) Bill, Notaries Ordinance (Amendment) Bill, Powers of Attorney Ordinance (Amendment) Bill, Wills Ordinance (Amendment) Bill, Registration of Documents (Amendment) Bill, Prevention of Frauds Ordinance (Amendment) Bill are scheduled to be taken up for debate. From 5:00 pm to 5:30 pm time has been set aside for Questions at the Adjournment Time. The Second Reading debate on the 22nd Amendment to the Constitution Bill is scheduled to be held on 20 and 21 October from 10:30 a.m. to 5:00 p.m. Thereafter, time has been allotted from 5:00 p.m. to 5:30 p.m. for the Motion at the Adjournment Time brought in by the Opposition.

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Differently-abled persons to get library, restroom
author: Author not found
Content: Minister of Transport and Highways Bandula Gunawardena has instructed officials to construct a library and a restroom for differently-abled persons at the Makumbura Multimodal Centre to mark International White Cane Day. The Minister said, out of the country’s population, around 8 per cent are differently-abled and as such the onus is on the Government to cater to the needs of such persons 24/7, as it has also been guaranteed in the Constitution. He said, the Makumbura Multimodal Centre has been built in a manner to cater to the needs of differently-abled persons and hence he has instructed his Ministry officials to build a library and a restroom as part of the increased facilities being provided to persons with disabilities. Gunawardena also said, arrangements will be made for differently-abled persons to go on pilgrimage to the sacred city of Anuradhapura via the Rajarata Tourist Train Service which was launched recently by the Railways Department.

title: ‘The way we played is the worry’ – Dasun
author: Author not found
Content: The Sri Lankan camp is in a state of shock after minnows Namibia stunned them by 55 runs in the T20 World Cup opener on Sunday. Following the loss, the Lankan skipper has said that it’s a worrisome sign for the team. Speaking at the post-match press conference, Shanaka said, “We didn’t execute our plans well. I think we went for the yorkers and we didn’t execute with low full tosses and half volleys. I think that’s where it went wrong. I think if they had stuck to that hard length, wicket-to-wicket, like the Namibian bowlers did really, really well, it would have been different.” After being put into bat first, Namibia posted 163 for 7 in 20 overs. With 93 for 6 in 14.2 overs, Namibia were in deep trouble. Jan Frylinck (44 off 28b; 4×4) and JJ Smit (31* off 16b; 2×4, 2×6) put on a 70-run stand for the seventh wickets in just 34 balls. The partnership proved to be a match-winning one. Lanka will now need to avoid any further slip-ups against Netherlands and United Arab Emirates to progress, and could even then see their fortunes come down to run rate permutations. Interestingly, Sri Lanka have come into the World Cup after winning the Asia Cup in UAE. On the other side, Namibia still made it through to the Super 12 stage in 2021, and captain Gerhard Erasmus said his side has taken great confidence from that experience at the top level. Sri Lanka will face UAE and Namibia will lock horns with the Netherlands on Tuesday. By Wichithra Weerasinghe reporting from geelong

title: Collate information on uncultivated lands
author: Author not found
Content: Prime Minister Dinesh Gunawardena instructed Divisional Secretaries to promptly collect information on uncultivated lands owned by all government institutions and plantation companies in the 12,000 Grama Niladhari Divisions. “There are a large number of uncultivated lands owned by government institutions, corporations, boards as well as plantation companies. To overcome the economic crisis that we are facing as a country, the President advised us to take necessary steps to cultivate all the cultivable lands. Accordingly, information regarding uncultivated lands that are cultivable within all Grama Niladhari Divisions across Sri Lanka should be collected urgently,’’ he said. He added that the aim of this move is to give these lands to the younger generation, who can cultivate them for a period of around 2 years to provide a quick solution to this economic crisis. Gunawardena added that all necessary steps have been taken to commence the Rural Economic Revitalisation Committee programme with a view to controlling the increase in food commodity prices in the country and that the programme will commence in Galoya. The programme seeks to formalise and accelerate the upliftment of the rural economy. The five public officers representing the village are responsible for achieving these goals, he said.

title: Commerce Chamber calls for greater transparency
author: Author not found
Content: Ceylon Chamber of Commerce (CCC), whilst acknowledging the rationale for the recently proposed tax changes, nonetheless also calls on the Government of Sri Lanka (GoSL) to show greater restraint, accountability and transparency on GoSL spending, it said yesterday (17). While the tax hike will invariably impact businesses and private sector employees adversely in the current context of high inflation and negative economic growth, however, it is the widely held perception of the tax revenue not being fully utilised for the benefit of the people, it said. Hence, it is imperative that the GoSL effectively communicates the actions it is taking to reduce GoSL expenditure and prioritise spending on areas that are critical to the public, it said. As a part of the fiscal reform agenda, the focus should be in terms of rationalising and curbing GoSL expenditure wherever possible. In 2021, 31 per cent of the recurrent expenditure was on public sector salaries, of which 30 per cent was spent on provincial councils, while 34 per cent was absorbed by defence, policy, and public security, CCC said. “These expenditures must be relooked at in terms of the current priorities of stimulating growth and the need to reallocate expenditure towards spending on more critical areas like public education, health, and research and development, CCC said. In addition, greater accountability, transparency, and governance of existing GoSL expenditure along with visible steps to curb corruption are also essential requirements to motivate taxpayers in knowing that their contribution is being well spent, it said. To drive higher tax collection, the existing taxpayer base will need to be widened further so that the burden does not fall on the current base consisting of a small number of corporates and the salaried workforce to a large extent, CCC advised. This will require significant reform in tax administration and improving the capacity of key revenue collecting agencies to reduce the leakages and ensure greater compliance. Policymakers should make better use of digital solutions to link existing GoSL agencies and efforts like the introduction of a digital ID should be prioritised in this regard, it said. The fiscal reform agenda will need to be complemented with genuine efforts to unlock growth and investment opportunities through state-owned enterprise (SOE) reform, improvement in the ease of doing business and investment climate, and providing a more conducive trade policy environment for exports to flourish, said CCC. This will ensure that growth does not stagnate in the next few years and there will be opportunity for the private sector to reinvest and create more economic activity that will stimulate tax collection. “We hope that the improvements made to the fiscal framework will steer forward the discussions with the IMF and help mobilise financing to address the current shortfalls in external cash flow,” CCC in conclusion said. (PA)

title: Windies humbled by Scotland in another upset
author: Author not found
Content: Twice winners West Indies crashed to a shocking 42-run defeat by Scotland in their T20 World Cup opener in Hobart on Monday, the second major upset inside two days at the global showpiece tournament. The Caribbean side, who won the event in 2012 and 2016, were bundled out for 118 chasing 161 to beat the Scots a day after former champions Sri Lanka lost their Group A opener to Namibia. Left-arm spinner Mark Watt, who took 3-12, and off-spinner Michael Leask, with figures of 2-15, sealed victory for the associate team, who earlier rode upon opener George Munsey’s unbeaten 66 to post 160-5 in the Group B match. Jason Holder, who picked up two wickets with the ball, waged a lone battle for West Indies with a knock of 38, but it was not enough. Zimbabwe meet Ireland in the day’s second match at the same venue with the top two sides from each of the two groups progressing to the Super 12 stage. Scotland seemed to thrive in the cold and overcast conditions at the Bellerive Oval and got off to a brisk start after they were put in to bat, racing to 52-0 in the sixth and final over of the powerplay when rain forced the players off. The interruption, however, seemed to halt their momentum with experienced all-rounder Holder sending back opener Michael Jones, who made 20, and number three Matthew Cross in quick succession after the restart. Munsey anchored the innings but his 53-ball knock lacked fluency as the left-hander failed to find the boundary during the middle overs. Brief scores: Scotland 160/5 in 20 overs (George Munsey 66*, Jason Holder 1/14) West Indies 118 all out in 18.3 overs (Jason Holder 38; Mark Watt 3-12, Michael Leask 2-14)

title: Woman stabbed to death in Pannala
author: Author not found
Content: A woman was stabbed to death in a three-storey building in Negombo, Pannala, Police said. She was residing in a rented room located on the third floor. Police said, the murder occurred in the early hours of yesterday (17).  The victim is a 37-year-old resident of Kuliyapitiya, Weerambuwa. A resident had heard the woman scream and called the Police. However, she was already dead when they arrived. The murderer is still at large and the Pannala Police and Kuliyapitiya Criminal Investigation Division are conducting further investigations. By W.A. Sarath – Pannala

title: Commando Sergeant Major arrested
author: Author not found
Content: A Commando Regimental Sergeant Major (RSM), who had allegedly provided a T-56 rifle to a gunman to carry out the recent shooting in Ahungalla, has been arrested by the STF. The suspect armed with the firearm, who had arrived in a luxury car, had fired at a person inside a three-wheeler in Ahungalla town. The victim had succumbed to his injuries on 13 October night. The STF Officers had been able to locate the T-56 rifle at the spot where the victim had fallen after being fired at. Following inquiries conducted into the number of the T-56 Rifle, the STF had gathered information to the effect that the weapon had belonged to a soldier based at the Kilinochchi Army Camp. Thereafter, they had managed to arrest the RSM serving at the Kilinochchi Army Camp. According to the STF, the suspect RSM, aged 41, is a resident of Melsiripura and two mobile phones in his possession were seized. The RSM and another suspect who had aided and abetted in the shooting have been handed over to Ahungalla Police for further investigations. By Keerthi Mendis, Damsari Liyanage (Balapitiya)

title: Investors opt for T-Bills over Stock Market
author: Author not found
Content: The stock market fell sharply for the second consecutive market day to yesterday (17), as local investors continued to exit in droves to reinvest in tomorrow’s (19), Rs 75 billion weekly Treasury (T) Bill primary auction on expectations of higher yields. Complementing these developments, the weighted average yields (WAYs) of the 91 and 182-day maturities at the two consecutive weekly T-Bill auctions  held up to last week have risen by 111 and 194 basis points (bps) each to record highs of 33.05 and 32.53 per cent respectively due to Government of Sri Lanka’s (GoSL’s) voracious borrowing appetite. Nonetheless, though local investors exited from the stock market, foreign investors became net buyers for the twenty fifth consecutive market day to yesterday, reflecting their sustained confidence in the stock market. Subsequently, net foreign inflows (NFIs) into the stock market increased toRs 15,697 million (Rs 15.7 billion) in the calendar year to yesterday, aided by registering an NFI figure of Rs 87 million yesterday. Howbeit, the ASPI, yesterday over Friday (14) fell by 1.21 per cent to 8,983.74 points and the S&P SL 20 Index by 2.23 per cent to 2,720.73 points led by domestic investor exits. Turnover made yesterday was Rs 1.88 billion on a 69.66 million share volume. By Paneetha Ameresekere

title: Govt should revisit taxes on businesses – Dr. Guruge
author: Author not found
Content: The Government should seriously review its decision taken to impose taxes on domestic businessmen, as they are presently struggling to survive amidst the country’s economic meltdown, Chief Adviser to the Opposition Leader and SJB Working Committee member Dr. Dhanawardene Guruge stressed. He said compared to past esteemed politicians of the calibre of late PMs D.S. Senanayake and Dudley Senanayake, present-day politicians do not consider the plight of local businessmen and the impact it has on their industries. Dr. Guruge added that the Government should consider the predicament faced by local businessmen and the impact on their business establishments before venturing forth to impose taxes and cripple such industries, which would deal a debilitating blow to the stalled economy. By Nirmani Guneratne

title: Parliament conducts ‘Vidu Piyasa’ prog for MLC
author: Author not found
Content: An awareness programme organised by the Communication Department of Parliament was held recently for the students of Muslim Ladies’ College, Colombo 4. At the event, Director of Legislative Services and Communications (Acting) Janakantha Silva gave an introduction to the process of the Parliament Business of the day, and Director (Administration) G. Thachchanarani explained the process of drafting bills. The programme was attended by a large number of teachers and students. Principal, Nasriya Munas was also present.
