title: Solheim hired to liaise with Tamil separatists
author: Author not found
Content: Presidential Adviser on Climate Change Erik Solheim has come to Sri Lanka to liaise with Tamil separatist movements, Pivithuru Hela Urumaya (PHU) Leader, MP Udaya Gammanpila alleged. He said, it is questionable why Solheim was appointed as the Presidential Adviser on Climate Change with his ‘negative credentials.’ “The so-called peace envoy, Solheim has re-emerged as the Presidential Adviser on Climate Change. In fact, he has no credentials to hold this post. He became the UN Environment Head because of Norway’s huge monetary contribution to the UNEP. He wasted USD 500,000 for his foreign travel within 22 months. He was subject to bitter criticism by environmental experts,” he stressed. Speaking to the media yesterday (17), Gammanpila claimed, Solheim had grossly violated regulations of the UNEP and because of these reasons, the UN Secretary-General asked him to resign in November 2018. “India has informed Sri Lanka that they were not in a position to provide support any further. Signing the free trade agreement is a precondition of China. Japan has agreed only to restructure the loans. Russia has no capacity to support us because of the war.  Europe is in a deep economic crisis. The IMF funds will reach us only after debt restructuring. Hence, the Government has no option but to beg before the separatists,” he said. Speaking further, he claimed, the separatists earn millions of dollars every year through human smuggling, weapon smuggling, antique smuggling, money laundering, operating shipping fleets, TV and radio channels. Gammanpila also stressed that after the war ended, they do not have many expenses.  “Hence, they now have accumulated billions of dollars. Solheim has been tasked with appeasing them by meeting their separatist demands and to obtain their money by way of loans and investment. We have no objection in attracting their funds, but not at the cost of our beloved motherland,” he said.  By Thameenah Razeek

title: 96% of Lankans impacted by socio-economic crisis
author: Author not found
Content: The Complex Emergency Needs Assessment Report prepared by teams from the Red Cross identified that 96 per cent of people have been affected by the present crisis in some material way, with food insecurity, health concerns, livelihoods, and nutrition amongst the most pressing issues. The report also said deteriorating physical safety and security, as well as violence against women and children also stood out as major concerns. A special media briefing was held in Colombo by the Sri Lanka Red Cross Society on 14 October, to officially launch the Complex Emergency Needs Assessment Report – October 2022, and highlight the emerging challenges and obstacles that Sri Lanka needs to overcome to combat its present humanitarian emergency. Amidst the worsening economic crisis in the country, the Sri Lanka Red Cross Society, together with the International Federation of Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies (IFRC), has launched its Complex Emergency Needs Assessment Report – October 2022. The report is based on surveys conducted by teams from the Red Cross in face-to-face, in-person interviews with 2,871 households, case studies of 10 estates, focus group discussions and key informant interviews, to establish the true extent and scope of the humanitarian emergency Sri Lanka is presently facing. Through in-person interviews and expert data analysis, the Complex Emergency Needs Assessment Report – October 2022 provides accurate feedback on exactly how the economic crisis is affecting people across 11 districts in Sri Lanka. The panel at the media briefing comprised Regional Director, Asia Pacific of IFRC, Alexander Matheou. Discussing the report, President, Sri Lanka Red Cross Society, Jagath Abeysinghe said, “Working at the ground level and closely with communities, we regularly hear of heart-wrenching stories of loss of hope and fear for the future. Many people, particularly single women with children, people living with disabilities, the elderly, casual labourers and fishermen, feel as though they are fighting a losing battle, just to survive. The report has taken these stories and other data into account and coherently presents these facts and figures to help policymakers, donors, volunteers, and others truly understand the ground realities, so that relief efforts can be better tailored to meet the most pressing needs first.” The report highlights concerning challenges with regard to accessing food, either because of high cost, income stress, or lack of availability. Uncontrolled inflation and loss of livelihoods have delivered a double blow to the most vulnerable communities, and even less vulnerable ones, as they attempt to cope with the unprecedented rise in the cost of living. The deepening economic crisis is forcing people to make heart-breaking choices between going hungry, buying life-saving medicine, or finding the money to send children to school. Despite the developing tragedy, the Sri Lanka Red Cross is working hard to keep up relief efforts and provide at least the bare necessities for survival. The organisation is also working, through a multitude of efforts, to match donations with recipients who are most in need, while also working to create awareness about the humanitarian crisis in Sri Lanka and draw the world’s attention to the most pressing needs of the hour.

title: Dengue rearing its ugly head again – AHEO
author: Author not found
Content: The Association of Health Entomology Officers (AHEO) lamented that the number of dengue cases have increased by at least three times compared to last year. AHEO National Convener, Disnaka Dissanayake warned that the number of cases would shoot up even more due to rainy weather. The large number of mosquito breeding sites in home, school, and workplace environments could only boost the density of the dengue mosquito, leading to a further increase in the number of dengue patients in the country, he warned. If that happens, there may be a large increase in the number of dengue patients. “Therefore, you should make sure that the surrounding environment of your home, your child’s school, and your workplace are free of mosquito breeding grounds and prevent the start of another dengue epidemic in the country.” The National Dengue Control Unit (NDCU) website recently showed that by week 40 (3 to 9 October) the country had a total of 59,317 dengue cases. In 2021, the number of dengue cases by week 40 had amounted to 19,912.  The NDCU website showed that the number of dengue cases for the month of September 2022 amounted to a total of 4,527, while in September 2021 there had been only 1,370 cases recorded.  By Dilanthi Jayamanne

title: Differently-abled persons to get library, restroom
author: Author not found
Content: Minister of Transport and Highways Bandula Gunawardena has instructed officials to construct a library and a restroom for differently-abled persons at the Makumbura Multimodal Centre to mark International White Cane Day. The Minister said, out of the country’s population, around 8 per cent are differently-abled and as such the onus is on the Government to cater to the needs of such persons 24/7, as it has also been guaranteed in the Constitution. He said, the Makumbura Multimodal Centre has been built in a manner to cater to the needs of differently-abled persons and hence he has instructed his Ministry officials to build a library and a restroom as part of the increased facilities being provided to persons with disabilities. Gunawardena also said, arrangements will be made for differently-abled persons to go on pilgrimage to the sacred city of Anuradhapura via the Rajarata Tourist Train Service which was launched recently by the Railways Department.

title: ‘The way we played is the worry’ – Dasun
author: Author not found
Content: The Sri Lankan camp is in a state of shock after minnows Namibia stunned them by 55 runs in the T20 World Cup opener on Sunday. Following the loss, the Lankan skipper has said that it’s a worrisome sign for the team. Speaking at the post-match press conference, Shanaka said, “We didn’t execute our plans well. I think we went for the yorkers and we didn’t execute with low full tosses and half volleys. I think that’s where it went wrong. I think if they had stuck to that hard length, wicket-to-wicket, like the Namibian bowlers did really, really well, it would have been different.” After being put into bat first, Namibia posted 163 for 7 in 20 overs. With 93 for 6 in 14.2 overs, Namibia were in deep trouble. Jan Frylinck (44 off 28b; 4×4) and JJ Smit (31* off 16b; 2×4, 2×6) put on a 70-run stand for the seventh wickets in just 34 balls. The partnership proved to be a match-winning one. Lanka will now need to avoid any further slip-ups against Netherlands and United Arab Emirates to progress, and could even then see their fortunes come down to run rate permutations. Interestingly, Sri Lanka have come into the World Cup after winning the Asia Cup in UAE. On the other side, Namibia still made it through to the Super 12 stage in 2021, and captain Gerhard Erasmus said his side has taken great confidence from that experience at the top level. Sri Lanka will face UAE and Namibia will lock horns with the Netherlands on Tuesday. By Wichithra Weerasinghe reporting from geelong

title: Collate information on uncultivated lands
author: Author not found
Content: Prime Minister Dinesh Gunawardena instructed Divisional Secretaries to promptly collect information on uncultivated lands owned by all government institutions and plantation companies in the 12,000 Grama Niladhari Divisions. “There are a large number of uncultivated lands owned by government institutions, corporations, boards as well as plantation companies. To overcome the economic crisis that we are facing as a country, the President advised us to take necessary steps to cultivate all the cultivable lands. Accordingly, information regarding uncultivated lands that are cultivable within all Grama Niladhari Divisions across Sri Lanka should be collected urgently,’’ he said. He added that the aim of this move is to give these lands to the younger generation, who can cultivate them for a period of around 2 years to provide a quick solution to this economic crisis. Gunawardena added that all necessary steps have been taken to commence the Rural Economic Revitalisation Committee programme with a view to controlling the increase in food commodity prices in the country and that the programme will commence in Galoya. The programme seeks to formalise and accelerate the upliftment of the rural economy. The five public officers representing the village are responsible for achieving these goals, he said.

title: Commerce Chamber calls for greater transparency
author: Author not found
Content: Ceylon Chamber of Commerce (CCC), whilst acknowledging the rationale for the recently proposed tax changes, nonetheless also calls on the Government of Sri Lanka (GoSL) to show greater restraint, accountability and transparency on GoSL spending, it said yesterday (17). While the tax hike will invariably impact businesses and private sector employees adversely in the current context of high inflation and negative economic growth, however, it is the widely held perception of the tax revenue not being fully utilised for the benefit of the people, it said. Hence, it is imperative that the GoSL effectively communicates the actions it is taking to reduce GoSL expenditure and prioritise spending on areas that are critical to the public, it said. As a part of the fiscal reform agenda, the focus should be in terms of rationalising and curbing GoSL expenditure wherever possible. In 2021, 31 per cent of the recurrent expenditure was on public sector salaries, of which 30 per cent was spent on provincial councils, while 34 per cent was absorbed by defence, policy, and public security, CCC said. “These expenditures must be relooked at in terms of the current priorities of stimulating growth and the need to reallocate expenditure towards spending on more critical areas like public education, health, and research and development, CCC said. In addition, greater accountability, transparency, and governance of existing GoSL expenditure along with visible steps to curb corruption are also essential requirements to motivate taxpayers in knowing that their contribution is being well spent, it said. To drive higher tax collection, the existing taxpayer base will need to be widened further so that the burden does not fall on the current base consisting of a small number of corporates and the salaried workforce to a large extent, CCC advised. This will require significant reform in tax administration and improving the capacity of key revenue collecting agencies to reduce the leakages and ensure greater compliance. Policymakers should make better use of digital solutions to link existing GoSL agencies and efforts like the introduction of a digital ID should be prioritised in this regard, it said. The fiscal reform agenda will need to be complemented with genuine efforts to unlock growth and investment opportunities through state-owned enterprise (SOE) reform, improvement in the ease of doing business and investment climate, and providing a more conducive trade policy environment for exports to flourish, said CCC. This will ensure that growth does not stagnate in the next few years and there will be opportunity for the private sector to reinvest and create more economic activity that will stimulate tax collection. “We hope that the improvements made to the fiscal framework will steer forward the discussions with the IMF and help mobilise financing to address the current shortfalls in external cash flow,” CCC in conclusion said. (PA)

title: Windies humbled by Scotland in another upset
author: Author not found
Content: Twice winners West Indies crashed to a shocking 42-run defeat by Scotland in their T20 World Cup opener in Hobart on Monday, the second major upset inside two days at the global showpiece tournament. The Caribbean side, who won the event in 2012 and 2016, were bundled out for 118 chasing 161 to beat the Scots a day after former champions Sri Lanka lost their Group A opener to Namibia. Left-arm spinner Mark Watt, who took 3-12, and off-spinner Michael Leask, with figures of 2-15, sealed victory for the associate team, who earlier rode upon opener George Munsey’s unbeaten 66 to post 160-5 in the Group B match. Jason Holder, who picked up two wickets with the ball, waged a lone battle for West Indies with a knock of 38, but it was not enough. Zimbabwe meet Ireland in the day’s second match at the same venue with the top two sides from each of the two groups progressing to the Super 12 stage. Scotland seemed to thrive in the cold and overcast conditions at the Bellerive Oval and got off to a brisk start after they were put in to bat, racing to 52-0 in the sixth and final over of the powerplay when rain forced the players off. The interruption, however, seemed to halt their momentum with experienced all-rounder Holder sending back opener Michael Jones, who made 20, and number three Matthew Cross in quick succession after the restart. Munsey anchored the innings but his 53-ball knock lacked fluency as the left-hander failed to find the boundary during the middle overs. Brief scores: Scotland 160/5 in 20 overs (George Munsey 66*, Jason Holder 1/14) West Indies 118 all out in 18.3 overs (Jason Holder 38; Mark Watt 3-12, Michael Leask 2-14)

title: Woman stabbed to death in Pannala
author: Author not found
Content: A woman was stabbed to death in a three-storey building in Negombo, Pannala, Police said. She was residing in a rented room located on the third floor. Police said, the murder occurred in the early hours of yesterday (17).  The victim is a 37-year-old resident of Kuliyapitiya, Weerambuwa. A resident had heard the woman scream and called the Police. However, she was already dead when they arrived. The murderer is still at large and the Pannala Police and Kuliyapitiya Criminal Investigation Division are conducting further investigations. By W.A. Sarath – Pannala

title: Commando Sergeant Major arrested
author: Author not found
Content: A Commando Regimental Sergeant Major (RSM), who had allegedly provided a T-56 rifle to a gunman to carry out the recent shooting in Ahungalla, has been arrested by the STF. The suspect armed with the firearm, who had arrived in a luxury car, had fired at a person inside a three-wheeler in Ahungalla town. The victim had succumbed to his injuries on 13 October night. The STF Officers had been able to locate the T-56 rifle at the spot where the victim had fallen after being fired at. Following inquiries conducted into the number of the T-56 Rifle, the STF had gathered information to the effect that the weapon had belonged to a soldier based at the Kilinochchi Army Camp. Thereafter, they had managed to arrest the RSM serving at the Kilinochchi Army Camp. According to the STF, the suspect RSM, aged 41, is a resident of Melsiripura and two mobile phones in his possession were seized. The RSM and another suspect who had aided and abetted in the shooting have been handed over to Ahungalla Police for further investigations. By Keerthi Mendis, Damsari Liyanage (Balapitiya)

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Bus fares will remain unchanged – Mirando
author: Author not found
Content: Bus fares will not be reduced in the near future, National Transport Commission (NTC) Director General, Nilan Mirando said. Mirando, responding to inquiries made by Ceylon Today following the price decrease of Auto diesel yesterday (17), said the NTC is still reviewing the price reduction of diesel. “Bus fares can only be reduced if the effectiveness of the reduction of fuel price is more than four per cent. We are still assessing the effectiveness. If the reports say that the price reduction of fuel is greater than four per cent, the bus fare will be reduced. If not, this fuel price reduction will be taken into account in the next price reduction,” he added. Minister of Power and Energy Kanchana Wijesekera announced that the price of 92 Octane Petrol will be reduced by Rs 40 per litre and the price of Auto Diesel by Rs 15 per litre effective 9:00 p.m. on 17 October and accordingly, the new price of 92 Octane petrol will be Rs 370 per litre, while Auto Diesel will be Rs 415 per litre. By Nabiya Vaffoor

title: Up Over 150% to Rs 13,460 by Aug
author: Author not found
Content: Sri Lanka’s monthly official poverty line (OPL) increased for the sixteenth consecutive month to August 2022, increasing by 2.45 per cent (Rs 322) to Rs 13,460 month-on-month (August 2022 over July 2022), Census and Statistics Department (CSD) data released on Friday (14 October) showed. In the previous month (July), this monthly figure (OPL) was Rs 13,138. In the 16-month period beginning from April 2021 to August 2022, Sri Lanka’s OPL has increased by over twofold or by more than 150 per cent (Rs 8,297) to Rs 13,460 led by a depreciated rupee, fuel shortages, scarred harvests and import bans and controls, official data further showed. The last time OPL declined was 16 months ago since August 2022, that is, April 2021 over March 2021, where the OPL fell by a negligible 0.01 per cent (Rs 4) to Rs 5,177, before increasing since. The OPL in March 2021 was Rs 5,181.   By Paneetha Ameresekere

title: Draft ‘Rehabilitation’ Law would spur abuse – HRW
author: Author not found
Content: The Government should withdraw a draft law that would give the authorities broad powers to detain people in military-run “rehabilitation” centres, placing them at great risk of abuse, Human Rights Watch said yesterday (17). The Bureau of Rehabilitation Bill, submitted to Parliament on 23 September, would allow the compulsory detention in centres of “drug dependant persons, ex-combatants, members of violent extremist groups and any other group of persons.” The Bureau of Rehabilitation Bill would establish a new administrative structure controlled by the Defence Ministry to operate “rehabilitation” centres staffed by military personnel. The proposed law, which human rights advocates have already challenged in the Supreme Court, does not describe the basis for being sent for “rehabilitation,” but other recent government policies provide vague and arbitrary powers to forcibly “rehabilitate” people who have not been convicted of any crime. “The Sri Lankan Government’s proposed ‘rehabilitation’ efforts appear to be nothing more than a new form of abusive detention without charge,” said Meenakshi Ganguly, South Asia Director at Human Rights Watch. “The Rehabilitation Bill would open the door widely to more torture, mistreatment, and endless detention.” The Sri Lankan Government has previously used coercive “rehabilitation” centres to enable arbitrary detention and torture. Following the war, which ended in 2009, thousands of people whom the Government identified as members of the defeated separatist LTTE were detained in military-run “rehabilitation” centres, where some were allegedly tortured and subjected to other abuses, including sexual violence. The current Bill seeks once again to “rehabilitate” “ex-combatants” 13 years after the war ended. The Rehabilitation Bill is the latest measure in a long history of laws, such as the Prevention of Terrorism Act (PTA), that authorise arbitrary detention and torture in Sri Lanka. The law could be used to target minority communities or anti-government protesters whom President Ranil Wickremesinghe has labelled “extremists.” Under the Rehabilitation Bill, which would allow prolonged detention without judicial oversight, government officials would be protected from criminal liability for their actions if they act “in good faith.” The Bill also empowers officials to use undefined “minimum force” to “compel obedience” from detainees. Another provision provides that an official who “without reasonable cause” strikes, wounds, ill-treats, or wilfully neglects anyone under rehabilitation can be punished by up to 18 months in prison, suggesting that there might be a “reasonable cause” to harm detainees. International law absolutely prohibits torture, and other cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment. The Rehabilitation Bureau Bill and the proposed amendment to anti-narcotics legislation are only the latest measures in President Wickremesinghe’s assault on fundamental rights, Human Rights Watch said. An attempt to use the Official Secrets Act to restrict public gatherings in the capital, Colombo, was withdrawn earlier in October amid widespread objections that the action was unlawful. On 6 October, the United Nations Human Rights Council adopted a resolution expressing concern at the human rights situation in Sri Lanka and mandating enhanced UN monitoring, as well as renewing a mandate for the UN to collect and analyze evidence of past human rights violations for use in future prosecutions. “President Wickremesinghe is pursuing abusive and repressive policies that make it difficult for Sri Lanka’s international partners to wholeheartedly back desperately needed economic measures,” Ganguly said. “Foreign governments should make clear that they will support the urgent needs of the Sri Lankan people, but they will also take action through targeted sanctions and other measures against those committing serious human rights violations.”

title: ‘Mahinda Nite’ to be held 5 November
author: Author not found
Content: Mahinda Nite 2022 organised by the Mahinda College, Galle Old Boys’ Association (OBA) Colombo will be held on 5 November 2022, at the Bougainvillea Ballroom, Galadari Hotel, Colombo. The event is held to raise money for the Mahinda College OBA Colombo Scholarship Fund and provide financial aid to students who have made special contributions at national and international level in sports and studies. Entertainment and music will be provided by Vision with Damayantha with guest performances by Mariazelle Goonetilleke and Mahesh Senanayaka as the compere. The Mahinda College OBA was started by Henry Woodward Amarasooriya in 1947 and some of the others who have committed to the development of the association are Professor M.B. Ariyapala, Vincent Panditha, Albert Edirisingha, Somasiri Ambawatta, Professor Vinee Vitharana, Edvin Ariyadasa, Professor Nandadasa Kodagoda, Dr. A.T. Ariyarathna, Dr. W.J. Wimaladharma, Lal de Alwis, Oliver Goonathilaka and Guinness Record holder W.B. Benet.

title: President hopes talks with China will be successful
author: Author not found
Content: President Ranil Wickremesinghe emphasised that he recently discussed Sri Lanka’s debt restructuring plan with the Chinese Finance Minister and he hopes that the discussions will be successful. The President mentioned that the Finance Minister, who is in Washington and leading a delegation met for the first time yesterday with the International Monetary Fund and the three main countries that have given loans to this country, China, India, and Japan. He stated that the government will prioritise confirmation. President Wickremesinghe said this yesterday (16) after touring the cultivation area around Rathumada and Weerakandawala in the Siyambalanduwa regional secretariat division. He said if a proper programme to provide food to the people is not implemented, they will not have to shed blood but will die in shame, and he emphasised that politics should only be discussed in parliament and that everyone should work together to fulfil the needs of the people regardless of party affiliation. The President visited the cultivation area around the fields of Siyambalanduwa, Rathumada, and Weerakandawala and engaged in friendly conversation with the farmers. Farmers had the opportunity to directly present their problems to the President and they informed him about the shortage of fertilisers, insecticides, and herbicides, as well as land problems, water problems, and the threat of wild elephants in the area. At that time, the President, who summoned the relevant officials to the farm land, was unique in taking steps to provide immediate solutions to the problems, and the farmers, who mentioned that this was the first time a President had visited their area, thanked the President for coming to them and investigating the problems. After noting down all of the problems presented by an officer of the President’s Office, the President appointed a separate Additional Secretary of the President’s Office and stated that he will take steps to provide quick solutions to those problems in coordination with District Political Authority officials. Many problems of the province’s people were also presented to the President, including issues such as education, roads, and housing.

title: Bangladesh hopeful SL will pay back USD 200M by March
author: Author not found
Content: Bangladesh is hopeful that Sri Lanka will repay the debt of USD 200 million that it owes to the country by March 2023. Abdur Rouf Talukder, Governor of Bangladesh Bank, provided a positive outlook on the matter after a meeting with his Sri Lankan counterpart, Nandalal Weerasinghe, in the United States. The Central Bank Chief travelled to Washington, D.C., to attend the Annual Meetings of the International Monetary Fund and World Bank. The two governors held a discussion on the sidelines of the seven-day event which began at the World Bank Headquarters on Tuesday. Speaking to reporters on Thursday, Talukder said, “We [Bangladesh] gave USD 200 million to Sri Lanka under a currency swap agreement. But due to Sri Lanka’s economic crisis, they could not return the money on time.” In light of the crippling economic crisis that gripped the island nation, Bangladesh twice extended the deadline for repayment on Sri Lanka’s request, Talukder said. “Sri Lanka is supposed to return it in three instalments in February and March 2023.” On the talks with Weerasinghe, Talukder said, “We had a very good meeting. The Governor assured me that they will meet the deadline for repayment. They are now restructuring their debts and have spoken to India, Japan, and China about it.” “And Sri Lanka is also working on a deal with the IMF that has also been roughly confirmed. A final agreement on the programme will probably be reached between November and December.” Last year, Bangladesh agreed to give Sri Lanka loans of at least USD 200 million from its foreign exchange reserves under a currency swap deal. The credit was to be repaid in instalments over three months, the Central Bank said at the time. But as the economic and political crisis in Sri Lanka worsened, its external debt became unsustainable. With political stability gradually being restored, Sri Lanka is now moving towards repaying its debts. Central Bank Governors from Commonwealth countries are also holding a meeting on Friday. Bangladesh has been given the opportunity to chair the meeting, according to Talukder. The Governor is leading an 11-member Bangladeshi delegation at the annual event in place of Finance Minister A.H.M. Mustafa Kamal, who could not make the trip. Talukder also met the Vice Chairman of the US banking giant JPMorgan and the Managing Director of Standard Chartered’s Asia-Pacific region. “They want to offer various facilities to Bangladesh. We told them that we appreciated their interest. If we increase the size of our loans in future then why not. We asked them to support our private sector.” (bdnews24.com)

title: Kottu price down by Rs 50
author: Author not found
Content: The All Island Canteen Owners’ Association (AICOA) has decided to reduce the price of kottu by Rs 50, following the reduction of the wholesale price of 1 kg of wheat flour to Rs 290. Speaking to Ceylon Today yesterday (16), AICOA Chief Asela Sampath said, the benefit of the price reduction of wheat flour should be shared with the people. He added that the main wheat flour companies can reduce 1 kg of wheat flour to Rs 250 as Minister of Trade Nalin Fernando said in Parliament on 3 October. By Nabiya Vaffoor

title: Only JJB can re-build country – AKD
author: Author not found
Content: Only the Jathika Jana Balawegaya (JJB) has an honest team capable of rebuilding the country, Leader MP Anura Kumara Dissanayake said. Addressing the Divisional Council in Kesbewa on Saturday (15) Dissanayake said the people have real power because they were able to depose the ‘Rajapaksa’ clan. However, the people are disorganised, which is why the second uprising must be organised by the JJB, Dissanayake said. “Former President Gotabaya Rajapaksa was forced to flee Sri Lanka. Former Prime Minister Mahinda Rajapaksa was compelled to flee Temple Trees and seek refuge at the Trinco naval base. Basil Rajapaksa was unable to get a flight to leave the country. The Rajapaksa camp, which was once rock solid, crumbled in front of our very eyes. From this, it is clear that the people have power. However, the people are disorganised. The JJB is currently organising people through Divisional Councils,”Dissanayake said. He said a key responsibility is to protect the people in the face of the country’s bankruptcy. “Production in the country has collapsed and inflation has increased greatly. People are losing their jobs. Monthly wage earners cannot pay off their loans. People are rising up against this oppression,” he said. Dissanayake said the Government is trying to push such an uprising into violence. Therefore, the JJB Division Council should give leadership to well-organised groups, he said. BY Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: Climate change secretariat to be set up
author: Author not found
Content: The Government has decided to establish a climate change secretariat. It will be set up under President Ranil Wickremesinghe’s directives to manage future climate disasters as Sri Lanka is also subject to constant climatic changes, a spokesman said. The Sri Lanka Climate Change Secretariat will be established under the supervision of the Presidential Adviser on Climate Change, Ruwan Wijewardene to prepare plans to deal with climatic challenges across the island. An Act regarding the establishment of an International University on Climate Change in Sri Lanka and to deal with climate changes is scheduled to be drafted and passed in the Parliament in the near future, according to sources. President Wickremesinghe will comment on the Climate Change Secretariat to be established in the country at the COP 27 World Conference on Climate Change which will be held in Egypt from 6 to 18 November. Wijewardene said many countries have set up such secretariats to face future climate challenges and have collected funds to face future climate challenges.

title: 34 DS Divisions on red alert
author: Author not found
Content: The National Building Research Organisation (NBRO) issued landslide warnings to 34 Divisional Secretariat divisions in six districts across the island. Accordingly, level three – red evacuation, level two – amber and level one – yellow early landslide warning alerts have been issued to 34 Divisional Secretariat Divisions in six Districts. Senior Scientist of Landslide Research and Risk Management Division at NBRO, Dr. K. P. G. Wasantha Senadeera said the Kalutara, Kegalle, Nuwara Eliya, Colombo, Galle and Ratnapura Districts were among them. He said as rainfall exceeded disaster limits, the level three high risk evacuation level landslide early warning alerts have been issued to Walallawita, Ingiriya, Palindanuwara and Bulathsinhala DS divisions and the surrounding areas in the Kalutara District, Ambagamuwa DS Division and the surrounding areas in the Nuwara Eliya District and Kalawana and Eheliyagoda DS divisions in the Ratnapura District. On the basis of showers occurring in a particular area, two amber warnings have been issued to Dodangoda, Agalawatta, Bandaragama, Millaniya, Horana and Matugama DS divisions and the surrounding areas in the Kalutara District, Dehiowita, Warakapola Ruwanwella DS divisions and the surrounding areas in the Kegalle District and Kuruwita, Ayagama, Nivithigala, Elapatha, Ratnapura, Kiriella and Pelmadulla DS divisions and the surrounding areas in the Ratnapura District, according to Dr. Senadeera. Dr. Senadeera said yellow warning alerts have been issued to Seethawaka and Padukka DS divisions and the surrounding areas in the Colombo District, Kalutara, Beruwela, Panadura and Madurawala DS divisions and the surrounding areas in the Kalutar District and Yatiyantota, Deraniyagala, Mawanella and Bulathkohupitiya DS divisions and the surrounding areas in the Kegalle District. People living in other hilly areas have been asked to be vigilant of possible occurrence of landslides in case they notice any landslide signs such as slanting of trees, telephone and light posts, emergence of sudden springs and muddy water in close proximity and neighbouring areas and cracks on the ground or walls of buildings, to move to safer places after informing the  authorities including the police, Dr. Senadeera added. Meanwhile, the  Meteorology Department yesterday predicted that shower or thundershowers could occur at times in the Western, Sabaragamuwa, Central and North Western provinces today (17). While commenting on the current nature of the atmosphere, duty meteorologist,SadhushkaPremachandrasaid heavy showers above 100 millimetres can be expected at some places in the Western and Central provinces as well as the Galle and MataraDistricts. She further said showers or thundershowers can be expected elsewhere over the island during the afternoon or night. Fairly heavy showers above 75 millimetres can be expected at some places, she added. Premachandra also cautioned of possible heavy winds and lightning strikes and in the event of such circumstances, adequate precautionary measures should be taken to minimise damage caused by localisedtemporary heavy winds and lightning strikes. BY Naalir Jamaldeen

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Only JJB can re-build country – AKD
author: Author not found
Content: Only the Jathika Jana Balawegaya (JJB) has an honest team capable of rebuilding the country, Leader MP Anura Kumara Dissanayake said. Addressing the Divisional Council in Kesbewa on Saturday (15) Dissanayake said the people have real power because they were able to depose the ‘Rajapaksa’ clan. However, the people are disorganised, which is why the second uprising must be organised by the JJB, Dissanayake said. “Former President Gotabaya Rajapaksa was forced to flee Sri Lanka. Former Prime Minister Mahinda Rajapaksa was compelled to flee Temple Trees and seek refuge at the Trinco naval base. Basil Rajapaksa was unable to get a flight to leave the country. The Rajapaksa camp, which was once rock solid, crumbled in front of our very eyes. From this, it is clear that the people have power. However, the people are disorganised. The JJB is currently organising people through Divisional Councils,”Dissanayake said. He said a key responsibility is to protect the people in the face of the country’s bankruptcy. “Production in the country has collapsed and inflation has increased greatly. People are losing their jobs. Monthly wage earners cannot pay off their loans. People are rising up against this oppression,” he said. Dissanayake said the Government is trying to push such an uprising into violence. Therefore, the JJB Division Council should give leadership to well-organised groups, he said. BY Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: Navy puts 36 relief teams on standby
author: Author not found
Content: Sri Lanka Navy has kept 36 relief teams on standby to extend relief measures to people, in the backdrop of inclement weather conditions reported in several areas of the island. On the directive of Navy Commander, Vice Admiral Nishantha Ulugetenne, the Western Naval Command has sent two relief and rescue teams to Rathnapura and four teams to Kalutara. In addition, 21 more relief and rescue teams in the Western Naval Command and nine similar teams in the Southern Naval Command have been kept on standby for swift deployment.

title: COMPANIES TO HANDLE ORGANIC FERTILISER DISTRIBUTION
author: Author not found
Content: President Ranil Wickremesinghe emphasised that organic fertiliser distribution will be handled by companies in the future and not the ministry. He said one problem in regard to fertiliser is that there are bills of Rs 8 billion from last year and the Government has settled about Rs 4 billion. “I am here to review the implementation of the Food Security Programme in the Ampara District. We also identified the shortcomings in the implementation of the programme at rural level. The problem of organic fertilisers was raised. The distribution of organic fertiliser was made by the Ministry last year, but this year we have left it to the companies. So, those companies will provide the fertiliser. Secondly, discussions will be held with the Civil Security Department and relevant officials for this endeavour. We did not mention the armed forces, that make a considerable contribution to production. Therefore, we should also involve the armed forces in this programme,” he said. Speaking further, he also said although food could not be brought in during the Second World War, the economy did not collapse. He said now the economy has collapsed and this year the economy has recovered somewhat, in comparison to last year. “But still there are issues. If we print money, the inflation rate would rise. There are limitations when dealing with the available money. Somehow, we should all come together to find solutions to these problems. What the people need to do now is to commence the cultivation activities in their own areas and report it. Thereafter, our food security bureau will inform us about the types of food that we require. There is no issue with paddy cultivation. If this season is successful, we will have an excess stock. Production of crops such as maize should be increased. I request you to obtain additional space for such crops and carry out cultivation,” he added. He said first, food security should be ensured, and second, a food programme should be launched to eliminate malnutrition. “We too would support them. Food banks and community kitchens have been set up to support this programme. We are going through a difficult period and we must not allow anyone to starve. Once the next Maha Season is successful, we can move forward and we need to continue this programme until the end of 2023. Even if our problem is solved, a global food crisis may arise, so we have to continue this programme to ensure food security in our country,” he further said.

title: COORDINATE RELIEF WORK WITH DMC
author: Author not found
Content: President Ranil Wickremesinghe instructed all District Secretaries to coordinate relief work with the help of the Disaster Management Centre for those affected by inclement weather. The President also said the Ministry of Finance has allocated resources and he has directed officials to provide food and medicine to affected people. He advised the officials to pay special attention to the sanitary facilities of affected people. The President further instructed the District Secretaries to work in coordination with all the Divisional Secretaries and officials of the line ministries to get the support of government officials and the armed forces in this relief programme. According to the Disaster Management Centre report, as of 16 October, 15,404 families in 52 Divisional Secretariats have been affected by the strong winds, landslides, and floods that affected 11 districts, namely Trincomalee, Galle, Kilinochchi, Kalutara, Gampaha, Colombo, Puttalam, Ratnapura, Kandy, Hambantota, and Kegalle. Three people have been killed and two people have been injured due to inclement weather. The report said five houses were destroyed and 193 were partially damaged. It said 1,927 people from 439 families who were affected by bad weather are taking shelter in 21 relief centres islandwide.

title: Poultry meat, egg prices to rise
author: Author not found
Content: Minister of Agriculture Mahinda Amaraweera said the production of chicken meat and eggs may be problematic next year due to a decrease in parent animal imports due to a lack of foreign exchange. He said in 2021, 80,000 parent animals were imported to Sri Lanka to breed chickens but in 2022, due to a lack of foreign exchange and the suspension of parent animal exports by countries such as India, the import of parent animals to Sri Lanka has been reduced to 7000. He said although the annual production of eggs was between 1000-3000 million, in 2021, due to the lack of chemical fertiliser, production of maize dropped and although the production of eggs in Sri Lanka was 2934 million in 2021, by June 2022, the production of eggs in Sri Lanka has decreased by 34 per cent to 1,963 million. He further said although the per capita consumption of eggs in this country was 35 ten years ago, it is expected to increase to 125 by the end of 2022. He also said despite egg prices rising, the egg industry in this country is currently in a state of crisis. BY Nirmani Gunaratne

title: CEB generates electricity without fuel oil for the first time this year
author: Author not found
Content: Aided by rains, for the first time for the year, Ceylon Electricity Board (CEB) didn’t have to burn the more expensive and pollutive fuel oil to provide electricity to the country on Saturday (15), CEB’s data showed. Of the total electricity consumed by Sri Lanka on Saturday which was 33.96 Giga Watt hours (GWh), cheap and clean renewable energy (RE) provided 70.64 per cent (23.99 GWh) of the island’s electricity needs,  while coal provided the balance  29.36 per cent (9.97 GWh), statistics showed. Sri Lanka’s record daily power cuts and Saturday being a holiday also aided in CEB not having to burn the expensive fuel oil, or procure electricity from the private sector (PS)/ Independent power producers’ (IPP’) after generating electricity by burning fuel oil by them. Coal at Rs 10.68 a unit (kilo Watt hour (kWh) was the second most cheapest electricity generation source for the CEB last year (2021) according to latest Central Bank of Sri Lanka data, while the most expensive was electricity generated by CEB after burning fuel oil at Rs 32.03 a unit and the second most expensive by procuring electricity generation from the PS/IPP at Rs 30.35 a unit of fuel oil, last year. Meanwhile the cheapest source of electricity generation last year was ‘CEB hydroelectricity’ at  Rs 1.67 a unit, second most cheapest coal (Rs 10.68) and the third most cheapest, “other sources of RE” at Rs 16.22 last year. On Saturday, “CEB hydroelectricity” which is another form of RE provided 61.07 per cent (20.74 GWh) of Sri Lanka’s total electricity needs and “Other RE,” 3.25 GWh, respectively, statistics showed. “Other RE” comprises electricity generated from a combination of PS run ‘minihydros’,  ‘CEB wind’, ‘PS wind’ and by burning ‘biomass’, respectively, while coal the balance 29.36 per cent (9.97 GWh). BY Paneetha Ameresekere

title: Palmyrah industry in the spotlight
author: Author not found
Content: Fisheries Minister Douglas Devananda said, Minister of Plantation Industries and Minister Ramesh Pathirana has promised him that he will take steps to address concerns of those involved in palmyrah-related production. He said, he discussed the problems of those involved in the palmyrah industry with Minister Pathirana, and that the latter promised him that an expeditious solution would be found to the issues. After 40 years, the Palmyrah Development Board finally has its own building. According to Minister Devananda, Minister Pathirana also praised the Palmyrah Development Board officials for their prompt action. He expressed confidence that a huge sum of money paid for the rented building where the Board was functioning can be saved today and can be used for the development of the palmyrah industry and to raise the living standards of people depending on it as well. Devananda said that during the discussion it was clear that Minister Pathirana has well-understood the problems the people engaged in palmyrah-related industries were facing and expressed confidence that it will be able to address those issues soon. “When I was the Minister of Trade and Small Industries I shifted the head office of Palmyrah Development Board from Colombo to Jaffna in 2010. The Palmyrah Development Board was established in 1978 and my father K. C. Nithyanantha was the first chairman of it”, Minister Devananda said.   The Palmyrah Research Centre constructed with sophisticated modern facilities in Kaithady area in Jaffna is currently engaged in research activities to provide more services to people engaging in palmyrah related industries and productions, Minister Devananda added. By Naalir Jamaldeen

title: Medicine shortfall to be eased- Rambukwella
author: Author not found
Content: Minister of Health, Keheliya Rambukwella, said it is expected to produce 50 per cent of the country’s medicines in the next three years. He said because this country’s population is so small in comparison to countries such as India, Pakistan, and Bangladesh, pharmaceutical companies cannot launch products aimed solely for citizens. The Minister also said an unprecedented 66 per cent inflation occurred today, and the World Bank stated in its most recent report that food inflation is 94 per cent. “Controlling inflation will be impossible unless we pay attention to this and implement special programmes. It is strictly forbidden to hold any type of ceremony in the Ministry. We need to import 25-30 per cent more medicines next year, and I informed the authorities that I would not import medicines next year after comparing the amount brought in previous years. The lower middle class is facing serious economic difficulties. Many of them cannot afford private medical care,” he explained. He said, low-income families use state-run hospitals because they cannot afford private hospital bills. He noted that the next generation cannot be raised in poor health. “It is completely wrong to claim that Indian loan assistance was not used to bring medicines. Something of that sort had been reported in the media. Thousands of documents have been sent to the Indian Embassy. They were sent to Delhi with great effort. Then approval has to be obtained. Sometimes, there are  unexpected delays,” he said. K. L. Suraweera – Kandy

title: Twenty housing units for Kajimawatta residents
author: Author not found
Content: Twenty (20) housing units will be provided to Kajimawatta residents who fulfil the minimum requirements while nearly 214 fall short of qualifying and are not entitled to housing. A report on the Kajimawatta fire was handed over to the Secretary, UDA. According to the report, as the remaining residents do not meet the minimum requirements it is not possible to provide houses in accordance with standards approved under the Urban Revitalisation Project. Kajimawatta, which caught fire recently comes under the purview of the National Housing Development Authority and is about five acres in extent. According to the report, Kajimawatta was handed over to the UDA on a temporary basis to run an intermediate camp under the initial urban revitalisation project in 2011 until permanent houses were provided to families residing on those lands. When the UDA releases land to construct apartment complexes, displaced families are temporarily settled in Kajimawatta. The number of families that were settled in that instance was 275 and Kajimawatta was subsequently emptied when families were given housing units. However, on several occasions, about 50 family units were settled in this intermediate camp. However, due to political intervention, after 2014 about 291 unauthorised families were settled on this land. The report also states that following the 2015 presidential election, people from different areas have been illegally settled here on several occasions due to political interference. But the urban revitalisation plan implemented in that year removed all squatters from Kajimawatta and the land was freed of residents.But since January 2016, 291 illegal residents have been resettled in Kajimawatta. It is further stated that according to instructions of the Ministry of Metropolitan and Western Development, the Management in 2019 approved 57 housing units to be given to families that fulfilled the minimum requirements.

title: Five local fishers detained in India
author: Author not found
Content: Indian Coast Guard said it detained a mechanised fishing boat with five Sri Lankans off the Kanniyakumari coast. Sources in the Coast Guard said the vessel, ICG Shaurya, spotted a boat registered in Sri Lanka fishing 90 nautical miles off the coast of Kanniyakumari on Saturday. As the boat was reportedly inside Indian waters, it was detained along with its passengers — five Sri Lankan fishermen. The boat is likely to be brought to the Thoothukudi Harbour on Sunday. After being handed over to the Marine Police, they will be questioned and then produced before court. (The Hindu)

title: Paddy farmers to get 176 kg urea per ha
author: Author not found
Content: The Department of Agriculture recommended providing 176 kg of urea fertiliser per hectare to farmers who cultivate paddy land. In the last Yala season, 100 kg of urea fertiliser was given to farmers for paddy cultivation per hectare, but this year, due to the recommendation of the Department of Agriculture to apply 70 per cent chemical fertiliser and 30 per cent organic fertiliser, the amount of urea fertiliser given to paddy farmers has been increased by 76 kg, Minister of Agriculture Mahinda Amaraweera said. Further, the quantity of urea fertiliser given for more than one hectare of paddy fields will also be increased, he said, adding that those with 2 hectares of paddy land will be provided with 352 kg of urea fertiliser.

title: Chinese officials in poor countries face unpleasant jobs as debt collectors
author: Author not found
Content: Across much of the developing world, China finds itself in an uncomfortable position as the world’s debt collector amid rising inflation and a weakening global economy. Over the past decade, Beijing has been the lender of choice for many nations. It doled out funds for governments to build bullet trains, hydroelectric dams, airports, and superhighways. However, as inflation climbed and economies weakened, China found itself in a precarious situation. Keith Bradsher, writing in The Sydney Morning Herald (SMH), said China holds significant sway over the financial futures of many nations and owes huge sums of money that may never be repaid in full forcing its officials to act as debt collectors in poor countries. When Suriname couldn’t make its debt payments, a Chinese State Bank seized the money from one of the South American country’s accounts. When Kenyans and Angolans went to the polls in the Presidential Elections in August, the countries’ Chinese loans, and how to repay them, were a hot-button political issue, the SMH report said. The economic distress in poor countries is palpable, given the lingering effects of the pandemic, coupled with high food and energy prices after Russia’s invasion of Ukraine. Many borrowed heavily from China. In Pakistan, overall public debt has more than doubled over the past decade, with loans from China growing fastest. In Kenya, public debt is up ninefold and in Suriname tenfold, it said. The nature of China’s loans is compounding the challenges. China issues far more loans to poor countries at adjustable interest rates than Western governments or multilateral institutions. With global interest rates rising swiftly, debt payments are soaring when these nations can least afford to pay. Bureaucratic warfare among powerful government ministries in Beijing has already forestalled any easy solution to the debt problem and threatens to delay it further. A new slate of ministers will take over in March, likely restarting the process to address debt issues, reported SMH. Notably, China and the United States have favoured different approaches to debt troubles. In the past, Beijing has tended to lend more money to some countries, including Argentina, Ecuador, and Pakistan, so that they can continue to make payments on existing loans. China’s approach helps these countries afford imports of food and fuel, but leaves them with ever more debt. The United States prefers requiring government agencies and banks to forgive part of their loans. This was done during the Latin American debt crisis in the 1980s, so that borrowers could afford to repay the interest on the remaining debt. But this approach requires banks to immediately accept heavy losses, a tough sell in China given its economic slowdown and housing crisis. Bradsher said weakening home prices and stalled real estate transactions have already left Chinese banks with bad loans to developers and homebuyers. Those conditions also mean that Chinese banks are reluctant to lend more to countries, including under the Belt and Road Initiative, China’s policy framework for developing countries. According to the IMF, three-fifths of the world’s developing countries are now having considerable trouble repaying loans or have already fallen behind on their debts. More than half the world’s poor countries owe more to China than to all Western governments combined. (ANI)

title: WFP aiding 3.4M Lankans
author: Author not found
Content: The World Food Programme (WFP) has begun its emergency operation to provide food and nutrition assistance to 3.4 million people in Sri Lanka, a Food and Agriculture Organisation (FAO) statement released on Friday (14 October), quoting Gerard Rebello, Officer in Charge at WFP, Sri Lanka, said. “We are also continuing to work with smallholder farmers to make food systems more robust and resilient to climate-induced shocks so that food travels uninterrupted from farm to table, even during times of crises,” he said. Rebello also highlighted that urgent action was needed to safeguard the most vulnerable and marginalised communities from the impacts of the crisis.  The occasion was to mark World Food Day which took place on 14 October, where an event was held in Colombo in this regard. “FAO is committed to working with the Government of Sri Lanka to ensure that the most vulnerable fishers and farmers, crucial to ensuring food security in Sri Lanka, are protected from the worst impacts of the crisis while providing essential agriculture inputs, such as seeds and fertiliser, through the support of our partners to boost production and help Sri Lanka move towards becoming a food secure nation,” the statement quoting FAO Representative for Sri Lanka and the Maldives, Vimlendra Sharan who also spoke at this event, said. International Fund for Agricultural Development (IFAD) Country Director Sherina Tabassum another speaker at this occasion said, “We are committed to continue our work with the Government of Sri Lanka (GoSL) to sustainably transform Sri Lanka’s food systems so everyone can benefit.” She further said, “Our goal is to ensure that the backbone of our food system – smallholder farmers – are prepared for, and can overcome, the devastating effects of the pandemic, climate change and other external shocks.” FAO, IFAD and WFP together with the United Nations system in Sri Lanka are on the ground delivering emergency cash assistance, essential fertiliser and livelihood support to the most vulnerable communities in affected districts, the statement said. Premier Dinesh Gunawardena who was the keynote speaker at this event said, “Nearly 30 to 35 per cent of the population directly or indirectly dependent on agriculture for their livelihood in the country. Sri Lanka needed to invest deeply in modernising and developing the agriculture sector, adding that his “Government is fully committed to achieving this gigantic task. Agriculture and food security remain a national priority.” President Ranil Wickremesinghe delivering a video message to mark the event said, “Sri Lanka is at a crucial and critical juncture with high levels of food insecurity. We are thankful to the United Nations system, multilateral and bilateral partners, and the donor community for joining hands and building this strong partnership to address the current crisis.”  Agriculture Minister Mahinda Amaraweera who also spoke at this occasion announced the introduction of a new Agriculture Policy to Parliament focusing on modernising and building resilience to enable the agriculture sector to withstand future crises, the statement further said. (PA)

title: Fifteen SJB demonstrators arrested in Nawalapitiya
author: Author not found
Content: Police arrested 15 persons, including Samagi Jana Balawegaya (SJB) organiser Sasanka Sampath, in Nawalapitiya yesterday (16) for engaging in a demonstration without Police permission. The group, which included Sampath, attempted to hold a demonstration in Nawalapitiya yesterday citing a number of demands, including solutions to the rising cost of living. While the group was travelling from near the District General Hospital in Nawalapitiya to Nawalapitiya town to engage in the demonstration, the Nawalapitiya Police informed them that they had not obtained permission from the Police to hold the demonstration in Nawalapitiya town. However, the group attempted to enter the town to carry out the demonstration. As a result, the police arrested the group. BY Neeta Pathma Kumari – Hatton

title: Ananda College students attend ICSQC 22
author: Author not found
Content: A group of students from Ananda College, Colombo will participate in the 23rd International Convention on Students’ Quality Circles (23rd ICSQC 22) organised by QUEST-Nepal from 14 to 17 October. The event will provide students with an opportunity to explore and enhance their personal and interpersonal skills and take advantage of valuable opportunities to showcase their talents at the international level. Front Row Seated (From left) Maduwanthi Mannapperuma, Teacher in charge Societies, Chandani Kannangara, Assistant Teacher in charge, D.L.S.K. Maduranga, Deputy Principal-Administration, D.M.L.P. Perera, Deputy Principal-Sports & Co-Curricular Activities, Risitha Dasanayake, Team Leader, Lanka Wijeratne, Teacher in charge of Quality Circle, Maduri Senawiratne, Teacher in charge of Societies. Middle Row (From left) Kulith Wickramasinghe, Ginura Kariyawasam, Thisal Dinsara, Tharuk Weerasooriya, Charuka Niwunhella, Senitha Senarathne, Okitha Karunadhara, Sathishka Lanka Geeganage. title: Poultry meat, egg prices to rise
author: Author not found
Content: Minister of Agriculture Mahinda Amaraweera said the production of chicken meat and eggs may be problematic next year due to a decrease in parent animal imports due to a lack of foreign exchange. He said in 2021, 80,000 parent animals were imported to Sri Lanka to breed chickens but in 2022, due to a lack of foreign exchange and the suspension of parent animal exports by countries such as India, the import of parent animals to Sri Lanka has been reduced to 7000. He said although the annual production of eggs was between 1000-3000 million, in 2021, due to the lack of chemical fertiliser, production of maize dropped and although the production of eggs in Sri Lanka was 2934 million in 2021, by June 2022, the production of eggs in Sri Lanka has decreased by 34 per cent to 1,963 million. He further said although the per capita consumption of eggs in this country was 35 ten years ago, it is expected to increase to 125 by the end of 2022. He also said despite egg prices rising, the egg industry in this country is currently in a state of crisis. BY Nirmani Gunaratne

title: CEB generates electricity without fuel oil for the first time this year
author: Author not found
Content: Aided by rains, for the first time for the year, Ceylon Electricity Board (CEB) didn’t have to burn the more expensive and pollutive fuel oil to provide electricity to the country on Saturday (15), CEB’s data showed. Of the total electricity consumed by Sri Lanka on Saturday which was 33.96 Giga Watt hours (GWh), cheap and clean renewable energy (RE) provided 70.64 per cent (23.99 GWh) of the island’s electricity needs,  while coal provided the balance  29.36 per cent (9.97 GWh), statistics showed. Sri Lanka’s record daily power cuts and Saturday being a holiday also aided in CEB not having to burn the expensive fuel oil, or procure electricity from the private sector (PS)/ Independent power producers’ (IPP’) after generating electricity by burning fuel oil by them. Coal at Rs 10.68 a unit (kilo Watt hour (kWh) was the second most cheapest electricity generation source for the CEB last year (2021) according to latest Central Bank of Sri Lanka data, while the most expensive was electricity generated by CEB after burning fuel oil at Rs 32.03 a unit and the second most expensive by procuring electricity generation from the PS/IPP at Rs 30.35 a unit of fuel oil, last year. Meanwhile the cheapest source of electricity generation last year was ‘CEB hydroelectricity’ at  Rs 1.67 a unit, second most cheapest coal (Rs 10.68) and the third most cheapest, “other sources of RE” at Rs 16.22 last year. On Saturday, “CEB hydroelectricity” which is another form of RE provided 61.07 per cent (20.74 GWh) of Sri Lanka’s total electricity needs and “Other RE,” 3.25 GWh, respectively, statistics showed. “Other RE” comprises electricity generated from a combination of PS run ‘minihydros’,  ‘CEB wind’, ‘PS wind’ and by burning ‘biomass’, respectively, while coal the balance 29.36 per cent (9.97 GWh). BY Paneetha Ameresekere

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

author: Author not found
