title: Navy puts 36 relief teams on standby
author: Author not found
Content: Sri Lanka Navy has kept 36 relief teams on standby to extend relief measures to people, in the backdrop of inclement weather conditions reported in several areas of the island. On the directive of Navy Commander, Vice Admiral Nishantha Ulugetenne, the Western Naval Command has sent two relief and rescue teams to Rathnapura and four teams to Kalutara. In addition, 21 more relief and rescue teams in the Western Naval Command and nine similar teams in the Southern Naval Command have been kept on standby for swift deployment.

title: COMPANIES TO HANDLE ORGANIC FERTILISER DISTRIBUTION
author: Author not found
Content: President Ranil Wickremesinghe emphasised that organic fertiliser distribution will be handled by companies in the future and not the ministry. He said one problem in regard to fertiliser is that there are bills of Rs 8 billion from last year and the Government has settled about Rs 4 billion. “I am here to review the implementation of the Food Security Programme in the Ampara District. We also identified the shortcomings in the implementation of the programme at rural level. The problem of organic fertilisers was raised. The distribution of organic fertiliser was made by the Ministry last year, but this year we have left it to the companies. So, those companies will provide the fertiliser. Secondly, discussions will be held with the Civil Security Department and relevant officials for this endeavour. We did not mention the armed forces, that make a considerable contribution to production. Therefore, we should also involve the armed forces in this programme,” he said. Speaking further, he also said although food could not be brought in during the Second World War, the economy did not collapse. He said now the economy has collapsed and this year the economy has recovered somewhat, in comparison to last year. “But still there are issues. If we print money, the inflation rate would rise. There are limitations when dealing with the available money. Somehow, we should all come together to find solutions to these problems. What the people need to do now is to commence the cultivation activities in their own areas and report it. Thereafter, our food security bureau will inform us about the types of food that we require. There is no issue with paddy cultivation. If this season is successful, we will have an excess stock. Production of crops such as maize should be increased. I request you to obtain additional space for such crops and carry out cultivation,” he added. He said first, food security should be ensured, and second, a food programme should be launched to eliminate malnutrition. “We too would support them. Food banks and community kitchens have been set up to support this programme. We are going through a difficult period and we must not allow anyone to starve. Once the next Maha Season is successful, we can move forward and we need to continue this programme until the end of 2023. Even if our problem is solved, a global food crisis may arise, so we have to continue this programme to ensure food security in our country,” he further said.

title: WECare Worldwide tackling rabies – 7,000 dogs at a time
author: Author not found
Content: UK veterinary charity WECare Worldwide announced that they are joining the fight against rabies in Sri Lanka by presenting a plan to vaccinate over 7,000 Sri Lankan dogs against rabies. This initiative will take place within the next six months, coming as a reaction to the issues associated with procuring life-saving post-exposure treatment for humans caused by Sri Lanka’s current economic crisis. “We have to take rabies seriously. This is one of the world’s most deadly infectious diseases and is endemic in Sri Lanka. The heartbreaking thing about rabies is that all of the deaths, whether human or animal, are needless as they can be prevented,” saidDr. Janey Lowes, Founder and Head of Organisation at WECare. Rabies is virtually 100% fatal once symptoms appear. According to the WHO, rabies transmission is preventable through the vaccination of dogs and the prevention of dog bites. The Department of Health recognises that maximum impact is gained when all organisations, including the Department of Animal Production & Health and NGOs like WECare Worldwide, work together. W.C. Devasurendra, PHI Anti-Rabies Unit, Matara said, “For the elimination of rabies, it will be the duty and the responsibility of every person to support the Anti-rabies activities.” There have been numerous suspected and confirmed rabies cases at WECare’s veterinary hospital in Gandara, dedicated to street animals. Since 2014, WECare has vaccinated almost 15,000 animals, but has now decided to upscale its efforts as an emergency measure, vaccinating and microchipping more than 7,000 dogs within only six months. The initiative is executed by WECare, and its partner Battersea, one of the UK’s oldest and most well-known animal welfare charities. This Battersea-funded programme will last six months, but WECare Worldwide plans to continue its increased efforts for at least the next three years. Currently, the Charity is expanding their organisation to include a dedicated outreach team of veterinarians, nurses, dog catchers, data managers and assistants to continue after the initial programme. “As veterinarians, we have the duty not only to the animals we serve but also to the public by protecting them from any diseases that spread from animal to human.” This six-month pilot project takes place in the southern province of Sri Lanka, between the cities of Matara and Dickwella. It will offer free rabies vaccination to the street- and privately-owned dogs and cats. People living in this area can contact the organisation to get their pets vaccinated, helping Sri Lanka eradicate this deadly disease. “We are committed to making rabies a thing of the past and collaborating with the government and other hard-working NGOs in this effort,” said Dr. Janey Lowes.

title: Complaints stack up against Priyamali
author: Author not found
Content: A specialist doctor has lodged a complaint with the CID, claiming that Thilini Priyamali, who is in remand custody on charges of misappropriating large sums of money, had taken Rs 750 million from him. He was accompanied to the CID by a well-known Attorney-at-Law. Another multi-millionaire female also complained to the CID that Priyamali took Rs 45 million from her. The total number of complaints received against Priyamali is now 10, Police said. Meanwhile, the CID recorded statements from employees of Priyamali’s company, Thico Group of Companies Pvt Ltd. yesterday (13). Ceylon Today learns that 35 persons who have connections with the company will be questioned in the coming days. Thilini Priyamali appeared before a prison tribunal, presided over by Colombo Additional District Judge yesterday (13). She was charged with having a mobile phone in her possession while being held in custody at the Welikada prison. Priyamali pleaded not guilty to the charges levelled against her before the prison tribunal, according to Prison Spokesman Chandana Ekanayake and the hearing was adjourned to 3 November for further examination. “Priyamali was produced yesterday at the Welikada prison before the prison tribunal, led by the Colombo Additional District Judge, on the charge of possessing a mobile phone, which is an illegal and prohibited item in the prison,” he said. Priyamali’s mobile phone was confiscated by the Prison Emergency Response Unit on 9 October during a search of the women’s section of the Welikada Prison. The Prison Emergency Response Unit, according to Prison Spokesman Chandana Ekanayake, launched an investigation in collaboration with the Welikada Prison authorities. According to the findings revealed through the investigation, it was said that the suspect, Priyamali, received the phone from another woman and information is being sought from the officers of the women’s section in this connection. BY Keerthi Mendis and Thameenah Razeek

title: Pera Uni lecturers say will resume lectures
author: Author not found
Content: Peradeniya Arts Faculty Teachers’ Association (PAFTA) issued a statement, confirming that they will resume the conduct of lectures immediately, once the Student Union (SU) assured their commitment to restoring normalcy and to a violence free environment in the Faculty of Arts. Prof. Arjuna Parakrama, President of PAFTA expressed these views, yesterday (13) in a special statement regarding the specific incident, on the 14 September, in which he confirmed that a group of students studying law in the Faculty of Arts were assaulted while they were dining in the canteen and were subsequently prevented from entering the canteen premises and that this practice has been continuing for years now. “Due to the behaviour of ‘Raggers’ the ‘Anti-Raggers’ are forced to find other inadequate spaces for their daily interactions and even to have their meals. The violent and intolerant culture of the rag in the universities is such that anti-raggers are either prevented from residing in the halls of residence or hounded out of the halls of residence through other means,” Prof. Parakrama noted. Prof. Parakrama further claimed that to return to the specific incident, on the 14th of September a group of students from the Department of Law, who could find no other place, decided to have their midday meal in one of the two main student canteens in the vicinity, which later has resulted in a faction of the Rag Group to assault these students, and to later bar the Law students’ from entry into the canteen. “On hearing the commotion, the Dean of the Arts Faculty, along with other members of the staff, intervened and made it clear on that occasion that all public areas of the University commonly accessed by students, were open to all students, with no exceptions at all. However, promises made at this meeting were willfully broken within hours, resulting in further violence against these Law students. To end this spiraling cycle, the Dean, on the basis of the Faculty Board’s decision, asked for a written assurance on the part of the two affected student groups and the student union, the official representative body of the students, guaranteeing their commitment to free and open access to the canteens and other common facilities to all,” he noted. Meanwhile, he alleged that initially, in the interest of protecting the anti-rag group, on-site classes were converted to the online mode. “However, after further discussion and clear intransigence on the part of the union and its allies, who alone of the three groups refused to provide such a letter, it was decided that until such an assurance is made, all academic activities of the Faculty of Arts should be suspended as such activities cannot be conducted in an environment of violence and intimidation. To date, the Student Union has failed to provide such assurance,” he added.Further, Prof. Parakrama noted that subsequent to the interventions made by the Dean, he became the target of threats and intimidation made by some students led by the Student Union. “An effigy of him was burnt near the very canteen and he was publicly vilified at a much-publicised student union rally on the 15 September. In condemning the rag and the violence of 14 and 15 September, we can only improve the quality of education and the well-being of the university system,” he added. Prof. Parakrama noted it has to be made crystal clear that they recognise the inalienable right of students to engage in political activities and to work towards constructive social and systemic change. (NV)

title: Outdated Acts to be amended
author: Author not found
Content: Minister of Justice Wijeyadasa Rajapakshe will take steps to submit to Parliament the amendments to five Acts that are outdated by more than 150 years.  He said arrangements have been made to present the five Acts, namely the Notaries Ordinance, the Document Registration Act, Wills Ordinance, the Powers of Attorney Ordinance and the Prevention of Frauds Ordinance, to the Parliament.  These amendments have been aimed at preventing fraud due to non-amendment of these Acts. The Minister said many activities are done using technology and making relevant amendments in a manner that is compatible with it is another objective of his.   The Minister said due to the fact that certain acts have not been amended, information has been revealed that some notaries and lawyers are committing various frauds and a large number of related cases are pending in the Courts.   Apart from this, he further said that the 22nd Constitution Amendment Act should be debated and adopted within the next two days on 20 and 21 October.   BY Kumudu Upul Shantha

title: Discussion on insurance claim fruitful – Sagala
author: Author not found
Content: All the discussions with regard to getting the insurance claim, for the MV X-Press Pearl disaster, worth millions of dollars have been successful, President’s Chief-of-Staff Sagala Ratnayake said. He said a discussion was held recently at the Presidential Secretariat with the participation of the insurance agents, representatives of the company that owned the ship and several relevant parties. All of them showed a positive response with regard to the matter, he added. He also said that the President has instructed to conclude the cases filed in the High Court against the Captain of the ship and other parties as soon as possible. Also, following the President’s instructions, the Central Environmental Authority (CEA) has appointed an experts’ committee to determine the true damages to the environment to obtain compensation from the responsible parties, he added. Meanwhile, Fisheries Minister Douglas Devananda said yesterday (13), that the third phase payment of compensation to fishermen impacted by the X-press Pearl disaster is currently underway and added that Rs 781 million has been spent for this so far. Devananda added that following the disaster, fishing activities the seas off the coast of Gampaha, Kalutara and Colombo Districts had been temporarily suspended and as a result fishermen had lost their employment. Those fishermen in these districts had already been paid compensation in the first and second phases. The programme to provide compensation under the third phase is currently underway, according to Devananda.  “The Treasury had set aside Rs 781 million for these districts. Accordingly Rs 520 million to Gampaha District, Rs 193 million for Colombo District and Rs 37 million for the Kalutara District has been allocated.  Fifty per cent of compensation funds have already been released to the Gampaha, Colombo and Kalutara District Secretaries,” the Fisheries Minister said. Funds have been allocated to provide compensation to 3,056 fishermen engaging in fishery activities in the Negombo lagoon area. The relevant officials have been instructed to provide them compensation expeditiously, Devananda added. By Naalir Jamaldeen

title: Two lost leopard cubs returned to mother
author: Author not found
Content: Two leopard cubs, which were discovered on the Dickoya Estate in Hatton yesterday (13), were returned to their mother that was going around in search of them. Two healthy cubs, a male and a female, said to be just 10 days old, were discovered at the base of the tea mountain by plantation employees, who afterwards contacted the Wildlife officials of the Nallathanni Forest Fauna Department through their employer. Later, officers from the Department of Wildlife took the required steps to rescue the cubs and return them to their mother.   She took one of the cubs and returned two and a half hours later to take the other. According to wildlife officials, the family was later relocated to the forest area. Meanwhile, a three-feet-long male leopard, caught in a trap set by farmers was rescued by the wildlife officials in the hills of the upper division of Seppelton, Bogawanthalawa yesterday (13). The leopard had been trapped for about eight hours and was struggling to escape. The workers had then informed the plantation officer in the morning of 12 October and he, in turn, informed the Police. The Police had called the Nallathanni Wildlife officials to rescue the big cat after sedating it. It is said that those who have vegetable farms had set the trap for wild animals. Caught in a trap wire, the leopard had been in pain for several hours. A veterinary doctor was called from Randenigala Animal Hospital and the leopard was rescued after being sedated. The leopard was taken to Minipe Animal Hospital for treatment. Officials said it will be released at the sanctuary after recovery. By K. Kishanthan

title: Arrested for assisting murder suspects
author: Author not found
Content: A person was arrested for aiding and abetting the suspects who were involved in the double murder that was reported from Moratuwa on 26 June 2022, Police said. The arrest was made by the Mount Lavinia Criminal Investigation Division on 12 October. He was later handed over to Mount Lavinia Police. The suspect was identified as a 20-year-old resident of Egoda Uyana. Police said the suspect had purchased two mobile SIMs using his National Identity Card of the suspects involved in the double murder. Police were able to find the two mobile phones that were used by the main suspects. By Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: Authorities decide against punishing teachers
author: Author not found
Content: The Western Province Department of Education (WPDE) has decided not to take disciplinary action against teachers who appeared in a video, circulated on social media, celebrating Children’s Day, claiming the event was coordinated by teachers and principals. The department decided to conduct an investigation following a video, on social media, of a couple of teachers celebrating Children’s Day dancing to the song ‘Madyapaane Thiyena Joliya Gaanu Nodanne.’ In a letter to the Western Province Education Secretary, Western Province Director of Education Srilal Nonis said the celebration was collaboration between students and teachers. However, the Zonal Coordinator for Negombo Zonal Education Office R. D. N. P. Chandrasena stated, in an annexure to the letter, that the video of the Children’s Day circulating in social media is the Children’s Day celebration at Kadirana Kanishta Vidyalaya in Negombo, and the principal of the school is fully aware of the situation and the celebration. “It was revealed that there was no prior knowledge about the song being played at the time of the incident, and it was an unexpected and unintentional occurrence. There has been no fault or breach of discipline by the parties involved, and no further action is required,” Chandrasena stated in the letter. BY Thameenah Razeek

title: ITAK MPs meet Solheim
author: Author not found
Content: Ilankai Tamil ArasuKachchi (ITAK) Batticaloa District MP Shanakiyan Rasamanickam said he and TNA Spokesman MP M. A. Sumanthiran yesterday (13) met former Norwegian Minister of International Development and Minister of Environment Eric Solheim, who is currently in Sri Lanka.   Rasamanickam said that they discussed the current economic crisis. Attention was focused on recovery of Sri Lanka’s collapsed economy, green development, political reformation, strengthening the bilateral political and economic ties between the two countries and various other current issues, Rasamanickam added. By Naalir Jamaldeen

title: Court issues notice on Sirisena, Dayasiri
author: Author not found
Content: Colombo District Court Judge Purnima Paranagama yesterday (13) issued notice on Sri Lanka Freedom Party (SLFP) Chairman MP Maithripala Sirisena and General Secretary MP Dayasiri Jayasekera, to make submissions before her on 19 October. This was in connection with the case, filed by Minister of Ports Nimal Siripala de Silva, who has prayed the Court, to issue an order invalidating the decision taken by the party, to remove him from his party positions. Via his petition to the Court, the Minister has stated that the SLFP, during one of its party meetings, held on 2 September, had taken a unilateral decision to amend the party Constitution. He had informed Judge Paranagama, via his petition, that as per the new powers vested with the party General Secretary, through the amendment to the Constitution, they had arbitrarily removed him from his party position. The petitioner has further observed that a clandestine meeting convened by the party, has no such powers, vested with it, to amend the party Constitution, according to their own whims and fancies. Hence, the petitioner has moved the Court, to issue an order, to make the decision, taken by the party, to fire him from his party post, null and void and to issue an injunction, preventing the respondents or their representatives, from obstructing his work at in the Party. By Hansi Nanayakkara

title: Cargills Foundation to implement their ECE Programme in the CP
author: Author not found
Content: Cargills Foundation will be expanding their ECE (Early Childhood Education) programme to the Central Province with the on-boarding of 50 preschools, including 1,500 children, from the districts of Kandy, Matale and Nuwara-Eliya. The ECE programme aims to provide children aged 3-5 an opportunity to develop and enhance their knowledge of the English language, through exposure to basic concepts of Science, Technology, Engineering, Arts, and Mathematics (STEAM). The programme was launched in Kandy at an event attended by the Central Province Governor Lalith Gamage, Gamini Rajarathna (Chief Secretary, Central Province), Premasinghe (Education Secretary, Central Province), Gunathilaka (Director of Early Childhood Development, Central Province) and teachers of the 50 preschools. The teachers received a starter pack comprising books, teacher guides, with day-wise lesson plans and guidance, on introducing a new language in an entertaining way that makes learning fun. Cargills Foundation has already implemented the ECE programme in the Western and Uva provinces. Plans are underway to implement the programme in all provinces across the country.

title: Cop in soup over kiss
author: Author not found
Content: The Police Children and Women’s Bureau (PCWB), yesterday (13) informed Colombo Additional Magistrate Keminda Perera, that they have commenced a probe into an incident, where a Police Sergeant, attached to the Parliament Division, had allegedly forcibly kissed a female Police Constable, also attached to the same Police Division. The Police told the Court, that in the complaint lodged by the plaintiff, it has been stated that while she had been on her way to report for duty on 29 September, the suspect Police Sergeant, who had been waiting on the roadside, had then followed her. According to the Police, the plaintiff had mentioned, that the actions of the suspect, had brought her much embarrassment and ridicule and it had also made her for her life. Hence, the PCWB told Magistrate Perera, that they are conducting further inquiries into the incident. (To inform about sexual harassments contact PCWB by phone number 011244444 or visit the PCWB Headquarters/nearest police station) By Hansi Nanayakkara

title: Legal action against hotels, bakeries
author: Author not found
Content: Hatton, Dickoya Urban Council PHI Ramiah Balakrishnan said legal action will be instituted against nine hotels and bakeries situated in the Hatton, Dickoya areas on charges of operating under unhygienic conditions and failing to maintain the necessary standards required. He stated that on the advice of the Urban Council Chairman Sadayan Balakrishnan several hotels and bakeries situated in the said areas had been inspected. He added that upon inspection they had decided to prosecute the owners of nine hotels and bakeries for failing to maintain the requisite standards while operating such places. According to Balakrishnan the owners of the hotels and bakeries have been noticed to appear before the Hatton District Court on 28 August. By C.D.H. Hewage (Watawala)

title: SL abstains from voting against Russia
author: Author not found
Content: Sri Lanka on Tuesday (11) abstained from voting at the United Nations General Assembly vote, held to denounce the attempt of Russia to annex four Ukraine regions. Thirty-five (35) nations abstained from voting, and 143 countries voted in favour of the resolution condemning Russia. China, India, Pakistan, Sri Lanka, and others did not participate in the vote. The United Nations resolution, ‘defending the principles’ of the UN Charter, notes that the regions of Donetsk, Kherson, Luhansk and Zaporizhzhia are temporarily occupied by Russia as a result of aggression, violating Ukraine’s territorial integrity, sovereignty and political independence. The General Assembly automatically took up the resolution for debate, triggered by Russia’s use of the veto in the Security Council over its attempted annexation. (FT)

title: Necklace snatchers arrested
author: Author not found
Content: Three members of an organised gang, known for snatching gold items worn by women, were arrested on 12 October, sources at the Kalutara Crimes Division said. They stated that the suspects had been arrested following inquiries into the snatching of two gold necklaces worn by a female teacher and an old woman from the Kalutara North and Anguruwathota Police Divisions. According to the Police the two gold necklaces snatched by the suspects have been estimated at Rs. 400,000. The suspects, who are residents of the Palathota, Alwiswatta and Tekkawatta areas, are due to be produced before the Kalutara Chief Magistrate’s Court. By Sumith Ranawaka (Pothupitiya)

title: VCs envision comprehensive strategy to fight ragging
author: Author not found
Content: The Committee of the Vice Chancellors and Directors (CVCDs) noted that the ragging complexities require a comprehensive strategy planned by Universities, law enforcement authorities, political parties, and media with the support of the civil society for its prevention and elimination. Responding to continuous reporting of ragging cases in State Universities, CVCD issued a statement, yesterday (13), there needs to be a strong movement against ragging in civil society to encourage the new entrants to universities, and their parents, to stand up to organised groups of student perpetrators motivated by political intentions. CVCD noted that the universities face the threat of cyber ragging, in addition to physical, mental, or sexual forms. “The universities are faced with multiple issues in their efforts to eliminate ragging. These include the lack of legitimate complaints with evidence or clues for identification of perpetrators; lack of a robust system for protection of victims and witnesses, inaction of law enforcement authorities to fully implement the provisions of the Act No. 20 of 1998 on prevention of ragging, and slowness of the judicial and disciplinary procedures. In many instances, dissemination of one-sided information obtained from highly vocal student movements opposes the university administration in taking action against the student perpetrators of ragging,” noted CVCD. It is common for protests to be stage-managed in front of University Grants Commission or the Ministry of Education to pressurise authorities to withdraw or mitigate punishments that have been handed to perpetrators after due process. “In the past, there have been instances where instead of supporting the Vice Chancellors and University authorities in taking stern actions against ragging and other acts of student indiscipline and violence, undue influences have been made by external forces to the legal and disciplinary processes. This aims to protect perpetrators with scant regard to the rights of the victims and the harm caused to them,” noted CVCD. The CVCD views with grave concern the fact that perpetrators abuse provisions in the legal system and exploit the facility of taking their complaints to the Human Rights Commission. This occasionally escalates to severe harassment of VCs and university authorities. The CVCD requests the civil society to understand that ragging has been in existence in Sri Lankan universities for 70 years, with damaging consequences. The CVCD notes that the recent reduction or near-elimination of ragging as has occurred in some universities, was the result of active intervention by university authorities led by the VCs, who risked their lives and positions. Hence, the CVCD reiterates its commitment to fight ragging in the Universities and to eliminate it. In this endeavour, it wishes to seek the support of the media, civil society, and the Government of Sri Lanka without which, this will be impossible to achieve. (NV)

title: Coconut cultivations hit by disease
author: Author not found
Content: Farmers in the Southern Province said their coconut cultivations have been hampered by a spate of reasons and they lamented that they will not be in a position to reap a rich harvest. They stated that a disease spread by a white coloured insect has begun to ravage their coconut cultivations in Dodanduwa of late. According to these farmers, the coconut harvest in the Dodanduwa has dwindled by 90 per cent and they request the authorities to intervene and curb the spread of the disease or their livelihood would be in jeopardy. By Dharmadasa Siriwardena (Ambalangoda)

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Court issues notice on Sirisena, Dayasiri
author: Author not found
Content: Colombo District Court Judge Purnima Paranagama yesterday (13) issued notice on Sri Lanka Freedom Party (SLFP) Chairman MP Maithripala Sirisena and General Secretary MP Dayasiri Jayasekera, to make submissions before her on 19 October. This was in connection with the case, filed by Minister of Ports Nimal Siripala de Silva, who has prayed the Court, to issue an order invalidating the decision taken by the party, to remove him from his party positions. Via his petition to the Court, the Minister has stated that the SLFP, during one of its party meetings, held on 2 September, had taken a unilateral decision to amend the party Constitution. He had informed Judge Paranagama, via his petition, that as per the new powers vested with the party General Secretary, through the amendment to the Constitution, they had arbitrarily removed him from his party position. The petitioner has further observed that a clandestine meeting convened by the party, has no such powers, vested with it, to amend the party Constitution, according to their own whims and fancies. Hence, the petitioner has moved the Court, to issue an order, to make the decision, taken by the party, to fire him from his party post, null and void and to issue an injunction, preventing the respondents or their representatives, from obstructing his work at in the Party. By Hansi Nanayakkara

title: Cargills Foundation to implement their ECE Programme in the CP
author: Author not found
Content: Cargills Foundation will be expanding their ECE (Early Childhood Education) programme to the Central Province with the on-boarding of 50 preschools, including 1,500 children, from the districts of Kandy, Matale and Nuwara-Eliya. The ECE programme aims to provide children aged 3-5 an opportunity to develop and enhance their knowledge of the English language, through exposure to basic concepts of Science, Technology, Engineering, Arts, and Mathematics (STEAM). The programme was launched in Kandy at an event attended by the Central Province Governor Lalith Gamage, Gamini Rajarathna (Chief Secretary, Central Province), Premasinghe (Education Secretary, Central Province), Gunathilaka (Director of Early Childhood Development, Central Province) and teachers of the 50 preschools. The teachers received a starter pack comprising books, teacher guides, with day-wise lesson plans and guidance, on introducing a new language in an entertaining way that makes learning fun. Cargills Foundation has already implemented the ECE programme in the Western and Uva provinces. Plans are underway to implement the programme in all provinces across the country.

title: Cop in soup over kiss
author: Author not found
Content: The Police Children and Women’s Bureau (PCWB), yesterday (13) informed Colombo Additional Magistrate Keminda Perera, that they have commenced a probe into an incident, where a Police Sergeant, attached to the Parliament Division, had allegedly forcibly kissed a female Police Constable, also attached to the same Police Division. The Police told the Court, that in the complaint lodged by the plaintiff, it has been stated that while she had been on her way to report for duty on 29 September, the suspect Police Sergeant, who had been waiting on the roadside, had then followed her. According to the Police, the plaintiff had mentioned, that the actions of the suspect, had brought her much embarrassment and ridicule and it had also made her for her life. Hence, the PCWB told Magistrate Perera, that they are conducting further inquiries into the incident. (To inform about sexual harassments contact PCWB by phone number 011244444 or visit the PCWB Headquarters/nearest police station) By Hansi Nanayakkara

title: Legal action against hotels, bakeries
author: Author not found
Content: Hatton, Dickoya Urban Council PHI Ramiah Balakrishnan said legal action will be instituted against nine hotels and bakeries situated in the Hatton, Dickoya areas on charges of operating under unhygienic conditions and failing to maintain the necessary standards required. He stated that on the advice of the Urban Council Chairman Sadayan Balakrishnan several hotels and bakeries situated in the said areas had been inspected. He added that upon inspection they had decided to prosecute the owners of nine hotels and bakeries for failing to maintain the requisite standards while operating such places. According to Balakrishnan the owners of the hotels and bakeries have been noticed to appear before the Hatton District Court on 28 August. By C.D.H. Hewage (Watawala)

title: SL abstains from voting against Russia
author: Author not found
Content: Sri Lanka on Tuesday (11) abstained from voting at the United Nations General Assembly vote, held to denounce the attempt of Russia to annex four Ukraine regions. Thirty-five (35) nations abstained from voting, and 143 countries voted in favour of the resolution condemning Russia. China, India, Pakistan, Sri Lanka, and others did not participate in the vote. The United Nations resolution, ‘defending the principles’ of the UN Charter, notes that the regions of Donetsk, Kherson, Luhansk and Zaporizhzhia are temporarily occupied by Russia as a result of aggression, violating Ukraine’s territorial integrity, sovereignty and political independence. The General Assembly automatically took up the resolution for debate, triggered by Russia’s use of the veto in the Security Council over its attempted annexation. (FT)

title: Necklace snatchers arrested
author: Author not found
Content: Three members of an organised gang, known for snatching gold items worn by women, were arrested on 12 October, sources at the Kalutara Crimes Division said. They stated that the suspects had been arrested following inquiries into the snatching of two gold necklaces worn by a female teacher and an old woman from the Kalutara North and Anguruwathota Police Divisions. According to the Police the two gold necklaces snatched by the suspects have been estimated at Rs. 400,000. The suspects, who are residents of the Palathota, Alwiswatta and Tekkawatta areas, are due to be produced before the Kalutara Chief Magistrate’s Court. By Sumith Ranawaka (Pothupitiya)

title: Missing Uni student returns
author: Author not found
Content: The third-year student of Peradeniya University’s Faculty of Engineering, who had been missing for 10 days, returned to the university in the afternoon of 12 October. Peradeniya University Deputy Vice-Chancellor Terence Madujith said that the missing student has returned to the university. The students had disappeared, from the hostel on 2 October, leaving behind a letter. The university had filed a complaint with the Peradeniya Police regarding the incident. It has been revealed to the Police that the student has returned to the university after spending a few days somewhere in Badulla. BY K. L. Suraweera (Kandy)

title: Tea Down 5% to $ 955M
author: Author not found
Content: Tea export earnings, in the first  nine months  of the year, declined by 4.79 per cent (US$ 48.09 million) to $ 955.33 million (free on board) year on year (YoY) and export volumes fell by 9.02 per cent (19.09 million kg) to 192.61 million kg in the same period, Forbes and Walker Tea Brokers’ data released  on Wednesday (12) showed. However, tea export prices gained for the fifth consecutive month to last month (September 2022), aided by high oil prices, accelerating by 4.64 per cent($ 0.22) to average at $ 4.96 per kg fob in the reviewed nine month period compared to a flat YoY growth experienced in the first seven months of the year. Tea prices move in relation to oil prices. When oil prices rise, tea prices increase, but when oil prices fall, tea prices also decline, Ceylon Chamber of Commerce Chairman Vish Govindasamy told this newspaper recently. Consequently, the ‘fob’ price of a kg of tea accelerated by 21.88 per cent (US$ 0.99) to a record high $ 5.52 per kg (fob), YoY last month. However, tea export volumes fell for the fifth consecutive month to last month, scarred by President Gotabaya Rajapaksa’s six month chemical fertiliser export ban from April 2021 to November 2021, declining by 8.02 per cent (1.88 million kg) YoY to 21.54 million kg last month. Subsequently, tea export earnings last month declined by 8.02 per cent ($10.37 million) to $ 118.93 million (fob) YoY.  Tea export earnings were Sri Lanka’s third largest foreign exchange (FX) earner for two consecutive years to last year (2021), Central Bank of Sri Lanka (CBSL) data showed. According to Forbes, Iraq has remained the No. 1 major importer of Ceylon Tea with an increase of 25 per cent imports YoY for January-September 2022. Russia secured second position with a total of 17.80 million kg, though a 12 per cent decrease against total imports recorded for January-September 2021. UAE sits in 3rd place with a total of 16.71 million Kg followed by Türkiye, Iran, Libya and Azerbaijan respectively during the period January-September 2022. However, a significant decrease in imports is reported from Türkiye (55 per cent), China (19 per cent), Chile(11 per cent), Syria (22 per cent), Japan (10 per cent) and Jordon (24 per cent) YoY, Forbes said, while a notable increase in imports is recorded from Azerbaijan (10 per cent), Germany ( eight per cent), USA ( six per cent) and Poland (13 per cent) YoY, it said. ‘Fob’ means the price of the goods when boarded on a vessel for export at the exporter’s port. ‘Cif’ or ‘cost, insurance, freight’ means the price of goods, after being received at the importer’s port. BY Paneetha Ameresekere

title: President will rebuild economy by next May – Vajira
author: Author not found
Content: UNP Chairman Vajira Abeywardena claimed yesterday (13) that President Ranil Wickremesinghe will be able to rebuild the collapsed economy of the country by April or May next year. Abeywardena said that the people of this country must be vigilant of current situation and should not be misguided by false propagandas and rumours. At a time when the country was facing a severe economic crisis no one appeared take the responsibility. However, President Wickremesinghe taking the future of the country into consideration is now working with proper plans for the nation’s recovery, he claimed. Addressing the media at Sirikotha, Abeywardena said at this critical juncture, the people should act with prudence and exercise caution. As there so many expenses involved with holding the election, the current situation of this country is not ideal to go for an election. He said that ‘Aragalaya’ was necessary but it should have been a national ‘Aragalaya’. If any narrow minded political party or leader is trying to mislead the people, they must not be given room to practise their agendas and must be barred from politics. “The National Council has been established in Parliament. Arriving at a common ground remains a prime focus of the National Council. If any political party is ready to present an unchangeable development policy framework, President Wickremesinghe is ready to bring it into effect immediately. Every political party can present their proposals and plans to the National Council” Abeywardena said. “When it was announced that Sri Lanka has become bankrupt, President Wickremesinghe, as an MP raised his voice against it. The Hansard of Parliament, issued on 8 April 2022, is evidence. At that moment no one was ready to support him. The authorities of the previous government made such an announcement in violation of Articles 147, 148, 149, 150 and 151 of the Constitution,” Abeywardena stressed. “These days some people are attending the protests with their children. After that they allege their children’s rights are being violated. They were the ones who violate the rights of their children. It has been stated by UNHRC that taking the children to places where there is a war or hot atmosphere is illegal. Certain countries practise strict laws in this connection. President Wickremesinghe has instructed the relevant authorities to take necessary action to formulate a national policy framework in connection with the protection of children of this country considering all these facts,” Abeywardena added. By Naalir Jamaldeen

title: Panabokke presents credentials to Korean President
author: Author not found
Content: South Korean President Yoon Suk Yeol accepted Letters of Credence, from six Ambassadors-Designate to the Republic of Korea, at the Presidential Office, the Korean Embassy in Sri Lanka said. Among them was Savitri Indrachapa Panabokke from Sri Lanka. A member of the Sri Lanka Foreign Service, Panabokke counts over 22 years in the Sri Lanka Foreign Service and has held many positions in the Ministry of Foreign Affairs in Colombo and at Sri Lanka missions abroad, Sri Lanka’s Embassy in Korea’s website said. She held the post of Director General of Regional Cooperation immediately prior to her assignment to Seoul. (PA)

title: Appellate Court warns Sanath Nishantha
author: Author not found
Content: The Court of Appeal yesterday (13) warned State Minister of Water Supply Sanath Nishantha that he would be remanded if he defaults appearing before Court when he is noticed to do so. This was when Nishantha failed to appear before Court yesterday (13) although he was noticed to do so in connection with the Contempt of Court cases filed against him. The case was taken before Court of Appeal Judges Nishshanka Bandula Karunaratne and R. Gurusinghe. Counsel appearing for Nishantha, President’s Counsel Faisz Musthapha informed Court that his client was not duly served notice to which the Counsels for the petitioners, President’s Counsels Romesh de Silva, Saliya Pieris and Upul Jayasuriya moved Court to issue an arrest warrant against Nishantha and to suspend any bail application. Taking into consideration the arguments made by the parties, Court issued an arrest warrant for the IGP to arrest Nishantha and to produce him before Court. However, as Nishantha later appeared before Court and his lawyers moved for the warrant to be re-called, the warrant was recalled and Nishantha was sternly warned. The Petitions were filed by Lawyers Vijith Kumar and Priyal Sirisena and the Judicial Service Association of Sri Lanka (JSASL). It was stated in the Petitions that Nishantha, who spoke at a media conference, held at the SLPP party headquarters on 23 August, had expressed critical views on the manner in which the Magistrates acted in granting bail to the suspects involved in the ‘Aragalaya’ protest movement and, added that the MP has damaged the honour and the image of the Judiciary. The petitioners further charged that Nishantha has committed contempt of the Court through the aforementioned act, adding that it is a punishable offence in accordance with Article 105 (3) of the Constitution. Accordingly, the petitioners requested the Court to issue an order to summon before the Court the original video clips of the concerned press conference which were aired by several private television channels. Furthermore, the petitions also requested the Court to issue an interim order for Nishantha to refrain from making any statements that may be in contempt, in the future. Moreover, the petitions sought an order to be issued to the Attorney General to file a charge sheet against the respondent, charging him with contempt of Court and a summons to be issued to the concerned MP to appear before the Court and further to question the reasons why he should not be punished. In addition, the petitions requested that a hearing of the petition be held and Nishantha be charged with contempt of Court under Article 105 (3) of the Constitution. BY Faadhila Thassim

title: Using Children in Protests a Serious Offence – President
author: Author not found
Content: As a sequel to the incident where children were taken to a recent protest at Galle Face Green, President Ranil Wickremesinghe yesterday (12) said using children as ‘human shields’ in demonstrations was a serious offence under Sri Lankan law and urged Police to take immediate action to prevent such behaviour from being repeated. He upheld the need for an Act to protect children’s rights to prevent them from being used for sexual activities and to protect their fundamental rights. President Wickremesinghe issued these instructions during a special discussion on the protection of children’s rights held at the Presidential Secretariat yesterday morning (12). Highlighting sub-section 13 of Article 27 of the Constitution, “The State shall promote with special care the interests of children and youth, so as to ensure their full development, physical, mental, moral, religious and social, and to protect them from exploitation and discrimination,” he further emphasised that protecting children was the prime responsibility of a government. Steps were also taken to assign the responsibilities of child protection to the Sri Lanka Police and related government institutions. Wickremesinghe advised officials to discuss this issue with the Attorney General in order to take necessary steps in this regard. The President drew attention to the detention of children who were among those arrested for illegally migrating to India, and therefore were separated from their parents. Wickremesinghe said, this situation needs to be rectified immediately and arrangements must be made to return the children to their parents. The President also requested special attention to be paid to the education of children in orphanages and protection of their rights. He advised officials to submit a report on those with special needs in such institutions. Discussion about taking children to protest sites was initiated following the recent protest in Galle Face Green on 9 October to commemorate those who lost their lives during the ‘Aragalaya.’ A 15-year-old child was arrested and a toddler had to be hospitalised following the use of force by Police to remove protesters from the site prior to the commemoration. (TR)

title: Vidura, Douglas conduct inspection
author: Author not found
Content: Buddhasasana, Religious and Cultural Affairs Minister Vidura Wickremanayake and Fisheries Minister Douglas Devananda paid a visit to Trincomalee’s historic Koneswaram Temple on 11 October. Wickremanayake and Devananda conducted an inspection following requests made by various factions, including the temple administration, stating that the makeshift boutiques set up on both sides of the road leading to the temple obstructed devotees and to relocate them. Both ministers attempted to find a solution to this issue in consultation with the kovil administration as well as the operators of the boutiques. They also paid a visit to the two sites selected to relocate the boutiques. By Naalir Jamaldeen

title: ESTATE LABOURER’S DEATH UNDER THE MICROSCOPE
author: Author not found
Content: Minister of Labour and Foreign Employment, Manusha Nanayakkara, yesterday (12) instructed the Ministry Secretary and the Commissioner General of Labour to immediately conduct an investigation into an employee of Namunukula Plantation Company being electrocuted. Nanayakkara called for an investigation as to whether the accident happened while the employee was carrying out work out of his own volition or whether he was forced to carry out electrical work even though he had no knowledge of the subject and to take action under the Labour Law  against those who instructed him to do so. A 25-year-old labourer, Harshan Ganeshmurthy who resided in the Karawanella estate belonging to the plantation company, died on 9 October due to electrocution. The post-mortem examination conducted by the Badulla Judicial Medical Officer was confirmed that death was due to electrocution. It is reported that the worker was a regular labourer and was forced to carry out electrical maintenance work. Based on media reports and information received in this regard, Nanayakkara called for an immediate investigation and strict measures to be taken in accordance with the Labour Law. Meanwhile, addressing the opening session of the National Occupational Safety and Health Week held at the BMICH in Colombo on 11 October, Nanayakkara said, measures are underway to introduce a system to pay immediate compensation  in such situations instead of having to wait for years to get compensation. Nanayakkara said, strict rules will be put in place to ensure health and safety of workers at the workplace, and a system will also be introduced to give compensation without lawsuits through an insurance fund in the event of an accident. (NV)

title: Malnutrition has increased to 14% – Keheliya
author: Author not found
Content: Malnutrition in the country has increased to 14 per cent, Health Minister Keheliya Rambukwella said. He was speaking to the media following a programme held yesterday (12). Rambukwella said while malnutrition was previously at 12 per cent, it has now risen to 14 per cent, and he hopes to reduce it to 10 per cent. “For me, the primary concern is people’s hunger, inadequate nutrition of children, and feeding time for pregnant mothers. Starvation cannot be eradicated. However, malnutrition was at 12 per cent. It has now reached 14 per cent. It has just increased by 2 per cent. We are trying to reduce it to 10 per cent. We were an economic powerhouse back in the day,” he said. By Thameenah Razeek

title: Erik Solheim appointed Int’l Climate Adviser
author: Author not found
Content: Erik Solheim, Norway’s former Climate and Environment Minister, has been appointed as President Ranil Wickremesinghe’s International Climate Adviser. Solheim arrived in Sri Lanka on Monday (10), and met President Wickremesinghe on Tuesday (11). In response to the meeting, Solheim announced his appointment as the President’s International Climate Adviser, alongside Maldivian Speaker, Mohamed Nasheed. Solheim further said, President Wickremesinghe has a great vision for green economic recovery and for Sri Lankan climate leadership. Earlier, Solheim served as a mediator between the Government and the LTTE during Sri Lanka’s separatist war. He also served as a peace negotiator when the ceasefire agreement was signed by then Prime Minister Ranil Wickremesinghe and during Mahinda Rajapaksa’s tenure as President.

title: Prosecute those responsible – Dayasiri
author: Author not found
Content: All those responsible for the shift of Sri Lanka from a middle-income country to a low-income country should be prosecuted, SLFP General Secretary, MP Dayasiri Jayasekara said. He said, the entire Cabinet ought to be ashamed of themselves for allowing the country to be struck by poverty. Jayasekara added that all those responsible for the economic crisis should be dealt with severely. He was speaking at a media briefing at the SLFP Head Office yesterday (12). By Savani Sheashadhi

title: Priyamali handed over to CID
author: Author not found
Content: Businesswoman Thilini Priyamali who is being held in remand custody, on charges of misappropriation of money from businessmen and VIPs was handed over to the Criminal Investigations Department (CID) yesterday (12). Prison Media Spokesman said Priyamali was handed over to the CID to be taken to four locations for further investigations. Priyamali was escorted by Prison and Police officials when she was taken to the World Trade Centre (WTC), Colombo where her office is situated. She was arrested following a complaint lodged by businessman, last week for financial misappropriation of Rs 226 million, USD 60,000, Australian $100,000, and gold items. Meanwhile, Police yesterday informed the public that if anyone is affected by  financial or property rackets linked to Priyamali, they could report their cases to the nearest police station or to the CID.

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Police attacked peaceful protests – CTU
author: Author not found
Content: The National Child Protection Authority (NCPA) should understand that it is the Police that created an unsafe environment for children when they attacked peaceful protests, the Ceylon Teachers’ Union (CTU) said. Responding to claims of NCPA Chairman, Udayakumara Amarasinghe that people use children as human shields in public protests, CTU General Secretary Joseph Stalin, said the Aragalaya was identified as Aadaraye Aragalaya (struggle of love) since it was a peaceful protest and parents brought children with them.  “Parents who brought children to the protest site in Galle Face Green recently did so because the protest was a peaceful one. Until the police attacked protestors without any reason as there was no violence in the protest and it was safe for  children,’ he added. Meanwhile, the CTU lodged a complaint with the NCPA on 10 October against police brutality on children during a protest on 9 October at Galle Face Green. The complaint was based on video footage that showed a 15-year-old child being arrested by Police at the protest on 9 October. The footage also showed a mother being dragged away from her child. Meanwhile, NCPA Chairman said, the NCPA will take serious note of the situation and will look into it as a special case as this trend of using children as ‘human shield’ is on the rise. By Nabiya Vaffoor

title: Pre-trial conference on 9 Nov
author: Author not found
Content: Colombo High Court Judge Navaratne Marasinghe yesterday (12) ordered the Pre-Trial Conference with regard to the case filed against death row inmate Gampola Vidanage Samantha Kumara alias Wele Suda, on charges of illegal possession of firearms, to be heard on 9 November. Drug kingpin Wele Suda is presently on death row after being convicted over charges of drug trafficking.  Accordingly, the Court ordered the witnesses, to be present to give evidence on the said date in the trial including the OIC of the Boralesgamuwa Police Station. The Attorney General indicted the accused before the High Court, on two counts and on charges of unlawful possession of a T-56 rifle and a revolver on or before 24 April 16 years ago and for flouting Provisions in Sections of the Firearms Ordinance and the Penal Code through his actions. By Hansi Nanayakkara

title: JJB meets Commerce Chamber members
author: Author not found
Content: A meeting between the Ceylon Chamber of Commerce and Jathika Jana Balawegaya (JJB) was held yesterday (12), at the JVP Head Office in Battaramulla. Attention was drawn to the economic crisis and the difficulties faced by the business community. Vice President Duminda Hulangamuwa, Deputy Vice President Krishan Balendra, Board Member Sarath Ganegoda, and Secretary Manjula de Silva represented the Ceylon Chamber of Commerce. In addition, JJB Leader Anura Kumara Dissanayake, Parliamentarian Vijitha Herath, National Executive Member Muditha Nanayakkara, and Economic Council Member Dr. Shantha Jayaratne represented the JJB. (AK)

title: CA to issue verdict tomorrow
author: Author not found
Content: The Court of Appeal set 14 October to issue a verdict on the Writ Petition filed by former President Maithripala Sirisena challenging the issuance of summons on him by the Fort Magistrate in relation to the Easter Sunday attack of 2019. The two-judge-bench of the Court of Appeal, Justices Sobhitha Rajakaruna and Dhammika Ganepola concluded preliminary hearings with regard to Sirisena’s petition yesterday (12) and announced that an order on his request will be made tomorrow (14). A complaint, by way of a Private Plaint was filed in terms of Section 136 (1) (a) of the Code of Criminal Procedure Act No. 15 of 1979 (as amended) before the Fort Magistrate on 16 September, alleging that Sirisena had failed to order the arrest of Zaharan Hashim and his followers, to oversee their arrest, to prevent the murder of those who do not profess the Islamic faith thus resulting in omissions in terms of the Penal Code. Oral submissions were made on behalf of the Complainants and the Fort Magistrate made an order issuing summons on Sirisena requiring him to be present before the Fort Magistrate’s Court on 14 of October 2022. Sirisena, through the Writ Application observed that the Magistrate has failed to exercise his discretion properly in deciding to issue summons and has erred in law in acting upon hearsay. Among other relief, Sirisena sought to issue a Writ of Certiorari quashing the decision/order made to issue summons, issue a writ of Prohibition preventing further proceedings being conducted in the relevant case of the Fort Magistrate’s Court upon the said complaint, to grant an interim order until the final hearing and determination of this Application, staying the execution of the said order and to grant an interim order until the final hearing and determination of this application.

title: Parliament backs electronic voting in student Parliaments
author: Author not found
Content: Parliament has expressed support to install electronic voting systems in student Parliaments islandwide. An awareness programme was recently conducted by Parliament on the use of the electronic voting system for the student parliamentary election at the Eheliyagoda National College. A number of senior officials of Parliament participated in this awareness programme, which was titled ‘Assistance for an Electronic Voting System in the Student Parliament,’ where students and teachers also had the opportunity to present their ideas and suggestions. Modern electoral experts say by using an electronic voting system, the cost of printed ballots, ballot boxes, etc. can be saved and the labour and time spent on counting the votes can also be reduced. Senior officials of Parliament explained to the students the information technology measures that can be taken to maintain these e-voting activities without any errors during voter registration, voting, and the final result. Director (Information System Management) of Parliament Mahesh Perera and other officers Narendra Lakmal and Daminda Willoraarachchi also participated in this online programme. In addition, Director (Coordinating Engineer) of Parliament Lalith Adhikari also presented a speech based on his experience on electronic voting in Parliament. Director Legislative Services and Communications, Janakantha Silva joined the programme and congratulated the first Student Parliament meeting to be established at Eheliyagoda National College after the election on behalf of Parliament.

title: Government’s repression won’t last long – Sajith
author: Author not found
Content: Opposition Leader Sajith Premadasa said the Government’s repression will not last long. Speaking at a Samagi Jana Balawegaya (SJB) meeting held in Viyaluwa yesterday (12), Premadasa said the Government fears public gatherings. “In this country, the Government uses weapons to suppress the youth. They do not care about humanity, about the hunger, pain, and suffering of the people. This is state violence,” he added. He said, the Government has set up a new agency to rehabilitate protesting youths. “But who really needs to be rehabilitated? The Rajapaksa family that bankrupted the country and who destroyed the farmers, who gave the exploding gas cylinders. The Rajapaksa family deprived the farmers of fertiliser and people of fuel,” he added. Premadasa said, instead of rehabilitating the Rajapaksa family, the Government plans to send every citizen who stands up for the common man, who speaks about the people’s sorrow, tears, and pain to the so-called rehabilitation centres. By Nabiya Vaffoor

title: CTU will initiate TU action – Stalin
author: Author not found
Content: The Ceylon Teachers’ Union (CTU) said trade union action will be initiated if women teachers who danced at a Children’s Day event in a Negombo school are brought to book. CTU General Secretary, Joseph Stalin said, this when Ceylon Today inquired about reports of an investigation by the Western Provincial Education Department on female teachers of a junior school in Negombo, who danced to the song ‘Madyapaane Bime Joliya Gaanu Nodanne.’ The video clip was circulated on social media recently. “This is not Iran, we don’t understand why everyone wants to act like the Police on this incident. This is an old song. The teachers are just trying to celebrate Children’s Day with their students. There’s nothing wrong with that,” he added. He also said, the song does not promote liquor consumption and was played only as a matter of entertainment. Meanwhile, Provincial Education Director Srilal Nonis was of the view that the teachers went beyond their scope when they engaged in dancing to the music of the song and an investigation has been launched. By Nabiya Vaffoor

title: Ammonia gas leak the cause
author: Author not found
Content: Fisheries Minister Douglas Devananda said yesterday (12), he directed officials to expedite the operation of the ice plant at the Galle Fishery Harbour. Minister Devananda said, the ice plant is run by the Ceylon Fishery Harbour Corporation (CFHC) to meet the ice needs of the large number of fishermen who rely on this port. Because of an ammonia gas leak in the plant, operations were temporarily halted. CFHC officials met Devananda at the Fisheries Ministry in Maligawatta and discussed the situation and the steps to be taken to reopen it as soon as possible. The Minister said, the officials told him that sealing the leak had commenced and the plant will begin ice production soon. Production of ice needed to preserve fish stocks should not be interrupted, he said. He called on officials to expedite the work and ensure that operations begin soon. Fisheries Ministry Secretary Indu Ratnayake and CFHC officials were present during the meeting. BY Naalir Jamaldeen

title: Police seek public help to arrest triple murder suspect
author: Author not found
Content: Police are seeking public assistance to arrest the main suspect wanted over the triple murder of a father and his two sons who were shot to death in Minuwangoda on 6 October. The suspect is Sanjeeva Lakmal, a 39-year-old resident of No.10 Mahindarama Road, Sri Jayawardenapura Kotte. Police said the suspect has fled the area and is currently in hiding. Accordingly, Police request the public to contact the numbers below if they have information regarding the suspect. Senior Superintendent of Gampaha Police – 071 859 1608 Assistant Superintendent of Gampaha Police – 071 859 1610 OIC Minuwangoda Police – 071 859 1612 BY Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: Five arrested for peddling moonshine, illegal sand mining
author: Author not found
Content: Vavunativu Police arrested five people for transporting moonshine and engaging in illegal sand mining yesterday (12). According to Vavunativu Police, the suspects were arrested for transporting moonshine on two motorcycles from Kokkaddicholai to Vavunativu. Another suspect was arrested for engaging in illegal sand mining with a backhoe. Police said a stock of 105 litres of moonshine was recovered from the suspects’ possession. Police added that two suspects transporting 25 litres of moonshine were arrested in Puliyamadu and another two suspects transporting 80 litres of moonshine on a motorcycle were arrested in Kanchiran Kudah. The suspects are aged 18, 22, 28, and 38 and are residents of Kokkaddicholai, Panayaruppaan, Munayakkadu, and Chillukodichenai, Vavunativu Police said. Meanwhile, Police arrested a 21-year-old engaging in illegal sand mining on a private land with a backhoe in Pavatkodichenai. By Naalir Jamaldeen

title: Hatton- Dickoya UC earns Rs 4.2M
author: Author not found
Content: The Chairman of the Hatton Dickoya Urban Council, Sadayan Balachandran said the UC has earned Rs 4.2 million by leasing plots of land to construct temporary boutiques in a few strategic locations selected in the heart of the Hatton town. He stated that this exercise had been implemented to enable the public to earn and celebrate the forthcoming Deewali Festival which falls on 24 October. Balachandran said 155 plots of land were leased in the Hatton Star Square, Hatton Main Bus Depot and the Hatton Public Fair on 11 October. He added that a lessee had consented to provide electricity to the temporary boutiques that are to be built shortly for Rs 400,000. He also said another businessman had leased the main hall of the Hatton Dikoya UC for Rs 250,000to carry out business activities during the Deevali Festival. BY Neeta Pathma Kumari – Norwood

title: ‘Fisher folk in dire straits’
author: Author not found
Content: The national organiser of the All Ceylon Joint Fisheries Convention, Rathna Gamage said due to the worsening economic situation in the country, small and medium scale fishermen have been forced to either pawn or sell their valuables and engage in the trade. He said these fisher folk who had previously pawned their gold items to Banks and financial institutions have now been compelled to sell them so that the money could be used to engage in their profession. Gamage said before long fishermen will be forced not only to sell their valuables but even their houses to engage in the trade as the earning capacity of fisher folk had markedly declined in the face of the steep economic crisis prevailing. BY Kamal Wijehewa – Galle

title: Leopards on the prowl in Hatton
author: Author not found
Content: Residents of Ruwanpura and Kudagama in Hatton fear for their lives as leopards roam freely in these areas. In addition, they experience immense difficulties in their day-to-day lives. A group of residents told this correspondent that they have brought this issue to the notice of the authorities but to no avail, as measures have still not been taken to solve the problem. They said at night leopards tend to roam close to their homes and as such remain indoors most of the time. They said chicken, dogs and animals which they rear have begun to disappear of late and they suspect leopards were in the habit of making a prey of these animals for want of food. They  urge the authorities to take serious note of the predicament they are facing and take measures to alleviate their anxiety. BY C. D. H. Hewage – Watawala

title: Garnier’s case deferred to 8 Nov
author: Author not found
Content: Swiss Embassy employee, Garnier Banister Francis, yesterday (12) filed initial objections before Colombo High Court (CHC) Judge Namal Balalle, insisting that there is no legal recourse for the further maintenance of the case filed against her on charges of supplying fake information and striving to destabilise the Government. Initial objections on behalf of the accused were raised by Kalinga Indatissa PC. Submitting objections, Indatissa PC, informed Judge Balalle, that charges against his client had been filed based on Provisions in Sections 189 and 190 of the Penal Code. He explained that on the face of it and upon close perusal the indictments cannot be sustained before the said Court. Deputy Solicitor General, Janaka Bandara prosecuted. DSG Bandara stated that there was no impediment to further sustain the charges filed against the accused. Taking the submissions into consideration, the Court ordered the defence and the prosecution to produce written submissions pertaining to initial objections at the next hearing and deferred further proceedings of the trial to 8 November. The Attorney General indicted the accused before the High Court and on charges of lodging a false complaint with the CID, stating that she had been abducted by a group of five persons in Cinnamon Gardens, Colombo 7, on 25 November three years ago. The Attorney General has stated in his indictment, that the accused in her complaint had mentioned that after she had been abducted, her abductors had threatened her with firearms and had detained her for hours before questioning her, regarding the whereabouts of CID Inspector Nishantha Silva who had fled the country at the time and that later she alleged that her abductors had proceeded to sexually abuse her. A Second Officer attached to the Swiss Embassy in Colombo had submitted a written complaint with the Acting IGP on 27 November, 2019, with regard to the ordeal experienced by his employee at the hands of her abductors. The CID had then commenced a probe into the incident, based on instructions received from the Acting IGP and it has been stated in the complaint, that the plaintiff had been allegedly abducted, when she had been on her way to her child’s school. The previous Magistrate had issued an order for the passport of Ganiya Banister to be impounded, as the suspect had failed to provide a statement to the CID, after she had been ordered to do so. Accordingly, the previous Magistrate, had ordered the Swiss Embassy employee, to provide a statement to the CID before 9 December 2019. The CID then named Ganiya Banister as a suspect in the case on 16 December of the same year, based on the advice received from the Attorney General and upon her being nabbed she was produced before the Magistrate’s Court. The suspect was then ordered to be enlarged on bail on 30 December 2019. By Hansi Nanayakkara

title: 30-year-old arrested for cheating Rs 11M
author: Author not found
Content: An individual was arrested by the Illegal Assets Investigation Division for defrauding the public of over Rs 11 million using social media, Police said. Police said the suspect duped the public, by offering gifts.     He had collected over Rs 11 million from persons from various parts of the country and had deposited the money to several bank accounts on several occasions, Police said. The suspect is a 30-year-old resident of Angoda. The Illegal Assets Investigation Division is conducting further investigations. By Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: Look into healthcare needs of ageing citizenry
author: Author not found
Content: With Sri Lanka’s population above 65 years topping other countries in the Asian region, the country should be more prepared to cater to their health needs, Member of the Sri Lanka Association of Geriatric Medicine (SLAGM), Dr. Dilanka Thilakarathna said. Speaking to the media at the Health Promotion Bureau (HPB), Dr. Thilakarathna said yesterday (12) to care for the increasing elderly population in years to come, Sri Lanka should be able to set up healthcare facilities that could provide long-term health services for them. He also said caregivers and healthcare personnel need to undergo training in this speciality.     Although Sri Lankan values and culture calls for families to care for their elders, the present economic crisis makes it difficult for families to fulfil these obligations. Therefore, a mechanism should be established to support the families with elders in providing them with care. Dr. Thilakarathna said, society and the Government should be able to do so. SLAGM Treasurer, Dr. Shehan Silva said, by 2030, Sri Lanka will have a considerably high population of those over 65. One in every four persons will be over 65 years, he said. Touching on the health issues that elderly women could face, he said incontinence and frailty were amongst them.  By Dilanthi Jayamanne
