title: Spring Valley Road impassable
author: Author not found
Content: Owing to work on the Spring Valley Road in Badulla being halted for the past 18 months, residents of Badulla have been greatly inconvenienced. They said carpeting of the road had commenced during the Good Governance Government, but they lamented that work had not proceeded as originally planned, resulting in its present impassable state. Residents observed that the stalling of the work had resulted in road mishaps and therefore they urged authorities to expedite the process. By Nishantha Abeygunawardene – Badulla

title: ‘Leave No One Behind’ gets 2.3M applications
author: Author not found
Content: The welfare benefit fast track programme ‘Leave No One Behind,’ targeting low-income families, has so far received 2.3 million applications, according to the Welfare Benefit Board.   The programme was initiated as per the instructions of President Ranil Wickremesinghe. The applications are being promptly entered into the system through Welfare Benefit Information Units set up in 341 Divisional Secretariats islandwide and as of yesterday (12), 624,714 applications have been entered into the system. A pilot project was initiated recently centred on several regional secretariats in the Colombo District and people had shown great interest, according to the Welfare Benefit Board. It is expected that the 600,000 families that have been downgraded to the low-income category, in the face of the second Covid-19 wave and the economic crisis faced by the country, as reported by the United Nations Development Programme, are also eligible to apply for this welfare benefit fast track programme. This is in addition to the 3.3 million families that are presently receiving welfare benefits or those who are already on the waiting list. Accordingly, it is estimated that 3.9 million families will apply for this social welfare programme. Hence, 3.9 million low-income families will benefit. The Welfare Benefit Board says, the programme will be implemented under six phases and the second phase is implemented concurrently with the first phase. It says the next step is to collect data through a door-to-door campaign. Those who are already receiving Samurdhi, Elderly, disabled and kidney patients’ welfare benefits as well as those who are seeking new welfare benefits should register under this programme. The application forms were published on 30 August, and the number of applications entered into the data system stood at 100,000 by 29 September. However, with the publicity given by the President Media Division recently, the Welfare Benefit Board has received 2,300,000 applications. The Board said, the closing date for applications is 15 October. The Welfare Benefits Board said the pilot project was a resounding success and the list of qualifying applicants would be announced at the Divisional Secretariat level by 15 December.

title: Milad-Un-Nabi celebrated in Beruwala
author: Author not found
Content: The Milad-Un-Nabi Celebration 2022 organised by the Ministry of Buddhasasana, Religious and Cultural Affairs and the Department of Muslim Religious and Cultural Affairs was held at Jamiah Naleemiah Auditorium, Beruwala on 9 October. The ceremony was held in collaboration with the management committee of the Jamiah Naleemiah Institute, China Fort Mosque Society, and China Fort Gem and Jewellery Traders Association under the instructions of Minister of Buddhasasana Vidura Wickremanayake. Minister Naseer Ahamed, State Minister Cader Masthan, MP Marjan Faleel, and several ambassadors also participated. By B.M. Mukthar – Beruwala

title: India comments on human rights situation in China’s Xinjiang
author: Author not found
Content: For the first time, India on 7 October clearly commented on the situation in China’s Xinjiang and said rights of people of the autonomous region should be “respected and guaranteed.” The remarks by External Affairs Ministry Spokesman Arindam Bagchi came a day after India abstained from voting on a resolution at the United Nations High Commission that called for a debate on concerns over the human rights situation in Xinjiang. When asked about the abstention, he said it was in line with the long-held practice of not voting on country-specific resolutions. “The human rights of the people of Xinjiang Uyghur Autonomous Region should be respected and guaranteed. We hope that the relevant party will address the situation objectively and properly,” Bagchi said. The comments came amid the continuing border row between India and China in eastern Ladakh. “India remains committed to upholding all human rights. India’s vote is in line with its long held position that country specific resolutions are never helpful. India favours a dialogue to deal with such issues,” he said. Bagchi said India has taken note of assessment of human rights concerns in Xinjiang by the UN Office of the High Commissioner on Human Rights. “We have taken note of the OHCHR Assessment of human rights concerns in the Xinjiang Uyghur Autonomous Region, People’s Republic of China,” he said. The draft resolution was pushed by a group comprising Canada, Denmark, Finland, the UK, the US, Iceland, Norway and Sweden, and was co-sponsored by some other countries. China has been facing mounting criticism over its treatment of Uyghur Muslims in Xinjiang Province. Human rights groups believe China has arbitrarily detained close to a million Uyghurs in camps in the name of combating religious extremism. In its recent report, the OCHCR said serious human rights violations have been committed in Xinjiang Uyghur Autonomous Region (XUAR) in the context of the Chinese Government’s application of counter-terrorism and counter-extremism strategies. “The implementation of these strategies and associated policies in XUAR has led to interlocking patterns of severe and undue restrictions on a wide range of human rights,” it said. “These patterns of restrictions are characterised by a discriminatory component, as the underlying acts often directly or indirectly affect Uyghur and other predominantly Muslim communities,” the report said. (PTI)

title: PMD Contradicts Bandula
author: Author not found
Content: The President’s Media Division (PMD) announced that Sri Lanka will remain a middle-income country, contradicting Cabinet Spokesman Bandula Gunawardane. According to the PMD, the Government is pursuing a ‘reverse graduation’ policy for a limited time. However, at yesterday’s weekly Cabinet briefing, Gunawardane said Cabinet had approved a proposal to downgrade Sri Lanka from middle-income to low-income status. The immediate clarification by the President’s Office seems to show a rift between the Cabinet and President Ranil Wickremesinghe. “The Cabinet of Ministers has approved a proposal to downgrade Sri Lanka from a middle-income country to a low-income country. The Cabinet of Ministers decided to downgrade Sri Lanka from a middle-income country to a low-income country in the hope that, in light of the difficult situation Sri Lanka is currently facing, international institutions will make it easier to obtain loan assistance,” he said. Speaking further, he said the per capita income in Sri Lanka has decreased and at the time of independence the per capita income was USD 120 and it took 56 years to jump the bar of USD 1,000. He said, specially after defeating the LTTE, the economy expanded, the manufacturing process was boosted, and the per capita income in 2014 was USD 3,827. “There was an awakening in the mass production process. As a result, by 2014, when the per capita income reached 3,827 US dollars, Sri Lanka moved out of the low-income group and joined the middle-income group. World organisations have informed the Finance Minister that this per capita income will further decrease in 2022. To facilitate the intervention of those international organisations, so that they can obtain concessional loan assistance in another difficult situation, the Cabinet Paper was approved, which included the request to include the country in the classification of a low-income country,” he said. Meanwhile, the PMD statement said Sri Lanka no longer qualifies for International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (IBRD) loans due to a downgrade of the country’s credit rating. Therefore, Cabinet approved a proposal on Monday (10) to request the World Bank to grant the country eligibility to obtain loans offered by the International Development Association (IDA). This is with the aim of obtaining concessionary funding from the International Development Association (IDA) — an arm of the World Bank that helps the world’s vulnerable countries. This facility is called ‘Gap.’ Twelve countries including Indonesia have availed themselves of this facility when they were facing an economic downturn similar to Sri Lanka. The Government is pursuing a ‘reverse graduation’ policy for a limited time period. By Thameenah Razeek

title: CID to probe train delays – Bandula
author: Author not found
Content: The Criminal Investigation Department (CID) is conducting an investigation to determine whether the present train delays are a result of sabotage. Transport Minister Bandula Gunawardena said an internal investigation into train delays will also be conducted under the supervision of the Ministry Secretary and the General Manager of Railways. He was responding to a query at yesterday’s (11) Cabinet media briefing. The minister also said, despite difficulties, he has taken steps to improve public transportation as a relief to the people due to the increase in fuel costs. Gunawardena said, the newly launched ‘Rajarata Odyssey’ train to Anuradhapura commenced operations on 8 October. But due to the derailment of the Uttara Devi train in Tambuttegama on that day, it had to be stopped mid journey and passengers had to be transported by bus. Gunawardena added that he went to the Fort Railway Station for the inaugural journey of ‘Rajarata Odyssey,’ which was delayed due to damage to a cable in Kelaniya on the main railway line. He further said, the CID needs to investigate whether saboteurs are disrupting the railway service, and put out a report. By Thameenah Razeek

title: Strengthen efforts to protect women
author: Author not found
Content: Women leaders from four provinces in Sri Lanka have urged local government authorities to strengthen efforts to protect women, who have been affected by the country’s economic, political, and Covid-19 crisis this year. From March to September 2022, UN Women hosted a series of Multi-party Dialogues on Women, Peace and Security in nine districts to identify and discuss solutions to challenges faced by women there. Close to 200 persons including women leaders participated in the sessions, representing the North Central, Uva, Western, and Sabaragamuwa Provinces. UN Women organised the first phase of the multi-party dialogues between 2018 and 2022 in 16 districts across five provinces in the country, which focused on strengthening women’s leadership and decision-making role within the peace and security landscape. The current phase of dialogues covered the country’s remaining four provinces and took place in the districts of Anuradhapura, Badulla, Colombo, Gampaha, Kalutara, Kegalle, Monaragala, Polonnaruwa, and Ratnapura. Participants raised concerns about issues including a shortage of safe houses, lack of awareness about available services, and weak referral systems for survivors of violence. “Over the last few months, complaints on violence against women have drastically increased, and most of the time, these women have no place to go,” said one dialogue participant, a women’s development officer from the Ministry of Women and Child Development and Social Empowerment. Another participant, a district coordinator from Gampaha District in the Western Province, said: “Because of the economic crisis, many garment factories are closing. Some women have worked in these factories for 20-plus years.  On top of that, they are burdened with taking care of their families. As a result, they are unable to find new jobs.” Ramaaya Salgado, Country Focal Point of UN Women Sri Lanka, said the multi-party dialogues aimed to gather a variety of stakeholders including women leaders, public sector officials, civil society organisations, youth leaders and the media “to collectively promote gender equality and women’s empowerment, and to ensure that there is no rollback of gains made over the years.” In each of the dialogues, participants developed district-level ‘work plans’ in which they recommended that the local authorities: Strengthen coordination between front-line government officials and civil society organisations to implement initiatives, on women, peace and security; allocate budgets and other provisions to establish safe houses for women in each district; carry out campaigns to educate rural women about public services such as legal aid and counselling for survivors of violence; provide gender sensitivity training for Police and other law enforcement officers; during the dialogue sessions, the participants also received training on the principles of women, peace and security, which calls for increased participation of women at all levels of decision-making and for ensuring that women and girls are not left behind in relief and recovery efforts. The dialogues are part of UN Women’s three-year programme on supporting the implementation of the Women, Peace and Security Agenda in Sri Lanka, which is funded by the Government of Japan. (SRM)

title: 59,317 dengue cases reported –NDCU
author: Author not found
Content: The number of dengue cases by the 40th week of 2022 amounted to 59,317, with 1,152 cases being recorded in week 40, the National Dengue Control Programme, issuing their bulletin said. The National Dengue Control Unit (NDCU) yesterday (11) in its weekly dengue update from 3 to 9 October said during week 40, 1,152 suspected dengue cases were reported in 24 districts in comparison to 1,161 cases in 22 districts during week 39. “There is a 0.8 per cent decrease in week 40, compared to the previous week,” the Unit said.  The NDCU said of all reported cases, 47.6 per cent were from the Western Province. Namely, Colombo Municipal Council 4.6 per cent, rest of the Colombo District 14.1 per cent, Gampaha District 24.0 per cent, and Kalutara District 4.8 per cent. It said 10.5 per cent were from Kandy, Puttalam 6.9 per cent, Galle 4.6 per cent, and Jaffna 4.3 per cent. The Kahathuduwa, Mirigama, Harispattuwa, Akmeemana, and Addalaichenai MOH areas were newly identified as high-risk areas. According to statistics given by the NDCU, areas such as Mannar, Kilinochchi, Vavuniya, and Mullaitivu have 165, 107, 75, and 21 cases, respectively. The total number of cases from January till 9 October in Colombo amounted to 14,383, while Gampaha and Kalutara had 9,606 and 5,336 cases, respectively. (DJ)

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Japan Aids ‘Green’ Industries
author: Author not found
Content: Japan’s Ambassador to Sri Lanka Hideaki Mizukoshi on Monday (10 October) signed an agreement with Environment Ministry Secretary Dr. Anil Jasinghe at the Presidential Secretariat on Joint Credit Mechanism (JCM) for a low carbon growth partnership between Japan and Sri Lanka in the presence of Environment Minister Naseer Ahamed, Japan’s Embassy in Sri Lanka said in a statement. Under this framework, Japan will contribute to the sustainable development of Sri Lanka by reducing greenhouse gas emissions through investment and technical transfer of Japan’s leading decarbonisation technologies and infrastructure as well as promoting renewable energy, it said. A Japanese Embassy official, speaking to Ceylon Today on condition of anonymity, said Sri Lanka is the twenty third country that has entered into a partnership vis-à-vis JCM. He said typically such modalities would take about a year to be in place, after which 50 per cent of the cost of such a ‘green’ project would be provided by Japan’s Environment Ministry as a grant to the concerned Japanese company and/or its partner company/Government of Sri Lanka (GoSL) institution involved in such a “clean industry” project.  The Embassy spokesman said this JCM programme, which is another form of the sale of carbon credits by developing countries to Japan, has seen Japan involved in such projects with developing countries for the past 10 years. He was, however, not immediately in a position to give the value of investment made by Japan in such projects thus far. Meanwhile, the Embassy statement said Japan has been discussing with developing countries on JCM since 2011 and Sri Lanka became the 23rd partner country of Japan’s JCM partnership. Under this partnership, the Government of Japan will be providing financial assistance as well as support in investment and technology transfer from Japanese companies to help GoSL achieve its sustainable economic growth and emission reduction targets toward carbon neutrality by 2050, it said. (PA)

title: Fmr Thai Embassy Building transformed into cultural centre
author: Author not found
Content: The building which previously housed the Royal Thai Embassy in Colombo, located in Town Hall, has been transformed into a multi-functional cultural centre called ‘Siam Nivasa.’ Siam Nivasa – or in Thai Language ‘Siam Nivas’ means the home of Thai people. Siam Nivasa was opened on 26 September. The event featured a Hun Kra Bork or traditional Thai puppet show and a traditional musical performance, followed by a workshop of the Thai puppetry art. In addition, participants enjoyed traditional Thai cuisines and desserts. The new facility will function as a cultural centre and a venue for events and activities to promote and grow the historic, warm, and friendly relations between Thailand and Sri Lanka. Thai Ambassador to Sri Lanka, Poj Harnpol, said, “Having enjoyed exceptionally warm diplomatic ties with Sri Lanka since 1955, in addition to centuries of Buddhist ties, the Kingdom of Thailand is very proud to unveil the new Siam Nivasa Multi-functional Cultural Venue. It is time that we had a dedicated space to celebrate the cordial friendship between our two countries, while also providing a functional venue for various occasions that can be used by Sri Lankans and Thai nationals in Sri Lanka. It is with great pleasure that I, on behalf of the Government of Thailand, thank all those who attended the inauguration ceremony, especially the ASEAN Ambassadors and Heads of Mission, who helped us mark this milestone with their valued and honoured presence. We look forward to working with Sri Lanka and our other diplomatic partners, as we continue to spread awareness about the Thai culture worldwide.” The event was attended by a number of diplomats and dignitaries. The Thai Government purchased this building in the 1980s. Later, due to the political situation and security concerns, the Embassy was relocated several times from Green Lanka Building at Wijerama, to the present location at Sir Marcus Fernando Mawatha – next to the Residence of Colombo Mayor Rosy Senanayake.

title: Japan, SL sign MoC on JCM
author: Author not found
Content: Japan and Sri Lanka signed a Memorandum of Cooperation (MoC), on the Joint Crediting Mechanism (JCM), for Low Carbon Growth Partnership, on 10 October at the Presidential Secretariat. The Memorandum of Cooperation on the JCM was signed by Dr. Anil Jasinghe, Secretary to the Ministry of Environment and Mizukoshi Hideaki, Japanese Ambassador to Sri Lanka. Thereafter, the Japanese Ambassador met President Ranil Wickremesinghe and engaged in a cordial discussion. After its withdrawal from the Second Commitment Period of the Kyoto Protocol, Japan introduced the Joint Crediting Mechanism (JCM) in 2013, to contribute to the global effort of reducing greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions. This mechanism has been developed to reduce GHG emissions jointly with developing countries and share the greenhouse gas emissions reduced as the percentage between Japan and the agreed party country. Japan introduced this mechanism as agreed at the 21st Conference of Parties to the United Nations Convention on Climate Change, to adopt the Paris Agreement to achieve the commitments of the Nationally Determined Contributions. Japan is currently implementing projects under the JCM mechanism in 17 countries, such as Mongolia, Bangladesh, Ethiopia, Kenya, the Maldives, Vietnam, Laos, Indonesia, Costa Rica, Palau, Cambodia, Mexico, Saudi Arabia, Chile, Myanmar, Thailand and the Philippines. Through implementing the proposed projects under this mechanism, the benefits such as introducing new technologies and technical expertise, capacity building, generation of green jobs and new infrastructure development could be achieved. The Government of Japan and its private sector will provide technical assistance and part of the capital investment to implement this mechanism in developing countries. Under this mechanism, projects in energy, industry, transport, waste, forestry and agriculture sectors for reducing GHG emissions are expected to be implemented. Moreover, Sri Lanka ratified the Paris Agreement on Climate Change on 21 September 2016. Sri Lanka also has submitted its Nationally Determined Contributions (NDCs) to the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC). Therefore, the implementation of the Joint Crediting Mechanism in Sri Lanka will support achieving the GHG emission reduction targets under the Paris Agreement and contribute to the global effort of reaching the global temperature goal of the Paris Agreement. Approval from the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and the Attorney General’s Department has been obtained for the implementation of the Joint Carbon Crediting Mechanism between Japan and Sri Lanka. Further, Cabinet approval has been received on 5 September 2022 for the implementation of the mechanism in Sri Lanka. When implementing this mechanism in Sri Lanka, a Joint Committee co-chaired by the Governments of Japan and Sri Lanka and representatives of both countries will be established to approve the projects. Minister of Environment Naseer Ahmed, Senior Adviser to the President on National Security and Chief of Presidential Staff SagalaRatnayake, Presidential Adviser on Climate Change RuwanWijewardene and others attended the event.

title: NFIs to Stock Market Enjoy 31-Month High
author: Author not found
Content: Net foreign inflows (NFIs) into the stock market passed the Rs 15 billion mark yesterday, by registering its highest NFI in 14 calendar days, a figure of Rs 828.5 million, thereby recording a cumulative NFI total of Rs 15,271.7 million to hit at least a 31-month high (April 2020) due to sustained confidence by foreign investors in Sri Lanka’s financial markets, sources told Ceylon Today. Complementing these developments, the stock market enjoyed NFIs for 21 consecutive market days to yesterday, also not seen for the past 31 months. Nonetheless, the stock market fell to a 43 calendar day low, with the ASPI declining for the third consecutive market day to yesterday, led by local investors exiting from the bourse in favour of the fixed income market, driven by higher rates, complemented by record-high inflation. Consequently, the ASPI, yesterday over Friday fell by 3.37 per cent to 8,744.61 points and the S&P SL 20 Index by 4.29 per cent to 2,652.99 points on Rs 3.04 billion. Meanwhile, the S&P last registered a lower figure than that of yesterday 69 days ago on 3 August 2022. A total of 91.32 million shares changed hands yesterday. Monday was a holiday for markets. The benchmark, albeit administered ‘spot’ closed unchanged for the seventieth consecutive market day at Rs 360/364 to the US dollar in two-way quotes yesterday (Tuesday, 11 October), market sources told Ceylon Today. Consequently, yesterday, the administered market ‘spot’ was down by between 80-79.31 per cent (Rs 160-161), year-on-year (YoY) in two-way quotes, thereby causing cost-push inflationary pressure, as Sri Lanka is an import-dependent economy, they said. Meanwhile, yesterday, the value of this official administered ‘spot’ was fixed at Rs 362.90 to the dollar, while a year ago it was fixed at Rs 200.40, down 79.30 per cent (Rs 160.50), YoY. In related developments, the straitjacketed, inflexible administered market ‘spot’ a year ago was fixed at Rs 200/203 to the dollar in two-way quotes, unchanged for the twenty third consecutive market day to 11 October 2021. The band in which the guided market ‘spot’ may currently operate is fixed at +/- 3 per cent of the officially administered ‘spot’ value, where the latter is applicable for transactions involving the GoSL, CBSL, and/or between the GoSL and/or CBSL with the market, which was fixed at Rs 362.90 to the dollar yesterday. They further said trades in the administered market ‘spot’ (Rs 360/364) on Friday were mainly restricted to ‘bank-client’ outright trades, while the interbank foreign exchange (FX) market was however dominated by swaps, which were outside the domain of the FX market for this purpose. ‘Spot’ trades are settled after two market days from the date of transaction. CBSL, the steward of GoSL debt and of its foreign reserves also deals in ‘spot.’ By Paneetha Ameresekere

title: Cabinet decisions
author: Author not found
Content: Allocating plots of land for industries Cabinet approved to allocate 16 plots of land under long-term lease basis for 35 years for 16 investors recognised under the regional industrial zone development programme as recommended by the project evaluation committee in operation under the Regional Industrial Services Committees that has been established as per the provisions of the Industries Promotion Act No. 46 of 1990 and the Ministry of Industries. The proposal was submitted by the Minister of Industries. UDA land for rest house development project Cabinet approved the proposal submitted by the Minister of Urban Development and Housing for providing land to Grand Mountain Hotel Pvt. Ltd. on a lease for 30 years with a view to implement a rest house development project subject to relevant conditions. A proposal was submitted to provide the land at No. 9, Kareithivu Road, Jaffna which belongs to the Urban Development Authority to Grand Mountain Hotel Co. on a lease for 30 years with a view to implement a rest house development project. Amendments to Civil Procedure Code Cabinet approval was granted to the proposal of the Minister of Justice, Prisons Affairs and Constitutional Reforms to publish the said draft bill in the government gazette notification and thereby to table it in Parliament. Approval of the Cabinet of Ministers was granted at their meeting held on 18 January to draft a bill to amend the Civil Procedure Code (Statute 101) (Section 205) which is applicable to provision of certified copies of decree nisi or decree absolute to the parties of a Court case. Accordingly, clearance of the Attorney General has been granted for the draft bill which has been prepared by the Legal Draftsman. Purchase of tug boat Cabinet approved the proposal presented by the Minister of Ports, Shipping and Aviation to procure a tug boat following international competitive bidding process. At present, there are 7 tugboats functioning in the Port of Colombo. It has been identified that one more tug vessel of 80 tonne capacity should be procured for future operations. Crew Scheduling System for SriLankan Airlines Commercial airlines worldwide operate Automated Crew Scheduling and Resource Management Systems. The contract period of the present system of SriLankan Airlines will end on 31 October. Therefore, the international competitive bidding system is being adopted to procure a suitable service provider. Accordingly, Cabinet approved the proposal presented by the Minister of Ports, Shipping and Aviation to award the relevant procurement to CAE Flight Services USA, Inc. company for a period of 5 years as recommended by the Cabinet appointed standing procurement committee. NCET construction contract Cabinet approved on 18 January 2017 construction of a National College of Education and Technology in Narangalla, Kuliyapitiya with aid from the Korean Government and local funds. Until the end of November 2021, it has not been possible to commence the construction work assigned to the Korean International Cooperation Agency (KOICA) due to various reasons. KOICA has agreed to assign these construction works to Central Engineering Consultancy Bureau as a direct contract. Cabinet approved the proposal presented by the Minister of Education to assign this contract to the Central Engineering Consultancy Bureau. Road Reconstruction Project in Galle A loan agreement has been entered into with the OPEC Fund for International Development for the reconstruction of the road section Suriyakanda-Rakwana (A017) of Deniyaya-Madampe road in Galle. The renovation work of that road section is planned to be done under 3 contract packages and out of these 2 packages are under the authority of the Ministry Procurement Committee. The other package is under the authority of Cabinet. Cabinet approved the proposal presented by the Minister of Transport and Highways to award the contract package under Cabinet authority to K.D.A. Weerasinghe Pvt. Ltd. on the recommendation of Cabinet appointed standing procurement committee. (TR)

title: FCDO Director calls on Public Security Minister
author: Author not found
Content: Director of Indo-Pacific Zone of the Foreign, Commonwealth and Development Office (FCDO) and Director of India Ben Mellor and British High Commissioner to Sri Lanka Sarah Hulton called on Minister of Public Security Tiran Alles at the latter’s office yesterday (11). In a media release, the Ministry of Public Security said during the discussions, Mellor had focused on how Sri Lanka’s Police Department strives to control public gatherings and public assemblies. He had highlighted the importance of the law enforcement institutions taking measures towards the control of public gatherings sans causing any form of grievances to the masses concerned. Minister Alles had stressed that when such public gatherings tend to take place without official approval, then the Sri Lanka Police Department will have to intervene to maintain peace and order and to protect civilians from being inconvenienced.  During the discussion, both Mellor and Hulton had agreed that it is the responsibility of the Police to maintain law and order at all times. The Minister of Public Security sought assistance from the two officials to train local Police Officers on crowd control.

title: Female postmasters to get 84 days maternity leave
author: Author not found
Content: Cabinet approved the proposal presented by the Minister of Mass Media to grant maternity leave of 84 days instead of the present allowance of 30 days to female postmasters. According to the Sri Lanka Sub-Postmaster Service Constitution, a Sub-Postmaster is entitled to maternity leave subject to employing a substitute at her own expense. It seems that many maternity Sub-Postmasters limit their maternity leave to only 30 days as they have to hire a substitute at their own expense for this period. Medical recommendation is that a child should be breastfed for at least six months. The recommendation of the World Health Organization is the same.

Content: An awareness programme on Water Conservation for Economic Development Officers in the Elpitiya Divisional Secretariat was held on 6 October. The event was organised by the Corporate Communications Unit of the National Water Supply and Drainage Board (NWSDB). Kalyani, Assistant Director Planning of Elpitiya Divisional Secretariat, Hemantha Abeykoon, Senior Corporate Communications Officer, NWSDB Head Office, Ratmalana, and Subashini Soysa, Senior Chemist participated as resource personnel. title: Two Australians charged with bribing SL officials
author: Author not found
Content: Two Australian men have been charged with bribing Sri Lankan officials to secure infrastructure contracts worth millions of dollars. Australian Police arrested the pair last month after a decade-long investigation spanning several countries. The men, aged 67 and 71, worked for a company which has been accused of misconduct in South Asian countries. They are yet to respond to the charges and were scheduled to face Court on Tuesday. The Australian Federal Police (AFP) say the men arranged bribes of more than A$ 304,000 to government officials between 2009 and 2016. The bribes were allegedly made in the pursuit of two Sri Lankan projects – which Police did not name – worth A$ 14 million. The charges follow an investigation into SMEC International Pty Ltd, an Australian-based engineering firm, which involved authorities from the US, Canada, India and elsewhere. More arrests and charges are possible, the AFP said. “Corruption undermines fair competition and can have disastrous consequences for developing economies, global anti-poverty and development efforts,” Detective Supt Helen Schneider said. Originally known as the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation, SMEC was formed in 1949 to build an iconic Australian infrastructure project. It has since grown to employ 5,400 staff in many countries. In 2017, the World Bank temporarily barred SMEC and four subsidiaries in India, Bangladesh, and Sri Lanka from bidding for any of its contracts. The World Bank said it had discovered evidence linking the company to suspected “inappropriate payments” in Sri Lanka and Bangladesh. At the time, a spokesperson for SMEC said the allegations did not relate to any Australian projects, and that the company would continue to strengthen its corporate integrity compliance programmes. Protests have erupted in Sri Lanka this year over corruption allegations and the country’s worst economic crisis in history. (BBC)

title: Charges for driving licences revised
author: Author not found
Content: Minister of Transport and Highways Bandula Gunawardena issued an Extraordinary Gazette Notification revising the levies charged for the issuance of vehicle driving licences with effect from 10 October. As per the Gazette, the fee charged for an application for a learner’s permit and a new driving licence (for one class) under the normal service is now Rs 2,500. Under the one-day service, Rs 3,500 will be charged. Meanwhile, the levy for re-applying for driving licence written and practical tests have been revised to Rs 500 and Rs 1,000, respectively. To renew or extend the validity period of a driving licence, Rs 2,800 is charged for one period, and an additional levy of Rs 500 for a lapsed period of one year or less than one year. By Mithun Jayawardene

title: Import and Export Regulations to Parliament
author: Author not found
Content: Cabinet granted approval for the submission of regulations issued under the Import and Export (Control) Act No. 1 of 1969 for the approval of Parliament. The Cabinet Paper was submitted by the President as the Minister of Finance, Economic Stabilization and National Policies. Import and Export (Control) Regulations No. 15 of 2002 relevant to the import of goods under open accounting system as well as the Import and Export (Control) Regulations No. 16 of 2002 to encourage financial remittances performed by Sri Lankans serving in overseas countries have been imposed.  Accordingly, the Import and Export Regulations No. 15 of 2002 imposed for empowering imports under the payment systems of open accounts/ payment of money after sale of goods basis in relation to import of essential fool items including milk powder and red legumes/ dhal and poultry food products has been published in the Gazette Extraordinary Notification No. 2297/79 dated 16 September. Further to that, the Import and Export Regulations No. 16 of 2022 imposed to enable Sri Lankans employed overseas to import electric vehicles to motivate them has been published in the Gazette Extraordinary Notification No. 2298/55 of 23 September.

title: President orders to streamline Govt communications
author: Author not found
Content: President Ranil Wickremesinghe has issued instructions to streamline the process of responding to letters, emails, and phone calls addressed to government institutions. It has been instructed that priority should be given to general letters from the public to government institutions, and in case final replies cannot be sent immediately, an interim reply stating that the letter has been received should be sent within one week and a final reply should be sent within four weeks. The President has focused his attention on streamlining and expediting the process of responding to letters, emails, and phone calls by the public instead of them having to waste their time, effort, and money by having to come to these institutions personally to attend to their requirements. Accordingly, a special letter signed by the Secretary of the Ministry of Public Administration, Home Affairs, Provincial Councils and Local Government, including provisions in replying to letters, e-mails, and telephone calls addressed to government institutions, has been sent to all ministry secretaries, provincial chief secretaries, and Heads of Departments. In addition, for all official letters, the direct telephone number, fax number, and e-mail address of the staff officer in charge of the subject should be mentioned below the signature of the relevant letter when sending reply letters. Emails sent to public email addresses of relevant offices should be checked daily and a specific officer should be assigned for the purpose. Emails to staff officers’ email addresses should also be checked daily. Efforts should be made to respond to emails the same day and if the relevant officer cannot answer them on the same day, they should send a reply stating that the letter was received and the time required responding to it. In the same way, arrangements should be made to provide answers to the inquiry within a reasonable time/ before the notified date. All phone calls to the office should be answered and if there are organisations/departments that receive many phone calls, a specific officer should be assigned to respond to those calls. The relevant officer appointed to respond to these calls should make a note of the caller’s name, the purpose of the call and contact details on which a response could be forwarded. In instances where an immediate response cannot be given, the relevant staff officers/officers in charge should take steps to respond to the caller’s query within a reasonable time frame.

title: Cabinet greenlights Jathika Jana Sabha Secretariat
author: Author not found
Content: Cabinet approved the establishment of a Jathika Jana Sabha Secretariat, to implement the Jana Sabha system. Cabinet Spokesman Bandula Gunawardena said the Secretary to the President will send the nominations for the Director General and other positions on the Secretariat’s Board to Cabinet for approval. In the weekly Cabinet media briefing yesterday (11), he said the proposal presented by President Ranil Wickremesinghe to establish the Jana Sabha was approved. He added that all Cabinet members agreed that this would allow the provinces to solve their problems and create a more equitable social democratic process through a voluntary assembly system, free of political, religious, caste, and ethnic discrimination. “We will hold discussions with civil society organisations this week to make this establishment more effective and efficient,” he further said. By Thameenah Razeek

title: Johnston, two others barred from overseas travel
author: Author not found
Content: The Commission to Investigate Allegations of Bribery or Corruption (CIABOC) served up indictments, on former Minister of Trade and Cooperatives Johnston Fernando and two others, before Colombo High Court Judge Amal Ranaraja yesterday (11). This was in connection with the case where they have been charged with utilising Lanka SATHOSA employees for political work, besides their official duty and causing a loss of profit to the State. Later, the Court ordered the three accused to be enlarged on two sureties of Rs. 500,000 each and on cash bail of Rs 50,000, while their passports were also impounded. Besides Fernando, the other two accused that were granted bail, were identified as former Chairman of Lankan SATHOSA Eraj Fernando and its former Director Mohammad Zakeer. After the indictments were served, the Counsels for the accused stated that they will be raising objections pertaining to the indictments, filed against their clients at the next hearing. Accordingly, further proceedings of the trial were deferred to 29 November by Judge Ranaraja. The CIABOC has accused the aforementioned defendants before the High Court, for having violated Provisions contained in Sections of the Bribery Act via their actions, committed 12 years ago and for causing a loss of Rs. 5.9 million to the Government through their actions. By Hansi Nanayakkara

title: JJB, JVP lodge complaint
author: Author not found
Content: A complaint was lodged with the CID yesterday (11) urging an investigation into the individuals who created a list, circulating on social media, claiming to be the names of people  and to publicise the list of names of VIPs who had “invested black money” with Thico Group Private Ltd owned by Thilini Priyamali. The complaint was lodged by a group of Jathika Jana Balawegaya (JJB) and Janatha Vimukthi Peramuna (JVP) members led by trade union leader and former MP Wasantha Samarasinghe. Samarasinghe said, the news circulating on social media that members of JVP and JJB had invested money is completely false and demanded an immediate investigation into the incident. “Our party is also accused of investing money in Priyamali’s business. Black money is invested in Priyamali’s business. It is clear who gave VIP protection to this woman. We consider this as a conspiracy led by people in Temple Trees,” he alleged. Attorney-at-Law Sunil Watagala, Dr. Nihal Abeysinghe, and Janaka Adhikari were present at the CID.  By Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: Two suspects arrested
author: Author not found
Content: A youth was arrested for owning two vehicles purchased using illegally earned money, Police said. The arrest was made by the Illegal Assets Investigation Division on 10 October. According to the Police, an investigation was launched into purchasing of a car valued at Rs 6.5 million and a SUV valued at Rs 25 million. These two vehicles had been purchased by the 20-year-old suspect using his father’s money which was earned illegally. The suspect is a resident of Boralesgamuwa. Meanwhile, a 49-year-old resident of Bandaragama was also arrested by the Illegal Assets Investigation Division on Monday (10) in connection with illegal acquisition of assets, Police said. According to Police, a woman from Waskaduwa had used her personal phone number to operate an ‘eZ Cash Power Vault account.’ Transactions of over Rs 10.4 million were made from the above account from 2019 to 2020. Additionally, over Rs 8 million was withdrawn from the account, Police said. Further investigations showed the money was earned through drug peddling carried out by her husband. By Aloka Kasturiarachchi

title: Charges against Mahendran et al dropped
author: Author not found
Content: The three-Judge Bench of the Colombo High Court yesterday accepted that charges cannot be maintained under Public Properties Act (PPA) against ex-Governor of the Central Bank Arjuna Mahendran and nine others, in the case over the loss of Rs 688 million to the State through the Treasury Bonds auction. After the acceptance of the initial objections raised by the defence, the High Court Bench, by a two-thirds majority, came to a conclusion that the charges filed as per the PPA, against the 10 accused, cannot be accepted. The verdict was announced by a Bench, comprising Judges Sanjeewa Moraes, Damith Thotawatta and Namal Balalle. Later, the Court ordered that the pre-trial conference of the case be convened on 16 December. The Attorney General had filed the case against former Governor Mahendran and nine others, charging them with causing a loss of Rs. 688 million to the Government, through the CBSL Treasury Bonds scam, which took place on 27 February seven years ago. The rest of the nine accused are ex-CBSL Deputy Governor P. Samarasiri, Primary Dealer PTL Private Limited, its owners Geoffrey Aloysius, Arjun Aloysius, its CEO Kasun Palisena, its Directors Pushpa Mithra Gunawardene, Chitta Ranjan Hulugalla, Muthuraja Surendran and Ajan Gardiya Punchihewa. By Hansi Nanayakkara

title: SL’s 2022 Average Inflation 48.2% – IMF
author: Author not found
Content: Sri Lanka (SL), among 30 Asian economies coming under the umbrella ‘Emerging Market and Developing Economies’ (EMDE), will record the highest inflation this year (2022), the IMF said on Monday (10). IMF, in a document titled ‘World Economic Outlook’ (WEO), forecast that Sri Lanka’s annual average inflation will rise to 48.2 per cent this year, from 6 per cent in the last (2021), before decelerating to 29.5 per cent in the next (2023), and to 5 per cent in 2027, respectively. IMF has, however, not forecast what Sri Lanka’s annual average inflation would be like during the three-year period from 2025-2026. IMF further said Sri Lanka’s last year’s year-end inflation was 12.1 per cent, while forecasting that this year’s year-end inflation will accelerate to 69.8 per cent, before decelerating to 9.1 per cent by the end of next year. IMF further forecast that among the 30 Asian EMDE, the second, third, fourth, and fifth lowest average annual inflation would be recorded by Myanmar (16.2 per cent), Laos (15 per cent), Palau (12.2 per cent), and Tonga (8.5 per cent), respectively. Meanwhile, IMF forecast that the lowest inflation this year would be registered by China (2.2 per cent), second lowest Brunei (2.5 per cent), and third lowest Malaysia (3.2 per cent), respectively. In the SAARC region, excluding Sri Lanka, high annual average inflation this year would be led by Bhutan (7.7 per cent), followed by India (6.9 per cent), Nepal (6.3 per cent), Bangladesh (6.1 per cent), and Maldives (4.3 per cent), respectively. Pakistan is not captured in this Asian EMDE chapter by the IMF, as it is deemed as being a low-income country (LIC). (PA)

title: Ports Ministry says Harin’s statement ‘NOT TRUE’
author: By Sulochana Ramiah Mohan
Content: The Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation has categorically stated that there is no truth to the claims made by Minister of Tourism Harin Fernando, during the Mumbai tourism roadshow, that an Indian investor might take control of the three main airports in Sri Lanka, including the BIA. The Tourism Minister, speaking at the Outbound Travel Mart (OTM), India’s leading and only travel show focused on outbound travel, said, “I will break the news that Indian companies are taking our three airports which is going to be a phenomenal decision to really help us. The fuel tanks are taken by the Indian companies, the solar power projects are also taken by the Indians.” Further, the Minister of Tourism also told a Hindu Businessline journalist and the Hindustan Times, Pune News and many other Indian media outlets that were present at the roadshow that discussions are underway between the two sides, potentially involving management contracts. The newspaper quoted Minister Fernando as stating that the Adani Group is in negotiations with Sri Lankan authorities to manage three airports in the island nation, including the BIA. He mentioned plans to collaborate with the Adani Group for airport management, as reported by Businessline on the sidelines of the OTM show in Mumbai. Sources informed Ceylon Today that Minister Fernando has been requested to provide clarification on the matter, as the Sri Lankan Government has no plans to allocate shares to any foreign investors for the BIA or the Ratmalana International Airport. The only finalised agreement concerns the sale of the Mattala Airport to a Russo-Indian joint venture. According to the Aviation Ministry, the statement made by Minister Fernando during the Mumbai roadshow regarding the transfer of the three airports to an Indian investor was misleading information. The Government has clarified that there are no such plans in place for such a transfer. Additionally, the State-Owned Enterprise Restructuring Unit has stated that they have no knowledge of the developments regarding the airport proposals. Ceylon Today has previously reported that the Mattala Airport will be managed by Russia’s Airports of Regions Management Company (AR), in collaboration with an Indian firm, as a joint venture. Sources indicate that the Indian company involved in this venture is likely to be the Adani Group. Secretary of Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Aviation K.D.S. Ruwanchandra, however, told Ceylon Today that discussions have led to an agreement to transfer the operations of MRIA to a private joint venture and it is being finalised, but the Secretary did not disclose the names of the investors.

title: Saruwa Sunil acquitted of rape charges on appeal
author: Author not found
Content: The Court of Appeal yesterday (11) acquitted former Chairman of the Akuressa Pradeshiya Sabha, Saruwa Liyanage Sunil, who was convicted over the rape of a 14-year-old child and sentenced to rigorous imprisonment of 15 years in 2012. This was when the case was taken before Justices Sampath B. Abayakoon and P. Kumararatnam. Sunil was indicted by the Attorney General in the High Court of Colombo with the rape of a 14-year-old and after the trial, he was convicted and sentenced to 15 years of rigorous imprisonment with a fine of Rs 25,000, in default of which one year rigorous imprisonment was imposed. In addition, Rs 250,000 was imposed as compensation payable to the victim with a default sentence of two years rigorous imprisonment. During the proceedings it was stated, according to video evidence, on 2 June 2012 Sunil had taken the victim to a guest house and committed rape on her. Prior to the incident, Sunil had helped the victim in numerous ways to continue her education and sport activities while a mobile phone was also gifted to her. Further, according to the evidence, few days after this incident, she was again taken to the same guest house by the Appellant and raped. Prior to the video recording she had given a statement to Akuressa Police but not revealed these incidents due to fear of the Appellant as he was the Chairman of the Akuressa Pradeshiya Sabha at the time. Sunil later appealed to the Court of Appeal. In the first ground of appeal, the Presidenat’s Counsel appearing for Sunil contended that the Trial Judge has failed to consider that the video recording, of the statement of the complainant, has not been corroborated in material particulars by evidence from an independent source as required by Section 163A (5) of the Evidence Ordinance It was held thereby that the prosecution has failed to adduce corroborative evidence in material particulars by evidence from an independent source which is a statutory requirement. It was also noted that irregular procedure had been followed by the prosecution in violation of Section 163 A (3) (b) of the Evidence (Special Provisions) Act, No.32 of 1999 adding that as these are substantial facts, it affects the root of the case. Considering all the circumstances, the Judges held that the prosecution had not proven the case beyond reasonable doubt and thereby acquitted him from the charge. BY Faadhila Thassim
